review: By far the best coffee shop in the area. ALT offers the best cold brew (with coffee ice cubes) and Americanos I've had. Their coffee leans towards the strong side but does not ever taste bitter. The baristas have found a way to brew coffee such that it does its job (wake you up) without leaving you with the usual aftertaste one gets from mediocre brews. The cozy patina may at first seem cramped or small, but how much better it is than a dozen desks full of people working or in meetings. The atmosphere you get at ALT is that people come here to relax, take a break from work, talk, and enjoy the city.Most customers do not stay so the three stools they have for sitting are surprisingly available if you do need somewhere to sit down for a bit.The current employees (Jake, Cooper, to name a few) are very good at remembering regulars and providing great conversation and good communication. And of course, they make awesome coffee.--Overall, ALT is an genuine coffee shop. It does not concern itself with being a coworking space that serves coffee or a faux-vintage caffeine dispenser. They just want to make good coffee. I finally made it (accidentally as the MTA is messed up on weekends and I had missed my gym class) Every time I've tried to drop by, they've been closed due to limited hours.There's a bar seating for three if you want to sip on your espresso beverage but most people seem to grab and go. I ordered a flat white, not on the menu. Not what I expected but still tasted very good. I was actually asked if I liked it strong and how much foam which probably added to the enjoyment of my coffee.I also tried the almond croissant and it was really good. Definitely taste the almond without an insane amount of sugary cream of sorts. The barista (until I know a better name for the people making my coffee) is super friendly with all the customers. Definitely a plus.I love the chill feel of this place. This is one of those places that makes New York great. It's a tiny little coffee cafe that basically takes up the small front part of a design studio (textiles maybe?). The cappuccinos and lattes are great and the service is really friendly. Haven't had any baked goods but plan to next time I'm in town and can stop by! What a gem - so glad we found this place! My coffee was amazing and really smooth and perfectly textured milk. It is VERY hard to find a decent latte here in NYC - trust me. As an Australian tourist I can say we are very very picky with our coffee and only espresso style coffee is the standard - no drip coffee for us anymore. I really enjoyed the coffee and the pumpkin loaf ( which I love and we don't have in Australia - we don't do anything pumpkin sadly) the loaf tasted very fresh and tasty. The shop is so cute and although small feels open and light. The staff are amazing and very friendly - was a delight to meet someone who knew were in Oz we were  from as his g/f is Ozzie too!!Definitely recommend coming here and supporting a great business with greater coffee. Nothing could beat a small cup of latte on a lazy Saturday morning. Little taste is conveniently located in the middle of Chelsea, and has carried a handful of baked goods, including my favorite almond croissants. Cookies were also made hearty and carried an light yet attractive scent. Surprisingly, my latte had a subtle buttery flavor on top of its original creamy taste. Loved every single sip out of it. Great little place to pick up a latte, expresso or specialty coffee.  Delicious selection of baked goods. A very little place. Interesting pastry selection. Good latte, but price is kinda high. There is no seating area, so I just made a quick visit. I was psyched to find this cafe down the street from where we were staying. I had the latte.... and almost went back for another. Easy to miss this little cafe in the floral district. Not the cheapest, but was the best coffee I had all weekend. No seating, you get your drink to go! Five starts to the barista and his piece of artwork Cappuccino.A Little Taste (ALT) is a gem, hiding itself in NYC's flower market on 28th street. Stopping by on a Saturday morning and all the three bar seats had been taken, I decided to wait. The barista checked in with me from time to time and told me I might have to wait for a while. I ordered a cappuccino and an almond croissant once I got the seat. The cappuccino is super fresh because the grinder was just got cleaned up by the barista while I was waiting. The almond croissant, from Colson Bakery in Park Slope, is not the best I ever had, but still good. By the time I finished everything and was about to pay, the barista just gave me an "everything is on me" smile.By the way, there is a show room behind ALT, which seems very interesting too. May worth a visit if you stop by on weekdays. Had a great coffee there before an interview-hit the spot!  Seating is limited but service great! Awesome little coffee shop that I stumbled when walking through work in the flower district. Great coffee and great choice of pastries and great service. My husband drug me here from the Waldorf, and all I could think during the trek through throngs if mid-town tourists to get to the 1 train was "I'm going to kill him, no coffee is worth this!" Well this coffee is worth it!! By far the best mocha I have ever had!! I plan tongue back again today for a second cup before they close!! Cute tiny coffee place near FIT. Coffee is really good, pastries are decent, and service is quick, but there's not enough space inside to sit and linger. Good for take away quick breakfast. This place is a gem! Sort of hidden but has great coffee and pastries for decent prices. The atmosphere is great and there is a showroom in the back, only problem is only about 3 seats inside so if busy (which it seems to be) then you have to take it on-the-go. Popped in this morning because I ran out of joe at home. Ordered a large drip and a soy latte for my girlfriend. I usually stay away from soy lattes to avoid the blandness (one of my least favorite espresso drink iterations) but I tried a sip of hers and mmmmmaaaan, if you walk by and the super tall guy is working, get espresso. Dude knows how to EXTRACT. Killer milk froth, killer extraction, killer latte art. Their drip is also good, you can tell they put more attention to detail on the batch brew than the average cafe. Cute little cafe hidden in the so called Flower Street. The place is tiny but tastefully decorated. Reminds me of a recent trip to Paris :) especially the baguette  though I have not got a chance to try them. Soy latte is not bad. Will stop by next time I need a coffee break. Overall: best latte I had in NYC so far. I recently became a coffee drinker and I tried some places and they were too sweet for me. This cafe's latte was amazing!Things I liked other than the coffee:- Interior design: petite, rustic, and homey feelThings I thought were meh:- A line outside the store with a wait of about 5-6 min to order, which isn't bad when you have time and considering the coffee taste- Location where if only I'm around 28th St and want coffee I would go (so if you're mostly on 28th St, this aspect wouldn't be a meh for you)- Not a place to hang out. A place to order coffee (and see pillows in the back).- Service where you just order, give money, and get your drink Cute little cafe with many handsome baristas but limited and average-tasting coffee and pastries. Plus, seating is also limited (meaning there are 2 tiny stools). Whoopie pies are okay and chocolate truffle cookie is more of a brownie. Flat white was pretty bitter. I love this tiny and cozy coffee shop. It has its own personality. I had macchiato which was rich and dense. I would definitely come back again even just for a regular coffee. This little shop is adorable and reminds Italy in many ways: coffee is superb and the interior design is warm and fancy. Sweets are excellent, I don't know where they get them from, but they picked the right guy! I had a kind of old-fashioned chocolate fudge and it was amazing.I have to give 3 stars instead of 4 since they served me espresso in plastic/paper cups instead of ceramic (it simply can't happen), plus it's not doable to have a chat inside - place is so small - , so it's not what I'm looking for when I get a coffee with a friend. I'm aware they can improve the first issue while there's not much they can do with the latter.

While the #1, freshest bagel in New York is David's Bagels on 1st Ave. and 15th St., the #2 victory goes to Brooklyn Bagel. Brooklyn sells such delicious, doughy, and tasty sesame bagels. All their bagels are great, but I'm a huge fan of their sesame. They're huge and chewy, and when combined with their fresh lox and onions, it's a feast. Get their delicious hazelnut coffee and - mmmm, divine.5 stars!!!!! Yummmm! I got a plain bagel with cream cheese, and boy was it tasty. The dough was chewy and easy to bite into. The cheese was light - not overly heavy, served as a great balance to the bagel, and complemented the bagel perfectly. I wish I had more time during my stay in NY to come back for a second round and to try the other spreads! I'll be back ;)Only downside: Limited seating to cater to lots of people, so best to only come here for a grab-and-go bagel. Works for me! 5 stars cuz the bagels are good, coffee is good, line goes fast and there are seats and wifi inside. dunno what ppl are complaining bout it's a solid bagel place with a million cream cheese choices in a pretty neighborhood. TWO WORDS: EGG BAGEL.It's devastatingly hard to find egg bagels in the Midwest. In SoCal, it was a little bit easier but still difficult. So, I was super stoked about Brooklyn Bagel's egg bagel offering. Their kettle-boiled bagels are amazing in texture - fluffy and chewy without being rubbery. They come in two sizes - Big & Mini. I wish I just ordered all minis because mini is like the size of a regular bagel. Big is real big - but I'm not complaining about the extra carbs. They also have an incredible variety of cream cheese. I went with a classic - scallion & cream cheese, but the rest looked great as well. I loved it so much that I ordered 13 more to take on the plane with me. I'm also impressed by how quickly they move here. The line wasn't too long, but you can get in and out of there if you're in a pinch!13/365 Come here if you're ready for a good hour or two.  This is not the typical grab and go bagel place.  The line is consistently out the door. We thought ordering online might help with the wait time so we did.  We ordered around 10am and our confirmation indicated a pickup time at 10.48am.  We were there on time, asked for the status with no one really giving us a good answer aside from just yelling the name on the order.  People with pick up time after us got their food.  We finally got our food around 11.15am.  And they were cold.  I really wonder if someone forgot about our bag.I saw people eating their fresh bagel there and they look mighty awesome.  Ours walker cold and not as great anymore.  They do scooped out bagel and dark toast which is the way I like my bagel but to bad it was almost rock solid when I finally ate it. I absolutely love this place! This is our go-to spot at work when it comes to catering breakfast. Brooklyn bagels never disappoints. Their bagels are always fresh, hot, yummy and with all the different and delicious cream cheese, the options are endless.My go to bagel is the egg bagel. Super soft and fresh. Delicious with some freshly made veggie cream cheese! Always in bliss when I chow down on this bagel.Very fast delivery and very amazing and friendly service. Came here around 11am on a Saturday and the line was out the door. Honestly, this was my first time waiting about 30 minutes for a bagel. Luckily, I wasn't disappointed at all. They had so many different bagel choices and spreads. I'm from NJ, so taylor ham and cheese (no, it's not a pork roll) is always my go to. However, I was feeling something sweeter so I decided to go with their coconut bagel with half matcha cream cheese and half cannoli spread. I asked for it half and half, but instead they decided to put the two together. It's a weird combination... but it actually turned out to taste like a green tea frappuccino from starbs, with java chips mixed in. It was actually really good. The matcha was subtle, but noticeable. The cannoli spread wasn't too sweet and it had a good balance of chocolate chips in it. The bagel itself was wonderful, had the perfect chew and a nice outer layer. Probably my new go to bagel place. I adored my onion bagel with scallion cream cheese. The bagel was perfect: lightly toasted, flavorful, chewy, and huge. The cream cheese was creamy and there was plenty of it. I took a bite of my boyfriend's breakfast sandwich, which was also great -- egg was cooked perfectly, and his garlic bagel was addicting. The price is a little high, but in-line with what I've come to expect from New York City. And it's totally worth it. The place obviously gets quite crowded, with a line out the door. I would advise doing your best to know what you want before reaching the counter. The staff is mostly nice enough but not very patient if you stumble through your order. They are great at remembering your order, though! I rattled off a somewhat complex order and the guy memorized it perfectly and my food was entirely correct. The line was nearly to the door with an approximate 15 minute wait which was expected for a mid Saturday morning. We got an everything bagel with garlic and herb cheese. There was a bit too much garlic unless you like a bite every bite. I will say, I would go again but this time try another cream cheese flavor since there was a multitude of other interesting flavors to try.I did snag a photo of what appeared to be chicken directly below the cream cheese that I don't know how to describe except for not something I want to eat. Would go back just that weird chicken business is the reason for the lower rating. Waited on line for like 20 minutes and then had to leave!Brooklyn Bagel I'll be back!! Not embarrassed to admit that I was in NYC for a conference and I came here every single day! It was THAT good.The line was long on Saturday, but they had plenty of people working and organized well enough that it went by super fast! During the week around 8am there was hardly a line to my surprise! Sausage egg and cheese on a plain bagel - 5 starsPlain bagel with bacon and scalion cream cheese - 5 starsEverything bagel with plain cream cheese - 5 stars!Everything was great, the service is great and they keep everything clean and well stocked. I even stopped on my way to Penn Station to get a dozen bagels to bring home! Solid bagel place in NY! I don't think you can go wrong with bagels and cream cheese anywhere but NY does it best of course. My friends and I got here around 9am and the line was pretty substantial but moved pretty fast. I don't know if it was just me but the menu wasn't very clear if you wanted a regular bagel with toppings, but it did show that they offered a wide array of sandwiches and other breakfast items. Someone correct me if I'm wrong cause I might've missed it but I didn't see a list of cream cheese or other toppings available. Since they want you to order pretty speedily to keep the line going, I definitely felt rushed lol I only knew what kind of schmears they had until I reached the deli case. Luckily, I saw that they had lox and cream cheese so I was good hahaThey had so many bagel options. I ended up with a whole wheat bagel with the topping was like $5~ and with a coffee, my total came out to like 7 bucks. I halfed my bagel with my friend because I learned my lesson from my last NY trip LOL they don't play with bagel portions. A half was the perfect amount for me for breakfast and I usually require a bit to get full. So if you have someone to split it with, it wouldn't be a bad idea if you aren't famished. There's maybe 4-5 tables and a bar area with stools but I'm assuming most people take these babies to-go. Wish l looked it up earlier but it turns out they have online ordering so that would've been convenient lol. There's an area clearly marked for you to pick it up if you do choose method. Definitely do this if you wanna skip the line! The best and freshest bagels can be found here. The bagel sandwiches are all terrific with the ability to customize to any taste. The coffee is even good too. The bagels here are pretty good, but also very pricey. They have a huge selection of bagels and spreads, which makes for endless combinations. It was pretty crowded when I popped in around 9:00 a.m., but the line moved fairly quickly. They have a small seating area with tables, and I was able to snag a seat for one. I ordered a poppy seed bagel with scallion schmear and lox, which was $13. I definitely was not expecting it to be that expensive, but portion size was huge, so that made up for some of the high price. While the bagel was tasty, it definitely wasn't the best bagel I've had. You'd likely be able to find better, cheaper bagels elsewhere, but this place is still a solid bet and worth checking out. Went into the city for a Broadway show with my mom and sister and I wanted to find a place near Penn Station-ish that wasn't too far out of where we were headed. Founds this lil spot on Yelp and holy crap--it held up to it's reviews.  We got there and the line was out the door. I don't know about you but I'm the type of person that is always happy to see this because I immediately know we picked the right spot. All three of us got everything bagels with different types of cream cheese (they have tons of tofu cream cheese options for all those non-dairy people like me!!). The bagels were huge, crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside, excessive seeds and overall the total NYC bagel experience. I can't stop thinking about these friggin bagels! PROS- Vegan cream cheese options! - Cream cheese flavors were creative and fun (matcha was the flavor of the week!) - Staff was v friendly and cheerful--sometimes harder to come across in a busy bagel shop like this one- Central location, close to Penn Station- Line moved quickly- V affordable- Bagels were perf! I'll be back in the city in a couple days and tbh I'm probably coming right back here. It was THAT good. Yep, five stars. As bagel shops go, this is as good as it gets. In just over a week, I tried the same bagel (toasted everything with cream cheese and tomato) at five different places and decided that this place had the best. Once the decision was made about the best place (I was on a mission to eat a bagel for breakfast every day while I was back in town) I got adventurous with my bagel order. I tried their pickle cream cheese (not bad), their low fat cream cheese, and...their pumpernickel everything bagel is awesome! The bagels are made right there, the place is clean, the choices are many, the line moves quickly, my orders always came out correctly, and the cashiers were pleasant. What more can you ask for? Well, perhaps good coffee. To be fair, I didn't try their coffee because the walk to get the bagel was fairly long and I passed several Starbucks along the way. By the time I got my bagel, the sugar in my coffee was dissolved and it had cooled off enough to drink. Morning perfection. Darn good bagels. I would know because I bought 28 of them, and lugged all 28 of them across Chelsea on foot in order to get them on my bus back to Boston. I sacrificed precious leg room for the two giant brown bags (and I mean giant. These bagels are huge), and don't regret a second of it. Every drop of sweat and every ache in my back was worth it because my freezer is now stocked full of these delicious rings of dough. Next time, I'm coming for you smears. And I can't wait. After moving out of the city for a year and a half, I have spent too many mornings daydreaming about NYC bagels while eating a toasted artificially flavored pumpkin spice grocery store bagel topped with 35% vegetable oil spread. I finally had the chance to be in NYC and had only 2 hours of free time in Gramercy. The New York City bagel, so elusive in any other part of the world, was my first big task in the city. I deprived myself from 2 hours of sleep the prior night Yelping for the best bagel within walking distance. The mini bagels were the ultimate selling point for me to choose Brooklyn Bagel & Coffee Company over Ess-a-bagel, Thompson Square, Zuckers, etc.I ordered an untoasted mini whole wheat with lox and full fat scallion cream cheese (cuz who would get reduced fat cream cheese? This isn't Halo Top, you don't get to have a low cal version if you're eating a New York bagel because that would defeat the purpose). I also ordered a spelt bagel, which only comes in the full size and it weighted as much as a 6 pack of my pumpkin spice artificially flavored bagels from the grocery store. You know those rare moments when you eat food so good that nothing else really matters because you are absolutely present in the moment, in touch with all your senses? The swirled patterns of the dough, the chewy and dense texture, the generous amount of lox, the heaviness of the cream cheese... I wish I had gotten the regular instead of the mini. The mini was definitely enough food and satiating, but I never experienced diminishing marginal returns. Each bite was just as good, if not better than the previous and left me wishing I had more after I finished. The spelt bagel was just 'ight. It was pretty dry, and I ended up throwing most of it away because it sent my luggage over the weight limit. Love the pumpernickel everything bagel! So good. Had it with the standard Nova Scotia salmon and cream cheese. It was as enjoyable as bagels get for lack of better terms haha. They definitely put a more than adequate amount of lox in the bagel which is a major plus since lox in any bagel leads it to be over $10. If you're big on cream cheese, there is a plethora of options here. Enjoy! So many choices for cream cheese. My wife got the loxs and bagel sandwich was amazing, I got the the eggs and bacon breakfast sandwich on an everything bagel. It all tasted amazing. I would go there again next time I'm In the area

This place is great! Got a soy latte in a cute little cup with a nice latte art. Very rich in flavor, tastes like coffee and isn't watered down by the soy milk. Fresh of course. Also got the iced coffee with soy as well and gotta say, not disappoint at all, great coffee flavor, not watered down again, even though it's iced! Must try when in the area if you're a big coffee fan! My girlfriend found this place and recommended we go here and study. This place is excellent local shop. They make a good cup of coffee and the space is also very clean. Very family friendly. If you are looking for a place to do work, look no further. They have about 6 tables for people to seat. I really like the vibe and energy of the place. We were there for about 2 hours and the place looked really popular on a Saturday. There were tons of people walking in and out getting coffee. They have another location in Chinatown which I have not been to. This afternoon I wish to come here with my best friend to drink a special, yes an excellent cappuccino, so nice presented, and have a chat over many news and things,, and enjoy the special moment. Whenever I am near chinatown and need a coffee fix this is my go to. The staff are cool and the coffee is great. This is definitely a good place for studying or just a little coffee shop for you to catch up with your friends at. There is free wifi for those who bring in their laptops. The trash area and the self pour sugar and creamer area is super clean ! Fabulous service today. Friendly, prompt and inviting just as they've typically been. Glad that today's service is a better reflection of the business as compared to a previous experience. It was a slow morning so I decided to go on a caffeine adventure-aka find a new cafe.After walking around Chinatown on such a gray morning, this place felt like a refuge.There was quiet music playing, the lighting was still dim as it was early, and the two relaxed guys behind the counter were joking quietly with a costumer.I ordered a soy matcha latte and a blueberry pumpkin muffin. Both were solid and satisfying. Lots of space to work, not sure about wifi.Decor was interesting, lots of wood and coffee memorabilia, without being overwhelming. Really did feel like I was stepping out of the city for a few minutes.Will be back, although I wish they'd had more food options besides pastries. I love 12 corners on mott & I'm so happy they have this bigger location , my go tos are the matcha latte, americano and in the fall they have a delicious pumpkin latte. Free WiFi, & a few bookshelves filled with books for you to browse. So worth the trip! I came in on a rainy day after reading the Yelp reviews, and opted to try the pumpkin latte. I have to admit the Instagram photos also attracted me - and didn't disappoint! The pumpkin latte was better than anything at Starbucks, and definitely less expensive. While I did not finish it all, it hit the spot on a cold day. This place is about a mile from my apartment & the walk is not bad at all so I will definitely be back. The gentleman behind the counter even went so far as to ensure my latte art was perfect after I requested a particular design. I appreciated the mellow vibe & quick customer service! I stumbled upon this coffeeshop because it's downstairs of my brother's apartment building (had dinner plans later that night) and wow, I am SO jealous. My favorite cafes to date have been Cafe Jax (UES) and Grace Street (Koreatown, no wifi), but I think 12 Corners might've actually stolen the spot for #1 with its great customer service, free & reliable wifi, available outlets, fantastic ambiance for studying, good hours, accessible and cute bathroom, solid drinks & pastries, and comfortable seating. I was pretty much there from 8:30am-7pm yesterday (got a late start to the day but I LOVE that it's open at 7:30) and it was pretty cool to see the staff's interactions with repeat customers. They seem like good people. :) They're also really nice about letting people use the bathroom; when I ran in from the rain after my lunch break and stared at the menu, they asked if I needed the bathroom (even though I hadn't ordered anything!) How nice. :) Speaking of the bathroom, it has some cute decoration. Check it out :p Although I really love Cafe Jax & Grace Street, I realized when I sat here that there's a HUGE difference for my back when I can lean against a straight, comfortable back. Most cafes will have chairs or benches, but they don't compare to 12 Corners' seating. I don't actually know what it's called (the bench is attached to the wall? and there's a cushiony back), but I loved it. I was actually super comfortable studying the whole day and I was so sad when the staff kindly came around telling us that the cafe was closing in 5 minutes. :( 12 Corners doesn't serve actual food, but it is located conveniently in Chinatown, so you can totally just grab cheap & tasty food nearby. Yesssss. I think I'd go to Lam Zhou noodles (less than a minute away) when I study here again. (: As for the actual drinks - I actually just got a jasmine tea (very fragrant and floral, yay), but my friend got an autumn spice latte and I thought it was really good. (And I usually don't even drink coffee!) Definitely interested in trying out their other drinks. I got a toasted ham & cheese croissant in the morning (very tasty and flaky, yum) and a cranberry rhubarb bran muffin in the afternoon (very healthy tasting! I approve :D). Can't wait to try some of their other drinks :) Everything is pretty reasonably priced - and there's Belly! Overall, I really like 12 Corners (and that it's literally right by my brother's apt, so I can hang out with him afterwards). Definitely going to come back! Just beyond the trendy restaurants and bars on south Orchard lives 12 Corners, a humble and inviting coffee shop that serves a very good cup of joe. It turns out they have been in the area since summer of 2012, before the Lower East Side turned into one big coffee spill. I stumbled upon 12 Corners using the Cups app when my normal LES go-to was closed for the day. For $3.60 (Cups discount), you can get a mean latte...strong and smooth and created with great attention to detail. Considering I am super picky and found myself super satisfied with the taste I did some research of their supplier, Kobrick. Kobrick is a family-owned business that has been around for 4 generations and takes great pride in their process. Their site is a great resource for knowledge and home brewing techniques and they've easily made their way into my top 5 beans in the city. When it comes to 12 Corners' service, it's lightning fast and very friendly. I will definitely be returning as much as possible and will now blindly trust their Mott Street location for an incredible cappuccino. It's a nice sitting environment to chat with friends over a cup of coffee or to read/study. A lot of the people there were sitting with their notes, laptop or books with a drink. I came with two friends, wanting to find a good place to sit and possibly study or just chat. The other 12 corners location is really small and we decided to walk the extra distance in the rain to this one. Luckily there were seats. I ordered an Iced Green Tea Latte, one of my friends ordered a hot Green Tea Latte, and another friend ordered a Hot Black Coffee. I really liked my latte, no sugar was added, all matcha taste. However my friends and I were wondering why they served my friends' hot drinks in to-go cups where everyone sitting down had their cafe cups/mugs. There was a big bookshelf behind where we sat. So if anyone wants to order a drink and just read but forgot a book, here's the place. There's a bathroom, just have to ask for the key if it's not right there on the counter. There's a big mirror inside the bathroom, I scared myself when I turned the lights on and closed the door, thinking someone was standing there (it was just myself). My friends and I ended up sitting there for a good 3-4 hours. I'll definitely come back when I decide to study and/or want to relax and read a book with some coffee. This cafe has a cozy, welcoming atmosphere. It's relatively quiet, making it a good spot to study or do some work. The outlets on the wall allow you to charge your devices, and Wifi is provided. Although most of the seats were occupied when I visited, it didn't feel busy or crowded at all. The staff were friendly and made my drink quickly.I ordered an iced green tea latte, and I can't say that I enjoyed it much. It tasted very milky and lacked the matcha flavor that the hot version has. The latte is unsweetened, and you can add sugar or syrup to adjust the sweetness to your liking. However, this didn't help diminish the powdery, milky taste.Overall, this is a nice place to stop by if you need to use the restroom or the Wifi, but the green tea latte leaves something to be desired. Perhaps the coffee is better? I like that they're open really early in the morning. They didn't have cold brew so I ordered an ice coffee which is pretty decent. The staff is nice and service is good. Location is a bit small with a few tables only but the overall decor and vibe is very cozy. This is close to home for me as well, so I will be back. Next time, I'll try the other selections. Stopped by on a chilly Saturday morning this month and was really pleased with this find! The place is pretty small and I was lucky enough to grab the last table around 11AM. I got an iced coffee which was pretty good, and sat down to do some studying. It seemed that most people who were lucky enough to get a table stayed for a few hours, so getting a seat might be tricky! With that said, I enjoyed doing homework here. Overall noise level is pleasant, where you can chat quietly with your friends and also get some work done. I will be back! I came in on a Saturday afternoon and was still able to find a table/seat!I got the green tea latte with almond milk. I wish they carried coconut milk or Lactaid here, because I don't really like almond or soy milk much, which were the only lactose-free options they had. I could taste the matcha in my latte, which is awesome! Only thing is the almond milk didn't really go so well with it. It was my first time mixing those two, so lesson learned. However, given the choice between almond milk and soy milk, I think I'll try the coffee next time instead. I stayed for about 3 hours to do some studying. Great environment. The music playing was not too loud, but still audible. My drink lasted me the full 3 hours so that's always a plus.Will be back! I wish they carried some savory options for food though :( LOVE this spot now - it's become my go-to spot for studying! The space is comfy and the staff is super nice and accommodating to every customer (my observation). I come here often because I live close by, which is convenient. The drinks are also top notch  and they have a good selection of pastries! I usually get a flat white (stronger than other coffee shops I've tried) with the occasional shake up in drink - I've tried the chai latte (yummy) and the matcha latte (unsweetened and yummy also). This place is great. $2.50 coffee with one free warm-up. Delicious, fresh pastries, though I doubt they're made on site. I went with the dark cherry Danish. Try that. Free wi-fi. Complimentary ice water. Friendly staff. And a bathroom. What more could you ask for in New York?There was some construction going on out front when I went here in October 2015, so for the time being, this may not be the most conducive coffee shop for studying if that's your goal. Great spot, nice, humbling and tranquil. Enjoy having my breakfast there when I can. Customer service is good, coffee is awesome, spacious, outlets everywhere to charge your device, price is fine and is better then most coffee shop around NYC. Highly Recommended!!!  Just read the reviews if you don't believe in it. This is by far my favorite coffee shop in the city. I've been coming here every day for many years and have never, not once, had a bad experience. The staff is so friendly, attentive, and diligent - you can tell they really care about their customers. Since I'm a regular, they know what I like and often get it started as soon as I walk in the door. I've seen them do this with many other regular customers as well. And the coffee is truly the best coffee I've had in NYC - I drink the espresso exclusively (I'm pretty sure they brew Kobrick beans), and the way they do their americanos is superior to pretty much all others I've had. The coffee shop itself has a great vibe, it's comfortable with a decent amount of tables and not overly trendy or corporate. There's a bathroom and free wifi for customers. They usually have a small-ish selection of muffins, croissants, and other pastries that always look really good and fresh, though I've admittedly never had one... they also have a selection of teas and do matcha drinks and other specialty lattes.I happen to live in the neighborhood so coming here everyday is a no-brainer. But if you like great coffee and appreciate top-notch service, this place is worth the trek. Location: I become more familiar with  LES. Lol, my pre work out or post work out place.  12 corner is definitely worth to try - their coffee bean is different from all other places in Manhattan and they do play attention how they brew coffeeCoffee: ice coffee is delicious. ( they sold out their cold brew....)Price: cheapService: nice especially with free wifi.

Came here with high expectation and was expectations were definitely met!Great variety at the sauce barGreat variety of meat and vegetablesDid not try the hot pot we came for the bbqBut definitely would come just for the hotpot I has 6 pm reservation. My party arrived before 6 but they had no table. We waited 10-15 minutes before a girl with a clipboard came out to the waiting area and started calling names, not mine.  I told her I had a 6 pm reservation and has been waiting. She looked perplexed. I looked at her clipboard and pointed my out my name to her. I was supposed to be next.  She seems surprised to see my name on the list.  She told me to wait a minute.  Even seeing my name on the list, she needed a minute to think about this really really difficult situation.  She came to fetch us and brought us to a table.  No one came to talk our order for another ~10 minutes.  After ordering.m the floor manager came by to tell us we have 2 hours to eat. I asked her "from now?"  Her reply "from the time of your reservation". Did I let her have it!!!  I told her I was there before my reservation.  They had no table and made us wait.   We also did not receive any service after we sat down.   We had just placed our hour so the 2 hours should start now. She also had that perplexed look as the girl before.   She said she'll check and see.  She never came back at 8 to kick us out. If she had, I would have made sure she get a piece if my mind. They never apologized for making us wait for a table. The floor manager, hearing that we did not get service for a while, did not apologize either or told us our time starts then. I used to love coming here. They just reminded me why I haven't for a long time.  There are now so many hotpot place around. I'll definitely give my business to another establishment. p.s.  the House herbal tea was so diluted it tasted more like water than tea. OH-EM-GEE!I'm usually not this dramatic but this all you can eat (Yes, i said all you can eat..can i get an amen?) hot pot spot is worth the wait! And if you don't have a reservation, there is a considerable wait.Found this place through yelp (thanks yelpers) and decided to check it out. As you walk up to the restaurant you can smell the delicious goodness awaiting inside! We figured the wait would be maybe an hour right? Wrong! it was 2.5 hrs! Put our names down and sure enough we get a call back in 2 hrs (ye we waited - we really wanted to try this spot ok). The menu - They have a wide spread of what you can choose from. From meats to veggies - they have you covered. They even had Fish roe balls on the All You Can Eat menu (one of my faves - def check it out)!!!Can we talk about their sauce station? They have a sauce station with every possible sauce, topping you would need for your meal! I'm talking, sriracha, chili paste, their homemade sauce (which is worth the extra cents!), peanut, sesame, garlic...i really could go on here. Needless to say we were STUFFED! (I may have had a friend roll me out)If you check in on yelp - you get a free icecream. Its nothing fancy but hey its F-R-E-E and I needed the cold cream (too much hot sauce!).Also - the table behind us was doing all you can eat BBQ which also looked so scrumptious!Oh thing that I can see people getting annoyed about is that if there is a birthday being celebrated (which I believe there were at least 8 when we were dining), they play this loud bday song and have this guy dressed up as a monkey dance about. I mean...sure it was a spectacle but embrace it y'all. Just embrace it. All in all - I definitely will return to this spot if I'm back in NYC. I love this place- wonderful service, great, plentiful/unlimited/fresh food! Sauce bar; dessert... reservations!They also offer aprons and a bag to put your things in! Make sure you go before 6:00 PM or the line will be SUPER LONG. I had the all-you-can-est hot pot and it was satisfying. The broth isn't pre-seasoned with much flavor, therefore you must go to the self-seasoning bar to collect your own spices. This allows you to have your own agency to make your broth and food spicy, sweet, or etc. You have fish fillet, mussels, crab, fishballs, spinach, and many more foods. *if it's your birthday, they have a super cute birthday celebrate song and mention they create for you--it actually has to be your birthday though* 99 Favor Taste is great! They offer AYCE hotpot, BBQ, good service, and make-your-own sauce station. The food is good and plentiful.They also give you free meal for someone's birthday (with proof) and presently- plastic bags for your coats to avoid your coats smelling like hot pot. The restaurant is large, with a second floor for big parties. I've been here multiple times: for birthday parties and casual lunches/dinners. Its very affordable, and you are guaranteed to leave very full! We definitely tend to overeat when it's a paid set price ($21). Be careful ordering because if you have leftovers, they reserve a right to charge you more. The food quality varies but usually the shrimp, squid, tofu, vegetables are very fresh. I like the Japanese pumpkin and noodles for the end of the meal, to absorb the delicious broth. The beef and lamb rolls are pretty good but the beef balls are usually frozen. The chicken is fatty and comes in huge chunks, I would avoid this order. I will definitely be back! I've only ever been to their Flushing restaurant before but I definitely prefer this location more! This one just seems more spacious and cleaner for some reason. However, that may also be because we went around 3 PM on a weekday. Even during such an off hour there was still a good amount of people in the restaurant feasting. We came in as a group of five and were seated right away. When you enter you choose whether you want the all you can eat bbq, hot pot or both. And then you pick all of the items you want from a menu and they bring it out. You don't have to order everything right away you can order after as well and they bring out the food fairly quickly. We had no time limit since it was not during the main dinner time therefore we were able to stay in the restaurant for around 3 hours to slowly eat and enjoy our bountiful feast. Additionally, make sure to check in on either here or Facebook because you can receive a free scoop of ice cream which is a great ending to a filling meal! 99 Flavors is great for large groups to celebrate birthdays and special occasions. The meat, veggies, and seafood quality is average and may take some time to come out especially on busy days. Since our party was 15 people, we tried to order many beef dishes at once, but were served only one at a time. Perhaps it may have been to prevent waste, but with a group as large as ours, we cleared the meat in less than a minute and had to wait 5 - 10 minutes for the next tray. Nevertheless, we were all stuffed in the end. The experience lived up to the name! The service was very fast and efficient. I was very surprised for a gigantic hot-pot place. The sauce bar could be improved and monitored for spills more frequently. I thought they had a great selection for all you can eat. Of course, the meat selection will not be as premium as a non-AYCE places go. Beers and alcohol were cheap, making it a great place for friends get-togethers. There's also a birthday special where the birthday person gets to eat for free. Came here for the first time and my experience is wasn't as great as I thought it would be.  I was a part of a larger party and the server was so rude to us.  I know that there is a language barrier but the eye rolling and lack of trying to understand us came off as super condescending.  When we asked for more vegetables, fish or meat we received an attitude.  When it was time for the bill to come the waitress told us that we would receive a discount if we all paid cash but this wasn't the case.  She divided our party into two separate checks and honored the cash discount to only half of our party.  It was trouble just asking for a paper check because she gave us a hard time when we asked for a printed receipt (probably because the incorrect break down was exposed). On to the food - everything was fresh and great and have no complaints.  The silverware that is located near the sauces was all dirty and if it wasn't dirty then it looked dirty because of the finger prints and dishwasher stains. The table was too small for our party of 10 and  even with a reservation we were squeezed in a high traffic area that we could not fit.Overall the employees ruined this place for me.  I wont be back. I crave hotpots now and then and decided to come here one cold Friday night to cater to my cravings. Asked how long the wait was and they said 3 hours. Yes, 3 hours!  Made a reservation for another Friday evening. This time the wait was 30 mins. Yes! We had a wait despite the reservation. Once seated, you are handed a wet napkin, a hairband and plastic bags to place your jackets in to avoid the lingering sichuan smell. They also provide ziplocks for your phones on request."All you can eat hot pot for $22.99" is popular here. Pick your soup base from original, chinese herbal, spicy, pig bone, curry, tomato, kimchi, mix mushroom. Unlike other hotpot places where you have a single pot with a divider placed in the center of the table, each seat gets a small pot and is placed on your very own mini stove. We ordered 1 spicy and 1 original broth. While the spicy broth needs no change, you can experiment with the flavor of original broth by adding additional (around 20) sauces. I personally loved the spicy broth as the spice was flavorsome and not over-the-top. Pick the add-ons from a plethora of veg and non-veg options and devour the spread. Highlights:* Make a reservation* Get the all-you-can-eat hot pot for $22.99* Get the spicy broth or experiment with original broth* Free meal on your birthday. You've got to show your ID.* Birthday +-3 days also gets you a free meal if you or your friends get an 8" cake.* If you get a cake, you get a minute to fame with a cosplaying, dancing monkey who sings for you. They also take your picture and print it for you as a souvenir. It's as embarrassing as it sounds.* Yelp checkin gives you a free scoop of icecream. No one-per-table rule. I wish I had photos of the cooked food but unfortunately it's all in my stomach. Too busy going in. We got the all you can eat hot pot and bbq. My boyfriend got the pork bone and I got the original. The original tastes more flavorful if it season it yourself some more with ingredients from the ingredients bar. I really liked the pork broth a lot better. The big squid was a winner for me along with everything else honestly. It depends on everyone's individual preference. There's a huge variety of meats to pick from so can't go wrong here I love AYCE hot pot, and I have a good time here every time I visit. For $24 you get a decent variety of meat, vegetables, and fish, AND you get a free meal on your birthday (or within the three days before or after)! We had reservations for 2 at 1pm on a Sunday. Always make a reservation if possible because this place fills up like you wouldn't believe. We originally wanted to come for dinner on Saturday evening, but the wait for 3 people was about 2.5 hours, and tables were reserved until literally 11pm. Make a reservation!Beyond that, I don't really have any helpful tips or advice. This restaurant is delicious and service is usually fine. You tell them what broth and items you want (get the pork bone broth) and they bring it to you. When you want more stuff, you let them know. Simple as that. You also get a scoop of ice cream at the end of your visit, so look forward to that! Hotpot is my thing. I absolutely love all things hotpot and try to eat at as many hotpot restaurants as I get a chance to try. I love all styles of hotpot -- Japanese, Korean, Chinese... if it's hotpot, chances are I'll love it.That being said, 99 Flavor Taste has been one of the best hotpot places I've ever ate at.Reservations are definitely recommended. They are a big birthday place, and if you come here on your birthday, you'll get a free hotpot for one person and a guy in a dancing bear costume singing happy birthday to you. While I am not usually a fan of those kind of theatrics, this place is so over the top that it actually becomes fun.You can get a hotpot with either two or three (the Benz) flavor broths. Since more is better, we opted for the Benz and got Chinese herbal, curry, and spicy. All three flavors were amazing! My favorite was the Chinese herbal blend; I was surprised how much I loved it, but to this day I crave it and will definitely be back for it, birthday or not!The choices of what you can add to your hotpot are incredibly varied, in meats, fish, and vegetables, and the all you can eat price is reasonable. The service is friendly and helpful.99 Flavor Taste is literally everything you can ask out of a hotpot place. Highly, highly recommended! This was my first time trying hot pot and it was a lot of fun! I made a res for around 4 pm on a weekday before a holiday, but typically there's a monster wait to get in here. Service was okay. I guess my main complaint is that the food wasn't super flavorful, but cooking it was fun and the experience was good overall. 3.5 stars. Reasonable prices (figure in taxes and tips), all you can eat, unlimited refills (we didn't ask for refills for after the unenforced 2-hour limit), birthday meal free!Don't be shy in asking for refills. It takes time for the food to prepare the food, so don't waste time waiting for the waiting staff, who are accommodating but may miss a dish or two.Get an earlier reservation so you have a chance at a bigger, more private table. I don't understand all the hoopla about smells seeping into clothing.Service was courteous and prompt. Just a couple of blocks from the Grand St. subway station. Grab a free ice cream on the way out. 99 Favor is one of my favorite hot pot restaurants. I've been many times with big groups of friends. The meat selection is diverse and high quality; ranging from beef, lamb, and pork to crab, squid, and quail egg. The veggie selection is equally as impressive. There is bound to be something you like at 99 Favor. There is also a wide range of hot pot broths you can choose. My favorite broth is the pig bone broth but the original and spicy broths are also great. There's a dizzying array of condiments to create your perfect hot pot dipping sauce as well. If hot pot isn't your thing, there's also Korean BBQ which you can pair with your hot pot. Your meal is also free on your birthday which is great. This is an excellent value.  Their seafood choice of crabs and shrimp were excellent.  The array of vegetables is good and the sauces for you to mix was excellent.  What a good value! No was surprised to get in for lunch yesterday!The table I sat in (communal table) seats 6 and had 6 individual burner imbedded in the table.  Each person can sanitarily use a pot for yourself.It has about 5 or 6 soups to choose from.  You can have all fish or mixture of fish and meat shabu  shabu  style cooking or hot pot cooking. You can also opt in to have hot pot PLUS grilled food for a slightly higher price.Here's another place I will consider to go back to. I came here with my husband and my friend and it is a perfect place for a cold winter day. All the ingredients were fresh and even though I stuffed my face, my stomach didn't feel too terrible. I especially liked the beef and all the vegetables. The place was very spacious with sensible interior. We only had hot pot and not the barbecue but barbecue seemed delicious as well. I will say this is not a bad option when you crave Chinese hot pot. This was my first hot pot experience and it was absolutely delicious. We had the Korean BBQ and hot pot option. It was worth the extra money and a nice break to be able to switch back and forth. I enjoyed everything except for the pig brain. No mater how long it cooked it was just squishy brain. The crab was hard to handle too. Shrimp, lamb and beef tongue were superb. They have a huge sauce selection and they were very prompt on the service. I never felt rushed at all and left incredibly satisfied. Hint: be careful about ordering too much food because they "can" charge you for the extra waste by the pound. It wasn't a problem for us but it might be if your eyes are bigger than your stomach. Enjoy!

I've wanted to go this cocktail bar for a couple of years now. I dare you to find another establishment that pays as much attention to detail then this place. I was very impressed with every element. I was slightly disappointed when I didn't see the lab coats. I'm not sure how long ago they stopped doing that. It's in an odd location right in the heart of china town with a discreet entrance. In the evening this particular street is deserted, so it adds to the mystique. I like the space, with enough seating in the lounge area for smallish parties and plenty of room at the bar. The bar starts to come alive later in the evening, but even with more people it never felt too crowded or loud.  I love the cocktail list. Be prepared to pay $18, which is more or less standard for an upscale cocktail bar or speakeasy.  I will definitely return. I wouldn't consider this a "speakeasy" but it has some pretty great drinks. The vibe is perfect in the early evening with plenty of room to sit and enjoy the barea (bar area... I just came up with that) *self-five*They also have limited lounge seating for groups and couples to enjoy. Perfect after dinner stop, but beware it does get packed later in the night. A cute little bar if you're into the following: 1. Hidden and discrete like a speakeasy in an old alley in Chinatown2. Kitschy in concept trying to emulate an apothecary in their decor and bartender uniforms3. Young and into the standing around a bar with little to no seating, hot, and crowded bar sceneThey have tasty drinks all made in front of your eyes, a little heavy on the wallet, but that's fairly standard NYC pricing and there isn't a long wait. What made my experience more fun was seeing Buzzfeed Worthit's Steven Lim at the bar with a friend. So I guess even media personalities find it worth it! Five stars for the best cocktail in NYC, one that I had six years ago and had been talking about ever since, never able to make it back to Apothke. But this was a different night, we got in easily, no line, and the bar was just waiting for our orders. The Kale in Comparison cocktail includes organic quinoa vodka, fresh kale juice, pineapple, ginger, lime and agave, and a smoked salt rim. Perfection. I had two and left happy. And probably much healthier, right? Lest you think I am a regular kale eater or organic quinoa kind of a guy... I'm not. I was at one time the world's worst vegetarian, basically eating cheese pizza and spaghetti for 13 years. This cocktail is amazing, worthy of my obsession, and finally I made it back! Okay, there's another obsession worthy drink: Sitting Buddha. With vodka with lemongrass, fresh pineapple, cilantro, fresh ginger root, squeezed lime, and agave. Damn good. Glad to be back! Now I can shut up about this kale drink, my friends will be happy never to hear me talk about it again. Yelp, now it's on you! Great place and a really cool speakeasy. It does look like the place is closed but when I stepped in - such a spacious, beautiful place. The bartenders really do their thing and I had fun watching them. I honestly don't know what the name of the cocktail was that I was drinking and I wish I remembered, but it was soooooo good. It was a rye cocktail and I told the bartender to surprise me. lol. It was amazing. Will return again for sure. No doubt about it. I'm so happy I checked this place out! This place is awesome once you're in and at the bar. Expect to wait up to an hour from the time you arrive till you get to the bar on a weekend. I would pre-game just to make that hour more tolerable. Once you're inside, the ambience is amazing! Music is great. The set up of this place is awesome; the decorations are very interesting! I didn't have to use the bathroom but went in anyway to see what it looked like. We went on a Friday so the bartenders were busy but they were still polite and courteous. The cocktails are an experience; all the ones we tried were good. Oh! Don't forget to try some absinthe. In summary, this place is a unique experience that everyone should try! This time we tried the Kale in Comparison and the Stolen from Eden because we needed to get in our veggies for the day. Both well-balanced, and tasted healthy and green and still gave me a bit of a buzz. I'd say it was a productive night. Not sure if these elixirs really live up to their prophetic labels but I'd like to think so. I was reluctant to believe that I could consume (alcoholic) beverages with egg whites, kale, beet etc. but not only was it easy, they make it enjoyable to do so. I happily sipped my drinks, lost count, and tried others'. I could pick a bad one in the bunch. Dr. Ruth MAY have been my favorite among the contenders. Decor and bar were sexy and intimate but not cliche. Great hidden drink spot in Chinatown. We came on 12/23 around 9 pm so because it was a holiday weekend and early, we were able to snag a table early on. The drinks here are probably the best I've ever had and as it gets later into the night, it turns from a cool speakeasy feel into a fun dancing bar. If I could have their drinks every day, I would!! Our friend took us here. The place was packed. There were limited seating, most people just stood by the bar area. The floor area was cleared up a bit from the crowd at times since they also had some dancing event going on. We stayed until it was late and were able to sit at a table after a group of people left. Some of the drinks that we tried: Sitting Buddha, Mr Tallymon, Dr Ruth, Tokyo Drift, Professor Plum, Deal Closer, A Daisy If You Do, Silk Road, The Matador, Stolen From Eden. All of them tasted very good and came in beautiful presentation. I also enjoyed seeing the bartenders wearing the lab-coat like it's a mad-scientist/chemist going on there. Drinks all very different. Cool ambience. Definitely my to go place when I'm around China town. The place is like a chemistry lab. Had my first absinthe here. Such a fun night here! I came on a Wednesday night with two other friends and we were surprised to learn at the door that we needed a password to get in (hint: if you don't know the password check their Instagram) and once we got it correct, he let us through! Apparently on Wednesday nights they have a burlesque show accompanied by a jazz band/singer. It honestly feels as if you've been transported back to the 20s or 30s which was amazing! The singer was incredibly talented and it was a wonderful environment just to sit with a friends and relax after work. For a Wednesday it was pretty lively! As for drinks they were strong & delicious but pricey (not surprising though as this is NYC). Definitely recommend coming for the experience though! I was turned away at the door because I was wearing tan Levi's boots and told "Timberlands" were against the dress code. I can't help but think this prohibition (along with no "caps/sports attire") is in place to keep black folks out. Will not even attempt to come back - I'll be taking my patronage to places that don't have racist/classist dress codes. Have to be super honest- I thought this place was totally fake every time I went to Nom Wah Tea parlor next door. My friend and I stopped in here during the summer and loved the vibe. I forget the drinks we had, but the "chemists" behind the counter are really good at recommending drinks. The prices are more than the average cocktail bar, but considering the ingredients they use, it's well worth the trip. This place is not for getting totally wasted... so yeah. After having dinner in Chinatown at Tasty Hand Pulled Noodles right around the corner, a friend and I decided to check out Apotheke. After hearing about this place and only being in Chinatown at the most inconvenient times, this was the perfect moment. We got there around 8 on a Saturday night and luckily it was not crowded yet. No line out the door, which would have deterred me for sure and the doorman wasn't there yet so we walked right in. There was no seating left but standing at the bar was good enough for us and since you can check your coat or any bag you have, it is do-able. I love the decor. There are a few couches pushed to the wall, the lighting is dim, they left what looked like some of the original structure to the building such as the ceiling and they designed it to look like an old European apothecary (hence the name). The bartenders are even wearing pharmacy coats. The menu is one of the most creative I have seen. The menu is divided into categories to go with the apothecary theme. 1) Health and Beauty; 2) Stress Relievers; 3) Pain Killers; 4) Stimulants; 5) Aphrodisiacs; and 6) Euphoric Enhancers. We started with the Dragon Fly and the Paid Vacation, which were both good. The Dragon Fly looks like a popular drink since a lot of people were getting it. Its a refreshing drink since it has the Sunflower blossom tea but has a little kick I think with the habanero bitters and wheat grass. The Paid Vacation is the best kind of spicy. Our final drinks were the Huntsman and the Kale in Comparison. The Huntsman is one of the most creative drinks on the menu served with scotch with duck fat, fig, chocolate, balsamic vinegar glaze, lime agave and a scotch mist. In don't know how, but this drink works and I dont know how to describe it, but its one of the most pleasant scotch drinks I have had and I dont drink scotch. The Kale in Comparison was also good. It literally tastes like a green juice with vodka, so only get it if you like green juice. Around ten, Apotheke starts getting annoyingly crowded, especially around the bar. Actually just around the bar. I think since there are only around six couches and this is a popular place for big groups, the only place to congregate is the bar but then the middle of the lounge is empty. They should try to fix this some how because it seems like a waste of space? Also I can see why some people would say the drinks are too sweet. With the Huntsman, you expect a heavy scotch drink, but it was actually sweat and light. I love a good speak easy, and Apotheke doesn't disappoint. The drinks are quite inventive and equally tasty. Drinks alone, Apothoke is deserving of 5 stars, took a star off because they dont limit the crowd, so it quickly goes from a chill speak easy vibe (where you are likely to find a comfortable spot to loiter) to a typical bar that is over crowded and uncomfortable. Waitress and bartenders however are on point and speedy. Amazing little cocktail bar with great live tunes. I came on a Tuesday night and saw the High & Mighty Brass Band which was a super fun show.I got the Dead Poet which had some smoke infused in the bourbon based drink and really enjoyed it.It's spendy but it's Manhattan so I think it's reasonably priced for the area and definitely worth it for the cocktail quality and atmosphere. Brilliant theme and decor. The drinks are fantastic and it's fascinating to watch the "chemists" mix them. Here's the problem: the drinks are mad expensive and the atmosphere is pretentious. Apparently I was dressed a little too casual for the place and they only let me in because I was with a group. Excuse me for wearing comfortable shoes in NYC! I'll stick with my tried and true dive bars where nobody gives a damn if I'm wearing sneakers. Went there with a friend on Saturday night. It was packed but we managed to find seat. The drinks are great. The names are really creative. I got the Dead Poet, it was strong and it tastes like the drink I had in angels share, I guess it's called daewoo? (100% spell it wrong) the services there were great! I came here for drinks to celebrate my birthday.  This has always been on my list of places to try because I have always walked past and seen a lot of people waiting in line to go in.  I came on a Friday night and did not have to wait long to enter.  However, I thought the staff here were really rude.  First off, let's start with the bouncer. I came with friends and told my friends they were too casual, but he'll let them slide this time.  Really, being too casual is an issue? It wasn't like they were dressed in basketball shorts and sneakers.Next, let's go into the place, it is nice but there was limited seating. A few couches and tables which was fine, but there was also limited space to stand around.  The place was dark and the music can get really loud.  Half the time you have to scream to each other.  Finally, let's go into the drinks.  A lot of people crowd around the bar so it's not easy to even order a drink.  So be prepared to wait a while to even get a drink.  The drinks definitely looked pretty, but they do not taste that good.  Strong, but that's not the issue.  They do have interesting combinations like using kale which I thought wasn't bad, but if kale isn't your thing like for my friends I wouldn't recommend it.  So they do have some healthy booze.  However, be prepared to pay $16-20 for drinks.  So drinks are pricey here, but I guess that is expected for a place like that.

This place is all that is right and wonderful with New York City. This dark, chic, cocktail bar is one of my favorite hidden gems. On the outside it doesn't look like much (looks like a door to an apartment) but the inside is gorgeous and secretive. Best part? No drink menu. Tell the waiter/bartender what you're feeling, a song, a memory, etc. and they will make you a cocktail accordingly. I told them to make me a drink that "tastes like Patsy Cline sounds" and it was 'Crazy' good. Looking forward to my next trip back :) This was everything I hoped for it to be. Had a surprise date night here and it was just right. All of the speakeasy vibes. You wait outside of what appears to be an alteration shop and enter into a dimly lit bar. Not sure if it'd just opened when we arrived, but it was empty aside from two other patrons. As expected, the bartender asked what I was in the mood for. I said whiskey and citrus and he created the most perfect cocktail--Blackberry Gold Rush. It was insanely good and just the right amount of strong. It was perfection. The music was also really great, so kudos to whoever's playlist was on that night. My second drink was what I asked for but not quite what I wanted. My bad I guess. I said refreshing and he created a strawberry, melon refresher topped with ginger ale. Too light for my liking, but next time I'll stick to the Blackberry Gold Rush or something along those lines. When I heard that Attaboy was #8 on the World's best bar list, I knew I had to see for myself what this LES haunt had to offer. What to look for: Nondescript metal door labeled with "AB" stickers. What to do: Ring the door bell. One of the bartenders will come out. He or she will add you to the waiting list. When you ask when you can have a seat expect to be told they have no idea. Wait across the street at the wine bar or go to the corner bars elsewhere.What to expect: Our group of 4 went out in single digit weather and waited 1 hr for a booth to open up. It's dark inside. Really dark. And really cramped. There's noise but loud enough to hear each other talk without yelling. It feels like the cleanest, quietest dive you've ever been to.What to order: The bartender comes to your table and asks what flavors you like. Our table asked for: 1) sweet, but not too sweet, with citrus, 2) sweeter and citrus, 3) smoky, 4) smoky but with some sweetness. The favorite: the strawberry honeysuckle- sweet, citrusy, with bursts of pulp. The smoky drinks ended up tasting like straight bourbon. The sweet but not too sweet was a little strong for my taste. Damage: $18/drink , but hey, it's New York.Consensus: for an hour wait, would definitely come back for a visit. But for the average wait, which is 2+ hours, for such a cramped environment and unknown time to table, I'm not sure if I would return. Hour wait at 2am on a Saturday. Civilized bouncer called Hunter. Quite possibly a pseudonym. Non-pretentious barmaid Katherine. Music is at a volume where one can converse at normal speaking volume.  No one dancing. No ugly people making out in full view.I believe they may only serve bourbons and whiskys. No ginger ale. No colas. Except Katherine took pity on my date and provided Coke as a mixer. Bravo, Attaboy, bravo! I felt the need to post this review for a few reasons.  First, this place is hyped.  It's ranked a top bar in the world on a list somewhere.  Obviously there's going to be a wait at the nondescript door and I expected some level of BS for a newcomer, because after all this is New York.  I'm about to detail what we experienced for two women showing up to enjoy a cocktail on a Monday night.  I can't emphasize MONDAY NIGHT enough.  We first arrived in the 10-10:30 PM window.  Door Guy, who we later learn is Everything Guy, greeted me and let me know it would be about 30 minutes.  Fine.  We already arrived, and would be more than happy to return, cause we're on a mission now if it's this good on MONDAY NIGHT.Fast forward to 11 PM.  I receive a call to come back, and our party of 2 ladies returns with a man friend in tow.  Everything Guy comes outside and lets us know our extra body is unexpected, he just may not have the space.  At this point I thought I was being transported to an alternate universe.  He then ushered us in to a dark corner of the bar just inside the door.  It was cramped, but doable, and we were about to order.Everything Guy reappears, suddenly happy to see us, letting us know how miraculously a table has opened at now 11:30 PM on a Monday.  What are the chances?  We are seated like we're about to partake in the Last Supper.  I get the no menu thing, in fact found it to be the most logical part of this adventure.  My cocktail, a bourbon concoction, was average.  Was it worth the trip?  Probably not.  What happens next solidifies the mark of a horrible service experience.  In a sentence, we were underwhelmed and wanted to get out of there after 1 round.  We were mostly polite about our desire to exit until we were ignored for at least 20 minutes.  The same guy now walking past, glancing at, and ignoring us with his horrible attitude while we were just trying to pay our bill.  I believe I said something on my way out.  I don't remember what it was, but here lies everything I have to say.  Never again. A true speakeasy. Totally nondescript exterior. You're going to walk right past it. Trust. It was early evening on a Thursday and it was a full house. I gather that they go to standing room only on the weekends. So expect a wait towards the end of the work week. Plan accordingly. But your patience will be rewarded. These are grown up cocktails. Complex and packs a wallop... if that's what you're looking for. And be sure to tell the bartender exactly what you're looking for. A rummy like me is easy to please. Put more than one rum in my drink and I'm over the moon. I was too busy enjoying it so I didn't take notes on what I had... not that it wasn't explained to me, I was just being a lazy hedonist. But once the bartender knew what I liked, he hit it out the park every time. For some reason I was completely fixated on the ice. I'm an ice eater, so the honking big pieces they have to chip in order to fit into your rocks glass completely did me in. I considered it an accomplishment to get one cube down enough to actually eat. Otherwise it's wasted ice! You can't waste ice! But the beauty of large ice is that it keeps your drink well chilled without watering it down. So all my other drinks were packing from start to finish. Yum. The bar is long with small booths in the back. It's not a place for very large groups. It's intimate, made for conversation. It can get a bit loud if there are loud talkers, but my partially deaf self didn't have a problem. I enjoyed sitting at the bar because I love watching professionals mix drinks. Dueling shakers are music to my ears. Their work is labor intensive and I fully appreciate it. A bar is only as good as its staff and these guys are top notch. You will enjoy their labors. Trust. Expensive, but worth it. I'm not usually the gal who will spend 17 bucks on a drink...even in Manhattan. Really intimate spot so I was concerned my two friends and I might not get a spot. We came @ 6:30 on a Thursday evening and had no problem getting a really nice booth. I would definitely also suggest sitting by the bar so you could watch the bartender make the drinks...they are super unique. The bar was super well run and organized. You basically just give the bartender some flavors or types of liquor you like and they come up with a really cool concoction.I had two drinks and both were super refreshing and strong. Worth the money in my opinion.As the night went on, the music got louder and more upbeat. Would definitely return for a special occasion. No food, so don't come hungry! Plenty of restaurants in the area though, so you'll be fine. Cool conceptual speakeasy that has a cozy charm inside. Bartenders were conversational and answered my questions. First, this Yelp page and the noted webpage was not created by the owners. I guess it's some sort of cult following thing. Even on a Wednesday night you may have a hard time getting in. A New York speakeasy found! Ring the doorbell and fingers crossed.This is a cramp and super intimate space. If you're with a group then there's only 3 or so booths so expect to wait. You can leave your number with them, and they will call when a booth opens up. Otherwise, hop on in at the bar. If you're there even before they're expected to open, also expect to wait. We encountered a gal that said she waited 30 mins. :/Drinks are basically $17 and are customized according to your taste buds. I was feeling a sweet/fruity cocktail, and the bartender created a cherry honeysuckle for me.The drinks weren't amazing or out of this world. It was about the experience and sharing a drink with friends. I was truly amazed by their cocktails! I would definitely go back again, and see if it's worth five stars. In a bar with no menus, I wouldn't ask for any classic cocktails. Instead, I tried my best to think of uncommon ingredients/tastes for cocktails.For the first drink, I wouldn't comment much. A waitress/hostess took my order, and I highly doubted her knowledge of cocktails (she said they have amaretto, but couldn't make almond flavored drinks....). The drink turned out to be really good, but not similar to what I told her. I guess she must not have communicated well with the bartender.The second one, which I ordered directly with the bartender, was mind-blowing. We asked for two drinks with two distinct cookie flavors and with no use of milk. They were unbelievable. They tasted exactly like hazelnut cookie and butter cookie. Both were bourbon based. The hazelnut one contained egg yolk, honey and vanilla liqueur (there's no hazelnut, but both of us tasted hazelnut). The butter one contained bananas and something else. The alcoholic taste mixed so well with the cookie taste. I was truly amazed by how they were able to do it. My favorite bar ever! One of the best bars in the world and the city. Best thing is that they don't really have a menu - they ask you what you are in the mood for and make a drink that EXACTLY matches what you want. Haven't tried better cocktails.The bar is also a cozy and small speakeasy where you feel really comfortableJust amazing! Please try it, you won't regret it. Please take into account that you should either go on a weekday and expect to wait about an hour or during the weekend no later than 6 pm. The waiting times can be impossible otherwise. I wasn't sure what to expect but I was pleasantly surprised.  This place is cozy and comfortable.  We showed up at 6 PM and we were greeted outside at the door.  Once our ID's were checked we were escorted in and seated at the bar.  The place is dimly lit and very quaint.  The bartender came over, gave us water and asked us what we like to drink.  The bartender created a cocktail based off of what I told him I enjoy.  The drink was fantastic, although pricey ($18).  The bartender was friendly and not pretentious at all.  I would definitely go back here. The door was pretty hard to find because you would pass by it and be like, is it this place? There was absolutely no markings so unless there's a line outside you probably won't find the door. The drinks were on the more expensive side and sometimes I feel like the people in there are rather snobby but the drinks I had were all good. A great little intimate spot for sure! It can get a bit loud so if you prefer a more cozy/intimate setting I would suggest coming a bit earlier before the crowd appears. Attaboy is basically my dream bar. It's dark, intimate, cozy, casual, and delivers an excellent drink. All this, without taking itself too seriously.As is my wont, I encouraged our party of four to arrive just shortly before opening in order to ensure we could be promptly seated. Apparently, we weren't the only ones with the same idea -- there was another group of drinkers already ahead of us when we rolled up a few minutes before the host started showing patrons in.As other Yelpers have noted, go early or be prepared to wait. (And I don't wait.)I didn't realize Attaboy doesn't offer drink menus until we were seated and a server explained the ordering system to us. It reminded me of Boston's Drink, back before Drink became the crowded, scene-y frat party that it is now.Both tipples I sampled were flawlessly executed and delivered with aplomb, exactly to my specifications (aged spirit base, spirit forward, featuring potable bitters). I fully appreciate a cocktail lounge that gets it right, down to the details of visually perfect transparent ice.On one hand, I'm a little disappointed that Attaboy isn't closer to home. I could see this becoming my local if I lived nearer. On the other hand, I'd probably be broke as fuck if they were, because their pricing reflects the superb experience they deliver.They've easily landed a place in my roster of top five favorite bars in the city, which is no mean feat. This speakeasy is as cute as it gets! Very, very narrow bar but it has the right feel. The bartenders were very knowledgeable and made a drink of my liking every time. Easy to find once you realize this gem is behind an ordinary metal door. Even this beer guzzler of a dude can enjoy a libation made from the finest ingredients now and then. The boozier the better I say. Living well is so choice.I could not believe that it had taken me this long to partake in the wonder of a liquid refreshment at this establishment. A good friend of mine asked me to accompany him on a bro-date and embellish in an evening of cocktails, conversation, carousing, and devious behavior. Who am I to decline an invite of such stupendous possibilities?I have a soft spot for Speakeasies, as they take me back to a more civilized time of NYC history. When gentleman had manners, broke the law, and drank in secret during the idiotic Prohibition years, while keeping it all hush hush. Honor among thieves for sure.As we pulled up in a taxi I was enthralled to realize that Attaboy was now housed in the old Milk & Honey location. Same nondescript metal door with no markings or signage letting you know a bar was there. (look for the fake tailor shop next door) We walked up and knocked on the door to enter, and were met by a doorman who happened to recognize my bud from a previous night there. He told us there would be a short wait of 20 minutes maybe so we hung around, and we actually got in a bit quicker.
