He escorted us to the bar area and asked if we could hold on for a booth, or if we would like a few seats at the bar as it might be a quicker seating. Of course, we took the bar. Everyone knows the best seats in a speakeasy type joint are at the bar. Great perch to watch the drinks being made, and view the bartenders work their magic. Plus, it's a social thing to me, as chatting up the bartender is always fun. Plus, you never know when you might be offered something on the house. Just for being friendly and tipping well. Take care of your bartenders, people!The inside space is pretty much similar to what I remember. Long and narrow. Dimly lit. People chatting in hushed tones, but with a look of merriment on their faces. Appropriate music played on a low volume level. Just a few booths in the back for couples or larger groups, and stool seating around the bar which has been enlarged from my last time there. As we sauntered over and slid onto our seats I felt as if I had never left this place. I was home.No menus needed. No cocktail list. Just tell the bartender or server what your palate is craving. Whiskey, gin, bourbon, rum. etc. Bitter or smooth. Fruity, sweet, or savory. You name it. From a classic, to a new mix-up of ingredients. Everyone has a favorite. Its all about the mixology here and those slinging the drinks do it right. We sampled many drinks over our visit and each was so different, and so tasty. I was feeling no pain by the the time we left! As with a cocktail bar such as this in NYC it ain't cheap, but it's one of those cocktail adventures you take now and then to splurge on yourself. Or, to take a date and enjoy drinks while getting to know each other on a more deeper level. It's all good.If you lamented the loss of Milk & Honey, and enjoy a perfectly crafted cocktail in a speakeasy atmosphere, chill adult vibe, and outstanding service, then by all means go here. Go here now.Start off with one of my fav cocktails, the Gold Rush, then see where the night takes you. A hole in the wall bar that serves the best cocktails. Their "Penicillin" is a must try! So overrated! The host/bartender was incredibly rude, he yelled at my friends and me in the middle of the bar. I don't know his name but he was a tall white guy with glasses and a long ponytail. He also kept staring at me with his palm open when he gave me the check even though I asked him twice to give a minute. Old Fashioned was less than average, it's better at my local bar.  Never coming back here! My favorite bar in the world. You tell the barkeep what you're in the mood for and what spirit you like and he or she, without fail mixes a delicious beverage for you! The seating is intimate and it's dimly lit. Wait time is long but they'll call you when you're up so you can bar hop and explore until then. Will always come back when I'm in the city The wait is long but they let you leave your number and eventually they will text you. It is worth it! It's a small very cozy place with good music and it does have a good volume . The mixologist are very talented . I had two drinks there and they got exactly what I was looking for. There is no menu which in my opinion is what make this place so unique . The talented mixologist with just a couple of questions will create a drink that fits your palette and it will surpass your expectations.

This is definitely my favorite spot for authentic handmade pasta in the city! The entire meal was divine and filled with flavor. We even witnessed fresh pasta being made upon arrival. Many thanks to Niko and Anthony for making our dining experience one to remember!My friend and I shared the artichoke and avocado toast, which was hands down the best Avo Toast I've ever had! Imagine smashed avocados topped with fried artichokes, pepper, and freshly grated parmesan. Shortly after our beet pappardelle w/ garlic pecorino and 4 cheese ravioli w/ vodka sauce arrived. The entire meal was equally shared and devoured. Pros:Service - Niko and Anthony gave great recommendations and really catered to our meal requests. Would definitely go back just to experience such awesome service and enjoyable convoFood - fresh, authentic, and rich with flavorAmbiance - hanging plants and reclaimed wood make you feel like you've stepped into another space outside of NY's cold winterCons:Zero Had okay experience overall. They do have some great authentic pasta and their cocktail was good too. I was also pleasantly surprised at how spacious the interior was when I went in further.My friend and I were both very satisfied with our food and the idea of "customize your own" pasta. They have many different options to choose from. Food is delicious.The service was what made my experience less than pleasant. I had a waiter who disappeared and didn't come  until we had to go and find. Since he was not around the area, i didn't get my water replenished until ive been eating without water. When we were done with our lunch and ready to leave, we had to wait forever for our waiter. He didn't show up, and we asked another waiter, but he told us that he's not our waiter and cannot do anything. He walked away, which the customers next to us also found it rude.Overall, the pasta and the food is great. My unpleasant customer service shouldn't stop anyone from trying their place. I think everyone will enjoy their authentic pasta, and everyone should try it. We just need to pray for a better service. This place is a hidden gem in my opinion. If I want Italian, ironically I don't head over to Little Italy despite the fact that I work a few blocks away. Reasoning being, I hate being pulled into tourist traps with bad service and/or food. Ugh. Gross. This place however has changed Little Italy for me entirely. Initially the place reminded me of Vapiano south of Union Square where it's basically an open cafeteria. Cool spot but not a place I'd go for a sit down dinner; perhaps lunch. But I was asked to join someone for dinner her and my god the pasta was fresh, the placed was filled with locals and the restaurant was really beautiful. The apps were ok but the main course was really what you need to come here and spend your money on. Don't bother with anything else... except maybe the mousse. If you want a great Italian spot in Little Italy without falling into those dreaded tourist traps, this is the place for you. Con: No bar! :( Went here the other day with a couple of friends for a reserved dinner. The outside decorations were really festive and invited. We came a couple of hours early to our reservation and they were able to sit us down at a ground level table. The place had a really warm Christmas-y vibe too it. Really great playlist in the background. Heard a lil Elton John, some indie hits. When we walked in, to the left there was a guy putting fresh pasta into the machine, great place to put a pasta making station. The menu had various selections of wines and beers and of course various pastas and appetizers. My friends and I all had a variation of the fettuccine nero pasta. I really liked the create your own pasta option. You're able to choose from freshly made pasta shapes and then choose a sauce for your pasta. I ordered the fettuccine nero with the Arrabiata sauce. One of my other friends ordered the fettuccine nero with the chicken bolognese sauce. And one of my friends ordered the fettuccine nero vongole.Our server was really attentive and knew the menu really well. Warm and and a delightfully airy basket of house made garlic sticks were served out. I wish we could ask for more, but I think they you had to pay more. The manager was walking around asking how the food was and joked that it was only "good". I love a place that can joke around, you saw that he really liked his work and everyone looked like they enjoyed being there.   The fettuccine nero with the arrabiata sauce was really really flavorful. I've never had fettuccine nero before but it was definitely a pleasant surprise. Squid ink is mixed into the dough made from semolina flour so the pasta has this rich dark black color to it. The pasta was rough in a good way, had a nice texture to it. The arrabiata sauce was smooth and spicy with a nice hint of chili pepper and a great spice coming from the roasted garlic. The manager asked our table to write up a Yelp review after our meal and here it is haha. This place has all the things going for it. Great service from the staff, great food, warm vibes, and a great playlist. 5/5 stars would recommend, would definitely come back again to eat some more food. I was really hesistant to come back after how salty everything was last time. BUT I AM GLAD I GAVE AUNT JAKE'S ANOTHER TRY. I made reservations for a table of 2 on a Friday night and was seated right away. The place was packed, but the manager and our wonderful server (Nicolas) made sure everything went smoothly. Our server made the best wine recommendation and it paired really nicely with our food. We ordered the mussels to start and the broth was delicious. I also ordered the Tagliatelle with the Sunday Sauce. They were super generous with the amount of meat and the pasta was very fresh. Aunt Jake's is truly one of my favorite places in Little Italy. First things first, the pasta is amazing! Secondly, Anthony hosted our pasta class and it was a complete delight! We drank wine, cut pasta shapes, learned a little lingo and then ate family-style with our group. I definitely recommend this class to others - friends, couples and groups alike. Molto Bene! I   had   some   time   to   kill,   was   by   myself,   but   wanted   something   tasty,   easy,   and   fresh.   I   soon   realized   I   was   out   of China   Town   and   in   Little   Italy   (my   dream),   and   didn't   know   where   to   even   start   for   finding   a   place   to   eat.   Aunt Jake's   should   be   everybody's   first   stop   in   LI   (little   Italy,   not   to   be   confused   w/   long   island).I   was   seated   in   the   back   room,   which   is   more   spacious,   very   light,   airy,   and   feels   like   a   greenhouse.   It   has   all open   windows   above   which   is   beautiful,   with   simple,   rustic   decor.   There's   another   backroom   that   looks   a   bit outdated   and   darker,   but   that   might   be   more   formal   for   their   dinners.   The   service   was   prompt,   the   prices   were very   reasonable,   and   the   ambiance   was   very   relaxing,   quaint,   and   authentic.   The   kitchen   is   open,   and   you   can watch   them   hand   roll   and   hand   cut   the   pasta,   and   then   make   your   sauces   all   right   in   front   of   you!My   favorite   part   of   Aunt   Jake's   is   the   menu.   They   offer   several   homemade   pasta   types   that   you   then   pair   with any   of   their   homemade   sauces.   It's   incredible.   The   pasta-bilities   are   endless.   I   want   to   try   every   single   type!   I got   the   fettucini   with   vodka   sauce   and   it   was   so   creamy,   flavorful,   and   super   fresh.   The   bread   is   a   4.5/5.   One   of my   favorite   things   was   the   massive   water   they   give   you   for   the   table.This   would   be   a   great   spot   to   stop   for   lunch,   or   a   great   dinner   date   spot   that   isn't   too   fancy   or   pricey,   but   the food   is   top   notch.   I   will   most   certainly   be   back. Like most people, coming to Little Italy is an overwhelming experience because you have so many people yelling for you to go into their restaurants, claiming theirs are the best, free round of drinks, etc., so I've found it's really much more helpful to depend on recommendation of friends to figure out exactly which place to try (unless you have the time and passion for Italian food, then by all means try them all!)Came to try Aunt Jake's by the recommendation of friends, and from the moment we walked in the door it did not disappoint. We were kindly greeted and shown to a nice little table in the back. Decor was lovely and chic, and everyone greeted us with such smiles.Our server was also friendly and helpful, made sure we had everything we needed, and even brought some jokes to our dinner table. Prices are fair for the quality of food, which is absolutely delicious by the way. Your options for pasta are their specials that are pre-set and selected, or you can build your own by ordering the type of pasta and the sauce/toppings, which is one of my favorite things - being able to build my own meal to all my favorite things! You can select the individual portion size or choose the larger family share portion. Their garlic-y bread sticks were also a MUST try. Overall, definitely recommend Aunt Jake's, five star experience all around! Bravo! Oh my gosh this is my first 2 star review and it's so hard for me to write this! Atmosphere: 5 stars. Excellent. Cozy, cute, trendy  Service: 2 stars :( our server was so inattentive and unfortunately kind of an awkward communicator. Food: no stars?? They were out of gluten free pasta on a Friday night and didn't have any alternatives. They didn't have shrimp and the special was shrimp scampi? I'm so disappointed! I've read great reviews about this place but honestly I had a terrible experience. So many great restaurants in nyc and particularly in Little Italy. Go elsewhere Love the atmosphere here! Staffs are so friendly and efficient. We were seated under the ceiling windows. They gave us complementary garlic bread sticks while we're browsing the menu. Ordered marinated mushrooms for appetizer, fettuccine Nero vongole, fettuccine Nero with arrabiata sauce, ravioli with marinara sauce and grilled chicken, glass of ros, sav Blanc, and east side cocktail. * Marinated mushrooms were quite nice, sauted then mixed in some arugula, good combo. * Fettuccine Nero vongole was a bit bland for my friend. It wasn't amazing, but it was good. It's a very settle dish with the clams and white wine sauce. Fettuccine was made with squid ink but it doesn't really have any special taste. * Fettuccine Nero with arrabiata sauce was delicious. The way it came out needs a little salt and pepper, which they have that in the table. Other than that it's the perfect portion and authentic. * Ravioli with marinara sauce was amazing! The grilled chicken I added was a tiny bit dry, but flavors were there. Eat the ravioli while it's hot! Once the cheese cools off it's not as good. I think I needed a little more sauce with the extra chicken and the bread they served with this. Otherwise give this a go! * Ros was ok, sav Blanc was great with the ravioli, ended up enjoying 4 glasses. I do prefer bigger wine glass so that the wine isn't poured to the top. East side cocktail was eh, can skip it. My friend said it was very weak and it wasn't worth the $11. Overall I would come back and try other pastas. I also saw a lot of people dining in themselves, when it got dark they gave each table a candle. Very good experience here! Great food. Beautiful interior. Friendly staff (a little slow on service). My boyfriend and I randomly came across this restaurant and without a doubt was absolutely in love with its ascetically pleasing interior! It's a beautiful restaurant, perfect for a date night or a girls luncheon during the day. The staff was very friendly and quick to seat us. The service was a little slow as there were 2, mayyyyybe 3 servers working on the entire floor that busy night with full tables of large parties. The food there was GREATTT! The proportions were huge.. way bigger than expected! My bf got the chicken parm and it was bigger than his face! But it was super delicious! I got the tagliatelle with Sunday sauce and it was sooo yummy.. the bread that came with the dish was in a little heart shape, which was a cute finishing touch to its massive pasta bowl! All in all, highly recommended!! Definitely want to go back and try other pastas on the menu! All the pastas and sauces are made in-house. They're divine!Baby John, the owner, walked us over from his canoli place across the street. He told us to make sure to order the "Sunday Sauce." Good call, Johnny!! It had all kinds of delectable, tender, meats in a super flavorful red sauce. YUM! Everyone at our table of 4 had different meals and every one was super delicious.Service is spot on. My daughter spilled a glass of wine, and the staff flew in to action like a NASCAR pit crew. Every drop of evidence of malfeasance was gone immediately without a trace.There are tons of choices in Little Italy for Italian food. You WILL NOT find a better spot than Aunt Jake's!Capiche?!!? Bomb place for create your own pasta.I loved Aunt Jake's because I could mix and match the type of pasta noodles and the sauces. I got the Roasted Garlic Pecorino sauce (garlic cream) and my friend got the Alla Vodka sauce (tomato cream) and we both really liked our choices. I will come back to try the other sauces.The restaurant has very cute interior design and made me forget that I was in the middle of the busy city.-- taste / 4aesthetics / 5vibe / 5service / 3price for quality / 3OVERALL / 4 Beautiful interior, great atmosphere, and delicious pasta. Who knew pasta could be instagrammable? We went on a Saturday in the early evening without a reservation and were luckily seated right away. When you walk in, it looks dark and like a small empty pasta shop in the front, with people making pasta from scratch there. You walk into the back for the sitting area, and wow! It's like you're in a sunroom...in the middle of NYC. Very bright, great atmosphere. I love the concept, where you could make pairings of types of pasta with sauces. I do wish they had recommended pairings on the menu, but the waiter was very helpful. I got the Fettuccine Nero (squid ink) with chicken bolognese sauce, which was delicious. The noodles tasted soft and fresh, and the sauce was delicious. It was a little on the pricey end for pasta ($12-18 for the pasta base, $2-4 for the sauce) but hey, that's NYC. I think it was worth it. I came here on a Wednesday afternoon with my two month old baby. It wasn't super busy. The servers helped me with the stroller right away and sat me indoor under the glass ceiling windows. The restaurant has a very cute and comfortable ambiance. They give you complimentary butte garlic bread twists. It was warm and fluffy. I ordered the squid ink clam pasta ($22). It was really yummy! The clams were cooked and seasoned just right. The pasta was al dente. I highly recommend and would definitely order again.It was my first time dining out with my baby alone. My baby fussed a little bit but none of the servers were bothered by it which I was really glad. I made reservations for a big party for me and my friends' annual holiday gathering. Can't wait to try their other dishes! I've lived in NYC for 7 years, and this is the only restaurant in Little Italy that my wife and I go to and bring our guests to. We are extremely picky and this place is beautiful and the food is delicious. They make all their pasta and you can watch them do it. You must get the avocado toast. Wish they still had the ricotta toast! Get a table in the back! Beautiful ambiance, aesthetically pleasing, friendly staff, quick service, DELICIOUS dinner! I came here on Wednesday at 7pm and the place was empty. We were seated in the back. It was extremely dark and hard to see but the ambiance was very intimate and romantic. I would say it's perfect for a date. We ordered:Artichoke and Avocado Toast - HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!! My god whoever thought of putting fried artichoke on avocado toast is a genius. It was such a perfect pairing. There was PLENTY of avocado (mixed with onions, tomatoes or pepper flakes I think?) topped on toast that was soft inside and chewy outside. It was garnished with some sort of cheese. All the flavors blended together nicely.Beef Meatballs - 1 serving comes with 3 large meatballs. It sits in a tomato sauce that had perfect consistency. Slightly acidic and not overly salty. The meatballs were moist and very good.Tagliatelle with broken meatball - Unfortunately the pasta was the least memorable. I had several bites and remembering that the tagliatelle was tasted homemade. The ingredients used were definitely fresh. The amount of sauce was lacking in my opinion. I'm almost certain that the sauce was the same as the beef meatball but this was slightly sweeter. It was good but not the best I've had. The price leans towards more expensive side but I left comfortably full. I can't wait to come back for brunch or even to grab a drink. Out of all the Little Italy restaurants this is certainly the most casual and least touristy.Went here early enough in the evening where they were fairly accommodating with a larger table (6) for my group of 4.While the food was delicious I did find it surprisingly get quite busy on a Monday as it progressed towards 8pm. I think so did the staff as it became immediately evident how understaffed they were with just 3 waiters serving the entirely filled restaurant.The food was delicious, atmosphere was right, and the service still came with a smile despite being behind due to the rush of folks.Normally 3 stars, but given the location, lack of high pressure sales person out front, lesser amount of tourists, and coupled with legitimately delicious food it gets a bonus star. I visited Aunt Jakes with a group of 5 while my family was visiting NY. When looking for a reservation, it was hard for me not to choose a restaurant in Little Italy with a fancy Italian name... and while this place doesn't have the most authentic name, I can assure you that they have plenty of authentic food!Upon arrival, the host sat us at a table in a large room decorated for the holidays. It was busy on a Saturday night, but not crazy busy like some of the other restaurants in the area. Another nice touch is that it was both well lit and the music wasn't overbearing. I could actually have a conversation with others at the table!Our server dropped off a bread basket and water and we contemplated which pasta to try. The whole theme of the restaurant is homemade pastas; you can even watch someone making fresh pasta on the way in. It is VERY fresh and delicious. We eventually decided to try a family-style sized bowl of cavatelli with their famous "Sunday sauce"- it has 3 types of meat!This bowl of pasta was no joke. 3 of us ate it and we managed to eat about half the bowl. It's also served with more bread because, you know, you can never have enough bread! My mom who is gluten free also enjoyed her gluten free pasta. It was also freshly made!The manager Anthony came over to check on us a few times throughout the meal and even brought over extra cheese (twice!). Thanks Anthony!This was my first trip to Aunt Jakes, but I can assure you that it won't be my last. It was reasonably priced, not a tourist trap like some other Little Italy restaurants, and they give you enough food to feed an entire Italian family. Oh and I saw on their website that they host pasta-making classes, so that would be a fun way to experience the area too! I was here twice, once as a sit down experience many months ago and the second time, a few weeks ago when I took to-go. I feel like they cook the pasta to a point of al dente where it feels undercooked but that is just my opinion, maybe you will like it?I am not impressed with their sauce despite them most likely making it in house it does not taste good. I think the quality has deteriorated and the food is not as good as it used to be. I ordered to-go and asked the sauce be placed on the side. It did not happen and I didn't bother calling them back...But my review is not based on that and simply based on the quality of there pasta and sauce. I tasted better in Brooklyn and, I doubt I will come back for pasta, maybe wine and appetizers as the ambience is very cute and staff is professional just not going to order pasta again. Credit cards and cash accepted.

I had been wanting to come to this place for ages and I finally had the opportunity on my last trip to NYC.  I made a reservation to meet a girlfriend for lunch.  I arrived and was seated. I ordered a glass of wine and shortly thereafter my friend notified me that she was running late.  I felt terrible for taking the table when she was going to be another 20 minutes, but the server seemed pretty understanding.  However, upon bringing my glass of wine he promptly spilled it all over me!  He was super nice and apologetic.  He brought me another glass of wine and when my friend arrived brought us both a glass of champagne to apologize.  Thank God I ordered white!My friend ordered oysters.  I don't eat those but they looked pretty.  We also shared the fries which she said were spectacular and I gotta be honest, they really were.  I also had the beef stroganoff which was incredible.  It was definitely one of the more expensive lunches I've had, but I didn't go here expecting it to be inexpensive.  I think my entree, fries, and wine came to about $70.  I really loved everything about this place.  The fact that I got a whole glass of wine dumped on me and still gave this place 5 stars should tell you how outstanding both the food and service were.  I definitely hope to come back. Came here for an early brunch right as the restaurant opened one Sunday morning.  The restaurant has a opulent feel, almost as if you've stepped into a past reminiscent to me of the roaring 20s meets French brasserie.  Tables are close together and seating for larger parties may be a little more challenging.  This place gets crowded quickly and the hum and din of conversation escalates as a result.  Servers are friendly and the service is quick and attentive.  Baked goods here are delicious (almond croissant!) but we also had eggs muerette (this is pretty heavy for the morning but good) and Balthazar salad.  It was a little on the pricey side, but hey - it's brunch in Manhattan. We went for brunch and I had the corned beef hash. It's not the corned beef I'd normally have where it's chipped and mixed in with potatoes. Here the meat was the type of shredded beef you'd find in a sandwich. It was fine, but not what I was expecting. I did love the eggs though. So full of butter that I am craving them 2 days later. Along with that dish, we ordered the pastry basket allowing us to sample a little of everything. The pecan bun was probably the favorite between us both, though I really liked the chocolate croissant as well. The monkeybread was a bit dry and I wish it was covered in glaze like the pecan bun. The croissant was just another croissant. Service was good, food was expensive and I would probably skip brunch and go with regular ol' breakfast times though. The ambiance is loud and bustling like a french cafe. The amount of food (aka carbs) we ate held us over until dinner. Would I come back? Maybe for traditional brunch if I was in the area. Solid! I came on a recommendation from a friend. Open Table did not have a reservation for dinner until 9:30. I called and they were able to work my party of two in. There was a crowd inside the and the bar was packed however we were seated immediately. The host had a French accent which was super cute. The interior was warm and cozy. Sexy and a bit romantic, but don't me wrong....there were families dining together. We were seated in a corner. I was excited because i read some of the reviews and it mentioned seating can be tight. We, fortunately had plenty of space.  I had spinach as  my side and the duck confit for my main. The meal was everything I had hoped for. Mouth watering in fact! The wait staff was prompt  and accommodating. Very nice dining experience. You know what it is with Balthazar. Its just such a beautiful place. It is this twilight zone moment that you imagine being part of a movie or dream. THAT is the unique selling point of Balthazar. It is definitely not their food.The oysters were absolutely delicious. $24 for 6 oysters. My partner ordered the trout ($31) and I ordered the steak au poivre ($47). The portions are big. And big doesn't necessarily mean better. The steak come with fries and a hump of cooked spinach. The steak itself was nice. Big slab of meat. A bit overdone with the fricking peppers but hey its au poivre so suck it up Richard! The fires were absolutely horrible. They were thin but fried to the core. So no light crunch outside just fatty crusts. I was so disappointed that I send the fries back. I got a new order and they were exactly the same. So its how they make it....ugh not even mediocre. The trout was nice. The veggies with the trout were good. But listen this is a $111.00 dinner. We didn't drink otherwise it would have reached the $180.00. And it really is just diner level in an absolutely beautiful place. There are so many great restaurants with excellent ambiance that offer so much better for this budget. The staff is wonderful. So I tip them generously. How they replace the paper covering your table, is a treat. But guys I am here for my food first. My partner has never been to Balthazar, so she was just excited and happy however for our next anniversary I am choosing the quality food that suits the level of her quality being and that is an A establishment. Balthazar is one of the New York establishments that I'd been looking for an excuse to visit. Thanksgiving Day seemed like the perfect opportunity for an old school feast here. I made reservations about a month in advance for 3 people at noon.Once we arrived, the hostess stand was positively hectic. There were a dozen or so people waiting, with a lot of walk-ins. We got seated about ten minutes late. We were in a comfy red leather banquette, although the wooden area behind us for bag storage needed a deep clean. Decor is that classic faux-French New York bistro.Although there was a Thanksgiving prix-fixe, they also allowed for a la carte turkey plates as well as their regular menu. My mom did the whole shebang ($72), with soup, turkey plate, and pumpkin pie, my dad did the beet salad ($20) and turkey plate ($39), and I did steak-frites ($40). We also did a bottle of Beaujolais, which was easy-drinking and paired well with everything we got.The beet salad was a winner, and more aesthetically pleasing than I would have expected from this standby spot. Soup was good. The steak was cooked to the correct medium rare and was tasty. Fries were sorry specimens with more coating than potato. Every component I tasted of the turkey dinner was good.The pumpkin pie was a highlight-- it's hard to improve on the original but the ice cream and small pool of vanilla bean cream were nice touches. We chose to cap our meals off with cappucinos, and the one I had (decaf) was, no joke, maybe the best I've ever had. (And it should be, at $5.75.) Our server was great despite the holiday rush. The meal was pretty slow paced, especially towards the end. It ended up running nearly two hours. It was a fun place to be in for the holiday, though it felt a little less special given the sheer number of people here. A definite tourist vibe.Overall, I'm glad that I crossed this one off the list, as the food was pretty good and it's an institution, but the prices are so high that I doubt I'll be back. For the love of all that is good in this world, please DO NOT COME HERE! I brought my girlfriend here for her birthday dinner because I was taken by all the rave reviews, but I could not have been more disappointed. It's honestly disgusting how let down we were - the food was horrible and expensive, the space was entirely too cramped and the service lackluster. I cannot comprehend what type of food everyone else had because ours was horrendous. We ordered the small beef tartar appetizer ($22), the trout ($31), and the duck confit ($35). Total was $95.80 before tip.Okay, so everything EXCEPT the beef tartar was atrocious; the beef tartar was phenomenal. It had a great spice combination and the portion was solid for the price. The crustinis that it came with were nicely sized for snacking and the pieces of meat weren't too big or too small. It all went downhill after this...The trout was SUPREMELY unsatisfying. The fish had almost no flavor and the skin wasn't crispy. In fact, I think they went out of their way to make the skin soft and limp so you could more easily remove the meat. That would've been a fine plan had the fish tasted like, well, anything, but it didn't, so you just ended up with bland fish with rubbery skin. The salad that came with the fish was similarly unfulfilling; everything on the dish was sad and pretty much a mile short of mediocre.Next up? Duck confit. Sound good? Wrong. Actually, if you like extremely salty food you may really enjoy this. It was like playing minesweeper with food; not every bite was like taking a big gulp of seawater, but you get really lucky every few bites. If you enjoy salt and oil, this dish is for you. The salad that accompanied the confit? Uninspired. Who even likes leek, anyway? I guess the potatoes were pretty okay, but that's not hard to accomplish when literally everything else on the plate is hot garbage. When we sat down we were going to order the creme brle for dessert but we quickly changed our minds when we tasted the cuisine.Service was very ordinary and not up to standards that one would typically expect with these prices. Our waiter was nice, I guess, but he seemed like he was pulled off the street and couldn't care less about providing great service. And who designed the restaurant layout? Who likes to sit like two inches from the table next to you? No one - that's who. Really unenjoyable experience all around, and I ended up apologizing to my girlfriend for such a terrible birthday dinner... There's no argument about it.It's the best brunch place in New York City! The host will take you to your seats without giving you attitude for missing one or two guests and you can wait at the comfort of your seats until they show up. And what's not to like when you find out that Eric Ripert of famed Le Bernardin is sitting next to your table. Magnifique! 2.5 stars, rounded down.Not very sure why this place gets such stellar ratings. It has mediocre american brunch items for like, 2-3x the price of an average brunch spot. Sure, the atmosphere is cute and it was nice that there was barely a wait for 7 people on a Saturday morning, but I just don't get it??Everyone ordered different things at the table and there wasn't a single thing I thought was very good. I couldn't even finish half my plate. No bueno. No good. Go someplace else. Unless you're starving and don't want to wait and don't mind paying too much for too little.. then go here. Hands down the BEST French restaurant in NYC. I haven't had such a delicious, satisfying meal in a long time. It is pricey, but WELL WORTH it and it'd probably be my go-to for special occasions. The ambiance makes me feel like I flew back to Paris. Each bite was hearty and incredibly satisfying, I left the restaurant with a very happy stomach. I ended up spending $60, but my friends spent $75 with wine. There's a reason this place has been around for so long.. it's a well run, nicely oiled machine that makes amazing food.The escargot was great. Everything an amazing pesto-y garlic-y escargot should be. We were scraping every last drop of that amazing sauce with our bread. DEFINITELY GET THIS. You won't regret it.The duck confit was very earthy and hearty, and the meat was so tender. My favorite part was the wine sauce they had with the mushrooms under the duck.. oh my. The salmon was perfectly moist in the center and crunchy on the outside.. a very well put together meal. The faro in makes you feel healthy for the week, and that salad it came with (whether or not it was for decoration) was SO GOOD. Last but not least, our favorite was the garlic shrimp pasta... WOW the texture was perfectly al dente and incredibly fresh. The sauce was orgasmic.. I LOVE garlic and this was just a little piece of heaven in each bite. The shrimps were cute and good, nothing crazy special but the sauce with that pasta... they really mastered their carbs. Who would have thought the french can make better pasta than the italians. For dessert, we got this meringue with berry compote. Normally I hate berry compotes and meringue is way too sweet for me. But GET THIS TOO, YOU WONT REGRET IT. It comes out nice and warm, the berry compote works really well with the meringue and the whole thing melts in your mouth. The combination and presentation of the dish deserves an award. I don't think it gets much better than that for the price. I definitely recommend the shrimp garlic pasta and escargot. I think duck confit is a stable in french cooking so you should get that too but the salmon you could get somewhere else. If you want dessert, a lot of people including us got the berry compote thing with meringue and it was well worth it. Service was great, our waitress was a little rushed at first but you could tell she had a long day and she made it up with her chill personality. We loved our dining experience at Balthazar.  The restaurant is elegant and classy, the service is professional and attentive, and the food is simply amazing!  Granted, we stopped in for a birthday brunch/lunch on an early Wednesday afternoon and cannot speak to their dinner service.  That said, after playing hooky for the day it's my opinion that mid-week brunch/lunch at Balthazar is something that should happen every week - special occasions be damned.  Anyway, I digress.As an Egg's Benedict addict, I can confidently say that this dish delivers!  The egg's were cooked perfectly, the portion size was generous, and the pommes frites are among the best in the city.  A little birdie told me that Balthazar employs two full-time staff members dedicated solely to making pommes frites (and it definitely shows!).The cheeseburger is also something that you should order!  The meat is well-seasoned, the burger was juicy... and yeah, it comes with a side pommes frites...  Shout out to our waitress who took amazing photos of us! Meh... for some reason my partner decided that we "must do Balthazar" for brunch. I don't know why. The brunch here is so basic it's not worth describing. And it's pricey... The service was pretty good (maybe a bit slow) and seating was tight, but there's no magic here...Mostly tourists and New Yorkers who love tradition (as opposed to great food)... we wouldn't return. Obsessed is the word I'd use here! I've been coming here for years and always have an amazing meal with amazing service. Literally, the service is impeccable. I'd recommend the moule frites, goat cheese tart and beet salad. Oh, and let's not forget the champagne. It wouldn't be Balthazar without a bit of bubbly! Cheers to this group for killing it. Every. Single. Time. Had dinner with my other half last week and it was a fabulous experience. We decided to check this place out after watching one of those cooking shows featured the place and their fries. Well...the fries which we of course ordered were probably the least impressive part of the meal. We started off sharing the liver and foie mousse. So good and creamy and rich. The onion confit was a great counterbalance to the decadence of the mousse itself. I ordered the duck leg confit which is the best I've ever had by far. It was like succulent and savory butter over some yummy veggies. My boyfriend  had the special which was essentially a chicken with potato stew dish. Very nice as well.We ended our meal by sharing some profiteroles, ice cream and some strong coffee (bad idea on a school night!). Perfect date night meal.The restaurant itself had the ambiance of a Parisian bistro and, although a bit tightly spaced in some areas (including our table), we managed to have our conversations without screaming across the table.The service was very attentive and, though we did wait a little longer for the check, it was for the most part timely and efficient.Would definitely come back here again as there were other items on the menu I would love to try. POSSIBLE SCAM?After enjoying my meal, I split my $127.40 bill between cash and debit card. Paying $100 in cash, $27.40 on my card & leaving a cash tip for the waiter. I then signed my bill for $27.40.  Balthazar then charged the full $127.40 onto my debit card. Myself & a representative from my bank called Balthazar Restaurant to resolve the issue. They promised to look into it but failed to contact me at the correct e-mail address.After calling back a few days later, the manager insisted that I had paid the full $127.40 on my card. Only after letting him know that I had my receipt of $27.40 did he promise to look into the matter. The manager then miraculously found my correct receipt. We really enjoyed the food here, but the experience with the bill left a bad taste in my mouth. The food and service was excellent. Came here with a party of nine and Marie was our waitress. She was attentive, kind and we never had to look for her. Our order was taken very quickly and Marie made sure everyone was well attended to and quickly made sure our drinks were served. The restaurant provided us with free desserts which were delicious. Most in my party had the steak frites and everyone said how delicious it was. I had the chicken paillard which was very tender and scrumptious. I will definitely come back to this establishment You gotta make reservations for this one - we came in to check in for a late lunch and the place was heaving. I've never seen so many people literally squished up to the front desk area, waiting to check in or waiting for a table. Once we checked in, lunch was efficient and delicious. Lobster bisque was so creamy and rich. The homemade linguine with gulf shrimp, garlic confit, lemon zest, chili oil and basil bread crumbs was garlicy goodness. Kir royale was the perfect start and then a glass of the Pouilly-Fume and I was a happy girl. Ok so I have been wanting to go here since I got back from the south of France 6 months ago. I've only heard people rave about how good the food is and how similar it is to the food I had while traveling in France. It definitely did not disappoint. I felt like I was right back in France at this place. I was with a group of 3 which was a perfect amount. We started off with the steak tartare and the chicken liver and foie gras mousse. They were both amazing and the perfect size. They gave us extra bread which is a plus in my mind! Then we all got the duck confit. This is something I ALWAYS get when I go to a French restaurant without fail. I have to be honest. It was OK... with the high standard I had going into it I was just a tiny bit thrown off. It was delicious don't get me wrong but I expected it to be better. We moved on to desert where we got an almond pear tart. I will leave it at that. The service was excellent. Our waitress was very attentive and also gave us the time we needed and did not rush us through the meal whatsoever. The only thing I would change is the fact that they really pack everything and everyone in. Which, it is a very popular place so they want as many customers as they can fit into the place. It was very loud and it felt a little like people were yelling over the tables next to them. I am very big into bread so when I was leaving and saw the complimentary brioche bread that had been freshly baked and left for people to take home I was very happy. Very good bistro,i have only been here 2 times. What a fantastic brunch experience. Extremely large always packed but food comes out on time.  I personaly love seafood tower and stake . The wine list is great alsoA must place to see and have brunch before you leave nyc. Its expensive but worth it. Oyster mary was great The service and the food was fantastic This was my favorite spot on our NYC Trip. I checked in but I didn't write because i was enjoying it way too much! Our waiter was friendly. The atmosphere was warm and beautifully decorated for Christmas. There was no wait but we had a reservation. They have a famous eggplant steak that is a vegan dish but i went for the waiters recommendation of the shrimp with homemade linguine. It was incredible.. I've never had a pasta that flavorful. I ate every last bite!! I wish we had this spot in Miami!

They take credit card/debit card.Half of the Banh Mi filled me up before proceeding to Kimchee Fries and chicken wings.Chicken wings were not so tasty but the Banh Mi and Fries were good, it was spicy.I recommend ordering with thai iced tea or bubble tea. I was overall disappointed with this place because of its rave reviews and awards. I will say the area, price, and amount of food you get you can't really go wrong- but as far as Banh mi sandwiches go, the bread was quite soft, and they were made ahead of time and weren't as fresh as they could be. For a quick and cheap lunch or dinner this is a food place with lots of options for vegetarians or variety of meats, but know that there are better Banh mi sandwiches out there! Update: After getting banh mi from Saigon Vietnamese Sandwich Deli, I haven't been coming back here. The sandwich there is far more superior that I can no longer give this place 5 stars. The bun here has always been rock hard, which makes it much harder to eat and enjoy. The tiny chunks meats are so crispy and hard, it seems like they've been stir fried for too long. I was in Jersey City for a business trip and with a free weekend in between. Without wasting the opportunity, I went about exploring in NYC. I happened to stumble upon Banh Mi Saigon and now their signature Banh Mi Saigon with chopped barbecue pork is my #1 on my [non-existent] list of banh mi places in NYC! The barbecue pork is generous, tender, flavorful, and slightly sweet. The baguette is crispy and stuffed with an adequate amount of carrots, radish, cucumber, and pate.The portion is huge for just $5.25 and their serving time is quick. I received and finished my sandwich all within 20 minutes. My sister LOVES Banh Mi sandwiches so I had to take her here while she was visiting. Had never been but was told this was the place to get Banh Mi in Chinatown. Went on a Sunday afternoon, once we walked in, the whole process of ordering and getting our food took about 5 minutes. We got the Banh MI sagon (BBQ pork spicy) which cost $5.25. Compared to other foods in NYC, this felt like a great deal although it was a lot of white bread. We shared the first half and I ate the second half for lunch the next day. The pickled veggies with cilantro complimented the BBQ pork seamlessly. The pork had a nice crunch to it that even a day later, was as good as it was the first bite. It has to be one of the best foods that withstands time for such a low price.Overall: Such cheap Banh Mi with a great BBQ pork that could be lunch for two days :) Came by on a Saturday and there was no line around midday. I got the classic and thought it was decent. Not the best in the city or anything but certainly tasty, filling and the right price. Cash only. I grow up eating vietnamese sandwiches at many places, trust me when I say this place tops them all. It's the lowest priced out of them too. These sandwiches usually contained pickled vegetables and your choice of meat (I chose my favorite, spicy pork) in a harty loaf of bread. It's absolutely delicious and the best part is it's so cheap and huge. For $5.25 you can split a nice sized sandwich with someome else, located in Chinatown Manhattan. Value: 8/10Experience: 8/10Taste: 6/10Great for a quick and cheap banh mi with seating along the wall.Value: I got the BBQ banh mi for $5.25. It was a decently sized sandwich and enough for a smaller meal. You won't find a cheaper banh mi in NY1 (And I'd love to know if you do know a place! ;))Experience: My sandwich was already packed and ready as soon as I ordered so that was a bit weird. The seating areas along the walls were clean and had sriracha bottles placed throughout. It also shares the store with a jewelry store with a fish tank so that's interesting.Taste: Definitely not impressed. The bread was too dry and cut my mouth as I ate it. The BBQ pork was cold and I could tell the sandwich has been laying around for a while. Maybe if it was fresh then it would have tasted better. Xe May Sandwich Shop banh mi's are much better IMO. Their banh mi is the epitome of mediocrity. Can't get a banh mi more average than this. Just kidding, it was actually pretty tasty. The sandwich is not made fresh since they just took one pre-wrapped and gave it to me. It's not as good as the freshly made ones, but it's cheap. I ordered the #1 BBQ Pork Sandwich.  The BBQ pork is almost ground, but the taste is fine and slighly sweet. slightly sweet. The sandwich comes with carrots, radish, cucumber, and pate. When you warm it in the microwave or oven, it tastes much better.The main draw for me is they sell snacks on the side. I found out that they sell this delicious Malaysian brand of mooncakes called Overseas. My dad bought some for me once at a Malaysian restaurant in Edison, NJ, and I have been searching for them since. I'm so happy that I found them here. The mooncake brand has a pandan and mung bean flavor called Golden Starlight. It is the best mooncake I ever had. You can get a box here for $32.I also tried the Bnh B Nuong (Vietnamese honeycomb cake) because I was curious how similar it was to bika ambon. It tastes nothing like bika ambon. It's more stiff and coconuty. I enjoyed it very much though. I didn't buy them, but they also sell these tasty looking mung bean pastries. I'll have to get some next time. Overall, average banh mi, but great place for some delicious Southeast Asian snacks. I was in the area, so I decided to drop by for a quick dinner. I didn't know what I to expect, because when I stepped into the store, there was a jade jeweler at the front with the Banh Mi shop at the back. On the right side, there were a group of Vietnamese employees gathered around a TV sitting on plastic chairs. I was pretty confused; it felt like I was in Asia. The sandwiches were probably pre-made because I was instantly handed my BBQ Pork Banh Mi right when I paid the cashier (this place is cash only).BBQ Pork Banh Mi: filled with daikon, carrots, cucumbers, cilantro, and ground BBQ pork. The bun was toasted and light and the veggies were crisp. The ground BBQ was a little bit sweet, but not overwhelming, and it was pretty fatty. A criticism regarding the sandwich was that it was cold. It probably would've tasted better if the pork was warm and the buns were toasted to order. Overall, this place is pretty good and filling for its price. It's somewhat expensive for a Banh Mi, but it is cheaper than other places in NY. Banh Mi Saigon will probably be my go-to Vietnamese sandwich shop in the city. If you're around the area, or if you're craving a sandwich, I would recommend coming here! I'm planning to come back and try other things on the menu. Looking for a no frills "Banh-Mi" shop? Then welcome to Banh Mi Saigon on Grand Street... not familiar? It's right across the street from Nyonya! ;) It's a shared shop with some odd jewelry place (to the left), some counter seatings (to the right) and head straight to the front, queue up, order & pay.   Menu screen-display (right side - look up) and don't forget those daily special inside the "heated" containers; pre-made snacks, drinks & a cup of "flan" for $2.50! Appropriately priced for Chinatown eats $5-$6, always add an ice cold Viet coffee $2.50! ALWAYS!! Banh Mi - pretty dang good! We got #1 (BBQ pork) and #4 (Viet Ham & Pate) - all comes with the goodies (pickled radish/carrot/cilantro/cucumber). Happy feasting Yelpers!#willtravelforfood The price point and the food quality were both amazing!! My boyfriend and I both got the barbecue pork Banh mi and bamboo/carrot drink, which came out to $12 total. Both items tasted amazingly delicious and the quantity of food was great. I would definitely recommend this place as a mid day snack or cheap meal. So yummy that I regret not finding this place when I lived closer! I tried this spot, because Saigon Vietnamese Sandwich Deli sold out of Banh Mi's. I was not disappointed at all. Clean, quick, and delicious. PS they only accept cash, but there is a Chase down the street. I will absolutely come here again! Since I've made nearly 10 trips here through the spring and summer months, I've become familiar with this spot's robust bnh m sandwiches. They're jam-packed with leafy vegetables and pickled carrots, and the bread is high-quality (crispy on the outside, and soft on the inside). I used to love Banh Mi Saigon's sandwiches, but since their options for vegetarians like me are quite limited, I'm opting for other lunch choices in/around the Chinatown area.That said, their sauted shrimp bnh m is worth a try: after devouring the vegetable add-ons, the best part of this sandwich was tasting the mayonnaise, bread, shrimp and caramelized onions all in one bite. Also, their bnh b nng (green colored chewy sponge cake) is top-notch: I've gotten slices for myself and friends, and they've all raved about it.Monetary transactions here are usually quick, and customer service related to other issues can be a hit or miss: once, I accidentally ordered a sandwich I didn't want and asked for an exchange, and even after I apologized to the staff worker, they continued to look pissed off and didn't give me a reply. There was so much ego and anger in that interaction, and it continues to define the tenuous attitudes that the staff workers can have at the shop. I have been visiting this store for many years before  they relocate to here from a tiny place a block away. It is one of the oldest Vietnamese sandwich shop around Chinatown and maybe even NYC. This is like a ma and pa shop to me. They are always original and their food is always good. I always ordered #1(BBQ pork) on the menus and it has never disappointed me. I ordered the sandwich then 2 to 3 minutes later, it is done. The fast service can always can take care of the long line in a timely matter. That is why I don't mind waiting in long line. The sandwich tastes the best when you just receive it. Why? That is because they just made it and the bread is still crispy instead of later becoming soggy from the vegetables that is inside. The main ingredients inside the roll are one type of protein(meat), cucumber, cilantro, shredded radish (carrot & daikon) and streamed pork roll. You can change what kind of meat you want as well as remove any other ingredients that you don't like. I just like everything on it and sometime I just add hot pepper to spice it up. The price at this place rarely change over the years and that why people like myself come back. This is prefect place, if you want to grab something quick to eat. I will always come back from time to time as long as they are still open. I've been coming here to get my viet sandwich fix. I always get the BBQ pork sandwich (Banh Mi) and honestly it never disappoints me. I always get non spicy even though I love spicy food. For the spicy verison of the sandwich they just put in a jalapeo pepper and make it "spicy". I've had other Banh Mi sandwiches at other places where their meat is actually spicy. But overall the sandwich is definitely worth getting, and the prices are reasonable, less than 6 dollars in Chinatown, where else can you get such a deal? Food 7Service 6Atmosphere 6 I'm straight into the 2nd half of my sando 5 hours later and it's just so good....still!!!!  Flavorful and yuuuuuuuumm meeeee!!!!  I don't always crave the bahn mi, however I am always pretty happy and satisfied that I got it. My style is the #4 wif double the meats.  Both the pate and the pork roll dubbed up is the way to go if ya ask me.  Straight up satisfying is what it is.  I get both my easy eating sando craving AND asian taste profile satisfied. This place is my go-to spot for my banh mi needs. I usually get the #1 (bbq pork banh mi) or the curry chicken banh mi. You can order it spicy or non-spicy (for those of you who like the heat, they do bring it). During the lunch rush, they usually have #1's pre-made minutes in advance, so you can get a fresh sandwich in a hurry. They're priced well and they don't skimp on the meat or the cilantro/carrots/radishes. They also have good summer rolls that can suffice as an entire meal, too. Also like their spring rolls and the fish sauce that comes with it (they make their own and it's not overly fishy like most fish sauces that come with spring rolls).There's a jewelry kiosk randomly placed to the side of the restaurant, but who cares, this place is one of my favorite lunch places in Chinatown. A good "change of pace" kind of lunch when you want something cheap and quick but you're not in the mood for Chinese food that day. Overall, just a solid place. Will continue coming again and again~ [Note: cash only, be prepared to order since the line moves quick]Currently #1 on my list of banh mi places in NYC! You really can't beat their portion size and $5.25 price for their signature Banh Mi Saigon, with ground bbq pork as the main meat.Disclaimer: Their Bun Nem Nuong is made with the same bbq pork, which suffice to say isn't the typical texture you'd get at a Vietnamese restaurant, but it's still pretty good and filling.This place also stocks Cha Lua and Cha Hue, so if you're missing mama's meatloaves you can get 'em here! It took 10 seconds to walk across the hall and jewelry stand, look at the menu, and choose #1 item (BBQ pork). Soft spoken man behind the counter asked, "spicy or no spicy?" I said spicy. He did a wide spin, grabbing a brown bag and something else, and returned with my lunch ($5.25, cash). I was in and out in 30 seconds. If you want to eat there, there are some high tops and AC. My spicy BBQ pork was *spicy*. There are chunks of jalapeo (or some other spicy pepper) with spicy sauce. I had half for lunch and the other half 4 hours later - plenty of food!

Friggin' love this place! I'm from the Bay Area and hadn't found Mexican food that even remotely resembled food from back home -- until BC.You must get the guacamole and the soups are really yummy. I always get the carne asada tacos and, though they are small, it's enough food for me.The spicy margaritas will knock you on your ass they are excellent. Located on the fringe of LES and Chinatown lives Barrio Chino, a Mexican restaurant inspired by their neighbors in Chinatown. The small and unassuming restaurant is well known for its margaritas and on a Thursday night, the full and bustling restaurant was filled with diners drinking margs, eating tacos and chips and guacamole. My friend and I were able to snag a bar seat and we shared 3 orders of tacos (each order of tacos comes with 2 for $9). All tacos are served on Chinese inspired plates, creating a beautiful blending of cultures and also showing appreciation for the neighborhood. My favorite tacos were the steak and least favorite were the cactus. I would definitely visit Barrio Chino again for a meal. This is not a great restaurant for large groups however, as its noisy and loud. This place is a little hard to find but it's white with no signs. I was craving some tacos and decided to come here at 9:55 a.m. and asked if they were opened at 10:00 like what the Yelp page says.. but they told me that they open at 10:30 a.m... Pescado ($12)- 3/5 They give you 2 sad looking tacos that come with some mango and onions. Without the guacamole that I paid $4 for, it would have tasted really depressing. It's a tad bit sour. Anyways they do give you a bunch of sauce inside the container, which I think is just filler..I don't know if I would spend $17 on 2 tacos though. As good as it gets, really! Great drinks, great food, an amazing staff, and a cool atmosphere. I recently went to Barrio for the 5th time, and a review of this place has been a long coming for sure. On this particular visit, it was New Year's Eve, so the plan was to come for drinks and dinner and stay for the later night festivities (on weekends they sometimes push the tables away, build a makeshift dance floor, and feature talented DJs). As expected, everything about the night was spot on! Continue reading for some highlights.FOOD - I got the chicken verde enchiladas AGAIN; these rule so much that I've had them a few times! Definitely worth it! Other stand outs I've tried include the tacos (all are good), the quesadilla, and their soups (again, all are good).DRINKS - Get the grapefruit margarita! You can't go wrong! It comes with a sugar rim, which I'm not a fan of so I always sub for salt! Soooooo tasty (and strong)!!SERVICE - From wait staff to bartender to late night DJ--always great service all around!This place is very small and often crowded, but the wait is definitely worth it if you have the time. Just have a couple of drinks and wait for a table! You'll be glad you did! Such a great little mexican spot in my opinion. Their tacos are amazing and so is the spicy margarita. The atmosphere is loud, trendy and fun. Good spot to bring out of town friends or going on a date.Every time I've come, the wait has ended up being shorter than they estimate, which is always a nice surprise. Easy enough to grab a drink at a nearby bar while you wait! I probably would rather insist on giving a 2.5/5 review but the extra half doesn't hurt anyone I suppose.The service is just ok.  Even on a Sunday night, nearly every seat was filled until almost 10pm.  So maybe the service couldn't keep up but it definitely wasn't the easiest thing in the world to get some help with our order being seated at the bar - I recall there being just one bartender to do drinks and bring food out to bar seats.Two tacos come for $9 which some might say isn't the worst thing in the world but they were small, not very tasty, and a tad disappointing.The enchilada plate offered a little more substance but I don't think I was able to taste anything beneath the plow of beans.Meh. What a beautiful restaurant. I came for a weekend lunch with a friend at 1p, walked right in without a reservation. There were several empty tables that stayed empty throughout our time there. Maybe it was the time of the day and how the sun shined brightly in its large storefront windows, or maybe it was the lack of people and the ability to talk intimately with a friend... In any case, I had a wonderful experience there. The food was delicious. Although it was brunch, there were plenty of non-brunchy items. I would recommend to get another small dish with the tacos - they're small. We ordered guacamole to split, which was perfect. One negative note -- our server grew impatient as we ended our meal. We wanted to linger and chat without forks in our mouths. The server first asked if everything was ok, then asked if we wanted something else, then asked if we wanted dessert, then asked if we were ok (again).I am coming back next weekend! Great drinks, nice neighborhood and good vibes! So definitely a few things to like about this place. Unfortunately the food is not one of them. Although the guac was ok, I am frankly baffled that anybody would serve those flavorless, greasy, hard as bricks chips. The salsa was chock full of smokey ancho chili. Different, but not good. The mole sauce on my chicken was grainy with an unpleasant texture and so sweet it hardly qualifies as savory. A good mole should be complex yet balanced and deep in flavors. The fish tacos (mahi mahi) was pretty good and I would come back for drinks! Being from San Diego I grew up eating next levelMexican food, Barrio Chino is the closest to SD Mexican food the steak tacos and chicken verde enchiladas are fire also the barbraco is really good! Never disappointed with the food or drinks.  The only thing I would like to change is they don't except cash it card only so don't forget your debit/CC card. If you have mole... I am coming for you. That isn't a cute name for guacamole. Guacamole's cute name is guac. This place has mole poblano (if I had to guess what type it is) so despite the worst rainfall in New York history that cinco de mayo. I came, I searched, I conquered!We kept it simple here, I really only wanted the mole, so I got that with a side of rice. Little fun fact about me I lived in Chiapas Mexico for 2 years and one of the biggest comfort foods for me was rice and mole. Though often served with chicken there, I just liked the mole and the rice. Something that tasted good and filled me up.The mole was borderline great. Definitely good, but nothing exceptional about it. The best mole I have had post my time living in Mexico is still in Salt Lake City Utah... which is crazy. This mole was the perfect mix of sweet and savory. I had two enchiladas with them and they were very filling. Perfectly cooked chicken. More importantly perfectly cooked rice.The to the sheppard tacos were also good not great but also took me back to the good ole days in chiapas. Perfectly topped with white onion cilantro and pineapple, and gave me one last nostalgic bite.The coconut flan, ended our experience and... take the coconut off. That is my only suggestion. The flan was easily the best of the three things we had. Perfect custard consistency, perfect flavor... and then... the stupid crunchy coconut. I like coconut but this dish was trying to do too much. THE VERDICT:Go try this place once. That is about the total number of times that you need to go here. Get a feel for the ambiance and the flavors of mexico. Also... they have a pretty awesome name, Barrio Chino or... Chinatown. Which is kind of near where we ate. Well played BC well played. However, I cannot say that I will be returning to this place ever... nevertheless a delicious meal, but nothing special. Came in for lunch on a weekday and there were plenty of seats available. I really dislike when I walk into a restaurant and no one is there to welcome me. You just stand there....do I just grab any seat? Or do I wait for someone? Don't want to disrespect the host if there is a host, right? Granted the Brianna ? Was working the whole place by herself, I was finally greeted and took my seat. Here's the breakdown:Vibe - typical LES, chill, casual with hipster music - go figure. Drinks - I ordered the hibiscus tea which was very tart but refreshing. Give it a try if you want but it's not a must. Food - I ended up getting the verde enchiladas. Basically a green sauce with 2 enchiladas, some beans and cheese. Oh and 2 pieces of tortilla chips. I devoured the whole plate, so it wasn't bad but it's not mind blowing. I forgot to mention that it took about 20+ minutes to get my food and it wasn't busy. Maybe that's the norm? But it felt long to me. I would go back a 2nd time to try them out again but this 1st visit didn't leave an impression. Arrived at around 5:45PM, just before the peak of dinner time. Shortly after we arrived, the restaurant did get pretty crowded and there was a wait time, as the place is not that big. Sadly, they don't have any happy hour specials. To start, we got a Watermelon and Classic Margarita. Both were so refreshing and they were definitely generous with the alcohol! To pair, we got guac and chips; the guac was seasoned really well and I loved the saltiness of the chips. Because we weren't that hungry, we just got Ceviche and an order of the Al Pastor Tacos. The ceviche also comes with chips, and I loved the tanginess of it all; though I would've been happier if there was more fish in it. The Al Pastor tacos were seasoned beautifully, the pork was nice and tender, and the pineapple added the perfect sweetness to it. To conclude, we got another round of drinks, I got a Hibiscus Margarita and my friend got a Coconut Mojito. The mojito was on the lighter side, while the margarita was still really strong and had a sourness to it. Overall, it was a great dinner, though I would prefer happy hour specials, because the drinks do get expensive, ranging from $10-12 a drink. I was here about a month or two ago with a friend. The space was very small and crowded. We didn't have a reservation(I also don't think they take reservations), we just walked in and thankfully got a table. I had a glass of white wine which was very nice and complimented my fish taco dish. This fish taco was everything. It was so good I ordered another one right after I finished the first one. If I was in the LES area and looking for something to eat, it would be the first place that comes to mind just because that fish taco was so good and pretty reasonably priced. I pass Barrio Chino on a weekly basis and have wanted to try it for dinner for some time now.  The BF & I went there last Thursday night.  Ambiance was lovely for a date night on the LES and the wait wasn't too bad either.Food was really yummy - had a homemade charm to it and didn't taste overly salty.  We started with the ceviche which was served in a fun sundae-esque glass with two long spoons and tortilla chips.  Flavors were on point - just wish there was more seafood in it!  We then shared two orders of tacos - one Pescado and one Arrachera.  Both were pretty good (tough because we're die hard fans of Los Tacos and Los Mariscos in Chelsea Market).  And finally, the Enchiladas Verdes which were really really good.  Would definitely come back for those enchiladas! Great atmosphere for dinner and drinks. The dining room is very small, so I was very skeptical when my party of four walked up on a Saturday at 8 and were told would have a table in less than 15 minutes. Well, we barely had time to finish a drink down the street when we got the call saying the table was ready. Once in we were treated to very good drinks - the strawberry vanilla marg really is as good as other reviewers have described, it has a fresh strawberry taste as opposed to an artificial syrup flavoring. The food was very good as well. The menu is small but carefully selected. Highlights were guacamole and tacos al pastor. The rice was also cooked perfectly. LOVE this place. The food is amazing. Came here for dinner and gets a bit crowded and it is pretty cramped. However, the food really made up for the spacing issue. Their guac is fresh and tasty. Margaritas were also at a great price and delicious! Great great food.The ceviche was my absolute favorite! The staff is friendly! Always packed! This is not your have a deep conversation kinda place as they pump up the music :-))) Great fun and great food! And they do lunch, dinner and brunch! Highly recommended! Barrio Chino is tiny! Keep that in mind when you stroll in with your huge Canada Goose jacket. We split guacamole, enchiladas, and soup. It was delicious! I would definitely recommend coming to dine here. The service is a little bit slow but overall a good experience. First off, I do want to say the drinks were good and the server was really hospitable and professional. Our negative experience mainly stems from these two very rude waitresses. Throughout our night, they were very insistent on kicking us out of our table.They really hit the final straw when one of the waitresses comes to our table and asks us to get out of our table to make space for people who were going to eat dinner. Normally, I would not be annoyed by that request, albeit a rude one, but the context of the situation was absolutely absurd. Other people in the restaurants were sitting down, without food on their tables and without drinks. She comes to our table, once we had all ordered a round of drinks for our table---drinks, which in all honesty are probably more expensive than any of the food those people were going to order. She asks us to take our drinks and sit on a window ledge near the corner of the restaurant. In other words, she was asking us to take out drinks outside. This was rude beyond comprehension. Again, the server was great and so were the food and drinks, but the service from these waitresses definitely needs some correcting from management. Cozy, dark and tight. It's a double date kind of place not a group hangout. No happy hour. Their cocktails are great! There's multiple selections of mojitos, margaritas and beers. I personally liked the dark rum mojito and their habenero grapefruit Margarita was pretty cool! It has a nice heat to your cold cocktail. Food wise i had their taco platter with a little of everything:  steak, chorizo, cactus salad and guacamole.  I thought their steak was very salty but everyone else i was with loved it. The chorizo was ok and the cactus salad was gross.  Haha...Their chicken tacos were better, not as salty and some hot sauce really helped. Next time i would skip the tacos. Come hungry and order enchiladas or something hearty.

Came here for my birthday dinner w my best friends and we had such a good time. Definitely need to make rsvps especially for dinner time! The decor is so unique, vintage and pretty! Yes, the front entrance appears like a pawn shop for necklaces. Once u enter, there is the bathroom downstairs (ladies restroom serves champagne by the glass!) and coatchecks. Im not sure whats in the ground floor level room but i think its a bar? We were seated upstairs where there was also a bar area with room for dancing.I drank "beauty elixir" pretty much for the whole night. Even got one on the house cos it came late (after the check). We ordered some appetizers and entrees to share. I definitely would recommend the bone marrow, lobster mac n cheese, and the devils cake!We had the steak, tuna w soba noodles (the soba noodles were served cold w a vinegar taste, not quite what im used to but tuna was good!) and lemon chicken.We enjoyed dinner here and i know i'll definitely come back again to try more items! TLDR: Upscale place for tapas at fairly high prices. Reserve in advance. Best dishes are lemon pancakes, grilled cheese dumplings, and short rib huevos rancheros! Overall rating: A-For first timers, here's how you get in: Walk through the pawn shop and head to the big door in the back in the left corner. Open it and head into the secret sanctuary. Dress up a bit. It's pretty fancy in here. It's hard to get a reservation. You need to make it well in advance to get your pick of times. Especially for brunch. I went here for my birthday brunch this year with 3 friends. I made a reservation a month in advance for Saturday at 1:30pm. Make sure you get there on time. They generally can't accommodate late parties. They will hold your table for about 15 minutes. It's beautiful inside. The ladies lounge downstairs includes complimentary prosecco during dinner hours only I think! It wasn't available during brunch. Make sure you bring singles for tip! You don't want to be THAT person! There were mostly women brunching when we went. A lot of them were very dressy. There's a big skylight in the center. They need more air conditioning though. It was pretty warm in there. It was 50 degrees outside that day. They suggest 6-8 small tapas dishes for a party of 4. We got 6 dishes. We were way too full. We will get only 5 dishes next time. We had 3 light eaters and 1 person with a big appetite. Most dishes seem to serve 3 but they'll ask if you want the portions to feed 4 or however big your party is (which means additional charges of course). The service is pretty good. They bring you out a couple dishes at a time. It took us about 2 hours to finish our meal.  The sixth dish took much longer to come out. Make sure you save up. This is a pretty expensive restaurant. Onto the food:-LEMON BLACKBERRY PANCAKES (sweet ricotta cream): Full sized large pancakes! So good and fluffy! Not too sweet. Also served with syrup if you prefer added sweetness. Not much fruit in the pancakes though. I think I just got one blackberry in the center. I'd love a couple more blackberries dispersed throughout the pancakes. We received 4 pancakes. A-GRILLED CHEESE, SMOKED BACON & TOMATO SOUP DUMPLINGS: Imagine a dumpling filled with cheese and topped with bacon crumbles sitting in a big spoon full of thick slightly spicy tomato soup. Perfection!! We received 6 dumplings, which is not easily divisible for 4 people though. A+-BRAISED SHORT RIB 'HUEVOS RANCHEROS'(sunny side up eggs, black beans, cotija): 2 inch wide fried wonton cup filled with  delicious braised short rib, cotija, and each topped with a sunny side up egg. This sits atop a delicious red sauce and black bean puree. Amazing! We received 4. A+-RED VELVET WAFFLES(cream cheese icing): Cute tiny mini waffles. Crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. The cream cheese icing is very sweet. I got this in place of dessert. We received 4. B+-FREE RANGE SCRAMBLED EGGS(smoked salmon, boursin cheese, chives): I hate seafood. This was no exception. I hear cooking smoked fish makes it stink. We received 4. I took a tiny bite and it was horrible! For me, the salmon ruined the dish. F--FRIED CHICKEN BISCUIT BITES (tabasco honey butter, red cabbage slaw): This came out after a long wait. I think the kitchen was backed up from the larger parties. We received 4. They're mini sandwiches. The chicken had too much breading and overall bland. Weird sweet butter. Skip! D-RISE N' SHINEcocktail (stoli vanil, cold brew coffee, coconut milk, vanilla, aztec chocolate bitters): Tastes like a spiked Vietnamese iced coffee! Yum! AI'd definitely come back here for a special occasion. It was really fun! So basic it hurts. Between the carding at the bathroom door (...for obvious reasons) and the ridiculously overpriced and oversalted food, this place just isn't worth it. I get that many people come here because it's "the place to be" but the crowd is just such a turnoff. Portions were resized appropriate for our group but this just meant that everyone way overpaid for what are already very expensive apps and entrees. Additionaly, we were here for a surprise bday party and the hostess(es) told us they couldn't seat us until the full party was here. ...I get that, I really do, but from a customer management point of view, and in light of the fact that it was a surprise bday dinner, they could've at least seated us when the majority of the party was there (which we tried to ask for but were ultimately denied). When we finally got them to seat us with a *gasp* two people (the bday boy and his fiance) still missing, the hostess's exact words were "Ok but you have to order as soon as you sit down."...Um. Screw that. Pass on this place please. It's not worth it. Everything about our trip to Beauty & Essex was a fantastic experience! As mentioned in other reviews, the entrance is low-key, but opens to a beautiful and classy space that really makes you feel like you're in Vegas or somewhere like it. We had a short initial wait (it was me and 5 other girls for a bachelorette party) but we entertained ourselves at the bar while chill but club like beats played in the background.After grabbing a drink to start (and finding out there is a BAR in the bathroom offering complimentary champagne), we were seated. Our waiter, Ryan, was fantastic, fun, and patient. He recommended several tapas sized plates and a round of drinks (I do recommend the Beauty Elixir) and we were not disappointed. My personal favorite was the kale salad (sounds basic - but it was really good), the shrimp, and the fish tacos.We had such a good time, we even went back to the bar area to hang out for a while more after dinner! I came here with high expectations based on recommendations and prior reviews. With that being said, my expectations were almost all met, which is saying a lot. Warning- prices are high! Ambiance:The highlight of the visit here was the ambiance. I was in search for a hip, trendy spot with great food and this place fit the bill perfectly.
