Seems to be one of the rare boba places that uses real high quality matcha.Tons of alternative milks to choose from. One of the only places I've seen oat milk at!!! Wow!! It's pretty tasteless but I feel hip while choosing it, so that's gotta count for something! Now I understand why my sister loves Boba Guys so much...this is some high quality bubble tea! In all my years of drinking bubble tea, I was so impressed with how my drink stood out to me. It doesn't taste generic and heavy like other typical bubble tea chains that are syrupy or/and powdery. My drink tasted very smooth, refreshing and not overly sweet. I tried the Strawberry Matcha Latte with Almond jelly. I loved how subtle and blended the flavors taste when mixed with each other. I definitely recommend putting Almond jelly in your drink - I've never had it anywhere else besides here and it tastes really good. They make it themselves in-house!I would totally come back here to try their other flavors! I also liked their speakers for music... Okay after having this for the first time ever I really think any other bubble tea place is just an utter waste of money...After dinner nearby I came here and got a really unaesthetic jasmine w/almond milk and grass jelly and it was so bitter and tasted so strongly of real green tea that I had to have a friend take a few sips to help me finish it, and then I couldn't fall asleep until 4am...it proved itself to be some good green tea. Grass jelly seems really strong though, I had some trouble sucking it up from the straw haha.My friend got the matchata and they accidentally gave her the bigger size-arbitrage! It looked pretty cool (Instagram it if you want) and tasted good, the horchata mellows out the matcha and it wasn't too sweet. I'll be getting that next time I drop by. A solid four stars for this place! The flavors are all unique and I like having the option to try different flavors each time, but the tea itself here isn't my favorite. I feel like it can sometimes taste a little on the watery side. I tried the classic milk tea the first time I came, and have since tried the matcha, horchata, and other flavors. I usually get mine with 30% (less or least depending on where) sugar and regular ice and tapioca.The actual bubbles are good and chewy but overall for the priciness it's not my favorite spot. I do stop by every time I'm in this area, though!

Easily the best venue I've ever been too. The interiors are gorgeous. There is a beautiful lounge right underneath the main stage where you can grab a drank and people watch while waiting for the show. The actual stage is small enough that you can actually clearly see the artist from most locations. I went there to see kelela and was probably the best concert I've ever been too. Bonus points for cheap and efficient coat check! Some suggestions if it's your 1st time. Wear comfortable shoes. Arrive early. They have a coat check Drinks are overpriced;12. for vodka and cranberry in an 8oz cup. Wear comfortable clothing (dress down)Be prepared to be packed in like sardines. Ladies, leave you big pocket books at home-wear a crossbody bag. Unless you are in the front or are over 6ft 2in be prepared to dodge and weave through everyone's cell phone to see. You enter and go downstairs to the bar early if you arrive early and then closer to showtime you are ushered up 2 flights of stairs to the venue where there is another bar. Not sure how much the upstairs VIP cost but well worth it if you want to sit, be comfortable, eat, drink and enjoy the show. We saw H.E.R..good live performance. This is a cool place. The sound is really good and the space is very big and well-kept. I liked the band we saw, too! There are bars spread throughout so you don't have to keep going up/down stairs for a drink. Drinks are priced pretty averagely - I paid $7 for a can of IPA.The one bartender we encountered was a bit rude, hence the -1 star. No need to be rude! Everyone there is just trying to have fun. I really liked the downstairs part - it's like a lounge area where you can relax before or after a show. I would recommend. I was very confused walking into Bowery Ballroom. We went downstairs to the bar area, thinking it was where the stage was. We had heard that the place is very small, and there was a large curtain in the back of the room, where people seemed to be clumping. We turned out to be wrong. The stage is on the street level, and this is a sort of holding area. It was a little strange, but it all made sense when they opened the doors to the main floor. The place is set up very much like Irving Plaza, but half the size. The sound system was a little screwy when we were there, for Neon Trees. Blame the venue or blame the band's mic guy (as Tyler Glenn Did), but the bass was too loud so the guitars weren't coming through. The mic also was in and out for a few songs, which was disappointing. Overall a very cool venue that hopefully was just having an off-night sound-wise. If you're into jamming to some smaller bands and musicians then you've probably found yourself all over NYC in a various assortment of venues. Not all offer the same experience and some can just be claustrophobic (I'm talking to you, Irving). A tinier location totally worthy of the trip downtown? Bowery Ballroom. Let's get to rockin'.My second time here came a couple weekends ago along with my girlfriend. We were here the first time for one of my favorite little indie bands and this second go around was for one of hers. She said it first in how much she enjoyed Bowery's set up, and when I stopped to mull it over, she was right! (A win for the GF is always a plus). There were definitely more people waiting to enter this time around, though once inside BB, things spaced out nicely. Let me just be sure to explain that the Bowery isn't going to win any award for size or space, but the way the place is laid out just works so well for a smaller venue. You'll start by heading down into the comfy lounge area. Here there are plenty of tables to sit and chill, a bar to grab a drink (come early and you'll hit happy hour), and a coat check with a clever sign reminder (see pic). This area is something truly not found at many venues, at least not to a regular ticket holder. Once the doors are opened for the stage floor, you can keep on lounging or head on  upstairs to check out your soon-to-be concert experience. With multiple entry points, this not so large area keeps traffic at a minimum with fabulous flow of peeps. You'll find a tiny bar in the back of the space and some stairs on both sides with minimal table seating overlooking the stage. It's got a classy, casual, and comfortable feel going on. When the show finally starts, the venue explodes in light and sound while still keeping things pretty darn intimate. I never felt like a sardine, and was able to get some pretty stellar pics and vids throughout. After the final note is played, a getaway is simple (gotta love those multiple stairways!). Not to be forgotten is the staff. They're kind and friendly from start to finish (a nice touch at a musical spot) and truly helps to cap off a joyous night of Bowery-ness.Overall, Bowery Ballroom might not be spatially bigger than many venues, but their set up, personable staff, and ability to carry out a memorable experience, makes this a spot I'll be returning to with excitement any time I have a reason. Rock on, Bowery! Loved it here! I go to concerts fairly often, so it's hard to believe that I only visited for the first time recently. In any case, I'm already planning my next trip back.The best part about Bowery is the layout. It's definitely not a super teeny venue, but it's not nearly as large as most other NYC venues which makes for an intimate concert experience. You can get a good view of the stage from any part of the pit, even if you are far back. And if you aren't feeling the pit you can always head to the second level and chill on one of the side balconies. Both levels have bars too.They book some pretty big names that you wouldn't expect to see in a venue this size. But because of that, tickets do tend to sell out. I'd suggest signing up for their mailing list, or going straight to the box office to snag tickets.Getting to and from the venue is a breeze because it's right outside of the path. And because the venue is fairly small you won't have to wait too long for the bathroom or the bar. I'd venture back to Bowery Ballroom without hesitation if a band I like was on the schedule! It's been years since I would trek into the city for show after show, month after month, but the memories I've got like it was just yesterday.From the knitting factory and the smaller mercury lounge, the Bowery was just one of those great bigger but somehow intimate spots to see a show.  All the mosh pits and crowd surfing, blood and sweat this place has seen.   You can feel it when you walk downstairs.All the alcohol and cocaine too...Anyway, the Bowery is an awesome venue.The end I usually like to tell a long story when I write a review, because if you're not being entertaining, then what are you being? But this one's shorter, because the reason I'm giving 5 stars here is simple: at a show I went to, there was a ticketing mixup, and the person working the ticket stand that night was beyond patient with us as we sorted everything. She didn't have to be--lord knows ticket desk folks aren't often patient like that--but she was, and at the end of it all, when we ultimately did manage to get into the show, she even wished me a happy birthday. I have no memory of showing her my ID or anything. It was pretty wild. So thanks, Bowery Ballroom, for working with an eager showgoer and being easy as hell about what was a pretty frustrating issue on our end. Highly unorganized event planning mixed with false bar promises could equal disaster so once I got over the fact that my ticket was never checked nor was my ID read for my bracelet...I got weird vibes and felt cheated. Thank deity the ballroom has wonderful acoustics. I used the balcony to avoid moshing and was happy I did. Add more bathrooms !! Loved my concert and will be back. Someone will scan my ticket next time !!! Rude doormen, pricy drinks and they blasted the heat so much.. it was very hot, almost ruined my experience.  Show was good though, and tickets were cheap. It's pretty rare to see a music venue get such a great review average, mostly due to the fact that if you're in one, you're likely to be in crowds, around drunk annoying people, possibly mean bouncers, and you probably paid a lot of money. Somehow Bowery Ballroom managed to remove all of the usual annoyances of seeing live music! The space is really well kept and beautiful in parts - I loved the big window behind the upstairs balcony bar. Very classy! It wasn't super easy to get a drink at the downstairs bar and it did get pretty warm and stuffy in there at times, but it was much better in the main room. The show I saw was well populated but the main room never felt annoyingly crowded. The sound was great and it was easy to see the stage, even for a shortie like me. Between set the band members all hung out casually in the stairwell near the merch or in the downstairs bar area. The whole night was really casual, unpretentious, and approachable even for someone who has never been there before! To top off a great show and a good night, I was thrilled to be able to stumble directly into the subway station right outside the door and zoom home easily. I'll absolutely come back to Bowery Ballroom next time a band I like is playing! Came to see one of my favorite bands, Honne, on a Friday night. I consider myself somewhat of a concert junkie, especially as of late, and this was actually my first time at Bowery Ballroom. When you enter, they check your ID, and you're led downstairs to the middle area with a horseshoe-shaped fully-stocked bar, with the actual concert hall, up the opposite staircase. The openers were playing in the hall upstairs, and we decided to get some drinks before going upstairs.Drinks at the bar were about $7, which ain't too bad, but to get people to stay after shows, they hold a happy hour, where all drinks are $2 off. Not a bad idea to keep people there, although by the end of the show, we were actually already properly in the right state of inebriation. The downstairs bar accepts credit cards, but the bar upstairs only accepts cash. $20 credit card minimum, so I recommend having one person buy the drinks, and then use Venmo. Service at the bar was pretty decent, and as previously mentioned, we managed to get a bunch of good drinks before Honne went on at 10pm.Acoustics were great, and Honne, per usual, killed it. The lighting is nice, and while there were a lot of people packed into the concert hall, it never felt overly crowded. You're always going to get the drunk patrons who kick and move around too much, but we thankfully managed to avoid them for the most part. Restrooms weren't too crowded after the show, which was very surprising to me. Would definitely see a show here again. They have some really good up-and-coming artists in their lineups, and the prices for tickets aren't too bad. Was really mad that I didn't know Bag Raiders was playing there the next night, so I'll actually have to follow their upcoming show listings. Probably one of my favorite concert venues in NYC. It's small enough that everyone has a good spot in the house, no barricade between you and the stage, but he best part of it is that General Admission includes your pick at the small tables on the 2nd floor that overlook the stage, that is, if you are there early enough! Had a great experience here watching San Fermin on December 19.What a great place to see a show.  Love the layout and feel of this place. $6-7 for beer. Excellent venue! I have been to Bowery Ballroom a handful of times. I went this week to see the ber talented, gothic, metal, electronic Davin Lynch-esque siren Chelsea Wolfe! I thought the venue was a perfect intimate space for the show. She had been at the Music Hall of Williamsburg the night before and I found this space to be a lot smaller and you could really get a good view from most angels. I came in early with cash in hand. I didn't feel like paying any stinky online fees for a day of ticket. She was recently in town and completely sold out. I was hoping this would would mean tickets available. And that they were. I took the M down to Essex and moseyed over. Showed my id for a 21 and over bracelet and then bought a ticket. Once you go in the only re-entry is for the smokers and through a different door. You enter through the bar downstairs. It's comfy down there with some couches and group seating. There's a small wrap around bar with two bartenders.I popped around the neighborhood for a slice and a quick beer before entering the show. And when I returned I made a b line to  the merch like a good little concert attendee. Wow!! Not only is Chelsea Wolfe amazing but the merch was all drool worthy from pins to totes to tees. I wanted it all. And who happens to be there but none other than Wolfe herself and Damien Echols from the the West Memphis Three . If you haven't watched the HBO series it's a must. It is not a band name....There's was so much energy in that moment. I got my tee shirt then grabbed a beer and then easily found a spot for the opening band, A Dead Forest Index then between sets people hit the bathrooms downstairs, got new drinks and ran outside for their cancers sticks. Shortly after 10 the fog machine got going. The flashlight helped the band get in position and it began....like thunder. The show was incredible from start to finish. No one talked and no one pushed. Everyone was in awe. If you have not seen Wolfe live, I would highly recommend her! And the lighting at the venue elevated the experience. The sound was fantastic and u could hear the rattling of the instrument cases at the corner of my ear. Until next time my beautiful siren! The Bowery Ballroom is a sweet venue to see bands and music acts. It's a smaller, more intimate space - from the bar/lounge area downstairs to the upstairs performance area and all the nooks and hangout spots in between. The acoustics are good here. The sound people know what they are doing. Plus, one thing that's great about the venue is that you can - depending on the act - also hear from the downstairs lounge. So, one thing that I like to do is, if I'm not really into the opening act, I can hang out in the lounge and still hear what's going on. If it catches my attention and sounds good, I can head on up. If it's meh, I can just stay where I am and hang out until the main act. The Bowery is very chill and that's the kind of atmosphere that I like when seeing a show. Also, and I kept a note to remind myself to mention this whenever I got to writing a review, the Security do a good job here. Aside from the security at the door, I never thought about security inside until it mattered. A few months ago, this dude started a fight with my boyfriend and security appeared out of no where and handled the situation really well. While I was prepared for fisticuffs, I'm glad that Security had things on lock so that everyone could still enjoy the evening. Lastly, it's so easy to get here by subway (your options are J/Z at Bowery, B/D at Grand, or F at Delancy - all are within walking distance). You can't go wrong with seeing a show at Bowery Ballroom! Went to watch the Revivalists last night as my boss had a lot of tickets and the son of one of the partners at our law firm is in the band. The venue is nice but it was REALLY crowded and the bar is tiny on the main stage floor (second). The bartenders were all nice and there were A LOT of drunk people and people were stepping all over my foot. I was dying to get out of there and was glad I did, but to be completely fair - the venue itself is nice. I'm in love with this venue! A friend pulled some strings and got us VIP tix to Marina & the Diamonds for the first show on her new tour. Even if you're not in the VIP section, though, the venue is so intimate that there really isn't a bad place to stand. Unless you want to be way up front, I would actually recommend skipping the wait in line outside -- it's a pretty creepy sidewalk/construction area -- and arrive closer to the start time. The staff is very nice, and the acoustics are good. I'd love to return for another show sometime! The Bowery is unlike any venue I've ever been to!Went here to see "The-Dream" who is a pretty A-list artist and I was surprised to find that he was performing at a place like this for such a great price. So of course I was skeptical...But fear not! The space was intimate and surprisingly it was sold out but I wasn't packed in on top of other people and I could actually leave my spot and run to the bathroom and not have to elbow my way back to the front.Coat check was a quick and easy since I arrived about 30 mins early or so and then the boo & I were able to chill out at the downstairs bar area until show time. The upstairs bar is CASH only, the downstairs bar is $20 min for cards. Downstairs is dimly light with a few spots for seating at the bar and small table sections on the sides and the concert space is upstairs. Also, the bathrooms were well kept, which is a big deal at concerts/bars. The sound system was amazinggg, and I had a great stress-free time and I'd definitely return. This is a nicely kept venue, it is not dingy. There is a bar up in the balcony for people to chill.

Cafe Habana was such a gem! It was a cute little cafe and the food was amazing!  I had a plate with grilled chicken, tostones, and the spicy spinach. I also ordered a cafe con leche that came in a milkshake glass. Everything was delicious.I didn't have to wait for a table during lunch time on a Monday, but I bet weekends are packed because the space is small. Our waitress was very friendly. The price was very reasonable, especially since the plates came with a lot of food.I will definitely be returning! It doesn't hurt that it's near great shopping in Soho! Came to this spot after hearing everyone rave about it. And it is pretty good. I got the chicken tortilla soup-it has no chicken in it. It's all chunks of cheese which was misleading..but whatever that's cool. Had other dishes. Weren't quite memorable. Definitely get that corn!!!!! I plan to go back to the shop right next to get the corn to go lol it's so good! But definitely you should floss afterwards, lol Best high-end Cuban sandwich in the Northeast.I was heartbroken when Chez Henri in Cambridge, MA shut its doors in 2013, as the Northeast was cut off from its supply of chichi Cuban sandwiches.  Fear no more, as the Cuban sandwich at Cafe Habana may be just as good!To be fair, the sandwich does stretch the rules of a Cuban sandwich just a bit, as marinated shredded pork (amazing) replaces the canonical sliced roasted pork.  Toasted bread crunches thunderously, giving way to an explosion of sweet-salty flavor; beware of dripping juices at the back of the sandwich.  Mustard notes are pretty light - pretty interesting that Cafe Habana offers Grey Poupon instead of the standard yellow stuff.Mexican corn two-pack is a must-try.  The mole, while pretty reasonable, is an afterthought in comparison. I can't believe I have never been here till now. I am not particularly fond of cuban/Mexican food though I was craving some corn tonight so I suggested to a friend. It was fairly empty as we were early and the food came quickly. I KNOW WHY PEOPLE GET THE CORN. It was done so well even as a person who's not completely into corn was like I can have another one. I asked them to have the chilli powder on the side as I do not eat spicy but man that corn... We also had the grilled shrimp taco and it was good. I am always worry about it being overcooked but it was done right.I would come back for the corn any day. I recently caught the cuban/latin food bug after my trip to Miami. Cafe Habana is a rather small restaurant with no obvious signage of the establishment's name. Cafe Habana is located on the corner of the block. I ordered the two most popular items on the menu: the corn and the cuban sandwich. I very much enjoyed the corn- I wish it wasn't as pricey as it was, as I wanted to order more. The cuban sandwich was pretty solid- the pork was moist and flavorful. I was pretty content with my food and restaurant selection. It's a solid choice if you want a really good cuban sandwich. East coast Cuban food is always better than west coast. I must agree! When we were in NYC, we made a trip to Cafe Habana in SoHo for their mind blowing Cuban sandwich and Elote corn. For those of you unfamiliar with the Cubano, let me explain: it's ham, pickles, mustard, swiss cheese and roasted pork (yes, twice the pig!) on Cuban bread and then pressed so that the bread toasts and the cheese melts. Elote is Mexican street corn roasted over an open grill and coated withsalt, cayenne powder, butter, Cotija cheese, lime and mayo.These 2 delicacies are my favorites and I've been here many times. I'll always come back and order the same items because they're so delicious and they'll never mess it up. Service was great and quick. Love this place! 3 for okay food.3 for okay service.3 for okay ambiance. 3 for okay environment.5 for the best elote-- Mexican corn !I've been coming to this restaurant since 2008, so I've seen it evolved into an expensive tourist attraction whose prices skyrocketed for what the meal is worth. In 2008 I probably would've given this place a 5; it was novel, it was hip, but most importantly it was affordable.As someone who loves good food to be accessible, I was surprised to see how much the prices have changed. The corn/elote was $10 for 2 pieces of corn. Wow. Wow. Sunset Park and East Harlem have very good Mexican restaurants that you can go and get great elote at for $5. This restaurant is capitalizing on its neighborhood. That's fine. I just won't be coming back.I had the avocado and cheese torta. Avocado  is typically always good-- $13.95 worthy? Definitely NAH. The highlight of it was the chipotle mayo sauce. I would suggest that it goes with the sandwich as a dip, so I can dip my french fries in it too. French fries were okay, nothing spectacular. I've also had the Huevos Rancheros and they're a 3.5/5 <U+200D> because they're pretty basic and standard. There's nothing incredibly special about them. And the red sauce isn't amazing & it should be the major highlight of the dish, but it's OK. Just okay.I used to rave about this place, But after being back, I wonder if I was just a young person in New York who was excited to eat something new and it became my spot and go to place because there were so many people talking about it. It was all the rage. After coming here for about 10 years, it's just OK. It's a solid meal. But it's not worth the money. There are too many other Cuban restaurants in New York City that I could get a good meal for the same price for, so hasta luego! Renee eats Cuban Cute little place on prince street. Has a diner feel to it with cute decorations. Came here for late weekday lunch so the place wasn't crowded, which is not surprising. Seated immediately and orders were taken immediately, service was very quick. Waitress was friendly enough but seemed like she was just there to do her job. I ordered the Cuban sandwich which was written to be the "Best in NYC". It did not disappoint. Pressed to perfection, definitely did not skimp on the pork. The chipotle mayo was a good touch and a perfect amount. The ham and cheese were also delicious (personally I thought it could've had more cheese). The fries were also amazing, thick cut like I like them and not burnt. Overall a great experience and would return again! Honestly, came by this spot bc Egg Shop had over an hour wait. Sad times. So the eggy wants was strong. And I don't eat meat, soo let's straight with those two caveats. Sunday brunch at 11:30am is a tough time to get seated, but not here. It was great. Except that the seats were REALLY cramped. We had a group of four, and one chair literally flowed into the bathroom area - making for a very awkward seating arrangement. Service was also limited. I saw the waitresses running around and giving at least two tables the incorrect orders. Feels a bit understaffed, but they got a majority of our order correct. Except the side of bacon my friend got. Didn't come til we were already done eating everything else. For the main entree, I ordered the Huevous a la Mexicana (veggie egg scramble) which came with home fries. And we got the corn to share for the group. Let's talk about this corn. Bc it was everything and then some. It's the messiest most delish thing you're gonna have in this joint! Okay, but back to the scramble. It's just not my jam. The eggs scrambled w the veggies this way tastes over cooked. And it's completely under seasoned. This is one of those times when I'm like okay, it's not my restaurant bc I don't eat meat. But I should've gotten the fish tacos. Welp, if I ever come back that's what I'll do. I def would never come back here craving any sort of egg breakfast sitch. But for the corn alone, maybe. 3 stars. This is a go-to brunch spot or for any matter, a go-to food spot!! So great for casual dining with friends.Food:Diverse menu with good vegetarian options and good prices. I've had the tacos al pastor and chorizo con papas, both which were tasty, flavorful and filling. My friend constantly gets the torta de queso blanco y aguacate, which is vegetarian. They make a bomb iced cafe con leche here as well!! Service:Fast and friendly service for a place that's often crowded. Ambiance:It's hip, colorful and inviting. A bit diner style. They keep the windows open on nice days and I love that. On a great corner location right in Nolita so the surroundings are always bursting with energy.Etc:My only complaint is that 1)the wait can get long because it's popular 2)there's a gap between brunch and dinner where they close up to prepare for the transition!! Their Cuban sandwich is amazing. So tasty and fresh. I love how chill the restaurant is during the weekday. We sat at the counter and ate our hearts away. We ordered the steak, the Cuban and the corn (gotta have the corn), and many delicious drinks. It was such a filling and satisfying lunch we didn't even want dinner. But all so worth it. A group of us are driving in New York to a wedding. My friend was almost-drooling as she talked about how amazing Cafe Habana is. I think she talked about Cafe Habana for 20 minutes straight. I thought to myself - I have to try this place! This was 3 years ago. Since then, I have been to Cafe Habana countless times for lunch, dinners, or stop by just to eat their delicious Mexican corn. Cafe Habana is known for their Cuban sandwiches, and grilled Mexican corn.Their Cuban sandwiches are juicy savory slices of roasted pork, stuffed with ham and swiss cheese. It is heavenly. The grilled corn is blackened sweet corn-on-the-cob rolled in mayo, cotija cheese and sprinkled with chili powder and lime. Their caipirinhas are strong. This is one of the best places to have a dinner in the Soho area. Be prepared to wait for the diner portion. Omg! If you're in the city this is a must!! Cuban sandwich and elotes!! That's all you need to know!! This place is okay borderline 3 stars. I'm not a huge fan of diner looking places, but since this place has almost 3K reviews, I thought I'd try it. The prices online and on site are different. One of the server was singing and dancing, which liven the place up a little. The service was good though. My bf had the chorizo con papas, which he said was great. He thinks this is one of the top 5 brunch places. Huevos Rancheros ($12)- 2/5 The online place says this plate was $6.95 but at the actual place it's like $12. Definitely not worth it in my opinion. Everything was very 'wet' and soggy. I didn't even touch the home fries. I didn't even know there was corn tortillas because it was all soggy under the eggs. Grilled Corn Mexican Style- 4/5 This was pretty good, but also a bit messy. Good thing they give you toothpicks with it! They didn't add too much mayo, and had a good amount of cheese and spice on it to give it a slight kick. The place is super small and looks like it would have a massive line during big hours. We split the Mexican style corn and Baha Fish Tacos. The corn was awesome and messy and the tacos were quite good. There is not a lot of room in the place or on the table. A great tiny place with good, simple, and honest food. Well worth the tight space. Very very good food and I definitely want to continue coming here. Seating is a little hard here and it can get stuffy but their cuban sandwich is WORTH IT. It's quite filling and I actually shared one with a friend. Perfectly toasted bread with melted cheese...a hearty, warmness in each bite!Seems like I missed out on the corn though - come to California please! Passed by here all the time and finally decided stop in today and try the food. I've seen a few sites and publications that they had the best Cuban sandwich in NYC and decided to see for myself. We got seated and ordered, food came within 15 minutes which was extremely fast! The sandwiches were pretty thick, bread was the toasted the right duration so crispiness was great. The sandwich itself was phenomenal. There was a generous amount of pork and the ham were both very juicy. The fries were hand cut and slightly crispy. Sandwich was very filling and well worth the $15. I would venture back here next time as I heard the grilled corn is suppose to be superb as well. My friends and I were shopping in Soho and decided to eat dinner here on a whim. The place is like a tiny diner, which I thought was so cute! Our waiter was really nice and did a great job of checking up on us despite how busy the restaurant was. I honestly don't remember the name of what I ordered and I didn't see it on the PDF version of the menu, but I remember it being some sort of delicious meat in a mole sauce (maybe chorizo?) with a side of rice and beans. It really hit the spot, and it was at a great price too!  I definitely would not be opposed to coming here again. Another "must visit" spot on my NYC Foodie list. I came here several years ago when visiting a friend in NYC for NYE and to this day I have NOT found a better Cuban sandwich or grilled street corn. So naturally, on my most recent trip to NYC, I made my way to Cafe Habana for lunch. With a constant flow of customers and the quaintest corner spot on Prince Street, I knew I had returned. I grabbed a spot at the counter and my tastebuds began to dance. Of course I started with an order of grilled street corn: mayonnaise slathered over grilled corn and coated with queso fresco and chili powder. YUM. YUM. YUM. One order comes with two ears of corn ($9) and I proudly ate both. As much as I wanted to stray from my typical order of a Cuban sandwich to try their brunch menu, I couldn't resist temptation. The Cuban came out the classic masterpiece that it is... thick, crunchy bread to support the perfectly seasoned, melt-in-your-mouth pork ... all coated in cheese and mustard and pickles and ham. Ladies and gentleman, you won't find a better Cuban anywhere. Even in Cuba (pure speculation). So if you've never experienced Cafe Habana, you don't know what you're missing.

What a pleasant surprise to find this place! We ordered mostly vegetarian dishes, and it was best vegetarian food I've ever had. Each dish was savory and rich with the flavors of the vegetable ingrediants, and the dishes had variations on the distinct regional spicy-sweet flavor. We ordered one dish per person, and shared the dishes and rice family style. A friend who spent a part of his life in the Tibet region said that the food really tastes like home (although a bit less spicy than the food he had in Tibet--I found the spice level to be medium and perfect). Service was quick as well.The smoothies are great, and pair nicely with the spicy food. Chili Dofu (tofu dish) and Tsel Shesha (mushroom dish) were my favorite entrees--so rich in flavor. The rice pudding for dessert was better than any rice pudding I've previously had--perfect consistency and not too sweet, with raisins and bits of fruit on top. It's a tiny restaurant in lower east side and you can get very cheap food here. We wanted to try both Tsel Momo(vegi momo) and Shogok momo (potato & herb). They said they can give us mixed one which was nice. So we got 4 pieces of each. I liked Vegi momo more because the flavor was better than potato momo. It was a good choices. We also had Tsel Gyathak Ngopa (sauted noodles with vegetables and tofu) and it was just okay for me. I just didn't like the flavor because it was new for me. Maybe I would like more next time. It's a small restaurant but it's pretty popular. We came here around 2 and the tables were almost full. I recommend Tsel Momo (vegetable momo)! I will come back here to try new food! I went to Cafe Himalaya for lunch this past weekend.  It is a small place where you seat yourself.  Very no frills.We were very torn between which momos to get, and also if we wanted Thukpa (a noodle soup), Tsel Gyathuk Ngopa (sauteed noodles) or Tsel Gyathuk Takpa (pan fried noodles).  The waitress was extremely helpful and gave great service.  We were torn between Tsel Momo and Shogok Momo Takpa, and she let us have half of each, which was great. And she explained to us that the sautees noodles were coated in sauced while the pan fried were not.We ended up going with the half and half momo and with the sauteed Tsel Gyathuk Ngopa.  The noodles were really tasty.  They had an unusual flavor that I liked.  The momo were not the best I've ever had, but they were solid.  I wished the potatoes in the Shogok Momo Takpa had a bit more chunkiness or texture to it. The flavor was good, but a bit too mushy for me.  The Tsel Momo was definitely the best.And the prices were very reasonable as well.  For the two dishes we spent under $20.00, which is a great deal for New York City. I don't know if I'd go back unless I was in the area.  Jackson Heights still has the best Himalayan food, but Cafe Himalaya makes a great meal! Cafe Himalaya is an amazing find in the East Village.  The small cozy restaurant is perfect for a quick, cheap, and delicious meal. Their soups are perfect for the winter time with my favorites being the Thang (tofu, noodles, ginger, and tomato's) or if your prefer meat the Chasha Thang. A must try are their Sha Momo dumplings. They come steamed or fried and packed with meat. All in all Cafe Himalaya is a perfect place if you're looking for a quick meal at a very affordable price. While it can get crowded, the service is very fast and you won't be waiting long. What you need to know: - there are only 28 seats for this tiny restaurant and it gets crowded after 6:30pm - accepts credit cards, but only one per table - an excellent choice for vegetarians (and meat eaters!) - menu has extensive vegetarian options - this tiny restaurant gets EXTREMELY loud, we were literally screaming to one another across the table - BYOB What we ordered: - Avocado Salad price $5.75 - do yourself a favor and GET THIS!!!!! Himalayan style spiced and seasoned potato and avocado in lemon dressing.  My eating companion said these spices sang in her mouth and is seasoned perfectly.  A seemingly simple dish but is absolutely fantastic! The spices are not hot spicy but gives your mouth an explosion of flavor. This remains our favorite dish! - Tsel Phing $9.99 - bean thread noodles sauteed with spinach, cabbage, carrots, peas and comes with one paratha bread.  The noodles and the veggies were cooked well and was filling, even though the portions are not too large. It is even better with the spicy red sauce they provide! - Tsel Shesha $9.99 - sauteed mushroom, broccoli, zucchini, carrots and spinach - comes with a bowl of basmati rice.  The veggies were cooked well (not too crunchy or mushy) and was more savory than spicy. Before I start, this is my first review (and I promise I am not a fake). I use yelp religiously to figure out what and where to eat, so after finding a few great places I've decided it's time to "give" back. It's just a typical boring Tuesday night and I needed dinner. I've been attempting to try new things & stumbled upon Cafe Himalaya. The reviews and pictures seemed enticing. I took a deep breath, and submitted my order. Less than an half hour later, the food arrived. I ordered the Sha Momos (pan fried beef dumplings) and Tsel gyathuk Ngopa (veggie and tofu sauted noodles). Both dishes were delicious. The momos were juicy & tasted fresh (the cabbage salad was a nice addition as well). The noodles weren't greasy, they were nice and chewy. I wish there were more hearty veggies (I woulda killed for broccoli) but they were still very filling. The hot sauce was also very tasty (I'm not big on spicy, but a few drops added great flavor). I won't say I was blown away, but being in the east village and living in fear of bad, dirty, greasy Chinese / Thai / Japanese Food this place really will stay at the top of my list for when I want some dumplings and noodles. #12. Tsel Momo (Steamed) 5/5These guys are a little on the bland side but totally amped up by the red sauce served on the side (looks spicy but it's not that spicy. Use it liberally Mix it with the soy sauce get crazy wid it) #19 Chili Dofu (5/5)Perfect amount of spice. Great amount of veggies piled on there. Don't fear the oily, embrace the oily, get extra rice for that oily#17 Tsel Gyathuk Takpa (5/5)Not vegan oops they use egg noodle. Small place though, just bring 1 trusty eating companion here A-ok defines this place pretty well.  This is definitely a "blink and you'll miss it" kind of place since it's tucked away on 1st St with inconspicuous signage.  We stumbled upon this place and just had to try.  We ordered the Gyathuk Ngopa, Chasha Shamdey, and Paratha to share.  I'll start by saying the portions here are on the smaller side.  The noodles were definitely a regular sized portion but the curry and paratha were both barely enough for one person!  However, the prices are very reasonable and the service is quick, so if you're still hungry, it won't break the bank.  In addition to the smaller portions, the flavor was just not present.  Thinking back on this meal, I can't remember any identifiable flavor except grease.  Am I mad I tried this spot?  No.  Would I go back again?  Probably never. This place is a gem. Great, fresh food and great prices! Cafe Himalaya is super vegetarian friendly, however they also have non veg dishes here. I just want to say though, I have had tofu in every way, shape, and form throughout my life and have disliked it until I had CH's Spicy Tofu. It's my favorite! I like it with their version of a Paratha. Also, $4 glasses of wine here make me very very happy :) i'm bettin' u ain't had Tibetan...hello Dalai!small dining room. very casual and simple. small tables. stripped down decor. perfect for solo eating or very casual meals.the dishes are balanced between vegetarian dishes and non-vegetarian dishes.the offerings range from soup to salad to noodle to rice entrees. the food has a good amount of spices and spiciness without being overpowering.PRO TIP: the lunch special is fairly generous amount of food for $7.50. served noon to 4pm.the pan-fried dumplings are quite tasty whether you get vegetarian or meaty ones. the dishes are like a cross between chinese/indian without the greasy or curry elements. the food is comforting yet has very simple elements. i prefer the sauteed/pan-fried noodle dishes here to the rice dishes. i really like the vegetarian ones like the Tsel Gyathuk Ngopa. there's a nice selection of fruit smoothies to choose from in terms of beverages--all under $5.drops mic for some comfy eatsi outzz One of the best fusion restaurants, the food speaks volumes of the Asian/Nepalese flavors. From spicy pan fried potato dumplings( No.13) to vegetarian noodles (no.16), this place has all the bearings to become a cult favorite. Drinks were surprisingly cheap (Merlot $4), then again it is not an ideal location and the street has a desolated vibe. But hey, taste matters.If you have a low threshold to spice, ask them for recommendations. And please if you order a take out, be careful as it will probably leak. In our case it was the noodles!, the oil completely drained and thankfully inside the bag. I came here on a Saturday night before a night out with my girlfriend. I decided on Himalayan/Nepalese because it had been quite some time since I had had it, and my girlfriend never had. We arrived around a bit past 18:30 and thankfully found a few tables open, at which point we got the table next to the window for people watching. Why people will get at the end of a 30+ person-deep line at a pizzeria is beyond me; maybe they just really like pizza. The ambience consists of a moderate light level, not dim to the point you have trouble seeing, not bright to the point it stings, the tables and chairs don't feel like they're made out of particleboard, and there are some assorted framed photos from the Nepal / Himalayan region on the walls. When Karen L. says this place gets loud, she was not kidding, so if you want a quiet dining experience, look elsewhere.Anyway, the waiter spoke English just fine, so if you are new to this kind of food, you should not have the problem with some restaurants like this where the waiter speaks maybe three words of English, and God help you if you ask for recommendations or any type of question. I ordered the Shapta (#41), choosing the rice because I was hungry and apparently its portion size is bigger than the paratha option, which the waiter said was the more traditional option, and my girlfriend got the Gyathuk Ngopa (#29). Upon the food's arrival, we were not disappointed.My Shapta was mildly spicy, not bland, nor was it spicy to the point it makes you sweat, which I love and routinely eat. I thoroughly enjoyed it, really savoring the generous beef portions and the ample ginger in the sauce. My girlfriend is the antithesis regarding my love of spicy food, we forgot to specify to go easy on the spices for her Gyathuk Ngopa, but she was able to enjoy it without issue. It came with a little serving dish of a red sauce that was moderately spicy and extremely heavy on the cilantro. It went quite well on my rice.Random comments; they take credit cards (Visa and Mastercard if I heard the waiter correctly), which a lot of small Asian restaurants don't, there is a single restroom in the basement, the Yelp prices reflect the actual menu prices, which is a huge pet peeve of mine when they are inaccurate, and when descending the stairs, you had better pay attention to that "Watch Your Head" sign, because unless you're 5' tall, you will smash your head against the ceiling towards the bottom of the stairs if you don't duck.In summation, if you want something other than overpriced bar food or pizza and you are in the Houston St. area, I highly recommend this place. In following tradition of trying different foods each week, my friends and I decided to try out Tibetan food. We were not sure what to expect but have heard good things about this place. The place itself is easy to miss and to be honest it does look a bit dingy from the outside. Inside the place is pretty small, but we got there just as some of the customers were leaving so we did not have to wait for seats. The people working were extremely nice and friendly. The menu is split up with a section for vegetarian dishes and another for dishes with meat. None of us are vegetarian so we went straight for the meat dishes. There were quite a lot of options for meat dishes which was great for us. Food wise: -Gyathuk Takpa with beef: The noodles were wonderfully flavored and was delicious. The only compliant I have about this dish is that since the noodles are fried it was a bit hard to eat it since they were not malleable. However, the fried noodles were crispy which I also really liked. -Gyathuk Ngopa: This dished used the same type of noodle as Gyathuk Takpa but the noodles were not fried, making them a lot easier to eat as well. All my friends that got shrimp said it was delicious so def. try it out! -Chasha Shamdey: I got to try a bit of this curry and it is pretty good, not really spicy but pretty flavorful.  -Paratha: This is def. a must get, it is super fluffy and so good especially with the curry. -Mango Lassi: This was super yummy and creamy!! Trying new types of food has always been a hit or miss but this place is def. a hit! Forgettable Asian food. Came in at 530 pm on a Wednesday , place started to slowly fill up by 7.  Avocado and potato salad was a tasty appetizer . The main dishes were disappointing - chili chicken was chewy and bland.  From the time we received our dishes to finishing them , the waitress did not come over again and left us with dirty plates for probably 30 minutes.  The price point is great but with the quality of food and chilly service I would not return. Love this place. Good is good and cheap. My friend brought me here a few years ago and every time we came the food is pretty consistent. I was pretty sad when I thought they had closed out, but they haven't. Can't wait to go back. Very solid restaurant offering a wide range of vegetarian and non vegetarian options. We had the vegetarian pan fried noodles and it was great - super crispy with the vegetables and tofu bringing a lot of flavor on the top of the noodles. The other choice was a traditional vegetarian curry that was good but not quite remarkable. By the way it looked I guessed there was a lot of seasoning going on there but it tasted a little flat. We also had pan fried dumplings with potatoes and beef - those were really good, way above average especially because they manage to make the crust very crunchy. Prices are very decent and the service is good and fast. I LOVE THIS PLACE. Small but AMAZING food! I have been going there for over ten years and haven't found Tibetan/Nepalese food like it anywhere else. Came here during the month of Saka Dawa, meaning it was vegetarian only. As a big lover of meat, admittedly, I was a bit sceptical.To start, we had the Momos, which are little vegetable dumplings that come with various chutneys and dips. These were pretty good, and have a vegetable samosa kind of vibe.We had the crispy chilli tofu which had great flavour, and a good amount of spice. The paratha bread was also the best paratha bread I've ever had. The main attraction for this place is that it's really cheap. You can easily get a substantial meal for two for $30!Will definitely be back, when its not Saka Dawa, so i can get myself some MEAT! Such a casual, afterwork dinner spot. Chill date spot, after shopping around the neighborhood spot. Really this place is good for almost any occasion. Just don't come in expecting a 5 star, super fancy, quick service restaurant. This place is perfect for what it is, just stumble in and you won't regret it. Came here with a friend after work and the space is small which I don't really mind. Once we were seated we were both comfortable. They were pretty busy on a Friday night so it did take what felt like over 15 mins before our orders were taken. Ordered the steamed beef dumplings and the chili chicken, both were delicious. The chili chicken wasn't overly spicy and well seasoned, full of flavor. Portion was great af most of all the prices were so cheap! To be located in the east village business must be booming with those cheap prices! My bill was about 22 dollars for both the chili chicken and dumplings before tipping. Definitely plan on coming here again to try out some of their other menu items. I had the Sha Momo beef dumplings to go. Overall they were juicy and savory. It could have used some sauce / condiments, but it was meaty and delicious. The dumplings are big, but you will probably want an appetizer or side dish for a full meal. Worth a try if you need a casual meal and you are in the area. I would try the vegetarian dumplings next time.

Cafe Katja was awesome! Loved the ambiance and the manager (I think?) or server was super helpful.My brother ordered the berner wrstel, which he loved. My parents shared a sausage sampler, which they enjoyed, but they aren't huge sausage people to begin with, so their favorite part was the cheese dumplings. Also, that's just a lot of meat. I ordered the hummus and ratatouille which is vegan (no substitutions or changes necessary)! It was wonderful and someone even came by to bring me more crostini. They also cooked up some veggies meant for a pasta dish (I think?) which were a m a z i n g. Everyone at my table wanted a bite and I did not want to share. We had a great time and they treated us so well :) We will be back soon! Had dinner on a cold winter night here. Place was quite and cozy as it was mid week. Ordered the Goulash with a beer. Very tasty and filling portion which had especially good sauce. Also had the cheese sausage. For desert we had a strudel with apples and grapes inside, on the side was the Kluge. Would come back again. We had such a nice experience at Cafe Katja.  I don't remember how I first heard about it, but I had been wanting to come here for a while.  We finally did.Although it may be true that they are located a little out of the way, that's why I like going out to eat in the Lower East Side.  It's not as touristy and has better quality establishments.I spent a year in Austria, and I really like Austrian food.  It's hard to find that cuisine in the US.  Turns out one of the owners is in fact Austrian.  The other owner's wife was our hostess/server.  She was just so nice and accommodating!  Best service in ages!What really impressed me was that they have Stiegl on tap, and it was not only VERY FRESH, but it was also served in the appropriate glass, as it is in Austria.  They also have a wine list with each of the major Austrian grape varietals, including Welsriesling, Zweigelt, Grner Veltliner, and Blaufrnkisch, which are very hard to find outside of Austria. Came here with 3 other friends on a Friday night around 7 pm. There were open tables so I didn't need a reservations. I just came back from Eastern Europe and wanted to try out the Austrian food in manhattan. It's ... somewhat authentic. My friends got the Ruben which was obviously more of an American dish. Heavier on the cream and the cheese. I got the Austrian meatballs which were good. Lots of pepper and very tender! My bf got the weiner schnitzel and we both thought it was alright. A little dry and there were a lot of air bubbles. Also huge beers for $8-9! I enjoyed the service! The owner or restaurant manager is personable and seems like a real Austrian. Cafe Katja is an LES classic, and I have no idea why it took me so long to finally grab a meal there. Actually, I do know why - Austrian food is rarely the first cuisine I default to when considering a culinary destination. Despite not having a palate that automatically gravitates towards Central European fare, I do gravitate towards homey, welcoming restaurants that are a rare breed around New York nowadays. The room has a whimsey and charm that a lot of newer restaurants in the neighborhood don't possess. You can't force it, it has to happen organically over the span of a decade with warmth trickling down from the top. The staff are wonderful. It's worth going just to grab a drink at the bar to be near these lovely people. The food is heavy - sausages, potatoes, schnitzels, etc... There's no denying that. But you can also dive into lighter options as well if you're watching your figure. Good thing winter is approaching, as this is the perfect hearty meal to get through long, cold nights in the city. This restaurant has it all - wonderful food, ambiance and service. My friends and I visited last night at 6pm. It's good we came early, because  it was packed by 7:30pm. The atmosphere is rustic and cozy - perfect to visit on a cold night. We were seated at a long table so, you can interact with other patrons. Our server was so nice and checked on us at even intervals.I've always been curious about Austrian cuisine, so my curiosity was finally answered. We tried the sausage sampler for two, and our other friend had the berner wurstel. The sausage sampler was so great but    unhealthy.  Although it was very delicious, I'm not used to eating that much meat at one meal and felt somewhat guilty. My friend loved the berner wurstel. The cucumber potato salad was really yummy. Next time, I'll try a vegetarian entree to offset the gluttony.I tried one of the fruity beers in their tallest glass. It was the perfect beverage to drink with a heavy entree. Please patronize this restaurant. It truly is a gem in the city. Love this place! Great food, great service!I've came here twice. Once for brunch and once for dinner. It's tough to get a spot for dinner since they don't take reservations but it is worth the wait. The food is amazing. For brunch I had ratatouille with hummus per the waiter's recommendation and thank you thank you for recommending this. I didn't think it would be enough but it was the perfect portion. It was the perfect combination of sweet and salty with smooth hummus and crunch bread and I just have to say the presentation was beautiful. Waiter was super friendly as well!For dinner, I had the wiener schnitzel and what can I say? Huge slab of fried chicken? Just yas all around.If this place was a little more convenient to get to, I'd be here all the time. Definitely recommend! Awesome German style grub, bratwurst, sausage, and pork belly plate for two was spot on with the pork belly super crispy on the top and tender meat on the bottom.  Sides of garlic chard and pickled plates were standouts, right balance of acid and seasoning.  The dumplings were super fluffy, light, fork tender.  Only wish the staff wasn't as rushed, 3 waiters/bartenders on a Friday evening wasn't enough. They were friendly but a little hard to get a hold of at times. This place has it all! Meat, potatoes, beer, sauerkraut and more meat! Yum!! This place has very high ratings for the amount of reviews it has and I can see why. Not only was their food spot on delicious, but the service was stupendous!I came here with some friends on a busy Saturday night and although there was a wait, the hostess was so attentive in keeping us up to date on the wait of our table as well as ensuring we had drinks on hand while waiting. When we were seated, the waitress along with the manager checked up on us at a well-paced regular basis to ensure we were having a good time. It was very appreciative. As for the food, we started off with their aufschnitt teller, a charcuterie dish essentially with pate and other spreads. Very appetizing. We then got the Sausage platter for two which comfortably fed three people. Thick, delicious, succulent sausages (two different kinds), fatty, moist pork belly with a slightly crusted skin, fresh sauerkraut and creamy, thick dumplings all on one plate. So good and so filling. We also shared their special of the night which was pork shoulder with butternut squash and potatoes with an apple slaw on top. Just as delicious. Potatoes were cooked perfectly. The pork was fall of the bone, super tender. Butternut squash was roasted to perfection. Great place for drinks and food. The restaurant is cute and cozy with a great bar in the middle. Great for a date or a group of friends just wanting to chill and eat some good food. So legit and so delicious! We came here for dinner after hanging out in a cat caf. I was starving and someone we met in the cat caf recommended Caf Katja for good Austrian food. I agree! The food was so good and the service was amazing! And the ambience is charming (candlelit tables and pine/fir lining the bar) for groups or dates.Food.We ordered the sausage sampler. I wanted to try everything! The sausage sampler has 3 types of sausage and crispy pork belly. If you want more options like me, its better to get a big group and order from the wurst section. I loved the savory garlicky bratwurst, and the crispy fatty pork belly. The emmentaler sausage was a sausage stuffed with cheese. The sauerkraut tasted homemade (and actually fermented instead of using mayo) and had bacon bits inside. So good! I'll have to come back to try the blood sausage. I love blood sausage usually.Service:Our waitress was so cheerful and happy. She was great and explained all the sausages to us after we ordered. She was so chipper! Thank you so much! Ambience:Loved loved loved the real candles on each table, but it was bright enough to see your food and your companion. Loved the simple wood tables. There was a random cute golden good luck Chinese cat on the mantle. We had a great time! Came here last year while looking for a good restaurant to eat in. Upon reading the Yelp reviews and looking through the photos, what hit me was the Reuben sandwich.My coworkers decided to celebrate with me here for my last day of work. We ordered a Reuben sandwich and bratwurst sausage with some cheese dumplings. Overall the the was good. I'll say the Reuben sandwich was the most memorable. The sausages were good too but the cheese dumplings were too bland and didn't really like it. I like the interior, very romantic and great for a first date. When we got there, the noise level was perfect and not too crowded. I also forgot to mention that the pretzel appetizer was good as well. What a good surprise!The place is very cozy, "Austrian-German" decorated and clean.Food is very good and good price for the value!We had creamy spinachs with poached eggs (suuuper soft and tasty) and a wurst, which was delicious. Lemonade ok.As dessert we tried the strudel... that was pretty average (it has grapes as well and we did not like it...)35$ check. Isn't that a good price?Will definitely go back Mmmmmm. Good German food in a casual but nice environment. The buttered spatula and the potato salad are standouts. Plus, you get a pot of mustard, and who doesn't want that? Delicious. First time here and have only had the bratwurst and sauerkraut but it was really good.I had a coupe of beers and they were very good too. I've been willing to come here for a while, and this evening I finally did. The place is very cute and welcoming. I got the Reuben, while my wife tried the duck breast. The Reuben was colossal! It can easily feed two people. I was a little turned off by the very small quantity of meat (usually Reuben sandwiches are loaded with pastrami), but the melted cheese was tasty. Unfortunately, the duck breast was so overcooked we had to send it back. They were beyond nice about it, though, especially the gentleman working on the floor. He was very apologetic, and despite our temporary disappointment, he made a huge effort to make us feel comfortable and well taken care. Because of the outstanding service, I would totally go back and try other dishes. Came here for brunch a few times and was always able to find seats. The food is delicious here and they have a great selection of beer! Holy crap this place was GOOD. the portions are HUGE and you will not leave hungry. I met an old friend here at his suggestion and it was fantastic. We split the cabbage salad, which was nice and refreshing, and a platter. The platter had frankfurters (eh), sausage (drooooool) and mofuckin pork belly. Oh and all this came with sauerkraut... cooked with bacon. I almost grew a curly tail.  AND... there were these fantastic little dumplings. The mustard this paired with was a nice spicy contrast to all the fattiness and juiciness.  A little pricey, and it was surprisingly empty when we got in around 6 on a Thursday. Would definitely recommend and return in Manhattan. I found my now favorite beer thanks to this restaurant. This is our go-to for the area and it has consistently been good. The expansion makes the place even better, although I did enjoy its coziness when it was still small. If you're in the mood for Austrian/German food in NYC; you've got to check out Cafe Katja. You'll definitely won't regret it. From my first visit to my third; they have always been consistent. Great atmosphere, great hospitality, service, and lastly great food. Four main components Cafe Katja provides. When it comes to food, everthing on the menu is worth trying; you won't be disappointed.I would definitely recommend their buttered spatzle; a must side and as well as any house made saussage; don't forget the pretzel as well :)Don't just believe what you're reading, go experience it yourself is my say. This place has been on my radar for a while, and after attending a fun event in Lower East Side, we decided to head over for dinner. They had their large windows facing the street open, which made it feel like the dining area was extended into the outside, making the large space even more spacious. The inside was quite large, bigger than it looks from the outside. There is a main dining area when you walk in, with a nice size bar taking up half (or more than half) the room. But, the dining area extends to the left, with booth seating and larger table seating that can accommodate larger groups of people. We started off with a beer, and of course, right after the first sip, we had to have their warm pretzel...! Well, it was more like steaming hot pretzel, it was great! As for the main dish, we wanted to try their Assorted Sausage Sampler which I heard great things about. It comes with several kinds of sausages, pork belly, sauerkraut, and dumplings. Most of everything is home-made right there at the restaurant, including sauerkraut and dumplings. The sausages were huge, plump, super juicy and packed with flavor.The service was very friendly, our server was super nice, she took a good care of us. She made us feel welcomed with a warm smile, made sure we had everything we needed.  I would love to go back for more great food, maybe a brunch on a weekend... Read my full review of the restaurant and food on my food blog, foodlovergirl.

This spot is STRAIGHT FIIIIRRRREEEE! You aint gonna find none of those fluffly yellow street fair arepas up in here! The food is magnificent. Oh and the SAWCE!!! Need that secret recipe bottled up like yesterday. The service is lightning quick. The experience is amazing. The wife and I spent our 6 month married anniversary lunch here. Delicious. Then grabbed a few brews up the block at McSorleys afterwards. It was money. From the religious themes to the food, to the spanish writing on the wall, this cozy joint is As authentic as it gets. Arepas run about $10 a pop. They got beers on deck too. Go get you some arepas ASAP This place is great for a quick sit down meal. It is very affordable and the employees are very welcoming. The only downside is the size of it. It is very small so if it is crowded there is no where to wait but outside. The food is very good and they have a good amount of options. Everything is cooked to order and delicious. They have a good selection of beverages and the soups are amazing. I would definitely go again. I would not go to this place with more than 4 people due to the size. Value: 5/10Experience: 7/10Taste: 6/10Cute tiny sit down with slightly smaller portion sizes than expected.Value: I got their classic arepa (forgot the name but it was like the 3rd one) for $13 after tip and tax. The arepa really was quite small for the price I paid.Experience: The interior had a friendly atmosphere and food came in about 10-15 minutes. They also had a bathroom with a small gap in the window making it kind of cold. The inside is definitely a bit cramped and we had to pull out the table for my friends to sit on the other side of the table.Taste: The arepa smelled delicious but the taste just didn't match that. The meat and filling were a bit bland and we needed the hot sauce to spice it up. I think there may have been too much potato or something starchy and drowned out the flavor. This arepas restaurant is literally one of those hole-in-the-wall places that people try to seek out. This restaurant can hold no more than 20 people probably, maybe even less. You walk in and the tables are directly in front of you and then there's a small kitchen in the area behind. It's a small business feel and someone approached us immediately and sat us down. We ordered two of the most popular arepas on the menu and started off with around of plantain chips as an appetizer. They do sell alcohol here but we skipped it for this mail so I can't speak to that. I absolutely love plantain chips and a bunch of different kinds came in a basket as our appetizer. I completely devoured our basket, it was so delicious!!! I would go back here just for those to be honest. Our arepas we're pretty large, and filled with plenty of meat. Mine was made with a beef and some sweet plantain, the combo was pretty unique but really delicious. My husband ordered one of the spicier options, but it wasn't an overbearing spice. We thoroughly enjoyed our food here and the serving size were perfect, especially when you down a hole plantain appetizer!If you're looking for some arepas this is a great spot to check out! More of a 3.5 for me. They hand make the arepa buns here! So good and so fresh. My go to arepa Sammie to order is the La Surena! It's chicken, pork sausage, avocado with their classic chimichurri sauce. Sooooo good and juicy and tender deliciousness! It is very messy to eat, but you'll eat every bite, licking your fingers. The sad thing I learned was their main restaurant closed down and they changed their carry out side to be their only Manhattan location, so it was very crowded and hectic to sit down to eat. The service also has gone down prob due to the crazy crowdedness. No warm and friendly service here, but the food is good, so I would still go back when the weather is warmer and I can eat it outside without having to wait for a table etc. This is the traditional Christmas dish from my Venezuela . Chicken salad, Hallaca (is like a tamal filling with pork, beef, olives, amazing excellent and ham bread. For my country this is a sad moment for all the political, economics and injustices that are happening there for the dictatorship. Please pray for us  and enjoy our food. @manudominguezm I'd had Caracas bookmarked for years, but it turned out to be overrated, overpriced, and underwhelming. I ordered the Yo-yo appetizer, which should actually be under the dessert category, the Hot Queen (made of pulled chicken, peppers, onions, mayo, avocado), and the Da Pabellon (shredded beef, beans, cheese, plantains). The arepas were small and ALRIGHT. The former was overtaken by the avocado, and the latter was pretty salty. One is not enough per person, and these arepas are not cheap. ~$10 for each one, which are the size of my fist, is kinda unacceptable.Place is abnormally small, so you may have a wait. For a party of two, we waited fifteen minutes outside and ended up sitting at the bar. Unique atmosphere, tender meat, tasty & plentiful sauce( bottle on table). The pulled pork sandwich was full of tender meat. Although the tomato was mealy & the Masa dough was a bit under done, it was still tasty. The beef sandwich with black beans and plantains,also loaded with ingredients! Again the sauce set it off. Expensive for what it was ,slow to receive the food combined with the dry personality of the staff knocked stars off. The Quick: Tiny location but big arepa (fried Venezuelan sandwiches) bursting with flavor. Love!The Details: not much can be said about this amazing arepa place without my stomach growling... The food is incredible. The East Village location is extremely small, so if you're looking to go with a group try their Brooklyn location that is large, bright, and trendy (so Brooklyn!) You can't go wrong. All the options are delicious, even the brunch arepas are exotic and savory.Pro Tip: if there is a wait, put your name down and split a lobster roll at Luke's lobster next-door. That's right, I sometimes pregame dinnerThe Damage: extremely reasonable! Each arepa is around nine dollars and they are extremely filling. If possible, I suggest splitting three between two people although it's messy. Or split an appetizer Never a dull meal at Caracas.  Attentive staff.  Quality Arepas with a healthy variety of fillings.  You might com hungry and try to order two, but trust me, that's a food coma waiting to happen.  La Suena is my favorite.  Go for the special sauce on the table it's perfect.  And for fun wash it down with a cocada on a warm day.  Love it there. The fundamentals are here but does not sing in harmony.  Skip the appetizers as they were mediocre.  The arepas were made well and freshly toasted.  The fillings by themselves were good but seem to lack cohesion as a sandwich filling.  Maybe a sauce would be the bond that ties it together.Passion fruit juice was nice.  Very small and limited seating.  Take out might be a good route. One of my favorite. This place is the first place I take out of town guests to taste NYC. It's best to go at lunch because you can get the lunch combo (arepa plus salad or soup). The restaurant is tiny. Expect a wait, expect to be sitting on a crate and to be sitting in someone else's "bubble". It's very very very tasty food. The chimichurri sauce (available for sale) is out of this world -- nectar of the gods! They won't tell you wants in it but if you have a good allergy I'm sure they will tell you to avoid it if it's going to be a problem. La Surenya with Chicken, Chorizo, Avocado is my favorite. I went with my Venezuelan friend, and she said they were good arepas. We both got the vegetarian arepa one... forgot the name... with fried plaintains, avocado, and some sort of white cheese. I really really liked it. The white cheese reminded me of mozzarella. It could be bland for some people, so feel free to use the sauce that they provide on the table. It came out quickly and tasted fresh.We also ordered the tequenos. She also said they were good, and they gave a good amount. They tasted like pillsbury dough boy breading with white cheese in it. It was tasty. I just don't know if it all should be $9.00-$9.50. It was more like $7.00-worth it, but again, this is New York. Place was small and cramped. Not good for big groups or to go when it's crowded. I recommend just taking it to go. Obsessed with this place! They make the best arepas!! The inside of this location is very small and is very busy, but worth the wait! The De Pabellon is my favorite arepa although any of them are great! Also love the fried plantains with salty cheese appetizer and the chips & guac! Caracas arepas are reasonably priced and taste delicious every single time! Don't miss out on this place! Why, Caracas, why? I've been going to Caracas arepa bar in east village for 10 years on and off and I thought the original location was tight. Since there was the fire, they've converted the former "to go" location into a dine in restaurant. Now imagine the teeniest little stools and tables imaginable. They've crammed as many tables as physically possible, which I appreciate, but cannot help but feel claustrophobic as soon as I set foot inside. That being said, I love me some Caracas arepas. Arepas are Venezuelan sandwiches made with corn flour stuffed with goodies. La surena or die, I am a girl who likes what she likes and always orders the same thing. It has chicken, chorizo and avocado, with the house sauce it is to. Die. For. I could drink that sauce its a little sweet and adds a kick, I would probably put it in my eggs in the morning if I wasn't too lazy to bring it home. Yes, you can buy a bottle for yourself - you're welcome. Please, arepa gods, let me love you and open a bigger location asap! I haven't had an arepa since my visit to Puerto Rico, so I was excited to try this place out. Inside is pretty small, not too much seating, so I wouldn't suggest it for a larger party size. Most arepas are around $10. I ordered the playa deluxe, which comes with tilapia, onions, mushroom, and avocado. All these ingredients are stuffed into a freshly made Arepa bun. It's tasty, flavorful, and enough to fill me up. This was stop number one out of seven on a food adventure night with my friends, and two of my friends said this was their favorite spot that night. We visited here a long time ago and recently ordered again for delivery. The first time we went we were really full (trying to get a good taste of NYC before a flight) so I chalked up the sorta average experience to that.But then we had it again when we were really hungry... and basically, it is what it is. It's heavy and it's messy but it'll get the job done if you're in the mood. If your trust fund spots your east village apartment and you have a pink whale stickered on your lap top this will probably be your favorite restaurant. You might also enjoy if you shop at brooks brothers or lululemon. Hands down the best Venezuelan food in NYC. I came here on Friday night around 8:30pm and waited 20 minutes to be seated. The place was really small literally a hole in a wall. The service was amazing despite the fact that it was only one waiter who served all the tables and took care of the seatings. What we ordered: - Guacamole and chips: The guac was okay, super pureed and had more of a sour lime flavor to it if you enjoy that. It comes with a variety of chips (sweet potato, plantains, etc). The ratio was off they give you a lot more chips than guac. - Hot Queen: The arepas come piping hot. It's starchy and so delicious. The pulled chicken was great but it had a really strong cilantro taste which I'm not a fan of. I would reccomend it to anyone who loves cilantro hahaha. - Playa Deluxe: Excellent!! I'm so glad I went with this. The tilapia was fresh, plenty, not fishy and went so well with the mushrooms, onions and the crazy flavorful homemade herb mayo. The spicy sauce they provide on the table also went really well with it. - Sangria: I'd pass on this. It was $16 for 4 small glasses. Quite expensive and not that great. It was a quick satisfying meal. My only complaint is that the chairs were so uncomfortable. My friend and I couldn't sit longer for 10 mins. The bill was about $60 including tax and tip which is expensive. I would probably return or possibly order for take-out next time.

Why do I have to write something, why can't I just drop 5/5 and go? Get the creme brulee. good place - good coffee, nice selection of baked sweets and chocolate if you like that, truffles are actually really good.It's also quiet and sometimes deserted. These croissants = CRUNCH CRUNCH CRUNCH.Maybe my expectations were too high going in after reading the Serious Eats article, but I was a little disheartened after trying the croissants here. I came in around 9 am on a weekday and got a plain croissant ($2.95) and an almond croissant ($3.75).1. They feel very greasy, even for croissants.2. The shell is very crispy and crunchy and shatter-y and hard, too much so - biting through it reminded me of childhood breakfasts eating corn flakes (though the shards here are much thinner).The plain croissant has a nice butter flavor but it's so so greasy, and I feel greasy after eating it. A little disappointed at the inside as the one I got had a massive hollow and the layers clumped together.2/5The almond croissant was very crunchy and shatter-y too, and most of its faults of this are also faults of the plain croissant. The outside tasted slightly burned, and even the next day after being stored in a bag it was super hard and crunchy instead of getting soggier from the moisture in the almond paste... I love the almond pieces in the frangipane though - it adds an amazing texture! One end didn't have any frangipane :( I haven't found my perfect almond croissant yet, but I think I've found my perfect almond filling.3/5 - +1 from the plain croissant for the frangipane I don't like to poopoo local businesses, but having had several bad experiences with their products I cannot help but feel obliged to review. My office bought a tart from here to celebrate a coworker's birthday and my slice had a large bug inside. I'm not sure what it was but it was a whole bug and about the size of a fingernail. Yuck.I gave them the benefit of the doubt - bugs are attracted to sweet things. This could happen to anyone. I purchase a croissant every morning from a local coffee shop who get their baked goods from Ceci-Cela (I saw the order invoice once). While a little unnerved to see this I continued to purchase my morning croissant. Once, there was a small fly cooked into the glaze. I picked it out and ate my croissant - it was that or starve until lunch time. Today, the final straw, my croissant had a black grit residue throughout the pastry. I have no idea what this substance was, but it was disgusting and definitely not supposed to be there. Sadly I will need to source my breakfast elsewhere, but I will certainly be steering clear of Ceci Cela. I think they may have some production issues that I'm no longer prepared to endure. Overall excellent experience. We had a cup of English breakfast tea that was fine but not great and even if you were sitting in they gave it to you in a paper cup. The pastries though we're all excellent. We got an almond croissant, a chocolate croissant a cherry cheese danish and mini apricot danish. The cherry cheese danish did have a pit in one of the cherries which was disappointing. It was great that they had the mini option in case you didn't want a full pastry.
