The croissants we're definitely the hit of the trip. Both the chocolate and the almond were in top ten category of croissants I've had. Service was quick and pleasant. There is a decent amount of seating it you do want to stay and sit but there's only one big table so be weary if you have a large group. If yelp did half stars I would have honestly given this place a 4 1/2 Had Ceci-Cela's fruit tart at a friend's birthday gathering. I was thoroughly impressed by the quality and freshness and can't wait to return to try out more of their pastries.A friend brought over a raspberry and blueberry fruit tart (I didn't buy it, so can't say much about the price) and it was absolutely divine! The fruits were so fresh, and coated in a sugary syrup that only enhanced their flavor. There was a custard in between the base and the fruit that was creamy but not too sweet. The crust was flaky and tied the whole pastry together perfectly. Overall, a delicious alternative to a more traditional cake! Definitely planning on coming here in the future. Ahhhh, at last. I've found the mecca for croissants and delicious French pastries in NYC. After being clued in to this place by 12 Corners (and apparently ignoring this storefront the 50 times I've walked past this block), I finally visited for a morning drink and nibble.The teas are from Harney & Sons, which are always lovely. The Paris blend smells and taste pretty damn heavenly. The pistachio Madeleine is plump and beyond moist. I curse myself for sloughing it with the Starbucks packaged ones lately. And finally, the chocolate croissant. The perfect balance of chewy and flaky, that doesn't deflate once you've taken a bite, even after the server warmed it up in the toaster oven for me for a hot minute. (Lol, hot minute.) And it has the right amount of chocolate to round out the scrumptious flavor of the whole pastry. This is it man. This is the one that I've been searching for, and it's thankfully downtown and near my home. Maybe some will argue there are better ones uptown/elsewhere, but idgaf. I'm good and satisfied with this one.Of course I wish it was as affordable as it is in Europe, currency calculations aside. But the space is lovely and the staff cheerful and accommodating.It has gotten a tad crowded and hectic post-10am on a Saturday morning. And I haven't tried the sandwiches and such, so I can't in good faith dole out the coveted 5 stars.But, the early morning hours right after opening is when you want to be here to get that little respite from the NYC grind and a touch of Parisian joie d'vivre. Stopped by on a snowy Saturday for some respite from the wind and cold. My friend and I shared an almond croissant and chocolate raspberry cake. Both were delicious (I love almond croissants so much). She also had a chai tea latte, which she enjoyed.Service was super friendly and we didn't feel pressured by the staff to leave at all, despite a growing crowd.Definitely want to come back for more croissants and to try the giant macaron cake! Craving a pastry on Sunday morning, we stopped by Ceci Cela based on the strong reviews. Sadly, it did not live up to the hype.At 11:30 am, they were already sold out of every type of croissant. Which happens, and there were ample pastry options still available.  We selected a blueberry danish and a sugarbread. Both pastries were incredibly dry. The blueberry danish kept losing berries because there wasn't enough pastry cream or fruit juice to hokd it together. My husband - who has never been known to leave even crumbs behind - could not finish his pastry.Worse yet, the service added insult to injury. I started by saying I was craving a croissant, did they have any? There were none in the case, but sometimes places have extra they haven't put out yet. The server bluntly said no. We then asked for some recommendations, which led us to the blueberry danish. When she pulled it out (with her bare hand!), She dropped blueberries on the counter. She did not apologize, but did quip, "more for me." Not even a thank you or a have a nice day when we left. Basic common courtesies are not too much to ask for, folks.Beautiful pastries, but dryness and poor service will keep us from trying this spot again in the future. Ceci-Cela serves up some amazing croissants. Although the croissant pastry seems like a simple French staple, it takes a long time to make--you have to freeze and re-freeze the dough, and that takes hours. At first bite, the taste and texture may seem like nothing much, but after a few more bites, the true essence of the croissant seems to come out: the oddly familiar, yet warm buttery taste embedded in the flaky layers, enriching the surface of the tongue with each mouthful. It's soo amazing. I've never had a croissant like that before. As for other items, I've also tried a Pistachio Madeline, but felt that it could be better. The texture was a bit stale and the "Pistachio" flavor was too sweet and sour(tangy?). And, oh, I almost forgot to mention this, but the cashier at the register is sort of cute. ;)) I had the most lovely time talking to the staff here. I wandered in on a lazy afternoon, looking for some type of pastry. The lady behind the counter recommended the classic croissant (less than $3, forgot the exact price) and explained to me that they have the best ones in the city! Upon checking the back, the lady came back and told me that there actually weren't any left, but recommended a few other items on display. Often times when bakeries run out of my first choice, I usually just leave, but the staff here was too friendly and helpful. They were just EXCITED to be working and seeing me as if it made a difference that I was there at all. I ended up buying one of the turnovers, and left the store feeling great! Long story short, I didn't actually end up eating the pastry since I just wasn't feeling hungry. I ended up passing by a homeless man on Broadway with a sign that had the word "embarrassed" plastered quite largely on it. I felt compelled to reach out and give him something, so I decided to pass along the pastry I bought so I really hoped it was a treat! Technically, my rating isn't about the food, but it's about the establishment itself. Nothing like going to a bakery that can uplift your mood and inspire you to pass on the good feels to a complete stranger. Next time, I'll definitely come by early and sit down to enjoy a lovely croissant! Come support a business that really does care about your experience! Update: still one of the best croissants in the city. I've come to the conclusion that the almond surpasses both the plain and chocolate-almond. we recently purchased the frozen croissants that are made my laurent dupal. they are easy to prepare and provide a very french, delicious, unusual breakfast for guests (or for your own private indulgence)run don't walk to get them if you can. Delicious croissants!Cute bakery with seating towards the back. Upon entering, you will notice it's a bit narrow in here with loads of delicious baked goods displayed on your left. Employees are friendly, quick, and wrapped up our goodies neatly. Picked up some croissants for my mom and aunt, who love them. They are delicious, with the consistency and taste on point. I enjoy their pastries but wouldn't say this is my ultimate favorite place for them in NY. I stick to the croissants here. Cute cozy spot to grab some good pastries and coffee! Stopped in here after lunch and I wasn't disappointed! They had an array of croissants, macaroons, and cakes! I got the Creme brle which was 5.50 and honestly SOOO worth it! definitely coming back! I've walked by this pastry shop over a dozen times but never thought much of it, until I was craving a croissant this morning and saw the raving reviews on Yelp! Walked in and loved alll the delicious cakes and pastries in their display windows mmm! Got a chocolate croissant to go - delicious, buttery, soft and flakey! Can't wait to come back and try more. The shop was relatively empty with open tables and free wifi - will definitely add this to my list of work/study spots, though dangerous to be so close to so many sugary & buttery delights! Definitely some of the best croissants in the city, now available in a much bigger spot.The original one on Spring Street was practically just a tiny hallway, so this new one with tables and more seating is a welcome change.The plain and almond croissants are amazing, so definitely make sure you stop by here to try either one or both. As an added bonus, they're giving out mini ones on this opening weekend, so get there now for a free taste. I was disappointed that their croissants aren't as good as they were when they were back closer to Broadway. Guess time changes and so do people and perhaps consistency. May be I went on a bad day or I just got the bad batch. Very good pastries, liked the raisin danish on my first visit.  There was also an almond croissant that looked great.  They even had a brioche w/ orange cream filling which is pretty cool.  The space was nice, but with very narrow counters to eat inside & just a couple outdoor tables.  Other small downside, most of the pastries are 4 bucks a pop, which is expensive.  But the staff was friendly and with a quality product, it is very much worth trying out or visiting on occasion if you're local.  Certainly not a daily spot unless you have a fat  wallet So over two years later I finally came back for more than just a chocolate mousse. I tried their turkey sandwich which was tasty, except the bread was a little chewy (rubbery, almost). Also came out pretty fast which leaves me wondering how long they stay refrigerated until somebody orders one...I kept my promise of trying their macaroons though. Sweet is definitely an understatement, like literally biting into sugar. I much preferred the fraisiers... They had one with raspberries which was great.I'll definitely be back but maybe just to stick with my traditional chocolate mousse.

Char Sue is a great casual asian spot with a cool vibe and a short list of delicious drinks. When we arrived, the staff quickly showed us to a table on a Friday night even though it was shortly after 7 and we had expected to wait. It turns out we arrived just in time, as within 20 minutes, the restaurant was full and there was a wait. There is a Happy Hour menu with a half-dozen deals on small plates (tacos, pork ribs, etc.) as well as drink specials. Happy Hour occurs from 5pm - 8pm. We each ordered drinks that were priced very reasonably as we were just within this timeframe. For food, we ordered the green papaya salad, Mapo pork belly, five spice duck wings, and crispy brussels sprouts. The standout was definitely the brussels sprouts, which we could have easily eaten two orders of, and the wings. The papaya salad was fresh, but could've used more dressing, and the pork belly was a little rich for my tastes. Overall, can't wait to go back as portions and prices are definitely reasonable and they have a good selection of sake that I would like to explore some more. Highly recommend. Good Asian fusion spot if you're into non-traditional Asian food with a flare. We started with happy hr appetizers that start at $6, pork belly taco came with a crunchy shell and tangy green sauce. The duck wings were a bit too glazed and fried. Same for brussel sprouts, which came out too charred but were well flavored.For the main dish, we had the duck with rice, which was garnished with pickled radish and peppers (wish they had more of the garnish to balance the fat from the duck). Our pieces were too fatty but the skin was very crisp and well flavored.Finally, the highlight was the vanilla cappuccino, which has dashes of the Vietnamese coffee and fluffy whipped cream. Char Sue on a Sunday @ 5:40pm as a first time patron... I wasn't sure what to expect. However, I do know this establishment has been bookmarked for some time. Before I was willing to commit I asked to see a menu, based on what I saw (majority pork, which I don't eat) I'm not clear on why I even bookmarked this place but I was already there and heck I must've saved it for a reason. So my bestie and I decided to give it a whirl. Boy oh boy... were we glad we did!Bonnie was amazing from when first walked in and wasn't ready to "yes to the plate" just yet. At first we were the only table and there were some gentlemen seated at the bar. She clearly explained everything to us and gave us the time to figure things out. We decided on the sharing plates and vegetables. They were Shrimp Summer Roll, Monkey Bread, Five Spice Duck Wings, Crispy Brussels Sprouts (OMG never have I ever experienced Brussels Sprouts this dang GOOD), Broccolini and Nigori to drink.Shrimp Summer Roll: avocado, chinesse celery, cilantro, carrot, ume vinaigrette ($10)- very tasty light and refreshing with an amazing vinaigrette that isn't too over powering. Monkey Bread: freshly ground thai green curry, roasted sweet potato ($12)- the sweet potato under the bread is a nice touch to prevent premature sogginess. However, the highlight of this dish is the thai green curry sauce/broth. You will literally be licking the bowl. Five Spice Duck Wings: plum sugar glaze, cucumbers, scallions, sesame (Happy Hour $6)- H/H is until 7:30 and this portion comes with 2 wings. Great flavor profile, sweet and salty but not over bearing. Crispy and saucy skin with very tender meat. Crispy Brussels Sprouts: nuoc cham, peanuts, chilies ($8)- FREAKING AMAZBALLS... So dang good we ordered it twice. I do not know what they did to this veggies but whatever it was, it was Amazing!Broccolini: charred, pumpkin seeds, soy ($8)- ok people, idk what they do to vegetables here but they do it very well. Another wonderful dish, with great flavor. SHO Chiku Bai, Junmai Nigori ($6)- explained as a cloudy form of sake ... Wasn't a fan only got it bc of my name.Clearly I had and enjoyable meal and look forward to returning. I will be ordering serval of the same things again like those Sprouts. Only complaint was that the menu consists of mostly pork and I actually do not partake. So that was initially part of my hesitation. 5 stars !Clean QuirkyAmazing serviceSharing platesSimple menuBraised duck Short ribsPapaya saladNot much to say because it was an amazing fare.Very simple and up to the point.Thank you The terms 'pan-Asian' or 'Asian fusion' typically arouse immediate suspicion, but those are words I would use to describe Char Sue and I really enjoyed everything I ate the other night! It's a very casual spot, with table service, a bar you can eat at, or a grab and go counter at the front. The first pleasant surprise was when we found out that we had made it in time for their happy hour, which goes til 8pm and offers lots of drinks and food items at $3-5 - a great deal! From that menu we got the pooty fries with the five spice short rib, which was my favorite dish of the meal. The short ribs were amazingly flavorful and tender, and next time I'm definitely going to get the full order of them over rice or noodles. The other dishes we had were also mighty tasty for the most part. We really liked the lamb in Japanese curry over rice, as well as the broccolini side dish. We weren't fans of the Japanese eggplant, simply because they were far too salty and a bit mushy. The ambiance is brightly lit and perhaps a tad too casual for a romantic date, but perfect for an easy meal with friends or on your own. Everything came out really quickly and was hot and fresh. Prices are pretty reasonable too, depending on what you get. I have to admit I'm curious about their full Peking duck dinner, which they say feeds 3-5 people and costs $150. A perfect location near the Essex stop, and lots of other bars to drop into for a drink before or after. This anti-pan-Asian may be a convert thanks to Char Sue! I've found a new favorite place.I love how no-frills this place is, yet the food is top notch. I can just casually walk into this place and have an amazing meal. That's a win-win in my book. Also, there's a counter for solo eating, in case you either have no friends or you have friends but you DON'T WANNA SHARE. Everyone's got that one food-stealing friend. (PS - If you can't think of one, it's probably you.)The roast duck with noodles is my newest obsession. Why is the duck so good?? The portion is just right, although I wouldn't mind just a teeny bit more noodles. The duck is juicy and tender and the skin is crispy, fatty, and flavorful. It's similar to roast Peking duck, but elevated somehow. Also, the daikon salad is a nice starter. Sweet, tart, salty, and refreshing at the same time. I'm eager to try the other items on the menu, although I'll probably order the duck a few more times before I move onto anything new. It's just that good.The service is pleasant enough, the place gets crowded unless you go early, and the happy hour wines suck. Go for the food and you leave happy. 'Nuff said. It's a quirky kind of decor but the tables are nicely spaced out. Service is pretty attentive and your water glass will be filled. The food is beyond delicious. The meats are cooked so well, tender and full of flavor. The curried lamb is just all kind of flavors bursting in your mouth. The star of the meal is the duck. Their take on the traditional roasted duck is done very well. The skin is crisp and there is a nice layer of fat and then the meat. It's tender and I would eat it every day. The Szechuan spice rub adds the new twist and it's not overwhelming at all. I love their take on something so comforting and executing it well. Char Sue was the bomb!!! It was worth walking from the village to this new comer in the LES. It is right across from the really cool covered market place and near Beauty and Essex. It is in a simple interior with no pretention that you enter this amazing eatery! You have a prep kitchen in the entrance, and a large bar towards the back of the place. We sat on high chairs and wanted to order everything from the menu! Small menu, which I like, the less you have, the better and fresher the food tends to be. There are traditional Asian restaurant appetizers such as green papaya salad, shrimp summer rolls, pork belly, wings... everything looked appetizing but we started off with a sandwich! There are 4 meats: 2 pork dishes, 1 duck, 1 lamb. They come in a bowl with rice or egg noodle or in a sandwich. We wanted to try all the main menu flavors, so we ordered 2 main dishes and 1 sandwich (and that's why we started off with a sandwich!)...We had one of the pork flavor on a sandwich and it was AMAZING. It reminded me of a bao meets banh mi. We loved it. The white fully cloud like bread was delicious. The meat was perfectly seasoned, the spices were on point! We chose our main dish to be the other pork dish (5 spices I believe) with rice and the duck with egg noodles. OMG. The flavors were unbelievable, like nothing I ever had before. It was perfect, just perfect. The pork was fantastic. It had so many layers, the juices and sauces are what dreams are made of. The duck was excellent. Crunchy of the outside, perfectly cooked on the inside. Beware of the little bones... Honestly, this place is a hidden gem and it should be on triple D for Guy Fieri to try. It's so tasty, so simple, and yet the depth of flavors is really to die for. I cannot wait to go back, and eat there again. The owner and chef has been trained by the best, and his talent, energy and creativity is clearly showing in the dishes presented. YUM! GO! I first stumbled into Char Sue several weeks prior, and had the chance to sample an array of their small plates and appetizers - which are ideal for any happy hour get together. I can still remember how flavorful and well-encased in an egg roll shell the Black Pepper Beef Tacos were and the seasoning and spice that were layered in the Five Spice Duck Wings... Needless to say, when the opportunity came to revisit Char Sue for a five course dinner menu, I immediately said yes.The restaurant is conveniently located just steps away from the Delancey-Essex stop in the LES, and is set up for diners and groups of all sizes. Looking to just grab a quick bite? Take a seat at the bar or one of the two tops to the side. Hoping to have a group of friends and family? There's a communal table that'll seat everyone at once as well. It works for almost any occasion, and the food alone is deserving of a special visit.Dinner began with a new menu addition: Monkey Bread served a top a slice of sweet potato in a Thai Green Curry. The bread is a family recipe, compliments of Chef Matty Rojas, and is soft and pillowy with no small amount of butter - perfect for getting that slight crisp at the bottom of the bed. It's the perfect vehicle for scooping up the spicy and creamy curry, and contrasts well with the sweetness of the sweet potato. The following dish isn't, unfortunately, on the permanent menu, but if I had my way - it would be. Tender, succulent slices of octopus were served with charred brussels sprouts and paired with a spicy pennywort vinaigrette. The flavors were reminiscent of the Yu Xiang (<U+9C7C><U+9999>) sauce that I've grown up eating, and was the perfect savory-spicy flavor for the protein.Next up: Crispy. Pork. Belly. No other words are really necessary, but I did my best to savor each of the three pieces that were served; they had a crisp, crunchy crust that yielded to a tender and fatty interior, and was highlighted even more with the side of a garlic-chili dipping sauce. It ties with the Char Sue Duck as my favorite dish of the night, but how can you compare to a plate of decadent dry-aged roast duck coated in a blend of Sichuan spices? A crisp, crackling skin, tender and juicy white meat, all served a top of bed of warm sushi rice... this would easily be my last meal (if I ever had to choose one) and is more than successful as a modern, elevated take on the traditional Peking duck.To finish, a sweet almond pudding with a strawberry jam provided the ideal light finish to the meal... and also cemented my desire to camp outside their kitchens for the remainder of my time. (You think I'm joking. I'm not.)I'm already planning a return visit to Char Sue, and would recommend it to anyone looking for a uniquely NYC restaurant. Here, Asian food is redone and reinvented to even better and more delicious forms, but still stay true to their core flavors and tastes - and truly, you won't find these dishes anywhere else. 3 stars because the food here was severely lacking some oomph. We tried the short ribs app ($9) and duck noodle entree ($17). The short ribs were cooked well, but not long enough because the meat didn't fall off the bone. They smothered some copycat teriyaki sauce on top of the ribs instead of marinating them which tasted really basic. The duck noodles were a hot mess. Duck breast had an interesting/okay flavor but was overlooked. The noodles/broth was way too sweet and the radish too salty. Overall one of the individual components of the dish complimented each other well. The chefs here really need to step up their game and pull together more thoughtful dishes.   In the other hand, ambiance was nice, and the interior is pretty cute. Our server and hostess were both really great. Such a pity that the food here is so underwhelming. Save your $$ and goto Chinatown for some cheap and yummy Chinese food. Walked passed here many times in LES and finally gave it a try tonight. I was pretty deceived by the name because i thought it would be Chinese BBQ pork. But their speciality lies in their ducks and five spice rub. Our waitress recommended the roast duck with noodles. We also ordered the spare ribs and brussel sprouts to share.The duck was very flavorful and The noodles were delicious but the duck to noodle ratio was off. Surprisingly there was more duck to noodle ratio! At best the food was okay but would not return again. I get rent is more expensive here than chinatown but for that money i rather go to big wong in chinatown for a fraction of the price I dropped into Char Sue for their first-ever beer pairing dinner with the good folks at Transmitter Brewing. Quite frankly, Transmitter was the name that caught my attention, as they are the brewery behind two of the best beers I have ever tried (FYI the W1 and G6). So, I grabbed a friend and grabbed two seats to this unique culinary event.The five-course menu was prepared ahead of time, and each course was better than the last. The highlights were a rainbow trout with cucumber coulis (Char Sue brings the sauce!), lamb merguez scotch egg with smoked (!) yogurt, and a sweet and savory ice cream bun. The beers were also great, and carefully chosen to pair with its respective dish. Beer winner on the night = G4 golden ale.Sadly, of the dishes we had, only one is currently on the regular menu: the pork belly taco, which is on the happy hour menu. While not a winner on the night, this was more because the other dishes were exemplary rather than a slight on the tacos. The tacos contained a great amount of heat and brightness thanks to a Thai chili salsa that will kick your ass.All in all, this was a uniquely pleasurable dining experience, and I hope they continue the practice on a regular basis. I will definitely be returning to Char Sue to see what other delicacies they have in store. I had this place bookmarked for a while and was excited to try it, only to be disappointed that it was not really Chinese BBQ. Don't get me wrong--the roast duck I had was really good, but the price, for me, was just too much at $17 and prevented me from giving 4 stars. The noodles that came with the plate were standard egg noodles and came in a sweet sauce. I liked that the dish came with a lot of duck, but I wish the duck and noodles were evenly proportioned because I didn't feel full afterwards. We also got the eggplant appetizer which was interesting. The eggplant was soft and came in a light sauce that was sour (think vinegar). I thought it was weird and much prefer eggplant in garlic sauce, especially since it was $7. Overall, not sure I'd come back because I'm never in the area and just a bit too pricey for me. Service and ambiance 5 stars, but food I would give is 3 stars. Definitely not your typical Chinese restaurant. Food here is definitely unique. The item on the menu that caught our attention was the beef tacos and after we finally got a chance to try it, I now understand why people rave about it. The taco shell was perfectly crispy, with well seasoned ground beef with hidden pieces of red hot peppers, topped with a generous amount of guac, and finished off with shredded cabbage to make it photo ready. Warning: it is super spicy but it's the kind of spiciness that makes you crave for more. Aside from that, we also got the Brussels sprouts, mapo pork belly, and the duck with noodles. Everything was good, but the duck with noodles was certainly not worth $17. A few pieces of duck, with 2 bites of noodles, and some random pieces of veggies on top that doesn't even make sense. I would like it more if the noodles actually have more flavor. Overall, cute date spot. Highly recommend you go try the beef tacos, you won't regret it. So. Freaking. Good. My boyfriend and I got the green papaya salad, duck wings, pork ramen, and braised pork with black bean sauce with rice. The papaya salad and pork ramen were good, but our favorites by far were the braised pork with rice and duck wings. The duck wing meat was falling off the bone and super flavorful. The braised pork tasted like the ultimate home cooking and almost reminded me of the Taiwanese pork and rice but better than any I've had here. The salty, savory flavors were on point and the added salad, pickled radish, scallions and garlic balanced the richness. We ended with the basil ice cream which was surprisingly refreshing.They ran out of the actual duck and ribs when we came, but after trying the pork, we will definitely be back to try those. As a skeptic of any cha siu place that isn't a hole in the wall, I was blown away by the deliciousness & quality of the food here, in addition to the atmosphere, cleanliness and friendliness of the waiters. Crispy roast duck in the mantou sandwich was super flavorful, and I highly recommend it. I was expecting a small mantou with a little bit of duck for a pricey $8 but boy I was wrong! Huge mantou with a bit of that duck fat grease, and enough pieces of duck that you'd see on an entree. Prepare for this to be messy to eat, naturally. Just pick up the duck pieces that fall out with your fork and add some of their heavenly chili sauce to it. The five spice short rib plate with egg noodles was surprisingly tasty as well. Short rib is fall off the bone, except they make it even easier and take out the bones already, topped with a bunch of garlicky, saucy garnishes including braised daikon. It was super delicious. My only feedback is that the egg noodles were a tad soggy and a tiny bit bland (though that might have been bc I didn't mix some parts of it well, as everything else was bursting with flavor), but this was entirely made up for when sprinkling some of their garlic chili flakes and oil. Admittedly an entire mantou sandwich and egg noodles plate was too much for one person, but I'm glad I tried both and was pleasantly surprised at the big portion sizes! I'll be back again for that crispy roast duck. Located directly across the street from Essex Market, this seems out of place from the rest of the area. I absolutely loved the interior. It has a very chill/laid back vibe that's great for catching up with a friend or a low pressure place to bring a date. We came in around 6pm on a week night and it was pretty quiet with just 1 other table. Prices are a bit higher for the type of food, but the portions are decent. It's about $8 for a bun, but they are bigger than what you would get elsewhere. Didn't try the entrees so I can't speak for those. We got the roast duck and 5 spice short ribs. The duck was so carefully crafted with just enough crispy skin mixed in and the short ribs were so tender, they just fell apart. Overall, the mantous were great and delicious. Cocktails were $10 a glass so of course we had to try them out. The two we got were very colorful and perfect for summer. Light, citrusy and clean on your palate. Something between a 4 and a 5. If the prices were slightly lower, I'd probably increase the rating a bit but not by that much (as well it couldn't go over a 5.)Instead of getting noodles I stuck with two mantou sandwiches, the braised short rib as well as the pulled duck with black bean. The bread was super fluffy and it held the sauce well.Of the two I preferred the braised short rib though both were excellent. I just found it less conventional for the price. Both were good and a bit messy. I found the duck with a bit of spice to actually have a good amount of sour heart.I tried a bit of their homemade hot oil. It was different but quite good good. A bit earthy in flavor compared to others.They have a very good beer selection. The cheaper ones range from 6-8 bucks. For happy hour at the bar only (change this as it's not that much for deals) you can get tap beers and wines for 5. The waitress offered me a seat there if I wanted but instead i stuck with an 8 dollar imperial stout which was quite delicious. I';ll probably get the good sounding Yuzu spritzer next time.Service was excellent.4.5 Bare 5. It's a newer place so I'll increase it slightly. I thought this was one of those Chinese food spots that cater to the more American palette with good service, nice ambiance, and alcohol. Definitely did not expect it to be somewhat different than similar spots in Chinatown. To start, they dust their roast duck with five spice and anise so its got a slightly szechuan taste. They also added some of the duck drippings to the rice underneath. Their pork ribs came in a stew that was light but flavorful, and went really well with the curly Cantonese style egg noodles. There's also little slices of pickled radish and roasted potatoes as well.The prices are a bit high compared to spots in Chinatown, but I think the prime location and the attention to detail well justifies this. An exciting new edition to LES! Char Sue is a play on "char siu", Chinese roast pork, and offers Asian-inspired dishes that will exhilarate your taste buds. The neon pink light-up sign outside instantly catches your attention to the establishment, and you will also notice the hanging meats to the left of the sign, which shows what meats are fresh and available for the day. I have to say the decor of the restaurant really fits - their color schemes work very well together without being too much. It's not super trendy or upscale and is a great place to grab a bite or a drink with friends after work for a good price. The bar in the back is my favorite area because they have BAG HOOKS UNDER THE BAR! This was the first bar I've visited that has those and I definitely give them points for the great idea. They offer a variety of beer and even have wine on tap! Their whole menu is very innovative, including the cocktails. I had the Char Fizzle, which has rice wine instead of liquor and has a unique rhubarb taste. I also ordered their five spice short ribs mantou sandwich, which is a classic Chinese soft white bun with their specialty of meat inside. The meat was SO juicy and flavorful and the wanton crisp was a good crunch paired with the softness of the bun. The only downside was that the bun was a little too dry, but given that the restaurant just opened, it was a pretty good sandwich. Their staff was also very friendly and attentive. 10/10 an amazing experience and will return to try more items on the menu!

A+++! I LOVE this place! They serve New Orleans food right! You must get their fried chicken biscuit. It's fried chicken, buttermilk biscuit, cole slaw, and gravy for only $6.50 ($7.08) after tax. About 7 bucks for this magic?! Yes please! It's made to order fresh so you need to wait 5-10 minutes. Since this is very heavy I only need one sandwich. If you're extra hungry get two. I sometimes will add a bad of Zapp's Voodoo kettle chips, which is hard to find in NYC. Imagine all the best chip flavors in one bag! It's a little on the salty side but you're planning to eat a friend chicken biscuit so it won't do much extra damage at that point! HahaSpecial mentions: For dessert get the Ben-Yay's (Delicious beignets aka deep-fried nuggets of sweetened dough, served 3 to an order) for a sweet $1! I wish I had room for this today! I had just come from brunch. (Hey don't judge! I was saving it for later when I got hungry again.) All the food is best eaten fresh though. The eggs and biscuit breakfast item is fantastic too. They also sell Cafe du Monde Chicory Coffee for $1. Only down sides: Very limited seating inside. You will smell like fried food after leaving. No bathroom that I could see. The rap/hip hop music sometimes gets insanely loud. I just get my sandwich to go and eat it at a nearby park. The store front is disguised and easy to miss. Didn't see much signage. Look for the store front that's mostly white, looks closed, and covered up in white paper. You're in the right place. I recommend this place highly! Although I had very high hopes for this place...it was just ok:( From the pictures and reviews, I figured it would be amazing but it wasn't. I ordered the fried chicken sandwich, the Beignets, and the pork sandwich. The fried chicken sandwich was extremely extremely bland. Not sure if there was mashed potatoes on it but combining that with the biscuit, you need some type of glaze so you actually have a tasty sandwich! The pork sandwich my boyfriend had and again pretty flavorless. The Beignets were good because I mean it's fried dough but way way too much powdered sugar! I definitely think the workers were very nice and the prices are EXTREMELY fair but this place was personally just not for me! A hole in the wall but with surprisingly good amount of seats. The prices of the sandwiches are on the menu but they're a bit microscopic. The sandwiches are everything everyone is tantalized about, especially the fried chicken biscuit sandwich. It is such a comfort food, the gravy is perfect without making the sandwich a sloppy mushy mess. The biscuit is still very buttery, flaky and did not crumble apart when biting into the crispy chicken. The cabbage slaw gave the perfect crunch and tartness for a huge flavor contrast. The fat girl that I am, I also got the braised short rib on challah bread. After having the chicken biscuit, it just didn't compare. It was still extremely delicious. Make sure you are a pro at squats if you're to use the bathroom. They do have a bathroom offered to the customers even though its kinda in the kitchen. The bathroom feels like a ship cabin, with the toilet seat extremely low. Beware of the hand wash sink, there is only one lever that dispenses extremely hot water if you don't finish washing your hand within 5 seconds. Who knew an unmarked dingy looking storefront would have such a delicious sandwich, from the outside you'd never know what to expect!The sandwich is messy, crispy, drenched with gravy, the biscuit was crispy & fluffy, and worth the $7. It's a sandwich that makes you want to take a nap right after.The menu has a lot of variety: braised short rib, veggie sandwich, pork so if fried chicken isn't your thing there are other options to explore. I can see why this place is so popular. Lately I have been pretty skeptical of a these popular restaurants because I've been let down by so many of them, but this one I was very satisfied. I came here the other night with a friend and we both ordered their famous chicken sandwich. It was so good! To start off, we both appreciated the fact that the sandwich was not only inexpensive ($7) but it was also a decent size, it wasn't no little bird or anything like that. As for the chicken, it was crispy on the outside but the actual meat on the inside was very juicy and tender. The gravy was not overpowering nor was it salty making it a great addition to the sandwich, same goes for the purple slaw. All of the ingredients meshed well together! And as for that biscuit...I could eat those by themselves. They were soft and buttery, not dry and overall a damn good piece of bread. Also, my friend and I made a new friend; Raymond. A very nice guy, who also is an adventurous eater and an overall cool dude. If you're reading this, it was a pleasure talking to you! All in all my friend and I had a great time, enjoying great sandwiches and great conversation. We also got complementary beignet, which were bomb as well! Looking forward to going back! What a great biscuit fried chicken sandwich! You start out with a buttery, flaky but dense enough not to fall apart, with a lightly golden outer shell biscuit, then add a nicely seasoned fried chicken, with a purple cabbage slaw with a nice crunch and just the right amount of vinegar, and then top it all off with a rich and creamy gravy. Sooo good. The place itself is pretty small and it's easy to miss if you aren't paying attention. The storefront doesn't look like much so you won't really notice it if you're just walking by on the street. Inside there's mostly bar seating and then there's one able at the front that can seat 5. My minor complaint for removing a star was that when I came in, they said the only thing they were available to make at that time was the chicken sandwich. While that's what I wanted it is a shame that they weren't able to make any of the other items on their relatively small menu. When I tried to order a soda, they had 4 flavors sitting out but then it turned out that they were out of all but 1 of them. Seems like there might be some inventory issues that need to be worked out. I found this spot on yelp but my friend I went with today has been a bunch. I saw photos of the fried chicken sandwich and that's what I got. It was delicious and packed with flavor! The biscuit added great texture and the slaw and gravy drenched over the chicken was fantastic. It's a small place but wasn't that crowded when we arrived. Friendly staff and quick service I normally don't opt for spots beyond out of my way (I'm from Bergen County NJ) but my good friend from California was visiting so naturally, I had to go look for an EXCEPTIONAL sandwich spot (as he loves sandwiches)I went for the "Sea"wich and he did the signature "chicken." The prices aren't disclosed on the store menu but it's cool that way, you don't decide to not get something for its price.Lastly I thought the prices were so more than reasonable. Mine was around $12 and my friend's was $7. James the guy who attended us was so funny and hospital. It turns out he's a musician so the music playing whiles he's on the clock is always going to be BOMB!!!Also, watch out for the toilet. It doesn't FLUSH but that vintage porta-potty look they were going for was super cute, you can't hate it in my opinion.I promise I'll be back!!!!! Awesome chicken sandwich.Venue: (4/5) the small hole in the wall is easily missed when you are trying to find it.  It looks like someone tore pages of coloring books and pasted it to the outside of the restaurant.  Either way this is most a pickup and eat place.  There were a couple bar seats and one table for a small group (3-4 people max).  Nothing fancy just order move over and get your food when it's made.  Food (4/5) this is an awesome sandwich if you love fried chicken sandwiches and biscuits and gravy.  I'm not a huge biscuit person but appreciate a good biscuit.  I'd recommend to anyone that loves both.  Service (5/5) great service.  The guys that served us were nice and patient as I tried to take photos of my food. The best sandwich shop I've ever been to! I currently live in Austin, Texas, and I still think about how delicious Cheeky's is. The fried chicken and homemade biscuit is an instant classic. In the sandwich world, Cheeky's stands out by offering only 9 sandwich's, each worthy of paragraphs of praise. The attention to detail is second to none, the quality is notable, and the hole-in-the-wall aesthetic complements the experience seamlessly. When I first visited, I literally stumbled on the place--a little white door on the edge of china town, in the heart of the east side, two steps down into a one room restaurant with newspaper wallpaper and bottled sodas and hand pressed sandwiches amongst an array of quirky kitchen tools and machines and ingredients. The space is cozy almost to a fault, forcing the owners to squeeze everything in. But that's half the charm. When I stumbled in, I instantly loved the laid back, casual feel. Even still, I  was skeptical. Could such a small, cramped little artsy sandwich shop produce a quality product? After my first bite, I was in love. Cheeky's is unlike any other restaurant you'll ever visit. Truly one of a kind. Great little place. Hard to find, little to no signage. Inside it's tight quarter's, very little seating, the staff is very freindly and the food is great. Their menu is small but the food packs a punch. They specialize in sandwiches, they have one sandwich for every protein category including a veggie. And for desert they offer biscuit w/jam, bread pudding and ben-yays. We tried their famous fried chicken biscuit sandwich. The chicken was nice and juicy, the biscuit was great as well it didnt just fall apart and the coleslaw and gravy really rounded the sandwich out. We also had to try their ben-yays (their spelling) for me I was a little dissapointed because they were really tiny and also undercooked. The great place, great staff and tasty food. I've gone here several times and I think it's time to give them a review. You're here for the chicken sandwich, I hope. It's a good sandwich! But how it's prepared, the place and the service has got more and more disappointing with every visit. Let's get to the breakdown:Place: small hole in the wall spot. It's usually packed inside so you'll feel super cramped. A few seats at the counter and a table for around 3 people. You're probably better off just ordering to go. Service: where are they hiring these people?? Hipsters with no professionalism and just weird. I don't care if you got that skinny jean type of style with your flower pinned denim jacket but address your customers, greet them! Ask them what they want! And most importantly don't look so lost. I went in the other day and that's exactly what happened. Observations: what's the point of wearing gloves if you're handling everything with them anyway??? Dude is slicing up limes, leaving it there for the flies to land and chill on them then goes off to handle the radio / iPhone to change it to hood rap. Listen, I love music but for you to play rap with profanity is not professional especially if you have younger people who are eating in there. I can only imagine how else they handle prepping of the other stuff where you can't see. Food: get the chicken sandwich. Everything else is not worth it. Like I mentioned it's good but I question how they handle the beginning to end product due to my observations. I'm giving this place a 3 star and not lower because I do enjoy the popular item here but I will not be coming back because I was disgusted & I don't appreciate the vibe I was getting. To each their own. I stumbled upon Cheeky Sandwiches during a search for late night noms. The restaurant was quiet aside from two others who had just finished their sandwiches. The guy behind the counter was super helpful and friendly when we told him it was our first time. He immediately suggested the Chicken Biscuit so we went with that. The chicken was perfectly fried and piping hot. I loved that they served it with gravy. However, the pickled slaw that they served it with was too tart for my taste. Additionally, our fried chicken came on toasted challah instead of a biscuit. They had run out of biscuits but didn't notify us until I inquired.Overall, for $7 it's a pretty good sandwich, but I feel as though I can't give a higher rating since it wasn't the original sandwich. I'll have to make my way back to give it another shot. Cheeky'sWhy have I not come to try this place until recently?? I've had this place bookmarked for years now. 7 years ago I use to come to this area weekly and I remember passing this place not knowing if it's good. I'm so glad this place is still around since there has been numerous changes in the neighborhood.First off, the chicken is a MUST. It's fried chicken on a buttermilk biscuit with coleslaw and gravy. It was such a delicious sandwich! The biscuit is buttery and flaky. The fried chicken is moist and has a nice crunch. I also had the beef which is braised short ribs on challah bread with arugula, cherry tomatoes and horseradish sauce. This was also good, but I prefer the chicken sandwich more. I can't wait till the next time I'm on cheat day. This is all I want! And also, they help you cut the sandwiches in half if you ask. Yummy fried chicken sandwich! Meat was juicy and perfectly fried. Biscuit was really soft and not tooooo crumbly, good for sandwich purposes. Comes with a free beignet!Staff was incredibly friendly too. My only complaint was the wait time, I think it took about 10-12 minutes for them to make my sandwich and I was the only one in the store at the time (around 11:30am). The NYC grit is oozing out of this place. A minimalist space transformed into a southern themed restaurant that looks like it belongs to an underground secret society. All this in the heart of Chinatown. At Cheeky, The chicken biscuit and the poboy are the two popular items. Beef, pork, and vegetarian sandwiches are also available, along with beignets straight from cafe du monde. As far as the food goes, I can't say anything in particular blew me away. The biscuit was a good size, but it had more of a bread consistency, while the beef sandwich lacked in flavor. The bread pudding is on the dry side. The egg sandwich with muenster is pretty satisfying. That might be your best bet. Cheesy+Fluffy eggs=winner winner. That being said, it's a great atmosphere with friendly service and fair prices. Cheeky is a decent option for a quick bite. Very good fried chicken sandwich, pretty bad beignets (or benyays as they call them). The fried chicken sandwich comes with chicken (duh), slaw, and gravy, piled between two soft and crumbly biscuits. Although I'd have liked a little more spice or vinegar to cut through the savory, it curbed my fried chicken craving. The beignets, on the other hand, were just plain bad. The inside was extremely mushy, rather than chewy, and the powdered sugar was clustered in a few places rather than spread throughout. Its only saving grace is that it was $1 for 3 pieces (we threw out 2 of the 3). Overall, a pretty solid place. Their other sandwiches looked and smelled good also! Just skip the beignets. Cheeky Sandwiches is the place to go for a solid fried chicken sandwich. The place itself is pretty hard to find and there is limited seating, however it is definitely a must go to spot for their fried chicken sandwich . The biscuit and slaw on the fried chicken sandwich really stood out and was the highlight of the sandwich for me. The chicken itself was of course tasty, but nothing special. They make everything fresh which means you might have to wait a while for your sandwich but it is definitely worth it. Another thing that really stood out to me was their hospitality and service. The staff was nice and offered to throw away our stuff, and get us water and napkins. Overall it was an A1 experience Wow. Wow. Wow.I've even looking for a true Po Boy for a long time New York. Finally, found one. When you walk in, disregard decor. Rock out to the incredible music, chat with the regulars and grab not one but TWO po boys. One for now and one for later. It's not very large but it is filling, I went with fried shrimp. The French bread was warm and not too chewy, flavorful fried shrimp and the sauce wasn't too tangy. That's super important when making a Po Boy, let the shrimp have its moment. Lettuce was fresh, again you weren't skimped on the amount of shrimp or toppings. You can also add the rare but delicious voodoo chips. Perfect addition to such a great sandwich. I can never find them but when I do I make sure to grab one. I'm ordering my second one now. Two thumbs up here all the way. Went to Cheeky Sandwich after reading the reviews on Yelp. I have a habit of taking apart sandwiches before I eat them and found this strand of hair sticking to the tomato of the shrimp po boy I ordered, as seen on photo here. I don't know where this hair comes from and don't care to know. I lost my appetite after that. Won't be going back

I had Buffalo chicken grilled cheese, and I'm pretty satisfied! The pic is what my friend ordered; triple cheese. Simple classic option. They have fresh bread everyday delivered from a certain bakery.  And they understand how to make it golden without burning them~It's great to have this for brunch~ and the amount is good for a lady. The grilled cheese is all about grilling the cheese all kind. What a taste to beauty and the delicious to delicate. With some nice interior design makes ambience better and good atmosphere with huge sitting area . Including the pictures on the wall makes even brighter interior.The buffalo chicken grilled cheese was perfection to taste that you could easily finish and order the second one . Don't get me wrong it's big enough for a lunch. Grilled cheese the caramelized onion makes it haven of spot with that beautifully served home made tomato soup smelling the all fresh tomato can make your lunch even better You know, we all crave for some good grilled cheese once in a while for sure and this is the spot that is taking your craving out of your mind because the grilled cheese only could be made this delicious with some or many kind of sauce you can choose.And like most people here saying it's good or it's the best. For me there is know best food that's why I look around for food all the time.  But good food is good food I love to be back soon to get that buffalo chicken grilled cheese with that tomato soup. Dope grilled cheese sandwiches. Enough said. First time trying cheese grille after seeing it all over IG (thanks @devourpower). Really cute interior with a good amount of seating. Staff was really friendly they even bring your food to u after u order. I would say it's a cute little date spot (granted u both really love cheese) especially in the summer. Now on to Le Food ...The buffalo chicken grilled cheese was amazingly gooey, crunchy, and spicy. The sweet potato tots were bomb (although I wish they were a little crunchier, I'm that weird tater tot lover who likes them super crunchy). The cheese fries, which was def more cheese than fries, were a bit soupy and the amount of cheese left over after eating all the fries kind of made me mad (who wants to waste cheese?). Regardless I was def pleased with what I came here for...the grilled cheese. Will be coming back soon to try the Mac n cheese! The food was so good! I wonder if it's because this dinner was my first meal of the day. I ordered the ham grilled cheese and it was so good!!! I wish the portions were a bit bigger compared to the price, but I was full after my sandwich, cup of soup, and bites of my friend's Mac and cheese. Grilled cheese: the caramelized onions were amazing! And the Dijon gave it such a great kick. My only request is that they spread out the onions and Dijon better because the edges which were missing those two ingredients weren't nearly as good. The Dijon was all in the center, so I'd get bites of intense, nasal passage clearing burns of Dijon mustard. Buffalo Mac and cheese: my friend liked it but I wouldn't eat it again. It was too heavy and fatty tasting because of the fried, battered chicken and the decadent, heavy sauces. Tomato soup: I liked it but it was too expensive for a cup (4-5oz for $3.50). Overall, the sandwich impressed me so much I'd come back! Traveled all the way down here to try out one of their grilled cheese sandwiches and boy was the wait worth it. As soon as I walked in I was greeted behind the guy at the registered and made we feel welcomed. I order their "Italian" grilled cheese and it was made to perfection. I will recommend this place to anyone. Nom Nom... We ordered a Buffalo Chicken (4.2/5 stars), Three Cheese (4/5) and fries (2/5). Overall pretty satisfied with our lunch here. The bread claims to arrive from Balthazar daily, didn't taste much better than your typical basic white bread. Personally I like more of a grill on my grilled cheeses. Wish we passed on the Fries.... lackluster, fried well... but very basic and seasoned 0% (no salt bae here). Chill staff. Cheers to the classy table of belching female tourists preaching about the difference between "love" and "in love" ~ burrrppppp! This establishment epitomizes why I love New York--this city manages to turn the most basic foods that you would never crave in any other city (e.g. bagels, pizza, grilled cheese sandwiches) into one of the best foods you've ever had. I've been living out of a hotel down the street since moving to the city and walk past this place everyday. There's a poster outside that reads something along the lines of, "Best grilled cheese in the city or drink on the house." I scoffed at this for a good week, like best grilled cheese? Low bar much? Ever read a sign that said, "Best candy corn in the city"? Not only do all candy corn taste the same, but also who the hell craves candy corn/grilled cheese?But it got to me. I craved a grilled cheese today. I walked in around noon on a cold Sunday and ordered the basic ham and cheese sandwich for $8. Dijon, gruyere, caramelized onions, white bread, whatever. Let's add a bowl of spicy tomato soup too because all the reviews said the portions were small, which really worried me because I grew up in middle of nowhere California and expect nothing less than Cheesecake Factory portions. The bread had a larger area than I expected, at least 5x5, and perfectly crisp. Turned to the side, the sandwich was pretty thin, with a small slice or two of ham, some caramelized onions, and 2 thin layers of cheese. I can't think of a way for the sandwich to be thicker though, because the ratio of bread to cheese to meat was just right. You have to get the spicy tomato soup--it elevates all the flavors of the sandwich without ruining the texture. The interior has a line of tables and chairs by the window so you can sit and enjoy this experience alone or sit at the counters to socialize. I highly recommend savoring this experience for yourself at least once. It's too easy to scarf down a piece of bread while talking without realizing that you finished your food. The downside was that the food took more than 20 minutes to come out and the restaurant was hardly full, so I wouldn't come here again if I were looking for a quick lunch before spending an awfully long day in Ikea. I would order for delivery or come back at night to have this along with some beers with a few bros--it stays open late and has a decent selection of drinks. So my friend and I kept scrolling by these delicious sandwiches on Instagram so we decided to finally check them out in person. We came to Cheese Grille on a Wednesday evening around 4:30/5 o'clock. Thanks to Yelp I already knew what I wanted...The Sloppy Joe grilled cheese which consists of sloppy joe ground beef and jalapeos. I also got an order of the sweet potato tots which are supposed to come with some type of sriracha Mayo which they must have forgotten so I just used ketchup. In addition to our food, we ordered a carafe of one of their white wines. The food was delicious and reasonably priced. The food is also super photogenic; therefore, you can get some great snaps. The ambiance of this place is super casual and laid back. Absolutely no frills. I'd definitely return and recommend to others in the area who might be looking for a quick bite to eat. However, I wouldn't necessarily go out of my way to return even though the food was good. So I've ordered take out from Cheese Grille the past three days in a row.  Not only because it warmed me up during our recent blizzard, but because the GCs are outta this world!  Especially when you add tomato and truffle oil.  They offer other sandwich toppings like caramelized onions, basil, etc.  I also add a cup of tomato soup to dip my sandwich in.  You can opt for gluten free bread as well.  I'm a big fan as these bread/cheese combos as they make me feel rite at home.  Comfort food at its finest! We were in a cheesy mood the other day so we  went and got some. The location is simple in decor, bright and open. Communal height too seating. The young man taking our order at the register was cheerful and very helpful in terms of explaining selections. We opted for the buffalo chicken Mac & Cheese. It was very good, lots of spicy kick. Keep a cool beverage on the side. I added some BBQ sauce to the Mac & Cheese just to balance the heat just beyI have low tolerance for heat but again it was very good. We also purchased the Little Italy grilled cheese sandwich which has a Pesto spread, oh so good! Overall, on point selections. I am sure we will return to try a few other menu options. When you are craving grilled cheese this is the place to go! It may seem like a simple concept that can be done at home, but going to this restaurant is worth it. It's not terribly pricey and your grilled cheese is probably amazing. I came with a friend and she loved her grilled cheese as well. She ordered the Sloppy Joe and she was a big fan. My order-The Mediterranean and Fries *yum* It was honestly so good! It didn't take long to prepare and it was very filling. Service- The guys who were funny and polite. You don't get served at this restaurant, you have to order at the register and you take your receipt with your number. The Place-Very chill, no one was there when we first arrived, but it started to pick up and it was pretty nice. It had a relaxed vibe, which is perfect when you are eating comfort food. Yummmmmm nothing like a crispy, melty grilled cheese with some hot tomato soup on a cold day!!Upon entering the restaurant, it was actually a little awkward. A man (who I later realized works there and was perhaps the manager?) completely didn't acknowledge me. I was a little confused too because I wasn't sure if you order first? Or get seated and they take your order. In any case, someone who was cleaning acknowledged me once it was clear that the other guy wasn't about to say a word. It was then made clear that I can order at the counter then they would bring the food. The man that took my order and the man who seemed to have been cleaning were very nice and helpful. The guy that seemed to be the manager was an interesting character though.. not that I saw him be mean to customers, but he seemed to very much micro manage and talk down to the employees... not necessarily directly relevant to customers, but still of interesting mention as far as environment feels of the establishment. There is some bar seating and some table seating. Good for anyone stopping in on their own, fun date, or meetup w friends. Random street art type stuff along the walls and really random stickers plastered. Casual and fun feel overall!The food though. Dear god. Crispiest grilled cheese I've ever had in my life that wasn't burnt. I got the Little Italy. It wasn't a heaping sandwich, but it was filling enough along w the cup of spicy tomato soup. Cheesy enough for sure, I wish there was more pepperoni, but man. The pesto really gave it a nice touch. The soup, while hot w a little kick, was also refreshing in a sense. The lemonade to accompany was pretty tasty as well - not too tangy/sour and not too sweet. I will definitely be back. There are too many amazing things that must be tried here o.o [Visited Back in April]This is a bit sad, but I stopped by with Hubby with the intention of eating a grilled cheese sandwich, but Hubby wasn't amused. The entire trip was basically me eating my way through Manhattan and it amounted to eating something nearly every hour. It was our last day there and I walked in... and decided to appease Hubby with just getting the sweet potato tater tots to go. We had a plane to catch in a few hours. I still think about the grilled cheese sandwich I missed but next time! Back to what I did buy: the tater tots were pretty good! I finally ate them on the plane so they weren't quite fresh but still satisfying. Tater tots were always a love of mine but sweet potatoes were a new one and I don't regret it one bit. I think we were their first customers of the day and the man did a slight double take when I only ordered the tots but got over it in a split second. We got out order in no time and we were on our way. The decor was nice; I would have liked to take my time to enjoy the goodies, but I still had a few more places I wanted to stop before we had to head to the airport.'Till next time, Cheese Grille! Whoa! Not a major grilled cheese person but dang this was really good.  LES has so many place to eat it's hard to pick a place. I was in the mood for something f quick and found Cheese Grille. Parking and traffic is annoying around her but worth the stop.I placed my order at the registered and since I love to people watch, they had plenty of open window seats so I planted my little behind there. 1. Goat Gouda, bacon and avocado??? AHHH so good. 2. Three cheese w/ bacon. So crispy it was great. Also ordered a cup of tomato soup. Had a bit of a kick. I have had better but was good w the grilled cheese. 3. Mac and cheese bites. 5 decent pieces. Was good not the best I have ever had but yummy. ;) I had quite a unique experience here and I doubt that it will ever be repeated, so I struggled with how to rate this place. The food was pretty solid, but definitely not life changing. So maybe a 4/5. But The immaturity of the people working there brought the score down to a 3/5. While I was ordering at the register a TV prank was happening in their very tiny sitting space. While I was just far enough away to be able to try and ignore it, my mother was sitting right in the middle of it. She eventually got freaked out enough to leave her seat and come up by me at the register (there was a man wearing 3D glasses who was freaking out, knocking things off tables, waving his arms frantically and bumping into people). Finally, the actors stopped, let everyone know it was a prank and that it was for a TV show. Too late, my mom was already pissed and didn't find it amusing. Frankly, I didn't either. But I'd just paid, so they already had our money. My mother expressed her concerns and was visibly upset, but it didn't seem to phase the man at the counter. In fact, he could barely keep from giggling as he explained that they had signed an agreement with this company and couldn't do anything to stop what had happened. We're I the business owner, I would be concerned about losing a costumer. I would, BARE MINIMUM, offer to add a drink or side dish for free, get the order out ASAP, and continue to check on the guests to make sure they were comfortable in every other way. But again, all he could do was giggle. Thank goodness the TV people were better. Maybe because they just wanted us to sign their paperwork. But after hearing my mom's concerns, they immediately offered to pay for our meal. We got a a grilled cheese with bacon and avocado. Pretty good! We also got a side of sweet tots. They were great with the chipotle sauce (which was extra $). Not sure I'm dying to come back to this place.... Cheese Grille is great when it comes to selling themselves on Instagram, though the actual experience of coming here is just okay.Came here on a recent NYC trip with high hopes for a delicious/cheesy experience. The counter worker was pleasant and walked us through the menu and we placed our order. The wait was fair, though admittedly there weren't many people there ahead of us. The food was very aesthetically pleasing when it arrived (as a brief perusal of Instagram can verify), though the taste didn't measure up to the hype, nor did the portions for the price. As an added thought, the drink selection here was quite good.Overall, I would consider coming back with friends for a (very) light bite to eat. Guess I just set my expectations a tad too high.Overall: 3.0 stars----------Pros:- Food is good, and very aesthetically appealing.- On warm/nice days, the open design of the restaurant is a great way to enjoy the evening.Cons:- Didn't quite live up to the hype.- Prices/portions were below expectations. Best grill cheese I've had in a while. The sweet potatoe tater tots are amazing, especially covered in cheese. You won't leave here disappointed!? The food itself is pretty dang good. We order the sloppy joe, garden melt and spicy tomato soup.  The bread on both was crispy to the end, great for dipping into the soup.  The garden melt was light and delicious, didn't feel heavy at all.  The soup however was light in both salt and spicy, could have used more spicy. All in all, food was great. Definitely more of a snack place than a meal.  But a must return kind of spot. Very satisfied with everything.The food was great and the service was great. It's a perfect place to stop by before or after Soho shopping I think. I had 'Little Italy' and everything was perfect. The bathroom facility was a bit small but somehow fits the restaurants mood? Overall, recommended for everyone! After a not so stellar first visit, I decided to return to try out the "Sloppy Joe" and Onion Rings-- which caught my eye last time. The grilled cheese was grilled perfectly, not too much cheese, not too much ground beef, and to top it off, I dipped in Chipotle sauce, which totally enhanced the experience. (Kudos to Michael for making the suggestion). The Onion rings also hit the spot, and weren't too greasy. As I waited for my order I checked out their Instagram page, and noticed they had Mac and Cheese--- I guess that give me no choice but to return for a third time to give that a shot!

This place is not just for seafood lovers, if you're seafood hater, they have amazing happy hour drinks and wings special till 7:30!If you love seafood, this place is heaven for you! Love their grilled (baked?) oysters for $1.50 during happy hour. If you missed happy hour, then get the Cajun shrimp bags. I personally think shrimps are better than Crawfish but it's up to your personal taste.I've tried almost every caprisuns and love every single one of them! Also came here on a wednesday for Craw Feast, and that was absolutely amazing!! Come for the happy hour and apps, do the boil - I had oysters and crawfish last time and lunch was good!But this review is for the "Feast" that was $35 a person. The snow crab legs were delicious, but we had a rotten clam that smelled and the shrimp was not fresh and definitely over-boiled. You know how a shrimp gets all mushy and hard to peel when the meat sticks to the shell? Yeah, that was 95% of the shrimp tonight. Won't be going back for the Feast - unfortunately not worth it for a table full of shrimp and clams since crawfish are out of season. Definitely could've used a few more crab legs! If you're debating whether to go here or the boil, Just go to the boil... the food was so mediocre. The medium seasoning was so hot I couldn't enjoy my food and the mild had no kick to it. The Dungeness crab was not sweet at all, actually just tasted like water. Very disappointing. The grilled oysters And sweet potato fries were good and so were the deviled eggs... skip the adult Capri sun too... they were strong for someone who drinks all the time but not tasty at all. There's so much more I could write but this place lacked well everything. The atmosphere was boring the drinks sucked the food tasted weird and worse of all.... I spent over $200 on a meal for twonot including tip. This isn't a 5 star restaurant there's no reason I should be spending this type of money at a bland mediocre seafood spot. Not as good as other similar themed restaurants. Although the decor and staffs were nice, I would not recommend coming here for the Louisiana seafood boil. I suggest coming here for the happy hour specials and then grab entrees elsewhere. This place has really good happy hour. Food and drinks were priced reasonably priced for happy hour. The Cajun wings were addicting; the wings were flavorful, crispy and not drenched in oil. The raw oysters were decent for a dollar each, but the showstopper was definitely the grilled ones. The grilled oysters were amazing! They were garlicky, buttery and cheesy; definitely get them. The crab cake fritters were good, but definitely passable next time. The adult Capri suns were good, but packed with garnishments and ice. Still delicious though. Overall, I don't recommend the Louisiana boil because it didn't taste fresh. The shrimps were all overcooked and tasted mushy. The sauce was okay but not comparable to The Boil.Come here for happy hour, but skip the Louisiana boil, especially the shrimp. The short: super fun and chill on a Friday night, and tons of really, really good happy hour deals. The longer: we came here as a party of 8 for my friend's birthday. We all LOVED it. On Friday there's a DJ spinning very loud music. The place was packed with couples, friends and some families. We started with the adult Capri Suns. I had the Yours Truly sans raspberry syrup... and was very, very happy. The drink had really pretty floating rose petals in it. Then, we shared a bunch of appetizers before the seafood boil. The fried pickles came in big chunks. The Cajun fries were perfectly crispy. The lobster roll had traces of truffle oil. The chicken biscuits were messy but delish. The star though: grilled oysters. Holy shiz. Delicious. Then, we did the seafood boil. I'm thrilled I got just water boiled king crab legs. They were perfect. I didn't love the head-on shrimp (head freaked me out a little), but the less wimpy people went nuts over it and the Cajun seasoning. We'd definitely be back here to take advantage of the happy hour deal. Bonus: Yelp cash back! I went for a friends birthday and the four of us got the claw feast with the claw daddy special sauce. Unfortunately claw fish wasn't in season so we didn't get to try it, but the shrimp and snow crab legs were delicious. The sauce went well with everything especially the corn.The waiters checked up on us only once, but when we had requests they fulfilled it with a smile. The menu states that they automatically add 18% gratitude for tables of 6 or more, however, it was automatically added for our table of 4.We made reservations, however, they will not seat you unless all members are present. The portion for the claw feast was also enough to fill 4 people. They give bibs and gloves to eat which is very nice especially knowing how messy it could get eating from a table with sauce and food in the middle. I came here with my boyfriend's family last weekend for his birthday. We tried to book online and call ahead on the day of, but they said to just show up.I came in around 1:30 on Sunday and was told a 15-30 minute wait; the guy was kind of vague and apathetic. The place was pretty busy. However, he said we could sit at the bar, which we did once his family arrived 10 minutes later.The bartender was super helpful and explained that we could order our food at the bar and get it moved to our table as long as we closed out there. We put in our seafood orders and started with a round of a dozen and a half happy hour oysters. (Happy hour runs all day on Sunday, and includes dollar oysters!) These are not the most knock-your-socks-off oysters of your life, but they were balanced and juicy. I'm kind of picky about my oysters and I would have kept eating these forever. Big crowd pleasers.Our table was ready after about 15 minutes, so we closed out and switched over. Then we got our bibs and gloves and suited up. Our food came out in about 5 minutes.My boyfriend and I focused on the king crab legs (MP, I think it was $30something a pound) in mild lemon pepper. Awesome. The snow crab legs ($23) and shrimp ($15) were also good, in medium Claw Daddy's Special. Both of them came with potatoes and corn in the bag. We also had a round of clams ($15) that were pretty good, as well as crab cake fritters ($9) that were much better than expected. Garlic noodles ($6) are not what I expect at a Cajun spot, but they were tasty and would be a welcome addition if you're trying to fill up.They warn you about the spice here, but even the medium I tried wasn't very spicy. The king crab was our best choice, as well as the medium Claw Daddy's Special sauce. Do note that they don't serve crawfish in December.The only other seafood boil spot I've been to in New York was Hot n Juicy, which had slightly better sauces. However, the atmosphere is just so far ahead at Claw Daddy's-- you're in a modern, light filled space, and it feels much more fun than being in a basement sports bar. Service was excellent. Bathrooms were clean.If you're looking to eat a lot of seafood, Claw Daddy's is a great choice. Do reserve if you can, and do try to take advantage of the happy hour. This Lower East Side seafood restaurant comprises a wide dining area with few communal tables in the middle, while the Mezzanine serves as plush waiting area-cum-cocktail lounge where they serve light bites and cocktails while you wait for a table, which could be a long wait if you did not reserve ahead! if you're not ravenous, light snack is somewhat adequate.For the main entree, we ordered Snow crabs and Shrimps Combo for two people with Corns and potatoes served with plastic hand gloves and bibs. It was not as messy as I might have anticipated.This place is definitely ideal for groups but probably not romantic enough for date night. A taste of NOLA in NYC...The grilled oysters are amazing the clams I would not recommend unless you like them really chewy. As far as drinks the Jays a dream was amazing. The fried pickles are not bad but too thick for my taste would have been a lot better if they were sliced thinner.The place itself is on the small side. Came here early on a Saturday it was practically empty perfect time to go. Full of flavor and fun! I've wanted to try Claw Daddy's ever since going to The Boil. It's a very comparable restaurant in both cuisine and price - both are cajun seafood spots. Claw Daddy's interior is clean and spacious. They had some nice lighting around the restaurant, maybe because it's the holiday season. I was with a group of five folks and we were immediately seated on a Monday at 7pm. We started off with adult caprisuns (flavored soju drinks), which are very fun and tasty. We were in time for happy hour (5-730 week nights), so we ordered grilled clams and grilled oysters, and crabcake fritters to start. Every appetizer was brilliant. The sauce paired with the crabcakes was well made and paired very well with the dish.For the main meal, we ordered a 2lbs of shrimp, 2lbs of clams, and a pound of snowcrab legs, all in a medium spice and claw daddy's special sauce. We ordered two sides of bread, a side of sausage and 3 sides of garlic noodles. I can talk for hours about the garlic noodle. The sauce is fairly tangy and rich in flavor, though it wasn't nearly as spicy as I would have liked it. The shrimp is the best bang for your buck as their shell is lighter than crabs or clams. All seafood was fresh, and if you order more than 2lbs, they give you potatoes and corn. The corn is a must-try in that sauce. The GARLIC NOODLES !!!! I would get them 100x over. They're hot, super garlicky, cheesy, and just a pile of goodness. We couldn't stop eating them and kept ordering more. It's also a nice palette cleanser from all the seafood doused in the rich sauce. All in all, Claw Daddy's is a fun and messy experience. I would definitely go again, but I'd choose to go to The Boil over it only because the special Claw Daddy's sauce was personally, a little too salty. This place has some of the best Cajun seafood you'll find in the city. We ordered the snow crab legs with a side of corn and potatoes and it was really amazing. They also have some great happy hour deals. Our favorite was the Capri Sun cocktail (not pictured here) with rose petals floating in it. The ambience was also nice and cozy. The atmosphere in general was chill and fun to spend a Friday evening at. Definitely will visit again. Most people love Claw Daddy's for their great seafood, or Lower East Side ambiance. All that stuff is good but I just care about their adult Capri Suns lol.You can choose between 7 different flavors, I always get Just a Dream ( my favorite ). Regularly the drinks are $10 but if you go during happy hour ( 5pm-7:30pm ) you can get it for $7 - and we all love a good happy hour.Now don't get me wrong, they are not the strongest drink you probably will have in your life. They are actually relatively sweet and smooth BUT they will sneak up on you lol. Before you realize it you probably had about 4 and once you stand up you will feel it lol.Im not a big seafood lover, so I don't want to judge the food because I really only go to Claw Daddy's for the drinks.Tip: Claw Daddy's opens up at 5pm and gets crowded quickly ( it be a line outside before it opens ) so call ahead to make a reservation to save yourself the aggravation or opt to sit at the bar.
