Do you ever get an overwhelming craving for crab claws? No? Just me? Well it happens to be on the regular, and seeing Claw Daddy's $35 special I knew I'd found the place to get my fix. What it lacked in ambiance it made up for in delicious boil sauce, and a couple of standout items that are enough to keep it on my radar should another craving hit me with a vengance. We came after crawfish season, which was fine with me because I don't actually like the little bugs, so our boil was chock full of shrimp, crab, and clams. The star of the show though? The sausage. Smoky and rich, it was some of the best andouille I've ever had, and dipped in the garlicky butter sauce? Heaven in my mouth. The crab was also delicious, succulent and not in short supply. Clams were a little chewy and the shrimp was a little mushy but a fine vehicle for the sauce, which I recommend mopping up with the provided bread the moment you've run out of room for crustaceans. Pro-tip: we're spice lovers and almost went with the "spicy" option. The server warned us against it and talked us down to the "medium." This was 100% the right call -- it was still spicy, but not overwhelming. I think kicking it up a notch might've made such a huge amount of food hard to eat. The adult capri-suns are a cute idea but so sweet -- I'll be sticking to iced tea or water next time. Beware of the 2:45 reservation spot -- the kitchen closes at 3:15, and the bar at 3:30, so there's definitely a little bit of rushing that happens if you're in that last slot. The canjun lobster is great and I love the sweet potato chips. The crab cake is okay. The environment and service is good. A nice meal. I don't think you can go wrong with this place if you're looking for a cajun seafood spot. We ordered the shrimp and snow crab with the original claw daddy's sauce and were not disappointed. We also came during happy hour which consisted of $1 wings-- which were amazing, I'd highly recommend ordering them. The capri suns are also a fun drink, and it was cool because they were all made with soju but they were a little too strong for my liking and tasted very similar to the mixed drinks you'd drink at a college frat party. The cajun fries and mac 'n cheese were also nice side dishes. I'd say this is a fun place to go with a group of friends especially since you can get seats for larger parties (they also take reservations which is a plus). It also can be a great date spot to go with a boyfriend or girlfriend (not for a first date though because it does get messy). I'd recommend making reservations if possible because the place is located in a popular area and it does get pretty packed. Claw Daddy's offers great seafood at a reasonable price. It's spacious and can easily accommodate a large group. Probably not the best place to take a date to since eating here can get a little messy. Try to make a reservation before going since Claw Daddy's gets packed. The adult caprisuns are not only cute but also very delicious. Their grilled oysters give me New Orleans flashbacks, which is always a good thing. All of their seafood tastes fresh and packs a lot of flavor.If possible, try to make it to their happy hour from 5:00 - 7:30pm. The have $1 oysters and good drink deals. This review might not be as comprehensive as possible considering I didn't try the seafood, but felt I'd leave my two cents regardless!Came with a party of 6 on a Friday night. We had a reservation and were glad we did - the restaurant was crowded! My friend and I stuck to the cocktails (adult Capri Suns!) and the Cajun fries while the rest of our group got some variation of the boil. They enjoyed it for the most part, had a few complaints / confusion over portion sizes, but overall had a good time. The fries, though, were out of this world. Some of the best I've ever had! Hot, crispy, meaty, they were insane. We kept ordering more and more.As for drinks, I chose the Sweet Georgia and enjoyed it so much. It was sweet but also strong, and the cranberry really helped balance the Soju out. My friends got the Blush and the Just a Dream and loved all of them. I'd come back for the drinks alone.Our server was so friendly and energetic, offering suggestions left and right and engaging in small talk. It warmed my heart how nice he was! I'll definitely be back to try the seafood feast when I'm hungrier but I'm already so impressed with my one experience here! What a fun, interesting restaurant / concept (and love the cute bibs and gloves that come with the feast as well). TL;DR Happy hour 5-7:30PM$1 oysters and chicken wings$1.50 baked clams and oysters$7 cocktails (normally $10)$5 draft beersVery good happy hour for oyster lovers. Mild is still kinda spicySi les gustan beber deben pasar por aqu entre las 5 y 7:30. I'm always down for a happy hour and I've gone to Claw Daddy's a few times. The drinks are always on point.  I ordered a couple of oysters, chicken wings, baked clams and baked oysters. They were really good. For drinks my fiend and I got Just A Dream and Sweet Georgia. For the prosecco lovers the Sweet Georgia is for you. When the waiter came out with our drinks he realized one of them was incorrect and quickly get it swapped out for us. We also got a pound of crawfish and head-on shrimp. Mild sauce. My one problem was that this wasn't mild at all. It was more of a medium spice than mild. We ordered 2 pounds because we would get potatoes and corn. We got 2 red potatoes and 2 quarters(?) of corn? Personally, I didn't think it was worth it. I'll stick to just one pound next time. The garlic noodles as a side was pretty good! Despite the spice situation this is definitely still a go-to for me. Tip: Make a reservation early ahead of time -- especially if you have a big group if you want to have the"Claw Feast".The Claw Feast is a hefty serving of crawfish, snow crabs, shrimp, and clam (2 lbs of each) and a generous serving of corn, potatoes and sausage on the side. This is all for $35/person with a minimum of 4 people. If you have less than 4 people, you cannot participate in this feast unless you want to pay for 4 people's worth of the feast. You get to choose a type of sauce for your seafood. The most popular options are the Claw Daddy's Special or garlic butter. I chose the Claw Daddy's Special which came spicy (with your preference of spice level). I selected medium but they were not as spicy as I anticipated. The drinks we ordered were the "Adult Capri Suns". They were cocktails with very fruity flavors in a little Capri sun-like pouch. Very delicious and minimal alcohol taste! You get a pair of gloves, paper plate, utensils, a wet wipe and 2 buckets for your shells. You also get a side of bread! Overall, this was an extremely filling meal. Although it wasn't all-you-can-eat, the portion size was almost too much to finish between 4 hungry people. The seafood was very delicious and paired with an excess of sauce: perfect. The service here is adequate. They get you what you need and check up periodically, you can't really ask for more. Would definitely come back if I'm in the mood for a lot of seafood! I had a great time!! The food was delicious this will be my permanent all birthday spot. Thank you for your hospitality

I've been wanting to try this brunch spot, and finally made a point of getting here on a Saturday morning. Luckily we planned for the long wait: 90 minutes for a table for two. So I'd definitely recommend getting there to put your name down, and plan something to do while you wait. Once you manage to get seated and order, the food comes out pretty quickly. Which is very necessary because after such a long wait we were famished.I ordered the Huevos Rancheros with chorizo. Such a good decision! It came with whipped sour cream, guac, salsa, beans, and two sunny side up eggs on a tortilla. Filling and satisfying. We also shared a plate of the Blueberry Pancakes for the table. I think you definitely need to try the pancakes if it's your first time here. They are so buttery and fluffy! Great brunch and a must try, but not sure how soon I'll return. There are so many other great spots I need to try. TLDR: the best fried chicken and waffles I've ever had; use the NoWait app to minimize wait time; cash only; friendly and attentive staff; large portionsLive close by to Clinton Street Baking Company and have always wanted to try it, but was discouraged by the long wait times. However, one of my friends mentioned that it was recently added to the NoWait app (where you can virtually put yourself in line if you are close enough to the restaurant), so decided to give this place a try on a late Sunday morning with my two roommates.We put our names down on the app around 10:45am and then headed over to the restaurant about 45 minutes later. Although the app said our wait time was up and to report to the hostess, we still had to wait an additional 30 minutes (unsure if this was due to the app or the restaurant). This was slightly disappointing, but better than the usual wait time.The restaurant was bustling with all tables and bar stools filled. Bright light was shining through the large windows and the place had a "diner" feel to it with wooden tables, regular and booth seating, a stainless steel counter at the bar, and chalkboards listing daily specials.While everything on the menu looked great, I knew that I had to try the fried chicken and waffles. My roommates opted for the crispy potato pancakes with house smoked salmon and wild maine blueberry pancakes with warm maple butter. Everything came out pretty quickly and was absolutely delicious. I had a bite of each of my roommates' entrees in addition to eating half of mine (had to take the other half to go since I was so full).While I'm not a fan of smoked salmon for breakfast, the crispy potato pancake was still delicious and served hot with the perfect amount of crunch. The blueberry pancakes were also great--sweet, fluffy, and decadent with the blueberry topping, powdered sugar, and amazing maple butter. The fried chicken and waffles were hands down the best dish out of the three and the best I've ever had. While other restaurants typically serve fried chicken on the bone, the fried chicken here was boneless, flavorful, and covered in a delicious glaze. Adding the warm maple butter and fluffy waffle completed the dish.I ate my leftovers the next day at work and all of my coworkers were commenting on how delicious it smelled. Head over to this place for the fried chicken and waffles and you won't regret it. Great food! Definitely recommended. Wait is really long though so go early. We came here for an early dinner since tales of their brunch line was too formidable for us to attempt. Even so, a line had already formed outside and soon it was a full house inside. Food was good, not amazing, and service was mediocre. I had the Sugar Bacon Burger with sweet potato fries, and we shared an order of the Blueberry Pancake that came with their divine maple butter. The burger was pretty basic, but the sugar bacon was extraordinary, thick-cut and beautifully caramelized. The pancakes were fluffy because of whipped egg whites folded into the batter, but surprisingly bland. They really needed the butter syrup to heighten their taste. Use it wisely because extra butter will cost you, and then the blandness of the pancake starts to peek through.Overall a novelty to try once, and the LES lends a lot to explore afterwards, but I probably won't visit them again due to brunch/dinner lines and quality factor. 3.5 StarsI don't know what to think of this place with all the high reviews, so I had to check it out myself. I was craving pancakes and therefore I got myself the pancakes with warm maple butter and banana walnut ($15). I personally thought it was okay and not the best I ever had. I think I'm too spoiled with SF brunch scene that this place just doesn't cut it. As for service, it was okay at times and other time we had to waive them down. I ended up not finishing my pancakes and some random guy looking in from the window was starring at my pancakes so I nodded my head for approval and he came right into the restaurant to get it. Tehehehe **CASH ONLY**Okay, now I may continue my review. My friend was craving fried chicken and waffles while I craved normal brunch food, I decided to bring her here to the famous Clinton St. Baking Co. I ordered the Country Breakfast, I opted for the bacon instead of the ham and the toast instead of the biscuit and my friend had the ginormous chicken and waffle dish. I was so pleased with my dish, the scrambled eggs was delicious, bacon was perfectly crispy, the hash was crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside, a pretty solid dish in my opinion. My friend really enjoyed the chicken and waffle as well. Overall, I'll definitely recommend this place to friends, but only for small groups because let's be honest, who carries that much cash to pay for a group of 5? Anyways, this place is worth the hype and the insane lines during the weekend. Finally made it to the infamous Clinton Street Baking Company for brunch! (...after a 1.5 hour wait, obviously) They are present on the NoWait app, which allows you to virtually get in line as long as you're within a 1 mile radius of the premises. Unfortunately, it said Clinton had a "special event" the day I went and wouldn't let me reserve a spot. Didn't notice anything special event related when I got to the restaurant to put my name down though. My friend and I ordered blueberry pancakes and the southern breakfast. The pancakes are as good as everyone says they are--light and fluffy. The maple butter it came with was AMAZING. I heard multiple comments around me about how people wanted to drink it with a straw, and I would totally agree with that sentiment if I wasn't worried about the caloric intake. The blueberries were also flavorful without being overwhelmingly sweet!I liked the southern breakfast as well. It came with two eggs (I got them over easy), cheese grits, and sugar cured bacon. The portions seemed slightly disproportionate. The amount of bacon given seemed excessive for the amount of grits I got (I know, you can never have too much bacon, what is this blasphemy). In this case, I actually really liked the bacon but if you eat too many in a row, it gets a little sweet. I personally liked "chasing" it with a spoonful of grits or eggs, but I ran out with around a few chunks of bacon to spare. With that said, I did greatly enjoy all the components regardless. The fried green tomatoes were amazing and were gone almost immediately.Overall, it was definitely worth the experience! I'm not sure if I would go out of my way to wait that long again, but if I was in the area and the wait time was shorter, I would definitely swing by. Cash only. This place was packed on a normal workday morning. It was about 30 minutes wait time. Space was very tight. Someone almost knocked down my silverware with her jacket without apologizing. Maybe it would be better to visit here in the warmer weather seasons. The service was average. It took a long time for the food to be served, at least 40 minutes. For a highly rated and super busy restaurant, I would expect less or no mistakes from the wait staff. However, I asked for the blueberry sauce on the side of the pancakes when the food came out, the sauce was on top. The wait staff did apologize after and I got a new plate of pancakes with sauce on the side. The first table to the left of ours had to wait for a long time to get their changes. Oh right, this place was cash only, which was a huge drawback. If the guy didn't ask for it, they might never get it back. I got the most famous blueberry pancakes. It was pretty fluffy, sweet and not overwhelmed with baking soda. I still think the pancakes from Tops Diner in New Jersey is the best pancakes that I have ever had. I was glad for asking to have blueberry sauce on the side. The sauce was too sweet. The warm maple butter was definitely a huge plus for the pancakes. It was warm, sweet (yes, it was very sweet and I could only have a little bit) and flavorful.My husband had chicken & waffles. The chicken was well seasoned and crispy but waffles were pretty dry and plain. Filled with my fellow Jews on Christmas weekend, and they're holding it down! Some points I don't think other reviews mention:- Download the Nowait app as soon as you're within a mile, and put your name down. My wait was barely twenty minutes on a Sunday morning. It's very very easy and makes coming here a breeze. The host is busy, but she looks out for everyone. - Clinton St Omelette with spinach and mushrooms was awesome. The potatoes are great, too. Perfectly soft, but not mushy at all. - blueberry pancakes are among the best pancakes I've ever had. The maple syrup house sauce it comes with is unlike any other sauce. - coffee was not bitter, but delicious. All sorts of milk available, including almond. Tried the mimosa with the blackberry puree and thought it was delicious as well. - great for families and dates. I wouldn't come here with a group, unless you have a reservation.To conclude, this place brunches, and it brunches well. There were afew positive elements from this restaurant and a couple not so positive . The positives are that this restaurant has great workers . It's evident by their hustle and their politeness. Another positive was the fact that they give great tasting biscuits before your meal and I was able to get some for the road as well . They comped my disgusting salmon entree . Their pancakes which I saw a lot of people getting smelled amazing and looked delish .The chicken wings were reallyyyy good .The negatives : The salmon entree was likely the worst salmon I have ever eaten . Before I could even get a bite in I was overwhelmed with a strong disgustingly fishy scent sorta like the scent you get when you are in the Whole Foods fish section. I initially overlooked it because of the crispy skin it had and i squeezed the accompanying lemon on it to cut the scent . That helped 0 percent . The fish was not cooked all the way through unsurprisingly and I was only able to get two bites in . Fortunately , I was able to sample my partner's chicken and waffles entree which was better but not stellar for me to bump them to a 4 star rating . The wait times for everything is ridiculous . For the wings , it took about 30 minutes to arrive and just as long for the entrees . It was not swarmed pack which is worrying if it eventually were to be . You can get unlimited biscuits but man can't live on biscuits alone . Overall this place is a solid 3 stars . Refrain from their salmon entree and eat breakfast foods and you should be A-ok . A place with so many positive reviews is going to be busy right? Well good thing we accounted for it before coming here. We allowed ample wait time and went during off hours to avoid long wait times. Our plan worked and we only had a relatively short wait. We were seated by the window which was nice. Our server was prompt at getting us menus and taking our drink orders when we sat. She was patient with us as we looked through the menu to make our selection. With how busy this place is, above average customer service.Mink ordered the Pancakes with Warm Maple Butter and I ordered the Fried Chicken & Waffles with a Clinton St. Bloody Mary to wash it down. Our drinks didn't take long to arrive. While we waited for our food, the place filled up fast and a line formed to dine here. Talk about good timing right? Our server got our order into the kitchen before the rush so we got our food quickly. The portions were HUGE! Mink's pancakes were very fluffy. My chicken was very moist and tasty. The waffle was soft and just paired perfectly with the chicken. There was also this red and greed hot sauce that I added to every bite of my meal. This place didn't disappoint and I see why they are so highly rated. Came here on a late Sunday morning. Generally, I always see a crazy long line here so I was happy to see that I lucked out and we only had a quick 20 minute wait. It must have been a weird gap in between crazy wait times because soon after we were seated the line started building again. (Yay for luck!)The first time I ever came here was for brunch in 2015 with a bunch of friends as we were planning the bridal shower and bachelorette for another friend. It was in an older restaurant. I think since then, they renovated the place and made it larger because I didn't remember it being located on a corner before. It was much more spacious and the large windows allowed a lot of light to come in. I had the Southern Breakfast with two fried eggs, sugar cured bacon, cheese grits, fried green tomatoes... I LOVE fried green tomatoes and these were done perfectly crunchy. The cheese grits were cheesy but not overwhelmingly so and the bacon was thick and felt filling. I also had the watermelon lemonade which was light and refreshing. Despite how packed the restaurant became soon after our order was taken, I still felt like the staff was really good at being attentive and making sure that we got the extra ketchup and hot sauce we asked for. All in all, a good place to brunch if you don't mind the wait times. Clinton Street Baking never disappoints! I bring all of my visiting family and friends here for brunch (weekdays only because it gets packed & the wait time can be ridiculous). This has actually been my birthday breakfast treat for a number of people. My favorite meal is the chicken & waffles but all the pancakes I've tried are delicious. Mind you, I don't even like pancakes. When they have the soft shell crab special, please order it. You won't regret it!In terms of beating the wait time, arrive early! The usual brunch times (11am-1pm) are super busy and you will wait a long time. Since it was my first time, I decided to be basic and get the two most popular dishes I saw on Yelp photos: Fried Chicken and Waffles and Wild Maine Blueberry Pancakes with Warm Maple Butter. Food: Both dishes came pretty quick and were both served with maple syrup! Fried chicken with maple syrup was a weird combination for me but it worked and tasted great! Although I would still rather prefer it with the Tabasco/red sauce they offer! What I love about the waffles was how surprisingly easy it was for me to knife through it! The taste of both the chicken breast with waffles was so flavorful and worked so well together! 5/5: I just found my favorite brunch dish here! The Fried Chicken Waffles were so good, it made the Blueberry pancakes look bad! Usually, I prefer sweet dishes but, to be honest, the pancakes were nothing special for the price! It does have a very buttery, pan-fried taste to it though. What stood out was the maple syrup which complemented well with the pancakes! 4/5!Interior: The overall location felt like a diner. It was packed but not too packed on a Wednesday afternoon. I really enjoyed the lighting given off from the big windows! Service: They were really attentive. A little bit too much to my liking. I know I take forever ordering but they legit came over to me like 3 times to take my order.Remember this place is cash only!!!!! Luckily, there is an ATM across the street if anything. If I had the money, I would definitely come back to try the other dishes they have! Since writing this review, I've finally gotten the chance to dine at the main restaurant, and one secret I've discovered is to go for dinner! That's right, though this place is a madhouse for weekend brunch, it's actually very chill for dinner, and they still offer their famous blueberry pancakes.I'm still partial to stopping by the bakery annex next door over waiting for a table if it's in the morning. My all-time favorite is their triple berry scone, though the chocolate chip and the goat cheese scones are also excellent. In my opinion, their scones far surpass their muffins. Thought those two new nuggets of info were worth an update. Enjoy! For me to give a 2 star rating, it means I regret going there. As a NY tourist, I was told that the blueberry pancakes here were super good. I got there and was seated immediately at the counter since I was a party of 1. Parties of 2+ were looking at a 1.5 hour wait though.The waitress at the bar gave me a menu and took my order which was fine. But the wait for the pancakes after that was a whomping 45 minutes. I could see the guy making the pancakes too, and was left wondering which one would be mine. When I was finally served the pancakes, they were indeed good. But some of it was undercooked.. also, at $15 for 3 pancakes.. no sides.. that is pretty steep.Things to note:Cash ONLY. This was a bummer since I didn't realize this was the case... and I didn't realize until 30 minutes into my waiting.. They really should make it more clear on their menus that it's cash only. the waitress told me there was an ATM across the street but I chose to walk the 10 minutes to Whole Foods (to make a purchase and get cash back) and 10 minutes back instead of paying for the ATM fees.. because after the ATM fees, my breakfast of just 3 pancakes would have cost me $28 after tax and tip..heck no, I'll walk the 20 minutes. All in all, long wait after ordering, undercooked pancakes, and overpriced food, I left wanting more. This was not worth my time or stomach space tbh. Even though it was hard to find this place (how are you supposed to know what street it's on?!), it was well worth the adventure. The first thing you'll notice is that there's a line, which means that there's some combination of great food and insufficient seating, which is an excellent start. When we went they gave us some sample pancakes, and honestly it was worth the trip just for that. You know how pancakes are fluffy and light and sweet and delicious and make you consider how infrequently you eat pancakes and how maybe you should eat them more? These guys definitely made me reconsider my dietary habits, which is the best compliment you can give a restaurant I think. Eventually we got seated, and since they're famous for pancakes and I had just had my world changed, I ordered the eggs Benedict. My dining buddy got the pancakes, because she's sane, and she got the blueberry version, because she's healthy, and they came with maple butter, because screw that, you're having pancakes, not salad. They were glorious. Buttery, fluffy, sweet, I almost cried when they were gone, etc. You know, the usual. The eggs Benedict were also probably the best in the city, so I guess I didn't mess up too badly in my portion of the shared meal. It came with salmon and the egg was great, and it was an overall awesome dish. But yea, pancakes are the move for sure if you don't get to split two meals. Definitely worth a visit! Fantastic. Ugh I can't get over how delicious and filling this place was. I read previous reviews of how packed this place could get so I planned on arriving close to opening time, despite it being a Monday. When I got there around 930, the place was already packed with people already waiting. My group of 6 was quoted a time of 20 min, which was not awful at all. I gave my number to the hostess and she said they'd text me when my table was next to be cleared so my party had ample time to be there. They won't sit you without a complete party so plan ahead! The hostess suggested that we could wait at their bakery next door and grab some drinks there. Two of us ordered their drinks before I received my text saying my table was ready! 10 min wait yasssOur orders: - regular Benedict and a side of fruit - salmon Benedict with a side of hash browns- chorizo scramble with a side of fried chicken- buttermilk biscuit sandwich- southern breakfast- country breakfast- stack of blueberry pancakes for the tableOur eyes may have been bigger than our stomachs once we saw how much food we actually ordered lol. But everyone was more than satisfied with their order! My regular Benedict was so flavorful and the eggs were poached perfectly. I tried a bite of the buttermilk biscuit and it was buttery and flaky. The fried chicken had a great coating on it and it was amazing. If I'm every back in town, I'm ordering the chicken and waffles lol. The pancakes were so fluffy but very filling! I could only eat a couple bites. Eat it with the warm maple butter that is served alongside! They're cash only so bring tons because you're gonna want everything. We definitely would've waited longer for the food because it was that worth it. Would recommend 1000%! While the wait to get into this place is pretty intense during peak brunch hours, I think the food is worth it! Most decent brunch spots in NYC will have an outrageous wait anyway. The challenge is striking a balance between not coming here starving, but also being ready to consume a large amount of food. I've been here twice, and both times, the food was fabulous! I'm usually not too crazy about pancakes, but the ones here were fantastic. Did they secretly slip in some addictive substances? (Maybe in the incredible maple butter sauce that comes with the pancakes?) Their chicken and waffle was also amazing. Both fried chicken and Belgian waffle had the perfect texture, and there was a generous amount of both, along with the same addictive maple butter sauce that comes with the pancakes. Service was not remarkable, but not bad, and I was way too busy focusing on the food to mind. I will definitely be back! The wait is forever and a day BUT totally worth it. Love their chicken & waffles and Potato latkes w/ salmon! I haven't tried their pancakes or French toast yet but heard they were a must! 2 tips ;; CASH ONLY &&&&download NOWAIT App and line up on the app and when you're closer they will text you to check in so you do not need to wait in the cold or heat forever

There are two Cocoron locations just a couple blocks from each other. Not sure about the one on Delancey, but this one on Kenmare is quite small and toasty. My first time trying soba noodles and I'm glad we chose Cocoron!I had the Japanese Curry with Sliced Pork Dip Soba, and the cold noodles on the side tasted really fresh, which complemented the boiling hot curry really well. The flavor was just right.My boyfriend got the Sliced Pork with Kimchi Warm Soba. Surprisingly, it tasted somewhat sweet. Overall, we had a good time and would recommend this place to others. The staff was attentive and the prices aren't expensive!NOTE: Cash only! We arrived at the restaurant at about 1:30 pm on Saturday. There were not many people at that time. I and my friend chose the seats at the bar and ordered two small size sets of dip soba. The ambience is nice and intimate. The dip soba we ordered presented as a pot of soup and a basket of soba. The waiter would then light up the fire under the pot, keeping the soup warm enough during eating. The dip soba we ordered were the Mera Mera Dip Soba and the Chicken Meatball Dip Soba. The soup of the Mera Mera is a little spicy and a little hotter than the other one when the fire is on. The taste is much heavier than the other one, too. Except for a little minced meat, there is no other things to eat in this soup. The taste of the Chicken Meatball soup is lighter. The meatballs and the vegetable with the sauce soup taste good. The soba is average. The portion of the soba is too small with the small size. I came here after eating 3 pudding cakes, but I could eat more other things after the soba. I think the ingredients in the soup is not enough with the price of $15.5, especially the Mera Mera. I had expected there would be more meat and vegetables. The fire under the pot was on long enough for my meal. Maybe next time will try its cold soba. Anyway, it's affordable but with not enough portion. such a great noodle place!  great place to warm up during a cold winter season.my brother and i came in for lunch on a cold and windy nyc sunday afternoon and were seated immediately. however, we must've beat the lunch rush bc everyone after us had to wait for a seat. We both ordered the dip sobas, which were SO GOOD. I ordered the spicy one which honestly wasn't that spicy! for someone that has no spice tolerance it wasn't that bad (it was more like on the hotter mild side). so what happens is the food comes out with a soup bowl and a noodle basket. the noodles are dry in the noodle basket. and what you're supposed to do is take the noodles and "dip" them into the soup bowl to flavor and then eat. Then near the end of your meal, they'll bring you a small teapot with broth where you're supposed to pour into your soup base to make it less concentrated and more like a real soup thing so you can drink it. I didnt know that, so i had already started drinking the concentrated soup anyway during my meal (and thought it was kind of salty but maybe im just super sensitive to salt which i am anyway). haha i am an idiot.Anyway, great experience and i loved the food! high quality food and great service. they're quick and friendly here! a must stop if you like noodles / japanese food / high quality food! PROTIP: cash onlyPROTIP: they also have cold soba for the hotter summer months Good casual soba spot that will hit the spot.  There's a very extensive selection of hot and cold sobas / soup and dipping options; possibly too many, actually, as it's hard to figure out what you want.  There's also a number of different appetizers you can try.Most recently, I tried the mera mera hot soba, mentai mochi spring rolls, and steamed chicken meatballs covered with sticky rice.  Everything was good.  I was most excited to try the spring rolls because I love mochi and have never had mochi in spring rolls before, and that was a good dish, although there was barely any mentai (cod roe).  Overall everything was tasty though.  May not be your highest quality food, but I don't think it will disappoint either. The best soba I've ever tasted. Always very consistent texture and the kimchi pork soup was always perfect!!!  Staffs are so polite and sweet.  Very cute little place.  Must go early otherwise, long wait. I tend to like this location more, because it tends to not be as busy as the Delancey location. I wrote a review for the Delancey location, but I felt the need to write a new review. My wife and I just got back from Japan. We were excited to try food right from the source. We had friends recommend a great Soba place in Hakone, a mile from the train station. We hiked in the rain and found this little wooden table and watched the river pass as we had delicious dip soba. But you know what? We both left thinking that it was just as good as Cocoron. I have a new appreciation for Cocoron. Had a tough time finding this place because it looks abandoned from the outside, luckily it wasn't! The hours are a little odd, and it was packed when we came even though it was only 30 min after they opened for lunch. The menu has lots of good choices even for a restrictive diet, so that's exciting. I got the warm curry soba noodles with beef, and it was delicious! It's a little unfortunate that it's cash only, that's a little limiting, but if definitely be back to try the rest of the menu! I also very much enjoyed the little cup of tea they give you at the end of the meal. This is the first place I've been to with dipping soba! I got their "MERA, MERA Dip Soba" because I'm a spicy lover. It has "Homemade SOBA noodle w/ Bonito flakes and spicy sesame based soup, Mincheed chicken, Bean Sprout, Bok choy, Scallion, Sesame, Sesame chill oil."I got the small which was a pretty good amount. The dipping sauce was super rich in flavor, almost like a concentrated ramen broth. I loved the combination of the cold soba noodles with the hot, spicy dip!They also gave us some broth later on to dilute the sauce into more of a soup, which was great. I drank EVERYTHING. haha They give you hot tea afterwards which was also nice. My only qualm was that the food did take a while to come out but other than that, great!**Cash only!** This place is excellent. I didn't even realize I loved soba noodles so much until I came here! It was easy to get a table, even on a Saturday night, and service was very efficient. The menu is a bit overwhelming. I had one of the warm soba noodles and my fianc had one of the dipped noodles. Both were excellent. I added some chili oil to make mine spicer and It perfectly hit the spot. The prices are fairly reasonable and the portions quite large. It's only an extra dollar or two to make yours even larger but I definitely didn't need that. The appetizers look amazing too and I would love to try those on future visits. This place is unique and absolutely delicious. I'll definitely be back to one of their locations! I never had soba before so I was a bit hesitant at first. After trying the stamina soba, I fell in love! I definitely will come back to try the other slabs! The food here is worth a 4 but I had to give this place a 2 because of their poor services.  The waitress are okay, but the busboy, I don't even know where to begin!  They hovered over us the whole time and it was not that busy that they had to rush us out.First off, when we asked for how much it would cost for extra noodles for my brother, we were informed it would cost $6.  Which is really expensive for just some extra noodles.  While the small and large is only $1 difference.  If I knew that, then we should have just ordered the large.  Then it took them maybe 10 minutes to get our beer.  It really doesn't take that long and they also forgot to bring us spoons and light the fire for sterno that keeps the soup hot.  Those are minor things that I can get over but then things started to get worst . While I was still eating there, one busboy would ask if we wanted the check.  Um...clearly I was still eating but my brother was nice to just take the check as I finished my soup.  After he came back with the check, and as I was still eating he asked if I was done and was ready to take my dish away.  Lastly he hovered over us to check if we paid our check.  We were maybe there only for half an hour for the whole meal.  There was no need to rush us out, I understand if they had 10 people waiting for a table maybe but even then I don't think we should have been treated that way! Finally get to try out Cocoron as I came earlier this time. Normally when I get off work at 7, it is packed with a long wait time. So how exciting to try a restaurant with a speciality of Soba! Even though put in a small tight seating space, the atmosphere still okay as the food is what matters the most. So we had order the Cocoron's original fried chicken and Soba no Kabayaki as appetizer. We were told that the Cocoron's original fried chicken will come later on as it takes more time to be prepped. I ordered the warm kim chee soba and it tasted not bad but after eating awhile I was tired of the taste. It is probably because I normally don't like a strong soup base. I did also like the Cocoron's original fried chicken which had seasoning inside the the breading as well as out. The soba no kabayaki was so so.Overall, The downside I had was after the meal me and my boyfriend got a stomach ache which is kind of yours the downside since I though the meal was not bad. I would want to give this place another chance and I wouldn't mind coming back to try something different, hopeful before the rush hour. I love noodles. Cocoron's Japanese soba is chewy and perfect for all types of soups. Cocoron is definitely not the traditional Japanese soba shop. Make no mistake. They do a great job staying in the roots which is making good noodles. Great selection of the cold, hot, and fusion soba soup. Must try. What you need to know: - Soba shop with an extensive menu of appetizers, hot, cold, dipping and vegan options - Shockingly impressive menu for vegans and vegetarians - Cash only! What we ordered: - Cold kimchi soba (price for small $13) - perfectly cooked bouncy and earthy soba noodles with finely sliced cucumbers, apples and nori. At first glance, I was expecting a dry dish since it's just cold soba noodles, kimchi, toppings and a poached egg on the side, but once you mix it all up, there is this amazing mildly spicy and savory sauce that coats everything. It was surprisingly good!!! Definitely will get the large size next time, as I felt hungry a few hours later. - Vegan warm sansei soba (small for $14) - the broth is kombu kelp seaweed based but had a very familiar taste to bonito based dashi broths! The soba was topped with an array of vegetables (bamboo shoots, mushrooms, scallions, etc) and kitsune (fried tofu). It was so delicious that I may get this next time! Cocoron was the first soba shop I visited in New York 3 years ago. The hearty and flavorful broth is still so memorable today. Upon deciding to get soba dinner, I immediately proposed Cocoron. Located at the boarder of LES, Soho, and Chinatown, Cocoron offer good value soba meals. They also expanded to a new location 1 block away from the original one.Highly recommend getting the dipping soba! It's fun and delicious. Soup is heated in a small pot and you dip the soba into the soup before eating it.Overall, good and hearty soba. Worth a visit.Note: cash only. I have been looking forward to a delicious ramen substitute since giving up on red meat and pork - and this place is IT!We went for lunch on Sunday afternoon around 1pm; the restaurant was full, but not on a wait. I drink water like a camel - and the waitstaff was constantly refilling my glass - and it was appreciated! They are a team waitstaff and they were prompt and friendly.I ordered the Vegan Meera Meera Soba Soup and my partner got the pork soba dip. My vegan dish was soooo rich - like stick to your ribs rich! However, when you get the soup - you need to eat fast because the noodles get soggy (because they are buckwheat). I think the dip might have been the way to go - but the soup was still wayyyyy delicious. My partners noodles were fresh and bouncey and he said his broth had amazing flavor.We also really enjoyed the Red Cabbage Kimchi!Overall - I can't wait to come back to try the Vegan Soba Meera Meera Dip! Went here with a friend to check out one of the acclaimed dipping sobas.Was this the best soba I've ever had? No. But the experience and the ritual of eating it made it quite enjoyable. It takes a bit of getting used to, but with some practice and guidance from the wait staff we were able to partake in this specialty.Overall, the soba was good and was very reasonably priced. I was a little annoyed at the lack of space as I was constantly bumped into during my meal, but otherwise the wait staff was perfectly friendly and attentive. Definitely worth checking out for a unique dining experience. So good! Lots of options to choose from & best thing about it is that I don't feel guilty for stuffing my face when it's soba. I much more prefer this place over any ramen joint. Sooooo delicious!!!! I have to admit, this place was great. The food was what I was hoping for but the restaurant is on the small/cramped side and there was a constant lingering feeling that they are trying to get you in and out as quick as possible. The one thing I didn't care for were the seats, the seats were like bar stools and weren't very comfortable. Overall, a good place to get solid soba but don't expect to stay too that long because it is uncomfortable or because they are trying to get rid of you.The food:Kamo no Roast- Slow roasted duck after marinated with homemade soy sauce, blueberry sauce on the side. The duck was pretty good, it had a nice smoky flavor and the meat was nice and tender but I was surprised the duck itself didn't have much flavor. I also thought the dish was expensive for what it was. I also wish the duck skin had some type of texture to it. https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=dxNEaJz5nyjwxc7rnQlMlg&userid=Y_iTTjKvV5hLy-880SZzlAMera Mera Dip Soba- Cold soba w/ Bok Choy, chili powder, garlic, ginger, minced chicken, scallion, sesame. I thought this was great. The idea of DIY soba was a lot of fun and I thought the flavoring of it it was good. I think this is worth trying but it does come off salty and a bit sweet but still worth a try. https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=WHUbVYjKIPaWw7wr-xRcDw&userid=Y_iTTjKvV5hLy-880SZzlAChicken Meatball Dip Soba- Cold soba w/ Burdock, chicken meatball, scallion, shitake mushroom. I think the dip sobas are the way to go. I really enjoyed the chicken meatballs and they give 5 meatballs which is a good amount. I think this is worth getting as well, but I thought the broth was a tad too sweet. https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=TFNX8lXQUj8C4a9-SsLHKw&userid=Y_iTTjKvV5hLy-880SZzlA Delicious Japanese food. There soba noodles are great. This restaurant is good at making vegan/meat lover noodles but not the one that is in the between (maybe i have visited it too little). One star off because it does NOT ACCEPT CARDS. cash only, which is a bit inconvenient.

This is my favorite soba spot in NYC for an affordable price. I usually get the Pork Kimchi Dip Soba (small $14.5) and it's perfect for a cold winter day. The broth is sweet spicy and full of flavor - just the way I like it. My mom always gets the Warm Buta Hakusai Soba (small $15) and it's perfect for revitalizing your body. It comes with sliced pork, hakusai (chinese cabbage), grated fresh daikon radish, ginger, watercress, nori, and bonito flakes. The portions are enough to fill me but not to the point where I'm super full. If you're very hungry, I would suggest getting the large. There are also different toppings you can get for extra $. I decided to get watercress (+$1). There wasn't much but then again, it's only a dollar. At the end of your meal, they give you a cup of tea which was nice. I'm certainly a fan of this place and I'll be back again! The dip soba is just so perfect for a cold winter! The soba and the broth are separated so that the soba will not be too mushy. I ordered the Mera Mera dip soba. The broth has full flavor, quite thick, a little spicy, and more of a fusion style.My friend ordered the Chicken Meatball dip soba, which I happened to like it more than their Top 1 Mera Mera. The broth is milder and thinner. You can taste more of the soy sauce and more of a traditional Japanese style. MY FAVORITE PLACE EVER. I always get two things:Soba no KaboyakiVegan mera mera dipDon't question it, just do it. I wish there was a Cocoron in Toronto because I would be a regular. Ever since I left Tokyo in 2012, I've been looking for a place to get high-quality soba. I'm originally from Toronto, so my search was pretty unsuccessful. Lo and behold, after a tiring day in Soho, we walked into Cocoron. I ordered the large pork kimchee dip soba while bf ordered the large cold buta shabu soba. The dip soba has much more visual impact upon arrival at your table and looks mouth-wateringly inviting. The soba noodles instantly triggered my nostalgia upon first bite. I was so happy to be reminded of how amazing soba noodles are. The broth was delicious, hearty, and well-seasoned. It is not spicy at all, despite how it looks. I highly recommend ordering the pork kimchee dip soba on a cold winter day to warm you up!My boyfriend also enjoyed his cold soba, but agreed that my dish was much better. Also, while $15 is steep for a meal, you will leave very full and satiated. Plus, I've noticed that $15 for dinner is the average in NYC. The quality of food is amazing, as is the service here.We wanted to come back here, but because there's so much to eat in NYC, we didn't have enough time. Bf also wanted to try their sister curry restaurant, so that will be on the itinerary next time. Cocoron is changing it up from all the ramen noodle places around coz they're all about soba. Hot soba, cold soba, dip soba. As soon as I heard they had a whole vegan menu I was sure to stop by.Important points to note: cash only, no reservations, no leftovers (they don't have containers), no takeout. Also, they have two locations within 200 feet of each other (because they're that popular) and a nearby curry focused restaurant called Goemon.If you're going for the first time you should try the signature dish, the mera mera dip soba. In my case I got the vegan version of this. It is essentially a serving of cold soba noodles (there are a few sizes) and a dish of broth that they light underneath. Then you can have all kinds of fun playing with your food and dipping the noodles in the broth. The broth gets quite hot/boiling after a while but cools down once the fire goes out.I was really impressed with the mera mera dish and how tasty it was. Often vegan/vegetarian versions of broth can be clear or tasteless. This one had many layers of flavor and was packed full of veg.I have been back a few times now and brought friends. I've tried a few of the other hot soba noodle dishes including those where they are more of all noodle soup. Although I've liked all of them the mera mera has definitely remained my favorite. I look forward to trying more of the cold soba dishes when summer comes around.The ambiance of the restaurant is casual, cozy and clean. I was happy with the service I received each time and the food/bills came fairly promptly. They can often get very busy at the peak of dinner time. As someone who had to (doctors orders) keep a gluten free diet, one of the things I miss the most is Japanese noodles, whether it be soba or ramen. So you can imagine my excitement when I found out this place offers gluten free soba meals with 48 hr advance notice!Fantastic noodles (great texture, even better than the gluten version), and very rich and tasty broth. I got the dipping noodles (both times) and drank up every last drop of the broth. The appetizers are very good as well, and I particularly liked the tofu and rice cake.  You can tell the ingredient used in the dishes are healthy and of great quality, which always make eating out that much better. The cabbage slaw was very good as well, though if you're hungry (like I was) you may need something a bit more filling.I got a chance to catch up with the staff there during my meal, and it sounds like they're trying to offer more heath conscious options and accommodate for dietary restrictions while keeping with the mantra a of amazingly delicious home cooked meals. I can't tell you just how much i appreciate that, and can't wait to come back again soon! "I want casual Asian noodles that are delicious and filling but I don't want Pho or Ramen or Udon". Cocoron is your answer.  Important discretion: CASH ONLY. I wanted to write "fast" but Cocoron on Delancey is anything but. We ordered at 8pm and they must have forgotten about us since our appetizer didn't come out until 45 mins later. The daikon mocho is surprisingly yummy (and sticky!). I recommend it!! It's like a turnip cake (at dim sum). The Mera Mera is what they're known but and thank goodness we ordered these. I had the Vegan Mera Mera and though it's marketed as "healthy" it's definitely fatty (from the sesame) but I guess I can give it to them that it's a healthier alternative than a McDonald's burger. The vegan was delicious but the original was better (and I think lighter IMO). It was packed on a Saturday night (8pm) but you might have more luck with the one on Kenmare. My dish was~$14 for a small. Note they serve large and small. I think small was fine but since I loved it I could have probably kept going with the large. Just please be faster / better with the service Cocoron! Otherwise you'd be a 5! Soba!! I'm so happy that my bf and I stumbled upon this restaurant while walking to a DIFFERENT restaurant we had in mind. We decided to eat here instead and it was such a good decision. This place is perfect for the cold weather. I got the warm mera mera soba and my bf got the mera mera dip soba. Both are kinda the same except the warm mera mera is soba in warm soup and the dip soba is a sauce where the soba is separate from the sauce. I HIGHLY recommend the dip soba because it was SO FREAKIN DELICIOUS! I was kinda jealous that I didn't choose to order that. Don't get me wrong, my warm soba was super tasty as well, but the dipping soba was way more flavorful and I kept on finding myself stealing some of my bfs soba sauce. The consistency in that was much more thicker since it's considered a "sauce" and not soup like mine. I loved the juicy spicy broth and the minced chicken on both of the items. Everything was on point. Both items definitely hit the spot and I can't wait to come back to New York to eat it again!*CASH ONLY* Cocoron is a great place to go to on a cold winter day. There are actually two branches that are about two or three blocks away from each other, so if one is busy, you can just go to the other. They specialize in soba and you have your options of hot, cold, and dipping soba. There are also plentiful vegan options. The first time I went, I got the Stamina Dip Soba, which has some chicken meatballs and pork. The soba comes cold on the side and you get a huge bowl of dipping sauce/broth. The sauce was very flavorful and warms you right up. I almost burned myself, but it was worth it! You can either get the soba in small or large, but I would recommend getting the large, since it was only $1 more. The second time I went, I got the Mera Mera Dipping Soba, which is their recommended spicy option. It was decently spicy at first, but not distractingly so. I would recommend both the Stamina and Mera Mera, depending on whether or not you want something spicy. Service was fast and attentive, and they give a small cup of tea at the end too. Make sure to bring cash as it's cash only. Awesome Japanese style curry dishes!! The service, presentation and dishes will have you craving more and planing your next visits picks. Food: I really enjoyed the soba ! I got the stamina soba which wasn't spicy. The beef and chicken in the broth was so delicious and juicy! The chicken meatball was interesting. My friend got Mera mera hot soba dip! That was too spicy for me. I love how it came cold and with a bowl of hot soup to dip in. It was chilly out so that combo was so wholesome and made me feel warm. Service: it was alright, the waitress was blank face serving but got our orders within 5-10 minute. She gave us tea at the end. The vibe wasn't like super welcoming like some Japanese ramen places where they yell "welcome" in Japanese. Price: I think for both bowls of soba it was around $26 pre tip tax. Vibe: cozy warm and on the darker side! Located: on Delancey, got off the J train and it was right there! This place is amazing!!Definitely worth the wait at anytime of the day. They do have two locations in walking distance of each other but they're both packed with a wait time that's about the same. Dont be fooled by the sign that says to visit their other location that has "no wait" because it's a bigger space. We ended up waiting the same amount of time at the "bigger" one. We got the mera mera dip soba and another one i forgot the name of but they both tasted really similar and delicious. We opted for the large size soba and ended up running out of broth to dip the noodle in midway. They provided us extra broth to mix in which definitely helped the extremely salty original broth but nonetheless tasty AF. i love salt but the soup broth itself was so rich i needed to cut the flavors with cups and cups of water until some regular refill broth came through. The presentation of the dish itself is very cute and aesthetic so if you're going to do it for your food blog or instagram or whatever, opt for the dip soba over the hot soba served in a single bowl. Will definitely be coming back here for s'more So good and cute food. First time here after hearing my friends talk about how good this place is. No regrets of course! First olac to try dip soba in blazing hot soup! We ordered :-Mera Mera Dip Soba ($13.5)-Warm Pork Kimchee Soba ($14)-Yokozuna Dip Soba (L: $15) -Japanese Style Curry Dip Soba with Pork: ($13.5) I ordered this since it was a must ! Such nice Curry flavor! Just be careful not to burn your tongue like I did! When the dishes came, they lit the little fire to keep the soup nice and hot. And you blow it out if you want the fire to stop So basically the way to eat it is, you dip the soba into the broth for a few seconds, then eat it. After you finish the soba, they give out hot water to pour onto your "soup" so you can drink it since it's pretty thick if not. After your meal, they serve you hot tea so it's a nice way to digest ! The faded fast food orange sherbet awning, with a cartoon face on it and the store windows annoyingly well posted with promotional health aspects of the menu betrays the sophisticated unpretension of Corcoran, with its, in Japanese style, plain dining room in light wood and communal seating.Despite the bad curb appeal, there was a small line to get in a few minutes before the doors opened for business at 5:30pm on a Saturday.  I gradually began being wooed by this place, and it all started with a curry soup with pork $13.  The broth was a little fatty, smooth, a little spicy, with a slight sour tang - it was exceptional.   Nice pieces of pork with egg and scallions. The fried chicken, $5, came last, as I was warned of the cook time.   It had a spicy crust and was served on the bone, and was perfectly prepared.Another quirk of this place, stated firmly on the menu, is that there is no take out, including to go orders.   That made me very full, as I wasn't going to waste one ounce of that soba.   The menu features a bunch of small items, Kim Chee $3, sauted spinach and other vegetable sides with the menu describing their each individual healing properties. Larger appetizers looked equally wonderful, including a savory mochi preparation topped with daikon. Toward the end of my meal this almost empty looking bodega space had transformed into a sophisticated and sleek dining room, and the place was full.The food is special here.I also like that I can get a $3 mini beer pour, it's perfect before going into work. Stumbled upon this place as I was walking around the neighborhood. They sell cold noodles and soup noodles. I loved the presentation of each dish served, very Instagram worthy. The only reason why I give it a 4 is because it's cash only, which threw me off since I wasn't carrying enough cash. A recommendation I can give to the owners is maybe to provide an ATM in the store? So people like me can have the option to take out more money and try more things on the menu ;) Food that's healthy and still tastes good!Feeling cold and slightly under-the-weather, I decided to come here for warm noodle soup. I'm usually partial towards soba, but the Mera Mera and Vegan Warm Sansai sobas I ordered really hit the spot. I believe the sobas are made from scratch, so the chewy texture is just right. The broths are also simple, light, but not bland.I'd love to try the cold sobas next time on a warm sunny day. Never had soba before this but I'd have to say this was SOBA-YUM. I've always walked pass this small spot in LES but I've never gotten to try it, but this is definitely one of my goto spots in the area to grab food. They have a wide variety of soba noodles weather its cold, hot, or dip soba. I tried the Mera Mera dip soba since I didn't know what to get and it was the most popular dip soba on the menu. The soba noodles were fresh and tasty. The broth itself was filled with flavor. It was so comforting to eat on a cold day!! If you're someone who takes forever like me to eat, make sure to not be on your phone too much when eating your noodles otherwise the soba will get soggy LOL. Also one of the perks of the dip soba is that you can dip each bite in the broth before eating so that each bite will be to your liking and that the noodles won't have to sit in the broth the whole time for it to get soggy fast. One thing to note is that the restaurant is cash only so make sure you get cash before coming here! This is one of there newer locations and I cannot get enough of Cocoron. All the locations are convenient and close to my area of interest. I have went countless of times and always order the same items. The Homemade Tofu, Mera Mera Dip Soba (Hands down, the best one!), Chicken Meatballs. The service is usually great every time I go. They have a very interesting menu giving vegans, vegetarians etc. great options. My vegan best friend approves. They are about to create some gluten free dishes too. Definitely recommend it to my diet restricted friends. The Homemade Tofu is served with a side of bonito flakes, seaweed, scallion and ginger. I recommend trying to get each component into one bite. It could be hard since the little wooden spoon is the size of your nail. I prefer heavier flavors so I like to add a drop of soy sauce onto each bite. The Mera Mera Dip Soba has a flavorful kick to it and it's heavily seasoned and thick for you to dip your plain soba noodles into it. The soup will be too salty to drink until later when they give you hot water to dilute it into a filtered level. You may ask them to bring you the hot water to adjust to your liking. I also like adding additional vegetables to my broth.  The Chicken Meatballs takes a good 20 minutes and longer when it's busy. I always like eating this appetizer but it's sad that it always comes out after I finish my entire meal. I wished they'd have some new items for desserts though. I usually get the same desserts. The affogato is served with a small amount of green tea. The dessert is mostly corn flakes, homemade matcha ice-cream, mochi and sweet red beans. My favorite palette cleanser is the coconut milk is a bowl of coconut milk poured over frozen fruits such as berries, peaches, bananas and mint. CASH ONLY. Yummm! I've never been a huge fan of soba, but that has changed after coming to Corcoron. We came for lunch around 12pm on a Saturday and had no problem getting a table for 3. I'm a fan of spicy food, so I was pretty sad to hear that they didn't have mera mera broth that day. We all ended up ordering the pork kimchee dip soba and all loved it! The soba comes cold to dip into sizzling hot broth that has pieces of kimchee and thinly sliced pork. The broth itself had a slightly sweet kimchee flavor which I enjoyed and the small portion was pretty filling. Will definitely be back to try the mera mera broth  also just FYI the restaurant is cash only. We came here on a Wed night around 6:30. The restaurant is a little bit on the small size but we were able to get a table pretty quickly.We ended up getting the summer specials. One with beef and the other one with eel. Its served with a serving of soba noodles, a small dish with the protein, seaweed and other toppings and a little cup of sauce that you pour into the topping dish. It was pretty good when you mixed it together though the portion size is pretty small. There definitely could have been more meat since you dont get a lot. But the flavor was pretty good.

TLDR: There's a latte here that will get you the most Instagram likes you've ever had. And it's super delicious!______I came here for one reason and one reason only.... the Deconstructed latte.Granted. I don't know if I was a local if I'd be getting this every day, but as a tourist I sure as heck was going to.Starts with an espresso shot.Then milk...that's been pasteurized at a lower temp. It's weird to say one milk is better than any other, but this was the best milk I've ever had. Didn't even taste like milk that I've had before.Then the latte. They mentioned all the notes I'd taste but I just tasted a perfect latte hat was creamy.Also got a little round bite that was cakey and had custard inside. It was a delight to nibble on while I went on the journey of my latte.Overall they are using great coffee and obviously taking special care when crafting their drinks! Check them out! So like many others I went for the Deconstructed Latte and it was actually a lovely short experience. Dine in only so you'll have to find a spot. When the latte was brought out I received a short explanation and how you should be drinking (essentially left to right with seltzer to cleanse at the beginning and end). The service was quick and the baristas helpful in choosing between drink options. The drink: ($7) so I've never had the opportunity to drink the milk and espresso separately so it was interesting to get to the end where everything comes together. Definitely gives you an appreciation for how the flavors (pungent and strong espresso and smooth elegant milk) come together. The tiny wafer is actually delicious and such a pleasant compliment to the coffee's slight bitterness (in a good way!). The drink of course is a bit pricey but if you want to treat a friend to a cool time without spending a whole lunch affair definitely try it out! The place: It's a great place to catch up with a friend but since the space is small I'd suggest do it at a slower time. One of the things I hate about hanging around coffee shops is the coffee stench that lingers on your hair and clothes and it doesn't exist here!! Rejoice for all coffee smell haters (not sorry). Deconstructed latte: each part was delicious, but surprisingly, the milk is the most memorable for me, I would order it again, just for the milk. The espresso is nice too.Not really a coffee shop to study or work at. I think the place has two outlets total.Service was friendly. Coffee Project continues to be the greatest gem in Noho/East Village for a great cup of coffee. Sum and Kaleena are the nicest owners and their passion for their "project" (pun intended) is obvious whenever an opportunity presents itself to indulge them in a conversation about all things coffee. Project #1 is a must try for latte and coffee lovers. It is not everyday you are offered a beautiful presentation of a deconstructed latte which allows you to experience the full espresso taste when imbibing a milk-based coffee drink. Their nitro brew was the one of the first and best before all the other local spots started adding it to their own menus. Make sure you go early for the deconstructed latte as space is a premium. It is merely part of its charm.  Coffee Project is a coffee destination worth going out of your way to visit. Love this coffee shop!  Such unique drinks and cute interior.  It is very small inside so hopefully you are lucky to snag a seat because you do need a seat for the deconstructed latte.  The first time I just happen to stumble upon this place as I was exploring East Village by myself but after trying it, I knew I had to bring my other half of #teamalwayshangry to this spot. One of their specialties is a deconstructed latte.  It starts with a shot of espresso, warm milk, then the actual latte and it comes with sparkling water to cleanse the palette and a nice waffle cookie was a treat.  It is beautifully displayed in these lovely glasses on a tray.  After they serve you, they will take the time to take you through how you should enjoy this experience.  Shot of espresso first, then the milk, then the latte.  The shot of espresso is not that bitter and is very enjoyable.  But the milk, it is milk like you have not tasted before.  I feel like this is the kind of milk you need each nice to have a good night's rest.  Then you come to the latte, probably one of the best lattes you will have.  I don't know if it is the temperature or what but they really have perfected the art of it.  I wish I could start all my Saturdays or Sundays with that deconstructed latte as you just immerse yourself in the experience and enjoy coffee like you have never before.  Highly recommend! Amazing coffee! I do think the deconstructed latte is a bit unnecessary - the regular latte is awesome on its own - but it's definitely fun. Honestly worth it for the waffle cookie. Pastries are incredible, too; I loved the berry scone and almond croissant. They get some of their stuff from Roberta's so don't miss that sticky bun if you've never had it. Super friendly baristas and great service! WARNING: Not a coffee expert!However, Coffee Project is the kind of place that can be enjoyed by java newbies and connoisseurs alike. My friend who is an avid coffee drinker frequents the place, so I had to give it a try.The deconstructed latte (aka Project One) is an ingenious move, borrowing from the modernist fine dining playbook. As with most coffee drinks, a latte is a deceptively simple cocktail of espresso and steamed milk. This format forces the drinker to taste each ingredient almost like a wine tasting, searching for nutty notes among the bitter ones in the espresso and different hints of sweetness in the creamiest milk.As this "third wave" of coffee continues to bring quality coffee, it can be easy to get lost in the chaos. At any rate, I would beseech you not to overlook Coffee Project, as its innovative presentation and all-around charm make it stand out. I'm a big coffee drinker. Also a little stuck up when it comes to the type of coffee I drink too..but surprisingly I was not in the mood for getting coffee when I came to coffee project *gasp*I read some great things about a lot of the items on their menu, and wanted to give the hot chocolate a whirl. It was just that kind of day. Couldn't drink any more caffeine, you know?First off, the gentleman who made my drink was just lovely. The place itself is tiny, but on a rainy sunday afternoon there was actually a table open. Also had two or three counter seats for solo drinkers to come hang.I decided to take my hot chocolate to go, but I could see this place getting very crowded during popular times. So drum roll please...the hot chocolate was *pretty* good but definitely not the best I've had in NY. A solid choice if you want a nice dark chocolate drink, but no frill. Whipped cream. Anything. Simple, delicious, but don't think I would get again if I were to come back.Definitely coming back for a deconstructed latte. Looked amazing and I'm intrigued. Innovative and memorable coffee shop experience in NYC. We came here because we wanted to try the specialty drinks: deconstructed latte and the nitro brew (+/- cream).The coffees were made well and delicious. I enjoyed the nitro brew a lot, it was smooth and creamy. The deconstructed latte was an interesting concept, and I liked that it came with a crispy waffle. However the espresso and the latte themselves were pretty standard. The $7 price is fair given that this is not your usual coffee experience.Would recommend for someone who enjoys coffee and is looking for an out of the ordinary presentation. Love would be an understatement.New York City is blessed with an incessant amount of good coffee shops. My coffee taste buds are borderline numb, but Coffee Project has revived it back to life. I got the deconstructed latte ($7), which I think is an incredible concept. You get an espresso shot, a frothy milk, a latte (mix of the two), and sparkling water to help cleanse your palette. Don't worry, someone will walk you through what you're getting and what order they recommend you drinking it in. The espresso shot and milk were both great on its own, and the latte was really great as well. I just love that you can taste the individual components before tasting it mixed together, because you get three very different tastes. The service was also really great. There's not a ton of seating inside the shop, so getting a flight can become an issue if you go at a really busy time.I'll definitely be back to try the cold brew flight and their individual espresso drinks. My friend and I first stumbled upon this place without knowing how much others rave about it. People here are so welcoming and knowledgeable about the menu/coffee. Space is a little tight with only a few tables and some window countertop seating, but I've always managed to find a table as soon as I ordered my drink. Presentation of coffee is always beautiful, and the flavor is great as well--robust yet smooth. This is a perfect place to stop by for a mid-afternoon pick-me-up or to catch up with friends over a good cup of coffee. This place is awesome. The service was really great.Me and my girlfriend ordered the deconstructed latte and I ordered the chai latte and let me tells ya.I drink a lot of chai lalalalatte and I was like "dude this was a bomb chai lalalalallaallalalalalatte.So I recommend that. It makes you go "mm this good" Coffee Project was the first place I stopped after taking a red eye from Las Vegas on a recent trip to NYC.  I had bookmarked it for its good reviews and especially to try the de-constructed latte.  Lattes are my choice for coffee stops and this one sounded so interesting that I knew I had to try it.  Luckily the shop wasn't so crowded that I couldn't get a seat because you can only get this particular latte if you stay; just look at the pictures of it and you'll see why.  The staff was very helpful about describing what the deconstructed latte was and the presentation was wonderful not to mention the taste.  With this order you get sparkling water to cleanse the palate, a latte, pasteurized milk, and espresso plus a treat to eat as you sip.  This is such a unique experience and I'd recommend it if you want to treat yourself. Coffee Project totally changed my perspective on coffee. First off I want to start by saying the service here is AMAZING. The guy who was working was extremely informative as to what everything on the menu was and he explained the whole process of how to properly enjoy a deconstructed latte very throughly. He was also super friendly and welcoming and let us sample the nitro cold brew. My friend ended up ordering the nitro cold brew, I tried it and thought it was extremely smooth and had a nice sweet note to it. The size was also good for the price. I ordered the signature deconstructed latte and hands down it was some of the best coffee I've ever tasted. The concept is totally unique and the espresso was smooth and not at all bitter. The milk was something heavenly and out of this world. Normally I'm not a fan of dairy milk, but as it was their only option for the deconstructed latte I had to give it a try. It was the creamiest, sweetest milk I've ever tasted and paired beautifully with the espresso and it's sweet notes. As for the caffeine, this latte definitely woke me up, but in a nice fully energized way rather than an anxious, jittery coffee high. I also want to capitalize on the atmosphere of Coffee Project. It's a smaller place, but didn't feel cramped. The decor was nice and the atmosphere was really chill and comfortable. It didn't strike me as a place that tried to force a certain image or vibe, and I liked that.  I also liked the concept of one table left for conversation and no laptops!100% I'm coming back here, this is my new favorite coffee spot. It's a hiding place .... already many people here to drink some thing. We ordered cappuccino and Americano. Taste so mild and good taste. A guy at register pretty nice deep voice and knowledgeable about menus. Good to take a break here! Tried this ginger drink that bubbles/fizzes when you mix it? I can't find it on the online menu but it was awesome! The shop is a little small, but seats are spacious and very nice setting inside the shop. I ordered deconstructed, which I liked the concept where you got to try the very raw original flavor of the espresso before consuming the latter. I also ordered a chocolate hazelnut scone, which was alright. I could not taste a strong chocolate or hazelnut flavor from the scone. Overall, this place is nice, and I will revisit. Almond Milk latte didn't need sugar it was perfect good start, deconstructed Latte was something different and I enjoyed it, a little pleasure if you have time to sit down and enjoy it and it's flavors. Cute little spot very friendly staff, will recommend and will definitely come back! Passed this small shop on the way to soho, and thought I'd give it a shot. Probably the best cold brew I've had in New York! The barista said that it's brewed from Mexican coffee beans. Friendly service and great coffee. I saw that they have coffee flights here. Will definitely be back to try! If there were 6 stars I would!!!1. Coffee is so creamy and DELICIOUS on the first day of snow in NY!2. Atmosphere is PERFECTO - nice quiet ambience 3. The severs are very kind and skilled barista4. I almost broke my lid and they offered to give a new one5. The quality of cups and machinery is High to say the least!

The food here is good. It's Cantonese style with a few creative spins on the traditional dishes. To our dismay, the sister branch on Bowery St has been changed to a hot pot venue. Luckily this location retains its normal menu. The 4 Stars is strictly for the food. Don't come expecting good service.  I had to ask for forks 5 times before someone actually brought it over. The cleanliness is typical of a crowded Chinese restaurant. When making my reservation, the lady only needed to know time and number of ppl. I don't know how she planned to honor the reservation without a name.Among the dishes I liked:-cauliflower with Chinese sausage (flavors of the sausage was really flavorful  and permeated the cauliflower very nicely), -fried shrimp with walnuts (delicious and was able to accommodate our request to put mayo on the side), -chicken with rice and mushroom in a bamboo log, (good as always)-pineapple fried rice-nice blend of flavors Only the DMV rivals this place in terms of how much the workers hate their lives.If you're in this part of the neighborhood, please love yourself and go somewhere else. Updating my review to a 4 stars, because I recently went back and we ordered a couple of dishes that I really liked.The first dish was the Fried Pumpkin with Salted Duck Egg. I was afraid my table wouldn't like the salted duck egg, but everyone loved it. Even the ones who have never tried salted duck egg before. The salted duck egg batter on the pumpkin was so crispy and delicious. It is quite oily and you could feel your arteries clogging up with each bite, but so worth it.The second dish I really liked was the Salted Fish Eggplant Chicken Casserole. This is one of my favorite dishes to order at Cantonese restaurants. I think it could have used more salted fish, but the eggplant and chicken was very savory and tender.We also ordered the Black Pepper Beef Short Rib which was also a hit with the table. I didn't like it as much though, since it was on the sweet side. I dislike when Cantonese restaurants make this dish sweet. The congee is still as blahhh as before. Even though they're called Congee Village, I'd rather come here for their other Cantonese dishes than the congee.I also forgot how huge this place is. Great place for large groups. I think I'd prefer coming here with a large group friends over coming here with parents. It's still not that amazing of a Cantonese place, but the fried pumpkin made up for it. Congee Village (CV) is one of those places where you either love it or hate it.  Of course I'm the former.  This restaurant is a hidden gem located on Allen in the Chinatown area close to soho.  Whenever I come here, I chose to come at off hours.  Whether it's during lunch or dinner, this place is Jam Packed!!The seafood here is fresh and tasty.  Especially their seafood congees.  We ordered the crab congee and the abalone congee along with some pea tips veggie.  It's simple and OMG good!!Remember, you've gotta come during off hours!! 5 star it is for CV!! I can't compare congee village's congee to other places since that was my first time having it. But, we ordered a ton of other dishes and they were all fantastic!
