My favorites were seafood cakes (not sure what they were called but they were crispy with chunks of seafood in it), spicy eggplant, and the steamed chicken with mushroom dish. If I go back again with a smaller group, I'd love to try some of the more exotic dishes. Only reason I'm giving 4 and not 5 stars is because it felt like they couldn't accommodate a group of our size (we were 15 people)--they kept forgetting enough plates, tea, chopsticks etc. We came here for a baby shower with ~60 people and we got an entire little room to ourselves with our own servers and bathroom.  This place seems very spacious and the interior is really cute and oriental. Their menu is quite large. I think if I picked the dishes out it would have gotten a higher rating. Sea cucumber with Abalone Sauce ($8.50/per piece)-5/5 I love eating things that my mom says will make me look prettier or is good for health. Don't think about them too much or else it'll scare you (lol). They're slippery and slimey but really delicious though! Braised Whole Abalone (S.P)-5/5 This is another one of the things that my mom say is good for health and it's also delicious. Young Chow Fried Rice ($11.95)- 3/5 Your typical fried rice. E-fu Noodle with Shitake Mushroom ($12.95)- 3/5 This is okay, very plain noodle in my opinion. Shitake mushroom was good but it only had a few. Live Fish Fillet with Scallion (S.P)- 4/5 This was pretty good. I love the fish and the soy sauce. This came with a ton of scallion and was devoured in a couple of seconds. The best Chinese dishes I have in the US! Even better than the one in China!The congee of the chicken and mushroom(<U+5317><U+83C7><U+9E21><U+8089><U+7CA5>)is like a traditional great-taste Chinese food ~ Chinese food on a carousel. Large groups, generous portions, quick service after being seated and an authentic experience. Does the job. Come here for the congee.  The congee is good. Veggies are pretty good. XLB is decent.The other dishes are OK, but not worth the high prices. If you are able, trek Southbound to Chinatown for better food. The beef chowfun was no bueno. Service is passable but don't expect any smiles or words upon departure. The hostess here is rude, hostile, and a liar. This is not a racist statement: she speaks perfect english but I literally don't believe she understands the definition of "reservation."We went in a group of 10 for a friend's surprise birthday dinner, and my friend made reservations for 7PM three weeks in advance. She then called at 5PM day of to confirm the reservation and was reassured that everything is good. You'd think everything would be smooth sailing after such meticulous planning but boy were we in for a ride. I was among the first group to arrived at 6:45PM and check in with the hostess, who looked up the reservation and immediately told me that there was a 45 minute wait. I inquired as to why, even with a reservation, there was a wait to which she said that by making a reservation, we were merely added to the front of the waitlist and had priority over the walk-in groups. I then pointed out to her that that's not how a reservation works and it just looked like they overbooked. She point blank just said, yes. Keep in mind, between all of this, she kept interjecting my sentences by speaking to others in Cantonese and ignoring my questions. By 7:00, our entire party had arrived. We go back in to check in with her on the status of our table, and she insisted that she could do nothing except go in and check to see what the situation in the restaurant looks like. However, that was just to avoid us because she would come back and ignore us and our question again, and offer no answers or solutions. By the time we chased her down again, it was 7:10 and we asked her if we could get seated by 7:30. She said no, 45 minutes. When we pointed out she gave the 45 minute estimate at 6:45, she claimed that she can't give us estimates because we were ATTACKING her for giving an incorrect estimate even though she was the one with a nasty attitude and practically yelling when she wasn't ignoring us. Then, she offered to get us a private room under the terms that we would order $400 minimum, and then raised it to $500 within a couple of minutes. HAHA GOOD JOKE 1) It's Congee Village, even for a group of 10 it's difficult to spend that kind of money; 2) Why should we be paying extra for their mistake?!; 3) They should be converting those private rooms to more efficient dining spaces because apparently they were all empty upstairs! Eventually, we got seated at 7:45-7:50, an hour after I first arrived, crammed around a tiny table where we couldn't eat without bumping elbows. On top of that, my friend's PLAIN CONGEE didn't arrive until the end of the meal, after we asked about it multiple times while we were eating. Looks like poor service was the theme for the night. Although we had a filling meal for less than $200 ($500 minimum are you fucking kidding me), the food was not as good as I remember from Congee Bowery days. SO upset that the Bowery location has changed to a hotpot place and we had to deal with the horrible, horrible hostess here. Needless to say, I will be staying away from this awful place, but unfortunately, I know there will still be an endless flood of people who will suffer the abuse of the nasty hostess to keep this place in business. There are more than congee to offer in this restaurant! So many more great dishes!!After I walk in through the entrance door, I see huge open space including upper dining area and lower dining area connected with stairs with original decorations. Dishes from XO sauce roasted ribs, strip steaks, steamed fishes, fried shrimps, squid, crabs steamed rice, to stir fry vegetables, steam pot tofu with veggies and mushrooms, styles of congees, ...etc. So many choices, and are fairly good. I would take friends gathering to this restaurant, for it's friendly and welcoming ambiance, and for the delicious food and variety of choices.Note: phone connection becomes weak if you take seats downstairs.This place is great for families gathering and Eastern style wedding banquet! Is it 9 pm on a Friday night, and all the shots you've taken for your Chitalian* brother from another mother's birthday are starting to catch up to you? Do you need a last-minute table for 12 drunk people in lower Manhattan before things get really ugly?Congee Village has you covered.This place is MASSIVE. It's a labyrinthian maze of raucous group dinners, and there's basically always a table available for you when you forgot to make reservations for someone's big birthday dinner.Is this the best Chinese you've ever had? Probably not. But I'm never sad about some salt & pepper squid, house special chicken, noodles of all kinds, and of course, my favorite White Man Chicken courtesy of the honorable General Tso. All these things taste good, as does the massive amount of watermelon they brought us for the birthday boy (which he subsequently shoved into his mouth all at once like a champion).And the best part of all this? Congee Village has a full bar so you can keep the party going with more than just Tsing Tao. Although I always have a few Tsing Taos, because when in Congee Village...I guess I drink Tsing Tao. I dunno. ____________*You know, your standard half-Italian half-Chinese friend that we all have. Be ready for a very noisy and packed restaurant. It's always busy at Congee Village. The place is bustling and it's action packed. Food is flying out of the kitchen, people are always waiting for a table, and there are so many waiters zipping by. Efficiency is the mantra here.The food is a solid 4 stars - authentic, delicious Chinese food served hot! The sticky rice with crab, lobster with e-mein, Congee, Peking duck, and morning glory veggies are my go to dishes. Tasty and warms the soul!They have private dining rooms but they require a reservation. The private rooms are great. It feels like dining in someone's living room and it certainly shields the noise.Not great for a date but fun for dinner with friends or family.Oh, and the peanut crepe dessert is amazing! The food was amazing, the prices were really good too. The service was atrocious. We were a party of 7, got 2 menus and were promptly ignored. I finally had to wave down the manager to ask if we had a server. He took our order and never came back to check. The guys who ran our food out were annoyed when we'd ask for napkins and water. We thought our meal was free when nobody bothered to give us a check. But I hunted the manager down to get our check. Worst service I have ever received. A great porridge place in Chinatown. A bowl is usually about $6. If you have a small party, you will end up in a tiny space in the back corner but people actually come around pretty often it is okay. If you want to order entree, u might want to come with more people. It can easily get a bit pricy. For those low rate yelpers--I'm speechless to your comments. I really agree with what Isabel L. said in her review, "you come in a Chinese restaurant expecting efficiency, not baby coddling". On point bro. Efficiency is an attitude for almost all the Chinese, so stop complaining about how shitty the service is or stuff like that -- actually, the service is quite good here in my opinion, the waiters are easy-going and considerate.So, as a Cantonese who is born and raised in Guangdong, I'm constantly in search for authentic Cantonese restaurant in the US. This place can be categorized as the MOST authentic Cantonese restaurant with the BEST quality congee that no other place in NYC can surpass by far. Their congee  is exactly the same as that in my hometown. My tears can burst out when I have the congee because it reminds me of home!!! My review is for my takeout experience:I've ordered takeout probably 5+ times now and my experience has been consistently good. They're pretty much no bullshit over the phone and take your order as fast as you can say hello lol. My usual order is the preserved egg and pork congee and lemme say, it HITS THE SPOT. Super simple, savory but not too salty and flavor packed. Ultimate comfort food and Congee Village makes it authentic. My order has always been ready in 10-15 min. P.S. there's a card minimum so cash is best...AND there's a delivery minimum of $10 too. TLDR: slow service; extensive menu; portions are good and food is on the heavier / greasier side, but authentic and delicious--the congee is definitely the stand outHave been wanting to try this place for a while but hadn't gotten the chance due to long wait times. However, came on a Saturday around 2:30pm and my party of four was seated immediately.Initially was overwhelmed by how extensive the menu was, but managed to decide on: two orders of pork, chicken, and duck porridge, beef chow fun, scallion pancakes, chinese broccoli with minced pork, and short ribs with brown sauce. While we had to flag down the waiter to order, the food came out relatively quickly and in a progression, which allowed us to enjoy everything hot.The congee came first and was the best dish. It was the most flavorful congee I've ever had with chunks of all three meats throughout and surprisingly stayed hot until the end of our meal. The short ribs came next and were served on a bed of green peppers and onions. The vegetables had the perfect amount of crunch and the short ribs were smothered in sauce, tender, and both sweet / savory although a bit heavy. The beef chow fun followed and was okay but a bit too greasy for my taste. The scallion pancakes were also greasy but the oozing sesame oil made them taste delicious. Lastly, the Chinese broccoli was served and was kind of spicy although this wasn't indicated on the menu. The broccoli was cooked well though and tasted flavorful.We ended up demolishing all of the food and then had to flag the waiter down again to pay. Overall, would return for the congee and avoid the greasier dishes. Food tasted authentic and think my grandparents, who grew up in guangzhou, would enjoy it. Yummy congee that tastes like how it's made in China. Prices are great. Giving it three stars because it's nothing special, but on a cold day, hits the spot. I used to go here all the time when I was younger but now that I no longer live in the city, I rarely come here. Came here for the first time in a while to celebrate my brother's birthday. We ordered Crab which was amazing. The taste was amazing and so flavorful. Then we also had the Lobster Fried Rice and some cold jellyfish. Sounds weird but it was amazing! Can't go wrong with this place!

Fantastic meal and excellent service at Cornerstone Cafe! Starters included delicious  pot of mussels (red sauce was my favorite), fried goat cheese balls, stuffed clams. The fresh salad with Cornerstone's house balsamic dressing (with goat cheese, cranberries and walnuts) was an unexpected delight.Main courses: the best ever all dente penne with vodka sauce and succulent shrimp (unbelievable!), fresh grilled salmon with sauted kale, grilled veggies.We had to pass on dessert because we were so full...although I did enjoy a cup of REAL authentic Italian cappuccino: the best I had during our NYC holiday vacation. I love discovering these cozy, intimate restaurants in the Big Apple! Cozy place with a neighborhood vibe but top notch food and drinks (with a nice variety) of local and organic fare.  There is a good wine list along with some specialty cocktails.  I had a strawberry Marguerite which was quite tasty which included a thick fresh strawberry/lime/mint pulp that could have been eaten by itself!  Come hungry: portions are big.  The wait was a tad long but there is god service, and attention to detail, so it is well worth it!  For starters we had the butterfly shrimp which were meaty yet easy to eat as finger food with a tartar sauce.  There were 5 or 6 which was no for Sharing.For the main course, we had the steak and mashed potatoes and cooked spinach - this was cooked to perfection, and HUGE!!  We were glad we had decided to share - there was still leftovers!! The food here is excellent!  The service...not so much.We went here because Clinton Baking Company down the street was so packed they stopped taking names for the day and had recommended two places to each breakfast, this being one of them.  It was 2 PM on a Saturday, so there was no wait to sit, but there were definitely patrons enjoying some brunch. However, the wait to get our order taken took quite a while, ad we didn't know who our server was so we waited at least 10 minutes before a server introduced themselves.  And by introduce, I mean no greeting, just a "Are you ready to order?" She was not friendly and seemed like she was over her day.  She never cracked a smile or a friendly anything to us.I originally ordered a hangar steak and eggs but changed my mind since I  read that the steak was small, so I order the 2 egg breakfast, which came with 2 eggs, a salad, fries, and 2 slices of toast ($4) with an extra egg ($2) and the French Toast ($11) instead.  I opted to up-grade my fries to a sweet potato fries thinking it would only cost another $1 since that was the price difference on the menu.  The server did inform me there was an up-charge as I suspected but failed to let me know that up-charge cost the same as a 2 egg breakfast, which I found out when I got my bill.  $4 for sweet potato fries?!The wait for our food wasn't too bad, but we had gotten half of our food order and the server made no mention of the status of the other half, so I as I was about to ask her, she said, "It's coming."  No smile. No charm. Just a pitiful "It's coming."  Uh...thanks?  On to the food...YUM!!!  That French Toast was totally worth it, and if not for the crappy service I may opt out of ever trying Clinton Bakery Company just for this French Toast.  It was piled with strawberries, bananas, and blueberries. It was very satisfactory.  I didn't even need the syrup. The egg breakfast was also good.  At no time during our meal did the server come to ask us how the food was or if we needed anything, and I was in need of a refill. For someone who makes minimum wage, she was not aiming to please. Or even fake it. Tipping is not compulsory, though I begrudgingly tipped her. I may have just gotten the wrong server, so I'll give this place the benefit of the doubt, but I will avoid her service from now on if I come back. The food is pretty good, so for a different server, it would definitely be worth the trouble of trekking to East Village. And they accept credit cards.There is a check-in offer for free coffee if you decide to come here. Delicious. We got the eggs Benedict, which was cooked perfectly. We also tried the baked eggs and they were super creamy and delicious, must try! The pancakes also look amazing and are an inch thick, but unfortunately we were super full. If you can eat a lot, get the baked eggs. Their mocha was good too, not too sweet but still delicious I really appreciate a brunch spot that does more than omelets and pancakes. We got the Eggs Benedict w avocado and the Egg Bake w Spinach Florentine, parmigiana, and tomato. The Eggs Benedict were good and can be customized; you can pick from spinach, avocado, smoked salmon, etc as the base. We had it with avocado, the eggs weren't super runny, and the english muffin was perfectly crispy. Their mimosas and peach Bellini are delicious too! The service was quick and efficient and the atmosphere is casual and cozy. There's usually a line here on Sunday afternoons, but I haven't had to wait more than 30 min the last 2 times I've been here. Coffee tastes from average to bland. I've had better experience with coffee elsewhere. Won't come back again. Heard this place had poor management.Service: 1/5Coffee: 3/5Decor: 3/5 I wish I can give more than 5 stars to this place! I love every bits of it! Never did I know brunch can be so affordable until I have met $4 brunch menu in cornerstone cafe! I came with friends to try this place that is worth all the amazing ratings and particularly, I don't believe $4 brunch exists (salad, fried potato and 2 eggs). I ordered coffee on the side (refillable too, say what) and I was feeling satisfied! My lovely friends ordered the $4 option too but paid additionally for sausages and bacon. They shared some with me because it was a generous amount, but overall we left with happy stomach and wallet! I would definitely come back to try their other options and the excellent customer service is a plus! Love the food, great but small place located on the corner of Ave B and 2nd Street. The food is delicious.  The only get 4 stars because of space. It's so tiny and clustered you almost feel like your eating at a communal table.  Which I'm honestly not the biggest fan of. Otherwise, good service and food. Hey, where'd my review go?... Did I delete it? HmmAnywho, I had the steak and the lady had eggs benedict. Food overall was uninspiring and the steak was small. That's it. Nothing memorable. Corner stone was a last minute brunch option as my girlfriend and I walked by. We saw the cool crowd and smelled the food and said hey why not. I went for the steak and eggs with home fries option while my girlfriend opted for the tremendously fluffy chocolate chip pancakes with their house syrup/honey. The yelp offer is free cup of coffee which works perfect for me I like to have a nice cup of coffee while I wait for my meal. The steak was well cooked and potatoes crispy yet fluffy. And the eggs buttery and delicious. Quite the filling brunch dish. My girlfriends pancakes looked quite amazing and huge! These things were the fluffiest  pancakes I'd ever seen next time I might opt for those instead. I just give those things a whirl. But there were a few options I wanted to try so I guess I need to go back a few more times to try everything cornerstone has to offer. The wait staff was also very nice and very attentive even with having a full brunch crowd and the wait wasn't bad at all about 5 minutes. Definitely a quality brunch spot! My wife was meeting her girlfriend while we visited New York City , so what do girls love to do....BRUNCH!  We waited outside in the bitter cold with a couple of heat lamps keeping use slightly defrosted.  The owner would pop out every once in a while to give us a heads up on when the next table would be available.  He was super sweet.  Once seated we ordered some craft beers and took advantage of the free coffee with a Yelp App Check-in.  Download the App, secret awards will await you!!!  Anyhoo...the girls split some pancakes and the baked eggs. To be the yin to their yan, I ordered the spaghetti with meat balls. It was a quality bowl of pasta that hit the spot.  The meatballs were big and light. Not full of bread crumbs.  Freezing my balls off was worth these meatballs.  Good food overall.  Worth the hype. At least I had a great experience here with my lovely French toast! The environment was nice and the food was great. One of the places I'm going to visit multiple times! Very nice. I came here for brunch on a Sat with a few friends when the original joint we wanted to go to was overflowing, and am so glad I did.We ordered the Eggs Benedict (one with avocado, another with salmon), and pancakes with berries & Nutella. The Benedicts were fresh and simple: runny poached eggs on a lightly toasted English muffin (with the crusts cut off), with a side of roasted potatoes and spring mix. Was it generic? Most definitely, but I'm pretty sure it single-handedly cured my hangover. My friend's pancakes were the fluffiest things I've ever seen, like maybe an inch high each, and incredibly light and airy. I can't imagine how much baking powder was used to make them, but if you want fluffy, order the pancakes. They also had your typical brunch cocktails and bottomless coffee, and caffeine fixes everything.The service was great as well. Our food came out quickly, and the servers were continuously bustling around, making sure that our coffee cups were filled and that we had everything we needed. The cafe itself was cozy and a bit loud, but it's brunch in the LES, so pretty much what you'd expect. The wait here seems to be unpredictable (we waited 10min for a party of 3), but I would drop by again if I were planning on dining in the area. UPDATE: I finally got my hands on their baked eggs. A super great deal for $12 (i got the spinach one). There was a little more spinach than I wanted and very little tomato and onions but the dish was very good. Came with a side of two large slices of bread and baked potatoes. Can't wait to try their other baked eggs Came back here for dinner tonight with a restaurant.com coupon and dinner was delicious. We walked right in around 830pm, no wait. Choose any available seat, server was nice even after we told them we had a coupon. We ordered a pitcher of mojito which was awesome! They brought us bread and salad which we didn't expect (well the salad). The bread was soft and toasty, it was good. The side salad had this glazed dressing on it that was really nice. A little sweet and tangy.  I ordered the Portobello guac burger and my boyfriend ordered the lamb shank. My burger was good. It had 3 Portobello caps and it came with fries. My boyfriend's lamb shank was amazing. I don't like lamb because of the gaminess but the sauce on it was amazing. To the gaminess out and it was so tender, no need for the steak knife. Overall experience, excellent. Excellent when I came for brunch and excellent when I came for dinner! Highly recommend! We grabbed dinner here before our Broadway play and I totally felt like I was on an episode of Sex in the City!Cornerstone is small and has a classic New York vibe! We loved our meals! I tried the chicken parm, mom had the salmon. Our entrees were DELISH, and the portions are massive.Our server wasn't really involved in our dining experience (aside from taking orders and refills), but thankfully we really didn't need him so that point was easily overlooked. I hear that Cornerstone's brunch is the bomb.com and hate that we didn't get a change to check it out! (Sigh.) Next time, maybe. I came by for dinner mainly because they were open and had outdoor seating, and it had been awhile so I thought I'd give them another shot. Despite closing soon our waiter was cool about seating us and letting us look over the menu, and let us know before the bar closed if we wanted booze or coffee, we never felt rushed.The chicken parm hero is good, the meatballs are also solid.Trying for once to be healthy, I ordered the grilled salmon with mashed potatoes and spinach (no substitutions). Everything was delicious and cooked perfectly. Flaky salmon, creamy mashed potatoes, and spinach that was overloaded with garlic- just the way I like!But that damn salmon cost me $26. I was so proud of my healthy choice that I hadn't stopped to notice the price tag and that HURT. For a reference point, Pardon My French charges just one buck more for their oxtail entree, I just can't imagine where this salmon is from or what tales it can tell that make it worth that price point. As a New Yorker, I've learned to realize that Brunch is not just a word; it's a way of life.  I've had my fair share of brunch spots and Cornerstone Cafe is my favorite go-to.  I initially went to Cornerstone because as a lover of pancakes, I was on a hunt for the best pancakes in NYC.  The pancakes are DELICIOUS; so thick and fluffy and hard to finish, but of course I manage to finish the whole plate every time.  Not only are their pancakes bomb, but they have an AMAZING $4 deal that comes with 2 eggs, greens, potatoes, and your choice of toast, which is hard to come across in NYC, where everything tends to be over $10.  It can be quite crowded on Sundays, and was told that our wait would be about 30 minutes for a table of 2, but we literally only had to wait less than 10, so don't get discouraged when you see the crowd of people waiting outside. I went to Cornerstone for the first time the other day and I had the most delicious omelette of my life. The potatoes that accompanied the meal were incredible and their bloody mary is an excellent choice if you're okay with a little spice...which i am! i hope i get to come back soon! Very small and elbow tight and mainly great for couples. My wife and I got seating right away compared to families 3+. For a small restaurant the waiters are a bit distracted and you have to call them over in most cases. My wife and I found this place after we were told the wait time at Clinton Street Baking Co. Cornerstone became plan B instantaneously without any doubts. We sat in seats close to the door which we soon regretted because of the cold air that followed every time the door was opened. The distracted waiter brought us water twice then took a while before revisiting us for our order. I ordered pancakes and eggs and my wife just pancakes. Pancakes are huge and filling and if you are not a big pancake eater I recommend getting just one. The rest of the brunch experience went ok.

Hits the spot!  If you find yourself in the LES, come here!!!  All sorts of yummy crepes and good vibes.   I will definitely recommend to others.  Happy New Year 2018!!! Crepes have actually turned out to be the perfect winter food: easy to hold in one mittened hand while toasty enough to power you through one slushy block after the other. I stumbled on Creperie on my way to brunch and mentally bookmarked to come back. I ordered two (don't judge me!): the strawberries/banana/Nutella and the turkey/swiss cheese/mushrooms. Let's just say they definitely don't skimp on the ingredients. Although the strawberries and banana could have been riper, there was so much Nutella, I didn't have a single dry bite. Definitely ask for extra whipped cream. The savory one was solid but I wish I ordered the neighboring table's bacon, egg, and cheese. Or a second dessert crepe. The lady manning the counter and the crepe station was very sweet; she saw that I was clearly struggling to pick and walked around the counter to stand next to me and go through the options. She also treated both regulars and newbies alike with so much warmth. I'm sad that I don't come through this neighborhood more often; otherwise, I would definitely make Creperie a regular haunt. My friend and I were looking for a dessert place to sit and catch up and we found Creperie, which is open until late. We ordered the Famous Crepe which included strawberry, banana, Nutella, a scoop of vanilla ice cream and whipped cream with chocolate drizzle.It wasn't anything too different, but the crepe was made well with a good flavor, along with the fruits to give it the extra oomph and texture - a classic. I would go back to try some of their other concoctions.My only gripe is that it's a super tiny place and there is a $10 minimum for credit cards. One of few dessert places open at 12am when my friend and I were looking for a place to chill and catch up so we went on Yelp and walked over to this hole in the wall place!It's a pretty tiny place with seatings along the wall as well as a couple seats in the restaurant. Sitting next to the grill was probably not the best idea, especially in the summer but it cooled down after a while when the chef wasn't constantly making the crepes.We ordered the Famous Crepe which came with Nutella, Strawberries, and Banana which was a bit too sweet for me (probably the nutella) but nonetheless really delicious. I liked the fluffy texture and how thin it was and best of all, it wasn't overcooked! I will probably opt for something more savory next time to balance out the sweetness of the nutella but the fruits was definitely a nice touch. I did see the chef make something that looked like philly cheesesteak which looked quite interesting. It'll be on my list of flavors to try next! It was also nice that we were able to sit there for hours without being kicked out. Give this place a try with its many unique flavors. You'll be surprised at how delicious it is. :)PRO TIP: $10 Credit Card Minimum An awesome hole-in-a-wall crpe place in LES which opens late until 4am. I ordered a crpe with shredded coconut and caramel, and it hit my spot. Was looking for a late night crepe place open past 12am and found this gem. Saw the new Canoli Crepe and had to try. Also got a strawberry and banana crepe for the Mrs. Both were great. A real small place so you may have to eat outside. Needed a little bit of sweet and stopped in for the sugar and butter crepe.  Traditional crepe batter and it was good.  I think it had a little bit too much powdered sugar on it but overall not a bad snack to have when you're on the Lower East Side. These crepes are loaded! I got the Famous Crepe to keep it simple. The crepes are really thin, a perfect balance to the strawberries, bananas, and Nutella on the inside. I don't know how they do it, but it melts in your mouth. I basically inhaled it then and there. The Chocolate Lovers crepe is exactly what you think it is - filled with chocolate on chocolate on chocolate. Honestly a little too much for me. We packed half of it to go.It's a tiny space with limited seating, but thank goodness there was no one around when we went (during a snowstorm). Thought the crepes were a bit pricey, around $10 per crepe. Located on a narrow street with a lot of pubs nearby. Once you walk in the smell of pancakes roam the store. Its very small so I recommend to find somewhere else to eat your crepe. Theres a few benches to sit but not much. Overall the crepes were DELICIOUS. Nice dessert place I went to with a group of friends on a late Sunday night following the Super Bowl. First of all, this place is very small so don't be bringing 5-10 people with you. It's meant more for intimate parties. They have a vast selection of crepes so variety is there. I went with the Reese's with strawberries. Big crepe and was made within a few minutes. Also impressive was that they are open late and even deliver.Overall, it's a nice crepe place. I've had many crepes so far and this one holds its own. It's not my favorite dessert place at NY (see Serendipity 3) but it'll do. When people talk about the great "hole-in-the-walls" of New York, they are describing the rare breed of desert place. I came here after some brunch and wandering around the area. I had read some great reviews, but would not have thought much of it from the outside.Thankfully, my girlfriend and I went in and ordered a Fudge Crepe to share. It was made without the seemingly artificial showmanship of other Crepe restaurants, which was appreciated. When we first bit into our Crepe, we were really impressed. The decadent, melted fudge was both rich and creamy and the Crepe itself was thin and soft. It was really great, especially for a $8 price point. I'd definitely come back if I'm in the area! Had the grilled chicken with mushrooms and cheese very delicious would come again for sweets or for another. Good place to take it to go. Holy tamale! These crepes got me feeling all types of ways! The perfect balance of Nutella, banana and strawberries folded in such a light crepe! I have to admit eating this in a to-go-container in a car parked by the curb makes it extra special. And why not? The street is so lively and colorful! Next time I'm sitting on the curbIm docking a star because the whipped that sat regally on my beautiful crepe came from a can. The creperie is amazing. The cheesecake crepe was phenomenal. Tiny place barely anywhere to sit but there is a bench to sit on outside, or be a true New Yorker and eat while standing. Truly no other place like it A LAAAAAAARGE group of us converged upon Creperie last night (gave them advance notice lol) in celebration of our friend's 30th birthday. We literally took up the whole sidewalk and kept ordering all types of crepes until they ran out. Not only were we amazed at how they handled our group, but these crepes were AMAAAAZING, so hard to choose a favorite. Definitely can't wait to go back!!I wanted to share the video but seems I am unable to do so! Creperie... you are the temptress in all of us drunk people.Opened super late, great reward for bar hopping and a great way to end the night. How can you complain about Nutella?Though priced at around $10-$12 for crepes that I can make back in my apartment, I dont care. I need you for to finish my drunken adventure.Sober Patty probably would go for Creperie, but drunken patty does. Just load the nutella, please!! I shared the 'famous crepe' with my husband which is sliced banana and strawberries with Nutella, cool whip and and a scoop of ice cream. My daughter had the Nutella and strawberries and she ate the whole thing by herself. The crepes fill up the entire paper plate they are served on. Delish! They also have savory crepes on the menu but didn't try those although I certainly will next time. Small tiny space maybe enough room to seat 6. Good crepes, cute place.Friday nights are crowded for this tiny hole in the wall, but the crepes were worth it! Not sure how much crepes on average cost but my strawberry banana crepe with whipped cream and chocolate drizzle was $9.80 including tax. It was made very quickly, a good size, and tasted yummaay. You can also get the mix packet cup of hot chocolate for $2. There is a total of ~8 seats, so very very small. Literally a hole in the wall. Go check it out! I would give 5 stars if the guy behind the counter wasn't so mean!!! Delicious crepes! I got the famous crepe :-) Best crepes! Small place adds to the cool factor. They have savory and sweet crepes but I always go sweet. One is definitely enough for two to share. Get the Nutella, brownie, banana, whipped cream and vanilla ice cream. Amazing! Has a couple chairs to eat inside but mostly meant for grab and go

I have been twice. Once for dinner and once for brunch. The carrot hot dog is middling but everything else was fantastic. The monkey bread was especially good. Get the Korean fried broccoli Good brunch cocktails as well. I had a Bloody Carrie, which had mezcal and carrot juice. At brunch the celeriac Po boy was fantastic. Also enjoyed the biscuit. Overall, not that expensive for the quality of the food and how hip/cool of a place it is. Good beer selection as well. Make reservations far in advance Dirt Candy excels in my three core pillars of a great dining experience: atmosphere, food and service. And it earns my two bonus pillars: playlist and bathroom. Not only do they offer a delicious and adventurous vegetarian journey amid a unique environment that's simultaneously inviting and captivating, but Dirt Candy is also filled with delightful quirks that help place it among my favorite and most memorable dining destinations in New York City. Genius.The food here demonstrates how you can combine creativity and vegetarianism to achieve unparalleled excellence. I honestly don't have words to describe the food and the experience. Each course was superbly flavored with a mix of fresh ingredients, flavorful condiments (oh those fennel seeds were yum) and beautiful presentation. We had the five course meal and the lineup included broccoli hot dogs, brussel sprout tacos, carrot sliders, fennel salads, fried asian-style broccoli and more. Look at the pictures for the mouth watering presentation. The service is also brilliant. The menu states that the staff are fairly compensated and also get in with a share of the profits. Tips are discouraged. This is great to see. Complex flavors melded together expertly to create fantastic and beautiful dishes. You don't have to be a vegetarian to truly enjoy this amazing restaurant. They only serve chef's menu. You have a choice of a 5 or 9 course meal. We went with the 5 course, and I left full. Apparently the 5 course meal usually consists of restaurant classics, while the 9 course they usually include some experimental new dishes. I definitely need to go back for a 9 course meal. What we had:Beet dish - Beet balls stuff with some spicy beet something-ness. With beet cake, and some sweet twill-like glassy thing, with some amazing sauces. How am I supposed to remember it all. There were a lot of beet components, and it tasted amazing.Mushroom something and fennel salad: I'm not much a salad person so my friend enjoyed that. She isn't much of a pate' person, so I devoured that mushroom pate with the thin toasted bread that came with it. The mushroom on the plate was divine, and there was some candied pear? on the plate that was ok. Didn't love that. I thought it was carrots. Carrot Sliders and Broccoli "Dog" - The carrot slider was amazing. Had a great sauce with it, and I gulped it down in 2 bites. The broccoli dog - broccoli was really amazing. For me, this course had way too much bread. Perhaps I'd try to ask for Gluten free next time I go.Brussel Sprouts Tacos  - a pile of butter lettuce, a hot griddle with delicious brussel sprouds and about 12 little bowls of accompaniments. Guac, hot pepper, vegan crema, salsa, - ok, i don't remember them all. But you make your own little tacos and go to town. Its a huge portion. and really filled us up.Desserts: OMG. I'm usually too full for dessert, but thats the beauty of chef's menu.. you get em anyway. lol. Chocolate tart with carmalized onions, with a smokey almond (?) ice cream. You'd never believe it's vegan. It was amazing. Almond cake with almond ice cream - also great. Very light and airy. probably the dessert I'd opt for if it were a la carte, bec. its lighter. The service was impeccable.  I'll be back. Dirt candy has been on my list forever and I ideally wanted to go for dinner but i could never find a reservation (says a lot about how good it is). I went in for brunch and was extremely pleased with the food and service. Will definitely be going in for dinner. I loved everything. The moment I arrived I was greeted and seated at the bar. I knew what I wanted and the waiter was impressed that I made a great selection. I'm not a vegan or vegetarian but I'm starting to enjoy food without meat. I will be back to try more dishes from there menu. The Green Huevos was amazing. I've never had a tempura poached egg. It was amazing and the squash biscuits melted in my mouth. I felt like I was at grandmas house. I love biscuits. I don't even know where to start. The staff, the patience, the food, the artistry, the the the the food. The dessert. The cocktails and wine. The the the the whole of it. It's beautiful memorizing gracious dream. Initially I was skeptical, how good could this place really be? Let me tell you it's out of this world. Everything is cooked to perfection with a high level of culinary excellence from presentation to taste, this place will not disappoint. If you want a chic, up scaly evening come here, vegetarians and non-vegetarians alike will rejoice. Coming from a life long vegetarian, I was extremely delighted with the food. We had the 5 course meal and I've attached some photos. My favorite if I had to choose were the carrot burgers and the panfried broccoli (spicy and delicious).  The dessert was equally scrumptious as the savory items. I look forward to my next evening at Dirt Candy! Very creative and unforgettable experience. My favorite are actually the desserts. I absolutely am amazed by the popcorn cake and popcorn ice cream (where does the idea come from!), the fennel pudding (who knows that fennel can be so versatile), and the chocolate cake (there was something inside but I forgot) I also love the spicy broccoli, the Brussels sprouts taco, the tomato cake with carrot bread as the crust, the portobello mushroom foie gras. The bok choy with fermented black beans at first was the least impressive.  The carrot slides are also amazing with carrot bread as buns. The carrots in the middle is so soft and flavorful and full of juice. The five courses is such a fulfilling experience and next time I wish to try out the nine course option. It took us three hours to finish dinner and I can feel the waitress is a little impatient but she did not show her emotions. I felt bad though. When you call the restaurant, you can end up with a voicemail as the option but they will call you back. Make reservations ahead, and be ready to be amazed. Per one of my culinary school chef's suggestions I decided to check out Dirt Candy with my sister during my NYC visit this year. Our waiter suggested we order more than we had initially thought and it was probably more than we needed. Everything was creatively flavored and plated beautifully.  This was a true dining experience.We got the veg monkey bread with smoked garlic butter, Jalapeno hush puppies, Korean Fried Broccoli (wow! punch of Korean flavor and spicy to boot), Mushroom mousse with sauted Asian pears (I could eat this all day), the Zucchini takoyaki (i'll pretty much eat anything takoyaki), Onion tortellini (slightly under seasoned but amazing presentation) and the Butternut Squash Pad Thai (slightly over seasoned but really fun way to present a dish without your typical rice noodle.If you lost count .. we got 8 items off the menu. We were only going to go for 6 (which we probably should have) but I'm glad we got to try such a great variety. They are small plates. They are meant to be shared. So share away! Chef Cohen was gracious enough to sign her graphic novel cookbook for me as well as take a photo. Really cool experience.If you're out this way or if you're searching for a truly vegetarian (and vegan options as well) restaurant, this is a great place to hit with fun and creative flavors, this is the spot. Very chic restaurant - the open kitchen with the wide marble bar is also a great place to sit at and observe the food being made (especially since it is easier to get a reservation at the bar vs. a table)The menu is very creative, and the dishes come out beautifully plated. it is not just some random side-dish style vegetable dishes that don't make sense when put together. A meal at dirt candy feels like a wholesome meal.The yummy:Korean fried broccoli - it packs a punch in terms of spice level!Popcorn beets - the thai green curry goes great with itMushroom - the pears give a nice twistZucchini - one of my favourit dishes, the rolled up cucumbers stole the showBrussels sprout tacos - the accompaniments make the tacos interesting...beware though it is a huge portionThe cocktails were very interesting...if they opened up a lounge area, I would come here just for drinks too!Desserts are every bit as inspired, like the chocolate tart peppered with caramelized onionsNot so yummy:The jalapeno hush puppies - hardly any jalapeno, and a bit too dryCarrot sliders - the carrot sliders themselves were not a winner (I wish the sliders were a little crispier rather than a soft mushy middle), but the gingery slaw almost made up for the disappointment All the waiters were very polite and seemed happy to be working there. It is a no-tipping restaurant, so the service also feels a bit more genuine.PS: the restaurant lives up to its tag line "Anyone can cook a burger; leave the vegetables to professionals" :) To be fair, I am not a vegetarian, but my daughter is and she didn't want to go back. I would describe this place as a great eating adventure! The service is amazing and each course was beautiful. I have learned to cook a great deal of vegetarian food and it had flavor and I never felt deprived. Here, I felt like I was on a diet. The atmosphere was great, the staff wonderful and the drinks were perfect, I think it was just not my thing. Go and try it, you will have a great time! I cannot think of another dining experience in recent memory that compares. Amanda Cohen transforms a cuisine so often defined by what it is not to a cuisine that showcases the breathe and variety of foods that are often relegated to side-dishes and accompaniments.  The restauants logo is, anyone can cook a burger; leave the vegetables to professionals. So true ad so tasty! On top of that, the cook staff is at least 50 percent female which is unheard of in the industry. They make delicious cocktails too. This place makes amazing vegetarian food with an experience but I felt it was way to long. I started at 9:30 and finished at midnight. I got the 8 coarse meal and quickly realized it was too much. The interesting use it eggplant in dessert was really good. The non alcoholic beverage with beets was to die for! I looked online and the next reservation was not available until mid July so I had to see what it was about. Fortunately, if you do walk in right around their opening you will probably get a table as we did with no lines. The staff were extremely nice and attentive. The lighting and decor are so peaceful and great for photos!It's tapa styles so we ordered 6 things for 3. Truthfully probably could've done with five since I was kind of full. Word of warning though, don't over index to the fried section, you may feel kind of woozy later.We ordered the monkey bread, pumpkin pad thai, fried broccoli, zucchini takoyaki, truffles bread with mushrooms, and Brussels sprouts taco. My favorites were the monkey bread, zucchini takoyaki, and the truffle oiled bread. My least favorite was probably the Brussels sprout tacos, the price tag was quite high but overall nothing too special. We were a group of 3 carnivores but still enjoyed our experience, highly recommend to try! Went with family to diet candy, did the 9 course tasting menu for 4 people. We were very happy with this choice. Loved their cocktails! The first course with nasturtium flowers was wonderful and exciting. Most of the courses were good but out of 9 maybe 2 or 3 we weren't crazy about. So overall, pretty good! We had a truly magical experience. Service was absolutely wonderful. There were a few dishes we truly loved - the carrot sliders, don't remember the name but handmade spinach pasta,, the mushroom dish was my favorite!!!!, the beets were yummy, potato noodles were good. The Korea bbq was too salty for us. The desserts were delish! Our favorites were the chocolate onion cake and the parsnip cake! Really couldn't go wrong with dessert here. I've been wanting to come to this place for a while and reservations can be difficult to get. Fortunately I booked this place weeks in advance. The atmosphere is very nice. It has an open kitchen which gives off a nice relaxed ambience but the decor is still fairly nice to keep it somewhat upscale. The food was good but not as amazing as I expected. Don't get me wrong, it's still around a 4.5/5 but I think I had some high expectations for this place since I read about it in some different articles. The plating and presentation was on point as everything looked great. The flavors were very interesting and I even discovered some combinations that I didn't even expect to work together. The two dishes that definitely stood out to me was the Korean cauliflower dish, which my date said tasted legit (she's Korean btw), and the brocolli hot dog. The best thing about this place however I would say is definitely the service. All the waiters were very polite and seemed happy to be working there. They were also very good about clearing and setting our places between each course. There was one mishap where one course took a long time but we didn't really notice it too much since we were fairly engaged in each other's company but you may see evidence in the amount of bread I ate during that time. Eventually they brought it out and apologized for the wait. I thought that was nice of her to do that but then another person who was the manager also came out and apologized for the wait. Now, that's a good way to make us feel important! Eventually when we got the check, they even took off one of the meals for us so that saved us about $57. I was so impressed with the service I was planning on tipping them the amount they deducted from our bill but there wasn't even a tip line on the check! It's ironic that a place that doesn't accept tips ends up being the restaurant I would say has the best service. Obviously as you can tell we really enjoyed our meal thoroughly and definitely place on coming again (getting the garden next time!). I was so appreciative of their hospitality that I felt bad that I couldn't repay them somehow so that's what mainly compelled me to write this awesome review to them. Keep it up Dirt Candy! Very creative! This vegetarian place is on point. Their kale soup, hush puppies and money bread ore a must try! I mistakenly thought it was a vegan restaurant but it's vegetarian. But they made all my dishes vegan so it wasn't a problem.This is as Manhattan an experience as you're likely to get. Cerebral. Prix fixe. I did the 5-course. Some courses were mindblowing, some less so. All were original with complex, layered flavors. Will be going back for the 9-course when I can. I was quite disappointed with my experience at Dirt Candy - especially being that I was extremely excited to try it and support a fellow Canadian like myself! Initially I was required to wait much longer than my reservation time, which was fine being that it's a very busy restaurant although I received no apologies or anything like that. Once seated, I noticed that the chef was on the floor and visiting tables throughout the restaurant. I had read up on the chef and was very excited to see that she was there that night. I notified my server that I would like to say hi, being that both I and the chef are from Canada (Toronto). He said he would surely have her come by the table - this never happened. I reminded him again about an hour into dinner, although to no avail. The service was very lacking.As for the food, I thought it was very overpriced for the portion sizes. I can't even imagine how much you would have to order/spend should you go with more than 2 people. We started with the korean fried broccoli (which came with 6 small pieces) and the monkey bread which was probably 3 bites. As for mains we got the mushroom, carrot and pumpkin dish. The mushroom and carrot dish were good, although again very small. The pumpkin dish was almost laughable - for $20 you receive probably 10 noodles. Additionally, one of our drinks had to be sent back as it was essentially water.With that being said, the restaurant is very nice and has a great ambiance. Keep in mind that the menu prices online do not reflect the menu prices at the restaurant (each dish more expensive by a few $ at restaurant). Perhaps we had an off night.

Delicious food, wonderful and friendly service. Beautiful ambiance, music was relaxing. Such a wonderful date night spot. Conveniently located right next to the wonderful Bhakti Center. What is your dosha? Well, once you know - they have everything for you here. Coconut rose dessert was so delicious. Avocado dip is a must order. Have some tea too.. it's cold outside! Service: 5/5Ambience: 4/5Food: 1/5.I really wanted to like the food here but alas. The menu sounds very sexy and I am confident they pick the best ingredients. The food is so bland though, absolutely no salt or any sort of spice, which in my opinion, is a must for any version of Indian food. Summary:Food - 4 stars (soup and entree); Desert - 3 stars (pistachio fudge). Ambience - 4 starsDo I want to go back? Maybe.. The food was good and a little pricey but it is NYC and East Village.  I had the following:3 prix fixe dinner menu consisting of:lasagna - delicious and it was a big size and very tastymung soup - very tasty and wish they gave me some crackerspistachio fudge - didn't look what I expected. It was tasty but I was still shock. I have been familiar with Divya (the chef) since 2010 when I took several of her vegetarian cooking classes at the same building (Hare Krishna building) - upstairs room.  Then I attended her Open Center Events and food outings.  Been a fan of Divya's and was happy to hear she finally re-launched her restaurant. There have been several versions throughout the years and this was does stand out as the classiest and trendiest of all of these evolutions. We don't always eat vegetarian, but when we do we prefer Divya's.One of the best vegetarian / vegan experiences in our beautiful city. We ordered way too much food so we can sample everything in sight.  It is rare when you come across a place like this - one that makes you forget that it's vegetarian.  The creamy vegetable soup was particularly memorable as well as the apple crumble.And Divya herself came around to each table to make sure everybody was doing well - that as a gesture is something we always appreciate as it shows that the chef takes pride in her craft. Everything about this place is SO important. The atmosphere is classy but approachable. It's like going to dinner at your richer-than-you friend's house. You want to be mad, because your friend's life is put-together, and perfect, and so aesthetically pleasing, but you can't be mad because she's also down-to-earth and friendly and looks at you in the eyes and genuinely nods when you tell her about your peasant problems.It was so pretty in there that as we sat down, my friend said to me "wow, let's fall in love tonight". The waitress smiled but seemed like she'd heard that before. And if we weren't already in love, this dinner would have made it happen.Spiced coconut chips are so delicate and flavorful and important. Waitress almost took the dish away before we had cleaned up the last crumbs and we both involuntarily yelled at her with absolute, desperate fear. She left the bowl, we licked it clean.Vegetable curry was perfectly warm and healthy and delicious and IMPORTANT. I tossed the mint chutney all over it and also had to lick this bowl clean. Busy night for my tongue, gotta say. Side of beluga lentils was thrilling and well worth $4. Beluga lenTHRILLs.Service is super fast and friendly and everyone seems to care about eating healthy wholesome food!Go here to fall in love asap. My time at Divya's this Sunday was absolutely wonderful. Such a cute and pretty atmosphere. Exposed white brick walls. Our server, Cody was SO KIND... personable and made our experience 700x better. We started off with the hummus appetizer and GF crackers. So yummy. Just wish there were more crackers hahaThen we shared the curry & roasted vegetable bowl (as is). Both were delightful. What a great experience. Good prices. Will definitely be back!! This is my home away from home. Cozy ambiance, friendly and hospitable servers, and nourishing food that reminds me of the meals served on meditation and yoga trainings. Date and I had a couple of teas, coconut chips, and shared 1 pre fix plus another entree. It was so filling but not heavy, with some leftovers to take home. Mung soup was definitely soothing, the curry was rich, lasagna was comforting, and the carob coconut cake was a delightful way to end a beautiful meal. Came here with a friend who was craving healthy (I'm always down!) and hated every second of it except my walk across the well decorated restaurant to our seats.Nothing on the menu sounds particularly appetizing, but I go with the summer bowl after my friend says she hears its good. She orders the seasonal khichari bowl, and the waitress, who is white and not Indian, corrects her pronunciation of the word "khichari", and says that this is just for her "future reference."LOL I'm sorry but WHAT? First, I don't think you have the authority to correct the pronounciation of a word that is from another peoples (what are the chances you are also pronouncing it wrong, lady?). Triggering Triggering Triggering TRIGGERING. Second, what "future reference"? There should be no assumption that we would be back again. . .The food came for both of us, and it looked meh, and tasted horrible. The combination of ingredients is incredibly random, and do not play well with each other. I'm not sure if its because they have left out a lot of spices and seasoning ingredients, but you really shouldn't put coconut into savory dishes when it's not a spicy curry dish. It tastes milky oil on my vegetables, but the fragrance of the coconut makes you think of vegan dessert. The sauce that came in a plastic dish was brown and tasted like barbeque sauce so I did not put it in my food.We all make mistakes, but at $16, this was a relatively expensive one, one that came with an incident that could have been funny but in the context of our identities and the environment, actually just triggering.  I'm usually down to go where people want to go, but I really don't want to come back here, even though the breakfast menu actually sounds pretty interesting/tasty. I mean with a dish title of "Asian Stir-Fry Bowl" and baby bok choy with "cashew sour cream" how can you NOT internally scream and run far away? Stopped in Divya's for a quick solo breakfast//lunch. The place was super cute, good for groups and small parties as well. The staff was welcoming, my waitress Ariela was attentive and friendly. I chose the savory waffles, it was rare for me to find a gluten free waffle. It had a good texture, different from a traditional waffle, definitely not in a bad way! I'd say it was more doughy than a regular one. The sauces were flavorful and the greens really gave it that something extra! I would love to go back with a group and try a few things to share. I went this place for the first time and had a vegetarian curry with roasted greens. Oh my got,,, it was the best Indian curry I ever had in my life.  I'm not vegetarian or vegan but it wasn't typical vegetarian food taste like. I am very happy I tried this restaurant that I have been very curious about for many months. I needed a place close to me to meet up with a vegan friend, and Divya's came in clutch. I was a bit nervous since we came at 9:30 and they were closing up at 10, but other than having us put in dessert orders a little early, they didn't rush us out and gave us amazing service.The atmosphere is peaceful and great for conversation. This works for a low-key date or a catch up with friends. You could definitely do a (non-rowdy) group dinner here, too. Decor is rustic elegance, with lots of white tile and beachwood.We started with the avocado dip ($7), which was garnished pretty watermelon radish slices and was tasty. Size is very small for the price so can't say I would recommend, though.My friend had the summer bowl ($16) and I had the khichari ($13). Mine was basically a lentil and rice mash loaded with vegetables, and it was super flavorful. Portion was nice and big-- was able to have some for lunch the next day and it held up as well. I felt nourished and not heavy at all.We finished off with the carob coconut cake ($7). Good stuff. Loved the rich, chocolately sauce, though the cake was a touch dry.Overall, I had a lovely time here. Divya's continues to impress. Would recommend even if you don't have dietary restrictions. I stumbled into this place on a whim, looking for a healthy lung after a yoga class and let me tell you I was BLOWN AWAY. The interior is beautiful and cozy. As I sat waiting for my to go order I was wishing I could stay and take in the dreamy decor. I ordered the Roasted Veggie Biwl and added leafy greens and roasted sweet potatoes for more nutrition. (DO THIS.) All I can say is that this was a phenomenal meal. The veggies were seasoned so well I forgot that I was basically eating a salad. The grains were fluffy and the sauce was creamy. I felt like a million bucks afterwards. New favorite spot. I discovered Divya's Kitchen through BlackboardEats, which was offering a 30% off deal plus a free yoga at the Bhakti Center upstairs with your dinner receipt. I like food and I like yoga, so of course I took advantage of that deal!My friend and I came here for dinner on a Thursday night. We had:- Coconut chips - crunchy, sweet coconut flakes that were sooo good- Focaccia - three pieces of focaccia bread that were dense like cake, and had little bits of veggies like carrots in them. Came with basil-parsley pesto on the side.- Carrot risotto - I got this as my main. I didn't know carrot could be so creamy! They make it using carrot juice and it also comes with basil-parsley pesto. Great alternative to regular risotto which can sometimes be too cheesy/heavy.- Pineapple upside down cake - served semi-warm with nuts on topThis place has a lovely, rustic ambiance with lots of fresh plants and flowers all around. There are some big tables too that could accommodate a larger group. Everyone there was incredibly friendly, and the chef (Divya) and the owner both introduced themselves. Overall, I'd definitely come back for a healthy and delicious meal! It was such wonderful experience of relishing soul food In a spiritual environment. A beautiful, peaceful start to the new year. Am glad I got the book . The lunch menu at Divyas was extremely limited and only two of the four options were available with only one plate left for one of the two. I ended up with the Kichari and my friend had the stir fry (the last one). I liked my entree, they give you a large serving (which hopefully you like since it is a lot of food). I also tried the Carob Chocolate cake which taste a bit like carrot cake. I would consider coming back if they expand the menu options. The decor is absolutely lovely here btw. I'M BACK!! And this time it was just as good as the last, or even better, because that pineapple upside down cake was DIVINE.I ordered the hot ginger tea to start and it was just what I needed on this super cold windy day, the kind of tea that will cure all colds if you had one. I like my ginger teas extra spicy and it was just that, just a hint of sweetness too. My friend got the almond milk chai, real chai made with real tea, more spicy than most - she found it a bit too intense but I liked it! The only weird thing was that the almond milk had a weird consistency that did that cloudy thing you often see happen when added to coffee, much like soy too. Taste-wise, it was fine!We shared the carrot risotto made with fresh carrot juice, celery, green beans + basil-parsley pesto sauce and the roasted seasonal veggies with quinoa wild rice pilaf served with tahini sauce. The carrot risotto was excellent! I normally don't like traditional risotto because I get sick of it easily (probably because it's always so creamy/cheesy), but because this version is made with carrot juice, and paired with the pesto sauce, every bite was delicious. I loved the roasted seasonal veggies dish especially because there were super crispy taro and parsnip cubes!! I went to town with the tahini sauce. YUUUM.My friend suggested that we get dessert and boy we made the right decision. The dessert special of the night was a pineapple upside down cake served warm with crumbled pecans on top. Oh my god, the smell of it as it arrived at our table was incredible. For your sake, I really hope they are serving that when you visit.Another special treat as we were paying - our waitress gave each of us a bar of chocolate because they were promoting it in their store! An orange/pistachio infused with turmeric 70% dark chocolate bar and a peppermint one. So sweet! Can't wait to try it.This place manages to wow me every single time. My only suggestion is that I hope they start doing specials for main courses since the menu is pretty limited - I say this because I want to keep returning!!! :) This place was absolutely delicious. Love the concept of healing foods and they did not disappoint. They serve the water at room temperature as that is better for your body (cold shocks your system). I've been to many places that claim they use Ayurvedic techniques and foods, but this place actually delivers. The juices are fresh and delicious. I had the Asian stir fry and it was one of the freshest I have had ever. The mint tamarin that came on the side was calming and yummy.2 yums up!! If you are looking to heal your gut (or just eat great food), this is your place. Best described as the spot to take your one vegetatrian/health-conscious yogi friend when you're not in the mood for rabbit food. This place caught my eye while I was walking down 1st ave because of the gorgeously insta-perfect decor. The place looks like a page out of a West Elm catalogue with cream linen seats, dark oak, exposed brick and rose gold stainless steel fixtures. But, the best part of this restaurant isn't the beautiful interior, its the food. Also FYI - they don't serve alcohol here. They are holistically-focused on a concept on health and they're consistent with their choice of not serving alcohol. They do have an assortment of health-friendly teas however. Started with the AVOCADO DIP ($7) which came with multigrain crackers and watermelon radish. This is pretty much peperry guac, delicious, but still guac. Loved the radishes. Then ordered the LASAGNA ($22), and my oh myy it was so delicious. Its made with pesto and veggies, and I would've that chosen over many non-veg lasagnas. Great flavors and perfectly cooked veggies, the the cheese/cream was a great combo (not vegan).This place is fantastic, and I will be returning. The menu is a little pricey, but the quality and the care in each dish does make it a higher quality meal. The service was fantastic and I was very pleased. Who said you need a glass of wine at dinner to have a good meal anyway? :) Lovely vegan menu closely managed by Chef Divya. Curry bowl, savory waffles, sweet waffles all wonderful. Amazing selection of unique teas. The restaurant is so pretty and has such a calming zen ambiance to it.  My friend & I (both health food lovers) each got the roasted vegetable entrees with added leafy greens along with a cup of their Sugar Down hot tea.  The tea was so aromatic and heart-warming, wouldn't have expected anything less from this place!  The roasted vegetable dish was simple but delicious - very well seasoned and a nice big portion too.  The only complaint I have is that it's all a bit pricey for food that should be more affordable (aka veggies, legumes, and grains), but it was all good so I'd love to come back and try another dish!

I visit New York City around 15 times per year and without fail, I stop by The Doughnut Plant each and every time. When I began coming here, the only location to choose from was Grand St. Then Chelsea opened up and now you can even score these doughnuts in some Dean & Deluca shops. Look: without a doubt these are the best doughnuts I've have had- in New York, in the US, in the world.  I've tried places like Glazed & Confused and Doughnut Vault in Chicago- which are awesome too, but nothing holds up consistently than the Doughnut Plant. You get a choice of cake and yeast doughnuts here in addition to doughnut seeds (which are these little balls of dough filled with creative creams and jellies. Most famous is the creme brle doughnut which has a caramelized outer shell with delectable custard filling than even the most discerning French pastry chef couldn't deny!In the assortment of cake and yeast doughnuts you'll find some unique flavours not found at standard doughnut joints. Even better are the seasonal doughnuts that change, get this, with the season. At moment, you can find some Japanese inspired doughnuts like Yuzu (in both cake and yeast) as well as Black Sesame. If you live in NYC, then I don't have to convince you. Chances are you already know and visit the Doughnut Plant.  If you're visiting the city- make this a stop. You will not regret it. P.S.  this place makes one of the most authentic tasting chai.  And believe me, having had chai at home, in Toronto, in India and everywhere else that purports to make this Indian version of tea, the folks at Doughnut Plant make it right. This place serves very basic and bland donuts. I ordered the chocolate sesame and the glaze donut and my taste buds were not pleased.The chocolate donut tastes like a basic chocolate donut any other donut shop has; only difference is that it is overpriced at $3.50. The glaze donut was also very bland. I do not recommend place to satisfy your donut cravings. Any other donut shop will surely serve the same taste. Walked 40 minutes to get to this place and upon arriving, the doors were locked. It was an hour until closing and there were people still inside. We tried to read the sign that was posted, but the font was way too small and the people inside were giving us side-eyes. We assumed the people inside were employees having a meeting. I find it strange that they chose to do this during business hours and did not acknowledge us tugging at the door to let us know they were closed even though they made eye contact with us. If you plan on having a meeting during business hours and closing up shop, please at least post up a bigger sign in big cap letters that says "CLOSE - HAVING A MEETING". The sign had a paragraph of words and it was so hard to read. Since we couldn't read it, we weren't even sure if the sign was intended for the meeting.Didn't get to try the donuts, but read they were good. Will change my review if I get to visit again and it's actually open during stated hours this time. The doughnuts here are super unique and really get someone like me excited to try! I was in the area and decided to (finally) try this place out.I'm a sucker for carrot cake and tres leches cake - so you can guess what donuts I got! Each donut was $3.85.The carrot cake donut was moist and tasted exactly like a good carrot cake. Some bites had cream cheese frosting, which I absolutely loved. It's a somewhat heavy donut but well worth it! The tres leches donut didn't exceed my expectations but it was still good. I expected it to be more moist and sweet than it was. There were bites that were more moist but I expected that throughout the donut.Side note, there isn't much indoor seating so this isn't great for large groups. It's designed to be more of an "in and out" place.Nonetheless, both were good and on the higher end of donuts I've had. I definitely recommend checking this place out. This is my go donut spot in NYC, they have a variety of flavors so there's something for everyone. Their filled donuts really stand out here and it's what I love about this place. Most people love this place or Dough (which I am also a big fan of) but their filled donuts edge out Dough by a drop, they just make it so perfect here This donut shop is da'bomb, they have a wide range of flavors at one time. The donut section is in different categories, filled, cake, glutton free, vegan and specialty. These are a little pricey ranging from $3.75 to $5 and they don't offer any discounts when ordering in dozens.We tried the banana peanut filled donut, this one was a square donut (similar to Valhalla to my Orlando peeps). This one was pretty filling on its own, so it's a good choice to share. The second donut we tried was the carrot cake, although I was hesitent because it seemed to ordinary, it was actually really good.The last one was the limited edition Christmas tree donut, so pretty and insta worthy. It's a green donut that is mint flavored with chocolate filling.If you're visiting NYC, this place is a must, excellent sevice, great variety and comfortable sitting area. This was my first time coming before they started running out of flavors! My friend's go-to was the chocolate cake (Brooklyn Blackout Cake) and I was surprised at how good it was!MUST-HAVES: Brooklyn Blackout Cake!* Pumpkin - 3.5 starsI usually love anything pumpkin, but this was mostly sugar. The texture could have been softer as well - it seemed a tad stale.* Concord Grape - 3 starsThis was fine, grape is just not usually my thing (I didn't pick this one). * Brooklyn Blackout Cake - 4.5 starsI wouldn't normally choose a cake doughnut, but this was incredibly moist and rich.* Tres Leches - 4 starsAlways a good go-to! I really love these doughnuts. We made the mistake of going to the other location, as it seems the doughnuts are actually manufactured in this location. The last time that we had went it was during the cold months and the doughnuts were ice cold from the transportation.That being said, I'm very glad we came to this location. Every dought we ordered was a hit; yeast or cake it didn't matter. The yeast doughnuts were soft, chewy, and toothsome; the glazes were spot on and not overbearingly sweet. The cake donuts were moist and not dry; and the flavors were excellent as well. We had a large meal beforehand but still had room for the doughnuts; dare I say they would be even tastier on an empty stomach.I believe the flavors we ordered were the pumpkin seed yeast, tres leches cake, blackout cake, apple cinnamon yeast, cinnamon bun yeast, PBJ yeast, blood orange rose yeast, and the valrhona yeast. I would say the standouts were the blood orange yeast (it was the most expensive one), blackout cake, and the valrhona yeast. But, they were all excellent. I would say this is an astro doughnuts with better selection and flavors if I were to put it into DC terms. I had high hopes for the Doughnut Plant base don the yelp reviews.  We came here after lunch looking for gourmet donuts.  I tried the creme brulee doughnut and I have to say that I was a bit underwhelmed.  Maybe my expectations were too high after reading the reviews.  Potentially if the doughnut was warm it would have been different.  The place has a bit of an industrial look with Doughnut cushions/pillows on the wall. The decorations were funky and cute.   Overall though, I probably wouldn't go back, too many other places in the city to try. God damn you, Doughnut Plant. Coming back to NYC, I stayed in LES this time around. You were approximately 8 walking minutes away. Thus, I stopped by to eat here every morning for 5 days. Star Jones would've been proud. Peanut Butter Banana Cream [$4]F*CKING. CRACK. THAT. YEAST. THAT BANANA CREAM. F*CKING CRACK. By far the best doughnut I've ever eaten. ORDER NOW!Apple Cinnamon Yeast [$3.80]Had the right amount of apples to cinnamon, wasn't too overpowering and not overly sweet.Vanilla Bean with Blackberry Jam Yeast [$4]Recommend this one. I thought the blackberry would be too much sugar but Doughnut Plant just knows what they're doing.My suggestions: just get anything WITH YEAST.SKIP: Vietnamese Iced Coffee. This ain't Vietnamese iced coffee. I know my stuff - my ancestors are even upset with this wack attempt. Nonetheless, for the 4 days that followed I continued to get a flat white instead ($3.75). Approved. I have been wanting to try this place so bad and I finally had a chance!! I'm usually not a cake donut person so I went with the cream blurre everyone talks about and green tea cream filled.  I tell you I have never paid $4 for a small donut but the cream blurre was the bomb!!!!   The surface is crispy with burnt sugar and it had the perfect sweetness to it.  My favorite for sure!  Green tea filled was pretty authentic as well.  The filling had the bitterness from green tea but sweet at the same time.  There are about 5 tables inside and two benches outside (which is obviously too cold for the winter).   I would love to go back and try some more!!! They have another location in Tokyo as well. Small but cute place with delicious doughnuts. The doughnuts are more of a cakey consistency than most doughnuts so they're pretty dense but I'd say worth the price (~$3.75). I tried the glazed and double chocolate ones (Not sure of their exact names) but both were delicious. They also brew/sell their own coffee here. I'm not a big fan of donuts but when my friends took me to this place I fell in love their donuts instantly. I love their unique flavors especially oriental ones. Another thing that makes me keep coming back here the texture of the donut. It's almost like cake and flavors are so rich I feel like I'm having a meal. Haha I usually hate the taste of fried donuts bc of that distinct oil flavor left in your mouth, so while everyone was pressuring me to check this spot out, I didn't want to at first. However, after three more friends said it's THAT good, I caved. And I'm glad that I did. Came by on a Thursday morning, to a very small crowd and line. This is a very tiny spot. Three tables? A bench outside? Grab and go is def what this spot is. Anywho, I wasn't sure what to get. There were so many choices! I'm usually a citrus or fruit-loving baked goods kinda girl, but that day, they unfortunately didn't have any. Welp, fall season brings out the pumpkin, so pumpkin flavor it was. Got that small pumpkin filled donut. The girl behind the register gave me a "seriously, that's it?" Hahha. Seriously, that's all I wanted. In the end, I was surprised by how much I liked it! And it was the perfect size for me to try. I'm still a lover of my baked donuts...so I'm gonna have to stick to my 4 stars for this one! Plus the smidge bit of judgement for my one donut, geez! The doughnuts here are pretty good, but for all the hype... I've had better "gourmet" doughnuts elsewhere.I have a hyperactive sweet tooth, so I stopped by one day to sample their crme brulee doughnut and coconut crme doughnut.  The crme brulee was really delicious - I loved the crispy, caramelized brulee layer on top and the generous amount of vanilla custard inside.  The coconut crme was okay.  I couldn't taste much coconut flavor... The people here are really nice and friendly, and made a lot of good recommendations on what to try from the menu.OVERALL: 3/5.  Good doughnuts, inventive flavor combos.  As "gourmet" doughnuts they're a bit pricier and there are other places I prefer, but I'm happy I tried Doughnut Plant while visiting NYC. I LOOOVVEEEE doughnut plant and try to make a point of stopping by anytime I happen to be in the city. My favorite is the grand street location.
