Some were running late and they were very flexible with us while we waited for the rest of our party to arrive. Once we sat down, Lola came over immediately got us started on our drinks. Lola helped make this whole experience an enjoyable and unforgettable one! She constantly refilled our drinks, ensured we were ok, and offered to provide anything that was needed. Thanks to Lola for her efforts and efficiency; she is a gem! TL;DR: the $31 bottomless brunch undoubtedly draws people here.Like many other LES brunch spots, Essex is unabashedly trendy and survives on it. The promise of inexpensive bottomless mimosas/screwdrivers/Bloody Marys is what likely draws in crowds of yuppies (though more racially heterogeneous than other LES spots) which is how I found myself here on a Sunday morning. After waiting 2 million years in Brunch Time, a floating host led us to our seat by the kitchen, where we got a front row seat in seeing else's food come out except for ours. Onto the food and drinks. I did not get a bottomless deal bc I was not trying to ~turn up~ but I tried some of my friends'. Mimosa was really watered down, Bloody Mary was just way too strong and I don't think any of us wanted to know what their screwdriver was like. Food-wise, I had the eggs Benedict with kale which was ok. They had the smallest poached eggs known to man which were not runny in any way, on English muffins that seemed rather stale. My friend's cheesy grits looked amazing, though, as did the potato pancakes, but I'm vegetarian so neither of those were available to me bc they come with salmon or shrimp. So all in all, I don't think it'd be back unless i were trying to day drink and I suddenly started eating meat, though maybe the food is better when turnt. The service overall was amazing, the second your drink went empty they were there to refill it instantly.  The food however was a completely different story.  I got the short rib hash, this sounded like a good choice but I was rather disappointed by what it actually was.  I ordered my eggs over easy and they came out over hard and the short rib in the hash was about 30% meat and 70% gristle.  For around 50$ the service was exemplary but the food fell very short of what was expected.

It's rare when an establishment puts equal detail and attention into service, decor, atmosphere and food. Excuse My French does just that. Upon entering, I was taken by the warm atmosphere, colorful wall paper and beautiful paintings hanging throughout. We ended up choosing seats at the chefs table/bar where you can see things being cooked. This area actually had built in outlets which were great for iPhone charging during dinner. We started with cocktails-The French 75 (gin simple syrup, champagne and lemon) and The Sidecar- (Armagnac, Countreau, Lemon, Sugar rum). Both drinks were sizable and very well made. The food here is tapas style and the waiter recommended 5-6 shared plates for two. We ended up ordering The Burrata salad, soft shell crab, foie gras lollipops, escargot and duck confit. Pretty quickly after ordering our settings were placed with the the prettiest blue and white napkins i've ever seen at a restaurant. Our dishes came our nearly all at once which made it a little crowded, but it was also nice to be able to go back and forth between dishes. Nothing here was less than delicious, but the highlights of the meal for me were the burrata salad and foie gras. These dishes all came out so pretty & beautifully presented that you almost feel bad devouring them. The amazing decor and detail in here continues all the way to the bathroom area in the back, which is covered in bookshelf wallpaper to give a hidden door feel. Overall we had a very memorable lovely time here and will absolutely be back. The kind of bar you want in your neighborhood.All sorts of tasty French dishes. Loved the bone marrow.Wine by the glass and cocktails for a low key evening.Foie gras Lollipops to splurge.Roasted cauliflower for the veggies.Small place, no reservation. Very fond of this place. Came here for happy hour and ordered the sparkling wine. For some sides we ordered the Foie Gras Lollipops and the Escargot. If I could eat the Foie Gras lollipop for the rest of my life I would. It was simply amazing and hit all of the spots.Excuse My French is a bit on the smaller side so good for small groups. The decor is very pleasant and the space has nice ambiance. The staff also made you feel very welcome. Also they are festively decorated for the holidays. Can't wait to go back again ! Cute little spot. Not much seating space but not bad seating at the bar. Nice decor. Food:Cheese plate; always a great choice at a French restaurant. Hard to go wrong with this choice, and this restaurant did not disappoint with their cheese plate. Pan seared yellow fin tuna with espellete; pretty good. The pepper on the periphery added a good flavor to the tuna. The couscous did not add much to the dish. Duck Confit Parmentier; duck Confit with truffle puree, crushed potatoes and olive oil. A bit disappointing. I usually expect the duck confit to be very soft, with the duck meat falling off the bone. Having eaten duck confit in France may have spoiled me. Unfortunately this duck confit was quite dry and the potato was overpowering. I felt like I was eating a potato dish with maybe some meat mixed in, which is not what I wanted from this dish.If I come back I want to try their crepes. I've been here twice now and I must say--the cocktails are my favorite. The royle--lavender and rose ones are so good. I wanted to try the orange blossom last time but unfortunately, they were sold out of it! (Can't wait until I come back for it).I think the tapas are pretty darn good. My favorite is the Steak Tartrate with quail eggs--mmmm. I loved the idea of it, quail eggs--it's hard to find a place that serves it, at least for me anyways. I would say that's my favorite tapa from them thus far. I also had the salmon and scallops, which I thought the salmon wasn't bad but the scallops were pretty amazing as well. I can taste the garlic sauce and it doesn't take away the fresh taste that scallop brings out. It was pretty amazing.I would also comment that it's a pretty romantic spot for couples who just want to sit and chat. They have flowers everywhere and it goes well with the dcor and their setup. Honestly, I would love to bring my friends here just for the cocktails to sit at the bar and drink.. because why not? Nice atmosphere, not too loud, cute set up, long bar table (my fav) and wonderful staffs? So why not?Highly recommend it if you're trying to find a date spot or bringing a friend or two to chat with. It's a nice place *wink*. Really cozy and great interior. Had the 2 for 1 deal and had 4 cocktail for 4. This happens before 7pm when we went on Friday. This place is a little gem, great food, great cocktails and lovely staff. They always play good music but at a level where can you can still hear your companions. I came here with a girlfriend of mine on a Tuesday night. We ate before we came so we only ordered drinks. They have a great selection of cocktail. I ordered the rose syrup Prosecco and my friend ordered the cherry blossom cocktail. Rose syrup Prosecco: they make the rose syrup in house, from real roses! The drink is not too sweet, it was perfect. They also put real fried roses in the drinks, super girly and pretty! Cherry blossom cocktail: very strong. It has vodka and other cherry liquor. They also put edible flowers in the drink, very pretty. They have happy hour from Sunday - Wednesday from 5-7, so I will definitely be back! Oh! The owner and bartenders are super friendly. I'm a sucker for cozy, cute cocktail/wine spots, and EMF got me hooked! It's a little tapas joint that oozes a profoundly quaint, unpretentious, and charming vibe. It was only 5pm on a Friday, so we made it in for HH and ordered several cocktails and glasses of wine before heading for dinner. The bartender was pretty awesome - good humor, great attitude, and attentive to details and requests for suggestions/recommendations. Wish I caught his name. I'll make sure to ask next time.  The food looked great but we already had dinner plans (and had eaten only just hours before getting there). It's a hidden gem in the midst of all the chaos in Chinatown. Sit down for a quick drink or a romantic date night - you won't have to excuse your French ;) Cute little tapas spot, we nearly tried everything on the menu, the escargots, the desserts, the duck confit, the pate, scallops, seared tuna, brusselsprouts, foie Gras lollipops melted in your mouth. The chicken breast in the quinoa dish was not that well cooked, must've been an off night though. Service was only ok but we had a new server who only started his second day. The French pressed coffee was really good and after a long day at work, I definitely needed it for a long night after to celebrate a co birthday. All in all it was a good place for some food, will be back to try all other dishes. This was a huge disappointment. A group of five of us came here from a day of rooftop day drinking because we saw it it had high accolades on yelp and was a reasonable walking distance away. The saving graces were our server Perry, the Bordeaux, and baked Camembert with fig jam. However, the negatives are unfortunately glaring. I am normally very positive but this one was such a let down. The scallop carpaccio was very bitter, the foie gras lollipops cold, and worst of all the duck confit was bland and tasteless. My friend described the duck the best - cheaply blended and molded. We expressed our dissatisfaction with the duck confit to our waiter and urged him to try what we were tasting. He took the dish, presumably tried it, and came back saying it was prepared the way it was supposed to taste. Then, proceeded to return our half eaten dish to the table, which we left untouched. We found that extremely odd and unprofessional especially if he had tried it like he said. When the check arrived, that duck confit was still on it! We paid graciously and obliged to the automatic gratuity for parties of 5+ but left extremely disappointed. Our friends from the NYT will be writing our experience as well. With all the other wine bar options in the area, won't be back. Came here yesterday with some friends to enjoy some tapas and some cocktails. One of my friends confused this place with "Pardon my French" which is totally understandable, I asked their owner about it and there is some friendly relation between the two chefs.Excuse my French is one of the most beautiful cocktail spots I've been to recently. The walls, the ceilings, the paintings, the lighting - everything screams romantic, vintage, artsy...it's a gorgeous place for a date. I had 2 cocktails here - champagne with rose reduction with an edible hibiscus flower (I felt like a princess) and an Ocean Mist because I'm obsessed with all things ocean-related and it's blue. Both were delicious. I also got to try a cocktail that was dedicated to a French woman who died in an elevator...fascinatingly sad story, beautiful cocktail. They also brought out a special layered cocktail made for Bastille Day, it was made to look like the French flag and served with a pop rock rim and a rock candy skewer to to stir with. Cocktails and candy? I'm sold. Sign me up!We pretty much tried all the tapas and the ones that stood out to me the most were their own-seated tuna and their grilled salmon gravlax with dill citrus marinade on toast. For dessert they brought out a sugary crepe with light orange flavor that had been drizzled with grand mariner and they lit it on fire. Dessert set on fire and drizzled with alcohol? SIGN ME UP AGAIN!! The crepe was pretty good. I liked the texture but it was sugarier than I prefer.Overall my friends and I had a really great time here and I would definitely return for some more awesome cocktails! When we first walked in, it felt like a speakeasy bar but of course it's so much more!  The place is small, inviting and there are lots of attention to details from the pattern on the napkins to the etched cocktail glasses.  Food was good but not the most amazing French food we've had.  There were some misses.  The Country Pate didn't have the savory flavor and I'm not sure it's made of liver?  The other miss was the duck confit served with potatoes.  The presentation looked nice but the duck and potato were dry and we did not taste any truffle at all.  The cocktail menu had a good selection of spirits.  I think this place is great for drinks and light dinner or snacks but we came for full on dinner which it was good overall but we might have ordered too much where we experienced some of the not so good dishes. Okay, so maybe I'm just not a Francophile.  But I really wanted to like this place.I had high hopes coming here, but in the end, I just can't muster up the energy nor the enthusiasm to look on the bright side.  Almost all of the foods we had were mediocre and overpriced and WAY TOO SALTY.The sea scallop carpaccio?  It had an awful fishy smell and way too salty.  The baked portobello?  It was hard as a rock as well as a very potent salt bomb.  The croque monsieur was way too salty too.  The only thing that I could say was decent was the cajun chicken with the side of quinoa and ratatouille.Even the drinks weren't that good either.  Service was good though.I just can't. Small but very cute tapas bar. The service was good and they had great decor. For drinks we got the Moulin Rouge and Bastille Day, and for food we got scallops and Brussels sprouts. I highly recommend the Brussels sprouts and I heard the salad with burrata is good. I've been in this area for years and on this same exact block and had no idea that Excuse my French was located in a little cozy basement. I had dinner here on a Thursday and it was very packed. Don't worry, grab a beer next door at Top Hops while you wait. The only thing that I didn't like at Excuse my French was the seating. It's basically a long bar all the way down except for a couple small tables in the front. As we seated at the bar, the waitress recommended a nice French red that was very good. We ordered a bunch of tapas for the table. We started with a bunch of cheeses and charcuterie. They paired nicely together especially with a little wine sip. We also ordered the duck rillettes which was probably my favorite thing the whole night. We shared a steamed artichoke for the table. Cooked nicely and brought back childhood memories which can sound weird. My other favorite dish was the sea scallop carpaccio. Cut very thin with a lot of flavor. It's topped with salmon caviar and yuzu. For my entree, I ordered the duck confit parmentier which is a gorgeous presentation. It's paired with crushed potatoes, olive oil and truffle pure. This dish was pretty good but I thought it would be better. Next time, I'll listen to reviews and order the foie gras lollipops. Heard they are amazing.For dessert, they gave the table a free crepe. I kid you not, it's because they liked my cousin. It worked out well for me because it was delicious and a great way to finish a meal. I ordered the cheese camembert plate and some type of tartare dish along with a royal lavender drink. All I can say is - simply DIVINE. I keep raving about the herb infused drink and I desperately want to go back to grab another drink and scoop up another tartare dish. The cheese plate was a nice touch too, but I was tired of it after several scoops (split between two people). This restaurant introduced me to what french cuisine consists of. Other french places I've been to typically include sandwiches and salads, and I was always somewhat disappointed in the complexity of the meals offered. Overall, TRY excuse my french. You will not be disappointed. A tiny and utterly charming place that I would have walked by completely if not for my friends who live in the neighborhood and are regulars there. We stopped by on a cold night after dinner, so we indulged only in drinks and desserts, but that was enough to show me the quality of this spot. As for drinks: whether you're into the straightforward stuff or something a little fancier, you'll find something to your liking here for sure. They have a whole menu of just royale drinks with housemade syrup, and as I can never pass up anything rose flavored, I went with that. It wasn't too sweet, perfectly bubbly, and just lovely. The drinks range around $12-13, which in NYC terms isn't bad at all for an upscale bevvy. For bites, my group shared a few crepes including the strawberry chantilly, which was my personal favorite. They also had something called the 'imperial mandarin souffle,' which looks and tastes and extravagant as the name suggests! Again, it's cozy, warm, frilly, and a lot of fun. A perfect spot for a date night or a girls' get-together. I'm a big fan and I think you will be too! Excuse My French is a charming (and narrow) restaurant that serves French tapas.  For dinner, we decided on four dishes to share.  Three of the four were delicious - brussel sprouts with lamb merguez, organic chicken with ratatouille, and the croque monsieur.  The tuna with Israeli couscous was meh.  Appreciated the authenticity and home cooked style.  In no rush to come back but definitely glad we tried it! It becomes my favorite spot in LES!!!  I have been this place few times already and never got disappointed!!! I love all dishes on the menu!  I went there tonight again with my friend, my friend loves the place too. The service is very friendly especially the manager is attentive to ensure we were good.  I definitely go back again and bring different friends to be there!  Excuse My French, please keep it up!  Will visit you soon again!

TL;DR Latino approved. This place is legit.--I was craving Tamales for quite some time and I was happy to find this place. I walked from Wall St to this location.The mole and rajas are so good. The tamales are very authentic and priced well. I got 2 tamales an an horchata for less than $9.00.I spoke with one of the workers and he said that this location was opened up so their family had a place to eat together. Their previous space wasn't big enough for everyone. The tamales are not made with masa.I can literally go on and on about the history of this place but you have to give it a try for yourself. Came here on a lazy weekend for a pre-dinner snack. The restaurant is a small space, but cozy. I ordered a few things on the menu to get a sampler: rajas con queso tamales, chipotle with chicken tamales, and an egg sandwich with bacon. I really wanted to try to mole pablano with chicken tamale but they didn't have any, which was unfortunate. Hopefully this was a one off thing. The tamales were pretty decent. Chicken tamale was a little dry and the rajas tamale didn't have much filling. Egg sandwich was well executed with a perfectly runny fried egg with crisp bacon on a nice brioche bun. Would definitely try again just for the mole pablano chicken tamale. Fingers crossed. They're well known for their tamales, but hot damn if they don't have one of the best breakfast sandwiches in NY as well.Because so much has been said of their tamales, I'll talk about the BEC. The king of breakfast sandwiches in this city, this bacon, egg, and cheese rests between a soft Balthazar brioche bun that makes it just a bit magical. A bit more pricey than your bodega's, but well worth it. Great price for a delicious tamal. Filled generously and there is a varied selection. The space is small and there is sparse seating so not suited for a large group. Great lunch spot for a tight budget! Just happened to walk by and tried a Tamal de Rajas con Queso. It was as good as the ones my mom makes in MX D.F. Eh, underwhelming.  If you want good legit tamales go walk along Roosevelt ave or Spanish Harlem and hit up the street vendors.  You'll see ladies pushing shopping carts with large pots or coolers. Delicious $3 egg sandwich on a brioche bun as well as very friendly service.  The $2.50 tamales are also very delish. It is a very comfortable and warm atmosphere that feels inviting when you sit down. Stopped by since I was in the neighborhood and had heard great things! It was before lunch, so unfortunately I only allowed myself one tamale and that was the chipotle chicken tamale -- piping hot and steamy. I devoured it! Definitely will be back to try all the other tamales, along with the avocado salad (which looked amazing)! Very good prices and friendly staff too Factory Tamal is a cozy Mexican cafe serving sandwiches and tamales. No burritos or tacos here! Its great to see a place giving love to the other great Mexican dishes.  The space has one standard table, one couch with a coffee table, and a counter for two by the window. We came in during breakfast hours but the full menu was available which was nice. My wife ordered a vegetarian torta, which she enjoyed. I had tamales. I tried a chicken and green salsa, a chipotle chicken, a cheese and pepper,  and a bacon and mozzarella. I was slightly skeptical of a bacon tamale, however it was excellent and my favorite item from the meal. The tamales we're decent sized, moist and flavorful. I also tried the the house made horchata which provided a nice compliment to the tamales. Overall decent place if you are looking for tamales or Mexican sandwiches. Neat Mexican cafe that sells tamales in the Lower Eastside. However the name is rather a misnomer. It is neither a factory (for tamales) nor is it solely a tamal purveyor. In fact, there are only three to four tamales options: Mole poblano, rajas con queso, salsa verdes and chicken, and bacon and cheese. When I was just there, they did not have the fourth option. The rest of the menu is filled with sandwiches and salads, making this more of a cafe.Prices are genuinely cheap. Each tamal ran for $2 apiece including tax. I ordered all three of them to try. The tamales were smaller in size compared to Aguila uptown or the Mexican place inside Essex Street Market, but they are rather filling and delicious. The rajas con queso tamal was packed with the peppers and cheese. Decor is really nice, and gives it a feeling of someone's house. There are portraits around the walls that contain tamal leaves and corn kernels, appropriate for an establishment that founds its name in kernels. Welcoming, authentic, unpretentious heaven.Making things from scratch...quite rare these days!I ordered three different kinds of tamales and I'm planning to go back soon for more! All good and flavorful! This place is legit. Best tamales I've ever had. We really appreciated that their menu had a lot of chicken items (as opposed to mostly pork) and they were all delicious. We started by ordering 2 tamales to share for a snack: Chicken Salsa Verde and Chicken Mole. Smackin'! So we ordered 7 more and tried allOf the other flavors ;) Salsa Verde and Rajas were my favorites. Really well balanced and tasted fresh. I washed everything down with an Orchata, that also tasted homemade. The space is cute and cozy. There were about 10 people in there with us. Food is reasonably priced (I wouldn't be mad if they increased their prices a bit). Service is just right. They make everything from scratch including the masa, which was delicious. Super nice owner/chef and would recommend this joint to everybody (New Yorkers, Californians, and everyone else)!Thank you for having us and treating us so well! Very small restaurant but the food is good and the prices are very afforable. I had the avocado salad which was delicious. The mole poblano tamale was pretty good too and it was only $2! The salads are $7 and drinks are mostly $2. They also offer tortas and cold soups. The space is pretty small so groups are not recommended; they have two small tables and some bar seats. Best place for Mexican flavor in lower east side. It's deli style food so you can get sandwiches as well as the tamales that they're famous for. Very good prices for what you get and they even have smaller options like an egg sandwich for $3 which is really tasty. I always get the TortA and just add chicken. Great food, service, value. Tried the three chicken tamales--all delicious. Nice lunch spot in LES where most of the surrounding places seem more focused on the dinner crowd. My mom and I had a GREAT lunch here today. Just 3 blocks from where we live, I couldn't wait to try this spot as I really like tamales. My mom was eager to join me so we took a little stroll in our 'hood to this local eatery. They have tamales mainly from 7am-noon. They have salads and cold and hot sandwiches. They have sodas and hot beverages native to Mexico. We had 2 chipotle chicken, 1 mol poblano, and 1 bacon and cheese tamales. Tasty, tasty, tasty savory treats that donned enough spice and flavor. The masa was great and the fillings were enough to tickle our throats and palettes. The chicken one was our favorite. The mole one had that sorta chocolate note. And the bacon and cheese one was just that. Soft bacon and white gooey cheese. We also partook in the turkey, swiss and pesto sandwich. Pressed and crusty and not overwhelming with meat, cheese or pesto. Just the right size and enough for 2 people who just downed 4 tamales. And what friendly staff members. I engaged with them. My mom spoke a bit with them. We can't wait to visit again and again. I also was really into my 2 fruit punch Jarritos sodas and my mom liked how her strawberry lemonade had bits of strawberry and was not too sweet. We loved it here and can't wait to visit them at this location and at their new location as of 8/15 on 34 Essex Street. Factory Tamal is neither a factory (in style) or a tamale specific restaurant. This small caf is soulful and family owned, serving a variety of lunch plates with an eclectic palate of ingredients ranging from Mexican to Italian. What impresses me most about Tamal is its ability to source incredibly fresh ingredients regardless of its varied offerings. So the avocado and pico de gallo salad has chopped mozzarella...it's bizarre but delicious. The Lower East Side has a lot of trendy places for a salad but none of them plate consistently fresh greens like Tamal does. In addition to the great eats is warm service and reasonable prices. All of my colleagues frequent Factory Tamal and I will recommend them with enthusiasm as they truly deserve the praise. The tamales were awesome. 5 different kinds (we tried all but the bacon one). The mole was so chocolatey. The others were all super fresh tasting. A good variety of spicy and non-spicy ones. Friendly staff. The woman behind the counter helped me under what I was doing wrong with our homemade tamales! Can't wait to try out her suggestions. Tamales are generally pretty tasty but extremely small by tamale standards.  I've tried the rajas, verde, and chipotle.  Mole has unfortunately been available during each of my visits (around 4-5pm on the weekends).  Chiptole is defintely the standout, with verde and rajas being pretty good and on the mild side - unfortunately since tamales are very small you don't get much filling.  However, the corn of the tamale is very distinct and comfy/hearty.  Also had a torta which was tasty, and the horchata was solid.  Customer service is excellent.  That said, I'd probably only go back for the chipotle tamale and the torta. Chicken Salsa Verde Tamale!!!  So yum! Delicate, flavorful, amazing!!! I could eat a dozen. And the guacamole is spot on, just the right amount of spice and cilantro. Delish!

loved the ambience here - feels like you're in an English cottage but with more space.The food is mainly your typical English breakfast with American twists - something for everyone. The egg skillet was really good as well as the French toast.The brunch beverages were average, I usually go for a Bloody Mary but was not impressed here so switched to a mimosa.Front staff and waitstaff were both friendly and helpful. This place lies between 3 and 4 stars for me. There isn't anything wrong with the food, but I wasn't impressed enough for 4 stars. This could reflect on my choice of dish rather than the restaurant, as I got the simple English Breakfast. But I did get the chance to also sample my friend's salmon avocado toast, and found the dressing too bitter and the salmon a touch too sweet. The price was typical for NYC brunch, the waiters were attentive, and the decoration was Western unique, but I didn't leave wanting to return anytime soon. Been there twice, been stuffed full of tasty food twice. Just thinking about the place makes me hungry.Pretty much everything on the brunch menu is good: poached eggs, grits, thick-cut bacon. But the winner: Skillet Eggs, Bacon, Spinach, and Gruyere buttered sourdough toast.The decorations add a bunch of character: artwork, taxidermy, pots hanging from the walls, stairs that go nowhere. The alley entry is a nice, unique approach. This is a cool place to show off, since it's out of the way for most people who are not familiar with the East Village (I include myself). Unfortunately, that probably means it will soon become way too popular.Just make sure to get there early on the weekends, because they don't take reservations for small groups, and the place fills up quickly. Came back to Freeman's this weekend and sat at the bar for a quick breakfast, bar tender was attentive, quick service and not bad to look at ;) I ordered the chocolate chip pancakes (soooo good)! Their coffee is still to die for! I've come here for brunch a few times-initially just really wanted to see the artsy alley and take cute photos. It ended up becoming one of my favorite brunch spots in Brooklyn. Freeman's may look tiny from the outside, but there are multiple, interesting cabin-esque dining rooms inside, and we've never really had to wait a painful amount. Their servers are friendly and I've never had an unpleasant encounter, despite how crazy busy they typically are.Their cocktail selection is awesome - I've never had a bad drink here. We always get the cheesy-artichoke dip to start. I could eat those all friggin day. Their Mac n Cheese is baked perfectly and their pancakes could feed two. We've yet to come here for dinner, but it isn't exactly the most convenient location-wise. I'd recommend this place to those looking to spice the vibe up for brunch. The taxidermy on the walls aren't as intimidating as it sounds on Yelp. They did some things really well, but one basic dish not done right is the main reason for the low rating. The mac and cheese was guilty good. The trout was surprisingly juicy and true to its natural flavors with simple seasoning. The steak tasted so dry and rubbery, a mere two bites was too nuch before it was sent back to the kitchen. Absolutely clueless why they would serve it at all... especially for a restaurant of this level. Surprised they would still charge it on the bill. Disappointed neither the server nor the chef came to explain. Thoroughly enjoyed the fillet mignon, delicious cocktails too - I recommend the Fog Horn:gin, pernod, jalapeno, rosemary, lime This place is amazing! The french fries  are very heavenly. The design is also very interesting. On the outside, it doesn't look like much. But the food and inside is awesome. The one thing I don't like is that there is no WiFi, even though I didn't use it. Was in NY for the weekend and this spot kept coming up as a recommendation when I searched for brunches. I got a vegetable omelette (comes with a mixed green salad) and a biscuit. Omelet was kind of rubbery, salad and biscuit were just ok. The ambiance is great though so it's worth visit- save it for a visit during the winter since there's no outdoor seating. They have a ton of taxidermy on the walls and it's very cozy. Entrance is down an alley. I'm assuming people really come here for the ambience.  The food is average and nothing to come back for a second time.  I came here with some friends for brunch and came to find out that they had no Almond or Soy Milk, out of most dishes on the menu and the maple syrup they make was just ok.  I would have preferred Almond Milk with coffee and some decent maple syrup.  The waiter was either sleep walking while waiting our table or just had no personality.  Isn't that something you look for when hiring staff?  I ordered an omelette and some pancakes which were both average and left me hungry when I left the restaurant.  Maybe come in for a drink and to check out the decor. Pros:Homey vibe. But if you're creeped out by taxidermy, don't go. Entrance is photo-worthy and cute.Not $$$ prices, more like $$. Large amount of space inside (though it's mostly at the bar if you don't want to wait).Cons:Food isn't that good. I got the Egg White Omelet ($14), and the broccoli was surprisingly embedded in the omelet. The combination of broccoli and cheese was unappetizing. Salad on the side was decent though. My friend got the Smoked Trout ($17) and that, the little olive-like things on the side, and mini pickles were all too salty. Only the cheeseburger ($17) tasted really good. The secret sauce, which might actually be hollandaise sauce, went well with the lettuce and patty. However, even though the patty was Medium Rare, the outside was partially burnt. Fries were thin and crispy. Artichoke dip ($15) is good though, as the reviews have raved about. But eating bread from that, then having bread from the Smoked Trout was too much. Service was good and water was filled promptly by bartender. Luckily the appetizer took a while to eat and when we were almost done, our main dishes came at that moment. I probably wouldn't come again, as I don't like the animals looking at me and there's nothing special about the food, besides maybe the dip. I have so many positive things to say about this place! It is in the back of Freeman's alley and is so cute! The decor and ambiance are so nice and intimate. For the food: The service is always amazing and you will never be waiting on your food! I've been there for brunch and dinner and both are amazing!!!! Brunch: Pancakes or their eggs with hash browns and bacon never fails! I'm sure the other options are all delicious as well! Dinner: Cheeseburger, any of the sandwiches, etc. I've been going to this place for years and the quality is always superb. Basically the food is seriously TASTY. JUST GO! We ended up here because there wasn't a wait... Its located at the end of a private alley filled with graffiti.  The decor is VERY rustic and cool.  Its a dark, cozy old house with several different rooms hidden away and decorated in their own quirky, outdoorsy manner.IF YOU LOVE BRUNCH COCKTAILS GO HERE!  The pre-designed cocktails are great!  I was craving cucumber so the bartender created something original with Mezcal and it was perfect!  I had a squash salad filled with squashes I had never heard of before, and also the shrimp and grits, and waffles.  The shrimp and grits was a more coarse texture than I'm used to in the south but still very good.I appreciate that its hidden because it keeps it from being so touristy as most of the brunch destinations in Soho... Great setting for a nice long meetup with friends! Wow! Totally and completely disappointed with the experience we had at Freemans. It was my fault that I didn't look at the opening time correctly but we got there only about 20 minutes early. Because of the high reviews, we decided to walk around and wait until they opened.The service after we entered was friendly and efficient. We ordered the Mac & Cheese and the Fish Sandwich for lunch. Honestly, both items left a lot to be desired. My husband who's a huge fan of Mac & Cheese was even disappointed in this one as it was a bit gritty and the crumbly topping was kind of a let down. The Fish Sandwich was not much better; it was fairly small in size but I still didn't eat the whole thing. It came with fries which were on the greasy side, completely unappetizing.Overall, very disappointed! I had really high expectations but maybe their breakfast / brunch is better. Bummer too because the location was in an alley but still super cute. LOVED our friends bridal shower here this past weekend! Her aunt ordered a bunch of family style selections from the menu and it was delicious! The cheesy artichoke dip was so great- highly recommend for a starter! We also had French toast with maple syrup, squash salad and their House-Smoked Brisket sandwiches - the french fries were hot and crispy. They also brought out the egg white&mushroom omelettes for the table. We had great service but we could have used 1 more waitress in the room- she seemed a bit overwhelmed with about 30 of us crammed into this back room. I definitely would like to go back- cool hidden location and the food was awesome!! Come to Freemans for the cocktails and the picturesque atmosphere. They are famous for their unique location down a charming, graffitied ally; slightly hidden but not difficult to find.Overall I am UNIMPRESSED with the food.The baked skillet eggs shakshuka was probably the most underwhelming that I've tried. It was neither spicy nor saucy...as shakshuka SHOULD BE and the eggs were poorly done. Two were underdone and one was overdone... How does that even happen. Smh *face palm*Also, I am unsure how or why the artichoke dip ($15) is popular because although it looked appetizing, it was greasy/oily rather than creamy. It made me nauseous. Honestly, I'm not an artichoke connoisseur but this cannot be what the good stuff tastes like.Freemans could be a good first date spot... you take her for a few cocktails, but don't wanna spent $$$ on dinner, (thankfully there's room at the bar), but at the same time you won't look cheap or boring because *ambiance* is A+ TL;DR: cute tiny space with good brunch, but no substitutions available on the weekends makes it a little tough for vegetarians. A friend and I came for brunch on Saturday and only had to wait 20-30 mins for a table, which I felt was very reasonable. There seemed to be a good number of options that could be vegetarian, i.e. If bacon or some meat were taken out or replaced, but when I asked, I was told that the kitchen didn't do replacements on the weekends bc they're so busy. Makes sense, but I was glad I'd never been here before bc that made a grand total of like 3 things I could eat. Lots of tasty looking sides, though - I could imagine this being a good group brunch place.My friend and I both got the poached eggs with cheesy grits and collard greens, as we're both from the South and miss grits. These were delicious and hit the spot - portion size was great and I felt satisfied but not overfilled. We both paid ~$20 and left feeling pretty happy. I'd come back but maybe with some non vegetarian friends who can appreciate the variety of options here a little better. Location: I finally made it here! Freeman is cute inside and out. Why outside, becuase they have this freeman alley which has many posters and graphs and fun drawings that you cannot stop taking photos. Why inside, the decoration is like Sitting in a farm at Colorado where hunters gather here discussing how they wanna hunt for this year. Foood: had their brunch. But the whole menu is available to choose. Of course, I had their most famous brunch. And I think  it's one of few brunch spot that their signature food tastes actually goodPrice: average Service: waitress is absolutely caring. She gave us privacy but always show on time whenever we need here. Overall: absolute good. N their lounge is incredible! 4 stars!I'd recommend come early tho! Came here cause of all the rave reviews on here. Ambiance was as expected - quaint and cozy. The food, however, was disappointing. I had the steak and eggs; the steak wasn't that tender or tasty at all. Perhaps I ordered the wrong thing, but expected better food for the price. I'd have to say this place is overpriced and overrated. Freeman's entire environment is why I gave this place a 4 stars. I've been dying to try the restaurant so when it was Sunday morning and i was staying at the Public hotel, I decided to give it a try. Their brunch menu isn't exactly the most extensive or include a lot of typical "brunch" options, but we ordered some blueberry pancakes, a salad, and a quiche.The services was very attentive and the food was decent. I'll have to come back for other meals!

LOVE LOVE LOVE this restaurant!! This is my go to spot for super authentic Italian cuisine. The food is DELICIOUS! The only place that has this quality of food is in Italy itself.  I've ordered so many dishes here and they all come out cooked to perfection. Some favorites are the sviziosa, gnocchi, calzones, and Panninis. The space is small and not fancy...It can seat about 20 people. No reservations are needed at lunchtime but dinner always requires a reservation. It's always packed so expect a wait but it's really worth it. I've waited so long to try this place (a year) and finally had the opportunity tonight. It's adorable. It's unconventional and a bit gritty and tad unkempt but all it's imperfections contributed to the owner's nonchalant, no joke, no time to waste, stiff but oh-so-cool attitude. I say this with 0 sarcasm. I love her. I love how haphazard G's decor is. I love the fact they use ikea kiddie plastic ware with small red solo cups for water and how enormous and unapologetic their antipasti are thrown together with the only measurement of oil and Parm being A Lot. We had the bresoela carpaccio, pesto lasagna and spicy garlic spinach ravioli. I even love how they came out in oversized foamy aluminum ramekins under a wooden trivet. The carpaccio was a bit salty but it's cured meat with a good vinegar and plenty of Parmesan. I love the pesto lasagna- only needed a nice dash of sea salt. The ravioli was surprisingly spicy which almost never happens to someone who orders and lives to love hot and spicy. It wasn't perfect but G is that cool. The entire establishment of a one woman show that makes one go through the hoopla of reserving a time to make a reservation is actually ingenious. Once you've entered the door, all the mystique and regulation falls to the wayside- it's clear why G is so popular. She is only here to serve 2-3 hours of no frills good food in a sub-level almost secret club that was never there if you never got the invite.*to say that cost has nothing to do with the assessment would be naive. G is the best deal in town. The fact I had to report to her what we had and remind her to charge us for our drinks goes to show how busy she was and how this place is ran- in good faith* this place clearly does not want any business.  Rudest woman on the phone.  Good luck trying to make a reservation here.  I've called countless times and no one answers.  Twice now I have called and an actual person has picked up- neither of these times has my reservation been taken (reservation for weeks in advance mind you).  I called at 4:57pm to make a dinner resveration for a month from now.  The restaurant's hours are until 7pm.  The woman who answered the phone said they only take reservations until 5 (??? how does that make sense when it is open until 7 and this is a reservation for weeks out??) and since it was 4:57 it was too close to 5 to take my reservation and to call back tomorrow.Would have liked to try this place but not after the attitude I received on the phone.  Maybe this place should get with opentable or resy if they're not going to endure the labor of writing down a reservation from a phone call.  You're not that exclusive and your restaurant is never full, just thought I'd follow your policy that's listed on your website of calling in a res ahead of time.rude rude rude Just found this as we were close by. The first time I walked in. I headed towards to counter thinking there might be a waitlist as people were waiting in front. After getting there, the owner told us to get towards the back (near the door) to avoid blocking people. Which is fine, but was said in a little rude tone but it was understandable. I know they were trying to work at a fast pace to accommodate the amount of people coming. But after waiting about 20+ minutes, I would at least expect better service and cleaner plates. I had a total of 4 people and one of the waitress said 2 of us can sit first while waiting for the next table to finish and clear up. That didn't happen as one said we had to order or give our seats up for the next customers (that just got here recently). As for the food, it was decent for the pricing but the portions are small. I shared two dishes with my friend (2). We got meat lasagna (had good bread with it// soft and warm) and meatballs n potatoes (bread was cold and ok). Priced at $10 and $8. The total was around $19-20. It didn't fill us up but that's alright. I don't think the food was too bad but the service could be better. The owner was a lot kinder towards the end, but in the beginning it wasn't the best. It was a rough afternoon I guess. Not the best start to our day. A no frills affordable, BYOB Italian restaurant.  I found this restaurant on Yelp and decided to try it because of the high ratings.  I already knew the lack of customer service was a sore spot because of all the complaints but wanted to have an open mind and experience for myself.  I browsed Gaia's website and knew about their unique policies. Reservations had to be made beforehand so I called and spoke to the owner/chef, she was pretty dismissive and borderline rude ("You need a reservation!  Didn't you read the website?!"  Umm yes, that's why I'm calling!) but I made a reservation for 5:30pm, although my first instinct was to hang up!  I'm grateful I made that decision but didn't know that at the time.  I was worried the restaurant would turn out to be a disaster!My husband and I arrived at the restaurant, wary of the appearance.  Talk about a hole in the wall/basement!  There wasn't a host/hostess to greet us and barely a glance from the cooks in the kitchen.  We found a table with my name on a card and sat.  I opened the bottle of wine we bought (from a liquor store across the street) and started drinking.  No corkage fee, 1 star!  After looking through the menu we decided on the dinner for 2 ($40 for a medium Antipasto Italiano Plate, Bruschetta, Pasta of the Day, and a little dessert) and ordered at the counter.  Someone would bring each course out to us but no one came to clean up in between. If a dish was being brought out and we had finished plates, they'd get taken away.  Most of the time, I just brought the used dishes to the front counter.  Once we got over the abrupt but prompt service, we devoured our meal and really enjoyed it.  My husband ate most of ithe foodand I was still stuffed!  The food was authentic, simple and delicious.  I felt like we were eating in someone's home, not a restaurant.  We ordered a cappuccino in addition to the cookies that were brought out to us as part of the meal.  No regrets with anything we ordered.  It hit the spot without breaking the piggy bank!Overall, I'd give Gaia 4 stars because the food was delicious and priced so well.  This restaurant is a hole in the wall, service is questionably lacking to the point of defiant but it's worth going to for a super laid back and scrumptious meal. We ordered the chicken "Milanese" panino and mushroom truffle ravioli. The panino was 3.5/5 stars. The sandwich's chicken cutlets were small though the chicken it did have was well-executed: juicy, well seasoned, crisp on the bite of the crust. The bread was thick, soft, and light crisp on the exterior. Unfortunately the bitter arugula dominated the flavor profile and made the pesto and tomatoes at most an afterthought. The ravioli on the mushroom truffle ravioli was handmade, lightly chewy, and just the right taste. The mushrooms inside were savoury, well-seasoned, and juicy. These were complemented well by earthy romano cheese shavings on top. The sauce was a medium-bodied bechamel with hints of truffle oil. Light sprinkling of parsley balanced the cream and fat of the sauce with a fresh and green flavor and mouthfeel. The ravioli was good enough to redeem the failures made on the panino, but not enough to make the experience 5 stars. Hole in the wall type of place that serves one of the best Italian food I've tried. No frills - you order and pay at the counter. They give you plastic plates, utensils, and cups. We came on a Thursday at 5pm, and there was no problem with seats. By 630, the place was filling up. We saw a bunch of people bring their own bottles, so it's BYOB people! Can't get any better than that. We got their dinner for two special, which includes the antipasto, bruschetta, pasta of the day, and dessert. It was $40, which was a good price for the amount of food we got.The antipasto was amazing! I wanted to buy the cheese from them, but they said it's from Italy, and they don't sell it anymore due to shortage. Sniff. The bruschetta is make your own, so they give you a bunch of toppings (Eggplant, artichoke, peppers, olives etc) and you decide what to put on your toasted bread. Both of them were so good that we had to get another serving. They were both different, which made it even more interesting because we got to try different cheeses and meats. The pasta of the day included buffalo cheese ravioli, and that was fantastic. Each day they have specialties, so I'll upload the menu that explains it all. We also ordered the lasagna, and loved it as well. They were both so flavorful that you just had to dip the bread in the sauce. The dessert is just an assortment of what cookies they have, which made a great accompaniment to the cappuccinos we ordered. She sure knows how to make a great cup of coffee. Overall, amazing food experience and service that we can't wait to go back on different days to try out different pastas! Since I moved uptown I had not been to Gaia for a while. Today I was so pleased to see the restaurant very busy with lots of happy customers. A friend and I ordered crab meat salad, bruschetti, burratina, and the pasta special (orecchiette with gorgonzola and tomato). Every dish was perfect (I might be spelling some wrong). We could not finish any of the dishes and the whole thing was around $50. The owner is very kind with a beautiful personality. Will definitely try to come down more often. Gaia Italian Caf is a small hidden restaurant that specializes in Italian food at unbeatable prices.TIPS:-Reservation mandatory after 5pm, no other option.FOOD (5/5):The food here is very good. I recommend ordering several options for the table and splitting them amongst yourselves. My recommendations are -Fico Panini: fig goat cheese, tomatoes, prosciutto di Parma-Mushroom ravioli special: mushroom filled ravioli in a spicy tomato sauce (medium portion)PRICE (5/5): Here is the kicker for this establishment, most of the food is around $10. If you are traveling NYC on a budget, Gaia's is a must-go.SERVICE (2/5):Unfortunately very rude service from the cashier. Hopefully it was just one worker & not represented by the whole staff. I had such high hopes for this place. I made reservations (because it's a must for dinner) on a Thursday because it was gnocchi and ravioli day (my favorite types of pasta). We ended up getting only one item from the special daily menu because the top choice was out. That item was the shrimp ravioli with brussel sprouts in lemon sauce. The shrimps were ridiculously tiny and just not pleasant to eat. The ravioli itself was ordinary. The brussel sprouts were cooked funny -- I was expecting charred and flavorful. Disappointing and waste of $14. Don't ever get shrimp dishes there.The pesto lasagna, $10, was pretty good, but it didn't blow away. It looks better than it tastes. The spinach ricotta gnocchi was basically just balls of spinach and ricotta. Maybe I just don't know what gnocchi is. It was also $10 for 5. Finally, the bread. Ew. It was hard, old, greasy. But it came with the meal and the sauces were good... and you needed something to eat the sauce with since the pasta was so minimum. Just disappointing. Were looking for Italian for a late lunch.  Gaia popped up on yelp and reviews looked good.  Had a long cold walk to get there but it was worth it!!  Entrance is below street level and we almost missed it.  Took the stairs down and entered the small cafe.  Nothing fancy here, but sure looked like a neighborhood place, which was perfect.  There wasn't a table free (there are only 9), so we had to wait a bit.  That gave us time to look over the menu.  Eventually we were seated (after a young couple slid over to another table so we would have room for the additional chair we needed at ours).  We started with an arugula salad that was fantastic.  Large serving, great flavors.  Then we split a meat lasagna and spinach gnocchi.  They were both good (I didn't do much with the gnocchi- they were indeed spinach, and I'm just not that big a fan.  That gave me a chance to go back up to the counter (order and pay there) and get a Delicato panini - provolone, ham and mozzarella- was really great.  Visited with other diners who confirmed that the food is always great.  Pasta dishes come served in metal bowls on wood plates.  Bowls are very hot, so your dish stays warm  the entire meal.  Service was a bit laid back, but that just added to the charm of the place.  Got to talk with the owner when I paid the bill (all that for only $35!) - she was sweet and thankful we chose her establishment.  Thinking about going back tomorrow! Good food but service is lacking. They have to come up with a better of getting folks in and out. We ordered coffee but never got our sweetener and coffee went cold so we drank it so could wrap our meal.  And wrapping up we had to line up to pay. A few visits to Gaia made obtaining a meal here feel like I riddled the sphinx, or broke the DaVinci code, or actually saved up for a trip to Italy. I arrived at lunch a little late and ordered a spicy shrimp pasta dish.  It was served in a delightfully worn, dare I say beat up, silver pot, with a warming love, wonderfully baked pasta noodles and spicy shrimp in a rich tomato broth.It was dirt cheap and felt like a visit from grandma.  My soul quickly arrived to that spot named "home" on the soul dial as I sat in this sort of dingy little basement. The rough edges of Gaia are its charms - old world non pretense and a good home cooked meal.Here is a guide to the logistics ofobtaining a meal here -1. Lunch is the easiest time to eat here.    Check the website for when the kitchen      closes, which I think is around 2:30pm.2. Dinner is reservation only and served     within a time window between 5pm and     7:30pm.    You cannot just walk in and eat dinner under any circumstances. This is such a great hole in the wall!! It's in a basement on Houston Street so some people might miss it initially. I made a reservation for 2 on a Thursday at 5:30 PM. There were only two other tables seated when we came. We walked up to the counter and they informed us that we should seat ourselves and order at the counter when we were ready. We ordered a panini to share, and two entrees. They brought the food over to us when it was ready.The Milanese Panini ($7) was so delicious. It was chicken cutlet, arugula, tomatoes, and pesto sauce between two slices of crispy bread. The bread was so crispy and the chicken cutlet was seasoned just right. The pesto sauce, arugula, and tomatoes came together so well. I ordered the Meat Lasagna ($10). Some reviews on yelp mentioned that it was too salty?? But I thought it was just right - if anything, it could use a little more salt. The lasagna was covered with tomato sauce which i used to dip the complimentary bread they provided for us. My friend ordered the Pesto Lasagna ($10). I had a little sample it was just as delicious! I would recommend this place for lunch if you're ever in the area. For dinner, they have a special for two people for $40. It comes with an antipasto plate, bruschetta, pasta of the day, and a small dessert. And, you must make reservations if you wish to come in for dinner (more details on their website). Came in here for a late breakfast, they had a decent amount of options to choose from which sounded like they'd make a good breakfast (vegetarian paninis). Got my self a Mediterranean (which is spelled in Italian on the menu). Goat cheese, tomato, red bell peppers, oils and a nice crunchy bread. Absolutely delicious. The bread was fresh and crunchy without being burnt. The goat cheese had a great taste and texture to it. Tomatoes where nice and acidic. I don't like bell peppers but ate them anyway because they actually complimented the panini. Place is pretty small but cute and intimidate, real hole in the wall kind vibe.Portion was really generous, especially when you realize the thing sells for 5 bucks. Reviews on here are pretty consistent about food and service. With food being consistently good and service not so much. I kinda got where that was coming from. The lady is a bit rough around the edges, and if you're not used to it I can see why it would be negative. But seriously, don't take everything at face value, she is pretty nice and how she speaks doesn't make the food taste any better or worse.5/5 because Place is really cute Plenty of options Food tastes great Price is reasonable Service was quick and orderly It's a super hole in the wall type of place; you wouldn't think it was a restaurant if you were just passing by. You walk down a flight a stairs to enter, and upon walking in everything is super vintage. We had made a reservation for 5:30PM on a Thursday, but it really wasn't needed because we were able to sit wherever we wished. You order your food at the counter and then they bring it to your table. It's also BYOB! Amongst my friend & I, we got a Milanese Panini ($7!!!) to share - this was probably my favorite menu item that I tried. The 'bread' of the panini was more of a cracker, the chicken was cooked nicely, and I love pesto over anything so it complimented the sandwich well. In addition, we also got a Pesto Lasagna ($10!!!) and Meat Lasagna ($10!!!). These were just mediocre, I think it lacked flavor and salt. They also give you some bread to dip in your sauce. After we paid, we were also given some complimentary Italian cookies. Overall, I would come back because you can't really beat the prices. For the two of us, it was roughly $29, which is unbelievable for both Italian food and the LES. Customer service is also not amazing, but couldn't complain. bunch of my girlfriends recommended this small italian restaurant to me so i had to try it out and now its one of my favorite restaurant to go!! its not expensive and the employees are friendly. my helpful tips~ -you have to make reservations after 5:30pm, it's a small cute restaurant and they get pretty busy. -it's BYOY( love it lol). no cork fee! -you have to order your food to the cashier and they bring it out to your table. -they make different special everyday. they're all so delicious. we (party of 2) ordered three different dinner special & one cheese ham small plate. everything was delicious and of course we brought a bottle of red wine. there's a word for combining wine and dinner - it's winner! The Illy coffee (I've had two cappuccinos) is outstanding and the pesto lasagna is truly perfetto and my favorite restaurant food in all of NYC.  We would have licked our metal bowls clean if that were acceptable public behavior!  Word to the wise: this place has an information page and rules to follow.  Some unfortunate folks have great difficulty understanding that the world does not revolve around them and display abrasive manners.Gaia's efforts are a gift to anyone with good manners and a heart open enough to appreciate the tremendous deliciousness.  Mi piacciono molto!!! I really really wanted to love Gaia but it's just alright in my books. I've come on three separate occasions and each time, I felt like there was a little something missing. Gaia is a particular woman and wants you to enjoy her food her way. I would recommend checking out the "Informations" page on her website before dining. If you're cool with it then she's cool with you. When you walk into the cafe, feel free to drop your belonging off at a table. Then, make your way up front to check out the menu/daily specials and place your order. You pay after the meal. They'll hand you some utensils for you to take back to your table, but they will bring out your food.During my visits here, I've tried their antipasto italiano con focaccia, arugula salad, panini, and homemade pastas and lasagnas. Their food is decent, especially for the portion and the price. However, the pastas and lasagnas I have had could have used more salt. The other dishes were good, but not amazing. Overall, Gaia serves up a nice selection of Italian comfort foods at a good price, especially for the city. However, having been spoiled by $9 pasta at Il Corvo, in Seattle, I'm a pretty tough critic when it come to delicious pasta at a value. If you're looking for good Italian food, this is the place to go. Be sure to read the rules of the restaurant before coming. Simple rules like don't ask to alter the menu. What you see is what you get. When one member of our party asked to change the pasta, the guy taking our order was patient and explained the rules to him, however I got the feeling he was a little annoyed. The bread sticks are so amazing! Don't bother asking for seconds, they know how much to give each person. I did take a star off because the plastic cup they provided me still had lipstick on it. Thankfully I had my own water bottle and used that. Overall the meal was flavorful and authentic. Would come again next time I'm in New York.

Not your typical taco joint but equally as good!  The fillings are placed in paratha "shells" which are slightly crisp.  Something to try if you've never gone do before. I had the pork belly and beef mojo today.  Both were amazing and I'll definitely be back to try the others- particularly the paneer! Stopped by here for a quick lunch. The front can get easily get packed but there is a dining area behind the counter on the right side. We ordered the saag paneer, beef mojo, and pork belly tacos. All three were different and tasted delicious. My husband thought the two meat tacos were filled with good flavor. It's a great idea they have fusing Mexican and Indian foods together. My favorite was the saag paneer. It had such great texture and full of flavor than the meat tacos. Their scotch boonet hot sauce was amazing. It was full of flavor for a hot sauce with a good amount kick that helped cut the heavy flavors of the tacos.It can be a bit messy to eat. We didn't see utensils. The pouches the tacos come in may fold out to a plate but we ended up using the stack of napkins on the table. Goa Taco, you are my ambitionYou satisfy taste and nutritionRed squash and sweet honeyYou're sure worth the moneyOh please, come again to fruition I didn't know what a "paratha" was until I came here. It sounded like a cannibalistic fish or something. This is one of the best tacos I have ever had, probably the best. The best. Yeah, the best.I mean, they're in a league of their own though...is it even fair? Usually I hate paying more than $2 for a taco, but I was totally fine with paying $6 for this one. It was like 4 tacos in one. I had the mojo beef with pinto bean puree, smoked jalapeno and plantain chips. Plantain chips in a taco.My god.The crunch.My partner in crime had spinach pesto, garam masala fried chickpea and pickled tomatillo in hers and it was good as well. Fried chicpeas...what a time to be alive.Are you alive? Then why are you still here? Go get some chicpeas and smash then call it hummus! I never flummox! I don't understand the hype... it's a Malaysian paratha which you can buy from Indian grocery stores, stuffed with very basic things you can get at home and make yourself. My main issue was that I badly wanted to try the paneer taco (in the mood for vegetarian) but they ran out of paneer (why!), and settled for the tofu one instead - which I absolutely do not recommend. But overall I'm just not seeing what's so great about this... it's like a Kati roll but with a Malaysian paratha and in taco form with a cute envelope packaging. I'm not sure if the other tacos will be able to get there with the flavors when they failed tremendously with the one I tried. I do believe the price is reasonable for NYC, meal itself is filling, but just heard too many good things and did not meet expectations. I will say that I found their hot sauce intriguing - it was WAY SPICIER than I imagined it to be Service was good, he was a very nice server. Not sure I'll be back... I ordered the Tofu Banh Mi Taco (thinking it was the lighter option) since we actually just came from brunch but wanted to try Goa since it was right down the street. The mushroom pate was tasty and the overall taste was very fresh. I enjoyed the paratha but it probably would've tasted better with one of the warmer options. The taco was overflowing so it was a little hard to eat, especially since we were sharing as well. But overall it was pretty good and I'd come again for one of their other tacos! I went here based on previous rave reviews. I am sad to say that I was underwhelmed. I ordered the chorizo taco and my best friend had the pork belly taco. For $8 each, the tacos weren't all that big. The toppings and the taco shell were unique and delicious. The meats however were just okay. I enjoyed my chorizo sausage but the pork belly did not look or taste like pork belly, more like pork loin. The concept was great so A for effort. We were hungry and wanted something delicious and cheap in the city. We couldn't decide between The Halal Guys or here, but I probably will not return to Goa Taco in the future. These are seriously the best (nontraditional) tacos in New York! So delicious, they are in this fried pita bread that is so tasty with whatever meat you order. The pork belly is the crowd favorite - but I preferred the lamb shoulder because it wasn't as fatty. The staff was very friendly and the atmosphere was fun and effortless. I also had the house sangria which surprisingly was pretty good and strong! Can't wait to go back - delicious treat! I was wandering the city one Friday night when I realized I hadn't eaten anything that day. Pulled up my bookmarks and found that I was only a block away from goa taco!I like Indian food. I like tacos. What I got, was Indian food in the shape of a taco. It's basically a kati roll in the shape of a taco. They take a paratha, which is like a flaky tortilla and stuff it with Indian food. I got the tofu bahn mi and palak paneer tacos. Both were pretty good and both were vegetarian. The excessive amounts of ghee keeps them from being vegan though goa taco is the perfect late night greasy meal you need in your life after a night in grungy LES.The tacos are made with paratha which is the same texture as a scallion pancake, the Indian roti they offer at Chinese restaurants (I dunno why?!?) or perhaps if your tortilla was fried first. They manage to stuff so many ingredients in this little paratha to where it is a bit messy. It's not the easiest especially if you've been raging recently. But the little specially designed goa pocket helps.I have enjoyed myself almost all of the taco options and they're all solid. My favorites are the tofu banh mi and the paneer. I can't eat more than one of these suckers but sharing is caring. Next time you're here share the wealth! I had the pesto paneer one. It was great! So filling!!! A goa taco and a drink for just $7? Good deal!!By time I ate only half of it, I was already full.It's a walk-in place but there is a doorway into a bar / Lounge where I sat and eat. I went there mid September on a Friday afternoon and it was dead, but that's not a reflection of the food at all.Amazing Fusion food. You must give this place a try Delicious taco that's very much like a scallion pancake packed with your choice of filling. I ordered the pork belly taco, which comes with pickled cabbage, chipotle mayo, and 2-3 nice long slices of pork belly for $8. It's more of a heavy snack as opposed to a meal, but if you're a light eater it should be perfect portions. Though I don't believe this type of taco is very indian since it reminds me of flavors that hit close to home (xiaobing?), I did love it nonetheless. The shell was crispy, warm, and not oily at all. It was folded nicely and snugly tucked into their cardboard which you can rip apart to facilitate a less messy eating process - but trust me, bits and pieces will still fall down. Some things guess can't be salvaged I guess. Very excited to try their cheese paneer taco next! Small sit down store with seating right in front of the cashier. If you don't mind having them eaves drop on your conversation, or you're simply stopping by for a quick bite that shouldn't really matter right :). Yum yum yum yum yum yum! I had the pork belly and the mojo beef! Tears of joy...that paratha bread taco is crispy and buttery.Make sure you try what you like because I can't imagine it ALL BEING GOOD! Woah! Was my first thought when I took a bite out of the taco. I really didn't know what to expect. When I think tacos, my Bay Area, CA raised self thinks al pastor on tortilla shells. I don't go out of my way for anything but Mexican tacos.However, I've recently moved to the area and the boy came to visit and really wanted to try this place.  So it's actually a paratha shell meaning its crispy and sort of like the texture of a green onion pancake (Chinese food lovers can relate). The size of them are the size of 2 tacos.We had the pork belly and the lamb and pork belly was definitely my favorite. I'd give this place a try! Brunch, lunch, dinner, or late late night, it's always a good snack. I would take these paratha tacos over regular tacos anyday! The shell is incredibly flaky, and all the filling on the inside comes out hot. I chose the brunch taco this time (i believe it's a special, so check with them to see if it's available), which came with bacon, fried egg, peppers, and this spicy mayo...YUM. Not the cheapest, but super super delicious and I would totally come back! I also shared a churro with my friend, i think they use the same paratha shell to wrap around the chocolate hazelnut filling instead of the traditional way of making a churro. Really yummy too. It was a little steep, at $2.76 per churro (it's a mini one!), wish it came with multiple in the cone.The cute space is pretty small, but when I got there, there were a lot of seats open (there's 4 bar counter seats inside, and a couple of tables outside). Goa Taco is awesome! Its quick service for a healthy taco, all their meats are antibiotic and hormone free, which I really appreciate. Their lamb taco especially is so freakin good! The sauce the soft lamb and the paratha taco combined is really great. Love the idea and the taste. Not a huge fan of presentation and inflexibility of the food. Although I ate it accordingly from the far end of the taco, my friend prefers to eat hers from above and make her way down. It just got messy and drippy. I had the paneer. The taco shell is fried and a bit oily but worth it because it was crispy. The flavors compliment and does not compete against each other. Chips and verde sauce was good. A new location has just opened on Macdougal, serving the same concise menu of great Paratha tacos.They're all delicious, but I went with the Chicken Chorizo this time. The flaky paratha shell is soft and buttery and makes a for a really different and delicious experience than you would except from something called a taco. Hopefully they last longer here than Piece of Velvet did, because the food is great. One Friday night, the boyfriend and I decided to try a new  place for dinner outside of our usual comfort foods. Requirements: had to be around soho/chinatown, had to be tasty, had to be below $20/pp. After a quick search on google maps and yelp, we settled on goa taco. At first, we were confused with the restaurant description. What is an Indian taco anyways? As it turns out, instead of the regular taco skin, goa serves their tacos with paratha (prata?) which is a buttery, flaky pancake not unlike a Chinese scallion pancake. We ordered the mojo beef and the slow roasted pork belly. The mojo beef had great flavor and was a little spicy. The Indian spices used definitely complemented the taste of the paratha. On the other hand, the pork belly tasted refreshingly light, although the pork was a little dry. The pickled red cabbage gave the taco a great crunch and kept it from being too heavy as the paratha is pretty oily. The total for this meal was less than $20The next day was not a great day for the boyfriend. He is positively certain that the cause of his indigestion were the tacos and it is with great dismay that I have to knock a star off this review. I found Goa Taco through Meal Pal. Although Delancey was a little bit of a hike from my work - delicious vegetarian tacos are worth traveling for.These are "paratha" style tacos, Paratha = crossaint + tortilla; LIFE CHANGING.The Bahn Mi taco and the Saag Paneer are amazing. The guac and chips are a little pricey for a small amount of guac and a massive amount of chips - however - the taco was so delicious, all was forgiven. I am now a regular :)

The best place in town for roast baby suckling pig! Be sure to come early as it's a hot commodity! I've been there 4x and they were out 2x! They are CLOSED AGAIN - since January 10,  2018 - Looking at the City web site. how can they score them an "A" for violations time and time again ? and it was last updated 2016.last time they were sited....Inspection: 2016-03-18 00:00:00Score: 20Violations:Live roaches present in facility's food and/or non-food areas.Cold food item held above 41 F (smoked fish and reduced oxygen packaged foods above 38 F) except during necessary preparation.AInspection: 2015-09-25 00:00:00Score: 12Violations:Food contact surface not properly washed, rinsed and sanitized after each use and following any activity when contamination may have occurred.Non-food contact surface improperly constructed. Unacceptable material used. Non-food contact surface or equipment improperly maintained and/or not properly sealed, raised, spaced or movable to allow accessibility for cleaning on all sides, above and underneath the unit.Pesticide use not in accordance with label or applicable laws. Prohibited chemical used/stored. Open bait station used. I've been coming here for many years and I've got to say that the food has improved. Fhe food has remained consistantly good from the 3-4 visits I've made recently.I always get 'Chasu Wonton Noodles' and the first time I had it was that it was ok but now.. wow! Noodletown must've hired a new chef because the difference in how the food was cooked was noticable. The chasu before was nowhere near as good as it is now and it's something I recommend getting as a plate or in your noodle bowl. The food really got better and I highly recommend coming. The food portions remain the same iirc. I mean, the "Grade Pending" sign probably should have been enough to make us stay away, but after a drink or two one does not make the best decisions. We all ordered the wonton noodle soup and it was ok. I guess it would hit the spot if you were really really drunk but I definitely was not drunk enough. The shrimp dumplings were actually pretty good until one of my friends pulled out what looked a piece of newspaper out of hers. It's probably like when you go to the deli and they wrap your meat in butcher paper. I've seen the Chinese grocery stores wrap stuff in newspaper, but who wants icky newspaper ink on their shrimps? I try not to endorse this place too hard because it's already hard for me to get a seat when I want one.  But this place is one of the examples I would cite if I had to prove life was inherently good, humanity deserved to exist, heaven should be like earth, etc.. Nihilists and optimists alike, poor and scathingly rich NYU students, Manhattanite affluence, aging NYTimes reviewers in drab dinner jackets, corporate thrillseekers drunk on success and Prosecco, hostel-hoppers with grubby backpacks, and the occasional Chinese person can be seen packing themselves into the narrow spaces they call tables here.  The line to get in to eat, or to escape the cold while you to-go order cooks forms a mob across the front door fire-hazard style, making it impossible to see anything the customers might be eating inside the restaurant. All you can see from outside is the selection of roasted meats hanging from the ceiling, the cashier's plateau next to a chef with a large knife and a wonton soup station. This is often obscured by full clouds of steam pouring from the rice cooker and the bone broth, and the hasty breath of so many people inside slurping their noodles and gasping in surprise with each bite.  There is something about this place which nourishes the soul.  It seems like a warm bath in the dead of winter, even if you come here in the summer.  Somehow its ability to warm the void remains as you roll in your own sweat May through September.  But I fear I've said too much.  I've said most of it before, but I try to keep it brief, keeping the spiritual side of this experience to myself. The food is magnificent, authentic perhaps not to China but to being here, to living a life in this area where this is the place you end up after heartily celebrating your own existence.  The bone broth really struck me this time, which I don't usually drink because it has noodles in it and is very porky.  This time the collagen cried out to me.  The pig and I formed a chemical bond as our bones became one.  I might ask to be cremated and have my ashes added to the incense holder at the traditional altar.  Or just Char Siu me. My thighs would look great hanging from that window, glistening with sticky sugar and steam.  If I think of this place before entering oblivion, I will smile. Excellent duck and roast Pork.  Found the place toBe a bit dirty the last time I went and I just heard from my cousin that they are closed due to health code violations.  I'm sure it will be much cleaner when they open up.  They have been there for ages... I came here for dinner with friends. Food was great, service was not. My friends and I ordered a lot of things to share: roasted baby pig; mushrooms with foo noodles; salt baked calamari; salt baked scallops; fried rice with roast duck and pineapple; and salted pea shoots. Everything was delicious. The salt baked calamari and scallops were definitely a favorite because the flavor palate was so different. The salted pea shoots were surprisingly addicting. And the mushrooms with foo noodles was perfectly cooked. Service was terrible. We were ignored for a long time after we sat down. We had to stop a few people, not sure who our waiter was, in order to order food. Some of the servings are very large and when we asked for a knife to cut meat and mushrooms, we got the impression they were not too pleased. We had to share one knife, which was fine, but when it appeared that we were finished with it, it was taken away from us. Also, our small table for four was given four special menus. At one point during the meal, a worker reached across our table, over our food, without asking, to grab special menus for other tables. At another point in the meal, another worker interrupted us, demanding that we provide more special menus.
