When we finished some plates, we were asked bluntly and impatiently if we were ordering more food or leaving. Overall, customer service is not a priority here. Please note that this place is BEER ONLY. However, they let you BYO Wine. Also, this place is CASH ONLY. Great little hole in the wall in Chinatown.Known for its BBQ meats and Noodles, this place is a great value spot.I got the three meats (crispy pork, char siu, roast duck) over rice.   All three were nicely done, tasty and meaty.My BF got the pan fried chicken lo mein, and it was a bit bland...not too much flavor....not a repeat dish.....for sure....The place is a bit cramped, not the cleanest place around (but again, this is NY Chinatown !!!).Service is prompt and efficient. Good little noddle spot, clean and prompt service. Single restrooms were nice, place was complete with hanging duck and pork in the window. Recommend the pork wonton noodle soup, seafood e-fu -all washed  down with a Tsingtao. I came here with my fam on a Sunday night. It was full and we had to wait about 20 min before being seated. The table of 8 that came in before us had to wait even longer, about an hour.We ordered a variety of things, but the ones that stuck out were the beef noodle soup and the roasted pig over rice - they're both so good! We also got the roasted duck over rice which was fattier and bonier but still good. We got the beef chow fun noodle dish because we saw the table next to us had it and it looked delicious. It was good, but I wouldn't be able to eat only that for a full meal and I probably wouldn't choose to order it again. We also got the Hong Kong style noodles with duck and that wasn't too flavorful so I wouldn't get it again either. Service was excellent! I look forward to coming back to try different dishes because I was only a fan of 2 of the 5 we ordered this time. I'll have to try the soft shell crab that everyone's talking about. Convenient spot for late night eats (usually get wonton noodle soup, a rice or stir fried noodle dish) after a night out on the town, however, last time I ate here (one week ago - January 2018); I had paper INSIDE the wonton I was served. Beware. This place is such a gem. It's rough on the edges but definitely a must have. My sister brought me to this spot in Chinatown a few weeks ago and I've loved it since. You walk in, you get shouted at to sit down, you're brought a pot of tea and the menus are placed underneath the glass table top on your table. I've had the baby bok choy and fell in love with it. My boyfriend loves the roast duck especially the green ginger sauce it comes with. You can order three meats over rice to find out what you like. We also tried to roast pork which is juicy and tender. My favorite is the beef and vegetables pan fried noodles. The noodles are sometimes really crunchy or have just enough crunch. It's a big portion, definitely something good to share. I always order a few things and share them with the table. Makes a good friend family din din. It's super casual. They give you oranges at the end with you bill- which I've always paid at the front by the register. I do look forward to coming back and trying the soft shell crab. I never know what to expect when eating in Chinatown, and I usually mentally prepare for the rude, loud, quick table turning experience before walking into any venue on or south of Canal, but this service was quite the opposite!  For a nearly empty restaurant on a wintery Friday night, they were over staffed, but none of the waiters wanted to help anyone.  All the waiters stared at the floor or talked to each other or went out for coffee.  Me and several other diners had to literally wave our hands after sitting for minutes for someone to decide to come help us (take our order, bring the check, you know, the basics!).  I even saw the chefs staring out into the restaurants wondering when the orders would actually be taken.  I ordered char siu wonton mein and salt & pepper squid.  For my noodle soup, I was a bit surprised that the char siu looked and tasted like brisket.  Normally cooked from the loin, my pieces were marbled and broke much like brisket.  The wontons were ok, nothing out of the ordinary.  The broth did taste deeper and richer (and not like "socks") than some neighboring establishments.Salt & pepper squid was questionable.  The batter and salt were good, pepper was a bit lacking.  Squid was also very firm.... and no tentacles served.  I once read an article that some Chinese restaurants serve pig colon instead of real squid... I couldn't get that article out of my mind when eating this dish.Eddie the Human Panda raves about this place.  While I wanted to love it, I left a bit confused by both the service and the food.  Nothing was really wrong, but nothing was really right either.  I'll put this one in the relatively large pile of mediocre hole in the walls of Chinatown. I tried the roast duck & wonton lo mein today. Generally I think it's the No. 1 or No 2 in china town already. Recommended by my Cantonese colleague which means the taste has already reached a certain level. Normally it's difficult to find proper Cantonese food here in china town and the taste is not even close to those in HK. I quite like their roast duck as well as the soup. You can feel that the soup is cooked long and all the flavor already goes inside the soup. The lomein can be a bit too wet but generally a go to restaurant for lunch:) I'm not even going to kid myself, I was really really really wasted and starving to death when I came in here a few weeks ago, thanks to Jonathan T.'s suggestion! Hidden in the middle of chinatown and kind of on the verge of being near all the courthouses, this gem serves up cheap chinese food that tastes homemade out of someone's kitchen and with plenty of noodles. I had the roast duck in noodle soup for only $5.25. Deal of the century because they give you what looks like half of a roasted duck in the middle of your bowl of soup. Everything else my friends ordered looked great, I just wish I remembered what it was. Place is fairly spacious with round tables spread out and seemed pretty clean. Extra bonus points - They are open until 4am! I'm sure I've been here before but it had to have been years ago. I stopped by a few days ago mainly because it was across the street from the M103 bus that I needed to take uptown. I was also hungry and it was chilly out so..wonton noodle soup!The order took about 7 minutes to prepare and cost $5.50. I caught the bus. I did not end up eating until about 35 minutes later but the noodles held their own and still had a nice chew. The wontons really stole the show though. There were four big ones and it was all shrimp. Each bite was so light and fresh! How does the shrimp stay so bouncy and light sitting in soup for so long? I wanted more.I'll be sure to return. You know this place is great when you walk into the tiny old space and it's packed with locals, tourists and cops. The food here is fast, cheap and good. Majority of times I've come here it's just to take out, but they do have tables if you want to sit and eat from the expanded menu. They offer most of what us white people would expect from their Chinese restaurants, but I'd recommend trying something new. I love Chasu Fan (roast pork over rice), just a real comfort food for me, and they do it pretty well here. Not as good as it use to be. I usually order Cha siew (roast pork) with Lai fun but it's not the same. The roasted pork was not flavorful and the noodles were more on the hard side. Soup base was good but overall, it was not a good experience. Ordering was super fast though ! Cash only establishment...This is a 3.5 star rating. Since Yelp does not give partial star, I rounded up to the nearest star.This place is located conveniently off of Canal Street. I understand that many shops in NYC are cash only establishments, however, they need to fix this.Now that's out of the way, this place is interesting. First off, rather than picking up a menu as you sit at your table, they have their menus underneath a clear glass that is held on the tabletop. That way, they wont need to distribute the menus to each guest / table. This is clever because the menu won't ever get dirty as it is sheltered by the glass tabletop.Food wise, their prices are reasonably priced. Some dishes are very cheap whereas others are priced a bit high. Their BBQ dishes are cheap. I ordered the 2 BBQ dish over rice. It was about $6.75 before tax. You can choose between roast pig, roast pork, roast duck or chicken. You can order a 3 meat BBQ dish for $1 more ($7.75). Unfortunately, they did not have the BBQ meat that I wanted, so we didn't order the dish.Congee - fairly good. Good for 2 people.A popular dish everyone ordered was their pan fried noodles with seafood and veggie. It was about 13 dollar dish. Fairly good. However, they only gave us 2 jumbo shrimps total. They were generous with the squid and scallops though.Overall, this place is best for late night as they open till 4am on weekends. However, given that they only take cash dropped it 1 star. Also, their kitchen area is a bit dirty. But then again, this is New York Chinatown. I'll come back here again for late night eats. However, if I am eating out earlier in the day, I'll go elsewhere. Cantonese style comfort food.  Don't come here for the decor or service. However I was pleased to see traditional Chinese style tables and chairs which are rare in a restaurant at this price range.  But maybe they chose the chairs because they are not very comfortable so the tables will turn quickly.It was not busy so I was pleased that they let me sit at a table even though my daughter had not arrived.She had pan fried noodles with char shiu and I had beef juk with a Chinese donut.Everything was good, but not exceptional.There are numerous servers so there wasn't a waiter who was assigned to our table. One person refilled our tea cups and another person cleared the table, taking my cup right after it was refilled before I could drink. I thought of making a comment but did not bother. I had already paid the bill and definitely over tipped!

I've come here for the oysters on a weekday and bar hopping on Saturday. The oysters were fresh and paired well with the drink specials they had for happy hour.  The Saturday night I went bar hopping in the LES, I found this place really packed so try not to go from 11:30-1:30 unless you love crowded bars. Music was pretty good with lots of 90's pop/hip-hop thrown in. Never underestimate the power of a good bottomless brunch. For $40, you get your pick of a gigantic plate of food, a small side, and all of the mimosas and/or Bloody Marys you can drink. I would highly recommend calling beforehand and making a reservation; otherwise, you definitely won't get a booth seat and the bar and couch areas fill up fast, too. At 11:30 on a Sunday morning, we were fortunate enough to squeeze into some bar seating, but it wasn't the most comfortable and we didn't really have enough space on the countertop.The mimosas are STRONG. 3 carafes later, my friend and I were nicely buzzed despite eating a whole plate of food. Totally worth the trip.The food was great, too. We both ordered the Farmer's Breakfast and I got the yogurt parfait as the side. The bacon was a nice, thick and fat strip of meat - some of it was a little overcooked while other parts were perfectly soft. The sausage was excellently flavored. And the grits were chunky, just the way I like 'em.Service is pretty quick and the staff is really friendly, so come on by if you're looking for a place to get your bottomless brunch fix. Solid place. Cute rustic decor. Booths for food service. Fun dance floor. Average priced NYC drinks ($14 cocktails). I enjoyed the "Flip the Frog" gin cocktail. Friendly bartenders who kept their cool and were kind, despite the constantly crowded bar. Option for party reservations in an XL booth, which was intimate and surprisingly spacious. The place was fully packed around 11 on Saturday night, but it significantly cleared out around 12:30/1am, probably with all the suburbanites rushing to catch trains back to the Island/NJ. I'd come back. Good cocktails, good music, and good crowd. They also have a room with couches inside. My friend booked it before for her 30's bday party, and it was pretty decent. They also have booth area and high tables as well. There's dance floor near the bar. The only downside about this bar was they only have two bathrooms and there was always a huge line... but other than that, I enjoyed my time here. Came here for my cousin's birthday. She reserved the small couch area in the front. She had a lot of people and it was really tight, I wish they had removed the table from that area so that we could've had a little more space. All of her guests were buying drinks at the bar. There was more space in the back but because it was so crowded it was body on body wall to wall. The negative to this place is the single bathroom for men and women. I waited until I got home before I got on that line. Otherwise the music was good it was a chill place to hang out and meet people. Everyone at her party had a good time. Not sure about how the prices were because I didn't purchase any drinks. A friend of mine offered to treat me to dinner and drinks, and Hill and Dale was their venue of choice. I wish I could give this restaurant 4-and-a-half stars, because it ranks pretty highly among my dining/drinking experiences, even if it does not quite hit the 5-star mark. It's definitely high on my list of places to return to!The interior is lovely - spacious, to say the least. There are tables, a bar with a decent amount of seating, and a lounge area with sofas and chairs. It's very tastefully designed, and the dim lighting sets a calm, relaxed atmosphere. I had trouble choosing what to eat, because a lot of things on the menu caught my eye. I settled for chicken fingers, while my friend chose the wings. As soon as I smelled the wings, my mouth began to water - I just might have to try them next time!In keeping with my native Buffalonian ways, I ordered my fingers with a side of Buffalo sauce, in addition to the sweet mustard and Chipotle mayo that come as a standard. The Buffalo sauce was great - it was closer to an authentic Buffalo flavor than I think can be found at most places in NYC. However, I also loved the other 2 dipping sauces - each one tangy and unique in its own right. The tenders were cooked perfectly - crispy on the outside, but moist on the inside.The bartender was very friendly and knowledgeable on the menu items! She was happy to provide my additional side of Buffalo sauce, along with the 2 sauces the tenders come with - something you wouldn't think tends to be an issue at restaurants, but has been for me in the past (though I'm always happy to pay an upcharge if that's the policy). As far as a portion-to-price ratio goes, no complaints here.The biggest recommendation for improvement I would make is to have more wines available, although this isn't a deal-breaker for me. I'm glad I came here! Hill and Dale is also one of my all time favorite place. I love coming here because the bartenders are extremely friendly (especially Winnie). What I love most about Hill and Dale isn't just their drinks (Summer Fling & Floozy *screams*), but their food... Their food is what really gets me.You MUST try their mac & cheese, devil eggs with pork belly, oysters, and their artichoke dip--absolutely amazing. I am a person who loves extremely cheesey food. Think CHEESE and Hill and Dale definitely delivers on that.If you want a nice bar to come to where it isn't that crazy, come here on weekdays! It's always great on those days. It gets crazy on Thursday and Friday (definitely Friday because, Friyay). They also do Victorian Burlesque on Thursdays (or was it Tuesdays? Pretty sure it's Thursday but please call them and ask) if you are interested. As for weekends, it is packed for brunch!p.s.-$1 oysters for happy hour, how could you hate this place? Nope. I made a birthday party reservations with Hill and Dale's private dining manager Aya.When we arrived our party was divided into two diff booths. When we asked for a bigger table to seat the whole party the MANAGER, Ryan, came over to our table full of aggression and what he called "sarcasm". We politely said we would like to all sit together since it was a celebration. He told us he didnt have other tables for us. Then he asked me if I was "lying about the reservation". Yes, he was the manager. Then he tells us, "you are not going to be happy until i kick the other big group out and seat u guys." We never asked to move or kick anybody out. After my friend mentioned that his comment and attitude were completely uncalled for and made all of us feel uncomfortable andHe ended up shoving us into a tight table in the back. We all had to squeeze. "You guys have to end by 9:30." Omg. Can we just start our bday party?  I was very very disappointed by the service. I was embarrassed and called a liar. Such a joke. We are the paying customer and the manager treated us like we were a pest. We wont be coming back.But the Floozy was good Bottomless Brunch - MUST TRY!  We will be back!First of all, our waiter Joey was fantastic!  He was so friendly and knowledgeable about the menu.  I ordered based on his health-conscious SUPER THOUGHTFUL recommendation and ended up getting baked eggs (just whites, no cheese) and a side of fruit.Okay, now let's talk ambiance.  Intimate dark leather booths with wood-paneled walls and ornate wallpaper (see photos). The lighting is dim with various vintage fixtures.  All around the restaurant, antique radios and record players are on display.  You MUST go here!  I highly recommend making a reservation for the bottomless brunch.  You can choose between mimosa or bloody mary.  They also let you switch if you want to.  The service is excellent and it makes for a great IG backdrop! Trashy bar with trashy clientele. I wouldn't bother going here. Plenty of nicer bars in the LES to be honest. All nasty b and t people and the staff are rude too. Save your time and go down the road to Antler or Marshall Stack where the service is real. Don't be fooled by the fake accelerated reviews like we were I'm really neutral about this place. Really nice decor and vibe but not so great music and DJ. He seemed really nice at first and was taking requests -- but then never played them. Why not just say you're not taking requests? Who doesn't play "Hey Ya!" when requested??!?! Mad man. Anyway, they've got nice cocktails and dim lighting. So it's a good place for a first date or smaller groups. Where do I start? Upon entering I was a bit confused because no one was in front greeting guest. No host and all the servers and cooks overlooked me. So I walk to the back/bar approached the bar tender who turned out to the manager Ryan. I politely asked if I should wait to be seated or if i should seat myself. His only response was "No" . Very confused, I took a seat at the bar and waited for someone to at least offer some service, about 5 minutes pass and nothing so i walk to the front, ironically the actual bartender walks in, I question about being seated she asked how big my party was and suggested we sit at the bar. At the bar i let her know the rest of my party will be arriving a little late. To keep it short and simple up until the point where my guest arrived the bartender gave me horrible service and was pretty unresponsive with my inquiries about the menu. 15 minutes later my guest shows up and the bartenders attitude lifts just a bit. We ate and without even asking she gives us the bill, that's fine we pay and she comes back and questions us about the tip amount. I let her know our tip is representative of your service. She grinned and said ok, now guess what i have an extra $30 charge on my account. Idk if they thought i wouldn't neck or wouldn't care but I'm did and now they have to deal with the rep of having a dishonest bartender. I would not revisit here or even try it to begin with. Don't let these reviews from their friend fool you. I had my 33rd here - yeah it is hard for me to even recognize that I am that age. I could not have had a better experience. I e-mailed about a month in advance to reserve a space, and Aya could not have made it easier. It didn't cost me anything to get a space for 10 reserved on a Thursday (I have no idea if there is a fee Friday or Saturday, but I could understand if there was. Hung out for the first hour at the bar with Winnie, who is a goddamn hero, good for a laugh and good with the pour for a whiskey shot. She'll make anyone have a good night! We had table service throughout the night and the happy hour on weekdays go to 8 pm. LOTS of drinks on happy hour and great food specials as well. Any draft pint $5, well cocktails and select wines $6, as well as daily bartender specials. I guzzled down the bubbly rose (It was April and hell summer is right around the corner), and at $6 a glass, it was a steal. If you're looking to have a birthday party I can't recommend them enough, the bar seems small from the front but it opens up into a big and beautiful space, with plenty of seating for large groups. Not far from the FMBD, easy access to the rest of the City and BK. I'll be back again for sure! I will never come back here. My friend Called a week ahead and reserved a table with Aya for my Birthday. The hostess confirmed we would have the large booth in the front of the restaurant that would accommodate our party of 10. We arrived last night and placed at 2 separate back to back tables. The MANAGER, Ryan, came over and We politely said we would like to all sit together since it was my birthday. He threw his hostess under the bus and said "she must have messed up. We can't put you all together at the front booth. So, either my hostess was misinformed or you're LYING!" He flat out accused us of lying. After my friend mentioned that his comment and attitude were completely uncalled for. It made all of us feel uncomfortable and unwelcome, Ryan, the manager, had a nasty reply: "it's sarcasm. What do you want me to do? You wont be happy until I move you to the front booth." We never asked to be moved to the front booth (which was being occupied). We just wanted to sit together. He ended up shoving us into a tight table in the back. We all had to squeeze. There weren't enough stools & he gave us a time limit. He told us we Needed to be out in 90minutes. All of this because his hostess didn't book our party properly and gave us wrong information and false promises. This place has a snotty attitude for basically being an immediate post college bar in the lower east side. We were was embarrassed and called liars. Save yourself the hassle and go across the street to Grey Lady. Your establishment physically threw innocent female bystanders who had drinks thrown at them out of their bar.  Shame on you for not getting to the bottom of the situation and just throwing the easier targets (women of color) out of the bar. Be sure that we will never visit this bridge and tunnel establishment again. Love this place!After actively searching for an appropriate bar to celebrate my birthday, a friend suggested Hill & Dale. It had everything I was looking for: unpretentious vibes, fairly priced drinks, and good music. When I got there at 9pm, the place was already bumping. I drank a fair share of the floozy which was DELISH and adorably adorned with a daisy. The music was on point. Everyone in my group commented on what a great bar it was. There was a good ebb and flow to the crowd so it never felt like it was impossibly stuffed. I did email them a few weeks in advance to try and reserve the couches in the back, but they were booked. They were super nice and tried to find me alternative options, but I decided just to wing it and I'm super happy I did! They offer great party packages as well. Highly recommend! Awesome vibes! Tried this because of the reviews and was not disappointed. Great ambiance and bottomless brunch is worth it- strong mimosas, good music. They were slammed that day and our food was cold- waiter took back right away and gave us our drinks on the house. Must go for Sunday funday! The service, the food, the people of Hill & Dale are amazing.I love their pancakes and the maple syrup they have, it's the perfect balance during Boozy Brunch. They have a projector in the back where you get to play Mario Kart with your friends during Brunch, how much better can this place get? I say expand the menu. AMAZING DJ on the weekends with a relaxed, casual atmosphere and plenty of seating ranging from booths to lounge areas.  A great venue for gatherings and birthday drinks.  The only challenge is that there is only 1 bathroom so that can present some very long lines. Totally recommend Came here few times! Love their happy hour! Food and drinks are on point. Great for groups

Came here for a birthday dinner and we had a great time! The menu was a little overwhelming, but since it was a big group of us, we decided to stick to just hotpot (the other option was just Korean bbq, or a combo of both). Everyone had their own pot which was great, because it meant we could all choose what broth we wanted (personally I don't like spicy but almost everyone else did, so I'm glad to have been able to choose individually). We tried to not go too crazy with ordering (someone said that while it is unlimited, you get charged for whatever you leave behind - makes sense but not sure how strict they are about it or whether or not that's true), so we stuck to a few basic meats and then a ton of veggies that always taste amazing in hot pot! The service itself wasn't great - understandably we required less attention since we were just cooking everything ourselves, but when we wanted to order more of stuff or even just get more water, it was a little stressful to get someone's attention. However, it was also a friday night and super busy.The other thing that was annoying was the line for sauces - it would be nice to have the option to either just pick some and have them brought to the table (maybe in some type of squirt jar so that whatever you don't use isn't wasted) and only going up to the sauce bar if you wanted to see them all. Especially with the 2 hour limit, having something take 15+ minutes was frustrating!Things to note before going - birthday girls or guys get free dinner within three days of your birthday and if you bring a cake, which we took advantage of. Next, we brought boxed wine because despite there being a $15 uncorking fee (it's BYO but it looked like you could also order if you wanted, not sure about this but I saw a ton of beer bottles that were all the same), which is pretty low, we figured we'd save a little more and only "uncork" one white and one red for our group. Last thing that we didn't like was that the shrimp came with shells, tails and heads and getting all that off yourself isn't the most enjoyable thing, especially at a dinner table. Would have been nice to have the option of clean or whole!There was, as listed on the menu, a 2 hour limit to seating/drinking, however we were definitely not rushed out. It might have been because we had dinner towards the end of the night, or because we had a bigger table that another big group wasn't waiting on, but it was nice to not feel rushed out. Overall we had a great time and would definitely come back! I use to come here literally all the time when they first opened. Food is always super fresh and service was always amazing until my recent visit (-1 star for the most recent visit).It took about 40-45 minutes before we were seated. Prior to that, both the hostess completely ignored us even though we were standing right in front trying to get their attention. Finally someone acknowledged us and told us it'll be a 40 minute wait. Be prepare to wait longer so go take a walk around Little Italy. They do give a call once your table is ready so don't worry!The service was extremely slow! It was a full house in the basement level but there were many waiters. We received menus immediately but took about 15 minutes before we were able to call a waiter over to take our drinks order. On top of that, the music was way too loud that our server didn't seem to hear us when ordering and I had to scream it to him a few times. He definitely could not hear over the loud music because I received a few wrong items and a few items were missed.Moving on to the food!You have a choice of hot pot(24.99?), BBQ or both(31.99 I believe). We went with the hot pot option. You can choose personal pots or duo/trio pots. Many soup options to choose from! Highly recommend the curry flavor or herbal soup. You'll get the options of the usual hot pot items. Highly recommend fatty beef, different kinds of fish balls and fish tofu, udon and lastly veg. Sauce stations are on both floors so don't be a dummy and walk upstairs when you're seated in the basement floor! There's man options to choose from so play around with it! My new current favorite is the bbq hoisin but I do love a good mix of peanut sauce, regular hoisin, scallions, cilantro, garlic and sesame oil. Don't forget the hot sauce!Notes:- Reservations minimum of 7 people.- Don't forget the dessert at the end! Black rice sweet soup and taro sago!- Check in for ice cream. One check in for the entire table (4 people = 4 ice cream!) Vanilla, chocolate or green tea.- Limit of 2 hours.- Credit cards accepted.- Order what you can eat and continue to order throughout your meal. Not all at once in case you have too much leftover I loooove them here.I took them up on their birthday offer two years ago (free dinner for the birthday guy/gal within three days of your birthday and if you bring a cake). I was more into pie than cake at that time, and they okayed us bringing a pie in lieu of a cake (which they do keep cold for you). We also had a party larger than 6 people, so we were able to make reservations. It was a fun, fun time.I went again yesterday (why it took so long for me to go back there, I have no idea). And they are still just as awesome (actually, even more awesome). Apparently in all the hubbub of my previous visit, I totally missed out on the amazing artwork (that are copies of street art found in Malaysia). Not just the big one of the kids on the bike you see when you enter the restaurant, but in more hidden areas as well.The space is huge (there's a downstairs area further back), with two stations for your sauce mix and dessert. And it's AYCE for hot pot or BBQ or BOTH. How can you go wrong?!Admittedly. Admittedly. The quality isn't the highest. But if you expect high quality from an AYCE place then you'd have to be willing to shell out major, major dough. But the price point is great here (you pay more if you don't finish what you order, friends). The only thing I think they are missing are tomatoes for their hotpot, but I can live.I love that their tables include both the larger burner or the smaller ones if you want to go individual. I love how quick they are with bringing out the noms. And I love the people. The hostess in charge (boss lady?) was very sweet when I told her I was early, but two of my friends were coming (they only seat entire parties). The server who took our order was very nice, all the runners who brought or food/refilled our soup/refilled our water were also great, and then when I was eating, I knocked my water glass over and it shattered all over the place, and they were really nice about it.Also, I LOVE their desserts. There's the coconut xi mi lu (taro, yam, coconut, tapioca) and the red bean & black glutinous rice with coconut milk. Two of my favorite desserts. They are lacking in the amount of tapioca and black rice, respectively. But WHO CARES?! THEY ACTUALLY HAVE THAT! Awesome.Love them. Love this place. Would be happy to celebrate many, many birthdays here. They don't take reservation unless you come with a party of six or more so expect to wait especially on a very cold winter day. Luckily, we came here with a party of six and they do require that everyone shows up before being seated. If you can't wait and want to be seated right away, then they will start docking your 2 hour time limit once the table is set up. Their food is definitely fresh and delicious. Though not everything is available even though it's listed on the menu. They claim it's because they ran out. Hmmm...quite interesting to run out of crab when arrived around 6:30pm. Dunno, but this seems too convenience. Either case, if you're into hotpot and something that's healthy and interactive, then Hometown is one spot to check out. Though do expect a very long wait and excruciating wait. Their price is reasonable, for Manhattan rent and their food service is excellent. Great place for hot pot/kbbq. We did both and both were fantastic. The selections on the menu was decent and we thoroughly enjoyed ourselves here! **TIP**They have a 2 hour eating limit as do most all you can eat hot pot places and bbqs and any food wasted will have an extra charge. There's not overly strict with the food waste, but you have to use your best judgement. Also if you come for your birthday it's a free entry meal, of course with proof of birth (License). **Atmosphere**Very airy place. I definitely enjoyed that because the last place I went for hot pot, it was very hot and we went during the winter time! So I definitely appreciate the air circulation and how open the restaurant is. **Food**Everything that was brought out was fresh. You also have the option of ordering a large version of the item you want or the small so that you don't overdo it on the ordering. **Service**Service was great too. The servers were all very attentive and they all seemed to work together. **Comparison**Hometown and 99 Favor are both relatively similar in terms of service and food. I think Hometown has a more modern feel to the place and the place has more open space which is good when everyone wants to do hot pot, so it allows for more breathing room. I think either or, you can't do wrong. Hometown seems to have more english speaking servers versus 99 favors where I had to have a friend do a lot of the translating. A friend recommended this place so as a hotpot professional i decided to give it a try. We ordered hotpot with 3 broth (tomato spicy and normal soup). Broth is not tasteful meaning the spicy section is not spicy at all. Menu has very limited selections of veggies and meat. And the dipping sauce section is ok, pretty standard.Good thing about this place is that its pretty spacious and has big tables. Its also clean and the waiters are good. Its just the food that lacks. hot pot on a freezing night in NY? YES PLEASE! we put our name and number down and it was about an hour wait which was perfect because we walked over to an ice cream spot for some pre-dinner dessert and you know, get a lil colder! hahaonce we were seated, we ordered damn near everything on the menu! i got the tom yum broth and it was so flavorful! all the meats and seafood tasted fresh so did all of the veggies. the sauce bar tho! they have everything you need to make your sauce! minced garlic, green onions, sesame seeds, sesame oil, chili paste, chili oil, wasabi and some yummy house sauces. enjoyed every bite! Tip of the day: You can call in to claim your spot in line as there's usually an hour wait.I got the AYCE Hot Pot ($24). It was an immense amount of food and I'm glad they had pre-made sauces as I'm the worst at creating my sauces now for some reason. All the meats and veggies were good, but I agree with the others that the blue crab quality was subpar. In addition, the table is really long so you pretty much have to shout in order to have a conversation.Even after being extremely full and not able to finish what we had left, I got the red bean soup dessert, which was really good. They have a coconut soup dessert with mochi/other beans as well.Meal Value (from 1-10, my measure of quantity/quality of the meal compared to price): 8Pretty standard AYCE Hot Pot value, but from all the sauces to fresh veggies and good meats, I give this place better value than usual. Oh what an adorable place. This place is pretty huge I have to say. Seating everywhere and they even have a downstairs. Which is where the bathroom is FYI. We came in right before several other groups came in. We got all you can eat hot pot and bbq. $32? A person for that. Oh em gee. Get the beef with black pepper sauce for the bbq. You won't regret it! I liked how they had chicken satay and even beef satay for bbq. They love their peanut sauce, I mean look at their sauce bar. I liked the variety for hot pot meats and such. They didn't have a lot of green leafs options which is fine as I didn't care for them anyways. They had an okay selection for vegetarian things I believe. I just remembered a bunch of veggies and tofus stuffed with fish paste. More for Pesci pollo vegetarians. Overall the selections were okay. Nothing crazy. The beef melted in my mouth for the hot pot. It was delicious. I was scared it was going to be chewy. The lamb for the Hotpot was okay. Not melt in your mouth but it's decent. It's a little bit gamy. You can definitely tell it was lamb. They had a good variety for hot pot broth. Like 6-8 ish? I think I came to the fact that I'm not huge on Szechuan peppers. Not really because of the numbing part but because it gives off a floral taste and it makes me gag a bit to be honest. Well from a past experience. It's not terrible here. The broth was good. Not really florally until you bite into a peppercorn which I did by mistake. The curry broth was very curry. It was my favorite of the bunch. Super coconuty and strong flavor. Kimchi, well my friend chose that. Was okay with it but I did like to eat the cabbage itself that was in it. I wonder what Tom yum taste like. When it came to the stuff coming out. I got majority of what I asked for except one meat on the first round. But got it on the second round. Other than that, got everything I wanted. The staff wasn't very interactive with you. They just did their thing then left. Which is whatever I guess. He brought out what I wanted so I'm not complaining. There is complimentary dessert at the sauce bar. Two kinds: a taro and sweet potatoes type of soup and a red bean one. They're both served warm/hot and I loved the taro one. From being full, I ate two bowls of it and a bowl of red bean. I would like to try other places as well for all you can eat. I am not a AYCE fan but this place exceeded my expectations.  I meet up with a bunch of friends who wanted hot pot in Chinatown.  Since I normally only go to Flushing, I used Yelp to help me find this place.We went in 6:30 on a Friday night, the hostess told us the wait was 2 hours.  Our party of 5 was seated in about an hour.  $23.99 for hot pot, 27.99 for BBQ and 31.99 for both is reasonable for AYCE in the city.  Best part is they offer individual pots on induction cook tops.The waiter came and took our orders and the food came out pretty quick.  The sauce bar was re-stocked frequently and was pretty clean for such a crowded place.  Next to the sauce bar, they also offered sweet soup desserts (red bean soup with coconut milk or sweet potato with tapioca and coconut milk).  The food was fresh and presented well.  I got the spicy ma la broth and boy it was spicy.  The large amount of szechuan  peppers left my tongue slighty numb..lol.  The wait staff was quick to clean up and also was readily available for re-orders.  Overall this place server really fresh and good food for a very reasonable price.  Only con is the long wait since they don't take reservations. We arrived at 5:30 on Christmas day for hot pot and BBQ. They indicated it will be an 1.5 hour wait. Since it was 35 degrees outside, we decided, let's wait. It is $32 for both hotpot and bbq, so we decided to do both to get an idea on the quality on both offerings. The place is much bigger than you think because they also have a downstairs area. It is super clean and the ventilation is good. It's important when the place serves hotpot and bbq. The menu is huge and has pictures for each item. This is important when you're not familiar with hotpot and can see what you are getting.The positives is that the hotpot was more successful. The seafood was very fresh. Loved the stuffed items that are special to them, especially the jalapeno stuffed with fish paste. The soup bases were all really good too, curry, kimchi and tom yum. The sauce bar has a ton of options. Much more options than most and the quality is very good. The beef was really good, but I think we need a better balance of fat and meat. It was almost like beef belly, but it was very tender and delicious.The not so good is the lamb and bbq items. The lamb was so thickly sliced and lean that after cooking, it was quite tough. The bbq short ribs and jerky we ordered were way too sweet. I've never had fresh raw jerky prepared right on the grill before, so it was quite a novelty. The style is like the Malaysian jerky. The nice thing about the bbq is that the servers cook for you.Overall, I feel that we have better hotpot places with higher quality of meats in SF and SF Bay Area. This is my go to hotpot place if I'm in Chinatown and craving hotpot. But they're always so busy and packed, lunch time is less busy than dinner. I've been here many times and there were once or twice when I waited over an hour for dinner but it was worth it. There's something I really like about hometown, not just the food. Service isn't bad either. I really liked how clean and bright it seems whereas other hotpot places give off a dimmed and dirty feel. I also like the high ceiling making the space seem bigger than it already is. There's an upper and lower level. They're pretty quick with bringing the broth base and food out usually. I really really love their dessert, well one of them. The purple rice sweet soup? I always leave space for 2-3 bowls of that at the end! Even if I'm already full, I still go for 2-3 bowls. You know what that says. The dessert is hot like it should be not warm or almost cold. There is one weird thing though, I don't like how the pot locations are arranged on the tables and the tables are really wide and far from opposite sides. So it gets hard to speak to friends or hard to hear them. Other than that, I would keep coming back. This is one of my favourite AYCE restaurants. We had the hotpot and bbq combo. The food is good and clean. The service is even better. The stuffs are very nice. They have a wide range of sauces. Highly recommend. The wait isn't long. They are less busy comparing to other hotpot places in Asian communities. You get free ice cream if you checked in on Yelp upon existing. A good variety of sauces to choose from. They didn't have crabs and clams that night. These two are my favorite when it come to hotpot. However, missing crabs and clams didn't bother me much. What really bothered me that night was the service. The wait staff didn't know take the initiative to check on our table or refill our soup nor the plates. The place is severely lacking management IMO. It was also hard to catch the wait staff's attention even when they weren't busy. Hotpot is such a joyful type of meal. I usually enjoy hotpot very much wherever I go. Hometown's service really disappointed me. Best hot pot experience I've had in the states. It all starts when you walk by the walls painted with quaint artwork, past the tables of friends stuffing their faces and chatting the night away, into the back area where it opens up into multiple levels.So many meats/veggies/dumplings/everything. Naturally, I got the all you can eat hot pot. The menu is so amazing and so overwhelming - SO MANY OPTIONS. You tell your waiter what you want and they'll bring it to you. And don't worry too much about if you order too much because the more types of things you order, the smaller each portion. In other words, get a wide variety so you can try a lot!So many soups/sauces. You can get up to 3 varieties of soup for your hot pot. We went with the classic, spicy, and tom yum (all great). As for dipping sauces...there must've been about 50 varieties (and yes, it's serve yourself so you can mix and match as many as you want).TL;DR: great atmosphere, epic variety of everything, definitely coming back. Solid 3.5 stars. Sauce galore! Now, I love hot pot no matter if it's a hot or cold day. Now this place elicits mixed feelings from me because though they had great service, offered an abundant sauce selection, and even the option of doing 3 soups, they quality and taste just fell short. Now for $23.99/ person you can get all you can eat hot pot. If you go for just hot pot, the meat selection is very limited.  The AYCE BBQ is $27.99 which has a much larger meat selection. However, if you can't decide then go for both hot pot and bbq which is $31.99/ person. Since I just had KBBQ the night before we decided on just getting the AYCE hot pot. The meat selection was not as abundant as I'm used to for AYCE hot pots, but I wanted to give it a try. Normally, I enjoy a little marbling in my beef, but this place just had too much in their cuts. Maybe that was an atypical experience, but for AYCE it wasn't bad. The veggies were fresh and had all the veggies I really like including A-coy, bok choi, and tong ho. Overall, it was a satisfying hot pot meal, but not a meal I would wait for an hour for. Thankfully, we came during off hours and were promptly seated :) Honestly, I prefer 99 over hometown any day after the last encounter. Hometown meat is supposedly better quality than 99 favor but overall, I think 99 has better choices. FYI, if you come during your actual birthday, you need to bring ID and it's a free meal. If you come 3 days before or after, you need to show ID and a cake. If not, no free meal for you! Hometown Hotpot opened a few years ago but I had never gotten around to trying it. I kept going to 99 Favors. That is until I found out Hometown also has the free birthday dinner, so I decided to come here on my birthday. My boyfriend and I came in at around 7 pm on a Tuesday and it wasn't too packed. We were seated immediately. The birthday special works the same way as the one at 99 Favors. If you come on the day of your birthday, your meal is comped. If you come within the week, you have to bring a cake and then your meal will be comped. I opted for both the hot pot and the BBQ.For hot pot, the quality is pretty much the same as 99 Favors except Hometown seems to have fewer selections. Still, they had a good variety. BBQ was so much better than 99 Favors. At 99, they use the same damn marinade for every single dish, so after a while, it feels like you're eating the same thing. Here, they use different marinades, and they cook it for you. The quality of the meats also seem slightly better than its competitor.Sauce station was great! It's clean and compact, yet it has all the sauces you'd want - including a few of their 'Hometown special sauces'. I'm not quite sure what was in these sauces but we both really liked them.Service was very good. If you started looking at the menu again, someone would immediately come over. This did get a little annoying at one point but I would definitely rather this than not being able to find a waiter to order. Food comes out very quickly so it's best to order a little at a time, and not eat with your eyes.Finally, Hometown feels cleaner than 99 Favors probably since it's newer. But overall, I liked Hometown a lot better. I'll be coming here from now on whenever I need my hot pot fix. $32 for all you can eat hotpot and kbbq??? Free meal on your birthday??? Hometown is a dream come true. We came for a late dinner on a Thursday night and we're in meat heaven. Two hours of grilling, steaming, and Asian sauce combo testing. All the beef/steak options are well seasoned and tender and we ordered plate after plate. The chicken options are good but not as great and given limited stomach space, I'd opt for something else. The hotpot options are diverse as well but avoid the noodles and the veggies early on or else you can easily run out of appetite! Great seafood choices like fish balls, giant shrimp, and crab legs as well. The price is right, the quality is fresh, and if you optimize your selection you will have a surprisingly affordable feast. Con: This place does not take reservations, so we waited exactly 1.5 hours for dinner on a Sunday night. It's fine to wait on a freezing winter night, but idk how I'd feel about that in the summer....Pro: They gave us little treats while we waited in line-the mink creme brle that was really good, but it didn't came back around a second time :(Meal: Nice concept. Tried the hotpot, where each person cooks their own bowl. I got the kimchi soup base, which was actually spicier than the curry base! When you order beef, one order is 5 slices, so make sure you get at least 10 orders for a table of 4. We realized this later in the evening and was so full after  ~15 orders. Everything else is your standard hotpot ingredients - mushroom, fish ball, tripe, chicken, fried tofu, watercress, corn, etc. Honestly I didn't think there'd be enough food but we had more than enough after ordering the above.I can't stress how cool their concept is for hotpot-aside from the DIY you also get to mix your own sauces at a buffet-style counter and the tech used here is super chic and modern! Can't wait to try their BBQ next time.

Note: This review is specifically for BRUNCH!While I reluctantly admit to being a regular at Hotel Chantelle as a nighttime destination during my party girl days while living on the Lower East Side (haven't we all?) I am proud to say I have graduated to being a regular at brunch, and I can't tell you how much I love it. Anyone that knows me well knows that this is one of my favorite go-to's for a consistently solid brunch: the atmosphere is open, airy and gorgeous - and the retractable rooftop means that you get natural lighting and an "outdoor" feel, which is something you don't get year round in New York. The service is top notch (insert shameless plug about the lovely hostess Shauna), the delicious select brunch drinks flow seamlessly (at $0.92 each), and there is something on the menu for everyone. Everything I have ordered here from the burger to the burrata to the egg crostini to the lobster caesar has been great, and don't even get me started on their parmesan truffle tots. Typically they have a band for weekend brunch that is always fantastic and really elevates the room's overall environment. The vibe is usually on the dressier side as there are always a good amount of birthday parties or celebrations happening, so while there's no need to go overboard you definitely want to look decent. So come here for your birthday, a girl's day out, with your visiting friends/family from out of town, or if you're like me come for any and no reason at all and enjoy! Yo this place is okay I've been here 3 times now. But the last time I rolled in and was about to buy drinks for my party of 25, however the bouncer asked me to move seats so I asked my group if they wanted to move to the bar next door and we did.  It's a great place however with standards like that you may bring in big spenders but you also lost out on like $500 just from one drink each of this group. Keep doing what you're doing but if you're not a bit nicer I guarantee your bar will be empty by 2020. Good luck guys. My review is strictly for the night scene of this place. I haven't been here during the day, but at night all I can is that the bouncers, staff, and bartenders are EXTREMELY rude and saying this doesn't even do it justice.They must be told by management "You have to be rude" because if not they need to clean house or do some serious staff training. There's a difference between being strict and being extremely rude to your paying customers. The bouncers were kicking people out for no reason, the bathroom staff were yelling at people for wanting to go to the bathroom, and the bartender acted like asking for a water after buying 4 shots of tequila was like asking for free alcohol. Good luck if you want to go here at night This place has been my cousin and I favorite summer time to spot for years. Finally today I made it a point to brunch and love love loveeed the dj! So shouts to the DJ. I enjoyed my burger and fries .. I kept it pretty basic with a mimosa, followed by a pitcher of vodka, prosecco and lemon juice shared amongst my cousin, aunt and myself. Wouldn't mind coming back to try dinner here and of course partying. Came here last night to model in a fashion show.  My gentleman friend who came to see me got a bottle ticket from the show organizer where he was told it was $30 for gratuity.  He accepts this and our group (the models, designers, hair/makeup professionals, photographers & the like) partake in 1 bottle of vodka.  I drank less than 1/4 of it in one glass poured for me (since I have next to no alcohol tolerance and my father was an emotionally abusive alcoholic so I don't really drink).When we get ready to pay up (which I was asked to do by my gentleman friend in an unappreciated ambush but that was a conversation amongst ourselves), I receive this.  Being more than 3x the amount we are told is owed, I speak with the event organizer & the designer I was working with (who'd experienced his own grievances there, including 2 VIPs being rejected at the door for lack of ID though I know one of them personally; he doesn't look under 21 & is a celebrity).  During this time, my friend speaks with a guy I presume is the manager who says we can pay the $30 after all.  I say this to the event organizer.When this manager returns, the event organizer gets upset at him & tells me this bill is an "estimate" + we can pay what we want, including nothing.  I asked why they couldn't just give us a proper bill listing the 1 bottle we actually had (I couldn't drink 1/4 of a bottle in a sitting & we were both present for the bottle service) & that when you give someone a bill like this, they are going to assume they owe this.  The event organizer is not pleased here, I inform the manager than I'm an attorney (and have been for over 9 years in NY) & that under NY law, you are not required to pay a tip.  I also stated that because he said we could pay nothing, that is exactly what we were paying and I told my friend "Darling, let's go."Had we simply gotten a corrected, accurate bill with the $30 quoted price, we'd have been fine.  I feel bad for the bottle service lady but I didn't appreciate this extortion attempt nor any attempt to fix this situation.  Security escorted us out & I left with my head held high having maintained principles.  Don't try messing with a sober lawyer's limited income. Note that this review is only for brunch, and I cannot speak to the club scene that occupies the same space later on. Hotel Chantelle offers a phenomenal brunch downtown. The service is adequate and what you would expect from a bar-turned-brunch restaurant. The setting is great, though, with a covered ceiling when it rains or open when the weather is nice.I ordered the Breakfast Pizzette which was every bit as good as it sounds and came out piping hot. The truffle tater tots are also a must and a great complement to any entree. They were offering two 92 cent cocktails while I was there. The Easy Passage was good but not as good as their seasonal drink, if offered when you are there. Overall the brunch is well-priced and underrated due to the negative reviews for the bar/nightclub. Keep in mind that they will charge you $1 for water (disclosed in small print on the menu)--let your server know that you do not want to pay and they will not charge you for it. Had an great time at Hotel Chantelle for brunch on Saturday!I booked a reservation for 4 a few weeks in advance for 11:30 AM on the rooftop. However, due to personal conflict, we moved our reservation to 12:30 PM. Unfortunately, there was no space on the rooftop - and no cancellations either - so we were seated inside instead.At 12:30 PM, my friends and I were the only people in the entire restaurant to be seated inside. The space inside Hotel Chantelle is honestly very nice - a bit unsettling because it was so empty, but only because everyone else was on the rooftop. A thing to note though: the rooftop doesn't really have a view and is quite a small space, so besides the lack of sun, we didn't really mind being inside. First and foremost, the drinks here are CHEAP and STRONG. You can get a variety of drinks for under a dollar. We ordered pitchers which were $8. At first, they didnt taste too strong - but I ended up getting drunk quite fast, so it's definitely worth it!The food is also phenomenal. I ordered the Egg White Frittata and I customized the order by adding truffle oil. The waitress was very accommodating in tweaking my order. I will say that service was a bit slow. I assume this was because we were the only people inside and most of the waiters/waitresses were concentrating their efforts upstairs. However, once the food came my friends and I were more than pleased with what we ordered. Highly recommend the egg white frittata as well as the Eggs Benedict (They have options for build your own!) and the fries.Overall, I had a wonderful experience and will definitely come here for brunch again. Came here with reservations for my friends birthday at the upstairs bar/dining area. They informed us they couldn't seat us until our entire party arrived but when they did arrive, we still had to wait an additional 30-45 minutes for a table. Pretty disappointing since  these reservations were made weeks in advance and my friend had to put a card down to hold the reservation. To make up for it, however, they gave us our first round of drinks on the house.The food while small and pricey was good. The only dish I clearly remember getting is the Spicy Tuna Avocado Toast which was good but the hardened toast made it hard to eat. I definitely recommend the drinks- I'm not a huge fan of cucumbers but the Libertine was surprisingly good and very refreshing. I was visiting New York and we came here for brunch with a group of four people. As soon as we got upstairs I could already tell this place was going to be adorable. It's decorated nicely and is the coolest little rooftop restaurant/bar spot. There's also a cute private room off to the side (perfect for parties) that's totally secluded from the rest of the place. We had to wait about 30 minutes before getting seated so we decided to go sit by the bar. The bar area is really clean and open and we were right by the live band (which was awesome).I ordered the crab cakes and my fianc ordered the chicken and waffles. The crab cakes were absolutely amazing and hands down one of my favorite crab cakes I've ever eaten. I love seafood and these crab cakes were delicious. They were lightly fried so it wasn't overwhelming and they came with an aioli on it that was the perfect compliment. There was also a corn chowder and arugula sprinkled on top. It comes with two crab cakes and it's definitely filling. My fianc loved the chicken and waffles. The breading was perfect on the fried chicken and had a little kick to it. The waffles were also really good and the portion size was huge, so it was definitely more than enough food. We also ordered the truffle tater tots. I definitely suggest ordering this for the entire table to share because not only is it a lot, but it's so good. For dessert, we got the bread pudding... This was some of the best bread pudding I've EVER had. It was so soft, warm, and gooey. Simply delicious. It also had Nutella on it, which is always a good idea.The prices are definitely a little higher here but I definitely felt it was worth it considering the presentation and taste of the food. It was great and I hope to come back here the next time we're in NYC! Solid 3 stars for Hotel Chantelle's brunch. Hotel Chantelle offers a fun brunch. While it isn't a bottomless brunch it's still fun and boozy! My personal favorite on the menu is the French toast. It's cornflake encrusted, big, and very rich. I also enjoy the avocado toast to share! In terms of the drinks there are a few options: half priced cocktails, mimosas for around $4, and a couple of 99 can't drinks that I didn't love. I strongly recommend the pineapple jalapeo cocktail drink. I've had it on several occasions. Aside from the food, the ambience is nice but it can get quite crowded with people at the bar so I recommend making reservations. I have only been here before for the clubbing portion of it but yesterday I decided to try the restaurant with a friend. I have to say the food here is actually extremely good. Everything that we tried from the tuna cigars to the fish tacos and the grilled octopus was impeccable. The service was very attentive and everyone was so polite. However, I will say the one thing that actually really bothered me that only happened at the end is that they charge you for tap water. I couldn't believe it when I saw that on our bill there was a $2 charge for premium water. I have NO idea what was premium about it. I feel it's something they do to jack up your bill and it's not right. I had a nice meal and having an argument would have ruined my mood so I just left.. but I posted a picture on yelp of my receipt. Such a cute brunch place. Love the vibe here. Plus the drinks are so cheap! Good food, good drinks, and good vibes all around. Definitely recommend this place to anyone in New York. If you do plan to come here for a weekend brunch, I highly recommend making a reservation because this place does get packed and full. I first heard about Hotel Chantelle because of a Groupon listing for dinner.Ambiance: The rooftop space is so cute! I have been in the summer and winter, and while it's nice with the closed roof, the openness of the space during the summer is 10x better. There was a live jazz band playing during dinner, and it set the mood for the evening. I wish they always had something like that!Food: Half and half? We had a Groupon for $80 off our bill, so we ordered quite a lot of food. To start, we tried the tuna cigars, chicken n' waffles, and buffalo cauliflower (we wanted the brussel sprouts because they're our favorite menu item but they had run out). Everything was very tasty and I decided my new favorite is the cauliflower - it's crispy but really flavorful because of the buffalo and bleu cheese.For our entrees, my boyfriend ordered the burger and I got the salmon. He loved the burger, but my salmon was just okay. I didn't like that it came with skin on it - I feel that it holds all the "fishiness", and I spent most of my time trying to take it off so I could eat my meal.Service: Good - our first server left after taking our order, and his replacement was probably still training. She was sweet but kind of slowPrice: I would not consider dining here without a Groupon. The prices are not reasonable, and even with $80 off our meal, the bill was higher than most restaurants of better quality.Minus: Left with mosquito bites all over my ankles This place is the worst. There is no cell service, bouncers are mean and objectify women, and it's overall a scary place. Will never be back and encourage others not to go. Great venue.3 floors. The rooftop has some nice decor and not loud music. Good food for a dinner.The first floor is a regular bar, but on Fridays, they have a very fun burlesque show.And the basement is a big dance floor with very good music of all genres.I highly recommend that place of you want to dance and have fun.Not very expensive Apologies in advance for the slightly long post, but I want to be thorough when giving a bad review. I can't stress how disappointed I was with this restaurant. I was really looking forward to checking out the Jazz Brunch that I've been hearing about for so long. Let me start with the positives. I like the menu and the special brunch cocktail deals they offer. The rooftop area is pretty big and nicely designed. I enjoyed the food that I ordered. The hostesses were doing a very good job of keeping the situation under control because it's very busy and hectic for brunch on a holiday weekend.Now for the cons. First of all it is way too hot up on the roof, so I would advise you don't go on a day that's too hot/humid. Or you can simply grab a drink by the bar and check out the scene then eat downstairs where there's air conditioning. There are mini fans spread out in the rooftop area, but it didn't help at all. Most people are fanning themselves with the menu to cool themselves down. My main issue with this place was the scam they're running with the 'water service' they charge you for without asking first. I'm not sure if they're still doing this or not, but I went the first week of July. They set up the table and pour the water in all of the glasses before your seated. I didn't think anything of it, I just figured they wanted to get that out of the way instead of waiting until we're seating and asking for it. Low and behold we get the bill and see that there's a charge for $4. We inquire about this charge then the waitress explains that it's for Water service. We're all puzzled by this because we didn't ask for sparkling water or anything. When the waitress comes back we ask why we're being charged for water since it's supposed to be free unless we ask for anything other than tap. She immediately said she'd remove it without answering our question as if it settled the matter. This really turned me off. $4 isn't a lot of money, but it's the way they went about it. It is really poor form and not the best way to encourage repeat service if attempt to nickel and dime or rip off customers.  So overall, I like the concept of this place but there are clearly some areas they need to work on. I wouldn't completely rule out going in the future but it won't be anytime soon. Waited in line for a while - once in the roof top was pretty cool.  There was a burlesque show going on in level 1.  The drinks were overpriced but the bartenders poured heavy.   It wasn't overly pretentious, which was a win for me.   The crowded was very blended in age from mid 20s to 40s.    I didn't try any good - not even sure if they offer food.   But it was a fun rooftop for a warm night. Hotel Chantelle in the Lower East Side offers an exceptional brunch on the weekends. If brunch is your cup of tea, make sure to snag a reservation here as soon as you get a chance.We somehow snuck our way on the reservation list an hour or two before we actually sat down this past Saturday, and we were wowed from start to finish. The beautiful rooftop patio is adorned with greenery, and the natural sunlight peers aesthetically through the cloth canvases above. A duo of jazz musicians serenaded the patio with acoustic melodies, and the bartender kept the cocktails flowing (only $0.92/drink - yes, you read that correctly).Aside from the ambiance, the food isn't bad either. We ordered a few main courses to taste the variety, and each of the dishes were great in their own way. The truffle egg fondue was the champion of the bunch in my opinion, and I would certainly also recommend the Eggs Benedict w/ crab. The staff was a bit off-putting at times, however. The hostess at the front of house wasn't the most courteous to say the least, but thankfully the food, drinks, and setting more than made up for the staff's shortcomings.For rooftop dining, Hotel Chantelle is one of the tops. Come here for their well-known Weekend Brunch to experience great food, solid cocktails, and a wonderfully delightful atmosphere. to begin with it was a brunch for me and my friend we were greeted by the hostess  they were really nice.  #1- Everything was great if you are looking for a heavy brunch try out the waffles and chicken they are pretty known for. #2- Ambiance is beautiful make sure you ask to be away from the live singing group because we couldn't hear each other even though they were great.#3- server was great he was a Spanish dude I'm sad I didn't ask for his  name. #3- bartenders on the first floor are full of energy they're great #4-french toast could've been more filling but you get what you pay for #5- Last but not least this spot is only for teenagers so if you an adult looking forward to this restaurant you should opt out .  Salute to the bartender drinks were pure Ok so this place was one of the spots that i had came to when I was doing restaurant hopping with a friend in Chinatown area and mannnnnnn did we have a blast that day!!!!!!!I will never forget it and this place is one of those places that will forever b engraved in my mind cause it was everything that was relaxing, brunchy, beautiful, simple and delicious!!!!!When u first walk in they check ur ID. Then u walk in and go to ur right which will have a flight of stairs going up and u just climb to the top u too u see the hostess.We were lucky enough to have sat outside without a roof over our hear and the weather that day was not tooooo bad. It wasn't hot, it wasn't cold and it didn't start raining yet. We ordered fairly simple since we were restaurant hopping and eating minimally at each place. Even with its simplicity I was still blown away.We ordered a Easy Passage and a Strawberry Rickey and for me they did not skimp out on the booze. Both were delicious but the Strawberry Rickey was my favorite out of the 2. We also ordered a smoke salmon platter and that was uber delicious too. It had bagel chips with a smoke salmon flower and capers and red onion and cream cheese, cucumber slices and romantic slices.I just really enjoyed the atmosphere is the place and the waiters and waitresses was super attentive. And our waiter always came back to ask if we needed another drink and we did not pass that up. I was really happy that day and was super happy that they didn't force us to leave cause we were there for a while.I can't believe that after all these years of living in NYC I only JUST found this place!!!!I will forever go back to this place and bring ppl there!!!!!

I found out about JWF from their cookbook. I found it at the public library and borrowed it. Everything looked so good! I bookmarked this place in hopes for the next time I was in the big apple.Leo and behold, I was in NY in the winter of '18. On my last day there, I ventured out to Soho in the rain to finally give this place a shot. The fact it was raining and it was a Tuesday morning probably deterred people from coming. There was no wait! Woohoo! My sister and I shared the rosewater waffle and the Mediterranean breakfast. I also ordered a side of their duck bacon.The waffle was good. It was topped with yogurt and berries and came with honey syrup. I couldn't really taste the rose though, which I didn't mind since I don't like floral flavors. It definitely had a unique taste but it wasn't rosey to me.The Mediterranean breakfast was a nice change from your usual array of breakfast sides. It came with eggs, avocado, cucumber salad, pita and hummus. It was really delicious and on the lighter side. I could see myself eating this every morning. The duck bacon was great. I love duck, and this bacon had a nice quacky flavor.Oh, and don't forget to ask for their hot sauce! It's green and not that hot. It has a tomatillo/Serrano taste which I loved! I licked it clean.I skipped out on drinks because I was going to get a draft latte from La Colombe after. Regret not trying their cantaloupe juice though...This place did not disappoint! Usually, when I look forward to something, it's pretty underwhelming.I would definitely come back again the next time I'm in New York. Maybe people hyped it up too much.Maybe the wait was too long.Maybe the weather wasnt nice.I had an average experience at Jack's Wife Freda. I got the poached eggs with grilled tomato and haloumi and my friend got the waffle. It was both delicious.I think this is on me that I had a high expectation and the queue, service, and the food just did not meet my expectation.Maybe I should give it another try.. We arrived around 1 pm and there was a very long line trying to put their name down. The hostess was very friendly and told us it would be 1 hour and a half wait. We put our name down and walked around SoHo area, the good  thing about this place is that it is nearby all the shopping areas so even it was a long wait, there are things to do. We came back about an hour later and our name was called. The service here is very good. The food is very mediterranean, it tasted fresh. Will love to go back! Here's a tip: get a group of 6+ and make a reservation for brunch! The line is loooong if you come here during prime time business hours and I don't recommend you wait this long. It's good food-but don't wait an hour plus for it. You're in NYC--and heck if you're waiting outside it's probably a nice day and if it's not then stop waiting--enjoy the city! There are plenty of other places to eat. I got the Grilled Tomato and Halloumi with Avocado and poached eggs. They were delicious but I do wish they served more bread. Not enough for all the halloumi and tomatoes they give you. Also I get the decor aspect of the bread on the side but from a utility standpoint, it's not doing so much for me. But another tip, with this dish standing at $14 you can get your budget friendly version at Cafe Mogador in the East Village, which serves the same for $10 (I was just craving this one today so caved in on the higher price)The cappuccino is good - yes they have almond milk- left me shaky which means you know it's got the caffeine overload Atmosphere wise- as a group of six you're crammed into the center at a picnic-style table.  I was rubbing up against my neighbor my entire meal, so it's not the best place to go if you like your personal space. You won't get any. That being said the waiters are attentive and plenty and will guarantee you that you'll be out of there in a jiffy. Probably trying to avoid a riot from taking place outside. Cute spot with a trendy concept. There is always a line out the door. All of the staff dress "hipster"; wearing beanies, plain striped shirts and urban outfitters-esque attire.Food: The fries were DELICIOUS- I will give them that. But they charge $8.00 for one side of fries! Thats highway robbery. I  ordered the Mediterranean breakfast with two poached eggs- very standard. I could definitely get this dish at a high-end diner or fast casual restaurant . I am glad I got to see what the hype is about but I would only return to try the "Madame Freda" dish and then probably won't come back again. 4,5 stars. Showed up in the middle of the week for brunch/lunch time and still had to wait for 45 mins. Ended up walking to a coffeeshop nearby, grabbing a cup of coffee and walking back so it worked out perfectly.Service was SUPER friendly and fast. The food delicious. Portions per price ratio just okay.Would still be back because of the cuteness of it all. Bookmark this one if you live here or your visiting NYC! The amazing staff starts to greet you upon entering this charming cafe, if your lucky to sit at the bar like me and get Dolan to take care of you, your definitely in good hands.I tried their Maya's Breakfast Bowl- perfect blend of spaghetti squash, kale, red quinoa, avocado, and roasted tomato....LOVED IT!Great portion, fresh ingredients, friendly service- they've got it dialed in.Try it, you won't be disappointed! This place was fantastic. I wish we also had time to come here for brunch, but we only made it here for dinner while in town. We arrived at 5:30 on a Wednesday evening, I'd recommend coming a bit earlier since you can't make reservations (except for larger parties). It was super empty when we arrived and we were seated immediately. We were seated in the corner booth table (who doesn't love booths?). I think they use the menus as placemats, because they never took them from us after we ordered. My sister ordered the matzo ball soup and the curry bowl, I opted for the schnitzel. I absolutely love schnitzel and this did not disappoint -- the chicken was juicy and tender with a wonderfully crisp and breaded outside (side note - why is it so hard to find schnitzel, anywhere?) I've never had matzo ball soup here but it was wonderful (especially on a cold day). My sister loved her curry, I'm not a huge curry person so I wasn't a huge fan, but at least she liked it.The service was great, everyone was super friendly. I ended up leaving my credit card behind and they were so awesome about it. When I called, the person asked me if I had left my credit card there before I even had a chance to finish my sentence, I told them my sister was going to pick it up for me (they had it stashed in the safe), and the waiter immediately recognized her when she came in. I would absolutely come here again and (sadly) I'd probably order the exact same thing.... There's a reason this place has such high reviews, excellent food, fantastic service... I only hope that I can also try the brunch someday. I've heard many great things about this place - even bookmarked as "high priority." Unfortunately they missed the mark one cold, weekday afternoon.  We came in without a reservation and were ready to wait a bit, as it was really packed. And wait we did. For about 25 minutes or so, which isn't too bad for a holiday week. I don't love the layout at Jack's Wife Freda; one long, communal table right in the middle, surrounded by smaller tables against the walls - making it almost impossible to walk towards your seat. We waited about ten minutes after being sat until we order. They were so busy they couldn't keep track of who was who. I feel like restaurants like this could really shine when they're busy. The servers seemed nice, but they really were just way too understaffed that day.The food was fine - nothing really stood out. Got a chicken prego and some fries. Lots of brunch places in the area are so much more worth the price and the wait. Dang, Freda! Your brunch game is on point. With a crowd of people waiting outside for 1+ hour, you know they must be doing brunch right. Jack's Wife Freda is the epitome of boozy brunch. It's a small, lively spot - you'll be sitting pretty closely with your neighbors who may or may not be doing shots. I got the poached eggs, which you can't really go wrong with. Perfectly poached and yolk-y, it made for a great social media story. My friend ordered a side of duck bacon, which she said was really good and a must try. Heard the rosewater waffle is also a must try, but we were already a bit full from our cheesecake pre-breakfast at Eileen's across the street. Hey, we had to kill time somehow! Takeaways: No reservations (so get in early to put your name down!), cantaloupe mimosa, madame freda all day everyday, good for small groups (2-4)The wait, the line are not overrated nor overhyped. This is a place I will return to for brunch on weekends with friends from out of town, but maybe not during peak hour between 11:30-1:00. Luckily, Jack's Wife Freda is located near many small shops and cafes so browsing around while waiting for a table to clear up is a solid option.
