No reservations, and it's a tiny space, so get there early with your full party to be seated!Pros:-looking for a boozy brunch? it'll be a bit pricey, but these bloody marys and cantaloupe mimosas will leave you happy for the rest of the weekend -sourcing is on point for dishes. i.e. tomatoes taste like real tomatoes, cucumbers like cucumbers. all fresh produce that hasn't lost its natural flavoring by way of being frozen in a former life or deconstructed by being over cooked-located right off the 6, convenient for those on the east side Cons:-long wait, lot of hangriness (but all the more to make the meal that much yummier)-cramped! you'll be seated with your friends for sure but don't expect a private conversation. you'll be sitting almost elbow to elbow with your fellow diners from another table The wait time during brunch is a bit obnoxious (and I didn't even wait my friends did bc they got there an hour earlier) but the food/drinks/service were amazing. Everything we ordered was so delicious and you can't order wrong since everything looked and tasted so good. Would come often but yeah.. that damn wait time. Expect the wait time to be over an hour on the weekends. But the wait is so worth it! The restaurant is tiny and cramped and it feels like your sitting on top of other people but the food is amazing here! Food is made fresh and not too heavy and the presentation is so chic! Meant to write a review after visiting this place a few weeks before New Year's. I had this place bookmarked for a while and took the opportunity to visit with my friend from out of town on a Saturday night. We were immediately seated despite it being packed. This place is definitely a brunch place for sure--wouldn't really come here for dinner.I really do appreciate how nothing is cooked with pork in this restaurant :) I ordered the duck prosciutto sandwich (Madame Freda) which was amazingly good. I never had that before and the pairing of a sunny side egg and gruyere cheese really went well together. My friend ordered the Greek salad and commented how fresh it was put together. The service here was nice too even with how small the place was. This place was recommended to me by a friend. As my NYC trip got closer, she reminded me that I needed to stop in for brunch multiple times. So I did. Quite pricey, but oh so delicious. I got the Medi breakfast which was complete with 2 poached eggs, a cucumber-tomato salad, labne, pita bread & avo! Since I'm a cheese addict, I opted to add 2 pieces of halloumi cheese. Perfect. (except for the fact that it was a $7 addition. wow!) My friend got the Madame Freda which was a sandwich with duck prosciutto, gruyere, cheddar bchamel & topped with a fried egg! I didn't try it, but my mouth watered as she did!When we first sat down we were quite hungry so we ordered the baguette hoping it would come before our meals. It didn't. BUT it was a delicious addition to the carbs already included in our meals. Had this place bookmarked for some quite time! I decided to finally check this place out with my friend. We both ordered the Mediterranean breakfast. She got the eggs poached and I got my sunny side up. The food was good! The little salad it comes with is super sour but doable. It was such a healthy meal! Would definitely come back to try more things but it gets crowded so go early! Cute places with killer brunch menus are what I live for! Jack's Wife Freda is totally worth the hype in my opinion.My friend and I got here around 9:45am and faced a ~30 minute wait, but it wasn't bad at all since we were able to do some window shopping in Soho. We started the meal with tall cups of fresh cantaloupe juice, which is just sweet, delicious, pulpy cantaloupe blended up. It's super refreshing and 100% worth a try! I ordered the green shakshuka, which was perfectly spicy and tangy and paired nicely with the rich, yolky eggs and fluffy challah. My friend got the tomato and halloumi Benedict, which was also scrumptious from the bite I tried. Everything was plated very attractively too. Portions skew towards the smaller side, which is good because you don't walk out feeling gross. The space itself is picturesque but cramped.I would recommend everything I tried here!!! JWF def makes it into one of my favorite brunch places. Cute little place in the city , great vibes but too loudy . The food is great I've tasted the waffle , it was really good. The owners are very nice ,as well . The place is clean and the bartenders were very polite (wevesat on the bar )The place looks very busy and I can understand why . Again , I'm not sure I'll be back for a round two but it as nice experience . Jack's Wife Freda is one of the best choices you have in the neighborhood full of hip spots. I've been here a couple of time in the past but somehow totally forgot to leave a review. So as I  was done shopping in Soho the other day, my bf and I decided to get dinner here. It's always crowded any time of the day but we were lucky enough to get a table outside right away. It's super noisy inside this tiny restaurant anyway. We ordered the Kefta Kebab, Peri-peri Chicken, and French Fries. I've only had brunch here so these are all new to me. The Kefta Kebab is lamb minced meatball with a lot of flavors coming from herbs and seasonings so the lamb smell is not overwhelming at all. It pairs great with the white sauce and pita bread. I LOVE the Peri-peri Chicken! It's a grilled chicken thigh with lots of seasoning on the skin, salsa salad and spicy guac(?) dipping sauce. It's seasoned so well and unique. The white meat is somewhat dry but it's unavoidable when you grill chicken. I highly recommend this dish. French Fries is delicious as well. The price is reasonable and the staff is beyond helpful. Definitely coming back for more! In my eyes, Jack's Wife Freda is one of the BEST causal brunch places in the city! If you're looking for a spot with a great abidance, friendly waitstaff, and a variety of food options to choose from look no further than Jack's Wife Freda.My friend and I decided to go to their Soho location on a calm Sunday afternoon. We had noticed there were already people waiting on the sidewalk (This place gets filled up fast), but no one had taken the two seats at the bar. We were offered and accepted since we really didn't care about sitting at a table.The waitstaff along with the bartender were extremely attentive. Right after we were seated they asked us our drink orders and gave us a few minutes to peruse the menu. I ended up choosing the Jack's Burger with a side of fires, along with their special hot sauce. All I can say is that I left full and satisfied beyond a doubt.A side note, this place does not take reservations for parties of two. If you're looking for table service either come early or be prepared to wait. It's that good. They also have a location on carmine street that is apparently less busy on Sundays? (That's only what I've been told)If you have the opportunity, definitely visit Jack's Wife Freda! You'll leave more happy (and more full) then when you had come in!

I planned my 25th birthday party with Jadis and was absolutely THRILLED with the experience! It was exactly what I had hoped for - a cozy, wine bar atmosphere with delicious apps and wine at a price that wouldn't break the bank. Edit helped me with planning and was fantastic. She helped me pick the menu for ~60 people at $40 pp and was extremely accommodating. We started off with a menu for wine and apps but she said that it was flexible. For example, if we chose mostly reds and guests were drinking more whites, she could swap them out for one another as the party went on. Same idea with the beer. The space was beautiful and I had 3 guests come over to me telling me it was the best party they had been to! If you are planning a party there, be sure to check it out beforehand and meet with Edit or another member of the staff. It was nice to put a face to a name and I found it was easier to communicate with her in person. Jadis does not disappoint, and I would highly recommend you plan your next event of up to 60 people there! I love Jadis (Zhaa-dee)! I was at VR place down the straight and needed to come back to reality. Jadis was a great place to do that and catch up with a good friend. A lot of first date/meet-ups here it seems. It was easy to overhear the convo of the two peeps right next to us who had met on a dating app.  We were at a table in the front as the back couches were full this time. I had the carafe the grapefruit rose sangria which was light and refreshing and the grapefruit was not overpowering. My friend had the kir royal which was equally good. I think I may have that next time.We stuck with the small bites this time around. We had the bruschetta, bacon-wrapped scallops, crab-cakes bites and smoked salmon on blinis. All were good, the tomatoes on the bruschetta were very ripe and slightly tangy, the bacon was the star in the bacon-wrapped scallops dish, and I was pleasantly surprised the crab cake bites as I normally don't like crab cakes. The salmon was probably the show stopper, though. Next time, I will explore more of the menu.Great service and ambiance. Our server checked on us multiple times and was always there when needed. I will not sit next to the heat pole next time. If you are always cold, then you should sit by it :P Loved this spot for happy hour. The happy hour deals were very good, and the food menu had tons of delicious-sounding bites. There was a single small table outside and we asked to be seated there. Excellent people watching. I had a couple glasses of the viognier before switching to another white. I ordered the ham, gruyere, and caramelized onion pressed sandwich. The sandwich was tasty and came with a delicious side salad that had the most perfect cherry tomatoes. My friend had the alsacienne tarte which was absolutely phenoms. I would definitely get that on a return visit. A visit to the bathroom revealed a really chic lounge area towards the back of the restaurant -such a cute place for a small group gathering. I'd love to return on a future visit to the city. Their wine list is great. Happy hour wine is $6-7/glass. They have an enormous back area with comfortable seating which I loved. Cant speak to the food they serve since we only stayed for drinks but everything coming out of the kitchen looked awesome! Not sure about the food here, but it's a perfectly cute little wine bar!Fair prices, cozy atmosphere and attentive service. I definitely would have gotten a charcuterie board, but we were too full so we just decided to split a bottle of wine. It was the perfect place to chat with friends and catch up for a nightcap! TRY ITTT.... I love the atmosphere here the muled wine (hot wine!) and they have the most tasty desserts ever!! Great food and ambience. We were seated at the bar. But they have a little lounge area with the couches. Great service. Like all the small plates we ordered. I've been to Jadis 4 times in the last 5 months which may lead myself to believe im a fan but after the last visit ive come to the conclusion that we end up there because of proximity, dim light ambiance & fair prices.  However, somethings can be said about the service.  Happy hour is a good deal for the area, plenty of 5$ and 6$ a glass selections or wines and beer, we usually get a cheese & meat board, pick 4 for $22 i believe it was, the mushroom puffs, flambes are good but wow, that beet salad was good.the setup is adorable, very european feel with a clutter of bookshelves, antiquey lights and really really really worn down soft sofas which sink once you sit down, that or you can opt for the uber hard stools with no back support.  the service has never been warm, its never been downright rude either however we always feel rushed to enjoy ourselves if the plates are emptied and our glasses are half full, the waitress' attitudes are very brusque and unwelcoming, they simply plop around and ask do you want another glass of that?  if you or someone answers no, they go off in a semi huffworth a visit if you're in the area but they are plenty of other if not better options A cute little spot! I enjoyed their cheese plate thats was $24. I got pecorino, gruyere, goat brie and camembert - it comes with bread, butter and grapes. We also got a bottle of red wine The design of the place is industrial and cozy and it was fairly crowded on a Tuesday night The staff is a little impatient and not attentive unfortunately. After an hour of looking for wine bars online, my friends and I decided to try Jadis. The food and wine completely surpassed our expectations! We got a bottle of the tasty Hungarian wine and I tried a glass of the Malbec. The service was quick and respectful and the charcuterie platter was divine. It was a special experience and I look forward to coming back soon. Cute wine and tapas bar!  We love coming for their happy hours.  We love sitting on the couches in the back cracking open a couple of bottles and having some cheese and meats.  They have good snacky food like the charcutuerie, the rillettes, escargot and a great variety in terms of wine.  The food is actually pretty good for a wine bar.  Service is always friendly and helpful.  The vibe is just right...kinda dim, with some music, and always a fun fun evening.. Perfect place for a mini-reunion of 10! As several observed, the lounge seating area felt like we were in someone's living room without anyone having to deal with clean up!  Food and drink was all superlative. Our orders ranged from a healthy salad to every kind of pizza on the menu, escargot, beet salad, some more appetizers I'm not remembering specifically and several desserts, of which the Hazelnut panna cotta left a particularly positive impression on me personally. As the various dishes got shared around the group I heard nothing but positive comments about the quality and serving sizes.  A winter gathering, the seasonal mulled wine was a HUGE hit though all drink offerings also got two thumbs up from one and all.Service was attentive, friendly and professional with very nice reminders about last call on Happy Hour. The value for money spent by our group was overall very high even after they added the automatic 20% for a party of our size. The group charge was completely understandable and appropriate.So why 4 stars instead of 5? They have a goofy reservation policy. They required a credit card for a group our size and asked that we cancel 3 days in advance (my plan only landed two days before so what if travel had screwed up?). When I asked how much they would charge if we didn't cancel in time I was told they don't charge, they just ask for the card number to encourage people to call. They are a small place so I can understand that holding a reservation that doesn't happen is a big deal. I'm guessing they've been stiffed by inconsiderate parties but really the resulting policy lacks logic. My credit card dispute policy became my backup plan so I gave them the card info. Since we all had such a truly fantastic night at this venue, I'm glad I took the risk but it did take a leap of faith, especially in Manhattan. I'd give them 4.5 stars if that was an option but just can't bring myself to give them a flawless 5 stars because of this first impression. super cute spot in the LES. great place for date night. they have a good selection of French wines at a decent price. haven't tried any of the food so definitely need to come back. Wine was good at this place. The server was very knowledgable about the wines. We said what we were in the mood for and she nailed a suggestion.The food was not as good as the wine. It was standard bar fare and nothing really elevated. The best thing we had were probably the mac and cheese bites. The bruschetta was average and the crab cakes fell apart and were kind of bland. I would come back for the wine not the food. Best kept secret. Sexy but casual. Had pate, salami, escargot, tarte. Rustic country French. Bean soup was a surprising favorite. Tasted like it was made by grandma. Wonderful smells like rosemary were wafting in the air from the kitchen. Charcuterie with happy hour wine and sangria? Look no further because Jadis has it! A cute restaurant in the lower east side, this place was the perfect spot to sit outside (only one table available at the front of the restaurant), drink some wine and eat some deliciously cut meat and cheeses. Although there is very limiting seating outside, the inside is wonderfully decorated as well, giving off a close and intimate vibe, great for dates or friend catch-up sessions.My boyfriend and I came here around 5 which was perfect as they have happy hour 5-7 Mon-Sat with $6-8 wines and sangria. I had their grapefruit sangria and it was deliciously made. It tasted super fresh and very well balanced. Great for a hot summer's day.As for the food, we started with the truffle mushroom risotto puffs. For $6, it was well-worth it. There were 4 delicious puffs of heaven. It had a crisp exterior from the filo dough and was soft and mushy on the inside from the rice and mushroom. The truffle was the perfect finishing touch. We also shared the mixed olives which was a yummy little plate of olives at $4. Both were great picks!As for the star, we got the platter of meats and cheese at $22. With that, you get a selection of 4 choices from a variety of meats and soft and hard cheeses. It also came with grapes, mustard and cornichons. We selected the Serrano ham, veal terrine, Fourme d'Ambert (a blue cheese) and Pierre Robert (similar to a brie but stronger). Everything was great for splitting between 2-3 people and they gave plenty of sliced baguette for the platter. At $22, it was so worth the price.Overall, it was a great experience. The service was so nice, very attentive. They constantly refilled our plates and checked on us to ensure we were enjoying our food and drinks. We definitely enjoyed everything. Delicious! Great food, service and ambience. Can't ask for a chiller spot to hang with friends! A return visit to this lovely little uncrowded dark french bistro space underlined a few of its strengths with a few new weaknesses.If you are looking for an affordable lovely European bistro spot with the basics, Jadis really shines in many ways - wines start at $9, with $40 bottles, and the food is pretty decent.  You can get single charcuturie or cheese items from $7-11, if you don't want to get a big board.  The small plates are good here - bacon wrapped scallops for $8 gets you about 7 medium barely bigger than bite sized scallops that are browned and just a little tender.The hazelnut panna cotta for $7 was creamy bliss, with a lovely blueberry caramel sauce, and just a nice perfectly small after diner size.The most enigmatic thing is that the service is so euro casual, almost ambivalent, you'll be waiting for perhaps ever to order something, and an additional something, since it's difficult to order more than one thing at a time.On the flip side it's nice not being rushed, but damn, I waited at least 15 minutes to order a wine after being seated, I had to stop someone 15 minutes later for a second glass and to order food, in this case duck rillette, $10.  An order of scallops, dessert and a third wine demanded I get up and order at the bar.  That kind of service doesnt match the lovely space on one hand, on the other, it does, you can spend three hours there and no one is going to bat an eyelash.The duck rillette wasn't as good this time, partly because of presentation.  It just looked and tasted a little haphazard.Atmosphere - dark lovely bistro Food - basic French small plates, sandwiches,      Quiche, salads and a few mains.Service - oddly absent, but you get to linger as long as         you want.Value - 3 wines, 3 small plates - $50.   A good sort of poor man's fine dining downtown. Decent wine happy hour and the food smelled good but I had to answer a quick work email and their Wi-Fi cost money. The bar is in a basement with less than amazing reception and it's 2017. So I decided to move somewhere this deluxe service would be included in my purchase. Nice staff. Poor mgmt, clearly. Will go back once I lose my job to try the bacon wrapped scallops. It's a shame. You can easily walk past this place and not know it. Tucked on a small side street and surrounded by mostly residential buildings, Jadis is a diamond in the rough. They have happy hour every day from 5-7 with wines ranging from around $6-9. The food menu boasts quiche, olives, meats and cheeses. Very cozy decor - rustic book cases in the front make me feel like I'm not even in the city. They have leather couches in the back, which sort of give the place a bachelor-pad feel, but if you're into maximum comfort, they do the job. I'd come here again if in the area.

Two words: Vegan Mexican. I honestly wasn't sure what to expect for an all vegan Mexican restaurant. Everything I love about Mexican food is centered around meat. On top of that, Vegan alternatives can be super hit or miss. Thankfully, it was a definite hit on their part. First of all, the smell upon entering this place is absolutely mouthwatering. The staff are accommodating, welcoming and check up on you regularly which is always nice. As for the food, I was blown away. My friend and I ordered their vegan nachos and cocktails to start. I tried the Matcha y coconut (very sweet and refreshing) and my friend got their margarita (extremely sweet, but still so good). The nachos were stupid good, topped with this amazing vegan cheese, meat, and mountain of guacamole. Like, I can die happy. We both ordered fish tacos, which we weren't sure how we felt about "vegan fish." The fish is a cucumber-like veggie that was breaded. It was okay, but I wish I had tried something else on the menu that wasn't trying to mock fish. Overall, I cannot wait to be back. They also have a smaller shop connected to the restaurant if you want to order to-go. Wow, Mexican Vegan! Who would have ever heard of such a thing? This hole in the wall gem is to die for! For your vegan lovers, be prepared to satisfy your inner Mexican food cravings. First off, staff are nice and welcoming. The setting, and mood of the restaurant felt homie, with spanish'esque music playing. However, the restaurant felt somewhat crammed and squished, so I recommend you order your dishes one at a time. Regardless, savor the flavors and take your time enjoying your meal! If your on the go, then you can always order for takeout. Now, onto the food. We (Me & gf) started with a nacho appetizer, which was highly filling and filled with delicious flavors. It absolutely boggles me how one can manipulate flavors so well, emulating a meat taste and texture. Afterwards, we went onto the main course: Papusas. My girlfriend is Mexican, so she explained to me exactly what it was. It was a Torta (filled tortilla) with meat or vegetables layered on top. Again, it was delicious. My girlfriend ordered the Chorizo Buritto, which was decorated with a sauce dressing, representing the Mexican flag. I was able to taste some of the Burrito, which again, was delicious.I most definitely recommend if you're looking to try something new. For you fellow Mexican Vegans whom are in search of reconnecting with traditional Mexican food, this is your spot. Bravo, jajaja. I had low expectations for this place based on a few reviews from friends. After dining here a few times, I wonder if I can ever trust them again. I am thoroughly impressed by the innovative and thoughtful dishes. They did not rely on Daiya or Vegenaise as most veg restaurants do and they even went so far as to use fermented beans. Our server, Justin, was an absolute delight and seemed just as excited as we were about our experience. He even offered me a sample of the soup (which is more annoying than anyone who hasn't worked in a restaurant can imagine). I can't wait to go back and try more dishes. Since this place is only 5 minutes away from my work, I decided to try this place for lunch. Since the fish taco seemed like the most popular menu, I got it. It's $8 per two tacos but if you pay $3 more, you can get 3 three tacos of a same kind. I also got Mexican hot chocolate ($4.50) which was rich and delicious. It was missing the spice and cinnamon I like about Mexican hot chocolate but I still enjoyed it. I tried one bite from my friend's plate which was sweet chile relleno ($10) and it had well-balanced flavor as well. I was definitely happy about feeling full and healthy and I'll be back for sure. They knocked it out if the park. As a vegan from Texas, I really appreciate good Mexican Food. This is one of the best Mexican food places in the city, began or not. This is better the meat dishes I have had in the past. I came in the first time in my own. I sat at the bar and had the Mezcal drink and small (huge) nachos. The flavor was amazing. It had their own vegan chorizo too. I ordered this as an app, but I could not eat more. I ended up taking some home too. The bartender was really nice. She was having a good time chatting with the couples next to me and being a great bartender, so it did take me a while to get her attention. The second time I came with friends. They had a frozen aperol drink. I had the Margarita and Sangria frozen drink. It wad the best I have had since Aqui in the bay area. We ordered the large nachos (humongous)  they were still amazing. We also got the chayote "fish" tacos. They were the bomb. Two tacos are eight bucks, and you can order an additional taco of the same kind. The music is great. The ambiance is fun, and the food and drinks are perfect. I will definitely be back. Let me start off with the food OMG it was so delicious. First i had the gauc so tasty then I had the spicy tinga tacos and the palm carnitas tacos which were phenomenal, and then i had a pupusa. This vegan food at its A game great place. It does get pretty packed so there might be a bit of wait but it sure is worth it. Also the drinks are delicious bartenders are professional service is very attentive and friendly and they also have a great music selection. I recommend everyone tries this awesome restaurant This place is vegan heaven. We got three kinds of tacos, and 2 were insanely delicious, and the other was good. The nachos are superb, they layer the "cheese" and toppings so the bottom has just as many goodies as the top. Service was great, ambiance is trendy and cool. I can't wait to come back for more tacos! This place is amazing and I eat all cuisines. They add amazing flavor into food and drinks! You will appreciate it along with the decor and service. We ended up here after a friend's show on a Sunday night. Not the traditional place for Sunday nights out but we were pleasantly surprised by this place.I even asked the bartender for one of the drink recipes because I liked it that much. Groups: It is small so don't bring a large group. I was really excited about trying out a vegan Mexican place and was slightly surprised by how small and cozy the place is. That said, I was really pleased upon being seated because the booth seats open up and you can put your coats and the rest of your stuff away and enjoy yourself without being smushed by your and your friends' crap. Here are my general thoughts:Ambiance: Casual but intimate setting. Low-lighting, as evidenced from the lack of clarity in the posted pictures. Service: Amazing! My friend has a severe nut allergy and our server was incredibly accommodating and understanding about having to asking the kitchen about ingredients. 5 stars. Food: The nachos were delicious, but it was the typical nacho issue where there could have been more toppings and "cheese" sauce given the amount of tortilla chips. Still, delicious. I had them months ago and often, when my mind wanders, it's to those nachos. I got the pupusas which were also delicious! I'm usually a little wary of vegan pupusas because I've had the homemade traditional ones and those are pretty mind blowing. However, these were great and I'd even recommend to a non-vegan Salvadoran (pupusas originate from El Salvador, and I'm thankful to them every day for it). 4.5 stars. Drinks: The drinks were interesting and different and tasty, but not very strong for the price. 4 stars. Overall, I will definitely go back and try other things on the menu and highly recommend! Finally made it to Jajaja and I can honestly say it was amazing.  From the moment I walked in the hostess was friendly and made sure to make my fiance and I feel welcomed.  The atmosphere was great, the music was perfect and the energy felt great inside. Before being seated we both had a spicy pomegranate y jalapeno which was perfect.  It was exactly the right everything.We finally sat down and right away the waitress introduced herself and brought over some water.  She was friendly and made us feel very welcomed.  It didn't take us long before we ordered the nachos which were without a doubt amazing!!  If you like nachos I would highly recommend you order this here, you won't be disappointed.  We then both ordered some tacos and I must say the flavor was outstanding and everything else was perfect.  We also ordered the mexican street corn which was flavorful and just incredible. I can't say enough about this place and I can tell you for sure I'll be back for some more delicious food.If you want a great meal, service, ambience and restaurant priced well then this is the spot!  Don't miss an opportunity for an amazing meal. Came all the way from San Diego CA to try the restaurant. The vegan Mexican nachos where delicious. The place is small and it's located in China Town. It was worth the walk. Lol The newly made vegetarian wife has been excited about going to this place so we went on a Friday around 5:30. Got a drink at the bar then were seated right away I got the Chorizo Burrito with cauliflower rice, black beans, and guac smothered in Sour Cream & Salsa. It was amazing. Def doesn't have that chorizo taste, but that's not the point. The cauliflower rice was an excellent carb substitute, the fermented black beans were great and the smothering sauce was PHENOMENAL. Wife and friends got tacos. 2 Buffalo (Cauli) Flower tacos and 1 chorizo taco. They were quite pleased with their meals.The pomegranate & jalapeo cocktail is spicy deliciousness!! 1-2 is the perfect amount.Food is perfectly priced. Drinks are a little more expensive than one would want, but made with love and care. Being on the same block as the F train make this very accessible eats. So far I've only been here twice but I have to say I feel so lucky to live so close to such a great vegan spot. I've been to a number of vegan/veggie spots such as nix or dirt candy but I still (surprisingly) like this place best. Firstly, the place is not too big or anything. But it is at a pretty good spot being at the corner of an intersection so you can people watch and it's right next to a subway stop for people that have to travel here. The atmosphere is also pretty chill and they also have a cactus in the bathroom which is nice for character but nothing too spectacular. The service is pretty good too. I've never had an issue with the service and the people are very inviting and friendly which allows me to enjoy myself more easily. The most important thing is the food tho which I have to say is amazing here. Nachos taste like legit nachos, empanada is no joke, and the bowls were great with an amazing dressing. Even compared to places like dirt candy or nix, I thought the food was better here. It probably because the food here is more relatable and not anything too unfamiliar (although nothing compares to dirt candy's presentation). I would definitely recommend this place even to meat eaters. The food is just impressive in general. And if you're looking for vegan food and are feeling Mexican, I would even say this place is worth traveling to (which makes it nice that it's next to a subway station). Chlorophyl. Is that something that sounds like a safe word or a vegan ingredient? ohhh yeah... got you thinking. But seriously, you see that on the menu and if you are the type of person that wants to explore and are curious -- you have to have it. It's something that can go really wrong or really good. This was amazing. Everything on the menu is worth exploring. Few places can do vegan with fun, taste and innovation. This place delivers. The coctails are awesome. Great for date night. One of my best friends is vegan and his favorite food is Mexican, so he was pretty stoked to hear of Jajaja's existence. We came by on a Sunday afternoon and were immediately drawn into the bright, festive interior. The walls and ceilings are all wooden panels, the floors are made up of colorful tiles, and beaded curtains hang in different areas of the restaurant.The menu is pretty eclectic. Don't come here for your standard burritos and tacos. The tortillas on their taco menu are all made of unique combos like blueberry & flax seed, tumeric, and tomato & beet. The fillings are just as interesting - jackfruit and chipotle almond butter are a couple of the stranger ingredients. Outside of tacos, you can get things like nachos, tostadas, ceviche, pupusas (!), and even french toast at brunch. The cocktail menu is notable, with more funky concoctions like matcha, coconut and tequila, or cilantro, mezcal and coconut. I went with the pupusas because it's a dish I grew up with that I very rarely see in NYC. As far as pupusas go, they certainly weren't the ones I grew up with, nor was I expecting them to be, but all in all they were tasty. I paired them with the 'Matcha y Coconut' cocktail which ended up being a little too umami for my taste. I wanted it to be a little more coconut-y and less matcha-y. Perhaps matcha just doesn't belong in cocktails...My friend went with the nachos and was a fan! Very beautiful presentation of the nachos as well. All in all it was a pretty good visit, but neither of us were particularly blown away by the food or drink. The principle concern for omnivorous NYers (myself included) re. vegetarian/vegan is less "i can't live without meat", and more a fear that meatless dining won't have any flavor to it. After all, it's true that for the uninitiated, non meat products conjure grim visions of iceberg salads, vegan brownies, rice milk and other awful concoctions etc.Jajaja changed all this for me. Though there are no animal/animal products here, you wouldn't even suspect it unless someone explicitly told you. Only after had I finished eating (my burrito) that I was told by my server that the entire menu actually was meat free. At first I felt taken aback, but since I was on a roll, I decided to get the flan with coconut whipped cream as well. To my surprised, coconut whipped cream turned out to be even better than the regular stuff. This flan is distinct from that which utilizes eggs and milk- still very good, though textually different. I came back another afternoon and tried the Chayote 'fish' tacos, which were also excellent. The interior bears its own special mentioning: it's absolutely beautiful here. They managed to do the windows in such a way that the light that hits this corner of e. bway is fully maximized, giving the inside a classic lazy sunday afternoon kind of lighting, which exudes a sense of calm, and makes you forget you're in nyc. Another thing about the layout is the partition down the middle of the store: the left segment being the restaurant, the right segment selling items (tacos) to go. They also sell their signature, homemade hot sauces here, which were all incredibly good in my opinion, and made my chorizo burrito that much more enjoyable.I am slightly conflicted about this review because of the nature of my first experience- it's as if Jajaja obfuscates the fact the menu is meatless. Items such as "our chorizo" and "chayote fish" might seem a little suspicious upon close inspection, but to your average, voracious diner, it's not something they'd notice. It might have been nice to know what I was eating before I ordered, but perhaps this is strategic, in order to lower the boon on overly critical, self professed 'carnivores' only once it's too late- they will have already enjoyed their food, as it happened in my caseOverall, a great foray into the vegetarian variety. With lots of classic dishes, a beautiful interior, a 4.5 rounded up is a fair assessment of this restaurant- excited to go back soon. Amazing! The mole enchilada is the bomb, the inside has jackfruit which you can not even tell isn't meat! Great for anyone who wants a healthier Mexican dish.  No cheese used, but everything is packed with flavor! Jajaja, I am in love. This place is incredible in so many ways. The food is creative, tasty, filling, and surprisingly very well priced. The staff is very friendly and helpful. The atmosphere is casual and the location is conveniently right next to the subway. I am so happy Jajaja exists. To find good vegetarian Mexican food is usually very difficult because almost everything including rice and beans normally has chicken broth and/or lard. This place has an extensive menu of authentic tasting dishes that are all vegan. The food is heavy on flavor but light on the stomach and you don't leave feeling gross even after eating a chorizo burrito and breaded fish tacos. The fish tacos, burrito, and enchiladas were all outstanding. It was a real treat to have mol sauce, which traditionally is cooked with meat products. The presentation of the chorizo burrito is beautifully done, with a perfect coating of three different colored sauces. The nachos are enormous and filling. They can definitely be ordered as a full meal. I will definitely be coming to Jajaja frequently. It is very unusual to find such a high quality, accessible vegan restaurant with such fair food prices. I am sure this place will do very well going forward. WOW. Blown away by this spot!! There was a 45 min wait but TOTALLY worth it and I can see why the wait- this place was so good! The service was phenomenal but the food... oh the food.. it was top notch vegan food and the menu was marked with whats gf and whats spicy. The server recommended a few menu items- chorizo nachos, chorizo burrito, and something else. So, we started off with the chorizo nachos- great recommendation- crispy multi colored chips, creamy queso (couldn't even tell it was vegan), fresh guacamole, good tasty salsas, fermented black beans. The flavors were on point to say the least! For our mains- I got the carnitas tacos, my bf got the chorizo burrito, friend got the civiche, other friend the dino kale bowl. Carnitas tacos were so dang good. Pulled jackfruit seasoned perfectly, good taco toppings, microgreens, and a soft blue tortilla- I loved every bit of it! I tried my friends civiche and that was very very convincing! Made with hearts of palm and seasoned like authentic civiche, served with plantain chips- I loved it!My bfs chorizo burrito was so beautiful he didn't even wanna cut into it- but when he did I took a bite, mmm, also a good dish suggestion. My friend with the kale loved it as well and ordered tortillas on the side to go with it. I cannot wait to come back and to show more friends. The space is very nice, not too tight, the bar is beautiful, the bathrooms are so cute and Mexican decor throughout, the open kitchen with women chefs topped it off. I WILL BE BACK!!! Fulfilling Mexican cravings without all that oily, porky guilt: This is the strategy at Jajaja, which also happens to be casually vegan. I say casually vegan because it's not an in-your-face vegan place, and the general lack of tofu and substitute plant-based meats actually works in their favor. Cocktails are visually stunning but lack an alcoholic punch, but the nachos made up for it and I'd actually mainly endorse this place for the nachos alone. Some of the larger plates are hit and miss (I was a bit confused by my veggie bowl) but my friends were into their pupusa and burrito. Order the nachos.

This is our go to Dim Sum place. My mother in law refuses to go almost anywhere else. The place is huge, but almost always packed on weekends. Carve out a morning and just start pointing at whatever looks good. They'll take care of the rest.Lately they've been catering to a more bak gwei crowd (like myself), which I'm generally not a fan of, but the random nutella/drink cart going around isn't too much of an inconvenience. Visiting new york to take care of some businesses and this was a recommended place. Always a long line very popular.They have the old fashioned push carts with the food items so that's kind of cool as most places now are built with more seating so it's harder to to navigate the carts in most places.Being from Chicago and having had dim some many times I have to say the food quality and tastes of this place is 1 star.Also the fact that they have smaller parties share tables together I not a fan of. It's ok and I understand due to the large size of the banquet hall it's understandable, but I prefer to have q party per table no matter the size.They get 1 star for food and 1 star for service.Will definitely not be back. There is a popular place the flushing Chinatown that blows this place away. It's been a while since I've been to Jing Fong. What has always been true about Jing Fong as the largest dim sum restaurant in Manhattan's Chinatown is still true today. There are large crowds and its presence in many guide books makes it a destination for many tourists and locals alike. I heard that there was a renovation not too long ago and it really shows. The color of the restaurant is a muted brownish gold tone with warm lighting. I noticed there's a new bar that serves liquor and beer. There's a dim sum cooked food station, large chandeliers and new updated dim sum baskets. All in all it's a pleasant dining room to sit in if you don't mind the din of a thousand fellow diners chatting away next to you. We had a standard dim sum meal. We had items such as cheong fun, chicken feet, leaf wrapped sticky rice, spring rolls, ham shui kok, har kaw, and sweet and sour pork. We concluded that Jing Fong is still up to par when it comes to dim sum quality and variety. The only small problem here is service. We left a teapot open for nearly 45 minutes before having to wave down a waiter to refill the pot. Also, the circulation of the dim sum was a bit inconsistent. We sat for two hours and found that some new dim sum didn't make it to our side of the restaurant until toward the end of our meal. It would have been nice to circulate the carts around the entire restaurant so we would get a nice variety. I also got the sense that the restaurant is a bit understaffed both in terms of the cart ladies and the waiters. Despite this everyone we dealt with were nice and cordial.As for value, we were happy that the small dim sum were $3.25. However, there is a five tier list of prices, topping out at $13.25. In my opinion, if you order something that is $13.25, you may as well order an entre. It is us to the dim sum cart ladies to determine which tier your dim sum belongs to. Finally a pro tip here is that if you come in a small group, maybe 2 or 3 diners, you will get a table first because they could squeeze you into any shared table. Jing Fong was and still is one of my main Manhattan dim sum restaurants on my Manhattan repertoire. I am continuously shocked that dim sum places in NYC actually charge for tea. The actual dim sum plates here were disappointing. As someone that went to dim sum every weekend back home, I feel like I know good dim sum and this place isn't it. Sticky rice in lotus leaf is a fav of mine but my friend and I agreed that the rice was gross. A lot of the offerings were cold which is pretty strange since there are so many people you'd expect that the food would have a quick turn around. Turnip cakes were loaded with taro. That's confusing. At $11 a plate, no thx bye. The space itself is massive. As any other restaurant in Chinatown, don't expect good service, if at all. Sharing tables with other parties is common so cross your fingers and hope that you sit with people who aren't savages :)))))Still on the look out for a good dim sum spot. Good cheap Chinese dim sum place in the heart of Chinatown. Very authentic in every way, including their service. (There is almost no service but that's how dim sum is like in Hong Kong too)If you have never had dim sum before, this is a good place to start. They have all the dishes you can think of from chicken feet to cow intestine stew. There will be carts going around the table, but for some popular items, you gotta spot it yourself and head to the cart to grab what you want.If you are here to be pampered, you will be disappointed. But if you are here to get your tastebuds pampered, then you gonna love it here.Tips:- dishes have different pricing, but everything is still cheap We pre reserved a table for 8 on Thanksgiving for lunch, kind of keeping with that A Christmas Story vibe, lol.Everything we tried was very good although I was a little disappointed that some of the dim sum items that I had hoped would be on the carts were not. Specifically I was hoping for some soup dumplings and for dessert maybe some egg tarts.The only other issue I would have to point out to anyone in a similar situation is that my husband has a shellfish allergy and it is a little difficult to determine from some of the wait staff whether or not the item that you are choosing has any shrimp or other shellfish in it... We still got those items for the table we just were trying to determine if it was something that he could eat or not so I felt as if he ended up with the short end of the stick as far as options because there were so many things that we just weren't quite sure if any allergens were present.It was fun, we ate until we had to waddle out! These people be crazy yo. Jing Fong is a huge, loud banquet hall with a ton of space and enormous round tables, and a section for weddings, so it's ideal for groups, but the food sucks and is overpriced. Why did I drop $50 on a bunch of lame dishes and leave still hungry? The chicken dumplings are extremely dry. The stuffed eggplant is super oily. The beef meatballs tasted like pure shit molded together. The shrimp patties were okay, but so salty. My friend got pork dim sum and another bacon dish, and didn't like them. Genuinely could've gotten better food at Taco Bell. The beers were super small for the price too. Their service is brusque, but quick or organized, I'll give them that, but I wish we'd gone elsewhere. I don't know. This place is huge and maybe overhyped with lots of tourist who are at the place. Again, the place is huge so normally finding a seat shouldn't be a problem. It definitely feels like a nice meal when there are customers who are enjoying the place. Feels fancy with the escalator and big chandelier leading up the dim sum restaurant. People have weddings here to, so don't be surprised if on a typical day, you get seated on a regular table elevated on the stage. They're just utilizing all the space available! Other than the experience of feeling good, the food is decent. Not the best dim sum I've had and definitely not the cheapest. I find that depending on where you sit, the cart ladies may not pass your table frequently or you may miss some food if the ladies never make it to your table. With that said, you might need to get up with your order sheet and walk around to look for the ladies yourself, which I think defeats the fun out of dim sum, part of the fun is enjoying food without doing the work! On a typical day when I do want dim sum, I don't think I'll head here. Unless possibly I'm bringing a friend visiting or want to show someone a vibrant and popular/cultural atmosphere. Maybe. I wasn't happy with our meal but apparently it's a popular restaurant. I don't know why because the prices are steep. I think the two dollar signs on Yelp are for the lunch special because dinner is at least $20 per person. And we were very careful not to order a lot.We ordered the $15 plate of Beef lo Fun and fortunately it was a huge portion. It could feed 2 comfortably. However, we were very hungry so we also ordered a side order of chicken steamed buns and spinach dumplings.The beef lo fun I didn't like at all. The noodles had a strange taste. Almost as if the noodles were boiled in rancid water. I swallowed it whole just to get some food in my stomach. The beef pieces were okay but scarce and the onions were super strong...almost as if they weren't cooked. The spinach dumplings were fine. Nothing special. I wish we ordered more of the steamed buns because those were good. But then again, it's hard to ruin a steamed bun. After spending a good $15 each on dinner we were full...but that have been because the noodles made me lose my appetite. I had never experienced dim sum before entering Jing Fong, but from what my friends have told me, it's quite a fun experience--not only with the company you invite with you, but for your taste buds.On the two occasions I visited, my friends and I ordered a variety of items from the menu: pork buns, sui mai, dumplings, spring rolls, wontons, turnip cake, bacon wrapped seafood balls (or fried shrimp, I can't recall) as well as roasted duck, mayo shrimp, steak filet with onions, and the list goes on and on. Everything here is family style and extremely affordable, especially in this city. Similar places will charge double for what they did here. Granted, the service isn't the best, but as long as you get your order in and correct, what can you complain about?The location is up a long escalator down a side street in Chinatown, and the seating area is similar to a banquet hall. I've heard they do special celebrations for Chinese New Year and it is available for other occasions. My favs to order: mayo shrimp, turnip cake, and bacon wrapped seafood (shrimp)! The dim sum here is just alright given that my standard is based on growing up eating dim sum in San Francisco and Oakland Chinatowns. If you're in New York and need your dim sum fix, but aren't near Brooklyn or Flushing, this place is satisfactory.This has to be the largest dim sum restaurant I've ever been to. I don't think words can do it justice on how massive the capacity of this place. As a result, they have decent turnover and the lady at the front must have rattled off 10 numbers In a row. Beware if you wait outside because you won't be able to hear your number and they aren't about to go out there to find you either.As for the food, the cool thing is that there are tons of carts and there is also an area where you can bring your ticket up to get food. They have clams, vegetable, tripe/ tendon, turnip cake, etc.The spare ribs and chicken feet were pretty good and probably the best out of the bunch. Lotus seed paste bun was on the smaller size.Overall, it's worth a try if you find yourself in the Manhattan Chinatown area. Seems to be very friendly for large groups. I came here with three friends, and the servers rarely checked on us. There was a large event that took up about half of the giant banquet hall; the party was separated by a divider, but the event was very loud and disruptive for us. Perhaps there was a shortage of staff, but we waited a long time to get served and get our checks. The dimsum was standard quality.-- taste / 3aesthetics / 2vibe / 2service / 1price for quality / 4OVERALL / 2.5 10/08/2017I've been to this restaurant a few times, and reason being the food is worth the wait. However, sadly this visit was a disappointment. Not only did I have to get up and chase the food carts but the selection was very limited, rice rolls, spring rolls, and fish and beef balls. Mind you they seated us at e other end of the room the furthest point from the kitchen, and any food carts that made to to us were carrying the dishes no one wanted, do repeatedly I had to get up and walk to the other end of the room! I would've taken pics of the food but it was devoured by the time I rested the plate on the table, because after a 35 minute wait no body wants to wait for meager food carts that never show! So disappointing, after this experience I'm seriously thinking about calling it quits! On a happy note, they have a bathroom attendant so the bathroom was quite clean :)Happy Yelping! Not my favourite place for dim sum, all though they do have specials that can save you money. I felt like the place was dirty. When you first walk in you think it is going to be an amazing experience because the room is so large and the staff is dressed nicely but it is a let down once you get past the chandelier. Our tea pot and cups had left over food smudges. I could tell the had been sanitized but not wiped. I get that it didn't break any food codes but it doesn't make the experience better to have to wipe off your own cup before you drink out of it. Also, the floor looked like it hadn't been vacuumed in days. It was filthy. On the upside some of our dishes were delicious.If you go try the following:The dim sum sampler plateThe eggplant (it is not the tradition Cantonese flavors but still good)The mayonnaise shrimp with nuts (I know that sound gross but omg it is good)We didn't try any desserts so I can't recommend anything in that category. Tripe stew or offal stew is one of my favorite dishes. I remember I used to sit on the corner of the street back home and enjoyed a hot bowl of tripe stew after school. Since moving to the States, I haven't found anywhere to make tripe stew like back home until my last visit to NYC. I was so happy that I found a restaurant made good tripe stew! I will be back for sure, despite their bad customer services. That's why I'm giving them a three star. The place to go for authentic dim sum! I went with a group of 5 friends this past Saturday and despite arriving around 12pm, we were able to get seated within 10 minutes. I picked this place out to give that authentic hustle and bustle feel of traditional dim sum place in Hong Kong and this place did not disappoint. As many have stated, it's a huge palace of a place with carts rolling throughout, weaving between the banquet tables. Food was pretty spot-on. We were hungry and ordered right away - hargow (steamed shrimp dumpling), tripe, siu mai, spare ribs, bean curd pork roll, and changfun (what they call shrimp rice noodles). Their changfun was so delish (available in beef and shrimp - i got shrimp both times) and authentic with right amount of flour to shrimp ratio. We also got pan-fried turnip cakes, sauteed veggie, and clams in black bean sauce from the side station. They were all spot-on except beware the higher price (e.g. clams were $12.95 compared to regular dim sum plates ranging from $3.50 - $5).Because the turnip cakes were taking a while, we went up twice only to come back to wait some more. Then we were pleasantly surprised when the lady came over to our table and served us the cakes once they were done. (We were sitting right in front of the side tables) That was a nice gesture. Since the place is huge, I had to get up and hunt for char siu bao (steamed BBQ roast pork bun) and egg custard bun. CSB is spot-on delicious - not too big and doughy with nice chunk of meat inside. Tea is $1 per person as is the tradition in dim sum joints, and they kept it flowing throughout. We also had the silken tofu with ginger syrup as a dessert and it was divine. Service was generally very good. The ladies were friendly and could understand and speak some English, and they weren't overly pushy with the food recommendations. They were also nicer than your average Chinese servers, often smiling and even joking. I did use some broken Chinese here and there so I think that certainly helped. :) Tip: Sitting right in front of the side buffet area (and the kitchen) is a good idea. I even had the bill brought and taken from me though normally I would need to go pay up front. Also, rest rooms aren't too far from there as well. Btw, rest rooms are bright, spacious, and clean for those of you a bit squeamish about using public restrooms esp. in Chinatown. Bill came out to like $103 for 6 people not shying away, so ended up around $21 per person. On a hindsight, I would probably skip the clams and other expensive items and get more of the regular dishes. It's not for everybody - especially not for people who like a bit more peaceful dining experience. But I for one left very content with a full belly (no stomach issues afterwards) and will be back again for a leisurely weekend brunch this time over some of their cocktails. This place was crazy. I think there were at least 500 seats and everyone was having DIM SUM (Yes, we were there on a Sunday). Be prepared to wait a bit for a table. We were a party of 6 but that was fine (we took a walk while we waited). I  can not tell you how much dim sum we had -did not disappoint. steamed shrimp, noodles, I did not love the beef or the pork however -too tough to chew. This place is noisy so don't expect intimate conversation!  I love dim sum so its hard to disappoint me. Not expensive at all. Recommend highly. This large banquet hall of dim sum is scumptious. Since the restaurant is so large, it's hard to flag down the carts so it's recommended you just go up and order. Better yet, you can sit right outside where the carts come out of the kitchen and get first dibs (like we did). This is the first dimsum I've had in NYC so all I have to compare with Jing Fong are dimsum restaurants in Philadelphia! The egg tarts here were some of the best I've had at dimsum. I would also recommend getting the tripe, zhongzi (sticky rice with pork wrapped in a lotus leaf). We ordered a table full of food, which we didn't end up finishing, and ended up costing everyone around $20. I enjoyed the dimsum here more than Golden Unicorn. They had more veggie options for sure. The veggie steamed dumplings were very good. Lots of carts going around and you basically pick whatever you like! The ladies seemed less rude/pushy than golden unicorn. Great variety of steamed and fried dimsum and also sweeter dimsum for dessert. There was even a whole cart just for cheong fun (steamed rice roll). Fresh & good!There is a section in the middle of the restaurant where you can go up and get select dishes such as freshly pan-fried turnip pancake.The dimsum is priced by small, medium, large and there are higher prices for "special" items like seafood. The only thing is when you pick a dish you don't really know which pricing level it falls under, so it ended up that most of our dishes were medium/large and it added up quickly! Service is decent. They come around clearing your empty dimsum baskets/dishes quickly. It's not warm & fuzzy if you are familiar with "cart dimsum service", but they do their job.In terms of wait time: when you get here they give you a number and the wait time was pretty short for 2 people. Went on a holiday (Labor Day) around noon, walked around for 20min and they actually already passed our number, so they let us go upstairs immediately. When you go upstairs you have to wait about an extra 5min to get seated. The restaurant is huge!! Turnover is fast and they are pretty efficient. Have not been on an actual weekend so I can't speak to that, but I have heard it is pretty busy on the weekends. So the earlier you go is probably better.  Overall I would definitely come back here for some yummy cart dimsum! Chinese friends recently invited us for dim sum here on a very busy Sunday. We had a wonderful time together in this huge and lively red and gold, old fashioned Chinese restaurant.Before this visit, I had not been here since I performed on the big stage for a very big Chinese event 3 or 4 years ago. I never really liked the food here, but the atmosphere was always festive and a lot of fun. With seating for 1,500, it used to take me a long time to get from one end of the restaurant to the other.This time, the dim sum was just OK but it didn't really matter since we were having so much fun.  Also, I was pleasantly shocked that the ladies bathroom had been updated and was actually clean. In past years, I always dreaded having to visit the bathroom in my long, tight-fitting 'qi pao' since the ladies room was so awful.I sincerely hope that the Jing Fong will survive the nearby gentrification since this place is such an important part of old Chinatown.

Typical Chinese restaurant to me! I liked their XLB because it was bigger than the typical XLB from places like Din Tai Fung. Ordered pork XLB, crispy beef chow mein, and string beans. Overall, I think it's a good place for XLB and if you're a visitor of the city. Just one of those... Try it once since you're visiting kind of places. Price is always a bit above average because... New York. First things first, this is just average soup dumpling.I don't understand why people hype it so much, because to me, this is just a little better than the frozen soup dumpling.I got the scallion pancake, lo mein, and 2 stacks of soup dumplings. All tasted fine, but I guess I just have high expectations for the hyped restaurants where some places meet or exceed my expectation and some place just disappoints. And this would be one of the one that didn't meet my expectation. I grew up loving this place as THE place to get soup dumplings in NYC but I've back a few times in the past 6 months and was rather disappointed. Maybe the quality has gone down in the past few years? Or maybe I've just been spoiled rotten by the recent opening of other, better restaurants in Chinatown. When I go, I usually order the crab and pork soup dumpling and another dish of beef noodles. The beef noodles are an oily mess of flavorful thick noodles - so slimy yet satisfying. The soup dumplings come out piping hot but some of the soup dumplings didn't have SOUP which is strange for a place famous for its soup dumplings. For the 30min-1 hour wait, I expected better soup dumplings. Also note this place is cash only and it's mostly all communal seating, so you'll be sharing a table with other groups. This place also feels extremely touristy - there were few Asian people actually at the restaurant. I'm not sure if I'll be coming back because there are definitely better places for soup dumplings in Chinatown. If you like dumplings, this is the place for you!Beef noodles are great here also. This is a very popular restaurant for locals and I learned long ago to go where the locals go.It's a very affordable and clean eatery. I've been to the one in Flushing and quality and look of restaurant is the same. We arrived around 9:30 on. Monday night so it wasn't very busy but still a good amount of people - they sat us right away. We got the pork soup dumplings, chicken fried rice, and Shanghai noodle soup. Everything was fresh, came out very fast and was delicious. Can't wait to come back and try some other dishes! *CASH ONLY *Typically a 20 minute wait to eat at a shared tableAll you need to know about Joe's Shanghai is that they have the best XLB (soup dumplings) ever. I've had many in NYC and around the USA, but nothing compares to here. The amount of soup in one of their XLB is double the normal amount for only $6. I gotta give a shout out to their wine chicken ($8) as well, tender with a pronounced flavor.Meal Value (from 1-10, my measure of quantity/quality of the meal compared to price): 9The best soup dumplings at an affordable price - come eat here already! This place is way too packed and way too popular. Most of their customers are white so I don't mean to be racist or prejudice in any way but the food was very "americanized." My group of friends and I stayed in Manhattan by time square so it was quite the distance to get to China town. We were expecting some authentic chinese food.  Right when we showed up the lady host said "our party was too big and told us to wait 30 minutes." Cool, it's chinatown so lets do some sight-seeing. We walked around and when we came back, 30 minutes later, she said I cannot seat you guys until you're whole party is here. Mind you that the dining area is about 1000 square feet and I have a party of 14. We aren't just going to come into the restaurant and stand around until you have a table ready for us. So the stand-off began. Half of my party was standing in the door way and the other half was standing outside. The host finally took our word for it and gave us 2 tables. The tables are really cramped and each one can fit only 6 comfortably; we had 14.  Onto the food: it was pretty decent. Just very americanized. If you are wearing a white shirt or an expensive shirt i advise you to eat the dumplings VERY CAREFULLY. Once you bite into one of their dumplings the juices will squirt everywhere. Their calamari could use some better battering(it was way too light and bland) and no honey walnut shrimp?!?! I substituted it with salty pepper shrimp and they actually clean the spines out for you here which is really impressive. And our flounder was cut up and deboned for us without asking. The tables aren't so big either so we got our courses 2 entrees at a time. Nevertheless we were stuffed and content with our food choice. Great experience! You seat next to a bunch of friendly strangers  and start to order food. Dumplings are famous and delicious! We tried the ones with Pork! Overall great atmosphere and service! Food: it's good, not great.Service: leaves much to be desired. Our waiter walked away from us irritated and rolling his eyes after we ordered 2 orders of soup dumplings. We had to call him back to tell him we wanted to order more food. He must have thought we were lowly tourists coming to try a trendy spot. Also, I hate communal tables. I had to sit sideways in my chair to keep from staring at another couple across the table. We tried both the crab and pork XLB. I liked them both but didn't find the broth to be as savory and rich as some of the places in Jersey that I like. I have no doubt you could find yummier XLB in Chinatown. We also shared a tofu dish that my boyfriend loved but I found slightly too sweet. It was #100 on the menu. It was quite oily too. Every bite I took of tofu, a hot stream of water and grease poured down my chin and I felt the ghost of future zits forming in it's wake. Glad I tried it but wouldn't run back anytime soon. I came because my friend recommended this place to me. I was hoping for a great experience, but I left feeling a bit disappointed. Service was horrible, our server was rude and didn't help us with anything. It was also strange to be seated with other parties too instead of having our own table even though there were open tables around us. SHRIMP FRIED RICEThe flavor was so simple and basic. It definitely wasn't worth the price. There was way too much soy sauce in the rice and it was very salty. It definitely was lacking the authentic fried rice I was looking for. SAUTEED STRING BEAN- with minced porkThis was one of the better dishes. I really liked the crispness. It definitely added some textures to some of the other dishes. CRISPY PEPPER SKIN DUCKLINGI really disliked this dish. The skin was crisp, but salty. I didn't like the flavor and it was just too fried for my liking. The flavor didn't stand out in anyway other than the salt. It was very disappointing. CRAB MEAT WITH PORK MEAT SOUP DUMPLINGSIf I ate this dish alone, I would give this restaurant 5 stars. The dumplings were my favorite part of the meal. It was so sweet and moist. I really like the sweet broth inside the dumplings. I've tried other places that have tried this, but have failed. If I ever come back, it will only be to order this and this alone.I most likely won't be coming back. The service and food are disappointing. I did like their staple soup dumpling dish, but I don't know if it's worth the whole experience. The food here is flavorful and comes out fast, but the service is lacking. While we were starting to get up they already seated people at our table so we trapped against the wall. We then were repeatedly bumped towards the door even though we didn't have our coats on. That being said, we didn't have to wait and were seated as a party of 5 at a shared table immediately at 11:30. We ordered Scallion Pancake, Pork Soup Dumplings, Crispy Shredded Beef, Eggplant, Green Beans, and Shanghai Noodles with chicken. The tea was hot and refilled quickly. The table was set with a soup spoon and small dishes of vinegar waiting for our first order of dumplings.The beef was sweet and crispy but not chewy like other versions of this dish I've had. What I thought were shredded carrots were bitter pieces or orange peel mixed into the dish. The eggplant had a crisp, blistered skin which yielded to a squishy center but it needed flavor. It tasted solely of the oil it was fried in. Green beans were salty with firm wrinkly skins that snapped with each bite. The Shanghai noodles were almost the size of udon noodles and were very comforting and familiar in a slightly sweet brown gravy sauce.But the star here is the XLB. The soup dumplings, when plucked from the steamer (I used my fingers since the tongs are more risky) had the perfect mouthful of soup. The broth was flavorful and the dumpling wrapper wasn't too thick. The meat inside was actual dumpling filling, not mystery meat that I've seen ooze out of other dumplings.Cash only, but not that expensive! There's an ATM right when you walk in. We hear that the place gets pack quick, so we arrived before they were even open!  We stood in the cold weather for some good xao long bao!  The place did get pack quick when they opened though, so come early!  The service was fairly fast, we had the following:Pork soup dumplings - steamy hot porky, rich soup with a splash of vinegary soy.. yumPork and crab soup dumplings - almost the same, with just a hint of crab, delicious stillBe careful when biting into it, I was overexcited and ended up burning myself.. but so good!! Came here to try their ever so popular soup dumplings and now I'm wondering if there's any possible way I can get them shipped to me in Houston. These soup dumplings definitely live up to all the hype. They have the most delicious broth inside that just burst into your mouth when you take a bite.. it's dumpling heaven. Other than the crab and pork soup dumplings, we ordered the Shanghai noodles and scallion pancake. Both were delicious. The noddles were a little on the oiler side but oiler the tastier right ? There was also complimentary tea wish was perfect for the weather outside. At the end of the meal, they give you sliced oranges and a wet towel which is super nice. Something that I found funny is that once we sat down, our waiter came to us and asked "do you want soup dumplings ?" Instead of the typical, "what would you like to drink ?" It's like they know what everyone comes here for !! Tips for if you're wanting to have the amazing experience of Joe's Shanghai soup dumplings: don't go on the weekend if you're not willing to wait hours and BRING CASH. Honestly, I feel like this place is waaaaaay too overrated. It's a busy restaurant. However, tho there's always a wait, the rotations are pretty quick so most likely you'll get in faster than you expected. Joes Shanghai have their customers share tables with other customers. Meaning you'll be seating with other parties, which may be but awkward. Because the restaurant is so busy, the customer service is..... nonexistent. The only things that the staff members will do is quickly take your orders, give your foods, and give you your bill. No ones rude, But no one is friendly and nice.The foods other than their dumplings are... pretty gross...my table ordered the famous soup dumpling, green bean, sweet and sour soup, and orange chicken. I'm not going to lie. The foods (minus the soup dumpling) was gross..... the green bean was dumped in oil, wasn't seasoned properly, and tasted awful. On the other side, the soup was seasoned very heavily and I felt like I was eating a salt soup. Additionally, the plates were nasty. Which was very unpleasant. Though the soup dumpling was great, flavorful and cheap, I didn't have the most exciting experience Heard all about this place for the longest time, and i finally got to try this myself. It definitely lives up to the hype, not like any other shao long bow I've tried. Filled with so much flavorful broth, the meat itself was so tender and delicious. It's definitely a little gem and somethjng you must try when visiting NY. The Soup Dumplings were Amazing! Totally loved them!It was definitely worth the trip downtown. Although it was very crowded, we didn't have to wait long to be seated. I guess the table-sharing is the reason behind that. We even shared some food with our new table buddies. Not the soup dumplings though, obviously. . . to good to share with anyone actually ;-)We had ordered some Chinese greens as a side-dish and they did as well, so that was good to share. Greens and dumplings are a good combo and all in all we were pretty full, ordering two sets of dumplings for two was more than enough, leaving you satisfied and not craving desert afterwards. We got here around 3:30 and there was already a wait.  You get a number from the hostess and you wait until she calls your number.  We waited about 20 mins.  Once seated you will be sitting at a table with other patrons. It's definitely a little awkward but after a while you don't even notice the people at the table because you're busy eating.We ordered the pork dumplings and crab dumplings. Both were just ok.  The soup seeped out of the dumplings and the skin was a little thick on some.We also ordered scallion pancakes which were very delish. TRY THESE DUMPLINGS! The best soup dumplings I've ever had in my entire life. You have to try these. Seriously, stop in and get the soup dumplings. I liked the pork more than the crab, but that may be a personal preference in meat.Still dreaming about these dumplings. Pretty big juicy dumplings with lots of meat. You have to the patient picking them up without breaking them and wasting the soup. The skin is a bit thicker than some of these other ones I've been to.There were only three of us and we had three orders of pork and one order of crab.Tip: come before 11:15am to be seated without wait. After that, you will always see a long line outside the restaurant. I realize I may be Yelp crucified once the soup dumpling experts get ahold of this review...I've had better. They were good, but I've had better.....(luv u Nom Wah) Pork dumplings 8 for $9, good broth but a little more fatty than I would've liked. (Pork and the pork with crab combo are the only dumpling fillings available). My boyfriend had white fish in white wine sauce with fungi and a side of steamed white rice. (See pic) Simple but delicious. I really appreciate the ambiance here. Kinda feels like someone's dining room. Home-y, family style and you even sit with strangers if there aren't enough of you for a large table. My boyfriend and I sat with 4 men who were already well into their meal. To our surprise, not awkward. Everybody just rolls with it. Complimentary tea throughout your meal (loved it, next time I'll ask what kind it is) and orange slices at the end of your meal. It was pretty good. Not spectacular as it is painted but solid. Give them a try. I'll return for other stuff & report back! Oh! CASH ONLY

We wanted some dessert and the rolled ice cream really hit the spot. We got the green tea oreo and it was delish! Could taste both the flavours. They take a little while to make because they literally roll it fresh in front of you. Ive seen it in thailand, so it's cool to have it also in LES. Good selection of smoothies, juices and aa bowls which are made fresh and to order. I got the green aa bowl which has kale and spinach added for some extra greens-- can't taste it at all if you're afraid it might be bitter. I really enjoyed my bowls which was very filling and can be eaten as a meal if you are not super hungry! The other bowls are mostly fruit based. They have lots of healthy toppings like almonds, walnuts, goji berries as well. Note- the granola has honey and isn't vegan. For more desserty items, they have thai ice cream rolls that are customizable, waffles and bubble tea but I didn't try any of those. For food they have avocado toast, nut butter toast and now salads too! Not much seating, small store with no bathroom. Overall a nice spot in LES for a healthy boost of fruit! Literally stumbled here earlier today. I love juices but this place has a lot more to offer.It's clean, quaint and cute with several tables available for eating/drinking in.Although I only ordered a juice (the wake up call made with carrots apple, lemon and ginger), they also serve ice cream rolls ( not sure what it is but the picture resembles an actual roll and apparently you can make your own & add toppings), smoothies, shakes, juices, bowls, salads and various beverages (teas/lattes). Prices seemed standard/reasonable. Juices were 3 sizes: 12 ounces at $5.95, 16 ounces at $6.95 and 20 ounces which was $7.95.I enjoyed my juice &  pitstop at Juicy Spot. I've tried pretty much every flavor at this place and none of them disappoint. The toppings and the ice-cream flavors complement each other, making a perfect end-product. You can't go wrong with any flavor, but my favorites are below:Unique Dragon: Yogurt base with dragon fruit, topped with dragon fruit, strawberries, dark chocolate shavings, and chocolate drizzle. Love the rich color of dragon fruit and the chocolate drizzle.Ferre-Roll Rocher: Base with nutella, topped with crushed wafers, chopped hazelnuts, and nutella drizzle. Anything made of nutella can't be wrong, no?Watermelon Lychee:  Lychee base, topped with watermelon, granola, mochi, and condensed milk drizzle. I am biased 'cos lychee is my absolute fav fruit.I also love how this place is not as crowded as similar Chinatown joints. That's probably why Leonardo Di Caprio snuck into this place to satiate his ice-cream cravings! Yes, they have a picture of him on the bulletin board. Yelp checkin gives you a free topping! Pretty decent place with rolled Thai ice cream, smoothies, fresh juices and drinks folled with boba/tapioca, or flavored jellies. I had a Spring fling (1/2 sugar) and it was pretty good.  Green tea with strawberry and lychee jellies and puree.  The prices a tad more than other shops, but I suppose location has a lot to do with that. I would come back to try some of the rolled ice cream. I like that this place serves both healthy and unhealthy items. There's something for everyone! I chose unhealthy when I stopped by though ;) I got the Ferrero Rocher ice cream rolls. Service was fairly prompt. There was nobody else in the cafe that afternoon so there was plenty of seating. They do have a bench outside, as well, which is nice. The ice cream was really good and I liked the presentation, too. I would come back here to try more but maybe an acai bowl next time, since there are so many ice cream roll places to try in the area. It was right besides our dorm and I always went here for ice cream rolls!! I loved everything with yogurt base and chocolate base in some flavors. I really enjoyed all the flavors I had! It is a thai ice cream roll spot that also has acai bowls. I tried the "Acai": Aai blended with banana and apple juice and topped with strawberries, mangoes, banana, granola, and chia seeds. Every ingredient is fresh and solid. The granola has a good crunch to it. It feels slightly smaller than I accustomed to. The $8 price is in line with other spots in New York.
