If you want to torture yourself, eat an acai bowl in the shop as you watch other patrons eat thai ice cream rolls. I have not tried them at Juicy Spot but they look so good.If you are looking for recommendations for good acai bowls in New York, feel free to message me through Yelp and I can share my personal list of acai bowls in the city, which includes my Yelp reviews. The information for an electronic copy can also be found via my Yelp profile. I tried rolled ice cream for the first time here. I had heard that rolled ice cream wasn't worth all the hype, so I didn't have extremely high expectations (I was mostly just curious). After trying it, I can say that I really enjoyed the rolled ice cream here! My sister and I shared two things: 1) the watermelon lychee and 2) a make-your-own with green tea ice cream, strawberry flavor, mango topping, and condensed milk drizzle. I liked being able to watch the employees make the rolled ice cream. It was definitely a plus for my experience. There were three female employees working, and they were all really efficient. For the green tea ice cream with strawberry flavor, they pour the ice cream (which is liquidy at first) onto this thing which is like the cold version of a stove, and they mix/chop up strawberries in with the ice cream. Once that's all done, they flatten out the ice cream and then roll it up. It was cool to watch!The watermelon lychee consists of "original" ice cream with lychee mixed in, topped with watermelon, granola, and condensed milk drizzle. It was sweet, a little tart, and perfect for summer. The green tea ice cream with strawberry flavor was a good balance, since it wasn't as sweet but had some different flavors than the watermelon lychee. Overall, I really enjoyed the whole experience of watching my rolled ice cream being made and eating it (it's definitely different than eating a normal scoop of ice cream). I see why rolled ice cream is a thing, and now I want to try more of it! I ordered the "sunshine" juice, it's grapefruit, Apple and lemon, I got my vitamin boost. Very happy, it is very sweet though. Didn't get free ice cream topping after checking in, because I didn't order ice cream. We love their thai ice cream. Got to create our own. Definitely go back when the weather warmer with my kids. Juicy spot is on the money, the creative possibilities are endless with this ice cream. The staff is super friendly and helpful. When I walking in, I thought "well just another place where you can get rolled "Thai" ice cream". But it definitely turned out to be quite different. I came during Juicy Spots anniversary when they were giving out as many free toppings (so added stars for that). Price was pretty justifiable. Adding the concentrated milk reminded me of my childhood which was great! My friends and I had a late dinner in Lower Manhattan and were looking for something refreshing to end our night with. We found Juicy Spot Cafe a short walk from where we were and decided to try it given the 4.5 star rating. It is a block from the Delancy St station (F train) and a couple of blocks from the Essex St station (JMZ trains) - very convenient.This is a small store with 3 or 4 tables in total. It has every healthy option you could ever want: thai ice cream rolls (yes, ice cream is healthy), smoothies, acai bowls and salads. There are a lot more options for flavors in store than what you see on their menu online and there is also an option to create your own smoothies/bowls/drinks/ice cream rolls. I made my own large  smoothie ($6.95) and added the maximum four flavors. My friend got the Super Acai Bowl ($10) which she loved (tastes like a smoothie) and the Hangover smoothie ($5.95) which was also very yummy. Overall, I would recommend this store if you are craving a yummy drink. If you are looking to try the acai bowls then you also won't be disappointed. I will be returning the next time I'm in the area to try other flavors and their Thai ice cream rolls. Don't forget - if you check-in on Yelp you can get 1 free topping! I miss this place so much!!!!The best dragon fruit ice cream with unlimited toppings.It was so hot and beyond perfect for the weather. I wish I didn't have to share with the BF. AhahahOpen one in the LA. Please!!!!! Better than some of the other rolled ice places I've tried. I split the raspberry combo and it was enough for two people, which is great because this stuff is pretty pricey. Worth it for the experience of watching them make it! If you like to live on the healthy side, this is another Juice spot I would highly recommend.Look for LIN, she is awesome and knows how to make everything healthy taste good :pI love the Ginger Lover Fresh Juice, it's also the most popular juice there ...Enjoy Only been here once but I would say it's definitely worth a try. It's such a unique experience to watch them make the ice cream and it sure is tasty Came across their 'off the menu' ice cream roll combo called Double Fun in the Sun, which is a combination of mango and dragon fruit ice cream, and decided to give it a try since I'd been hearing rave reviews about Juicy Spot ever since the ice cream roll craze hit NYC. Unfortunately, neither the experience nor the ice cream really delivered.  I'm not sure if it is due to inexperience,  inefficiency, or the fact that they only have two ice cream slabs to work with, but the employees were realllyyyy slowww. I think we waited half an hour or more for one cup of ice cream!!! I'd definitely recommend coming at an off hour if you don't have that much time to kill. The ice cream roll was super cute and totally Instagram worthy, but it was also super bland. It was neither sweet nor tart... It really didn't taste like anything, tbh. We decided that we couldn't really taste the mango or the dragonfruit because both were overpowered by the milky taste of the base. I checked in too late on Yelp to discover that we could have added a free topping - which might have helped with the lack of flavor - but overall I was pretty disappointed with the taste of the dessert. Also, there is an $8 credit card minimum, which is super annoying because all ice cream rolls are $6, so you kind of have to order something else... We ended up trying the hangover smoothie, which was super healthy tasting but not really my cup of tea. However, my friend really enjoyed it! Riding the rolled ice cream wave in NYC...The ones I tried:- Unique Dragon: I thought this would be my favorite, but the dragon fruit yogurt base actually didn't stand out among the other flavors. It sure is beautiful though! - Good Crazy Matcha: my favorite of the night. The green tea base had an ever so slightly bitter flavor that I always look for, and the lychee, whiled canned, went very well with it. - Black Sesame: the black sesame base was very good, the mochi added some nice chewiness. Good service. Reasonable lines. The only suggestion I have is to lower the AC because we all froze off our rears in there.

The sponge cakes are so light and airy!! Minimum of $15 on credit cards so be prepared to bring cash. They're super efficient and you should be prepared to order when you get up front. Regular sponge is $0.75 and all other flavors $1.25. You can also buy a dozen per box. Seating is available but generally you'll find lots of Asian families sitting and enjoying their sponge cakes and coffee/tea. They also have other savory/more entree like options but didn't try. TLDR; get the sponge cakes (all flavors) and be ready to order. They're super cheap. Price/taste is high value $0.75 for an original sponge cake that is AMAZING!! It might seem small when u get it but its an e x p e r i e n c e. Its not overwhelmingly sweet and its inner part is moist and wonderful. Pairs well with a cup of hot milk tea. Their green tea flavored spongecake is also delicious with obvious hints of matcha. Ive had their fishballs once too and they were hot and uber flavorful. Their Vietnamese iced coffee tastes concentrated and sweet, as well.There is some seating inside, and there are a bunch of old people. To discourage people from staying too long there is a 15 minute sitting limit. Love this place, and I will continue to buy their spongecakes forever. My friend was like WE HAVE TO GO, THE COFFEE SHOP WILL CLOSE, and I was like, I'M KAMHING, I'M KAMHING.And I came so fast, that we went all the way. To Kam Hing, in about 15 minutes.I'm not a fan of the famous coconut Tarts at all but the little doughy bread with the chocolate chips in it is wonderful. Really underrated actually. So it's all about the little sponge cake desserts. A lot of people said oh it's just like Wonder Bread well no it's really not. Maybe you don't have very developed taste buds, but the stuff is actually unique and delicious and made with a lot of love. The lovely young man who was friendly AF recommended that I try the legendary chocolate chip. There are many different flavors, but the chocolate chip is really the way to go. Definitely one of my favorite little secret treats in Chinatown and extremely unique. If there were 6 available, it would get 6 Stars. Hipsters need not apply.I'm not sure if them getting 4-and-a-half stars "Hing"-es on my rating, but in my opinion, this place should have 1,000 5-star reviews. The new owners took the original sponge cakes and gave it faces.  Love the caricatures in the store.  They expanded the flavor options with chocolate, green tea and whatever they can think of. I tend to stick with the original flavor.  Their sponge cake is super moist and flavorful.  It stays pretty fresh for up to 5 days (never pushed it further than that).  Not sure if you want to either.They also added steamed rice noodles and curry fish balls.  Tried both and surprisingly they were both AMAZING. Looking forward to what they will spin out of their kitchen in the near future. BEST SPONGE CAKES in the area and for a good reason. If there's anything you need to try from Chinatown, this is it.You won't be able to find another place that makes them like Kam Hing does. My favorite is their original - for $0.75 each expect a light fluffy moist melt in your mouth buttery subtly sweet sponge cake. I'm happy to say that although they have expanded throughout the years, the sponge cakes remain affordable and their quality and flavor hasn't changed except for the additions of new flavors.PS. Be sure to buy a few when you're here cause you won't be able to stop yourself after eating just one! Come here for their signature sponge cakes as the reviews are true.  Incredible delicious.  Must try! Soft, flaky, moist, slightly sweet, fluffy, good snack size, and good price for one piece original flavor $.75.  It is best to consume the sponge cake while still hot as it is fresh.  Flavor sponge cakes are priced slightly higher.  Original is always indelible.  In 2017 ailing economy what can you purchase under $1 especially in NYC (aside from Lucy Van Pelt's psychiatric help for $.05)? Four stars due to filthy tables from residue of previous patrons who do not clean after themselves.  Staff does not clean the tables.  Interior appears very outdated dating back to early 1980's or possibly earlier.  Occupying the tables is a fifteen (15) minute time limit.  There is also a minimum of $15 for credit card, ergo I suggest come with plenty of cash.  Pending the time of the day families are occupying the space while children are running amok screaming boisterously loud while the elderly are sipping tea and enjoying a sponge cake in silence and solitude.  Gimme sponge cake!!Kam Hing's sponge cake has surely peaked my interest. There isn't alot of things that can be bought for less than $1 in NYC. I'm glad Kam Hing's sponge cake is one of those few things. Their original sponge cake is 75 cent (only!) . It is a less sweet, more substantial version of an angel food cake. Pairs especially well with a milk tea or coffee.I came here on a Sunday afternoon and had to wait in line for 10 minutes before I can get my hands on their famous sponge cakes, While in line, I was able to peek into their kitchen where I saw their bakers moving trays of freshly baked sponge cakes. So glad to know that I'm getting freshly baked cakes and not stale ones that have been sitting on a bakery case for days. This place is still my favorite for a couple of sponge cakes whenever I'm in the area. This little shop is VERY casual and Chinese. What I mean by that is since it's family owned, you will see their kids' toys and a table or two on the side where they put their belongings. At times, it's a super loud environment with kids yelling and playing and grandparents chatting away. I usually just grab and go (real fast). Besides the sponge cakes, I have not tried anything else but they have a lot of coffee selections and they also sell fish balls - good for quick lunch. The sponge cakes are $1 each, $1.25 for flavored ones. I would stick with the original because sometimes the other flavor takes a bit away the fluffiness. For example, the coconut actually has coconut pieces so the texture is not as good. However, green tea flavored is worth a try. DELICIOUS SPONGE CAKES.  Been coming here for 2 decades.  Sponge cakes are made fresh daily.  So soft and delicious.  Their original flavor is the best.  The green tea flavor sponge cakes are a little dry.  Cash only.  One time I had to stop my mother from bringing a suitcase to load it up with sponge cakes. I always buy 3-4 dozen sponge cakes when I travel to New York.    I think I'll have to buy 2 dozen in the future to cut down carbs in my diet. BEST. SPONGE. CAKES. There. I said it. Soft, fluffy, MOIST, slightly sweet, and the perfect size! I always take at least 2 dozen back to Boston. I've never tried the other flavors because the original is so good. When I walked into Kam Hing, I immediately understood why it's a neighborhood favorite. Its sponge cakes definitely live up to the hype. Its vibe is a throwback to the 1990s, (of course) an era where none of us were walking down city sidewalks while looking at our smartphones. For 75 cents, the original flavored sponge cake is one you can't go wrong with. Like many other commenters mention, its subtly sweet taste and moist texture make the sponge cake decadent without weighing you down after you consume it, since this treat isn't dense.As I mentioned in my tip, the Kam Hing staff stopped making toilet paper available in its bathrooms, because people kept on stealing them. The chalkboard menu, kitschy / humorous signs and cash only policy give this spot its charm. I hope Kam Hing stays in business for a long time. Hole in the wall place. This coffee shop is known for their sponge cake. It says so outside!I was eating at Taiyaki and saw the yellow sign that said "best sponge cake in town" so i immediately ran inside! Their regular sponge cakes are 75 cents each, sort of tiny looking. The flavored ones cost more. There are a lot of really funny signs around the front counter.I was surprised to see that the Chinese workers there were not only really fluent in English, but also talking to each other in English! There is a huge flat screen TV in the eating area as well as a lot of chairs. There are a few game machines, but they are all not plugged in. This seems to be the place that all locals know about. I saw a business man all suited up come in and buying a spongecake and coffee to quickly scarf down. Boy, i've been missing out all these years! The spongecake was so light and fluffy. Not too sweet. Milk tea here is also very good. It was a little stuffy in here because the air conditioning wasn't on. But maybe that's just to make customers not linger around too long. The food here was great! I've been coming here for 4+ years. They have THE best sponge cakes in all of NYC. I don't know how they make it but it's so moist and fluffy. Personally I love the original, the other flavors are good too.They also sell chinese rice cake rolls with fish balls. The rice rolls are pretty good, it's mad cheap. The fish cakes are not that great but it's dirt cheap. The service is super fast and some of the people working at the register are hispanic but they understand Chinese. I was so impressed! AND they are SUPER friendly, even to all the chinese grandpas and grandmas who can come off very rude. Nice airy and light sponge cakes that are inexpensive. Perfect for a mid day snack with tea or coffee. $0.75 for the original and $1.25 for flavors. Definitely get the original and one of the flavors when you're here. I've come here twice and both times the green tea sponge cake ran out! Luckily the guy at the counter said I can call to have them hold my order for pick up! Conveniently located right off Canal Street. It's a bit tricky to find but just look out for the sponge cake flag hanging above the building. Will have to come here again to taste the green tea sponge cake! What you need to know: - this is THEE place to get sponge cakes, it is their specialty!- there is a small seating area for when you can't wait to grub on the sponge cakes- these cakes are so special that I bring them as gifts from NYC all the time! - cash only! What I always get:- the original flavor $0.75 remains the best! There are other flavors such as chocolate chip, green tea, cappuccino, strawberry, butter scotch, etc that cost $1.25. - ask them if you can get fresh and hot sponge cakes and it is seriously 5 times better! Normally, biting into the sponge cake feels like eating a fluffy cloud. If you are lucky enough to get them hot, it's seriously heaven!!! Love this place!!! Their little sponge cakes!! Drooooolllll I've been coming here for those cakes for years!!! They've been a hole in the wall for way too long. Glad they were able to expand to such a larger place! Their cakes are still great. There's a new flavor they have. Already forgot what it is cuz I only wanted the original. Sorry!!! But a box of 12 is $9 right now. Not a bad price. There have lots of tables and chairs if you wanted to eat cake and have coffee. They sell other little things too. They have a bathroom for customers. Love this place!!!!! The people are super nice! They speak cantonese. =D Browsing through Yelp, this store intrigued me all the raves that this is the place to get sponge cakes.  I'm down for the best of anything especially if it cost about a dollar.I found the store's decor amusing.  I'm sure they didn't hire a decorator, but the owner probably found some signs that amused him and throws it up around the store.  I would describe the place as whimsical and they some signs that did make me smile.I went during a slow period and there was no lines, but all the seats were taken. Luckily the sponge cakes are perfect for the road.   I got the original flavor and the green tea flavor.  Both were about the same size.  Small.  I think 3 bites is all it takes to make it disappear, but I ate it slowly so I could actually taste it.  These sponge cakes are a bit denser than what I had in other bakeries, but it had good flavor.  The original is very buttery and the green tea had enough flavor to make you know what it was.  I personally would have liked the green tea taste to be more intense, but it was good enough. The original was 75c and the flavored ones were $1.25.  Is the flavored ones worth 67% more than the original?  Apparently so, since that's the market rate.Having different flavors sponge cakes is what makes this place unique and special and it's enough for me to try the rest of their flavors in due time. The significant other was so giddy when his friend showed him this place. For a $1.50, you can get a small cold drink. This really made his day since we were walking around and being tired tourists. I ordered the milk tea while he ordered the coffee/tea mix. While our drinks went commando, without tapioca pearls, it was pretty good... His and mine only varied in the very sight hint of coffee. Seating space was rare as we encountered a large group of elderly Chinese sitting around chatting. There's a bathroom here that's open to patrons of the place. It didn't have a lock or door code so I saw one or two folks sneaking in and using it. A random outpour of rain led me and a friend here, and what a pleasant surprise! This cafe specializes in traditional Chinese paper wrapped sponge cakes, which are deliciously light and pillowy cakes typically eaten for breakfast or afternoon tea. This coffee shop even offers fun novelty flavors like strawberry, cinnamon, chocolate, and matcha, and most (unfortunately for me) were sold out by the time I came in around 4pm. I tried the strawberry and the original, and both were excellent - fluffy, moist, and subtly sweet, just how I like them.There's minimal signage outside but no signs on the door itself. I actually had no idea what this cafe served until an employee welcomed us to come in, reassured us not to be afraid of all the elderly folks in there (lol), and explained that this little coffee shop specializes in Chinese sponge cakes. They definitely take pride in their work here, and even let us try a small sample before buying. So sweet of them.Bring cash because it's cash only, and come before 3pm to try one of their hot sponge cakes fresh out of the oven! I heard this coffee shop is famous for their sponge cakes. I was thinking "Really? Just sponge cakes?" But then again, some people call it "legendary" sponge cakes. I am completely down for legendary sponge cakes! So off we went. It is a bit of hall in a wall type of place, you will miss it if you are not paying attention. The inside was small, plain, simple, no-frills. They do offer more than the legendary sponge cakes, like hot dishes and other baked goods, and coffee & tea of course. The infamous sponge cakes are in a plastic bin right underneath the cash register counter. They have the "Original" and few other flavored kinds. I hear the sponge cakes here are really popular, and that they get sold out quickly. We went there on a very snowy day, so we didn't have any issue getting what we wanted. It is always good to visit popular spot on a bad weather day. We got original, mint chocolate chip, and green tea sponge cake. They were really fluffy and airy, just as it was described by many of their fans. It was egg-y, sweet but not much, really light. As light as clouds. It is a simple sponge cake, but has that comfort flavor that reminds me of home-cooked or -baked feel to it. I see why their sponge cakes are popular. Very fluffy and light, and the flavored kinds have really strong flavors present in it. And the price, you can't beat the value. Super cheap!

Honestly, this review can be summed up as so: It was a good pastrami sandwich, but not a $20 sandwich.On a Sunday night, we had no problem getting in and out quickly, which was a surprise since so many reviews mention long waits and crowds. We were able to walk right up to a counter and order. The seats were all full (I believe this may be for waiter service), but we just ate at a counter. We paid at the front when returning our ticket, but I think you can pay by card towards the back.Make sure to keep your ticket because you need it to get out even if you did not order anything. TLDR: While a bit pricey and very busy during peak hours, there's no denying that Katz can make a great sandwich.As annoying as it may be for the New Yorker, a good reason to come to New York is for the food. NYC has quite a few different types of food associated with the city, such as pizza and bagels, but don't forget the pastrami sandwich.While I am sure there are no shortage of delis in NYC, I would come to Katz at least once in your life to experience one of their pastrami on rye sandwiches. Yes, it could definitely be a tourist trap here, and there are plenty of pictures and videos of the lines during peak hours, but the sandwiches live up the hype.If you're coming to the lower east side for a sandwich at Katz, it seems like mid morning would be your best bet to avoid the rush. I did not want to waste an hour or so of my day just waiting in line during lunch, and if you come in the morning, there is literally no wait. When you enter, you immediately get a ticket from a staff member up front. Even if you're sharing a sandwich with someone else, both people will need a ticket. I think this helps them with monitoring who comes in and out, as well as what you order, but if you lose the ticket, you'll be charged $50 on your way out. And by the way, this place is cash only. There a number of staff to order your food from and once your order, and they'll even give you a sample of the meat your choose. If you never have had a sandwich from here before, it's probably best to go with the pastrami on rye as that's probably their most well known sandwich. If you want something different, I think that their corned beef is also a Katz staple.Their sandwiches are absolutely gigantic - a half of a Katz sandwich is a sufficient meal for just about anybody. They do not hold back on the amount of meat you get on your sandwich, so you should not be leaving this place hungry.While it is a bit pricey at around $20 a sandwich, I would say it definitely is worth it and will be one of the more memorable sandwiches you'll ever have. All I have to say is whenever I am sick or a friend is sick, I have Marco ball soup delivered to them from Katz's deli. They will deliver all over Manhattan (can be pricey) but it is so worth it. If you love a good bowl of soup and great sandwiches, Katzen is the place.Their knishes are also delish. Very large and heavy, but if you want some comfort food, it's a perfect go to. After coming here for 4 straight years. The quality hasn't changed. Make sure you tip well and chose a deli guy with a heavy hand :)I've only gotten the pastrami but why waste your time on anything else? Always a long line but always worth the wait! Love you Katz Deli!!! Ended up here on an impromptu sandwich run after 3 hours of statistics hungry and with a headache. So glad I did! I usually steer clear of the "touristy" places but damn that roast beef and matzo ball soup hit the spot! My classmate had a pastrami and corned beef mix. Party in our mouths! Katz's Delicatessen is a true landmark in the New York restaurant scene and it fully embodies all qualities that New York represents: A no-frill, eat-and-get out kind of New York deli that's open late (or 24-hours on weekends) to serve this city that never sleeps.There are many signature dishes at this historical restaurant, with the pastrami being the star of the show. I am personally an advocate for the Reuben Hot Sandwich with pastrami because I appreciate a bit more condiments and toppings on my pastrami sandwich than just mustard - tradition or not (Yes, I said it. What are you going to do? Arrest me?) With that said, if you are a purist, then you may opt to order the Katz's Pastrami Hot Sandwich or the platter.Another popular dish is the Matzo Ball Soup. I wouldn't say it's absolutely the best, as I find the broth slightly salty and lacking depth. But the matzo ball itself is fluffy and light. Among the side items, I am a big fan of the Square Potato Knish. Deep-fried to perfection, these crispy potato treats are a must-have for potato lovers.Due to their fame and popularity, Katz's tends to be a bit touristy and typically busy at all hours of the day. Like many reviews mentioned, the attendant will give you a ticket upon entering the restaurant. Whether you use it or not, hold on to it with your dear life. It's been a few years since I've been back here, and it's still one of the best pastrami sandwiches I've eaten! We went on a Monday afternoon, 1pm, light lines and fast service. Walk up to any of the available counters, order your food, they give you a sample taste of the meat, they hand carve the meat to make your sandwich, slice some pickles on there, then you give them your ticket you received when you walked in. Don't lose that ticket!!! It has the total price of what you ordered.The pastrami was part lean and part fatty, and the deli mustard was perfect! Also, share the sandwich if possible... it's huge!! We went really early, so there were no line.  When you walk through the door, you are given a ticket for each person.  Make sure you don't lose your ticket, you will be charged if so!  We decided that we were going to split a pastrami sandwich, so that we do not over eat, since we plan on eating another place after this.  We walked up to a craver and was very excited, he cut us a piece of pastrami, and boy, was it delicious!We ate our huge delicious pastrami sandwich, and was contemplating on ordering another, since we shared one.. but we had to resist!  We was going to make a trip back to Katz while we were in NYC, but failed to do so... so I shall visit the establishment again! PROS:- I mean, this place is famous for a reason. You get to experience what Harry felt like when he met Sally ;) CONS:- So so so crowded. Honestly, this place is so hectic. It's expected from some place as famous as this but it still takes you out of an enjoyable experience when you feel like you're being rushed and everything is crazy.- I just simply do not understand the ticket system but regardless, don't lose the ticket since they charge a $50 fee if you don't hand them a ticket upon leaving the placeSPECIFICS:- Katz's Pastrami = Lots and lots of meat, which is good. But the proportion to bread and everything else is just off. Don't get me wrong, the pastrami is the best that I've ever had and to be honest, I'm not a big pastrami person and even I think it's good. But it is a little underwhelming after you've had the first couple of bites.- Fries = So good. There's a good balance of soft and fat fries to the thin and crispy fries so whichever kind you prefer, you're golden. - Pickles = Random thing to put on there, I know. But my god their pickles are so. good. I love pickles in general so that could just be me but I love how they had 2 types of pickles. The one that's not as pickled was delicious. It has a cleaner taste than the darker pickle since it didn't have as strong of a vinigar taste so the spices they used to soak it in was more evidentOVERVIEW:- If you come to NY and you're into the touristy stuff, then this is a must-stop. Despite any complaints that I've had, I'm glad I came here just for the experience and to see what all the hype is about. It's something that you should definitely give a try. But would I ever go through all this again for what I got? Probably not.Instagram @bowtiebowie for more food adventures I don't think my review will affect the sales or opinion of Katz's but having had a fantastic New Years Day meal here, I had to add my praise. The old Automat slogan, "you can't eat atmosphere" applies here since, ahem, the decor is at best, historic. Right out of a movie set (literally, as it turns out), you should spend time soaking up the century of cooking and eating that's plastered on the walls. Old photos chronicle The Who's who of past clients.  The program: Walk in, get a "ticket" that you hand to your server or carver and the adventure begins. Corned beef or very lean pastrami are the only things to order. You can get hot dogs, etc., elsewhere but this place is a pastrami palace and it's what I enjoyed. I had fries and a cream soda with my pastrami on rye. Good mustard on the side and I was in heaven. Noisy? A little. Fun? A lot! An adventure? Of course. Prices are NYC acceptable and downright cheap when you consider the quality. The now take credit cards too...Put this on your bucket list. Then after eating, cross the street and have gelato for dessert and get ready to send me a thank you card... ;-). This place had such a long line that it wrapped around the corner. I had heard so many good things about this place that I decided to wait in the line while it was snowing!  Thank goodness we were covered from the snow though or else I never would have attempted to try. Once you are in, you can choose to either continue standing in line and order once you get to the counter for to go or to find yourself a table which is hard because that place was sooo packed! The other option was to wait for a table for waiter service. I chose to wait for waiter service so I would be guaranteed a table. There is a waiting area on the side where you wait to get your named called. You can order a beer to enjoy just to make the wait seem shorter. Upon getting seated I tried the cornbeef sandwich and the pastrami sandwich. Each sandwhich was about a whooping ~$20. I don't think I've ever spent so much on a sandwich before. They are pretty hefty in size so if you don't want to be stuffed I would suggest splitting one with someone.The matzo ball soup is definitely one of the weirdest soups I had ever had. The broth is very flavorful with a beef flavor but then there is literally a ball of boiled dough with it too. It's not bad - just different for me!Now getting onto the sandwiches... I really never have had corn beef and pastrami this GOOD before. It went really well with the pickles they came with. Probably the best corn beef I ever had. Even though the sandwich was so basic... it was perfect. This place is a must if you're visiting New York or even a resident. I'm so happy to live close by, it's truly a treat! The pickles, slaw, and pastrami are unbelievable. While you're waiting for your sandwich aka watching them prepare it and having your mouth water like you've never known.... the guy cutting up the pastrami and other meat willGive you a sample. Seriously it melts in your mouth. If you've never been you need to go! It's always very busy so be prepared for a wait of some sort. I will be going back regularly and next time will try a knish! First review of 2018 goes to the famous Katz's. Prior to coming here, I've only seen photos of long lines crowding around the counter, waiting for large, juicy pastrami sandwiches. I honestly didn't know what else to expect. We came on a Monday around 11am and were so lucky to beat the lunch rush. We were immediately seated at the table-service section (didn't know that was an option). Our party of 2 had to share a table with another couple, which I didn't mind. Of course, we ordered the Katz's Pastrami and added cheese. The corned beef sounded good too, but after seeing other people's giant sandwiches, we decided to split one. For $22, it's quite pricey, but the quality and size is well worth it. The meat is tender and fatty, the cheese nicely melted, the regular bread worked well. They also have hoagies but I wanted the original. The mustard is a MUST. It completes the sandwich. They have a whole bottle at each table, so you'll always have the perfect ratio of meat to condiment.Cash only. Keep the ticket they give you prior to entering. They won't let you leave without it! True NY Jewish deli experience at Katz's. Bustling around lunchtime on a Monday afternoon. We chose waiter service, but you can also order at the counter and take to a table. Service was great, unfortunately didn't get our server's name, but he was amazing. Very genuine, and wanted us to have a great experience. I got the matzo ball soup with the half hot turkey sandwich. My pops got the corned beef sandwich and potato pancakes. Everything was fantastic. The matzo soup was flavorful, and matzo ball was airy. The potato pancakes had great flavor and were very well done. It was probably some of the best sliced turkey I've ever had. Definitely recommend the hot turkey. I don't do beef, so I skipped the gravy, but I can imagine that it would have made it even better! Pops said the corned beef was great too. Portions were monstrous as they should be from a NY deli. Food came out quickly too. All around great experience at Katz's! Probably the best pastrami I've ever had. This is simplicity at its finest. Juicy, fatty cuts of pastrami layered on to two slices of rye and covered with my mustard. The quality of the pastrami is second to none, and it's what makes the Katz's a worthy must-try for those visiting NY.Prepare to bring enough cash when you come here. You get a purple ticket when you first come in and they take your order on the ticket when you line up in one of six lines. Cash only and you pay with your ticket when you leave. It's a minimum of $20 per a sandwich so it is pretty steep, but it's worth it for the experience. We ordered the pastrami sandwich and corned beef sandwich on rye. Both were good, but the pastrami was my favorite because of the fatty juicy cuts. It doesn't overwhelm you with a blend of flavor, it just overwhelms you with fatty, juicy, pastrami goodness. Definitely a must try whenever you're in NY. Portions are pretty large, so you can split a sandwich with someone. Do expect a wait, took about 45 minutes to wait in line and get our food. The lines are usually pretty big (though surprisingly small when I went there most recently for dinner time on a Wednesday night.) I got a sandwich to go from station no. 4. I wouldn't bother getting sodas here as you can get Dr. Brown's go to go from some bodegas for under half the price but it's one way for them to help pay rent for how massive the place is.The pastrami here is world class and they deserve to be well known for it. The corned beef is also very good though I have had better. Sure the prices are very high but 25+ dollars for a massive sandwich which feels like is 2 or 3 pounds is fine as you get two meals out of it. I would say the pickle is just OK.As I have a local kosher deli, it feels weird when people order meat and cheese here. Then again, to each their own. Very good stuff here. It's a tourist stop but all the good things of being one (just get out of the way if you don't know what you want/where to go with a ticket.)4.5 A staple for my Jewish family, we've been making the pilgrimage here from NJ for as long as I can remember, although since I moved to the city about 5 years ago it's been a lot more convenient. We always go the self service route, how it's meant to be. Bring some singles to tip the sandwich makers and they'll likely give you some nibbles while you wait. If you have a pickle preference make sure to let them know (I'm all about the half sours!) Our recommendations are the square potato kinish, corn beef (you can get it lean if that's your preference), pastrami, and the brisket sandwich. If you're with a few people, get a side of cole slaw to add to your sandwiches. Don't forget the amazing mustard and in house Russian dressing. The French fries are nothing to write home about but my dad still loves them. Wash it all down with a Doctor Brown's soda (black cherry or cream are the way to go). Keep in mind if you go during prime time dinner it may be a zoo, but I've only encountered this a few times. Before we came to NYC, everyone said to come to Katz's Delicatessen and get the pastrami sandwich. They also advised to not lose our ticket that we get upon entering. If everyone says to come here, we had to come here. Make sure to bring cash because they are cash only. We got to the restaurant around lunch time. They advised us at the entrance, where you get your ticket, that we could wait for a table which will have a server to serve us or we could get our own food from the cutter then find an open table to dine on. There was a wait for a table and the place wasn't too busy so we took our chances to go cafeteria style. While I was standing in line at the cutter section, someone dining behind us left so Mink quickly took the table. Score! There are two sections in the restaurant. First section is the meats and sandwiches (left and middle of wall). Second section is the grilled items and soup (far right of wall). I first stood in line for the meats and sandwiches because the line was shorter. You'll get a sample slice to munch on while waiting for the cutter to prepare your order. I ordered 1/2 pastrami sandwich and 1/2 brisket sandwich, both with no mustard. It came with two types of pickles. The pastrami sandwich is probably one of the best, if not the best, pastrami sandwiches I've had in my life. Brisket was very good too but you have to get the pastrami sandwich. The pickles were legit! As full as I was at the end of the meal, I ate them all. After ordering in the meat and sandwich section, I stood in line in the grilled items and soup section. Mink wanted a grilled cheese sandwich and I wanted a bowl of their Matzo ball soup. The soup broth was very good and the dish complimented the meal perfectly. Mink really enjoyed her grilled cheese sandwich. Service is very friendly in the entire establishment. There is also free water in the back that is self serve. The restaurant is constantly busy so keep that in mind. You'll pay as you leave. If you have never been here before, you have to come here. Until next time that I'll be in NYC, I'm gonna dream about coming back here... LOVE!!! Need I say more? If you love pastrami, corn beef and steak fries, this is the place!! This is an excellent New York deli that needs locations on the west coast. Whenever we come to New York we always have to make a stop here.  This place was established in 1888 and the staff can be theatrically cranky. They stack the meat really high so hopefully if you come here you are hungry and love meat.  The pastrami is truly the best I've had. It's so good you can eat it plain. It just melts in your mouth. You are given a ticket once you enter. Make sure not to lose it as you use that to pay on your way out. You can either order at the counter or you can sit down and be waited on.  We always just order at the counter as we love watching them make the mile high sandwiches and enjoy conversing with the staff. The steak fries are also amazing and they stack a ton on a plate. We can never finish it.  We usually order the pastrami sandwich on rye bread with some mustard or pastrami and corn beef together.  Both are excellent.   Make sure to also get the two types of pickles with your sandwich! They come with the sandwich. I saw this place written on a post somewhere, looked at the insane amount of reviews on yelp and knew I had to come here to see what it was all about...When I first walked in, it was pretty chaotic. An organized mess. There were several lines everywhere by the counter, but it went fairly smooth considering the line. The seating was pretty packed from the front to the back, but we managed to get seats as well. I came specifically for the pastrami sandwich, so that's what I got despite the price tag on it. The pastrami itself is pretty thick and tastes good. They do stuff quite a bit between the rye bread, so that's a thumbs up. For $21-22 for a regular pastrami on rye sandwich, it's one of the most pricest sandwiches that I paid for, but after my experience, I would say that I'm glad that I tried it once.

Awesome decor, short wait time (late lunch), and friendly staff. The saganaki was the most oddly delicious dish I had all week. The crust was perfectly flaky, with a soft mozzarella like cheese in the middle. The cheese had a sharp flavor similar to parmesan which paired strangely well with the honey and lemon drizzled on top. The lamb and fries were also delicious. The grilled octopus was by far the most tender I've ever had. All in all a great experience. First time having Mediterranean food in Lower Manhattan, and Kiki's definitely lived up to its hype! I came on a Monday around 12:30, and there were only two other tables filled in the cavernous eatery. My two friends and I split two appetizers and two traditional plates, which was more than enough for us.Appetizers:We ordered the lemon potatoes and calamari. The potatoes ($7) were cut into around 6 huge wedges and drenched in creamy lemon sauce. Soo delicious and paired well with the other dishes. Calamari ($11) was lightly breaded and not drenched in oil like a lot of other calamaries I've eaten; overall a lighter dish than expected!Traditional Plates:Lamb Frikassee ($17): Delicious lamb with creamy lemon and dill sauce. Cooked to perfection and didn't taste gamey. Theres also bone marrow u can scoop out thats so freakin good.Moussaka ($15): thought this was a lasagna at first but was wrong af, in size its a little larger than an average slice of lasagna. Its has a toasted and bread-like top with ground beef and mashed eggplant underneath. Has a cinnamony taste that grows on you, my favorite of the two entree dishes we ordered.Overall, a reasonably priced Mediterranean restaurant, with great service and a waitress that allowed us to split the bill three ways (tysm!). The ambiance is comfortable, the bathrooms are seriously so cool, and the location is so low-key (dont let the chinese printing sign that plaques the restaurant fool you). You can't go wrong with this place! Came here with a friend for lunch on a super cold day. The dining area was so much under heated that almost everybody I saw kept their coat on throughout the entire meal. I came through subway so wasn't super cold when I sat down but couldn't feel my toes when I left (after about an hour). So, the meal wasn't comfortable.Food wise I'm happy with it -Melitzanosalata - Amazing! Highly recommended. The pita bread that came with it was nice and warm too! I would repeatedly order this.Loukaniko - Solid. Very nice flavors! But not blown away.Spanakopita - Disappointed. It wasn't even served warm... very blend. Would not order again.Bifteki - My friend liked it. I tried the fries which is nothing special. I'd give a 4 for the food but downgrade for the dining experience! I don't think I will come back until Summer.  The food is definitely not good enough for me to put up eating a meal without proper heating. Unassuming (and hard to find) Greek restaurant in Chinatown. Friday early evening, lots of seating inside and even more further around the back. To start off, shared the Roasted Lemon Potatoes ($7) - several giant potato wedges swimming in moderately chunky lemon sauce. Not too much lemon flavor (some prefer more) and went well with the free bread/pita. For the main course, ordered the Moussaka ($14) - a large square of potato, eggplant, and meat that's very filling. Particularly like the crisped mashed potato layer on top. Also got to try the Imam Baildi ($1) - a vegetarian medley of mostly eggplant and tomato. A little too sweet, so has to be paired with a different sauce to counteract.A range of servers helped us out as more groups came in as the night went along. A different option when in the neighborhood and looking for a quality sitdown. This place is such a gem! The restaurant itself is quite large so we didn't have too long of a wait. We weren't sure how much to order but all the starters were crazy good. We got the Tzatziki and Spanakopita - HIGHLY recommend both. For main dishes we got a bit too much but the Lamb Frikasse was delicious. It was also a lot of food and can be very easily shared. We also had the Garido-Makaronada (Spaghetti with Shrimp) that we opted to get with the anise ouzo cream sauce. Again a large portion and it can get a bit overwhelming with all that cream, but great to share. Overall a wonderful meal - super cozy and filling but oh so delicious! Has anyone ever been to Kokkari in SF?! Only THE top rated restaurant in SF btw. Well, Kiki's is Kokkari without the uppity feel or the uppity price! Soo hayy. Came by for a late night bite with the local buds, and damn, de-freakin-licious! My buds come here way too often apparently bc Kiki herself came up to us and started chopping it up. Comped us an order of the best hummus and tzatziki! YUM. Pita gorging ensued. We also got sides of grilled octopus and some veggies. Finished with the perfect branzino AND a side of spinach feta rice. THAT rice. Ahh. I still think of that rice. The perfect balance to the salty fish. Service was great. Food was fantastic. And ambiance was perfect for a late summer/early fall night. Kiki, you've won me over. 5 stars! Holy Greek wedding! Inconspicuous "speakeasy" Greek restaurant smack dab middle of Chinatown. Vanna, I'd like to buy proper grammar please.It is all amazing. Octopus. Yes. Branzino. Yes. Everything. FANTASTIC. The last time I went to a Greek restaurant this mind blowing and amazing was Kokkari in San Francisco and I used to live across the street. Granted, that was twice the price and I went once or twice in a year span. Yes, it is fancy. Yes, I miss living there.That being said, come here, expect to wait a little bit for a table, but check out a bar nearby to kill the time, but don't fill your stomach too much, because you'll need room for all the deliciousness here.Splendid. A great experience. Come. Three hour wait on a Saturday night.  THREE HOURS!!!  After they told our group of 4 only 1.5 hours.  I don't know what kind of berserk operation you're running to have those kinds of waits, but I don't think so.  I suppose we were the dumb ones to keep waiting but you keep thinking "just another 15 mins", and then next thing you know... Three hours.  In any case, the food was just blah.  Moussaka was too soggy, lamb was super fatty, but the saganaki was dope.  My advice is to avoid this restaurant on a weekend night, if not altogether. Super solid Mediterranean spot. I'd reco going early as they don't take reservations and get busy really fast esp on a weekend !! Moussaka- some of my friends said this tasted like pumpkin pie ahaha texture wise and I think there is a bit of cinnamon in the. Really good! I fully enjoyed. Super rich bechamel. Mixed grill platter - id say solid for 2 ppl. Lotsa fries!!Octopus - rly soft and tender. Not rubbery like most places. Would def come back Just wow wow wow . Everything we got from this place just blew my mind. The squids wow. The lasagna brother wow. The salad wow. The wine wow. But sadly the desert has scarrd me for life. I mean i will never be able to have cheesecake agian. Because 8 will compare it to here. Wowwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwww i ordered twice. I will always remember the taste and texture of it. Thing will never be the same agian. Too bad i live in LA California. I will miss this place. Hope to cone there agian soon Great service but the food was meh. Not exciting for the price... needed more spices. Tried a bunch of food that was all fabulous, but the savory standout was the Pastitchio. Basically it's a Greek lasagna. It's one of the house specialities, and you can't go wrong. All. That. bechamel. Yum. Ambience is chill, but I particularly love all of the different rooms you can sit in. We passed through about four rooms until we got our table, but it was a small, intimate space. Good for not having to scream over each other to have a conversation. KenScale: 8.0/10I was following Google Map on my way to Kiki's and then suddenly got lost briefly because there was a Chinese sign at the location where the restaurant was supposed to be. Interesting... Isn't this supposed to be a Greek restaurant? Well, this neighborhood is Chinatown after all, and the owner of the restaurant must've thought it wasn't worth changing the sign to Greek letters. In any event, the restaurant got quickly packed and there were people who started waiting on the queue soon after my wife Jun and I, plus another couple, got seated (we showed up around 7 p.m. on a Friday evening). Greek cuisine is still an area I haven't had a chance to fully explore (compared to, say, Italian or Japanese), but I can tell why Kiki's is a popular tavern in this remote area of the city. The solid food offerings here is likely to please almost anyone who is on the table. We started with a couple of spreads. Jun is always partial to tzatziki (the Greek yogurt dip with cucumber) so we ordered one here, along with fava (creamy golden split-pea puree topped with tomato onion sauce and capers). The favorite for our party, however, was the simple, smoky eggplant mash topped with crushed walnuts. The smoky feel of eggplant was quite addictive without overpowering in flavor. The Grilled octopus at Kiki's, while simply prepared, was almost cooked to perfection in terms of texture, which is often hard to pull off at a restaurant. We also ordered spaghetti with shrimp and light white wine-tomato sauce, which turned out to be slightly more interesting than a run-of-the-mill tomato spaghetti dish in flavor. The savory course ended with a large plate of mixed grill accompanied by hand cut fries and grilled pita. We had more mixed experiences here. By far the best meat items were lamb shops which were cooked very nicely without overpowering flavor while maintaining smoky feel; on hindsight, we should've just ordered more lamb chops instead of going with the mixed grill. On the other hand, loukaniko (orange peal flavor traditional sausage) and bifteki (classic Greek spiced ground-beef patty) were both over-seasoned such that we couldn't get much out of the texture of either meat. For desserts, we shared the classic baklava (honey-walnut-filled layers of filo dough) and a massive shredded pastry topped with creamy vanilla custard, whipped cream and pistachios. Both were a little bit too sweet for my taste, although my sweet tooth wife didn't complain as she savored every bite of baklava.The restaurant doesn't accept reservations so I highly recommend visiting early to get seated without long wait times. There are some interesting Greek wines (both white and red) that you may want to try to complement your meal. The hip atmosphere of the dining space, where the crowd was mostly on the younger side, makes Kiki's an ideal place for a casual dinner with friends before a night out in nearby Lower East Side. Kiki's is the type of no-frills place that I would love to come again and sample more dishes of Greece. We live around the neighborhood and have been wanting to stop by and try their brunch. However, we ended up coming here for dinner. We had the melitzanosalata, spanakopita the kayanas and the whole red snapper. The time frame they served the the appetizer til before the red snapper was probably every 3 mins. We felt rushed. The dish we liked the most was the melizabosalata. All other dishes were not hot enough. We're most likely not going to return. I really, really like it here. The only reason it doesn't get 5 stars is because the wait to get in is a real struggle. Expect a 1.5-2 hour wait for dinner on weekends. As I'm a fat kid at heart and love Greek food, I've eaten everything on the menu, and it's all delicious. The beef patties, octopus, dips, and zucchini chips. The one thing I'd maybe stay away from moving forward is this lamb dish cooked in hollandaise sauce. Get a FIX beer, too. The Greeks aren't renowned for their wine, but it's certainly nice to have at Kiki's. Don't miss it. I'm a fan. Came here for the first time as requested by a friend of mine. Was very excited to try this and wasn't disappointed with the food except for dessertOrdered:Mama's Oven Roasted Chicken: very delicious, this was served over potatoes and a lemon sauce which made it even more deliciousMoussaka : a mixture of eggplant, potato, beef & pork topped with bechamel sauce. Crunchy on top and soft and savory on the inside, one the favorites here! Pastitchio: aka cousin of Moussaka. This looked also like the moussaka except that the taste was different. Greek Yogurt: for dessert. We got this with honey and walnuts and apples. This wasn't very satisfying as there wasn't enough honey and walnuts. The walnuts were too chopped up you can barely taste it. Walked in on a Sunday evening and got seated right away, but the place was packed. Both the food and the service was outstanding! We had the spanikopita as an appetizer which was loaded with spinach and feta and had a crispy filo crust. The portion was sizable, definitely big enough for 2 to share. My friend had the moussaka which she gave 2 thumbs up on. I had the whole branzino which was one of the best I've ever had. Moist and flaky inside with a crispy skin. For dessert we shared the Ekmek Kataifi which was good. The cheesecake and yogurt both looked good too. The atmosphere is very cozy and warm.  I would definitely come back here! Cute restaurant, friendly service but food was just okay, maybe I had too much of an expectation to replicate my experience in Greece...We ordered the Briam, grilled octopus and whole grilled red snapper with lemon potato. Briam and the lemon potato were delicious, but the seafood dishes fell short. Octopus was of a mushy texture, but the flavor was there. Red snapper was overly charred, therefore very dry and hard to eat. You can really tell the freshness of the seafood by its texture; our red snapper was also of a mushy texture, which is not a good sign. Maybe I just had a very high expectation given the 4.5 stars rating on yelp, but in the end this is just New York, not some Greek island.... Good Greek food what else to add. We went with ground of three there was a wait but they had space at the bar so we went for it. Got bunch a small plates everything was pretty good and I enjoy it. The wine was ok but I'm usually not a fan of Greek wine unfortunately maybe didn't have a chance to try a good one:(we split some entrance was super easy in and out dinner. Probably won't go back unless I'm at the area cause didn't find enthroned so special but a good authentic food. A Greek restaurant with only Chinese signage and wooden flat tops and benches, serving La Colombe coffee and filled with hipsters. It is quaint, trendy, and all that, and cannot be more different from other Greek restaurants in the city like Milos and Limani. The food is traditional and straightforward, but can suffer in execution. The horiatiki comes with perfectly sized peppers and onions and some really delicious feta. The octopus was tender but sadly too soft. The moussaka was airy and fluffy but too bland. I think the best way to go is order some dips, pita and small plates, and stay away from the entrees, although the best selling dishes on a Sunday afternoon were from their breakfast menu.

Being a Sri Lankan and living in Toronto where we have our fair share of kottu, I was very excited to check out Kottu House on a recent trip to NYC and see how Kottu House elevates Kottu from Sri Lankan street food to a trendy dish in Manhattan. I must say that the end result lived up and probably exceeded my expectations! I got their chicken kottu and loved everything about it, from the package it comes in to that feeling of being back in Sri Lanka and digging in to a heap of kottu. Bonus points for the fact that it was Chelaka's (the owner) mom that made our food that afternoon.The "unfortunate" thing about my visit here is that kottu fills one up quite well so I was unable to try out their whole menu as would have been ideal despite being an unreasonable goal. I did have the lentil patties and they were delicious and made just the way I like! Thinking back, I do believe this experience of kottu is one you can never have in Sri Lanka. Kottu places in Sri Lanka are most likely going to have one beer in stock (Lion beer which is also found here) but the fact that Chelaka has paired his kottu with some great craft beer selections really does make for an experience that one can not find in Sri Lankan or even up in places here in Toronto where I've yet to experience a good beer with Kottu. And I think that's what makes Kottu House a unique experience! I was also introduced to Sangria in a can which was surprisingly good! But as many would attest, kottu goes best with a side of beer! I'd happily recommend anyone visiting NYC to give Kottu House a go for an amazing yet affordable meal in the city. TL;DR. The restaurant is homophobic. This happened on Jan 27, 2018. A group of us had been partying at The DL. We were about 7 members in the group and the time was 11 and we decided to grab dinner at Kottu House because it was near and open. Some of them in the group wanted to use the washroom as well but we weren't sure whether there were restrooms on the premises. One of my friends found it at the back and called out to another friend who had also wanted to use it saying "There's a restroom at the back." It was this point when the guy behind the counter dropped the remark "If you guys want to shag, go together." (FYI: All of us were gay) I initially dismissed the remark as something in jest but then I realized the entire episode has the unmistakable stench of bigotry. The remark as such was caustic, deeply offensive and in bad taste (Pun unintended). It wasn't a sign of open-mindedness but rather a regressive and petty mindset which I had been fortunate so far to not witness it in NYC. It reeked of homophobia and when we protested, he gave a non-apology apology and was smiling through it all, as if he had come up with something terribly clever. The whole episode was uncharacteristic of NYC which pretty much led the battle cry for LGBT rights from the front. I know I am not reviewing the food but I am reviewing the attitude of this establishment which defines the ambience of the restaurant. At a time when LGBT rights are being threatened, I strongly condemn the attitude of this unfunny guy (I think he's the proprietor of the restaurant). I urge any members and allies of the community to avoid a homophobic establishment such as this. I have just one thing to say to the guy who made the remark, "It's sad that you feel threatened by the members of the LGBT community. I suppose, unlike you, we prefer bedrooms to restrooms". The first time I tried this place a year ago, the food was SO flavorful and full of different spices. And I'm also a big spicy food lover so I was thrilled when I tasted the kick in the food! I remembered this experience and wanted to come back again! Unfortunately it changed COMPLETELY. I don't know what happened but it was so flavorless that I was struggling to even finish half of that little box. I only ate what I did because I was starving. Also, I asked them to make it super spicy. It wasn't spicy at all, so I asked if they could make it spicier. They gave me a little cup of sambol which did not do the job AND THEY CHARGED AN EXTRA $2 FOR IT!!!?? Lmao are you serious?? I do not recommend this place and would never go back. Born a South-Indian, you'd think I'm biased towards Sri Lankan cuisine, but going by the demographic distribution of the crowds that flock this place, I can tell you I am not. There are very few restaurants in town that serve the cuisine and this is one of my 2 favorites.Start with the short eats.- Fish Cutlets: Tuna fritters filled with vegetables and Sri Lankan spices. Yum yum yum!- Lentil Patties: Deep-fried patty with crushed lentils, onion and spices. The side-kick - minchi sambol comes with it. Very unique and traditional. May not blow your mind ('cos the dish by itself is simple), but get it just for checking off this dish from your to-do list of global dishes!Try the hopper next.- Egg hopper: Sri Lankan rice and coconut milk crepe with a sunny side up egg. If this is too heavy for you, get the plain hopper. You will also need to order one of the sambols, Lunu Sambol (with raw onions) or/and Minchi Sambol (with grated coconut) on the side to go with it.Now comes the show-stopper!- Crispy Prawn:  Fried prawns, anointed with Sri Lankan flavors along with chopped stir-fried roti  with a blend of curry, eggs and vegetables. This is hands-down, the best dish on the menu.-Tofu blast:  Tofu cooked in a black curry with coconut milk and spices is the best option for vegetarians.BEWARE of the spice-level. Even their "medium" spice is very spicy and that coming from a South-Indian! Also suggest getting a chilled ginger beer (oops, forget I said ginger, just get the lager) on the side to counter the extreme spice!Small, cozy place with not much seating. Love the demure black-and-white ancestral portraits donning the main wall. Zest across the street was packed and loud, so was the Mexican place.It's the lower east side, and this strip feels a bit on the gentrified side, but you can still eat for around $15.We ducked into Kottu House because it had no line.  We knew nothing about it.I didn't even know what a Kottu is.  It's a Sri Lankan fried rice and damn is it good.I had the chicken kottu on low spice $9 served in a little take out carton and it was purrfect.  Tasty, the right amount and for the quality, not over priced. The place is friendly, super casual with style and small.  They also have beers for around $8 and up.I felt so satisfied.  A little gem. Friday night, wanted something heavy and quick before a night of drinking. This spot has been on my list for some time as a fast, filling place for food in the area. Not a big place by any means; a couple tables in the middle and booth seating along the edges where it can fit. Was going to order up front, but the guy behind the counter told me to have a seat; giving me a menu and some water. Considering the size of this spot, lots of options to choose from - settled on the Deviled Beef Kottu ($10) and the Fish Cutlets ($6). Cutlets came out first, about 7 lightly fried tuna balls with heavy seasoning inside and served with Sriracha sauce. Fish is good, but creamier than what I expected. Kottu is up next: an extremely dense serving of chopped up roti, spices, veggies, and beef. I asked for medium spice and thankfully so - a significant kick in flavor (even for a guy who loves spicy food). Thankfully there's a water/napkin station to the side.Service here is great - the one guy who works up front keeps everyone happy and at a good pace. Would definitely return again for some of their other dishes. A cozy compact restaurant that serves quality food of Sri Lankan origin. My family loved their first visit here. The "Kottu" is probably as good or better than what is served in Sri Lanka. The beef rolls were excellent. The "watalappan" was perfect!The guy behind the counter was friendly & all in all it was much value for money. Never disappoints and great food! I've always ordered take-out at this place. Just 1 note, their Regular Spicy (spice level) is very spicy! So if you are not a fan of spicy food, I'd recommend mild spice level.Their Shrimp Kottu is my favorite, but they also have a nice Lamb and Chicken mix Kottu which is quite popular.Service has always been excellent at this place, no problems there! Very good food. Kottu House has many vegetarian options. If had to build a meal for this place I'd go with the lentil patties and the pineapple blast or the tofu blast kottu for vegetarians. My friend gets the chicken option and thoroughly enjoys it. I've also tried the sweet hopper, and it was a very unique dessert experience Tofu Blast Kottu (4/5)No joke spice in this they're not fucking around even with the "mild" in quotation marks because it wasn't even close to mild. But the kottu itself was really good, reminded me of Chow Fun noodles. (Vegan if you as for no egg)Lentil patties (3/5)Dry. The sauce they came with was good tho. South Asian French fries (1.5/5)I couldn't taste any French or any fry because the spice was really overwhelming. Friendly staff, delicious food, small spot with a cool vibe.  It's so fun to try different foods (I'd never had Sri Lankan street food before) and I love all the photos/memorabilia on the wall.  This is a great lunch deal-very filling, delicious and customizable.Awesome causal NYC restaurant, definitely check this place out if you're in the area. Delicious and spicy dinner. I'll come back to sample the other delights on the menu. I miss things that speak to my palate; this is certainly one of them My friend is leaving for Sri Lanka in a few days so she wanted a sneak peek and good ol Yelp showed us Kottu House.   The spot is small and cozy with a cool decor. We started with the spicy crispy calamari which was probably the best fried calamari I have ever had. Not greasy or chewy in the slightest. Dusted with cayenne and paprika and served with sriaccha on the side it is utterly addicting. For a main I had the classic chicken kotu which is chopped roti stirfried with egg,spices and chicken. Went with the second hottest spice level and it was perfect especially with the crisp,cold pear cider I got.   The service was great. Jeff our server was one if the coolest dudes I've met in a long time. A fellow comics geek he kept the small room engaged and talked to all the customers as if they were long time friends. -1 star is the price point for their main dishes. The food is really good, super spicy! I love spicy food, and when I got their spicy for the first time during their lunch hour, I literally died a bit. I could not take more than 3 bites in a row without tearing. Today, I went and got mild. Boy, it's still spicy!! A size large of their entrees are around $15, which is okay for a large. But, their large are not big, it's more of a mediumish size, which is ehh, because I won't get full. If you can't handle spice well, get the super super mild. I had their chicken last time, I can't really say much about the flavor because I couldn't finish it due to it being too spicy. I got the prawn today in mild, very good. Tasty but greasy. For what you get (a meal served in a doggy bag), it is not even that cheap. The staff is friendly, but allow a week for proper digestion. Did a delivery order yesterday with Uber Eats.  Crazy, it wasn't a bicycle it was a walking delivery guy!! Awesome, can't believe he did that despite the 10 degree F weather and the snow last night!  Makes you feel so guilty sitting at home all warm.  Oh btw, if you haven't tried Uber Eats, use this code to get $15 off your first order (sorry, guaranteed to work, but gotta be 1st time): eats-anitas561ueNote unlike other delivery services (Yelp, Seamless) that Uber raises prices slightly plus adds a service charge (pretty sure though you don't tip so that goes toward the tip).  Still worth it if you've got a promo code or you're deadest on ordering out to a place that doesn't do Yelp/Seamless (this place does do Seamless though I'm pretty sure).Love the fake newspaper lining of the boxes!! Yes, exactly like in Sri Lanka.  But well, you know they use real newspapers in Sri Lanka.  Well, I seem to recall they used a lot of kid's school textbooks as well - anatomy/biology diagrams, math equations, etc.  Yes indeed, another kind of recycling than what we're used to!We order 2 small kottus which was enough for us, and cheaper of course.  Only other place close-by that does kottu is Sigiri in East Village, and that costs like $16 so this is a nice compromise.  Really easy to recommend which is the best - get the classic chicken!! The black curry spices were so delicious!! The beef was just ok.  Be aware that medium spicy is a strong medium, so if you don't like spice you might prefer mild.We ordered the Pol Sambol (usually just called coconut chutney in Sri Lanka, or coconut chutney in southern India), you usually have to pay extra, $1-2.  That is super spicy!  But delicious since it has fresh grated coconut.As you can tell, this is mostly Sri Lankan fusion - Italian Kottu, Tofu Kottu, Pineapple Kottu, etc.  None of that obviously exists in Sri Lanka.  Go with the Classic Chicken if you want authentic.  But maybe the other flavors will help convert some newbies.  And if you're ready for the next step in authentic, go to Sigiri East Village or Staten Island ... or hell Sri Lanka 'cause its an awesome place! This place is exactly what you're looking for if you want something "off the beaten path" (whatever that means in Manhattan). While most of the big name restaurants were on a 2 hour wait, Kottu House served up a quick and affordable meal that was absolutely and uniquely delicious. My BF has to be careful about spices but they were able to make his classic chicken very mild. I ordered the crispy prawn kottu with a moderate heat level and it was perfect. If you've never had Sri Lankan cuisine, don't be shy. Kottu House is amazing. Just a bit too casual, with aquintances milling about it hanging around your space while trying to have conversation and eat. Food is good, not outstanding. First time having Sri Lankan street food. Were recommended here randomly by group of Sri Lankans walking through China town heading that way. Boy am I glad we stumbled across them! Food was spectacular. We ordered several kottu flavors, but the unanimous favorites for our group were the crispy prawn & egg. As other reviewers have mentioned, the spice chart runs much hotter than most, so even mild is considerably spicy. Be cautious of this, because in our group of four, only one could tolerate the medium. NOT GLUTEN FREE AT ALL.They cook everything on the same surfaces as bread, soysauce and their frier sees mostly breaded items which are battered with regular flour.Despite this, they advertise prominently as gluten free. And were absolutely rude when we traveled from Brooklyn to eat there and basically told that because I have food allergies it was "understandable" that I would not want to eat mislabelled food. Never one single apology or suggestion of alternatives.

This was my second time trying La Colombe in NY. I tried a regular latte and a draft latte at the location near Times Square. First off, the regular latte was delicious. Good coffee flavor, mellowed out by the steamed milk. The star of the show, however, was the draft latte. It tasted like a very thin milk shake that was not too sweet. I kid you not. It was so delicious that I probably could have drank three of them in one sitting.The draft latte was so good that I came here a second time on my last day in NY, skipped getting a drink at Jack's Wife Freda, just so I could sip on the delicious milkshake... er I mean coffee.I know there are lots of coffee places to choose from in NYC, but I definitely recommend giving Colombe's draft latte at least one go! So, so good. While I haven't tried anything other than their lattes, I can vouch that the lattes are awesome! The service is speedy so if you're in a pinch for some coffee, don't hesitate if you see a long line!I also brought home a box of the Ethiopian coffee beans. They are fresh and delicious even at home. 10/10 would recommend Great coffee long line that goes by fast.  I kinda ruined my order but they fixed it with ease.Would be been if I knew certain drinks were cold only before I paid and that's the minus one star.All else is good!Let the caffeine commence! Came here with several friends on a Friday afternoon because we were tired and wanted a jolt of caffeine while we were in the area. I've been wanting to try out their drinks here for a while now. Instead of settling for their famous cold brew, I went with several of my fellow-Yelper's recommendations and ordered a medium almond latte. There was a line, (there always is going to be) but it moved relatively quickly. When I received my drink, I was disappointed in the fact that my drink consisted of 75% ice and 25% latte itself. The almond latte itself wasn't bad, but it sure wasn't effective in keeping me awake.Overall, I don't really recommend the Almond latte if you're seeking an energy boost. I've been here before in the past, but only to grab a croissant. Maybe next time I'll try the cold brew to see what the hype is all about. All I can say is yum!They handle long lines like it's nobody's business! And the draft latte is just so insanely delicious!Why go to Starbucks when you can get a better cup of coffee at a place like this?! Probably one of my favorite places for coffee! I've been here multiple times and also drink their canned draft lattes when I'm not in the city. You can't go wrong with a regular latte but I would suggest getting the black and tan (draft latte and nitro cold brew). I find the draft latte in stores is a bit light for my taste so the cold brew balances it out and gives it more depth. Only downside is that there isn't much seating at this location. This is a super solid place for morning/afternoon coffee! Don't be intimidated when you come during peak times and the line is out the door because it moves super quickly.That being said, know what you want as soon as you enter because the baristas will call out and ask what you want when you're on line. They do that so by the time you pay up front, your drink is already prepared for you. Perfect for anyone who just needs a quick grab and go! Went here on a recommendation from a friend.  Nice little coffee shop.  Empty on a Thursday afternoon.  They had two different kinds of brewed coffee.  I tried the darker one and that was good.  My friend recommended the draft latte.  I thought it was good but not my style.  Very creamy. Meh. Needed an afternoon wake-me-up and found this place was close-by to wherever we were headed. When we walked up, it seemed like they had a decent stream of people in line that moved very fast. Maybe I'm not enough of a coffee aficionado to appreciate whatever this is but ordered two regular iced lattes. It's okay that they don't have flavors (vanilla, caramel etc) ... but my friend wanted a sweetened one and they just handed him packets of sugar LOL. It's pretty hard to dissolve solid sugar in iced drinks, usually just end up with chunks of crystal sinking to the bottom but welp.Very low interaction rate with customers and kinda comes off stand-offish, imo. Might be a normal thing for the city, but who knows, I'm a tourist LOL. Probably better of sticking with starbucks trollolol. In the city that never sleeps and is always constantly on the move, this is their ish but I'm used to coffee shop cafes where you can relax and lose track of time ... although, it is pretty interesting they pull their lattes off draft and also sell canned caffeine drinks. I have only to say that this was an experience. It may sound funny and exaggerated but my visit here was definitely a moment in my coffee-drinking life. The draft latte here is definitely one-of-a-kind. Very unique. This was my first time trying draft latte and I could see why others praise it.The draft latte is very light and refreshing - almost gives you the sensation that you are drinking draft beer. Unlike regular latte with rich milky flavor, this one is more pleasant. You must try it to understand. After brunching at Jack's Wife Freda a block away, we came here to have a second round of caffeine and a chatter. I enjoyed La Colombe coffee at every locations I've been to, and this place was no exception.The drip coffee was very aromatic and strong. I wish there were coffee shops like La Colombe in NJ and no more of Starbucks, please (although I'll continue to go to Starbucks for the rest of the year to use up all the gift cards I received over the Christmas holidays ;)While sipping on our coffees, it started to snow outside, which was pretty picturesque and romantic on this cold, gray afternoon. I missed small moments like this that I had while I was living in the city a couple of years ago. One small downside is that they had very limited number of seats. We were lucky to secure a table, but I saw a lot of people waiting while sipping on their coffee, and heading out to the door when they had finished. Coffee here is always dialed, especially for a 3rd wave chain. Recommend the house blend espresso straight up or the cortado. Also highly recommend the Black and Tan, a blend of the nitro brew and draft latte on tap. not my favorite.  I hate that you're supposed to know how to order here with no menu.  Staff needs to understand not everyone is an expert.  But the coffee is very good... Selection of Columbian coffee. Small range of espressos and coffees. There's a small seating room area but it's mostly a grab n go coffee spot. Biscuits were ok This place is by far one of my most coveted coffee shops!
