A little sweet Asian flavor mixed with the meat.I'm not totally obsessed with them, but with a cheap prices and how unique they are - and how delicious most people would find them, especially if you like sweet Asian meat - no pun intended - not trying to be dirty - then I will definitely give them five stars.I can now definitely said I've had sweet Asian meat and I've liked it. There are two things I always bring back from NYC: sponge cakes and jerky. I've tried the pork, beef, and shrimp jerky. My family likes spicy pork and the bf likes shrimp. Regular tastes good too, but the spicy has a nice kick. Just spicy enough for you to keep eating. The beef is a little more chewy than the pork. Nowhere close to meat pulp though. I've never tried the "Chop Beef Jerky"-- that might be less chewy. The owner is super super sweet. Bonus points if you speak Cantonese. Last time she told me her curry beef jerky was selling out like crazy. Cash only and no $100 or $50 bills. If you're unsure, ask for samples! Most tender and softest jerky I've ever had. Seriously. Beef jerky that's tender and juicy? Heck yeah! We passed by this spot shortly after we had already eaten, but the curiosity got the best of us. I got one piece of regular beef jerky and it was the best 2 bucks I ever spent in the city. I want to go back and try the chicken and pork, but alas, we were too full. Yes they do pack it in an air tight vaccum sealed package if you tell them you need to pack it onto the plane. For two pieces of beef, pork and chopped beef jerky i paid almost $25. They charge by weight. However this is probably the best jerky i ever had. Ordered the standard sweet beef jerky. The service was friendly and prompt. The jerky had a pleasant texture more juicy and tender than convenience store packaged jerky. The jerky was sweet and savoury. It was 3mm in thickness. For a snack, this is a nice quick treat. A very pleasant surprise snack discovered when I needed one the most. Super friendly owner and very delicious, unique-flavored jerky. In Chinatown for a day hangout.  Visited this place for some fresh Malaysian jerkies.  Two ladies assisted us and offering us samples before us making our purchase. Great flavorful and tender jerkies. But we cannot tell why they are Malaysian jerkies.  I do not find them any different from any Asian jerkies. Still love them to pieces.  Spicy ones are just as tasty as the regular ones. I would go back again and again if I  am around the neighborhood. Pros:- 6-7 varieties of jerky - Spicy and regular options - Regular jerkies were sweet and delicious. Haven't tried the spicy options but I'm pretty sure they're awesome as well! Cons: Can be a bit on the pricy side. 1/4 pound brings you 3 jerkies. Would definitely be back in the future! I went to this place with a friend who was raving about Malaysian Beef Jerky she had that was super soft and juicy. She happened to find one place in Chinatown. Note that this is NOT the dry beef jerky you find at the grocery store. It tastes like real meat (and it sure is real) with super tasty seasoning. $5.00 per 1/4 pound for most of their choices. (Look at my picture for pricing.) The lady there was so sweet. Knowing that it was out first time, she gave us a sample. What can I say that haven't been said?  Not much, but this is my first time there.Asked to get a sample of pork, spicy pork, and spicy chicken.  Got a sample of each at a good enough size for me to get a good taste.Ordered some pork and spicy chicken jerky.  The spiciness seem to vary with each bite.  Some bites I didn't taste much spiciness, but some others had a nice kick.I will be back to try the rest.Yums The best beef and pork jerky I've ever had is from here. This little hole in the wall is seriously jerky heaven. Their fresh jerky are tender, moist and flavorful, it will literally melt in your mouth. Unlike the packaged jerky, theirs aren't chewy nor dry. They also offer many different flavors and meats to choose from like pork, beef, chicken and shrimp. Although the prices are quite high compared to American/Chinese packaged jerky or should I say, there is no comparison, this is fresh stuff so you get what you pay for. Every time I come here, I always end up getting at least a pound or two of jerky for myself or a couple of pounds for gifting, which they vacuum seal the jerky for you so it stays fresh.  The staff are super nice and accommodating even when you ask for a specific dollar amount of jerky instead of their traditional quarter, half or 1 pound increments. A pound for $20/$21 gets you a good 9-10 slices and I highly recommend the spicy pork or beef jerky, chopped if you prefer it more tender, otherwise stick with the regular. At first you might feel like what is a beef jerky place doing in the list and whats so great about jerky but trust me this place is the best hidden gem ever. We actually don't even eat beef but they had al kinds of jerkies beef, pork chicken and fish. It was Malaysian style jerky which is completed different than the regular jerky. When you think of jerky you think hard dry and chewy piece of meat but the jerky here are so tender, juicy and fatty and they grill it on charcoal to give a barbecue flavor.  Everyone need to try it. Found this gem last year when I trod into Chinatown based on other Yelper's reviews and I have not been back to Malaysia Beef Jerky store since. Ling Kee's beef jerky is the real deal. Taste wise, it is as close as it gets to beef jerky you will find in Malaysia. What sets Ling Kee apart aside from the taste is their skills in grilling the meat.While others may not know, the Malaysian beef jerky is usually grilled over charcoal and you want to see a slight char and caramelization all over the meat. To achieve that perfection, the cook has to spent time to ensure the meat is well grilled over medium heat and not burnt.The other jerky place in Chinatown just don't want to spend the time grilling the meat, thus resulting in no caramelization to their beef jerky. At $21/lb for beef and $20/lb for pork, chicken and shrimp- I thought it's fair. Get the sliced beef or pork. I prefer it over the ground meat version. You can also get them spicy. Absolutely amazing jerky! So fresh, juicy... I don't think I'm ever going for store bought jerky ever again! This little shop that sell jerky is amazingly good! I just went in and point at which jerky I wanted and she heated up the jerky for me right then and there. The jerky was nicely seasoned with a kick of spice. Next time when I come, I would buy a lot more to buy back for my family. Best Malaysian beef jerky in New York. Comparable or less than other places per pound. I've been coming here for years - it's a tiny little Mom and Pop shop that does beef jerky well. The meats are tender with the right amount of sauce and the spicy flavors aren't overwhelmingly hot. It's a chewy, tender piece of heaven.Came in on a freezing cold day after wandering Chinatown - actually saw New Beef King and thought about it trying it out since it's new but the meat looked old and unappetizing, no sampling allowed and it was $27/lb. So we ended up walking and thank god we did.The shop owner is friendly and offered ample samples. She suggested we try the spicy and non spicy pork/beef. Left with about 3/4 lb of jerky for $16 which was about 9-10 slices. Tiny place but big flavor. Love their beef jerky. 2 pieces will cost you about $5~. It can get a little pricey but definitely a must try :) Super tender and delicious jerky! Chicken, pork, and beef! The shop is super small (no place to sit down) , but the owners are very friendly. Thankfully this protein snack is easy to carry and can sustain you for the whole day! Your tired Leg muscles will thank you :) Two words .Best jerk No.. I meant.. jerky Haha. But literally seriously, this place has the most delicious, soft, juicy, tender, spicy, jerky ever, I mean , I've never heard of jerky(or jerk) being anything like that, have you? I really wanted to try this place out due to my foodie friend mike Chen's recommendations (he's also on YouTube) and he made a video about how delicious it was. It's Malaysian style jerky and they have pork and beef and shrimp even. Lady was super nice even tho I was expecting rude ass service since it's china town haha but , she let me sample the spicy pork and spicy beef. I liked the pork better since it's a bit more sweeter. price: Yes it's pricy it's hella $20 for a lb I mean come on I'm broke always but if you just get a square slice of the jerky, it's around $1.8 and for me, it's a good price and I gues it kind of satisfies me? If not, well, walk back to main part of Chinatown and get some egg tarts haha Will be back, I recommend you too!

I am going to be critical here. Yes, yes first pizzeria in the US.  However, not the greatest. One could find better pizza in every direction 5-10 mins walking from Lombardi's. We ordered half margherita and half white.  Toppings tasted great.  Loved the slightly sweet tomato sauce. The slightly charred cheese on the white side of the pizza looked beautiful. But crust was not crispy. The sauce was too wet for the thin crust to absorb well. The crust was pretty much saturated with sauce. Sorry, but when a charred pizza becomes soggy, there was too much sauce. The crust appeared fairly dense, so if the crust was crispy, it wouldve probably been hard.  All in all, the pizza still tasted great. Above any chain or nice pizzeria outside of new york.At $26 for a small pizza was a tad high. And it's not like this is a nicer or a more premium place either. They serve you water and pizza with plastic cups and paper plates.  Even chipotle has nicer cutlery. It's almost like a single slice place but they charge you twice as much because its a sit-down restaurant. I really don't know where to begin. I'm from Oregon and we have way better pizza for 1/2 the cost. Maybe this is just NY, I'm sorry is all I can say. Paying $40 for a large thin pizza with two toppings. I read in another comment, "you pay for the atmosphere." I agree. The pizza wasn't that good. Now I'm still hungry since the pizza was so small with so few toppings. Off to Pizza Hut. Way better pizza for 1/3 the cost and no I don't work there. Also if your in Oregon I highly recommend Blind Onion, one of my favorites. Made with bagel dough. One of the best pizzas I've ever had. Thank you. HYPE HYPE HYPE. After taking on the quest to find the best pizza in NY- Lombardi's was the place I was most excited to try considering all the stellar reviews. Boy was this a giant disappointment. NY pizza- big, floppy, cheesy-goodness. Lombardi's- $34 for a pitcher of soda( sodas by the cup are $3-no refills) and a small regular pizza with 6 child-size slices, three spots of cheese, and an overall okay pizza. Go check out Artichoke Pizza if you truly want an amazing life changing slice. Btw- make sure to check out the same picture of buddy from cake boss plastered on the Lombardi's walls about 45 times for clout. What we got:- small pizza (6 slices)- half white half margherita- add. sausage on the margherita side and add. pancetta on the white side What we thought:- white was better than margherita- add a topping for the white to balance out the heavy flavors- perfectly baked crust (love that coal oven)- could be a little less oily- pretty pricey ($34 for 6 slices....)***CASH ONLY*** Great experience! Definitely a place you have to at least go wants to say that you've been. We started with the antepasto plate which was really great seriously get this... Also did a couple orders of meatballs for the table these were also delicious.We did a large white pizza and a large half margarita half Margarita plus sausage. Everyone was very happy. The kids love the Italian sodas as well. Don't forget to stop back near the carryout area and see the original oven from 1905! You are paying to say you ate at the first pizzeria<U+200B> in the United States and they get you for every single dollar while you are there. Those dollars you spend? Cash only here.$30 pizzas and up are the norm. $5 to add a topping. No refills on overpriced drinks.It was cool to say that we went and my daughter thought it was fun but the pizza was just ok, it was nothing special and the service was terrible. Long waits to get in and sit down and then too few staff for the number of people.I wanted to have something amazing to say about this place but at the end of the day, it just isn't that impressive. PROS:- Very good service. Our server was so kind and polite. Lots of smiles from the staff when we came in and during our meal. Very pleasant experience- I expected this place to be smaller since it seems like a common trend w/all famous pizza places in NYC to be extremely small with no seating so this was such a pleasant surprise since we were on a NYC pizza hopping adventure and we had to eat outside for every one of the stops we've made so far and it was one of the coldest winters in the last couple of years so it was great to just be able to sit inside and be warm and out of the 8 degree winter weatherCONS:- None that I could come up with! Great service and great food!SPECIFICS:- Original Margherita = Now THIS is the original NY style that comes to mind whenever you think of NY pizza. The mozzarella was melted to perfection and leaves a long string when you pull away from a bite. The sauce has a sweetness to it, rather than sour like how most red sauces are. The sauce to bread ratio was perfect. There was plenty of sauce but it wasn't deep dish and stuck to the original thin crust style. The crust was thin and crispy although it might have been just a little over cooked since some parts of it was a burnt. Another plus was that it was not oily at all like most of the pizzas that I've had. I didn't feel oily or heavy after eating here nor did I feel overly thirsty from excessive saltiness. OVERVIEW: I would definitely come here again! The red sauce is to die for!Instagram @bowtiebowie for more food adventures! I've never been a huge fan of pizza, but this joint got me going crazy! Of course, when you think of New York, you gotta think of pizza; so I had to find a good pizza joint and I chose this place based on yelp. The inside is like a maze, we walked through so many rooms just to get to our table. Our server was friendly and he worked pretty fast. ORIGINAL MARGHERITA- fresh mozzarella, tomato sauce, topped with grated romano and basil (toppings: beef meatball, coal oven sweet roasted peppers, and breaded eggplant)I absolutely love the eggplant. They were perfect and had such a meaty texture, which complemented the texture of the pizza. It was a thin crusted pizza that tasted very fresh, with hints of sweet and savory notes from the cheese and tomato sauce. The meatballs were very flavorful and went well with the sweet peppers. I can't wait to go back to NY for pizza. Never had I ever had such a flavorful pizza before. Definitely need to come back for more! As a pizza addict I HAD to go to the first pizza joint in the US (est. in 1905). Being a popular place it was packed, as to be expected, but they seated us quickly. Once there, they really nickle and dime us over everything. $8 for a cheap house wine, $10 for a pitcher of soda, $4 - $6 per topping, etc.We ordered a 12" half and half. Half white and half margarita with pepperoni (which they charged the full extra for even though it was only on half). The pizza took a bit come out which is completely understandable as it is oven baked fresh, but we didn't see our waiter while we waited. Even upon sitting down it took a full 7-10 min before he greeted us. The pizza itself was two experiences. The white pizza was a let down. There was almost no ricotta cheese on it. It didnt have any extra herbs or seasoning. It was just basically a mozzarella pizza. The perfect example of why my husband is so cautious when getting a white pizza. The margarita though was a WHOLE other experiance. The fresh herbs were there, the sauce was tangy, the cheese was gooey and bubbly. The pepperoni was spicy and salty which complimented the tangy sauce and gooey cheese.  It was exactly what you expect in an excellent pizza. The crust was perfect, a really traditional New York style.Again, it was another cash only joint so no points or cash back for us :-( Honestly now that I have experienced it I don't need to go back to dine in, but we would order out for sure!!! Came on a Sunday night with a group of 3 and was surprisingly seated immediately. The clam pizza is the highlight of the meal. Only comes in large size which is 8 pieces. Also ordered the margherita pizza in a small which is 6 pieces. Clam pizza has no shortage of clams. make sure to add the lemon on top, which really brings out the flavor of the clams. The margherita pizza was good, but not amazing. We were seated downstairs so service was a bit slower because there weren't servers or waiters down here very often. However, they did have pitchers of water so that was a huge plus. The highlight of the meal was definitely the clam pizza! Try it! It can be a 5 or a 3 depending on the time of day. A must for any pizza addict even if just to say you've been and now you can compare it to other great pizzas. When you go, and when you do not go is the most important thing to know about this place. The quality of your pizza hinges on what time of day you order it entirely.STAY AWAY WHEN ITS SUPER BUSY - THAT'S A 3 STAR PIZZA.Can't stress this enough. Save yourself a long wait by avoiding the lunch and dinner rush, or if you must, get there early enough that you are one of the first people seated. This is a true coal oven pizza, and the thing I've learned is coal ovens have longer waits due to the need to allow enough time for the coals to reheat before you put another pizza over the same spot. Though it has a much more touristy convenient location, this place has never had the lines as long as I saw at Grimaldi's back when it was family owned. This has been attributed to them not allowing the coals enough time to reheat. Doing this may allow for more rapid seating, but it leads to a mediocre, unevenly cooked pizza during the busier times. That is likely the cause of the many three star reviews posted. I've been here on those days.GO WHEN IT'S SLOW - IT CAN BE 5 STAR GOOD!Perfect time to go here is mid afternoon like 3 PM, or a slow time well after dinner. Slow times are the key because I have had some of the best pizza I've ever eaten in my life here. THE PIZZACash only, No Slices. $22.50 for a large Margherita. It's a sauce heavy, thin Crust, Neapolitan pie. Very full tomato flavor, nothing watery.  Some days the crust is just right, some days it's not crispy enough for my liking, but when they are on it's one of the best. The cheese is spread out in little pools of fresh mozzarella. I could swear they used to put more cheese on these pies. Fresh basil is sprinkled a bit unevenly in small snippets throughout. You can tell just looking at this beauty that it's made with high quality ingredients. I've had the pepperoni toppings in the past and it's the good stuff that curls up into tiny little cups in the oven.THE HISTORY AND LOCATIONYes, this is the first of the Original Coal fired pizza places, but that does not make it the best. I love history, especially the history of NYC so I can appreciate going to this place just for it's importance in food and the city's history. However, it's worth noting that this is not the original location. They were closed ten years and have been here since 1994. Don't expect a time warp when you come see the place. Lots of pics of celeb's on the wall, but other than that it's a dressed down version any other red-checkered table cloth, quick service place in Little Italy. THE VERDICTA solid 5 at it's best, a let down of a 3 at it's worst. Go at a slow time and you'll have some great pizza, but don't make this your one pizza you must eat when you visit NYC. John's of Bleecker Street is much better, and so are Rubirosa and Prince St Pizza right around the corner. Come here for the history just as much for the pizza. At the right time of day it's worth a trip. 2.5 stars, I feel bad for giving it such a low rating but it really was disappointing and just "Meh."WAIT - came on a Saturday around 5pm and the wait for us 2 was 15-20 minutes. They give you a little buzzer but it really doesn't have a far range (only near the restaurant).  ATMOSPHERE: The inside seems small at first but when you walk further in, there is another section of tables.  For a larger group it's not impossible but I can see why the wait is long because there isn't a ton of seating and the pizza takes a bit of time to come out.FOOD: I got the small (6 slices) with a half and half of Margherita and white.  It came out in about 10-15 minutes and was hot, but not piping hot where I couldn't eat it.  What was disappointing was the fact that the crust was almost too dry and hard.  I guess it had that "coal oven" burnt taste/feel but it wasn't that good.  I prefer fluffy, chewy, slightly crusty crust.  I'm even OK with crust that is crispy like at Bleecker Street Pizza, but this was just not good. On top of that, the ingredients had little to no flavor.  Again, comparing it to Bleecker Street Pizza, the sauce had barely any taste and the white pie was even worse! The white pie had a slight cheese taste but it needed more garlic or something to give it flavor.  I would not pay or wait for this.Overall, not impressed with this pizza. This place is just OK.The first time I visited, I waited for a long time and became super hungry. And when you're super hungry, everything tastes good... even Pizza Hut. So needless to say, I left satisfied.However, after trying other pizzerias in NYC and coming back a second time, I now don't see anything special. Surely, not bad, but not extraordinary. Also, $20+ for a small Margarita Pizza with no toppings is expensive for what it's worth.Definitely worth trying since this is the first pizzeria, but there are now also plenty of other options. Very touristy, pricey, but fast service. This restaurant is very old school or simplistic. Cash only, the waiter writes down the orders on a piece of paper, and paper napkins. There is not much seating so naturally there was a line before the restaurant opened. Food: Margherita pizza- the crust was more burnt than I usually like. The mozzarella cheese was excellent but the toppings were overall nothing special. I would have liked more basil and cheese so I can't see the sauce underneath. Overall the pizza was fine but nothing I will crave in the future. When in New York, pizza is a must, right?! Lombardi seemed to pop up a lot, so obviously it was on my to-eat list. From the reviews I read on Yelp, it seemed like a half margherita half white pizza was going to be the thing to try. When they brought out the paper plates, I thought to myself, 'ok, this is just part of the experience- the pizza is going to blow me away anyways, and the plates won't matter'. The pizza came out on a raised pizza tray. First bite into the white pizza.....it was ok, maybe not my thing. Into the margherita....still not blown away. The pizza was extremely thin, with barely any toppings. Lets just say there's a bit too much hype for Lombardi's (IMO). For the price I paid that night, I could have gotten some street pizza and been even more happy! By far one of my favorite pizza places in NYC! The pizza dough is baked to perfection. The toppings are ample, cheese are a higher quality and tomatoes sauce is on point. I would highly recommend this place. All hype. There's only 4 kinda of pizzas on the menu, none include pepperoni. No refills on sodas or teas either (why??). The small 6 slice Margherita we got was over $21 then an additional $4 for pep. We got it after a really long wait and, sadly, it was nothing special. We tried about 10 different pizza places during our stay and this was one of the blandest, most unimpressive ones we had. Anyway it's cool to try I guess for the history behind the pizzeria but they lack flavor. The service was pretty good so 2 stars. Great pizza for the price. I love a short menu, to me that shows confidence that the place does a few things, but they do it really really well!We ordered a small half ricotta pizza and half Margarita (with added toppings).The ricotta overpowered and was very heavy and filling!I would personally recommend the the Margarita over the ricotta but it was a good experience. Be careful of the serving sizes! It was a bitter and rainy night in lower manhattan and I wanted pizza.  Although Prince Street Pizza was only down the street, I was up for something new and decided to walk the extra two or three blocks to see what the rave was about at Lombardi's. I have no regrets but it is slightly expensive. I got the calzone, and with a tip it was $19 to be filled which felt spend although the ricotta cheese inside was soft but not overwhelming. It was cool because in the calzone you can pick any two toppings (even two premiums, so I got the meatballs and bell peppers). They went well together especially since the meatballs had breadcrumbs you could taste.  Not your casual slice of pizza since it is slightly spendy but it is definitely a place to bring your friends from other states who think they have good pizza there. omg you guys! the clam pizza is no joke! best damn clam pizza i've ever had! the crust is super crispy and every mm of that pizza pie was covered and smothered with clams!!! i was visiting from cali and just had to have some NY pizza! so glad i did! it really lives up to the hype! i wish i could back the NY just to have another slice!

Tasty. Good service. Clean. All vegan without compromise. I got warm curry vegetables, delicious! Big pieces of potatoes, carrots and broccoli in curry sauce. Taste as in my childhood. Tea is real tea too. No bags, no imitations, just real green tea, light and refillable as much as you want. Will come back again. I'm giving two stars rather than 1 because one waitress was nice. The other was rude. She impatiently took my order and comes rushing over as soon as you finish your meal and comes to collect the check as soon as you sign as if to check how much tips you left...As for the food... everything was overly saturated with salt. It was barely edible and I ordered several dishes. I think the food might be ok if they held back on the saltiness. It's always great to have more vegan restaurants, but please use less salt. My lips were cracking and shriveling with each bite of food. Also it would be nice to receive better service since I'm paying for it. I didn't make any extra requests at all. I think it would be reasonable to treat customers with at least a neutral attitude. Great food. I've been coming here at least 2x a week when I worked in Soho. I'm not vegan but I absolutely love their Black Pepper Seitan.Not 5 stars because I find the servers a bit misinformative this one time. I called to ask for an order to be picked up as I usual do. However, it was on a Sunday and I wasn't aware that they open one hour later than usual. When I got to the place, my usual server told me that I have to wait till they open. Obviously, I got upset because that detail of my order could've been said over the phone. I wouldn't have minded waiting for them to open but now I'm on my lunch break and I wasted my time waiting for my food. Food is excellent, and for that alone I would give five stars. However, I ordered food via a delivery service, and the container was open, with sauce leaking all over the container. I was told that LuAnne's would not process a refund or issue credit unless they could come and pick up the food, which is unheard of considering it is a mistake on their part.Honorable restaurants would issue a refund along with the food. In fact, I have never heard otherwise. Sad that the yummiest vegan option is now not an option, but I will have to find other alternatives. Had the lunch special and it was very filling and tasty. Comes with vegan miso soup and a spring roll with possibly the best sweet sauce I've ever had. Cute little place and love that it's all vegan! Will be back. Vegan Chinese that makes you want to quit meat for good. Literally one of my fav spots for it in Manhattan . I made the mistake of eating there alone, don't do that haha. Get the take out and food gasm in private Hey, you!Are you a vegan?Are you a loner?Do you have a date?Are you a low-key type of person?Are you into the whole wood interior design?If you answered yes to one of those questions, then this is the place for you!This is actually a cute little spot. ( I don't know how crowded this places gets but) In front of the restaurant, there are a couple of seat if you're waiting.I had the lunch special (11:30 am - 4:00 pm) which varies from $8-$9 and comes with a spring roll, steamed pumpkin, and miso soup:Basil Ginger Soy ($9)- Zucchini Asparagus and Bell PeppersMiso soup was more of a seaweed soup but it was still good.One reason I have chosen this dish was because of the asparagus. I was debating between Basil Ginger and Mango soy in Garlic Plum Sauce since they both have asparagus. I had to ask the waitress which she would recommend, and she stated that the Garlic plum dish was more on the sweet side so I picked the other one.Now onto the whole "omg why did you not tell me this" Basil Ginger Soy dish. When the dish came, I was a bit confused because I swear on the menu I saw asparagus.. I know I have a horrible memory but I was 95% sure... this dish comes with asparagus. So I dug through the dish and then I asked the waitress. Surely enough, this dish was supposed to have asparagus! The waitress asked another colleague and that colleague spoke to me and had informed me that the asparagus was not in season and that the market price was high... I thought to myself: why did they not inform me when I ordered this dish... Call me crazy but I feel like they should had informed me.The zucchini was bland. Asparagus was missing. Bell peppers and the soy were delicious and marinated pretty well.The coconut white rice was flavorless as was the steamed pumpkin.. wished it had a little salt for a kick.The spring roll was great.Even though the asparagus was missing, I would like to proudly announce that I have finished my meal! A little bit of forcing but I did it! The meal was actually filling. When I had the last bite, I finally tasted the ginger.. crazy, huh? It's like bam, wild ginger appears!At least this place is better than Red Bamboo. Yay.... go.. vegan..I would recommend this place if you're in a small group. This restaurant is pretty small. Mainly tables for twos or fours.Note to self: Do not arrive early to a dinner/lunch appointment with a Vegan because he is always 15 mins late.P.S. Mimi Cheng's dumpling is right next door. (;07262017Review dedicated to Tarzan. Food: Yummy, forgettable Asian food at an Americanized price point. My favorite part of the experience was the extensive menu. I had vegan tempura yam and taro, spring rolls, and Yaki soba noodles. The tempura was good but bland. The spring rolls were delicious but average for veggie spring rolls, and the Yaki soba tasted like barbecue. Sadly, the taste did not live up to the Yelp reputation today.Ambiance: Oddly dark, hard to read the menus in the middle of the day. Small, but that's typical.Service: Very short staffed and slow. It took four minutes before we were asked what we'd like to drink. I felt bad for the sole server in the restaurant today.Overall, three stars. Not sure if I'd ever come back but I didn't hate the place. :) I love LuAnne's. The seaweed salad with a side of rice noodles was very tasty. I also saw the House Bibimbap at another table and would definitely come back to try that. They also serve hot tea in a cast iron pot, and I love that, so I got it twice, kukicha and genmaicha. What you need to know: - this is an Asian restaurant that specializes in vegetarian dishes - accepts credit cards- small restaurant that seats 26 people, not great for large groups - the price point is a tad more expensive than regular Asian restaurants, why do vegetarians have to pay more??? What we ordered: - Crispy soy appetizer $7 - highly recommended! Crispy exterior and the soy had a shredded chicken texture. - Sizzling soy cutlet platter $15 - wonderful savoriness from the black bean sauce. Loaded with vegetables such as broccoli, zucchini, peppers and asparagus and thick soy cutlets. - Malaysian style curry comfort stew $14 - a really disappointment, it wasn't comforting nor resembled Malaysian curries.  I know the menu said it was mild, but bland is a better adjective. Also, there was only one piece of kabocha pumpkin in this dish. Lunch specials here are not to be missed.I ordered the teriyaki seitan which came with brown rice, miso soup, egg roll and a bit of squash all for 9 dollars.  The meal was filling and satisfying!  I will definitely be back.  They have a cute little space for dine in as well-it's quiet and dim and a perfect escape from the loud, busy streets of Chinatown : ) I'll note at the outset that I've been burned by my fair share of vegetarian/vegan restaurants in this city, so much so that I've made it a point to avoid any places that brand themselves as specifically v/v. Either the portion sizes do not justify the high prices or the taste just isn't there. As someone who loves her homemade veggies, I fully understand the struggle in teasing out the brighter, stronger flavors, especially when you don't have the hardier flavor of meat to work with. Still. It's no excuse to eschew any and all salt. LuAnne's has made me a little more hopeful. Plus, I really appreciate how there's some seating that's friendly to situations when you're eating by yourself. Definitely get:1. The house bibimbap. It comes with a small cup of watery, thin pumpkin soup. There's a wealth of goodies in this bowl: avocado, chickpeas, mango, kimchee, and what I only later found out was seitan. I actually liked how light and healthy-ish this was, especially since there wasn't an overwhelming amount of rice in the dish (as a child of the clean plate club, I refuse to leave a grain of rice behind when I'm eating out, even when I know better). The best parts were the mango salsa, seaweed, and chickpeas. 2. Malaysian curry stew. Although it wasn't as thick or savory as I expected, I still ate everything (this is going to be an ongoing theme throughout this review). The soy protein actually paired quite well with the taste of the curry. Shout out for the generous chunks of protein. 3. Thai curry. Yes, I know. I could have ordered this at any other self-respecting Thai place. But I was intrigued by the ingredients: okra, cauliflower, Brussels sprouts, eggplant. Plus, the taste was not your average curry - it was a bit sweeter. 4. Watercress salad. This item was a little polarizing: my friend absolutely hated this dish and refused to eat anything more than the introductory bite but I loved it. I also love watercress, that gingery, tart green. They give you A LOT of watercress and not as much avocado or beets to help temper all the roughage. Definitely only order this if you like your greens and you like a lot of it. 5. Chocolate bundt with PB mousse and the banana walnut cashew ice cream. Don't be a fool and load up on the real food because you will miss out on the creamiest, thickest chocolate cake that I've had in a long time. Was it vegan? I couldn't tell and I didn't care. I was meh about:1. Black pepper seitan. The points for this dish actually go more towards the gai lian (Chinese broccoli) lurking under the seitan for being cooked perfectly crisp. I'm gonna be honest and say that seitan and tempeh and all other veggie products that are made up to taste like meat but is actually fake meat still squicks me out. The black pepper sauce helped to mask some of that weird not-meat-but-imitation-meat flavor. 2. Wild ginger macro bowl. I should have learned from my previous mistakes of ordering macro bowls but this was very bland. As it should be, because everything was either steamed or really cooked down. I ended up caving and asking for a boat-load of hot sauce and sesame-peanut sauce.Service was a bit spotty: forgetful with some orders, neglectful of water, but overall really friendly and ready with explanations and recommendations. I loved this quaint spot by Canal. The ambiance was fairly quiet, with some soft music playing in the background. Nice spot for a date. The menu had a variety of teas and other drinks. The food was delicious and fairly healthy. I recommend trying the crispy soy protein and scallion pancakes w/ the mango salsa. If you get there before 3pm, definitely get the lunch special, which comes with miso soup, a spring roll and steamed pumpkin. Wait staff was attentive and friendly. TL;DR: a lot of tasty options for vegans and vegetarians, but somewhat pricy. Nothing special that you wouldn't be able to get at a traditional Thai/Korean/Chinese eatery if you just subbed out meat for tofu.I came here with a friend for dinner and we wanted to try a little of everything, so we split a bunch of appetizers and a large noodle dish. There was no wait around 7pm on a Sunday and the restaurant was minimally packed, which was great because it's a tiny place that I could imagine gets VERY loud when it's full.I started with a miso soup, and we split the tofu skin wrap, spinach shu mai, fried dumplings, and Singapore mee fun. Miso soup: Rich, warm with tons of tofu and seaweed. A small portion but it was only $3.50Tofu skin wraps: Amazingly crunchy and came with a delicious sweet/sour dipping sauce. Filling had a weird pungent aftertaste, kind of like cooked bamboo.Spinach shu mai: Meh. Too heavy on spinach and tasted more leafy than I wanted. Could have added some sticky rice to balance out the spinach.Fried dumplings: WOW THIS HAD THE MOST DELICIOUS MANGO DIPPING SAUCE!! The dumplings themselves were very average but my friend and I literally drank that sauce - it tasted like mango lassi.Singapore mee fun: curry powder + rice noodles = heaven. Peppers could have been cut a little thinner to complement the texture of the overall dish and the fake meat was a little funky, kinda like puffed tofu.Unfortunately, trying all small dishes meant we ended up paying $27 a person for tax and tip, which was a lot for what we got. I recommend sticking with one dish next time you come, which I would if I didn't have anywhere else I'd rather go for the evening. The food here is delicious and a must visit for vegetarians. I have only ever gone around lunch time, and the wait hasn't been long. They have a lunch special which is very reasonably priced. I was just reminded I didn't write my review by the wonderful Albert K who had some similar feelings about a vegan restaurant. First off I am an Omnivore teetering more towards the Carniwhore deep in my soul! Soooo this place was a true revelation for me. I've always wanted to try a "REAL VEGAN" restaurant & felt like Long Island just doesn't offer any good choices. So when my friend Applebomb took me to NYC I knew immediately what I wanted to try first. Applebomb is vegetarian, she loves cheese but not much else. But this place?! Whoa! This place put tastes in my mouth that I didn't think could be accomplished without some good meat. But they did!We started with drinks. I got the Lychee Mojito, a little sweet so I asked for some lime & all was good. Very refreshing. Bomb got the BBQ Satay Tempeh. It looked good but I didn't like it at all. But Bomb liked it. Frontseat passed, she had pumpkin soup instead. I ordered the BBQ Seitan Skewers, nothing short of amazing! Really! If I didn't know it was a vegan product I would've sworn I was eating some new meat protein deliciousness. I almost ordered another plate. Then we ordered the Crispy Soy. Sounds simple right? It was, except your mouth was confused. Are you SURE this isn't the best chicken nuggets on steroids I've ever had?! And those sauces! The sauces just kicked everything up another 3 levels! Bomb & Frontseat were full! But I wasn't done! Bring on those Curry Samosas please! Mint Chutney? Yes please! Yeah Bomb helped me finish these off. A wonderful ending to an amazing Vegan meal. I can't wait to go back! And I'm not joking! It was that good! Do it!11-19-2016 It was a warm but pleasant East Village night and the urge to explore this fabled town was eating away at me, and so was ny appetite after a long flight from The City by the Bay...Okay, these were the reviews I used to write in a different universe back when I hobnobbed with Yelp Eliter Starla D. But enough already..Seriously, if my first meal is any indication of how incredible the food at this place is, then I will be back at least once more before my work trip is over.I had the Vegan Bibimbap(Sp?) and it was simply delicious! I then followed it up with the Vegan Coconut Cheesecake wich was just as yummy. I could swear it also had pistacho in it.My next dish will be the black pepper vegan protein dish!Stay tuned!... Loved this spot! Ran in on a Thursday around noon and got a table right away! Super quick service and delicious food! I got the pumpkin curry and It was perfect for a late November chilly day. Pretty quiet, I was able to read and escape the New York streets. Great lunch plant-based spot:) I checked out LuAnne's for a lunch on a weekday. Their lunch specials are great, I tried the citrus seitan over kale and was really impressed. It also came with a miso soup and spring roll which were very good. The hot and sour soup (which I ordered separately) was . Everything was very flavorful and the staff were very friendly. Wow! Wonderful tastes from unknown land, very decent dishes, and crazy variety - we could eat there for few days in a row and never get enough of it. The service is great, and the place is warm and cozy. Who said that Vegan have nothing to eat?! Great experience to bring non vegans and change their mind and perspective.

Macaron Parlour is your almond biscuit heaven meets a team of amazing staff in Lower East Side. Simon is the lovely co-owner of this shop, with his wife. Everything is made out of love and respect for the community. Forget your faux macaron from Starbucks. This is the real deal. There are so many wonderful flavors here that will satisfy your adventurous side of life. From tiramisu to cheetos (yes), this will make great gifts for the holiday season! I'm so intrigued with the earl grey, passion fruit, and matcha macarons. The earl grey is welcoming with the bergamot flavor, which melts down to a chocolate-ty smoothness. The passion fruit is the perfect bite of tanginess and juiciness. At last, the matcha is a creamy crunch of your latest obsession with green tea. Really. I also love that the Macaron Parlour is present at the holiday markets all over NYC this year. I'm talking about Union Square, Times Square, Columbus Circle, etc. You're not going to miss out wherever you are. It will follow you. And you will die of joy.This store is also affiliated with Meow Parlour - which is owned by Simon's wife. It's super close to Macaron Parlour, just right across the street on Hester. If you love cats, do yourself a favor and meet some of the friendly cats there! Mmmm.. Fig macaron and peach iced tea.I passed by Macaron Parlour a few times and decided to check it out on a hot scorching day cause I couldn't walk anymore and needed to hydrate. So I got their peach iced tea and a few macarons. You can also ask them to make your tea more/less sweet, whatever floats your boat. Even though they have some interesting flavors like cheetos, I played it safe with earl grey, fig, and s'mores. The fig macaron really stood out for me, maybe cause I like figs? All in all it's a cute spot to cool off, chat up with your friends and get some sugar in your veins if you have a sweet tooth like me. I wouldn't recommend coming with big groups since there's minimal seating. I can definitely see myself popping my head back in again the next time I'm in the area. I love macarons! This shops sells many different flavors- unique ones such as candied bacon with maple cream cheese, and the cheeto flavored. Had to try both of them!!! They also sell cute cartoon character macarons such as tortoro, cookie monster, elmo, gudetama. Huge plus plus. There are a few seats in the back to enjoy your yummy treat. In addition to the candied bacon, and cheeto. I also got the fig, earl grey, raspberry chocolate, and the tiramisu. The macarons were chewy and baked to perfection. The unique flavored ones were interesting, probably won't get them next time. The candied bacon tasted like lays bbq chips, the cheeto one didn't taste like cheetos at all- sweet. I really liked the raspberry chocolate macaron and the fig. They were so full of flavor. I will definitely come here to try more flavors!! Lovely cafe and nice service. I appreciate all the colorful, cheerful decor which creates a happy and light/airy vibe. And super good blueberry ricotta muffins with refreshing strawberry basil lemonade. My friend gave this to me when she visited me @ work. I'm definitely buying the totoro design. Just too adorable to eat. Flavor and texture of the macaron was nice. I still want to try the cheetos flavor though! lol While visiting NYC, I knew I had to come here to grab some special macarons of my favorite character from My Neighbor Totoro. What drawn me into this shop was obviously for the cute cartoon macarons but I was really happy to see A LOT of different flavors including hot cheetos-wait what???? I walked out of this place with a box of 6 with no regrets. A big plus is that next door there is a cute cat cafe called Meow Parlour! Came for the character macaroons, but they didn't have the ones I wanted, so I bought a box of 6 instead. A few of them were hard and didn't taste fresh which I wasn't expecting. EnvironmentIt's a cute little shop on St Marks Place. When you first walk in through the door you see all the cute little macaroons. In the back, there is seating where you can order and chill. FoodIt's a very unique macaron store as they sell characters on their macarons. The only down side is that you should call ahead to find out if they have any. They are not always in stock. When my friend and I arrived on a Tuesday afternoon, the only character macarons they had left were Pusheen, and the emoji of the monkey hiding its eyes. We bought the 4 for $10 macaroons- Pusheen, tiramisu, cognac, and caramel. All were very flavorful and tasted as how they should. ServiceThe guy was helpful when we were ordering offering his opinion. I should've called ahead to see if they had unique macarons (Totoro, Cookie Monster, emojis) but I came to find out they had none I really wanted when I arrived...unfortunate but I still had to choose a few to try...because why not.I built the four pack for $10, with rosemary olive oil (amazingly well balanced), sweet corn (not very distinguished), lemon (sweet and tart), and earl grey tea (light and slightly spiced). Not bad for all but probably would call to see if they have the cuter macarons in store...because I think that it's what makes them more special than any other macaron place. The cafe area is quaint and good for even a small study session for students or those who just want to relax or enjoy some reading. Comfortable setting to enjoy a sweet or two! All you need to get is the Matcha macaron. I got four and none even came close to the goodness that was the Matcha one. I also got the Tiramisu, S'Mores and Apple Cider Caramel. There's so many to choose from, so don't get overwhelmed like I did! They're super chewy, if you're into that. I feel like a lot of them were just missing something, but if you do swing by here, again, the Matcha one is the best. I love this place so much. I used to visit the one on ST. Marks a lot and it made me a keeper to the company. The care bear macaron ice cream sandwich is one of the best things i've ever eaten - and I eat a lot! The workers are always courteous and great you with huge smiles. The decor is always clean and sharp, matching the really cute macaroons they make! I do wish that sometimes they would change up the consistencies of the creams in the macarons but overall 10/10 will always come back. Everyone has their own opinion on which place has the best macaron store in NYC, but from the list I found, which talked about top 10 or so specific macarons in NYC, instead of rating a store as a whole. In this list, a Fig Macaron from Macaron Parlour was among the top 10, so it got me curious. We got a box of 6 with our choices of yummy looking choices, of course including the Fig macaron. It is not some "fig-flavored" filling, but has actual figs in it. So, I was pretty excited how this infamous Fig Macaron would taste like. It came with Figs cooked in White Wine and Honey. That alone sounded great. As I cut it into half, I could see the juicy, shiny fig filling. It was very moist, flavorful, sweet, and decadent. I can see why this particular macaron was chosen as one of the top 10 in NYC.All the macarons we tried were quite good and tasty, I especially liked their S'mores, Earl Grey, and Red Velvet. I would like to try some more of their flavors. We also had Ice Cream Macaron Sandwiches, which I have actually never heard of before! We chose a colorful one called Care Bear Stare, made with Salted Caramel Ice Cream. The ice cream filling was quite massive, which was awesome. The macaron shell was a bit hard, making it a little difficult to eat it without squeezing out the ice cream to the side. The ice cream was really tasty, nice caramel flavor, very sweet. So glad that I stumbled upon this place while walking.  I spotted it from across the street and had to go in!  Lots of cool flavors and they have the special ones that they seem to rotate thru every so often.  I got a Totoro macaron (*squeeeeeee*) which was their Party Time flavor.  Definitely had a hint of salt which complimented the flavor nicely.  Also got the Apple Cider Caramel, Giggity, and S'mores.  Least favorite was probably the Apple Cider Caramel just because it didn't taste apply what so ever.  It didn't taste bad by any means, but didn't hold up to the name either.  The S'mores one was good for sure, but I would've loved to have some graham flavor to make it complete.  Giggity was my favorite with a great and not overpowering peanutty flavor.The girl working at the counter was really nice!  The only thing I disliked is that the macarons are "packaged" in a plastic bag to go.  Better eat them quickly after that or when they get softer in the middle, they sort of slide and then some of the filling gets on the others.  A box would've been nicer, but maybe you get one of those if you order a larger amount.Definitely coming back to try the other flavors!  One day when I'm feeling adventurous, I'll try their Cheeto flavored one O.o You never need an excuse to eat an extraordinary dessert. At.Any.Given.Time!We were walking around the East Village, and we passed by Macaron Parlour. Kathleen D bought assorted box of 6 macarons, which she seemed to enjoy. Personally, I haven't tried any, since I'm not a big fan of macarons, but can you please think of a more indulgent dessert?-Oleo ($2.25.) Moist and sinful brownie with cheesecake-like(I think yummm!) fantastic filling. (sigh)- Goodbit bar ($3.00)Chewy caramel & crunchy peanut butter- white chocolate square.Simply, a killer brownie! What's left to say?-Chocolatey Chocolate Chip Cookie ($2.25.)Nuff Said!- Peanut Butter Chocolate Cookie ($2.25.) This, dear yelpers, is the pinnacle of Cookies goodness.And when it comes to macarons, you have many choices. Cheetos macarons, carrot cake macarons, figs cooked in white wine and honey macarons? At the end of the day, you want some macarons that's going to meet your needs. P.S: if you obsessed with those macarons, and you want to make your very own at home, take the 3-3.5hour macaron class ($100) taught by one of Macaron Parlour's pastry staff.Four and Half Yelps. When you're on a frigid and smelly Greyhound bus coasting down the NJ Turnpike, you know what you need in your possession? A blanket and a surgical mask.You know what else? Macarons from Macaron Parlour. I can't say you'll really get too far with them unless you buy in bulk, but these light, inviting, delightfully indulgent puffs of sweetness will absolutely help ease your travel anxiety.I selected a box of six (for $15) in rapid motion after noticing this place next to Crif Dogs in the East Village. I actually don't remember all six flavors at this point. Red Velvet, Party Time, Strawberry, Raspberry, Dark Chocolate and...something. Nonetheless, they were INCREDIBLE.At one point I glanced over to see Sari A. looking totally confused on the bus. I had apparently consumed half the box before she could look twice! They're THAT good.The shop itself is adorable and even has booths with macaron-shaped (re: circles) pillow backs! They also have a bunch of pretty looking dessert items if you don't like macarons.Love, love, love this place. Will keep it in mind for future NYC trips! Found these guys in Greeley Park and bought an assortment of the most beautiful and delicious macaroons ever created.Super crispy outside and creamy good inside. Flavor assortment was amazing from carrot cake to red velvet to earl grey to s'mores to cheetos. Sold in a really nice dozen container. Great staff and friendly service. Lemon was a particular standout.Went back the next day for an ice cream macaron (red velvet with cheesecake ice cream) and while it was good, it wasn't amazing. Macaron was just as crispy, but ice cream was a bit hard and packed like it came from a factory. Probably not worth the $5 price and uncountable calories.This place is a definite stand out. Omg I had the red velvet and it was to die for. I got earl Grey, vanilla, tiramisu for my other flavors. 4 for $10 isn't bad. Some tasted creamier than others so there isn't consistency among the four I had The Macaroons were great and the staff was very friendly. My favorite had to be the candied bacon macaroon with red velvet coming in a close second. Some macaroons are crumbly while there are some that are chewy, it really depends on what you choose. So, you can use my tactic and just come in multiple times to till you've tried em all! Overall great experience, would come again. e First visit. I tried a variety of flavors and all were good but the smores and salted caramel stand out in my memory. Some macarons were fresher than others, the older ones were more chewy, but honestly I didnt mind because they tasted good. The best macarons are still Mille Fueille on the west side, with its delicately flavored light and airy yummy concoctions! I'd buy here again if I was in the neighborhood. Check my pics.Happy Yelping :) Really cute place on St. Marks. Unique flavors. They have baked goods other than macarons, and they have seating! Reviews for each of the macarons I bought in April 2016 (*Note: I bought them to take home. I put them in the fridge for two days before consuming them.):Matcha macaron: Good and visually appealing, but doesn't taste like matcha at all. The filling melted the fastest of the four that I purchased, and you could really taste the buttercream. Giggity: I like this one. The peanut flavor is really present. The chocolatey filling is nice. Sweet corn: I forgot what flavor this was since I didn't eat it immediately after. It just tasted sugary to me. After I realized it was the sweet corn, I guess I taste it? It's a very subtle corn flavor. This one remained hard the longest without melting (shell + cream). The filling was more of an icing consistency. Winnie the Pooh honey and cognac: This one is a limited time offer, and I took one of the last few for that day! It was around 5PM so be sure to get there during daytime if you want one of their special macarons. It cost more than the others. I believe it was 75 more. Brownie surprise chocolate chip cookie: I tried this because of Yelp reviews. It's quite good--very crunchy and reminded me of Tate's, but the brownie filling added a nice softness inside.

This place is kinda cramped. Minca sio ramen: 4/5 flavorful -- I did found myself finishing the soup. one thing I didn't like was the noodle, I felt like it was a little too chewy for me. I like mine a little al dente. The chashu was cooked perfectly -- not overcooked or undercooked. I kinda wish the egg was runny but it was hard boiled.  Plum wine: 3.5/5 I felt like the plum wine is a little too sweet for my taste. I like my plum wine slighly sweet and dry. I don't know if there were any server on the floor that day because I mean I did came in an awk time like around 4pm. But the cook or busser (I assumed) was pretty nice and friendly. so kudos to him! Would I come back again? Yes, if I am around the area. But I wouldn't travel all the way here since I do live so far from the restaurant. Get the Minca Sio ramen, it is so damn delicious! The salt & roast garlic flavor is to die for and they were able to make it saltier for me. The ramen comes with egg, seaweed, some vegetables on top. They replaced the chashu with brown tofu for me.The ramen price is slightly cheaper then Ippudo and similar ramen joints. The place itself was small and tight, making it harder to sit with my bulky winter coat on my lap. Cash only.I love it that they have pork, chicken and vegetarian broth to accomodate all dietary restrictions. You know you've been here too often when you order something slightly different from the usual and the waitress asks you if you're ok...The Shoyu Tokyo Tsukemen is by far my favorite thing on the menu. I am salivating just writing about it. Tsukemen refers to a method of eating ramen where the noodles are served separately from the toppings and broth. The broth is lesser in quantity than what you'd get with traditional ramen, but it is vastly more concentrated. When you dip the noodles, a thin coat is all that is needed for an explosion of flavor. On warmer days, I love to ask for the noodles cold; there is nothing better than the contrast of the cold, al-dente noodles and the warm, flavorful broth. If you have any leftover broth you'd like to drink after you've inhaled your noodles and toppings, you can always ask for additional stock to dilute the mixture. Multiple ramen-loving friends have recommended the spicy miso at Minca, so I caved in and finally stopped by. The place is cozy, to say the least. Tiny shop with the kitchen right in the middle. There's bar seating and a couple of tables, so expect a wait. Everything is pretty barebones and it's cash only.The spicy miso was good (especially on a winter night), but I didn't think it was extraordinary. There were two large chunks of pork (the charred bits were delicious, but part of it was cold). It came with all the extras that you might have to pay for at other places (menma, wood ear mushroom, corn, half egg). The broth was on the lighter side. The noodles weren't noteworthy at all. Mushy and kind of too eggy, if that's a thing.Portion sizes were really good though.It was a decent, no-frills meal. Probably wouldn't come back if there was a crazy wait though. Cash only!This is a cozy ramen-ya, so come early, otherwise there will be a wait.  This was highly recommended by a number of different reviewers and news articles about NYC's best ramen.  Since we love spicy food, we ordered the Spicy Miso Ramen and the Spicy Basic Ramen.  I've had many miso ramens before, but this is one of the most misoiest soup I've had.  Both soups are full of flavor and gelatinous (thick and rich) without being oily.  It is definitely the highlight, since most ramen soup bases are too oily and salty for me.  The chashui is seared with a blow-torch right before serving.  This creates a smoky flavor that melts in your mouth the minute it enters your month.  Definitely amazing.  We also ordered the homemade pork gyozas. It was perfectly pan fried, with brown, crispy bottoms.  The sauce was a good balance between salty and acid.This is truly one of the best ramen places in NYC. I ordered the Spicy Miso an OH WAS IT SO GOOD. You might think that miso soup is not as flavorful as traditional Tonkotsu, but Minca Ramen will prove you wrong. It packs a punch, with traditional miso, but also increases the intensity. The noodles are top class; no complaints there.Now to the best part. The meat. The meat essentially melts in your mouth. You take a bite, and you get hit with a plethora of taste not dissimilar to sex in your mouth. I think the meat, while different, is on par with Momofuku. I've also had the Spicy Tokyo tsukemen, but sadly, I don't have the pictures to commemorate my experience. Also really good, and one of the few places in New York that does good tsukemen.I got hungry while writing this review. Oops, time to go back soon. ***4.5 stars***My first time having Tsukemen Ramen and let me just say - I've been hunting for a good ramen spot that serves this in the Bay Area ever since my flight landed home. The presentation had me drooling and you get so much food! It's basically a deconstructed bowl of ramen and the way to eat it is to dip your ramen in the broth as you go. I loved the concept. You get to choose the thickness of your noodles - thin, thick, or wavy as well as which broth you'd like. I got their Salt and Garlic, while my boyfriend indulged in their Spicy Miso. Both were very good, but I will say not over the top amazing. We were served 2 slices of pork with corn, bamboo, shiitake mushrooms, green onions, and kimchi all on the side. Can you just imagine dipping your ramen into the decadent broth, biting a piece of your juicy tender pork, and slurping down that hot broth full of flavor?! It was heaven in a bowl. My boyfriend is a ramen fanatic and he ordered an extra full order of noodles because he just couldn't get enough! Keep in mind that this place is cash only and very small so during peak hours - expect a wait! We arrived at 10pm for a late night/second dinner and didn't have to wait at all. Service was excellent and our server was friendly and accommodating. Hot tea is served once you finish your meal. If you happen to not have cash on you, they have an ATM machine a couple doors down! Very good, hidden ramen spot in LES. My friend and I came for an early-ish dinner on a weekend night and were able to snag a table pretty easily! Staff was friendly and attentive, constantly refilling our waters and asking if we had questions.We ordered the pork gyoza as an appetizer. They weren't as crispy as they could have been, but were good nonetheless. As for ramen, my friend and I both got the pork broth - me the basic and her the Shoyu. I got the wavy noodles and she ordered the thick. Both were very good! I'm a bit of a ramen noob and always think it's too salty and heavy, so that's also a bit how I felt here. The noodles themselves were really good, though, and I like that all the dishes come with egg. My friend really enjoyed her bowl, and said it was comparable to Ippudo, her favorite! So points for that.Prices were very reasonable though it's cash only. The store itself is small and there is quick table turnover though it's probably easier if you have a smaller party! Will be back. I had high expectations for Minca after reading several good reviews on yelp and I have to say I'm not disappointed at all. We had a pretty good experience.We went on a Saturday afternoon around 1 pm. It was pretty busy but we got seated right away. There are only few chairs so you will have to wait to get seated if it's busy. We ordered miso chicken noodles and the spicy chicken. It's not the best ramen I've ever had but it was pretty good. Our server was friendly and knowledgeable. Overall a decent experience! Cash only & limited seating!I decided to come here for dinner on a Saturday night and luckily there was no wait for a party of two. I've been into ramen lately and it has become a mission of mine to find my favorite ramen place in the city. So far I've only tried a few places but Minca has made it close to the top. The broth here was so flavorful and I loved that they placed spices and sesame oil on the tables for you to add to your ramen as you wish. The waitress saw that we were putting the chili seasoning into our broth and asked if we wanted the house made hot sauce. She brought over some and it was just what we needed! The only drawback is that I wished the egg was soft boiled instead of hard boiled and the charshu was not melt in your mouth like other places. Even though $12 for some delicious ramen here is totally worth it, the search continues! Since it was my first time in New York City, I wanted to try ramen. This place was recommended by a friend of mine (wasn't with me at the time). Fortunately, this place was open on Christmas Day. It had about 20 minute waiting time which felt like forever since I was so hungry and cold...Service was pretty quick, I ordered the pork broth signature Minca Sio...The broth was amazing! and the noodles were even better! The pieces of pork in the soup were cooked to perfection and were full of flavour. Definitely recommend this place... Solid 3.5 ramen place, but didn't blow my mind. I got their classic flavor which was $12. Cash only!! The noodles were a nice texture and I overall enjoyed my meal. The one massive bummer was that the egg was not semi cooked gooeyness I've become accustomed to. I hope they change that in the future. Probably one of my favorite ramen spot I like to go to other than your typical Ippudo or Ichiran, if you haven't try it yet then you're missing out! Minca is this very small and cozy traditional ramen joint located in the middle of nowhere (no seriously, it's so freaking hard to get to!) and you'll have to either get there early for dinner or else you'll have to wait in line as they don't take reservations. At first, their menu may look a bit complicated but hey I always like to refer to the pictures on Yelp and see which one looks good. Most of the options are pretty good, I especially like to get the Basic Ramen with wavy noodles and then add whatever extra you feel like that night. Portion wise is pretty decent, you can also add extra noodles too if you're feeling like you need that "extraness". The broth is usually very flavorful, none of that water down shit around here. And last the price is somewhat reasonable, of course depending on what you get. Average ramen cost about $12 - $15 w/o anything extra, not like the outrageous Ichiran which can cost you about $18... On my check-list of things to do in NYC was ramen.  Minca lived up to all my expectations.  Hidden/hole in the wall?  Check.  New flavors that I hadn't heard of?  Check.  Approval from my sister's fiance who lived in Japan?  Check.Well worth eating here as we had no wait, the food was authentic, and appropriately priced.(Cash only though!) I've been to my fair share of ramen places in NY and I always return back to Minca. Definitely a no-frills kinda place, which I think adds to the authenticity. The price is right and their flavors are just right for me-not too overwhelming but not bland either. Personally I don't like ramen places that have super rich broths or noodles that aren't the right consistency, and Minca hits the sweet spot for me. It's a small place, cozy and no where near as fancy as Ippudo or Ramen Lab and best of all there's usually no wait, very little if any. It reflects the East Village neighborhood it's in-it's got a little grit but makes its spot its own. Kambi Ramen on 14th street is their sister restaurant but somehow their recipe and preparation is not on par with Minca, so I always defer to the original. My go-to is the Minca-Sio with wavy noodles with a side of gyoza. Pair it with Sapporo, and you've got yourself a solid meal. The ramen here is amazing. You wouldn't expect much from this place based on the exterior and interior, but I was blown away by how good the food was. I got the spicy miso ramen which I highly recommend. It was also a huge bowl so I was able to save half for lunch the next day. Note that it is cash only. Big fan. Best ramen in the city that doesn't require a 3 hour wait. Its small, so you aren't likely to get in right away, but its not bad and well worth it. I wouldn't suggest going with a group of more than 4 ppl. There's no tables larger than 4 and hard to push tables together. I highly recommend the minca sio ramen for those looking to break away from the standard spicy miso or pork miso. Their pork is divine and unlike most ramen spots their chicken is dark meat, huuuuuuge veteran move. Doesn't get all dry like breast does. Biggest think to know...cash only, so stop at the atm first. Probably the most underrated ramen spot in the LES. In my humble opinion this spot tops IPPUDO! Don't fall for their hype and come here!Humble service, this place is cramped. Don't come here with a party larger than 4 because they won't be able to accommodate. Keep this ish intimate folks! Bar seating is the best in the house!Now on to the food!Shrimp Gyoza: great whole shrimp with tail on; remember to cut the tail off before eating! Sweet shrimp with crispy light gyoza wrapping makes this a great appetizer for those whom don't eat pork! Dunk this in their soy vinegar gyoza sauce and it's a morsel made by the gyoza gods!Pork Gyoza: pork with scallion wrapped in their light crispy gyoza wrapping, nothing to complain about here! Just get it and do yourself a favor from drooling while waiting for your ramen to be served up!Spicy Basic Ramen: holy hell! The fiery red color of this ramen should give you a fair warning that this will be spicy! Some chili flakes did go down the wrong pipe and induced an unforgiving cough! Only order if you can handle the heat without coughing your way to the bottom of the bowl! Spice but that doesn't mean the heat over powers here. You can still taste the heavy pork based soup here. Wavy noodles soak up the broth well! I topped this ramen off with extra egg because hey who can't have enough egg here?Chicken Sio Ramen: I was utterly surprised by how this wasn't a bland disappointment! The chicken broth balanced well with the salt garlic finish. This is a lighter affair than any pork based soup and if you can't deal with heavy this is awesome! I personally loved the broth and probably could down the whole bowl, but sadly this wasn't my order.In conclusion: COME HERE FOR NO FRILLS RAMEN THAT MAKES YOU JUST WANT TO CUDDLE AFTERWARDS! Let the ramen shoyu the way. Tokyo date to this spot and let them experience some of the most savory, full-bodied broth you'll ever get. THe pork is melt-in-your mouth tender. The noodles are on the bouncy to slight crunch side. Miso hungry for this right now. Pretty standard ramen. I got the spicy miso and the broth wasn't at hearty and salty enough which is pretty rare for me but it was still pretty good. I liked how cheap their toppings are (extra noodles are only .50!) And their shrimp gyoza is definitely something you need to try if you're there. I probably won't be back just because the place is cash only and the ramen isn't really out of this world, but the food did come out quickly and the staff is super nice.

I am a huge fan of okra/lady fingers and they hit the spot with this one - their food is traditional and filled with flavors. If you like your chicken with no salt this place isn't for you Eating a cold piece of chicken is usually a reason not to come back to a restaurant, but at Nyonya it's all the rave! A malaysian restaurant situated between little Italy and China town that serves "Hainanese Chicken" (google it) one of the most delicious foods in the world (on the CNN list as one of the world's 50 most delicious foods). Although the menu is almost as big as the Bible, don't get distracted, the dish to get here is the "Hainanese Chicken". It looks simple and uninviting - steamed chicken on the bone with sauce on the side - but that is only until you try it. It is so tender and finger licking good that I had to convince my next table neighbors to order it as well. My only complaint: they should provide more napkins on each table when giving us such a hard task to eat chicken with chopsticks! (I proudly used my fingers). Usually love coming here for the hainanese chicken, squid tentacles & seafood scrambled egg chow fun. Those are usually are my go to items. Went in about two days ago and ordered the Curry Mee with young tau noodle soup and didn't taste as fresh as it usually does when I come here. Hopefully the next time it will be better lol. Really good Malaysian food here in Chinatown. It's always packed which is a good thing, and it's actually rather spacious so can accommodate all the Malaysian food lovers. Came here on a Tuesday night and had roughly a 20 minute wait (it was faster because we agreed to share a table with other people). Let me start with this: the menu is extensive. I could barely process page after page of food that looked delicious. We asked the waitress what was popular and kind of just went with that. Started with the roti. Delicious, some crispy and some soft, not overcooked. Plenty of curry with potato and meat in the curry as well. This was devoured very quickly. Next came the Malaysian spareribs, deep fried then glazed with a special sauce that was really good with a slight kick to it. My mom is big on vegetables, so we ordered the popular king king veggies. This was quite good, a bit salty but the flavor was unique. Had some spice to it as well but again not too spicy. Our last dish was a tofu dish, mixed with veggies and baby shrimp. This was probably the best, the sauce was great with a hint of soy and oyster sauce, and other flavors I can't quite describe. Overall the waitstaff were busy but still paid decent attention to everyone. Love the food and the place! The food is really good. I came here last night with a party of 9. We ordered 7 dishes and 4 appetizers which we thought would be too much food. However to our surprise, the dishes are all quite small. I think the food is excellent and the price per dish is reasonable. However when you look at the plates you get, its actually not a lot of food. So the price is very reasonable, but you don't get a lot of food in return. So I guess that means its overpriced for what you get in return. Get the house special squid and the half chicken. Cash only. $22 each between 9 guys. Not bad. If you're adventurous with Asian food, this one is for you. Don't expect to order your nasty teriyaki chicken or orange chicken. Nyonya gets the food right. Ordered the following: Nyonya House Special Squid: spicy squidChow Keuh Teow: noodles with shrimp. Not spicy at all. Nyonya Poh Piah: tofu and bean sprouts egg roll. Simple as that. Squid and eggplant: somewhat spicy with a hint of fish sauce.  I would've given a 3 star rating but we had to ask THREE TOMES for a clean tea cup. And hunt them down for water. Would I come back? Sure. But I have low expectation on service. BTW, cash only. CASH ONLYCame around 1 for lunch on a Saturday and the tables were just about filling up, but luckily we didn't have to wait!Price: 5/5! Opened the menu to be greeted by a lunch menu that starts at $7.99 for weekdays only, so I couldn't take advantage of it. However, most soups and rice dishes start around $8 so I was very pleased, especially since I work around Midtown.Food: 5/5! I had this place bookmarked! I ordered the number 1 rice plate and it was DELICIOUS. The rice is well seasoned and goes perfectly with the chicken and the sardines, which were fried to something like chips. My friend ordered the curry noodle soup and though it was vegetarian, it was delicious. The flavors of both dishes are deep and blend extremely well.Would return in a heart beat to try the other dishes! Reasonably-priced Asian fusion food in Chinatown. Really good tea and yellow rice. The aesthetic of the restaurant is pretty nice. There's a large mix of business people as well as casual people like students. Went on a Saturday night with my sister. When you walk in, if there is a wait, go to the hostess and get a number from them, I have attached a picture of mine so you will know what it looks like. When we first got our number, the hostess had called 41. I expected this to take awhile to get to our number but after about 20 minutes of waiting, we got our table. Not our own table because we were only two people, but we shared a table with two other groups of two. The food we got was:Roti prata: It was basically a big balloon of bread that had a curry soup thing to dip the bread. I like to use bread as a utensil so I enjoyed this. I did see other people using the chopsticks to grab the bread and dip but if you use your hands, you feel like a kid again!Fried dumplings: Were OKAY dumplings. Not the greatest chicken fried dumplings I have ever had but did hit the spot for something I was craving.Beef chow fun: As the picture shows, they were oily and wonderful to eat! The bean sprouts provided that subtle crunch that went with the fat noodles and beef. The marinade for it was to die for because you wanted to dip other things in it. It was clearly not the healthiest food item for you, but man was it good.I will say one thing that was frustrating was how the food at our table which we shared with two other groups was brought out. After about 5 minutes of putting in our order, a Roti Prata got brought out and just put in front of my sister and I, so we proceed to start eating it when in reality it was the pair to our left's. We felt very bad for about 2 minutes because the prata that was actually ours (which they took instead) came out just after ours. I hope they make these things more clear in the future when the people in the table do not speak to each other.Overall: dope place that was not overly priced and had good malaysian food. Just need to clean up the service. Large restaurant with plenty of seating. The downside is that with all the tables, it can be hard to flag a waiter down to place an order. The food also comes out as it's ready and not in courses. Remember it's cash only!Food wise - the roti canai and roti telur are both delicious. The roti is much thinner than you get at other restaurants. Chicken satay was super juicy and moist. For the entrees, the star was the spicy crab #16. It was just slathered in spices and dark brown caramelized onions. It can be tricky to eat but so worth it. Other dish we liked was the fried rice. I would say the masak lemak and sizzling noodles were quite blah. But I would 100% return for the crab and the sweet and salty peanut pancake dessert. Cash only. Good for the adventurous foodie. Having just been to Malaysia, I can confidently state this this food isn't that authentic, but that's not a huge issue with me. Food is just disappointing, but maybe we ordered the wrong things. Spicy squid tentacles - disgustingly fried. Not even one star. Stay away. Seaweed salad - the minor amount of seaweed and mango are good, but the rest of it is just lettuce and tomatoes. Meh nothing special. Hainanese Chicken - I really wanted to like this, but I just didn't. It's cold, which is just weird, but the big issue is that it's mainly skin and bone.
