The onion soy sauce it comes with, though, is delicious, but it's all on the skin, and most people don't want to eat the skin, so you pull it off, and with it, you pull off the soy sauce, so you kinda have to scrape it up and dip the naked chicken into it, but it's a huge mess and you lose a lot of the sauce, and you're left with cold wet chicken. It's gross. Kang Kung Belacan - sauteed veggie with shrimp paste; this was awesome. Make sure to get this. Couldn't get enough. Kind of a disappointing experience, but I'd give it another try if I'm in the area. Nyonya is my favorite place for Malaysian cuisine! Food is always solid. I've been to the ones in Brooklyn but I think that the one in Chinatown is the best. The menu seems to be more extensive as well. I almost always get the same three dishes when I come here: Roti Canai, Hainanese Chicken and Fried Pearl Noodles. They are all really good :) The curry to dip the Roti Canai is always spot on, I would suggest eating this before it gets cold. However, some parts of the "pancake" are a little too thin and flaky. Get the Hainanese Chicken with the chicken broth rice. It's sooo delicious, you won't regret it! The fried pearl noodles aren't too oily or bland and not too chewy just the way I like it. Will forever come to Nyonya if I ever need a Malaysian fix! Taking one star off because it's cash only and wait is pretty long during dinner time. Went in the day before NYE with a friend, looking for laksa. Yelp says it is a Malaysian Chinese fusion place and somehow has laksa. The restaurant was busy and we waited for about 10-15min to get seated. Menu has all kinds of Asian food. We ordered laksa, shrimp noodle and stir fry watercress with soy bean sauce. The server gave me a weird response when I said I wanted laksa and he asked again to double confirm...later I know why don't order the laksa here. Super salty, fishy with unappetizing ingredients (cat fish and pineapple.. seriously?)My friends noodle is also super salty. The only good thing is the stir fry watercress... I really enjoy their food, just really salty haha.We were able to sit there after everyone got there (party of 6) . It was a Wednesday night and super busy. We ordered but everyone got their food at different times and they bought the plates one by one rather all at once. They always made sure we had tea! Haha The roti canai, hainanese chicken with rice are my go-to meal. I share that with friend. I feel pretty stuffed after ! The flavor is good, chicken is tender, and sauce is so good I pour it over my rice.Their ice thai tea is good but too much ice not worth. My meal came out to be 14.5$ which is not bad shared. It's alway seems busy so expect a 20-30 min wait total to sit and get food, or longer. Interior is chilly they keep the AC on! It's on grand street so easy to get to dessert places afterward. We ordered three dishes - homemade Roti Canai, Beef Rendang and Kang Kung Belacan. I must say the beef was really good. If you don't mind shrimp sauce, Belacan is a good choice as well. The service was fast. Overall a great lunch. They are so willing to accommodate no meat/fish dairy/egg - you just have to ASK! All in all everything still tasted great and satisfying even though the meal was vegetarian/vegan. Some of the standouts were the roti, vegetable clay pot with coconut rice, Chinese watercress and sauted rice cake! Not too crazy about the vegetarian duck as it was extremely oily. Prices here are great and the meal comes with tea. It's been years since I last visited this place because I found out there is another branch of Nyonya in Brooklyn which was closer to me.I was craving for a Malaysian food (Nasi Lemak to be specific) and all I can think of is Nyonya. Honestly, I prefer this branch since the server are nicer and the food prep is pleasing to my eyes and palate. I also like how they presented the images of the dishes on their menu. Food porn! There is another malaysian place near my work but it is nothing compared to Nyonya's.Soon, my appetite for Malaysian food will surely be back again and I will have the Nasi Lemak of Nyonya as the benchmark. On my future visit(s), I will try out their noodle soup, looks delicious.Selamat Makan! Nyonya is an established Malaysian restaurant that has been around for years.  When I think of Malaysian, Nyonya is the first to come to mind.  The Roti Canai  is a must.  The homemade roti is thin and crispy and the chicken curry dipping sauce is delicious.  You'll want your own so don't bother thinking if you should share it.  I also recommend the classic stir fried noodle dish, Chow Kueh Teow. It's a flavorful, slightly spicy seafood dish with shrimp and squid. Portions are large even for lunch.  They also have a wide array of fun Asian drinks.  I opted for the frosty coconut milk with red bean.  It was yummy and perfect for a hot summer day.  I was with a table of 5 during a weekday lunch and the service was a bit slow.  I say we waited about 20 long mins for our food to arrive.  So beware if you're in a hurry.  Overall, an inexpensive and fulfilling option for lunch. Malaysian Chinese restaurant in the Manhattan Chinatown area. Had a good crowd waiting during Saturday night, but my friend and I got lucky and only had to wait a few minutes for a small table. Insides were packed... just like what'd you expect from Chinatown. We ordered a few Malaysian specialties. For appetizers, we got the Roti Canai (kind of like a naan, but puffed up and comes with chicken curry for dipping) and the Poh Piah (Malaysian spring roll), and both were pretty good. For main dishes, we had the Asam Laksa (noodle soup) which had a slightly sour flavor that opens up the appetite; the Hokkien Char Mee (stir fried noodles) which was very flavorful, and it tasted quite close to some Chinese chow mein that I had before; and lastly, Nasi Lemak, which should have had a bit more coconut flavor on the rice. Overall, the food was pretty good. My friend who is Malaysian said it was the best Malaysian food he had in the US. The two appetizers plus three main dishes came to $45 including tips, which was not very expensive at all. Last note is that the place is cash only, so be sure to have a few bills in your wallet before going. Asian food when visiting New York?!  Hell yeah!  NYC has a strong community of Chinese with many chinatown neighborhoods throughout its five boroughs.When I get asked what was my favorite meal on my vacation to NYC, I respond with Malaysian food at Nyonya!  Satisfying meal without paying top dollar.Our group shared family style and were able to delight on a handful of Malaysian offerings.  -  -  The fried rice had a little heat on it--very subtle.  -  Noodles were thin but with chili flavoring similiar to pad thai.  -  Their Roti Canai bread was paper thin and came with peanut sauce--this was the only dish I didn't really care for.  I like more substance in my roti.  -  The beef Rendang dish was tender and complemented well by the sauce.  -  Mango shrimp--winners!-  Their signature Hainan chicken dish--cold chicken with a sweet soy sauce--delivered on taste as well!  -  Their green veggies (think watercress but not sure)--wow!For the Hawaii folk, think of Nyonya as Dagon with a tinge of heat.When in New York, eat Malaysian!

If you want your arm clamped by a random bouncer walking in, come on in. I'm very youthful and was joining a friend who walked in for a shot. Showed my official California ID, didn't but it, showed my official NYC ID, barely bought it after loads of verbal harassment. Use their restroom for 2 min, friend ended up leaving, bouncer confronts me when I try to leave: "This isn't a public restroom etc. etc." last time I checked your job is to check IDs and keep it peaceful. My friend bought a shot, so what's the dealeo? I didn't spark nothing. *EDIT 10/27/17: Rachel is the best bartender and person I've met in a while. All relations mended. Come by to Old Man Hustle! Dropped in for happy hour after a disappointing experience at the Hester Street Beer and Lobster fest and the experience totally made my day. Super chill, divey kind of atmosphere, and the bartender was bro-ing out with us and cracking jokes. Note: don't be me and try to order an old fashioned and then a whiskey sour (don't judge me), because it's a super casual and relaxed place, and they don't have bitters or fresh sours. The bartender took pity on me and made up a fresh batch of sour mix (you go, man!) and we did a few rounds of shots and pours for the hell of it. Happy hour is long and cheap for beers and shots, and I'd definitely come back. I came here a while ago for comedy night. They host comedy nights on Wednesdays. The place is very small and can probably only fit about 15 people max. There is a little stage at the end where comedians can go perform. The vibe is very laid back and everyone seems pretty friendly. When we came, we felt like we were the only "outsiders" since everyone else seemed to know each other. Even though we were new, they made us feel welcome and directed all their jokes at us (even made us the butt of these jokes at times, all in good fun). The drinks are pretty reasonable priced too. This is a great divey kind of bar that's pretty nice to go to and you wanted somewhere to go chill. I don't usually go out to bars like this but I would definitely not mind revisiting a place like this if I ever found myself in need of a drink and a nice spot to relax at. The no cover comedy shows on Wednesday can also be a nice way to pass some time if you happen to be bored also. So come here on the 29th of December with my cousin and a friend from Miami and had a great time. Super random night and that up here because I looked for a local bars around the area and this one looked like a cool dive place. the bartender as soon as we walked in was open and nice and try to start a conversation with us that's the bar is extremely small and looks like a local community cool bar. Forgot her name but she's the one with glasses and also does stand up. If she's reading this I am the guy that tried to buy the fish and brought you a donut and a Dunkin Donuts bag. I had a couple drinks got a shot use the bathroom and stay until she did stand up comedy at 8 p.m. The question is was so well worth it? And the answer is hell to the year had a very personal good experience and will definitely come back to check this place out hopefully with the same staff. Loved this bar.The bartenders here are very friendly and cool, happy hour is long and plentiful and they even do comedy shows at 8pm every night (which  I plan on coming back for).This is honestly one of those places that I absolutely loved but can't put my finger on why-I just felt great there and had a great time! Cozy dive bar with great happy hour specials until 7 :) Rachel (bartender and comedian) chatted with us and made us feel at home. They have a free comedy show @ 8 each night, would definitely come back for that when we have time! Thanks! It's a little bar with a lot of heart, and I mean tiny. I've only ever been in for their Sunday night comedy open mics, a mix bag of up and coming performers who in my experience aren't afraid to go dark, blue, or politically incorrect. For such a small space they have a great beer selection (no taps, just bottles), and also make some great cocktails. You can count on good conversation with down to earth strangers here. Bathroom door can be a little tricky, the lock sticks. Best bar in NYC! Liquor beer and comedy! Everyday there is comedy at 8pm. Happy hour till 7pm and good vibes till 2am! Come if you like to drink and laugh. (:Always funny and cool bartenders behind the bar too!! I walked into this place thinking it was going to be a regular dive bar, but it is way more than that.  I ordered a whiskey sour which was great.  There was only about 15 people inside since it's a small place, but everyone was having a good time.  Apparently, it was open mic night for stand up comedy routines and after about 20 minuets the bartender got up on the tiny stage and started cracking some hilarious jokes to prepare for the routines.  I did not expect this at all.  She was engaging and really commanded the audience to get them ready. One by one, people got up on stage from the bar area and did their routines.  Some where hilarious and some were ok, but all were funny in one way or another.  What I love about this place is that no one judges you or the comics in any negative way.  They are very respectable and honest in their reactions and understand that each routine is very improv inspired so anything can happen.  Each comic is given their time to perform.  Since there's not many people inside you don't have to worry about heckling or people interrupting.  It's kind of like an exclusive private stand up session.  Many of the jokes were hilarious and I must warn you many are offensive as well.I can definitely see this place as a venue for aspiring comics looking to make their big break.  I even talked to a few of the comics after the stand up performances and all of them are nice and down to earth.  What is amazing is that they want to know your thoughts on the routines and what you liked and didn't like.  They are looking for constructive feedback so they can better strengthen their routines.  This is what makes this place awesome because it gets you thinking about comedy as an art form rather than a piece of entertainment.  You learn to appreciate it and interpret it much more adeptly.I highly recommend this place for people into small dive bars and comedy. Great local neighborhood spot. Ed and Rachel are always very welcoming to their regulars and new guests. Rachel makes an awesome spicy margarita. The space is tiny and cozy with a lot of character. It's a very homey meets divey atmosphere!Definitely swing by for the comedy at 8pm every night :) If you love dive bars and stand up comedy, this is the place to go. The bartender, Rachel, was super friendly and funny. I ordered whiskey sour, it was great. This is one of the best dive bars I have been to and highly recommend it to anyone. The stand up comedies were the best, I had one of the best nights of my life. You can sign up on the spot for doing so if you want to.The bar is very small so seating can be tight. It worked out for me because I made new friends.I will definitely go back in the future. Old Man Hustle is the epitome of a dive bar. It is very, very cozy (it can probably fit about 20 people max). Almost all of the people who were at the bar were middle-aged men, and it seemed like the kind of place where the people who go are regulars. There was one bartender working, and she was really nice, making an effort to remember my friend's and my name. The drinks were pretty solid, and maybe a little bit less expensive than typical New York prices. Overall, it's not really my scene, but I can definitely see the charm in Old Man Hustle! Old Man Hustle is one of my favorite places I've ever been.Only a few people can fit in here, so you can talk with everyone. Comedy was funny, drinks were cheap, people were nice.Go here. Discovered this place lingering aimlessly around the LES, with our group in dire need for a little refuge over the holiday weekendThis goes to show that there is indeed charm in the simple. Pretty much the tiny house equivalent to the New York bar scene. While lacking real estate, the bar and stage almost encompass a drunk man's feng shui, all without feeling claustrophobic.Good conversations (and their extensive cocktail offerings) make the space even roomier The name of this bar was too hard to resist. What a great hole in the wall in the East Village! It's really rare to find a $ bar in NYC, so we decided to come here to pregame one night. The drinks were all really cheap and the bar was cozy. It's capacity was probably 25 at most, but luckily the back booth was empty when we got there. I had a beer and a bud which consisted of a shot and a Red Stripe Beer. For only $9, this was a steal and quite tasty since the shot came with a shot of pineapple juice. Their drinks sounded great. They had a nice selection of craft cocktails for $10-$15 on the menu and a few craft beers and wines to choose from. The ambience of the bar was quite nice. It was dimly light and had a few chandeliers. In the back, there was a pretty sweet fuschia neon sign that read "Old Man Hustle." This would make for some pretty cool Instagram pics of ya ask me. It got extremely crowded as we were leaving, so make sure to come early. One of the best bars in new york! Great atmosphere and wonderful service! Sam and John have that running like clockwork! Thank you for my introduction to New York! Great place with the best bartender. Rachel remembered everyone's name and made us feel very at home. Great friendly place for drinks! This is a great place to have a drink and see comedy in the Lower East Side. The Comedy Shows are always free and the drinks are reasonably priced.Also the bar tenders give you a good solid pour. Especially Rachel. Perfect little spot for Friday Happy Hour after the first week of teaching. Specials did the trick and Rachel was really sweet. We'll be back! I seriously dig Old Man Hustle. I know people tend to get nostalgic about "old" New York; the places that comprised what we considered old NYC are certainly becoming more and more rare these days. That being said this city is always changing and adapting, and as long as that change is for the positive it's not necessarily a bad thing....but it does tend to make things more and more expensive, which can be (read: will be) a bummer for your wallet. OMH is a throwback for sure, but in a way that doesn't compromise quality for diveyness or confuse awesome service for bartender apathy (this disease is real; trust me I'm a scientist). In short, this place is not a dive bar, but should be the model every dive bar in the city is striving to achieve; cheap drinks in a relaxed atmosphere, where (if you're cool) the bartender will do a shot with you the first time you meet them. You would be forgiven for walking right past this place without even noticing it (I met some friends there last weekend and did just that...and I had been there before). The space is about as narrow as they come, and not overly advertised.  When you make your way inside, you'll notice that there is a tiny nook upfront that can hold a group of around four, a bar that takes up the majority of space that this place has to offer, and another small outpost in the back under the glowing "Old Man Hustle" neon sign. I really think it's a combo of that neon sign, and the fact that the bartender can make conversation with everyone in the place that gives OMH the retro feel I was talking about earlier. There is physically no way to be 2/3 people deep in this place, which forces conversation (and leads to those aforementioned shots with the bartender). The physical location of the bar also lends itself to "throwback" status, being buried deep in the LES off the east Broadway stop on the F; this neighborhood has looked the same for as long as I can remember. As for their drinks; nothing on Tap, but a solid selection of cocktails for around 11$, and a pretty decent bottle selection of beers. Where they shine is their happy hour. You can get a dollar off your beer, but will end up adding that dollar right back onto the price in the form of a shot (well of course, but the type of well is up to you). This can be dangerous. Like "I don't remember anything after OMH shot-happy hour, dear god why did we do so many shots", dangerous. If you find yourself deep on the lower east side looking for a chill place to have a beer or cocktail OMH should be high on your list.

Best deli in NYC by far, the coffee is always very fresh even at 3am and the food never disappoints. I come here every day and will continue to come back because the food choice is endless and cooked to your liking by BooBoo on the grill. I come here for bagels and sandwiches once in a while.  I went yesterday to order a sandwich and picked up a loaf of Pepperidge Farm white bread.  Checked the package and expiration date.  If you're familiar with their packaging, you know they have a heat sealed wrapper inside and a bag outside. This morning I opened it up to make toast and find the inside wrapper shredded open, a big hole that went through a few slices and rodent droppings!  I immediately tossed it because I was grossed out.  What I don't understand is how is the outter  wrapper still in perfect condition? As good as it gets when it comes to a LES bodega. Muhammed and his staff are extremely friendly and are always in the mood to strike conversation with all their patrons. Their sandwiches are on point. Keep up the good work, boys! Was starving and this deli was PACKED and it was 3:00am. Got me the Pho #2 it was definitely spicy and delicious. Great deliAlso Seth Rogan approves of this deli. Love this place!  Great food at reasonable prices, plus a super friendly staff - all of which can be tough to find in this neighborhood.  Very solid breakfast sandwich.  Highly recommended. I really enjoyed my chicken, cheese and avocado wrap.  It was around $7 and filled me up.  However,  they did put it in silver foil.  This is fine anywhere else in NYC,  but this is China Town and my wrap was mistaken for a sword.  Within just 2 bites, I was challenged to a duel by a Ninja and his Samurai sword outside the Hong Kong Supermarket.  A challenge I gladly accepted. I ducked his first swipe before rising to chop his head off with my chicken and avocado wrap.  Testimony to the quality of both the wrap and it's contents - his head came clean off and rolled down Prince Street. As for the deli?  Good people.  Well priced.  My favourite  deli in the area.  I'll go back for further lunches,  dinners and duels.  Highly  recommended. Life changing egg, sausage and cheese on a toasted bagel. Perfect ratios of bagel, cheese, sausage and egg. Wow!! My shop orders from them all the time. Mohammed is a very friendly and amazing guy. Food always comes quick and hot. Have yet to be disappointed by my orders. Breakfast sandwiches, burgers...It's all good. Delicious AF. Our entire office eats there 3x a day. The omelets are fluffy and magical. The iced coffee is superior to all others in the neighborhood (sorry Irving Farm) and it's $2.50. Every neighborhood needs their go-to deli for a big sandwich at an affordable price and Optimum is just that. Clean store, friendly staff, and fresh/tasty offerings. They have an extensive menu of hot and cold 'wiches, wraps, and paninis and are accommodating and fast. Recommended for an easy lunch on Ludlow St. I love this deli. The prices are reasonable, the guys behind the counter are always extremely friendly. They've got cheap milk and I can always trust they'll have my favorite flavor chip and gatorade for the weekend hangover. I can get a plain bagel toasted with butter and somehow it tastes delightful. I love living on this block with the deli right here and I'll be sad to move. The food is great and the price is inexpensive. But more importantly, the people that works here are awesome! They're super nice :) I usually get a salad w smoked salmon. I always see them prep the vegetables which is a great thing bc that means the veggies are fresh never stale or leftovers from previous days. Best deli in LES. The chicken cutlet is so crispy and the cheddar cheese is so gooey. Hot chocolate is bomb. The prices so low. I want to date optimum deli. I've been going to this deli for awhile now, the breakfast sandwiches and the Broome Deli Special are both great. Last night, on a whim, I tried the waffle fries. My god, these guys deserve a Michelin Star for those things. They are perfect. Optimum Deli comes to the LES from the same team that brought the neighborhood the vaunted and beloved Happiness Deli, which was formerly located on Delancy, just up the block from this brand new spot.The ownership structure is apparently quite similar to that of the now shuttered Happiness Deli.  According to the guys who work at Optimum (who I recognize from Happiness), it's the brother of the owner of Happiness that owns the new joint.  Basically, it's just Happiness Deli a block further south in new--and much nicer and cleaner--digs.  The (awesome) menu is pretty much the same, as is the selection of non-deli goods.  Right now they're not selling beer or wine, but, according to the people working there, they will be soon; the application for a license has just been submitted, and since the ownership structure has (barely) changed, as has the name, they have to get a new license.The food is everything that people in the neighborhood know and love.  Happiness was long regarded as one of the (if not THE) best deli in the neighborhood, and since I moved down here, it has been a favorite of mine.  They have a great selection of cooked-to-order sandwiches, including (and this rocks my world) breakfast sandwiches cooked 24-7, 365!  And, the sandwiches are GREAT.  The ingredients are fresh, the combinations work very well, and it's relatively cheap.  $7 will get you an amazing sandwich on a hero, and it will fill you up!  Many of their sandwiches, especially breakfast sandwiches, are only like $3.  And, once they get the beer going again, their beer prices are great.  I'm a big fan of the #7 sandwich, the name of which I can't remember off the top of my head, but it is a chicken, jalapeo, and pepper jack combo.  The other night I went and they were out of something they needed for it (I think jalapeo), and the guy offered to whip me up something similar, and he came to me with a chicken and spicy peppers sandwich that was nothing short of spectacular.  I was so pleased (and admittedly a bit . . . uh . . . tipsy) that I called them and told them it rocked and that it should be a staple on the menu, since it was off-menu!The people that work here are awesome, too.  They're friendly, funny, and totally willing to make jokes with you.Also, they take credit, and a $5 minimum.  Not a fan of CC minimums, but hell, at least it's not something ridiculous.If I could change anything, I'd have them stock a few more groceries.  Like bread.  But then again, it's a deli that stocks some groceries, not a grocery store that has a deli counter.I am SO, SO happy that Happiness hasn't left the LES.  Yeah, it's got a different name, but it's the same animal.  If you live here and need a great and filling sandwich, this should be one of your first stops.  It's easily my favorite deli in the neighborhood, and maybe in Manhattan.  It's better than the several delis around my old place in the Village . . . Optimum deli has a  very convenient location  l. I get breakfast there sometimes . The bagels are good but not amazing . They toast them well and put a good amount of cream cheese. I once or twice got fries from there and they were yummy . They have a good selection of candies and they have s'mores poptarts until recently when they disappeared. I will go back many times . 5 stars but the missing poptarts take away one . When they get them back I will update this review . I am indeed obsessed with these poptarts . Thank you for your time . best deli hands down in the LES.love all the sandwiches...they're amazing. including the breakfast sandwiches. also, the people who work there are great. Good sausage/egg/cheese sandwiches (better than most I've had at other corner grocers or restaurants), more importantly, very nice people who work there. best sandwhich ever whole wheat bagel lettuce tomatoes chesse light mayo and avacadoo  freshmen year of high was 3$, went up to 5$ now We went there based on Yelp reviews alone. Friendly service, pleasant people and great food. All at a good price. Can't ask for more.

Nice people, great products, and though it seems like it could be overpriced, the prices seem to be totally fair!Great sandwiches. Nice setup.I'm not vegan, but this place makes me eat more like one.A nice addition to the neighborhood. 3 words: vegan. sandwich. heaven.Dropped by here twice in one weekend because I was hooked. The Rocko and The Monty are both excellent, and their chickpea tuna salad is tasty too. Satisfying both flavor and texture for tofu sandwiches is no easy feat, but orchard grocer has mastered it.   You won't find bland or slimy tofu here, their food is filling and packs a flavorful punch that fuels you up for wherever you're headed.I'll definitely be back. Fabulous! .. and the staff is the best! They love what they do, and they love talking to and helping customers.   I would hire anyone of them tomorrow if I owned a food store. This is a New York treat, and a throwback to a time when NYC had quality products and quality employees.  I phoned to make certain they had Cavi-Art plant based caviar before I ventured over. The clerk on the phone was so nice, and when I casually asked her a question - she didn't just say "I'm very busy" (this was Christmas Eve for many last minute shoppers), instead, she had me hold for a nano-second and as I was about to say "not to worry, I check when I get there" she already had an answer for me.  That started my positive presentation of the place.Don't let the small size influence your decision to go inside and shop, order and take home some fabulous vegan products.   good things come in small packages - and this store is one of them!I would suggest Orchard Grocer to anyone, and you never know who you will run into while there.  I will also be back to shop for other items when I have more time to enjoy checking out their entire product lines. What a time to be alive. NYC now has a 100% vegan and palm oil free deli! Conveniently located in a busy shopping area of the LES, this modern bodega offers much more than just fantastic sandwiches. I was amazed by the selection of cheeses, dry foods, and specialty brands occupying the shelves. The assortment and merchandising products is reminiscent of a Dean & Deluca, but all vegan. They also have a selection of pastries from local companies, as well as soft serve ice cream. My favorite of the sandwiches that I tried was The Edith ($8)-a fresh NY bagel topped with a generous spread of cashew cream cheese, and carrot lox. I have never had real lox, but these tangy carrots are delicious, especially with the contrasting rich, creamy cashew cheese. The bagel sandwich was so huge that I had to save half for the next day. I was almost equally impressed by their Reuben (The Marlowe, $12) which was among the best vegan versions of the sandwich I have ever eaten. Piled high with tender, richly spiced roast seitan 'beef' and vegan cheese, which melts into the fresh sauerkraut for one seriously hearty sandwich. You will feel like a vegan Guy Fieri eating this one. My least favorite was The Monty ($12), which is their rendition of a classic deli sandwich-cold cuts, cheese, olives, and roasted peppers, on a hero roll. The bread to filling ratio was way off, with less than a tablespoon of veganaise, and only a couple slices of meat and cheese. Maybe it was an off day, but this sammy really needed more fillings. I highly recommend Orchard Grocer to any lovers of fine food, regardless of your dietary preferences. I look forward to returning the next time I am in NYC. I have read about Orchard Grocer all over Thrillist and Facebook and had it on my list of "must tries" for a long time. I happened to be on the LES for the Pickle Festival and found myself across the street. I finally went in and checked it out. Orchard Grocer is a clean grocery with all Vegan products. Super convenient.I ordered the Marlowe: Reuben with beet brined Blackbird seitan, local sauerkraut, house made thousand island, Violife provolone slice, on marble rye. $12.The sandwich was freshly prepared while I waited. crispy on the outside from the sandwich press and evenly heated throughout. All the ingredients were tasty. I wasn't expecting such a "briny" flavor but the textures were great. The prices are reasonable especially for vegan food.I'd come back to try more items on the menu. Can't get enough of this place. Wish they had a tiny bit more seating beyond the 3 window stools. Every sandwich is better than the next and their specials are really fun and creative (umm vegan shrimp po boys yes plz). Their soft serve never disappoints and worth the trip in 37 degree weather. Very good spot if you are on a vegan diet! Their sandwiches are carefully executed and you can see they really put attention to each ingredient in the sandwich. I had a Reuben (Marlowe as hey call it) and I have to say it was really good. Perhaps the only thing I would change would be seitan since in my opinion it was too thick. My girlfriend had a special they offered with an "omelette". I have to say it was excellent. You would never tell that was not a "real" omelette.While we were waiting for our sandwiches we ordered a soft serve ice cream. Wow...! I would say it was even better than the regular soft serve...!! Apart from sandwiches and soft serve :) they also offer a large selection of vegan products. Certainly a spot you should have on your list in you're in the area...! What could be better than an amazing vegan bodega? An amazing vegan bodega with a deli counter and local fresh baked goods! Fantastic array of vegan goods to be found here, including deli "meats", prepared meals, cheeses from all over (including the illusive Violife, which I have only found in Europe!) and omg try the "tub" of spreadable vegan cheese it is EXACTLY like mac n' cheese, but better! And cruelty free :)My favorite sandwich here is hands down the Bowery, which is a breakfast sandwich of vegan egg, bacon and cheese and is to die for. Get two, you're gonna want another one because you wont believe how good the first one was. This cute and tidy shot gun mvegan spot has counter sandwiches and a small specialty selection of vegan and vegetarian grocery items like vegan cheeses and "meats".  They even had vegan yogurt.  In the dry goods section - vegetarian brown gravy packets and tapenades and sauces.Although the grocery items are expensive, the sandwiches and salads at the counter are a rational $10-$12.  My friend got a cubano sandwich.  I got a pbj bar cause I wasn't hungry.   The bar was decent tasting if kinda chalky the way you expect, $4.  I've learned to love that chalkiness. The BBQ jackfruit sandwich looked good.The staff was nice and we scored some gluten free pumpkin donuts on the house because they said they were going to throw them away. My friends sandwich was enormous, definitely two servings.  My complaint was that the bread was too big.   The menu of salads and sandwiches looks good though and for vegan specialty items they are affordable.   Get it to go unless your lucky to score one of the three bar stools. New York is famous for it's sandwiches and now I know why! Try The Bowery for a vegan spin on the bacon and egg roll and be sure to check out their Instagram for daily special sandwich. The perfect hang over cure. This place is PHENOMENAL. One of the best sandwiches I've had period, vegan or not vegan. It really surprised me.I tried the omelette special on GF bread....outstanding. The tofu was seasoned perfectly and bursting with flavor, as well as the sauted peppers, mushrooms and shallots. The cheese was so tasty, and the contrast of the soft tofu with the crispy bun was so satisfying. Add the ketchup/mayo and arugula and you got yourself a perfect sandwich. My boyfriend had the Reuben, it was also equally as amazing and bursting with flavor. They clearly put care and attention towards each and every ingredient featured in their sandwiches.The soft serve ice cream, omg. Vegan soft serve can actually taste better than dairy soft serve!!! I was blown away.They also carry exquisite vegan macaroons. Try the rose flavor and you'll be transported to heaven.I already can't wait to come back during my next visit to NYC. A 100% vegan grocery store in Manhattan! Finally! And it's super cute and reasonably priced! I'm very excited about this place and you should be too. :) :)***LOCATION & INTERIOR***Orchard Grocer is located on Orchard St (self-explanatory), a.k.a. that small, weirdly ~trendy~ strip that runs through Chinatown. It's right next door to Moo Shoes, a vegan shoe store. PSA: Moo Shoes now carries the vegan Birkenstocks in black and brown!When I first visited Orchard, I was surprised by how tiny it was. It's more of a bodega/deli than an actual grocery store, so don't expect to find produce or anything like that. One wall is lined with shelves of specialty vegan items, like sauces, chocolate, and snacks, while the other wall is taken up by a refrigerated shelf stocked with a large array of vegan cheeses and some vegan proteins. The prices are pretty fair, especially considering that there are items you can't find at your neighborhood Whole Foods or natural market.Along the back wall is the deli/counter, where you can order their amazing sandwiches or pick up some fresh baked goods and soft serve. They often collab with vegan bakers (usually from Brooklyn) to feature a few of their items each week, so the offerings are constantly changing. You can even eat your food in the little store, at the bar along the front window.Oh, and the interior is very neat and clean, and the staff is super, super sweet. I'm obsessed.***FOOD***I ordered the much raved about Marlowe, the vegan reuban sandwich. Even though I asked for no dressing, it was still SO GOOD. It's made to order so I received it hot and toasted. The bread was thin and crispy just how I like, the cheese they used was wonderfully melty without a strong taste, and the vegan meat (seitan maybe?) was a great texture with a perfectly smokey flavor. It was the size of a normal homemade sandwich, but filling enough. My only complaint is that it's quite pricey at $12 for a relatively simple take-out sandwich, but on the other hand I've had much worse meals for $12 in the city.I also had a blondie from Gone Pie, the vegan bakers that frequent the vegan pop up shops. I wasn't really fan of it to be honest, but I'm still excited that Orchard carries local vegan brands and will definitely try their other Gone Pie/local desserts the next time I go.***NOTES/RECOMMENDATION***New York is the capital of delis and also one of the most vegan friendly cities in the world, and Orchard Grocer does a great job of bringing together these two things. I'll be back to try their other sandwiches (vegan bagel and lox!!!), soft serve (which I've heard is delicious), and baked goods, as well as to pick up some vegan pantry essentials. The bagel with smoked carrot and cashew cream cheese is amazing. Huge sandwiches. Amazing staff. Stocked with great products! Absolutely amazing even for nonvegans. Best lox I have ever had including real lox!!! Orchard street is one of my favorite streets on the LES. Where you can experience old New York with a little bit of a face lift. This grocer exemplifies the spirit of the neighborhood. It may seem like a typical deli/butcher store, but it is nothing but. This little galley is stacked from floor to ceiling with vegan specialty foods and has a great selection of meat-free meats. They have yummy healthy sandwiches and soups to go. If this is your thing it's definitely worth a visit. This place is lit! Finally came here yesterday after dreaming about these sandwiches. When I walked in, they were playing Alice Coltrane, so kudos to the  musical ambiance.I ordered the Edith and Pumpkin-Vanilla Swirl soft serve with naked sprinkles. I had the ice cream first, and it was delicious! I think the Pumpkin was prominent in flavor than the Vanilla, but lovely nonetheless. They should get cones (and gluten-free ones too).I ate the sandwich a little later. Wow, what a culinary masterpiece. The carrot lox had a nice smoky, slightly briney taste. Cashew cream cheese and the actual bagel (had it on an Everything) were a knockout! I passed out, woke up and ate various bites of it as the night progressed; amazed at every bite. I will definitely be returning. Can't wait to try their other sandwiches with gluten-free bread soon! A small cute vegan grocery store. I love how they stock a variety of chocolates and vegan food. I ordered gluten-free sandwiches a while back, but the breads were really dry and hard. I wouldn't recommend getting the gluten-free bread options for the deli sandwiches. The best sandwiches! We had to return here to taste more. The Bowery is simple but amazingly good, all the others were also great with special and rich flavours. Vegan food at its best This little grocery/sandwich shop is a trip to the past and the future. It has the classic feel of a vintage grocery store, with the best vegan snacks, ingredients, drinks, and so on. Their sandwiches and service are both terrific. The only downside is that there are no bathrooms for customers (I ate at the counter) and there are only 3 seats. Orchard grocer is an incredible addition the LES. Their deli is the bomb. I've tried two of their buffalo tofu sandwiches that have been on special, and both were amazing. Each was $10 (without tax) and a large portion size. If you go with a friend, I'd recommend splitting two sandwiches; both times that I've ordered my sandwiches, they had been cut in half, making them easy to share. The people working here are SO wonderful and genuinely kind. My two suggestions are 1) to have sample salads in the cooler to showcase those options as they all sound delicious! And 2) I would love for them to have a sandwich loyalty punch card, e.g. buy 10, get the 11th free. Nevertheless, I will keep coming back! Next on the list to try is the tiramisu they have from Rawsome Treats.

Remarkable, homemade pasta.  Attentive service.  Fairly easy-to-find location.  Comprehensive array of Italian options on menu.  Servers who actually spoke Italian and weren't Real Housewives from Bergen County or wherever who called themselves "Italian." Seating and navigating the space were rather cumbersome, though--because there's so little space.  The restaurant is tiny.I'd come back when in NYC. Hm. I came here for their Monday late night special ($12 pastas after 9pm/also available on Sunday). It's a pretty good deal then, but I still don't know how I feel. We tried the Cappelletti, Garganelli and Fusili. The cappelletti started off being my favorite, but the truffle butter just gets too rich once you're a few bites in. The garganelli had no flavor whatsoever for me. The fusili was sadly the most edible for me, but tasted just a bit better than boxed pasta with canned tomato sauce. Our server was really awkward and kept trying to clear our plates when we weren't even halfway done. Definitely don't come here if you're going to pay full price. Asians were forced to sit in the back of the restaurant by active kitchen doors when the place was still mostly empty.  My table and a neighboring party were the only Asians in the restaurant.  The segregation was clear. But I'll draw no conclusions.  I'm only stating the facts based on my experience. I shouldn't have to defend myself but there was nothing exceptional on my end that called for such treatment.  I arrived early, straight from work dressed in business casual. I'm an experienced New York diner, having lived here for over 3 decades and have frequented many fine dining establishments, including other Altamarea restaurants. The food is fine.  It might even be great.  Draw your own conclusions Nice spot, decent lunch. Good location & ambiance - it feels like a cozy lodge inside. However, the starters weren't great, and the sandwich our server recommended was a let down. RESERVATIONS: Made online about a week in advance. It was probably unnecessary; at 12pm we were one of two tables in the restaurant. By the time we left around 1:30pm, it was much busier, but there were still several empty tables.THE COST: $37.57 total per person (including tax/tip) for 3 starters & 3 entrees, shared between 3 people.MUST-HAVES: Cappelletti w/ truffle butter.STARTERS:* Burrata - 3 starsNot as soft as other burrata's I've had; overall a lackluster dish. * Roasted quail with fig - 3.5 starsPretty good sharp flavor. The meat was a bit tough, but paired well with the fig. * Polpetini - 3 starsNot too memorable or impressive. A bit dry.ENTREES: * Cappelletti w/ truffle butter - 4 starsUnexpectedly my favorite! The truffle butter was perfect, the pasta just right.* Fusilli - 3.5 starsNot really a standout dish; the sauce was plain & standard, lacking texture, and tasting almost like a canned pasta sauce. I'd expect this quality of sauce from a cafeteria but not from an Italian restaurant in NYC!* Egg and ham sandwich - 3.5 starsDisappointing (this was rec from our server); bun was dry, meats indistinguishable. My friends noticed one of the pancettas that had a bit of crunch, but I didn't notice it. One slight redeeming factor was the runny egg yolk. I came here on a Saturday night for a yummy anniversary dinner and this place sure satisfied my pasta needs. Being under the same umbrella as Marea, I was hoping for fresh made pasta and I got it. The service was wonderful and a good amount of tables in the back. Eating at the bar also looked enjoyable.We first got some fresh bread. Then we ordered the Fegatini which was duck liver mousse on thick airy bread. I loved it! It was super tasty, wonderful flavor of the duck mousse. The onion agrodoice wasn't overwhelming. Right amount of sweet to the mousse.Then we shared the capetelli which was delicious ravioli with truffle and prosciutto. It was large in portion and so delicious. The pasta was al dente. Plenty of ricotta with a delicious hit of truffle. Sauce was light and creamy. So GOOOD! The squid ink pasta was also made perfectly al dente. Ragu was nicely balanced, light and had great flavor from the shrimp. Overall, a great place for some fresh pasta. Came here for a late lunch. The food is inoffensive but not memorable. $22 for lunch pasta is fine. I got the pasta with truffle butter, cream, radicchio and prosciutto. The radicchio was a bit of an odd addition, and there was barely a hint of truffles. The pasta itself was cooked well and had a good. Overall, not a bad choice but not entirely worth repeating. The very first thing I noticed when I walked in here is that the tables are oddly placed in a diagonal manner. For those of you who like clean straight lines, this is going to drive you crazy. The food was really good though that I have to give it five stars. Wow, meatballs. I'm usually not a fan of meatballs, but when my friend ordered them, I was so glad because they were amazing!!! Flavorful right down to the core.My tagliatelle was meaty and delicious - they do not skimp on the meat and I loved that. Dessert was amazing. Wine was good. Service decent. Of all the Italian places in NYC, Osteria Morini is definitely in my top 5. Not sure why it's taken me so long to review this place. Actually the first time we visited had to have been 10+ years ago. I think, like most New Yorkers when it comes to really good Italian food, I sorta took it for granted that I had already reviewed Osteria Morini!I love a nice old-school (but still modern enough) Manhattan Italian restaurant. This place gets it right, from the expert waitstaff to the expertly crafted food. For the most part, you're probably coming here for the pasta (and you probably can't go wrong in that department). But for me, it's the porchetta. This is one of the few places that offers this dish all the time and they get it right basically all the time.So, yeah, I kinda like this place a lot. Not that cheap, but quality rarely is... Osteria Moroni was one of my favorite restaurants when I first dined here that when I saw a Gilt City coupon for a 3 course lunch, I immediately bought it. I kind of wish I didn't as the experience the second time was nothing like the first. We came this past Labor Day, the restaurant was pretty much empty, which wasn't surprising as everyone likes to take a longer holiday weekend. To start, ordered the meatballs and fried calamari / vegetables. The fried platter should have been called a fried vegetable plate as they was only like 3 half pieces of calamari. The fried cauliflower was good and my favorite. The meatballs were okay - nothing memorable. After receiving our appetizers, it took forever to receive our pasta entrees. I didn't know it took that long to cook pasta - we waited around 40 minutes to get our pastas after we had finished eating our appetizers. Service was close to none as no one came to acknowledge the long wait / explain why our entrees were taking so long. The tables that came after us even got their appetizers and pastas before us...didn't make any sense. When the tagliatelle and garganelli finally arrived, we were starving and dived in. The tagliatelle was delicious - we both loved the ragu. Our clear favorite as the garganelli (peas, prosciutto, and truffle oil) was too creamy that it completely overpowered anything else. There was a serious lack of prosciutto too. For dessert, we got the tiramisu and the chocolate pudding. I made a note that it was a special occasion, so it was nice that they bought out a complementary scoop of pistachio gelato. All the desserts were really good. I didn't have a definite favorite as each stood out in their own way. The chocolate pudding was really chocolatey and super sweet - if you love super sweet milk chocolate, this dessert is for you. The pistachio gelato was light and refreshing. It balanced out the other desserts. After this experience, sadly, I don't think I'll be back. I had dinner here last night with my coworkers and man, though I doubted the high-end esque Italian restaurants, I was wrong. I do want to note that expensive Italian restaurants are usually underwhelming, since the ingredients are generally cheap, you expect the meal to follow suit. The ambiance: dim lighting, and the restaurant is fairly large, so a lot of seating. Our reservation was for 8pm on a Tuesday night, and it was only about a third full. I'm sure that on weekends, it gets packed.Let's talk about the food at Osteria Morini. First thing to note, great bread to start. They provide ciabatta that has a hint of herbal flavors along with olive oil. We couldn't stop asking for more.We started off with crudo di agnello (lamb tartare), burrata, and polpettine (prosciutto and mortadella meatballs). The burrata was paired with a beautiful strawberries and balsamic; it was incredibly fresh. You can't go wrong with burrata. The meatballs were my favorite appetizer. It was perfectly cooked and topped off with a great marinara sauce. The crispy bread was well paired with the meatballs. My least favorite appetizer was the lamb tartare - it was a little too gamey.For the entrees, we ordered a tagliatelle, torcia (squid ink), and the garganelli (pasta quills with truffle butter). Of these, the pastas to note were the torcia and the tagliatelle. The tagliatelle is a basic and common pasta. Osteria Morini just made it exceptionally. The torcia, get it!!! It's a little sweet, perfectly cooked, and the flavors burst. Ok last... the veal with truffle cream. What a wonderful way to end a meal. It's heavy, but it's worth it. The cream sauce is heaven.I'll definitely be back to try more of Michael White's dishes. 2 things: Treated like a queen and ate like a queen.I had dinner here last night with my boyfriend to celebrate our anniversary. Our table was ready even though we arrived 20-30 mins earlier than our reservation. The hostesses were super friendly and even offered to store my bouquet in the fridge. Upon being seated, our waitress (I think her name was Lily) brought us a two glasses of complimentary wine for our special occasion. Seriously felt so special in the moment and it was such a treat!For apps, we started with some meat and cheese, we had the Prosciutto and "King of Salami" along with the soft cheese + Lamb Tartare. This was all prepared by the bar in the front of the restaurant and you can see them slice the meat! Not sure how we finished it ALL, but we did. IT was a lot of meat and the prosciutto was unbelievably delicious! Don't get me started with the lamb tartare... I couldn't stop eating it! We didn't order our mains till we finished our apps and it took us a while to finish it. An hour later, we killed it! By now, we were pretty full of meat and cheese... For mains, we shared the special duck breast with candied walnuts and also ordered the squid ink pasta. Not sure which one we were more excited about! Not going to lie, but all their pastas sounded so good and we were struggling to choose! The pasta was perfectly cooked, super al dente and had balanced flavor (perhaps could spice it up??) The duck breast was seared beautifully (medium rare) but I personally like it more on the medium side. Nonetheless, everything was delicious!Okay and now the most important part of the meal, DESSERT. Once again we were struggling to decide on a dessert. We were torn between the frozen peach custard and the panna cotta. On our first date, I had panna cotta, so a part of us wanted to have that again... But then there was the peach custard too... The waitress helped us decide on the panna cotta. Let me tell you... their panna cotta is dangerous! I could easily order 5 and have that instead of dinner... IT WAS PHENOMENAL. Texture was sooooo buttery smooth, with hints of citrus from the candied lemon and crunchy granola. What sealed the meal was that our waitress even surprised us with a complimentary dessert after we finished the panna cotta! She brought us the peach custard... We were so overwhelmed by the superb service, we were in a daze.Overall, our dinner was so special, all thanks to the team at Osteria Morini. The ambience was exactly what we were looking for, nothing too fancy that i'd need to dress up for but at the same time wanted fancy food. Can't wait to be back for the octopus and gnocchi!!Special thanks to our waitress, Lily!! My go-to for fulfilling my pasta cravings. I came here Monday night around 9:45pm, when the pastas are $12 (after 9pm on Monday's and I believe Sunday's as well). The two of us ordered 6 pasta dishes - we wanted to try them all but figured that might be overkill. My two favorites were the raviolis with truffle butter and the one with lamb. I'll definitely be back to take advantage of this amazing deal. Great Italian food! Came in on a Monday afternoon and it was virtually empty except for two tables. The host was nice and said if it got cold he could turn the heat up. The waitress was extremely sweet and prompt as well. I didn't get her name but she has lightish brown hair in a ponytail with a soft voice. The ambiance and decor of the restaurant was nice as well, modern and welcoming without trying too hard. For main dish I ordered the cappelletti and my friend ordered the fusilli. From pictures it seemed as if the cappelletti portion size was too small, but it's just enough! It's extremely filling and satisfying, however it's a 4/5 maybe 3.5/5 dish because the butter progressively became overwhelming with each bite. However, it's still a delicious dish and should be tried at least once. My friend enjoyed the fusilli and was pleasantly surprised, they also ordered two different kinds of beer and enjoyed both! They also asked if we wanted bread, but next time I'll skip out on it. It was dry and had a strong cardamom taste. For dessert, I ordered the torta di olio. It was my first time having olive oil cake and it was a great experience! The cake itself was dense and sweet, and the lemon buttercream on top tasted faintly of lemon and cream- very simple but I didn't like it as it was too thick. It also came with grapefruit sorbet on the side which was tart and delightful. Grapefruit is the worst tasting fruit but they managed to make it taste good! It also had granola which should be substituted for something else or opted out since it was really hard to chew and it didn't pair well with the cake or sorbet. Overall it was a really good experience and I'll be back! Found this place on Yelp and it was Ahh-mazing. I would highly suggest to any and all people. I came here on a date night so there was just two of us.For apps, we got a meat and cheese platter as well as a salad, both were amazing.For dinner we decided to share one pasta dish and one entree. We got a pork entree that was so good. Both were amazing.Overall, it is romantic and trendy. The wine and food were not only great, but affordable. Part of the Michael White empire this is their more casual walk in sit down restaurant. It's a nice space and great for groups or for a meal. Service was great with specials and dishes explained thoroughly, though they gave us the wrong salad they were quick to replace and give is the correct one after. The front area has a bar and the charcuterie cheese preparation area. Its a great spot to sit down for a quick meal or to have charcuterie. The back area is the sit down tables area and you get a nice view of the kitchen and the wood fired oven cooking up at this time tomahawk ribeye steaks. Stand outs of the night were the truffle ravioli. The taste of truffle really comes through. The pork ragu taglatelle which had a nice meat sauce that clung to the pasta. All the pasta was made fresh and the chewiness happens on each bite. I particularly liked my ribeye which was cooked perfectly in the wood fired oven and had a nice char. The porchetta was also nice with a nice crispy skin and tender pork. Our charcuterie board had a nice mix and match of items suggested by our server. The mortadella, olives, and sharp cheddar cheese made a great appetizer. It's a nice spot but at times consistency can be hit or miss. I've heard the hype about this place. Finally got to try it. I could have had really high expectations but it was not that impressive for me. I started with a charcuterie plate with smoked prosciutto, salami, duck liver, soft cow cheese and hard goat cheese. I'm usually very excited for liver when I see it on the menu but this duck liver did not deliver for me. I can't put a word on it but I just felt like something was just missing. I had two bites and I felt like it was a waste not finishing it. However, the prosciutto was one of the best I ever had. The Cappelletti pasta was a little disappointing. I love truffle, cheese, prosciutto and butter but this dish was just not cutting it. The flavor was just alright, pasta was overcooked and the sauce was very mild. I expected aromatic, creamy, rich , hearty bites but it was just light and plain. They do have a late night pasta special you could be interested in, $12 pasta after 9pm on Sunday's and Monday's. Food: 4.5Service: 4Ambience: 4Walked in a Friday around 7pm and managed to snag a table in the front - success! I'm usually all for making a reservation, but it's nice to know I can keep this place in my back pocket when I'm going for a spontaneous casual-but-cute date night. Loved pretty much everything! Starting with the wine list - they do flights which is pretty awesome when you just want a taste. I got the lambrusci flight, which is a slightly bubbly red wine. Onto the food:Rucola salad: kinda basic but done really well with slightly more special ingredients - the crispy speck is more interesting than bacon, and ricotta salata adds a little more funk than mozzarella or parmesan would. Tagliatelle: a classic that can't be done better, slightly thinner and thicker noodles than spaghetti that really laps up the bolognese sauce. Cappelletti: our server's favorite pasta, and it was delicious! Little packages that look like wontons filled with truffle ricotta (you can actually see black truffle specks inside and it's not overly flavorful) in a butter sauce that manages to NOT be heavy - how they accomplished this idk, but it was absolutely perfect. Bistecca: a perfect steak for sharing with a good crust on the exterior and a refreshing bunch of watercress. Budino: somehow I always end up ordering this as dessert, I just can't get over chocolate and hazelnut! It's a little small (for my huge sweet tooth) so you might have to fight for the last smooth delicious bite.Osteria Morini excels at being the neighborhood Italian restaurant that is refreshingly authentic (there are so many trendy places now), not complicated, making really good food. With Michael White, pasta genius, you're in good hands. Even though I've been to Marea, Alto, Vaucluse, Convivio and Ai Fiori, Morini is my absolute favorite Michael White endeavor (though I have enjoyed all of them with the exception of the long-shuttered Alto). My wife and I almost always go for lunch because there's an insanely good pre fixe lunch deal with an app and a pasta for around 30 dollars. Considering the quality of ingredients and the skilled preparation, it's an absolute bargain. All of the pastas are top notch (it's Michael White so that's a given anyways), but the salads and small entrees are great as well. I particularly love the seafood salad and the hangar steak. Service is as great as every one of White's restaurants and they make great homemade sodas as well. An absolutely gem of a place. Osteria Morini is one of my favorite restaurants, hands down. They have homemade pasta, which melts in your mouth. I come here all the time when I'm in the city, my family loves this restaurant. I recommend getting the tortellini in brodo, meat and cheese board, (the parmigiano gelato spread is TO DIE FOR), the gramigna is one of their signature dishes, the cappelletti is what i photographed and that was amazing, and you should try the garganelli. They also have amazing meats and cheeses, as well as great wine.If you want a great homemade italian cuisine, this is the place for you. Friendly service, excellent pasta, what's not to love?! Came on a Monday night for their $10 pasta deal (without reservations) and was lucky enough to be seated at the bar with hardly a wait.  Loved being able to watch the preparation of the deserts and appetizers from where we were sitting.  What we ordered: - Tagliatelle - this is always our go-to order.  Never disappoints. Highly recommend. - Creamy pasta with peas (forgot the name) - incredibly flavorful.  Also recommend - Cacio e pepe salad - SO GOOD. perfect start to the meal.  menu states that its served with an anchovy dressing but can barely taste the anchovies. Can't wait to be back!

If you put an orgasm between two slices of bread you will know the pleasure of eating here.  Sandwich-O for certain.  Those of you who know sandwich nirvana will appreciate.  I am not kidding.  If trump eats cheeseburgers in bed, it is only because he has not had the Dennis (well, and he is a sad orange man).  But behold the Dennis: thinly sliced perfectly bread chicken breasts, surrounded by Italian meat, with a delicate vinaigrette and warm homemade bread.  Everything super fresh and made to order.  Right there.  Magic.  My favorite was the Italian Combo. Meat, meat, and more meat and provolone or mozzarella that was so fresh.   Tomatoes or marinated red peppers with balsamic on the bread.  Two giant subs for around $20 bucks!! Now just find a bar to eat it in!!   LOVE it here.  We ate here two days in a row. Parisi is an unseemly gem of Little Italy/Nolita. They're known for their generous deli sandwiches, but the must have for any meat lover is the lard bread! It's available in loaf or ring form with a great crust, fluffy interior, and layers of cured meat. The first time I had it cold and this time, I asked for it to be warmed up and it was the best decision I made all week. The best thing on a chilly weekend morning.CASH ONLY This place is definitely creeping downhill. Usually get the Dennis off the NFT menu but was disappointed again for the third time. I think they may have changed the vendor for the bread/rolls because they now get soggy very fast and the sandwich is already uber messy. The chicken also use to be tender and fresh. But alas, this time the only thing moist was the soggy bread.The place is a solid 3 star lunch spot; but lack of seating, grumpy-cat counter guy and general lack of cleanliness knock off a star. Hope they get back to their usual goodness. But as of now there are a lot of better places close by, costing much less. I mean wowowoowowow. Great great sandwich. Arguably the best I have ever had. The bread was excellent - I recommend the sesame bread. They are famous for the Dennis but I got the Italian. Amazing. HUGE. so think, layered with so much meat and mozzarella and roasted red peppers. just I mean wow. Please go here. CASH ONLYYYY Real Little Italy baby. I went there for the first time on a walking tour and tried the pepperoni bread. It is simply addictive! This time, I took the lead of just about everyone and got the Dennis sandwich. Chicken cutlets, prosciutto, fresh mozzarella, tomatoes, pesto, and amazing balsamic on phenomenal crusty Italian bread. What a wonderful combination of flavors. I have a huge appetite, but I couldn't finish it. Definitely worth a return trip. I only wish they had tables and chairs outside, since there's no room inside to sit down and eat. So good! I got the chicken cutlet, fresh mozzarella and roasted peppers and for $12 the sandwich is huge (enough for 2 people). I didn't eat it right when I got it but I'm sure it would have been even better. My husband got the eggs and potatoes and he also loved it. I don't know which came first, Dennis the Menace the TV character or The Dennis sandwich at Parisi, but both both are an absolute handful. The Dennis sando is stacked high with a ridiculous four chicken cutlets, fresh-cut proscuitto, tomatoes, and house mozz. It's easily enough for three people to share. Add on roasted red peppers if you're planning to eat ASAP, otherwise it makes things soggy fast. I recommend getting extra pesto on the side for dipping purposes!NOTE: Cash only, ATM on site, closed Sundays, seafood specialties available on Fridays. Here's the Scoop: After reading some of the reviews I was a little apprehensive but to my surprise we came and it wasn't bad. We ordered the chicken cutlet. It was a nice sandwich in size and taste. I was pleasantly surprised. My husband enjoyed it as well. The bread was soft which is a plus. I think we would try them again.  Check them out guys. Pretty darn good sandwich. I was introduced to this small sandwich shop by a former colleague and am so glad he included my on this little secret. I get the chicken cutlet with mozzarella and roasted peppers. Nothing else, the juices from the roasted peppers soak into the bread and it's sooo so good. Things to note: it's cash only, there is no where to sit or eat so look for a bench somewhere, and eat immediately because the bread can get soggy with this particular sandwich after awhile. Plain and simple. Get the Dennis sandwich. You will not regret it.  It's the kind of deli chicken cutlet sandwich that New York should be proud of. One sandwich- two meals. My prosciutto, mozzarella, roasted red pepper, and pesto hero was piled high and amazing. Be careful of the copious amounts of raw garlic with the pesto though! They add a nice crunch but they're STRONG. It's a pretty messy sandwich and the bread did crumble a bit but still delicious the next day!I want to try the Dennis next time! Very small bakery with no space to sit. The service isn't particularly special but they was nice and fast making and packaging my order.The sandwich was amazing. I had the chicken cutlet with mozzarella and roasted peppers. It was huge, I could barely eat half. The portions are extremely generous. They don't skimp you on chicken or peppers or anything. You can also get sauces and peppers on the side and when you ask they don't act like its a huge deal like many other bakeries around the city. They also have a pretty good drink/chip selection. Just remember it's CASH ONLY. I had some reservations about going to this bakery. Would it live up to its reputation.I am glad to say this old style Italian deli does, and the Dennis is a must try for any serious sandwich lover. I have had massive chicken cutlet sandwiches at other legendary sandwich makers in Brooklyn, but it is hard to keep the sandwich moist. Parisi does an excellent job. The taste is complex and excellent.So don't be dissuaded by good reviews of other sandwich places, you must perform the haj, the pilgrimage to Parisi bang for your buck.!! Amazing sandwiches that are stuffed. Everything is fresh and delicious. Ordered The Dennis for the first time and it was everything Id thought it be. Get here early because they close at 4pm or earlier if they sell out. Favorite chicken cutlet, fresh mozz, mayo and Red pepper sub I ever had in my life. I carried the other half of the sub from spring st. to Staten Island and finished it off there. I ate every possible morsel. The bread is brilliant. If you like tiny portions that are certainly over priced please go waste your money there ;). Go to one of the actual good sandwich shops around there plus the people who work there could be much better I believe in love at first bite.. huge disclaimer i generally hate tomato sauces because I fall into the unlucky group where it leads me to get heartburn mehh:(.My co-worker was raving about this place and he always gets cold cuts and then he decided lets split a chicken parm and i was like haaaaaay why not.FIRST OF it was huge huge huge hugeee and cheap! I think it was 10? I took the first bite and holy moly love love love i felt my cheeks turn pink and warm my heart fluttering. I really hope that these sandwiches stay magically!If you are in the area you need to try it!if you arent in the area you need to get into the area and try it! These sandwhiches are monstrous and pretty damn good. Ordered the Dennis and shared with my friend, definitely filled us up for lunch.We went to eat at the park a block up and had a great time. Will be sure to come back and try another sandwich extravaganza. *CASH ONLY - $11 for the Dennis*Parisi is a 3.5 average. It was a solid 4 the first time but a sad 3 this time around. I can clearly recall my first Parisi experience and it was on one of my bad days. Upon first bite of pillowy, meaty chicken cutlets, the day was instantly better. Life felt better. It was by far the best few cutlets I've ever had in my lifespan. The prosciutto was spot-on and bountiful. I mean chicken AND cured ham in each bite? YOLO. The moz was fresh, stringy, and ooey gooey. The balsamic pesto had a hint of olive and was the perfect Dennis dressing. Parisi could easily be a five but their buns are pretty mediocre.I recently revisited Parisi on one of my good days and the Dennis was not of equivalent caliber. The WOW-factor I once experienced was missing. The cutlets were sappy and dry. Everything else remained the same but the cutlets, oh how disappointed was I in those cutlets! That was basically the deal breaker for me. P.S. If you come during lunch, expect a line! The Dennis is awesome. Gorgeous sandwich. The bread is not overpowering. The sandwich deftly combines crispy white breast patties with intense aromatic pesto, mozzarella, tomatoes and savoury prosciutto.

Patacon Pisao is a tiny plantain sandwich shop in the Lower East Side that offers delicious handheld eats. This is the perfect spot to grab a quick lunch or a bite before going out for the night. I came here on a Friday night and ordered the Cubano Plantain sandwich. As someone who isn't a plantain fan, they were able to make me love this sandwich. The plantains were cooked like a thick tortilla. It is crunchy and very satisfying to sink your teeth into. The portion is generous. I shared my sandwich with a friend. I was full on just half a sandwich! They have different sauces on the counter for you to use as well. Be warned though, there are some spicy ones!While eating at the shop you can tell it is a neighborhood favorite. A lot of regulars came in and had their orders ready and waiting for them. I would definitely come back to this spot. FYI: The shop sits about 10 people, so I wouldn't recommend coming here with a large party. It was hard enough fitting out winter coats on the seats. This was my first experience with Venezuelan food!The Patacon was ok. It was supposed to have sweet plantains on it but they were very bland. I am of Jamaican decent I know a thing or two about sweet plantains.Now! The arepas..... the arepas were GOOD! I will come back just for that! The store is small but has good character and the employees are extremely nice. After a long day of exploring the city, we decided to swing by for dinner. This place was on my radar for a while because of their patacons, fried plantain "sandwiches". Upon entering, we noticed the place was super small - definitely not good for large groups. There is enough seats/tables to fit about 8 people comfortably. I was there with 2 people and we took up like half the sitting space.We ordered the burger patacon (with avocado), half chicken/beef patacon, and yuca fries. The total came out to ~$30. That's honestly A LOT and more than I expected it would be. It took about 15 minutes to get our food.The patacons were honestly great. The flavor was there and the meats were seasoned well. My only complaint is the patacon itself was slightly hard to bite into. In addition, it is fairly dry but they had 3 different sauces to help with that. The sauces were delicious. We pretty much killed the bottles of salsa rosada (pink color) and salsa verde (green color) - sorry not sorry! I didn't try the hot salsa but that is also an option.The yuca fries were definitely one of the better ones I've had and it is served with a side of crumbled cheese and chimichurri sauce. I tried it with and without the toppings, and it really is fine either way. I personally prefer it with anything added.It was a great meal to end a long day but $30 for 2 people was a bit much for this kind of place. I would recommend trying this place out but I definitely won't be a regular here! I'm coming back here. I refuse to let one experience shape how I feel about this place. The cashier was polite and helpful. I struggled with ordering. I went with the patacon with just chicken. Didn't alter it at all (should have.) We sat down and the cashier brought us our food. The outer shell is so tough. 3 different types of sauce. Mint, chitpole, and hot I believe. You desperately need the sauces. The sandwich itself is so dry. So while you're drenching the sandwich with sauce, you realize there is no restroom. But they do give you like sanitizer wipes. I'll be back and order a wider range of dishes. First frazzled experience shouldn't deter me from a potential good experience. Filling yet inexpensive eats? YES for ~$10 this place will get you full but the food is nothing spectacular.Food - I came here wanting to try their Patacon (plantain sandwiches) and so I ordered a cubano and de pabellon. Appearance wise, they don't look the most appetizing but I promise you it tastes better than it looks. Between the two, I enjoyed the cubano more because it was juicier and had more flavor whereas the Patacon de pabellon was bland and dry. It's a must that you grab some of the sauces they offer because it was the added kick of flavor that these sandwiches needed.Service - The staff was friendly and helpful!Atmosphere - It's a very small shop with a couple small tables. Expect to sit for a quick bite and go. There's also no bathroom. I haven't left so satisfied from a restaurant in quite some time. I happened to have a craving for Venezuelan when my friend and I were in the neighborhood.At Patacon Pisao you place your order at the counter and bus your own table - there is maybe space enough to seat 8. It' is a small joint. I highly recommend a custom grilled arepa with avocado, maduros and shredded chicken, while my friend declared her reina pepia to be authentic - and you cannot forget a side of tequeno! delicious Venezuelan comfort food in the form of patacons, tacucho, cachapa, & arepas!the food here has that home-cooked street food taste & feel: filling and savory.this is an uber small eater. there are 3-4 2-seaters on the left, a small ledge on the right to stand and eat, and a small counter in the back for ordering/pay/and pickup. the space is super small but uses the space efficiently. the exposed brick decor is stripped-down, simple, bright, and clean with a few modern flourishes. most business is grab-n-go & delivery. tables turn fast. this is not a place to camp out, eat and go.i really enjoy the food offerings here. the food feel homemade/comfy. for first-timers, try the patacons: plantain patties as bread with hearty mix of meats, sauce, and extras. eat them hot. don't dilly dally.i am a big fan of the "BLaTin"-- bacon, avocado slices, lettuce, tomatoes, and salsa verde. the "cubano" is a hefy sandwich: ham, roasted pork, fried cheese, pickles, and salsa verse. you can't go wrong with any of the signature sandwiches or making your own.if you're in the mood for the "tacucho" (burrito), then try the "Bueno Dias"--eggs, chorizo, beans, melted cheese, and more. comforts of breakfast-y eats that can be ordered all day. the "mexican" arepa is EXCELLENT.most of the main eats are under $10. great food at a great value. the maduros (sweet plantains) are YUM and only ~$5.there are a variety of soft beverages: juices, sodas and water. no booze.dessert? tres leches or quesillo.the staff? friendly and full of suggestions if you're paralyzed by choice or new to these eats.drops mic cuz these patacons got me patting my bellyi outzzz I came in on a windy day and was greeted by the chef. He informed us that the cashier wasn't here so we would have to order through the website or through seamless. No big deal. While we stood there ordering through the website, he asked if it was our first time here and explained the most popular items. He then offered us some fresh hot cheese sticks on the house. Super nice of him and didn't expect it.Within minutes, our food was served to us. We ordered the Patacon sandwiches and they did not skimp out on the meat. Every bite was packed with flavor and I was surprised by how much I enjoyed it. It was so filling, I couldn't finish my second half. I asked for a piece of aluminum to wrap up my sandwich and the chef quickly put on some gloves and offered to wrap it for me so my hands wouldn't get dirty. Food and service was great! Will definitely be back! Hmm not sure if it's just cause I had high expectations coming in, or maybe I just simply wasn't a fan, but Patacon let me down... I have been planning a drunken night to come try Patacon after seeing stellar reviews, and finally made it out. I ordered the Patacon (plantain sandwich) with shredded chicken as my filling, and added some jalapenos as well. Each sandwich comes with fried queso blanco, lettuce, tomatoes, ketchup & salsa verde. I was expecting to be hit with delicious and unique flavors, especially since it was 1AM and I was experiencing major drunchies. But to my disappointment, the patacon was nothing unique--chicken was mediocre, the fix-ins were nothing unique, and I actually preferred a tortilla or even arepa to the thick, and slightly dry plantains. And to be honest, on any other day I love plantains.If I had to say what the star of the dish was, it'd have to be the salsa verde--odd though that they make theirs with mayo.
