All in all I will probably stick to Stanton Pizza or Essex Taqueria after a night out. I must say though the chicken tasted good mixed up with my leftover rice and topped off with sriracha back home. I came here wanting to try there infamous patacon sandwich! And I'll say it's definitely worth trying. The patacon sandwich, for those who don't know is basically a sandwich that instead of having bread it has flattened and fried Plantains that marries all the deliciousness in between.  This place in particular really makes good ones! I love that you can either customize them or order a premade one. And you can choose between having meat in it, or having no meat, getting cheese or getting no cheese, adding avocados (why wouldn't you add avocados?) Also when you get this, it will be hot so be cautious and it's not pre-cut... I think that's the only thing I wish they did, but I'm pretty sure if you ask they would do, it I don't see why they wouldn't. Staff here is also super friendly and so yeah overall great food and great vibes! Will definitely be coming back To start, this review is a combination of 2 separate opinions. I would personally give it 4 stars, while my well traveled friend (she does actually know great, authentic tasting food), would give it 0 stars-she said it was a waste of money and would never return. Therefore, I decided to give it 3 stars, erring on the side of more generous. We shared the grilled beef arepa and the de pabellon.I personally liked it. Our grilled arepa was very fresh and light. The "crepe" is like the typical heavier Latin options. Considering I don't know what authentic venezuelan food is, I would be happy to return. The price wasn't too bad considering it's manhattan. However, my friend said the corn crepe was far too thin compared to authentic food. It should be made mostly with corn and use flour(? Or something like that) to help bind everything, but it was mostly dough flecked with minimal amounts of corn kernels.In my opinion, this place seems reminiscent to Chipotle in that while it may not be authentic, this alien is happy with it. I heard about this place from a friend and thought it seemed interesting enough to schlep out from LIC to pay it a visit.  It's a relatively small shop (though there are a couple tables for dining-in) pumping out some yuge Venezuelan flavor! I decided to go with their namesake - a patacon (a sandwich with fried plantains replacing the bread) and went with the Patacon Paisa, which comes with grilled steak, chorizo, avocado, sunnyside up egg, ketchup and salsa verde.  This thing was pretty massive!  It tasted great as I got through half of my sandwich, but towards the end, it just felt a bit heavy with the fried plantains n fairly decadent stuffings.  I opted to go open-faced on the remainder and successfully put the beast down.  Very very yummy and great hearty flavors, but can get a little taxing by the end. I'd definitely recommend the spot, though, and would try their other offerings (including a cachapa - a type of sweet corn crepe).P.S. - load/stock up on their sauces! Delicious and fairly priced for NYC Venezuelan food. What's great is the pretty diverse menu with some typical Venezuelan players like patacones, arepas, cachapas and a wide variety of fillings. The portion is HUMONGOUS. Service is a delight! They're super friendly and attentive. Chefs would come to the table to make sure you feel good about the food. Gringos would love this place too because the ingredients and flavors can be adjusted to their taste. I wish they had empanadas but overall a great place for a meet up with a friend or two. I made it with 14 mins to spare before they closed. Winning!!!!!! The grill closes at 1 so keep that in mind.  I ordered a Patacon Pabellon.  It's a sandwich ( no bread but 2 slices of fried green plantains) filled with black beans, shredded beef, sweet plantain and queso fresco. Try the green sauce, it goes perfectly w the yummy sammich.  The only mistake I made and I regret it now, was to share it with my fianc. We both wanted more. It was a perfect sandwich to have before heading home. Oh and the fresh passion fruit juice was yummy too! The restaurant is very small and only has a few small tables. Enjoy!!!! Great Yelp find! Ordered the veggie Patacon sans cheese and it was quite tasty! I should have gotten some sauces for sure though as it was a bit full at times. Also I've never had a patacon before so take this review with that in mind.Def grab extra napkins and don't put the to go bag straight in your bag like I did because it's GREASY.Would def re-visit.You order at the counter and there's a few tables if you want to eat there. Very small and cool looking place. I had the Cubano Tacucho which is less than $10. Good amount of food for the cost.The place is not meant for sit in and more for take out. Restaurant is small with seating for 8-10 people. Also there is no restroom. Service is great. Cashier offered to help with menu questions and food was brought over to the table despite the lack of walking space. I've been here several times and the food is great. The space itself is pretty small with only a few tables, so if you can snag a table, definitely do so. They specialize in traditional Venezuelan sandwiches, and you can order one off their menu or build your own. They also have a few other sandwich options and a burrito option you can choose as well. The staff who work here are super friendly and I'd highly recommend coming here if in the area and searching for a delicious, yet not bank breaking meal. Extremely delicious!! We ordered Patacon paisa, Cachapa de pabellon, and some yucas fritas! We split it so we could try both, it was perfect! The people there are so nice and friendly! Definitely going back again with more friends I think I've found the place for some good fries! The yucca fries here!! They're beyond the regular level of usual fries. Usually fries are like a snack and not something that would fill me up. And the yucca fries here, it looks like a small portion of yucca fries but it can actually fill you up, at least for me, but I would still get a second order. Yes, it's that good. The texture is a bit different than potatoes (it's made from the yucca root), not as mushy as potatoes in fries. There's more substance to this. They come with some cheese you can sprinkle on top and a side of green sauce. For my the cheese was all I needed, I personally did not think the green sauce complimented the rich buttery taste of the yucca fries. Two friends and I decided to come here after a long search for a lunch place. One friend has been here before and she suggested this place and I have to say it didn't disappoint. I will definitely be back for more yucca fries and other things on their menu. Besides the yucca fries we got to share amongst the three of us, we each got different things. I got the el gringo burrito (tacucho), which I felt lacked a bit in its own department. It was loose when I got it and a little bit anorexic like. The one I got I guess wasn't anything special, it had chicken, bacon, lettuce and tomato. It was good but really nothing special. I used their verde and rosado sauces and I prefer the latter as it was a bit similar to tartar sauce and a bit spicy to it. The sauce went well with my burrito and the yucca fries when I decided to combine the two. My friends for the patacon and cachapa, both looking huge in portion and they ended up not being able to finish their orders. Both orders looks stuffed and packed. I will probably try one of those next time I come back.The price for everything was decent and the lady who took my order was friendly. Once you order, you can sit and they bring your food on a tray to your table. It's a small place with a few tables and can seat around 10 people. Came here for the patacon sandwich!!! I love all plantains so learning it could be made into sandwich patties made my stomach and heart VERY excited. I made my own with steak, egg, jamon, lettuce, tomato and it was amazing -- they have three sauces you can use to make it pop even more. Technically this is a 'cheap eat' but once you build your own patacon and add avocado or an egg it ends up totaling around $12, so still cheap but not as cheap as I expected haha. My friend got the cubano burrito, other friend tried the vegetarian patacon and we all really enjoyed our food. However if you're vegetarian the experience here may be a little less exciting since what really stands out here is the meat and how it brings all the fatty / crispy / crunchy bits together.

Super delicious soups bursting with flavor and complexity. The cold soups in the summer are excellent too. Cool little soup spot inside Essex market. Offers about a handful of different soup everyday and in two sizes. They also have pretty great cornbread and dessert cookies.The carrot ginger soup is pretty nice and has a light heat that is great for a chilly day outside. Cornbread is pretty hearty and for me, not as big as I'd like. Note, I love breads with my soup, so it might be decent in size for others. The cookies are small and light which is great after a cup of heavy soup and a solid cornbread chunk. 1.00 cars minimum, which is to say you can't buy a single cookie on a card (.85 cents per cookie).Prices are very reasonable and although many don't count soup as a lunch (me included) this I think will. It's not a heavy lunch like a steak would be but it will keep you filled till dinner time rolls around.Service is nice too, lines go fast and plenty of seating in the market. I stopped in for a cup of soup on a surprisingly cold October afternoon. The curry cauliflower and carrot soup was very good and was served piping hot. I think the smallest size was around $5. Good stuff! DELICIOUS vegan yellow split pea soup. I go out of my way to go here for soup. Great homemade tasting soups. Tucked away inside a little grocery market, you'll not only find a few aisles of produce, but you'll also find some little food stands. Once you meander around the market and find Pleasant Stock, you'll notice that it's not much to look at, just a few pots on a stove behind the counter. But in the soup game, it's all about what's inside those pots! I had the Spicy Chickpea and Tomato Soup. And my oh my, I felt like I could cry! So good! A hole in the wall inside Essex Street Market where magical, delicious soup is made in its little teeny tiny kitchen. Different menu each day! SO good! I'm addicted to this place...came here 6 days straight when I discovered this place. definitely a must try soup spot, especially if you're on a gluten free/vegan diet. (small $5, large $6/6.25) they let you sample their soup too. their buckwheat bread is awesome too but you have to get there early for it...they sell out quick. this place is located inside the Essex Market. I stopped in to try Peasant Stock's soup because of the great reviews...and I just love soup. Soups are $5 for small and $6 for large. They had flavors like Carrot Ginger Vegan soup, Chilled Avocado soup, but I had the chicken orzo because it was the only one with protein. While it was OK, I wouldn't say it was amazing. I feel like it's just regular chicken orzo soup that I cook at home but at least I didn't have to cook it. I'll need to try one of the other vegan soups next time. These are flavorful, hearty handmade soups, spiced just right. You get all the joys of wonderful soup just like a Mom who is a really good cook would make without the complication of actually having to visit Mom. This place is a hidden gem in the Essex Market.  We stopped in one afternoon for a light meal.  The soup is fantastic.  The maple bacon cornbread is addictive.  Service was very friendly.   Even our 6 and 10 year old kids ate their soup.  That is unheard of!  Thanks for adding to our NYC trip experience and we hope places like this stick around for years to come. Their $0.85 double chocolate cookies are shockingly exquisite, and perhaps the best thing we ate during the 2016 Essex Block Party. really good. I'm greedy so i bought two: Smoky Eggplant Tomato Soup with organicQuinoa and the Chilled Avocado Cucumber Soup. delish. i would most definitely recommend this spot especially if you are a soupy like me. didn't know how i would feel about a cold soup either but it was good. This is an old review from the winter that just got finished:  Tasty, fresh and affordable. What's not to like?  I had the carrot ginger soup and it was very good.  Assuming this place is still in biz, it's worth a trip, particularly in the cold weather! Very deserving of its 5 star average. Well done soup at a reasonable price. Very good corn bread. Vegan and gluten free options Delicious soup. I've been here multiple times and it has never disappointed! Cornbread and croutons are excellent too, but you don't need them to bulk up the soup - it's amazing on its own. There aren't many places in that strictly do soup and Peasant Stock is one, and does it extremely well! Its a bit hidden away in the back left corner of Essex market so you might have to make a round before you come across it. Basically its a tiny stall with a lady who makes some kick ass soup and a small assortment of cookies and baked goods. The soup rotates on a daily basis so you're sure to get something new. Everything is freshly prepared on a kitchen stove like you'd see at home so it has a comfortable feel from the start. We tried the asparagus, leek, and potato soup and got a large to share between two of us. Picked up some bread from Pain dAvignon next door which was killer too. About the soup... Im not a soup person really but WOW was it tasty! Super creamy, obviously lacking preservatives, not over-salted like most soups from the can, and went exceedingly well when paired with the bread to dip it in. It all tasted very fresh and clean and happy and would have even gone well as a sauce for chicken or something. Great for a cold blustery NYC day! And a large soup wasnt even that expensive... About $6 give or take depending what you get.We will absolutely be back - and soon! Making this place a go-to this winter! Peasant Stock is exactly what I had been told.  They're a small stand in the Essex Market, serving up some of the best soups I've had in recent memory.  You'll find them at the back left of the market, in a totally unassuming nook.  Every time I've been, it's been the same two women, and they're always super friendly.  You order, your order is served to you immediately and you can go sit at some of the tables in the general market area.  At this point, I stick to the same order.  I get the spicy veggie chili with a piece of cornbread.  The chili is hearty and filling.  It lives up to its spicy designation, providing a pleasantly intense heat.  The cornbread is a perfect compliment and is great for dipping.My only wish is that they had a brick and mortar location, rather than being in the sterile market.  Their soups make me wish I were sitting in an armchair, in a cozy caf.  Instead, I sit in a cold, open market as I devour my chili.  Hopefully they move to a standalone location soon though!  Peasant Stock is definitely worth the trip for some great soup at reasonable prices. In the back of the Essex Street Market lies a treasure beyond belief, Peasant Stock. Let me say that before I tried the soup here, I would only eat soup if I was sick. Now it's something of a tradition.I'll start with the product. They use the freshest ingredients and make their soups every morning fresh. I've had creamy roasted tomato basil, creamy potato leek, pasta fagoli, chicken and wild rice and so many more and they all (A) fill me up and (B) taste delicious. Oh and they are all affordable, which in this city is something quite rare. Oh again, this food is healthy for you, wow.Lastly, I will share with you the charm and spirit of Christine (the owner) and Emma (her daughter). They are so friendly and attentive to you. I've seen them both deal with their fair share of annoying customers asking for things so outrageous and time consuming that most people would lose patience for but not these two. They truly give you service with a smile, no matter how annoying and unruly you are (don't be a jerk and take advantage of that).I guess in summation you could say I rather enjoy this establishment and I will be going back on a regular basis as should you.Sorry, Peasant Stock. They only let me give out five stars. Had lentil soup for lunch and it was good not great. It was over run with lentils and really could use salt and pepper. Price is good..but go the bakery for super quality dipping bread. Simple, delicious and beautiful. I got the cream of broccoli soup today. What a treat when the weather is nasty

This is a such a cute little restaurant. I like the homey feel to it. Their food is delicious and very authentic. I tried their black linguine with seafood...it was very tasty. Mussels, clams, shrimp, salmon...a great combination. Complimenti alla cuoca! They also have great service. They seated us very quickly, even though we were few minutes late for our reservation. That's a plus. The waiter also stopped by our table a few times and refilled our water without us having to ask...verbally or through trying to make eye contact with the waiter to get their attention. That can always be a bit annoying. Bravo to the service!Definitely plan to come here again. Next time I'll try their sauted striped bass. Imagine this - its winter in NYC and we are in the midst of a deep freeze.  I'm traversing along Mott Street, looking for a warm place to sit and put food in my grumbling belly.  The wind is unforgiving, I'm pretty sure my fingers are frost bitten.  Chapped lips and wind burned face...I look into a window and see a welcoming intimate restaurant.  BOOM - inside Pepe Rosso Social.  I arrived on a Friday with my mom and fiance after a morning of some sightseeing on what was probably one of the coldest days of the year.  We were given a table and some menus.  This place is just DARLING, from the tin roofs to the exposed brick walls.  Its very cozy and romantic and I could imagine Loretta Castorini and Rony Cammareri enjoying the black fettucine in a corner with a glass of lambrusco.We ordered a liter of red wine and the calamari appetizer.  They brought out some bread in a cute metal colander and some olive oil and balsamic vinegar.  To say we housed the bread would be an understatement.  I ordered the oxtail pappardelle, my fiance the penne vodka with chicken and my mother the chicken al limone.  My pappardelle was to die for. The pasta is definitely home made and the soft tender pieces of oxtail we so well seasoned and tasty that I could easily eat that every day for a week.  We topped our meals with some cappuccinos and the ricotta cheesecake with amaretto crust.We left the restaurant happy and well fed.  What a great gem this restaurant is. A little disappointing for sure. I spent weeks planning our trip to NYC and this stop was not fulfilling. Fellow Yelpers have rated it high but our experience was blahh. I'm Italian and it's always hard to satisfy me when dining within my culture. Here's what was poor: shell steak was horrible. Full of fat and gristle and could not chew.. They made it right by taking it off our bill and giving us an alternative. The chicken limone was satisfactory. A little too much lemon rind flavor. The pasta dish that I had was not even on par for being homemade. The marinara did not stand out and was a bit slimy and bland. The desserts saved the experience. Nutella tiramisu and ricotta cheese cake. Also our waiter was very helpful and nice. He never made us feel uncomfortable even though he knew that we were not very happy. There are definitely more authentic places. Do your research. I had fond memories of Pepe Rosso both from To Go, which I frequented when I lived in Soho, and Social, which I had been to only once before. After our original Nolita plans were scuttled (Uncle Boons and Rubirosa, when will you cool off enough for me to come!), this was a reliable back up. We had no problem walking in around 7 on a Friday, though those arriving after us had to wait.Decor is nothing special but there was a festive atmosphere. The menu, though well-priced, is a visual monstrosity-- someone should offer their graphic design (and web) services as an act of charity.I had a glass of white, which was shockingly good for its price of $8. My boyfriend's glass of $9 red was also decent. I wish they served it in something other than water glasses, though.We started with the mushroom bruschetta ($10), which was great. It was truffle-y without tasting artificial or overwhelming. Nice cheese.For mains, I did the black fettuccine with shrimp ($18), and my boyfriend did the pappardelle with oxtail ragu ($17). The texture of both was on point-- fettuccine was a touch softer than al dente (which I like), and pappardelle was soft and great. The spicy tomato sauce on mine was perfect (though too much in quantity), and the ragu was good, though they could have been more generous on the meat. The shrimp was really blah, and I didn't want to finish it.They seated us by the door, which really ended up sinking this occasion for me. Lots of people coming and going, and they never even closed the velvet curtains, so we were in the cold most of the second half of the meal.Pacing of the meal was not great-- we waited quite a while for our wine (20+ minutes). In addition, we asked for the check when they were clearing our plates, and about ten minutes later a guy wandered over offering us dessert menus, though we managed to get the check after that. Given how slow things had been, we ended up slightly overpaying with cash so we could get out of there. We were really cold. It ended up taking about an hour and a half. I think they may be overwhelmed with trying to run Cantina downstairs as well.The food is good and cheap(er) for New York, and I like how they're trying to do it classic with some attitude. But thinking back to how we were literally wearing our coats in the restaurant, I'll skip it in the winter. Every time my boyfriend and I are trying to figure out what the heck to eat in this glorious melting pot of a city, I know one thing is certain--I ain't picking Italian. Now, don't get me wrong, I LOVE me some Italian food, but for some reason, *most* places I've tried in the city have just been mediocre in that effing-a-I-totally-could-have-made-that-at-home-myself-goddammit-dafkjdl;fjads;lfjadslkfj kind of way so I'm never one to suggest it because who wants to spend $$ on something they can make for like 5 buckaroos at home? So when my boyfriend told me he was in the mood for Italian and wanted to check out Pepe Rosso Social, I of course served him some major side-eye.I totally regret doing so now because hot damn, the food at Pepe Rosso Social was freaking DELISH and I sure as hell couldn't make any of the things we ate. We started off with the Fried Calamari + Zucchine and the Wild Mushroom Truffle Bruschetta, both of which I would order again in a heartbeat. The calamari and zucchini were lightly fried (which I much prefer over deeply fried) and perfectly salted while the bruschetta was just super flavorful and tasty. I then had the Penne Tre Porcellini (but opted for the fresh fettuccine instead) and oh my gosh, it was creamy, meaty, carby perfection (giggity). I couldn't get enough of the pancetta, prosciutto and my favorite of the three, the spicy sausage. Combined with the creaminess of the pasta, the dish was hands down one of the best Italian dishes I have ever eaten. My boyfriend got the Fettuccine with Wild Mushrooms + Truffle Oil which was also equally flavorful and delicious. While the food was absolutely fantastic, the service was unfortunately not and it is because of this that I have to give Pepe Rosso Social a 4. Several times during our meal when we finished our waters, we would ask our waiter for a refill only to be left with empty glasses until we asked a second time. Not only that but after we asked for a refill the first time around, every time we asked thereafter was met with a scowl. Now, I know that my boyfriend and I are some thirsty mofos and drink a lot of water, but we didn't think the negative 'tude was necessary. All in all, however, my boyfriend and I had a pretty dang good time at Pepe Rosso Social. Needless to say, I actually might be the one to suggest Italian to my boyfriend next time around. Cute little place and great for a date night! We got the octopus salad, chicken al Limone, and black fettuccine with salmon.Black fettuccine with salmon was probably my favorite. It was refreshing to have a seafood option for the pasta dish, other than shrimp or clams. The lemon chicken dish was pretty average with a cut of chicken and grilled veggies.Octopus salad had good chunks of octopus as well as sausage so that was a nice touch. Good service good food.We had tagliattelle mushrooms, gnocchi and mussels as starter.Everything was delicious and portions good.Love it!!!! After an early foot massage which I will discuss in a following review, my sister & I were ready for lunch/brunch. We walked a few doors down and stumbled upon this little gem. We were kindly greeted by Alpha, he was very warm and welcoming,  he quickly sat us in the the warmest part of the restaurant since, we were coming in from the cold. He immediately brought over the menu and he even suggested a few dishes for my question asking, inquisitive sister. I saw the brunch menu and immediately gravitate towards that, then even further eye opening some of the menu items begin at $4.99, say what?!?? In New York City, that seems impossibly unrealistic!!! Well it was real & I did order $4.99 brunch which included two eggs any style, toast, potatoes, and a salad. I added avocado for an additional $2. I also ordered the orange juice in which I asked Alpha, if it contain any alcohol because it was rather good and distinctive in taste. He assured me no alcohol was involved in the making, it was just good freshly squeezed OJ. I was totally satisfied with my super inexpensive meal. The house dressing was really good as well. The complementary bread and oil is a winner too. My sister ordered the chicken parm with penne, it was huge. The pasta was perfectly cooked & the sauce was delicious. Overall, solid place for really good pasta, sauce, & super inexpensive brunch menu. The place is cozy with cool rustic decor. The staff is friendly. Nice little recently discovered gem that I will return to often with friends. Found this place on Yelp as, for some reason, I don't have a go-to Italian spot when people visit. But I'd like to think I've got a go-to now until I find a better one! (!) WHAT I GOT: Penne tre porcellini ($17); fiancee and her friend got a pappardelle each ($17). Also, free bread. (Free-ninety-nine).(!) HOW IT DID: If we're talking about ordering choices, I won this time. I enjoyed my dish more than my fiance's pappardelle. The penne tre porcellini has small penne noodles with pancetta, prosciutto and spicy sausage. Cream sauce was delicious, and my only regret is that I didn't take more meat with each bite as I had a LOT more meat at the end hehe. Pappardelle had oxtail ragu, and, by itself, was great... just didn't compare to my dish hehe. (!) HOW THE FREE BREAD DID: This deserves its own note because Italian places usually hook you up with the free bread. I ran some experiments and they *do* give you more free bread if you ask. However, it's just plain ol' bread it seems. It's not toasted or anything and we didn't ask for any butter... but they do give you the olive oil and balsamic vinaigrette combo. Big ups for that.(!) SEATING: A fair amount of seating inside the restaurant--it looked pretty empty when we came in around 7:30ish as walk-ins. They asked us if we had made a reservation and said they could make room. As far as I could tell, they didn't seem too booked up haha. (!) TIDBITS: It's a nice, quirky little place with great ambience. Overall, you can't go wrong coming here. If you're reading this, by the time of this writing they have Yelp Reservations, so feel free to save your spot there. Overall a nice environment for 1, date night... or 2, a nice place to catch up with friends. Pasta the way it should be done, simple, al dente, and with enthusiasm (the menu is really cute, tells you there's no Diet Coke, no skim milk, no decaf coffee, only good food!).The first time I came I got a special with penne pasta, mushrooms, and salmon with a garlic & olive oil sauce. Not my fave but it was a special and I did substitute artichoke for mushrooms, so I probably wasn't getting the full flavor experience! They were very accommodating to the substitution - but after this, pasta dishes shouldn't be messed around with imo :pI LOVED my friend's agnolotti with pear, mascarpone, and walnut in butter & sage sauce. Big generous pieces of agnolotti and the flavors of the fillings were just perfectly paired with the simple sauce.We also shared a classic mozzarella, tomato and basil bruschetta. Super fresh tomatoes, large piece of crunchy grilled bread, and divineeee chunk of mozz! Worth it.For dessert, my friend and I checked in on yelp for the free dessert, we opted for the berry panna cotta and it was everything we didn't know we needed, creamy and only slightly sweet, perfect with the homemade tart berry jam!Today I stopped in for their $10 lunch special that comes with daily soup or salad and a limited choice of pastas/paninis. I actually ordered the rigatoni with eggplant and ricotta but they gave me rigatoni in vodka sauce with pancetta, tomatoes, and arugula (on the menu this dish was stated as with penne). I took one bite, realized it wasn't what I ordered, but decided not to change it because it was delicious (plus I didn't want to waste food). I'll just have to come back another time! I chose soup and today's special was a very simple minestrone with tons of vegetables, the mild soup balanced the flavors of the saltier and creamy pasta. The pasta was perfectly al dente and ughhh so good!Service has always been great here, I informed them of the messed up order after I paid and told them it was delicious anyway and my server offered me coffee which I declined, but how nice! Pasta here is CLASSIC Italian style and their lunch special can't be beat. The portion was great, it may look small but was super filling! I'll be back for sure. This is my favorite restaurant in Little Italy - prices are reasonable, the service is great, and the food is incredible. The complimentary bread they provide is soft and filling, especially since they refill the basket when empty. The pasta is the best I've ever tried so far in NYC - we had their penne tre porcellini (pancetta, prosciutto, and spicy sausage in cream sauce) and clam linguine. The pasta is cooked al dente, and the sauces, meat, and seafood complemented the two dishes perfectly. The restaurant is dimly lit, cozy, and romantic, making this a great place for a date. Also loved that the entryway was filled with potted plants and succulents, giving off a warm and welcoming feel. I have been visiting the Sullivan location for many years and since we were in Lil Italy tried their other location for a change rather than another well known place nearby. We were a larger party and got seated very quickly and service was spotless. The food overall was good, probably not as good as their other location, but was good. We had a diversity of plates and the majority, except for one plate (lamb), came out well.The only negative we fell in with was the use of the Yelp app. It provides for a free desert per couple and I tried redeeming it and was told that it wasn't for Friday's. The app didn't say anything but I wasn't going to argue. Additionally I related there were three Birthdays in the group and still nothing. I'm surprised since usually I get treated better in the latter location, even if they are half the size. I'm not one to ever make a bigger deal over things, but wish there would have been a better personable experience for an out of town customer that visits so frequently. Overall a great location with good food, but I still prefer their Sullivan spot for better tasting food. Arrived around 8:30 on a Thursday and we were able to be seated immediately, which was nice. However, it was absolutely BOILING inside - it was an exceptionally hot day and all of the windows were open so obviously AC wouldn't have been efficient, but seriously when it's that hot close the damn windows and crank it. My friend and I ordered a bottle of Lambrusco ($34) and it was served to us in, like, water glasses, which was just bizarre. And yes, I know Lambrusco can be served in tumblers but that's not what these were. Did the restaurant not have proper glassware? Very strange. It was also chilled more than it should have been. For such a cheap bottle of wine though I can't complain too much.We shared the fried calamari and zucchini to start, which I didn't like at all. The calamari was really, really chewy and not tender at all, the breading was kinda gross and soggy and the whole thing was too salty. For our entrees, I ordered the Penne Tre Porcellini (pancetta, prosciutto, and sausage in cream sauce) - $17, and my friend had one of the nightly specials, which was gnocchi in a pesto sauce - $19. In this place's defense, the pastas were delicious and the one thing they did right. However, portion sizes were, as many other Yelpers have said, fairly small. I wasn't starving so it was okay, but definitely a lot smaller than I'm used to for Italian. For dessert, we split the flourless chocolate cake (free with a Yelp check-in), which was very, very MEH. I expect flourless cakes/tortes/whatever to be really dense, and it was oddly not. It honestly tasted like regular chocolate cake from a mix. Service was fine, but not enough to earn a third star. TL;DR: Excellent pastas but rather small portions. No other reason to come. Will not return. I came here with a friend and I was satisfied. The service is really good and they aren't overbearing even though its a relatively small restaurant. We ordered the calamari and it was delicious. I order this almost every time and this was one of the best i had in a while. The waiter recommended the Penne Vodka and he was right. It was absolutely delicious!!! I would rate it among the best Ive had and comparable to pasta I've had in Italy. I brought Chicken Milanese back for my boyfriend and he enjoyed it. I also had their Nutella Tiramisu and it was delicious. It wasn't overwhelming. However, the only reason this place didn't get a five star is my personal preference for creme brle. Theirs is a lavender creme brle and the taste of lavender is extremely overwhelming. Made it borderline unappealing. However, I would highly recommend this place. This little place ticked away on Mott street is delicious!The service here was very kind, personable, and professional. This is a small little establishment. Reservations may be needed during peak hours. The service is excellent. Greeted us upon arrival, seated us right away, had drinks and appetizers on the tables very quickly.The food had great flavor! Exactly what you would expect in authentic Italian food. Unfortunately, they don't have their liquor license. So beer and wine only....no limoncello,'if you are into that. :)Pricing is very affordable too. Nice little ambiance and Italian decor. So really good food, great service, affordable pricing, and a nice environment....we would definitely come here again. I came here on a Friday night and it was definitely busy. We had reservations for 8PM but they don't seat you until your entire party was there. We were waiting on one friend for a while but they were still very accommodating and let us sit 30 minutes past our time. It is a small place on the upper level and apparently there's a lower level as well. We started off with some appetizers for the table. The pear salad and the mushrooms with bruschetta were very tasty. I ordered the papardelle with oxtail ragu which i liked. It very much so tasted like oxtail but the sauce could use a little more flavor. The pasta was well cooked and that's super important to me. Three of my friends had the fettucini with mushrooms and they thought that was pretty bland and the pasta was undercooked. Price was actually surprisingly decent. With appetizers, a bottle of wine and our entrees, it came out to $35 pp including tax and tip. All and all, it's an OK restaurant but you can definitely do better in Little Italy. Came here with a buddy today because this place has great reviews. The food is excellent, but I really wish there had been a review that touched on the price to potion ratio. I was pretty disappointed to learn that the bowls are pretty small... I hadn't expected to pay $17 for a relatively small dish and ended up eating a ton of bread to make up for it! That said...I ordered the pappardelle oxford ragu (again, $17) and thought it was very tasty. There's a good amount of rich sauce which isn't too tomato-y, and the meat flavor from the oxtail isn't too strong. Noodles were cooked al dente, so that was nice. I had to pace myself to not devour the entire dish in just a few minutes. My buddy had the penne porcellini (which is penne pasta with pancetta, also $17) and also really enjoyed it.We were also the only ones in the restaurant at 12pm on a Saturday, so we had the server's sole attention. He was very knowledgeable on the different pastas. All good at the end of the day, but know that the dishes are on the smaller side! I love this place! It's a very strong 4.5, but they do have great, friendly service that isn't overbearing, so I'm bumping it to 5 stars.The food is delicious! I've had quite a few different things here. Scallop special: awesome! The scallops were cooked well. Buffalo mozzarella: nice start to the mealOxtail ragu pasta: this is dynamite. My first bite was electric and had my taste buds tingling. Agnolotti: delicious! It's obviously ever so slightly sweet from the pear filling. I personally wished that the dough was rolled thinner since in the crimped parts where the agnolotti is closed, it's a bit thick with dough. Chicken a lemon: delicious. I didn't try the chicken aspect, but the lemon sauce was zesty and zingy. Tiramisu: I'm not a fan of tiramisu, but theirs was delicious.Complementary bread: I wish their bread was more rustic and had more texture, but this was complementary-so no complaints! It was my first time to this place, I brought my friends here and everything went really well! I love my lobster linguine, it was delicious with that spicy tomato spice. Their bread was pretty tasty as well, since I like soft bread more! It's really good. Every time I will try the black spicy pasta. I'm sorry I forgot the name but I have photos of it :D The appetizer with tomato, cheese, and ham is also very delicious! Please try it!Good vibes for friends dinner.

A year later, and Petee's Pie is still damn delicious. Petee's was at the top of my list to re-visit on my short trip to the city, and bless the pie gods, I made it. I once again ordered their chocolate chess, and it was every bit of heaven I remembered. Ten days later from my visit (12/30/2017), and I'm still thinking about it. I was close to ordering a full pie to go, but against my better judgement, I didn't, and I regret it to this day. I fully recommend ordering a chess pie (their speciality) on your visit, and definitely consider taking one to-go for friends/family/loved ones, near and far. TL;DR: Life is short, eat Peete's chess pie! If you're craving good pie, go to petee's pie company! There's a reason it's so popular. Their pies are amazing.I got a key lime pie slice for $7 and it was the perfect blend of tangy and sweet. My friend got warm apple pie a la mode. The place is small, so it might be hard to find a place to sit and eat your pie. I ended up eating mine right on the counter, but that didn't take away from how delicious the pie was! The wild blueberry pie is amazzzzinnnnn.I went at the worst possible time (the day before Xmas) around 1pm, and they only had a few pies left for the day.  But I was lucky enough to get the last wild blueberry pie.  The whole pie is not cheap, but ok for a treat once in a while. I'm shocked I haven't left a review here yet because I come so often. This place absolutely rocks and is what I love most about some nyc restaurants, specialization. They don't have a gigantic menu of a million different things like some places and make what they're best at, pies, and certainly they deliver. Have had both the savory and sweet pies and they're both very fresh with great ingredients. A must if you're even remotely into pies. They are solid pies and the people behind the counter are very sweet, and the shop is extra quaint for it's LES location, but I just thought the pies were OK.I got a slice of apple, pumpkin, and sweet potato. And they were all fine enough, but they didn't blow me away. I've both homemade pies and store bought pies that were better. The apple pie in particular was more tart than I care for (but then I'm a fan of sweet apple pies). The price point is also high for what you get, 3 pieces cost me around $17. Ouch! It's a tiny shop with limited seating, plan to grab and go. My boyfriend and I came here late on a Sunday night. The pie shop is pretty small, but there were people ahead of us getting pie to go, and two other diners eating inside. We ordered the apple pie and got vanilla ice cream to go with it. The pie was served hot in a matter of minutes. It was delicious paired with the cold vanilla ice cream. We loved the flaky pastry and soft pieces of warm again contrasted with the vanilla ice cream. However, the pie itself wasn't the best. Nice to try once, but nothing amazing. The ambience here is wooden and simple. It's very small inside with limited seating, so probably best to get takeaway. Loved this place! I tried the key lime pie and the classic apple and both were amazing. Highly recommend having the apple warmed up with ice cream. The crust was so buttery and flakey. The place Is very small with limited seating so we had to stand to eat but that didn't bother me. Well worth the quick stop in, highly recommend! Petee's is a small mostly to-go pie shop in the middle of Brooklyn. I say mostly to-go as they have like 3-4 seats against a small counter.Ordered their famous chocolate chess pie. It can be described as a slightly undercooked brownie. And that's truly accurate, but for a pie, it's extremely dry and almost tasted flourless . The better variants of Chocolate chess pies are hybrids of chocolate chess , plus other flavors. Legendary 'Big Wayne' pie from Gus's famous fried chicken comes to mind. It's a cross between pecan pie and chocolate chess and has a more silky buttery flavor. Pie was too dry for my liking but is undeniably probably healthier. Very delicious pies and extra points for being open late. This is a perfect spot to take care of your sweet tooth after a dinner in East village. I had the coffee cream pie because chocolate and banana were out. Was very delicious. One star off for being a pretty expensive slice $7 for a very small slice. These aren't thick pies so the slice was small. Also very limited seating. Overall will be returning and trying their other flavors!RIP Diet. Dear God... Possibly the best Peach & Banana Cream pie slices I have ever tasted. Sooo the many reviews here don't lie. The quality of these pies are phenomenal to say the least, all of my decadent sweets pies will be coming from Petee's for the holidays and just because life's better with a touch of sweetness anytime the mood calls for it. To elaborate...The Banana Cream pie is just as namesake says but not just any cream, I am talking about rich, fluffy, thick, melt in your mouth dreamy dairy creamy fresh with soft perfectly sweetened bananas, delicate and delightful so much so that you'd want to slather yourself with it and I guarantee your lover would love you even more! The Peach Pie is a mouth watering pleasure, each delightful bite was a taste of treasured goodness, succulent perfectly sweetened peaches and the butter rich crust baked perfectly. You just can't go wrong here. I ordered two small dairy dreamy creamy and lovely cups of their maple whip cream, talk about a delicate balance, this blew me away. The maple flavor is delightful to the taste buds tantalizingly sweet making the whip cream a total pleasure so much so that we ate this by itself never dolloping on the Peach slices as we intended. I Highly recommend everyone to go try a slice of your favorite pie 1st, guaranteed you'll be back for more, then order a whole pie online for a $5 discount. You can thank me later. Wow, how could I not have known about this place for so long?  Rather, I think I had a bookmark for a while but forgot to check and I immediately regret it.The warmed coconut custard was nice and went very well with a scoop of ice cream.  Albeit the slices are probably more expensive than the other desserts you find nearby I think this place is definitely worth it.  The two employees I met were great - friendly, helpful, and accommodating.  Unfortunately, I have a bad habit of forgetting new names almost immediately.The only downside is the seating availability is poor; there are only a few seats against the window and on a busy night they will most certainly be occupied.  But if you have the luck or patience to wait for a seat, it is absolutely worth your time to heat up a slice and slowly enjoy each soothing bite complemented with a cold touch of ice cream.Temporary Recommendation: Coconut custard pie a la mode Sooo I'll be honest - I'm not much of a pie person.  My dessert of choice is definitely of the "anything chocolate"-variety and/or soft serve. So I don't really go out of my way to eat pie.  That being said, I was pleasantly surprised with our options at Peetee's Pie Company.  Being the chocolate fiend that I am, my fave was definitely the salted chocolate chess pie although to be fair - it tasted like a slightly undercooked brownie. The blueberry pie was also very tasty, but all of us agreed that it would have tasted so much better if it was warm.  We didn't ask them to heat it up so I'm not even sure if that was an option.   TIP: Ask them to heat up the pie and don't miss the homemade ice cream on top! I've been waiting to try this store for a while. I love key lime pie, but it's not a particularly easy find in NYC.  I'm biased towards the key lime pie version that has the traditional graham cracker crust with whipped cream.  Petee's version has the baked Alaskan marshmallow topping instead.  The crust is also different, almost a granola base offering some nuttiness to the taste.  The four star rating is not because the slice wasn't great, it's because it's not the version I love.  All in all, the overall flavor was good.  I would come back to get a key lime fix. I visit this adorable little place when we had some extra time to kill and we were in the area. I planned on simply peeking in because pies are really my go-to dessert. But everything smelled and looked so good I couldn't help myself! I went with an oatmeal cookie and a slice of black bottom chess pie. Both ended up being fine, but not quite sweet enough for my tastes. I guess pie places still aren't my thing. Pretty neat place on the Lower East Side. They specialize in pies and it's pretty damn good pies. There are so many different types of pies, that you can easily get overwhelmed. The guy behind the counter was pretty cool with helping you decide which slice to get. They had a seasonal slice which he said was great but alas, I'm obsessed with chocolate. So I went with the slice, that is his gf favorite. Definitely wasn't disappointed. It was a decedent slice. The whipped cream had a salty aftertaste which was a cool way to cut through the sweet flavor of the chocolate. $7 a slice is pretty hefty, especially when the slices are tiny as well. But spot on flavor. Definitely worth visiting. Tiny little pie shop on the lower east side with a good selection of pies. You can order by the slice and sit at the small stools by the window and get coffee & tea too. Flavors change quite a bit, but you can't go wrong! Remarkable rotating menu is something to look forward to. Small place with very limited seating so best to just pick up a pie and enjoy at home. Pies are glorious! Crust is simple, buttery and flaky.  Fillings are not too sweet and there are some interesting flavors. Mmmmm!  You can order little individual sized pies.  They have several traditional, seasonal, savory & ice box pies to enjoy. I've tried the Apple Pie, Peach, Sour Cherry and Blueberry but my favorites are the Banana Cream Pie and Lemon Meringue. Top it off with some ice cream or whip cream and get one step closer to dessert heaven! I was craving some wild maine blueberry pie and since I couldn't visit this year, I found petee's. We also got the banana cream pie which was so delicious!!! Cant wait to try their chess pies...which apparently is like a custard pie but more firm in texture.Just go. We went right when it opened and already 2 people came in right after me. Pie is usually not my top choice of dessert to get but today I wanted to try something new.  I have walked by this place so many times and today I finally stepped in and I'm so glad that I did.  The aroma of the fresh pies when you step foot into the door is amazing.  It just makes me want to try everything, but we controlled ourselves and only ordered two slices, the peach blueberry and the brown butter honey pecan pies.  The peach blueberry is a seasonal flavor recommended by the staff.  Its definitely flavorful but personally I think the blueberries overpowers the peach.  You can only taste a hint of the peaches.  The crust was also really flaky and before we took a bite, the pie was falling apart already.  This would have tasted a lot better if it was warm and if it had some ice cream with it.  The brown butter honey pecan was definitely my favorite of the two.  The sweetness level and the texture was great.  The filling's texture is almost like jello and it just melts into your mouth and it goes well with the crunch of the pecan and the crust.  Definitely want to come here to get this for thanksgiving. I placed an online order for some Thanksgiving Day pies. I received an email the day before giving me instructions to the tee on pickup guidelines and best practices which I found super helpful. I arrived on time. My pies were packed and ready. I was offered homemade maple whipped cream as an accoutrements to my pies. I would've purchased it if I hadn't already spent $95 on pies I'd never tasted. Another $7 was out of the question. The pies are soooooo gooood. You know how sometimes apple pie can be undercooked in the middle? Even if you reheat it, it isn't the texture you want it to be? The harvest apple is nothing like it. It's smooth and the perfect consistency straight through. The apples aren't too mushy or too crisp. I'm a fan of sour cherry and Petee's doesn't disappoint. The crust on both pies are buttery, but each crust is different. I'll definitely be back. If you walk in to any party with one of these, you'll be getting compliments on your contribution by all who partake because these confections are truly impressive. We had a hard time spotting this place. Actually passed it up! Needs some better signage or lighting. I will say the aroma when you walked in, was heavenly! It's a really tiny place, but has many pies! We took a few home for the family! I had the coconut custard that was really delicious! We ordered banana cream pies (slices) and salted chocolate chess pie. Tried the pecan pie as well! Very good! The girls in there, were supper nice and friendly.

I went here by myself on the New Year's Day because I was craving pho and had nothing else to do. Despite many restaurants being closed on New Year's Day, I was happy to find out Pho Grand remained open. I liked how Pho Grand offered many meat options. It's cool that they offer even the organ meats, but if you don't like them, be careful when you're ordering. Make sure to look up the names of the parts so you don't end up with something that you don't want to eat. One of my favorite place to get pho in the city. convenient location, close by grand st subway station.Beef is fresh, broth is good. Definitely recommended when you in the area. Two stars for the food. Nothing special that would top other Pho spots but not bad at all. Service receives zero stars if allowed! Came here on a Saturday around 7pm because 99 hot pot had a 3 hour wait, I should've waited. Entering the place was pretty dead besides possibly 3 other tables. Party of 2 seated by ourselves. Was quickly thrown menus right as we sat down. Ordered a small pho, spring rolls and a chicken patty rice dish. My friends rice dish came out the same time as the spring rolls. I've finished my share of spring rolls and my friend is already 75% done with her meal, then my pho comes. From the moment I received my pho, the waiter hovers from a table away. The whole time I'm eating I feel someone staring a hole through my head. Not the feeling you would want while shoving food at your face. Not a mere second after my friend finishes her food, the waiter rushes over to scoop up the plate. Same happened when my friend picks up the last piece of spring roll and rudely asks if she still needed the fish sauce... well damn! can't a girl have sauce for her spring roll?!? Same after I was done with my pho. Wasn't even in the restaurant for more than 25 mins... was tossed the bill like they really needed us out. There is another Vietnamese restaurant down the block take your business there if you aren't trying to beat someone in a food race. Decent spot for pho. Typical no-frills decor, but more attractive than I was expecting. Maybe a quarter full at 6:30 on a Sunday.I went with the #9 small pho, with eye round beef and brisket. I got my toppings within a few minutes and my pho within five. Service in general was very responsive.A lighter, aromatic broth, with a healthy portion of beef and lots of noodles. The eye round beef was pretty good; the brisket was subpar. The noodles were fine, though I spotted a few strands with different widths-- what's up with that? One note is that the toppings are just bean sprouts, thai basil, and lemon-- no jalapeno, cilantro, or lime. They do have all the standard sauces though.My pho was around $7, or a ten dollar bill to cover tax and tip. This won't be the best Vietnamese you've ever had, but I found the price to be fair and the experience quick. Going to give them 4 stars for being nice even though the food is more like 3 stars. I splashed myself with some sauce and one of the waiters quickly appeared with a small bowl of soapy warm water. Anyway, I digress...I came in alone and ordered like a fat kid on death row or Pete Wells on a research trip. I raised some eyebrows but they still humored me.Banh cuon (steamed rice rolls with ground pork)was disappointing because there was so little actual filling inside the rice crepe and the crepe texture was bumpy and dry instead of smooth and chewy. Cha gio (crispy spring rolls) were whatever too. Pho Tai was tasty but the noodles could have been springier. My fave dish was the sauted water spinach. At least they take credit cards here. Clean, soothing broth and tasty noodles, that's what I look for in pho. This relatively larger pho restaurant offers a variety of Chinese food items along with pho. And yes, they take card. Thank god, since most Chinese restaurants don't. It's a get-it-yourself type of restaurant, meaning you get your own spoon and chopsticks at your table. It's a nice change from having to constantly ask for utensils or napkins. It's convenient. Most importantly this place is not overpriced and super affordable! Great place for pho and shrimps with the head! Food was average. Not great but not awful; but the waiter insisted on kicked us out even when we weren't  ready to leave! How rude. I almost didn't even want to tip them. And can I mention this place is full of non Asians which to me raises a flag. Tourist trap much? I mean maybe this restaurant is the reject of waiting two hours for 99 favor hot pot next door, cause that was my friend and I'd first choice. I'm gonna have to pass on this place since the customer service wasn't remotely up to par and there are plenty of Vietnamese restaurants in Chinatown. I come here for the Pho, which is awesome. Great for a winters eve. A huge bowl of Pho (a plethora of basil and bean sprouts on the side), a beer, and an order of summer rolls (2) = $20 Maybe I should have ordered pho.But I ordered summer rolls and bun cha.  Both were incredibly bland and in no way reminded me of Vietnam.I'd go back to try the pho, just go give them the benefit of the doubt, but so far, no good. Pho Grand is conveniently next to the D subway exit  so it is easy to pop in for a fresh Vietnamese meal.  The shrimp  was incredibly fresh.  No surprise with a fish market next door.  We tried the Spring rolls and were pleasantly surprised with pork spring rolls .I opted for my soup to be chicken broth with shrimp and rice noodle.  Lovedit Always able to accommodate large parties which is what I love about this place. Pho and other foods comes out at lightning speed and delicious. It's sanitary, delicious, and always great. Love coming here for any and all meals! My sentiments towards Vietnamese food in NYC is tepid at best. Perhaps the standards of this reviewer are exceedingly harsh, but my eyes have seen the light, and these lips hath tasted what good soup ought to taste like. So what's the deal with this place? Well, they give lemons with your pho... so that's an automatic one star deduction. I don't care if lemons are the cheaper citrus, give me my damn limes... if you did, perhaps this spot would be up a star in this review.Due to the phenomenon of cultural appropriation (see Taylor Akin of "Stock" fame spew his nonsense in the instruction of the consumption of pho)... pho prices nationwide are rising at astronomical rates. If you could buy "stock" in pho, from a retrospective standpoint, it would have been a good investment to buy lotsa stock 5-10 years back (you'd be rich by now). And this spot has fallen victim to the pho price increases (as if NYC food prices weren't high enough as it is).What is considered a small or medium (in less generous jurisdiction) elsewhere is what a larger bowl of pho here will be. At least the broth is quite flavorful and the noodles aren't falling apart in the soup; they've been consistently served al dente and right in the friendly medium area as far as not sticking together too much and not being too separated.You could certainly do a worse job acquiring pho in the city (Pho Pasteur... blech). At least the standard pho here doesn't come with those rubber "meat" balls... but they could be a tad more generous with the beef distribution. Disgusting! Just found a hair in the food! The waiter even refused to acknowledge it is from their staff! Disgusting as hell. Tell your chef to wrap hair up before cook food! my favorite pho place in chinatown. I love their crispy spring rolls! service is very fast. two thumbs up! I ordered the no. 1 big bowl of pho. I have to say that this place is pretty good compared to the other place I tried here in Manhattan. The broth is nice and beefy, not too salty, and the noodles had a good texture. The price is great and you get a decent portion enough to fill you up. I would definitely recommend this place and would come back. Was not particularly impressed by my experience here. Although to be fair, I can't speak to the pho. I got:Spring roll (rice paper roll) - The version here has too much vermicelli filling in my opinion. If you looked at a cross section of the roll in the middle, it looks almost entirely of vermicelli with a tiny bit of lettuce on the edge. The peanut sauce is a great though, and covers up the overwhelming use of vermicelli. And the wrap was good, not too gummy or hard. Just wished they put better stuff inside the wrap.Pork vermicelli bowl - The version here was disappointing. Some of the grilled pork was sliced too thinly so after it got cooked it was too dry and hard. And the best pieces were fine but not stellar (the way some other versions I've had have been). Would also have liked to have more pickled veggies / other stuff (and less vermicelli). I heard from my friend that this was a pretty decent pho place in NYC. Coming from California and especially from San Jose, where Vietnamese dishes reign supreme, I already had high expectations for the bowl of pho that I was going to get from here. I was surprised at how affordable the bowls were compared to all the other expensive food places there are in NYC, so that was a plus for me. Unfortunately they didn't have my all time favorite bun bo hue, but not all Vietnamese restaurants have that. I got a normal bowl of pho instead and it was actually pretty delicious! My pet peeve was that there was a big sign near the register saying that this was one of the top 100 Chinese restaurants... which is strange since "Pho" is in the name of this place. Also, our waiter was also Chinese. This is likely a Vietnamese-Chinese fusion restaurant though, which did catch me off guard. The food was not enjoyable. I got the shrimp "pho" which basically was just shrimp and veggie soup. Super basic, nothing special. The vegetable dumplings were gross, don't get them. The veggie rolls were the o my thing I really liked but they were so small there wasn't much filling in them. I would recommend finding somewhere else to go if your looking for authentic pho, this isn't your spot. We were told upon asking that "everything has msg in it", by our very brash waiter o_OThe upsides?The food was cheapish and the dishes were humongous ($10 for a large saute chicken and vegetables that came drowned in some type of sweet sauce that wasn't mentioned on the menu and made what I thought was going to be a low calorie dish decidely not).Our party of 8 had no problem getting seated walking in without a reservation on a sunday nightWe were not rushed and we got a lot of entertainment from our waiters bizarre actionsThe downsidesObvious town our waiter was not the conventional polite server you would expect. Everything we asked for seemed to be a hassle for him and he got our orders wrongThe msg, duhThe food wasn't anything to write home aboutDon't ask the waiter to take a picture for you. Somehow it will come out really lean and horrible lookingThe atmosphere / decor reminded me of a cafeteria instead of a restaurant Average Vietnamese fare. Pho came out quickly but the rice noodles were overcooked and the beef cuts and soup were nothing to write home about. They also seemed very eager to snatch away your food the minute you take your utensils away from it, trying to rush you out especially on busy days. The restaurant is kind of ill designed that if you're within a meter or two of the door you're bound to get blasted with cold air in the winter despite their draft door.

My first time at Piacere was excellent! One of the best Italian meals I've had in NYC! Loved everything about our experience at Piacere! The restaurant feels inimate and cozy with the wood burning pizza oven in the back. The servers are very friendly. The arugula pear salad was a perfect appetizer! It had light dressing and tasted fresh. Loved the complimentary fresh focaccia and white bread with olive oil. All of their specials sounded amazing, but I went with the cannelloni. The cannelloni was absolutely amazing! The rigatoni with bacon and red sauce was also very very good! For dessert, the tiramisu was heavenly! It was full of flavor and was creamy. This place is outstanding! I look forward to my next visit! Side note: **ITS CASH AND AMEX ONLY!** Came here with a large group on a Sunday night. It has a rusty decor. The service was good. The wine and drink selection was a bit sparse. For food: - pappardelle with wild boar: best dish of the night. The pasta was done well and the boar wasn't too gamey. - seafood pasta: the clams wasn't fresh and taste a bit rotten. Don't order this  - sausage and mushroom pizza: tomato sauce was lacking but the crust was nice. It makes a nice snack or appetizer, but definitely not as a main course.  Tldr; mediocre food and drink. It's a nice place for a large group -- long tables, loud and decent service. I visited Piacere on Christmas weekend for a pretty late dinner. We were hungry, cold, and ready to eat. We had a reservation but it wasn't too busy. The restaurant atmosphere was a bit more casual than I thought. I was craving something really creamy and cheesy but the waiter said they don't make any pastas with a cream base, which is find. One of the few specials he offered that was not on the regular menu was carbonara pasta. So we ordered the carbonara and a pizza (Salsiccia Fung) with two beers. They mixed up our order and brought out the wrong pasta at first. We shared the pizza and finished it among the two of us before the pasta came out because it wasn't that big.The carbonara came out but the portion was pretty small too. So we ordered another pasta (truffle mushroom pasta). The carbonara had a ton of bacon! The truffle pasta I was a bit more disappointed with. Both dishes were not bad but not what we had expected it to be.Also, we got our bill and found out that Carbonara is $21.95??? We didn't know this when we ordered because it wasn't listed on the menu. I estimated it to be much cheaper because their other pastas, including seafood pasta, ranged from $16-20ish. Considering that all it takes for a carbonara is some eggs, pasta, cheese, and bacon I was shocked it was priced higher than their seafood loaded pasta. Also, please be aware that they INCLUDE gratuity on their bill (Which the owner says was a mistake on the waiters below..? - is this not more problematic?) We didn't catch this until later and ended up tipping twice. We spent a total of $140 for two people.. I don't mind paying the money for good food/experience but I'm unsure the experience I had was worth that much. They also only accept cash or American Express and have an ATM in the restroom. To be honest, didn't really enjoy my meal here. Everything seemed maybe 10-20% overpriced for what we were getting, and some of the dishes just weren't that good. I came with a group of 5 people and we ordered dishes family style b/c we wanted to try a lot of stuff, but some of the pasta dishes took SO long to come out and the portions were quite small. Highlights: - Parpadelle with wild boar ragu: This was actually amazing; perfectly cooked pasta in a delicious ragu sauce. It also came out almost instantly after we ordered it. - Seafood pasta: This was some kind of special. It came with tons of seafood and the tomato sauce it came in was really nicely seasoned. - Gnocchi: I'm not a huge gnocchi person but the other people at the table really liked it. It was extremely soft and the basil pesto sauce it came in was pretty good too. Lowlights: - Tomato bruschetta: Extremely overpriced and very meh. It was something like $8 for two pieces of grilled bread, tomatoes, and olive oil. Barely tasted like it had any salt or any other flavors. - Linguine w/ clams: All I could taste was olive oil. It didn't have any of the typical seafood/clam flavor that this pasta usually comes with. - Truffle/mushroom pasta: I forget the actual name of this pasta but it's the only one of the menu of this type. I recommend skipping it. It's pricey b/c of the truffles but there really isn't that much truffle flavor (or mushroom flavor, for that matter). It was just salty. Overall, I'd pick a different Italian restaurant in the area (there are so many!) over Piacere. We had dinner here on Christmas Day. Great little restaurant with good service and even better food. We tried a pizza and the boar pasta. Both were excellent. Came here on a Tuesday night. I did not have any issue getting seats but it was really hot inside the restaurant. Portion size was medium and the food was good. Reasonably priced. God this place is good. It's the one place we look forward to visiting most when we're in town to see family. The products are fresh, homemade, delicious. Awesome wine selection. You absolutely need to try their pizzas! And the service is great -- definitely feels like you're dining in a place where the owners care about giving you a great experience. Located in between Chinatown and Little Italy, Piacere is open very late, as in all the way until 2AM. Its primarily a wine bar, but they also serve really good Italian food. For my first pasta, I ordered the Taglierini porcini e tartufo. Its basically a Linguine-like pasta served with fragrant mushrooms and truffles in a olive oil and garlic sauce. This was so RICH in flavor!! I was amazed at just how much the mushrooms and truffles really added to the pasta.I was ravenous tonite, so I ordered a second pasta. I went with my favorite dish, the Linguine Vongole. Another superb job here as well, the clams were plentiful and had this nice, almost sweet and savory seafood like aroma to them. I also had a grapefruit soda. The soda left a sparkling water sensation :) Our last night in NYC, we wanted pizza and pasta but did not want a touristy spot in Little Italy. It was early, 6:45 on a Saturday night, so we got lucky and there was no wait. The place had a cool, laid back vibe and the staff was extremely friendly and welcoming.My husband and I had red wine the server recommended and our kids 5 and 8 ordered sodas, all they have are organic sodas so they both picked the ginger ale. It tasted more like ginger beer but it was good. We started with the beef carpaccio, it was very fresh and had a great flavor, my 8 year old daughter wanted a second order. We also ordered Quattro Formaggio and Margherita pizzas, a Rigatoni Special with onion and bacon red sauce, and linguini with butter. The Quattro Formaggio pizza was awesome, it's served with a spicy olive oil on the side that adds just a little kick. The Margherita was good but there was hardly any basil on it. Both pasta dishes were great, the noodles cooked perfectly al dente. The rigatoni special had a rich flavor, even the plain buttered linguini tasted fantastic! My only issue with the rigatoni was that the bacon pieces were not small and they were pretty much all chewy fat. It added wonderful flavor to the dish but I couldn't eat them. We were too full for dessert, we had to take half of the Margherita pizza with us. There are tables out front and the front windows slide open so it feels almost like one continuous space. The bathroom is cool, my favorite part was the mannequin legs tp holders. If you want fantastic Italian food without the over-the-top cheesiness of Little Italy, eat here. Great little Italian place; great food, helpful friendly staff and good for birthday parties! We had a large good there for a birthday and the team were very accommodating, helpful and with prompt service. I would defo recommend going for their starter platters and sharing! EEEExcelent pizza! WOW! Perfect thin crust. I had the San Danielle and my husband had the Calabrese. Both just perfect. The environment is cozy, but it's half bar, half restaurant.....and you can feel that. Not necessarily bad or good, just noting that it feels a little like a bar. The wine list could use some improvement tho. The bottle list was ok, but a little expensive, and there wasn't much of a selection for glasses. It was ok, but not amazing. Service was spot on tho. Overall a great little Italian place! :) Very tasty pizza.However, they didn't take anything except cash or American Express cards. Portion for pasta is pretty small. Also, bread was never served to us. Excellent. Dine al fresco or inside which is intimate (not so much by NYC standards). Beautiful wood fired pizza oven. Very friendly, accommodating service. Not fancy but slightly rustic, exposed brick, warm, longer communal tables, low lighting, classic Italian background music. The food however, is excellent. Nice wine list. Limited beer selection that could use a little revisit.We ordered a variety of appetizers. The Burrata w spec salad was exceptional, definitely not average. The smoked mozzarella w nice char, perfect balance of smoke, served w spec was delicious. The mixed salad with avocado was lightly dressed, ultra fresh, nice portion. Grilled octopus w potatoes was perfectly cooked, fork tender, nicely seasoned. But the real shining star was the wild boar porchini mushroom parpadelle. Which is sheer perfection, ultra rich.Craving to go back as they offer many things we wanted to try but were quite full, like the spaghetti w bottarga, chili & lemon, wild red snapper in banana leaf, and of course the wood fired pizza.If you crave authentic regional Italian dishes, not Americanized touristy Italian, then this is a must. *Very dark, strange quirky restroom. I stopped into Piacere on a really chilly night and was warmly welcomed into this adorable restaurant. I loved the decor, very welcoming with the brick oven in the back and I especially loved that you could smell the fresh herbs! ALSO everyone was Italian, not Brooklyn-Italian but real Italian! To start they had a good wine list (and reasonably pricedl). I had the pizza with peppers and onions which was really delicious, it was a very thin crust and you can tell all ingredients were fresh. I also had the broccoli rabe which had great flavor. My two notes are that the brocolli rabe had a lot of stems in it and probably could have cooked a touch longer and parts of my crust were a little burnt (but that didn't affect the flavor, just was a weird feeling in my mouth). I definitely would recommend it! Phenomenal little place. Cozy, comfortable family sitting. Food is absolutely wonderful. A lot of flavors. You leave feeling light and not heavy. My friend and I had pasta dishes - homemade pappardelle with wild boar ragu and house gnocchi with pesto. We had their special appetizer - calamari in a marinara sauce. Delicious!!! Went here for dinner lastnight. We had the Carbonara Pizza and the Margherita Pizza! Both pizzas were yummy with a perfect crust! They also had a Moretti Rossa on tap that was really flavorful. No wait for a table and our waiter was really genuine. Will definitely be back! Smaller Italian joint on the outskirts of Little Italy, they tend to be busy!  I really liked the rustic interior of the resto, nice bar & wood burning oven in back.. great date place.  Smallish beer list & larger wine, it seems to be family owned.  The menu is nice they have like a dozen pizzas, great appetizer list, many pastas as well as some secondi, salads & meat/cheese plates etc.  Tried the taglierini wild boar ragu and it was exceptional...Give it a shot  PS- Cash & AMEX Only! Rip off & avoid at all cost. Went with a group of 6. Service was awful, forgot to bring wine and we finally canceled, we had to ask for bread wth our food. Half the table received their meal, while the other half waited 15 mins. Over- priced meal. There are so many other good places nearby like Sauce.  And the music was terrible. No idea how this place has good reviews, it's a tourist trap with meh food. This is the best pizza place in town. The owners are super friendly & hospitable. This is a great place to come when it is freezing cold out. It was Christmastime and we were in Little Italy. As if that right there wasn't enough to make the night super magical, we decided to stop by this cozy, adorable little spot on Broome for a delicious pickup to warm us up. It was perfect! It was my first time ordering takeout via Eat24 right from the Yelp app. The whole process was super simple. The order was ready and waiting when promised and everything was piping hot and packaged securely. We split the gnocchi pomodoro and tomato pie. Oh deliciousness!!! We didn't make it out of this section of town before we scarfed it all down. So, so yummy! The place was so sweet and cozy. It had an underground feel to it. Dark at night with candles, rustic tables, exposed brick walls all which can be seen from the street through the floor to ceiling Windows. It was louder but not in a bad way. It was in a "this is a really great, fun atmosphere" way with wine glasses clanking and people laughing. It definitely made me want to return and actually dine inside next time. Good vibes. Oh, and they have outdoor seating as well in warmer weather.  The man handling the order which I picked up near the gorgeous wood burning stove, just past the inviting bar was very sweet and welcoming. Cash only except for Amex which I think is strange. Parking is what you expect. Luckily we were able to just double park and run in. I'm sure it's not a problem for most patrons as no one drive here, but we had our car on this particular trip to NYC

I came for brunch - the food was amazing, but it took 40+ minutes for food to arrive, and when it did, it was served separately. Had to wait an extra 20 minutes for the second entree to come. I came for the brunch and while it was pricey, the khao soi was excellent. Only suggestion I have is to prepare the food in a way so it's hot and fresh at the same time as everything else, so no one has to feel awkward when some people have food and some don't. As a tip, you do have to remind the staff a few times you're still waiting for food. Came here for my birthday. We were seated on time for our party of 8. This restaurant has plenty of space for big parties so that's a plus. Service was not the greatest however. Didn't check up on us much and the food wasn't served all at once. Sisig took another 20 minutes after all the other dishes were served so we didn't eat till it came.Quality of the food was overall satisfying. However, a side of longanisa was basically 2 pieces cut in half at $3 an order. It tasted more like nam rather than traditional longanisa. It had more of a sour/pickled taste rather than the usual sweet or spicy flavor. Sisig was right on. Savory and texture was done right. Papaya salad is different from the traditional style but in a good way. The taro was a great addition. Best meal was probably the jowl which was a great balance between sweet, savory and spicy. Steak and eggs was cooked perfectly and the sauce elevated the dish. Drinks were strong and mediocre on quality. It's been almost two months since I came here, so my review may be a bit hazy...but from what I remember I didn't leave this place feeling that full nor satisfied. It's a unique kick to Thai/Filipino cuisine, but I don't really see the hype. The portions were smaller than expected and although the flavor isn't something I experience regularly, I would have liked a little more 'sustenance' to it.Three of us shared the grilled pineapple salad (very sweet but didn't have more than 3 shrimps in it), the sizzling sisig (flavorful at first but got tiring), and a rice dish that I now can't recall. Otherwise, service was great and the dimly lit vibe is chill for a girl's night out! The 3 of us were here for a Bottomless Saturday brunch. We had made reservations for 11 and when we arrived the place was quite empty with only 3 tables occupied by other parties.
