And of course a nice salad to balance out the meal. And to drink? Kombucha spritz. HELLO! I love kombucha and I love that they made it into a fun little cocktail. If you're in for a cute and cozy brunch with some slightly heavy but oh so delicious filling food, this is your place. If Root & Bone is in your bookmarks or you are in-between choices and this spot is one I suggest you come here... If you are with a group, grabbing a bit by your self or with your partner the seating arrangements can accommodate you. Window seating kitchen seating or bar seating, where ever you are you will catch a glimpse of the decorative concept used to make this place pop. Food hits the spot. I had fried chicken tiny waffles collard greens and Mac and cheese. Portions are perfect and the prices for the items on the menu could not be better. I'm looking forward to my next visit I'd rate Root & Bone 4.5 stars. Root & Bone has been on my brunch bucket list for awhile. I finally got to cross it off!We ordered sticky buns and "Fried Chicken &Three." The sticky buns were gooey and topped with nuts. They were a bit too sweet for me (and I have a major sweet tooth) but enjoyable. Next up was the entree. The mac and cheese had a nice consistency--creamy on the bottom and breadcrumbs on the top. It was extra cheesy in the best way possible. The waffles were fresh but I wish they had a softer texture. The collard greens had a small kick of spice which livened up the flavor. The fried chicken was incredible--super juicy and the meat fell right off the bone.The server was friendly and checked in with us sufficiently. The place is a bit small so I wouldn't recommend coming with big parties. It's also a pretty popular place so to avoid a line I'd recommend coming during off-hours. This spot has been on my list for awhile, and I'm happy I finally got to try it! My friend and I made reservations for a weekday night, and it was still pretty crowded given it was a Wednesday, so reservations are highly recommended! The restaurant itself really isn't that big, tables are small and close together. We had made it just in time for Happy Hour, which was from 4-6PM. We got 2 chicken biscuits and drinks. The biscuits were juicy, filled with flavor, and a tad sweet from the honey. I wouldn't think I would love it as much as I did. In addition we got the Root & Bone Fried Chicken, half bird to share, and a side of mac and cheese. The chicken was juicy, tender and flavorful. Though, I would've preferred if the skin were a bit more crunchy. The mac and cheese was addicting. Definitely very heavy, but sooooo good and creamy. Overall, the food was impressive. It was my first time trying a Southern fried chicken spot, and I will definitely be coming back for more! There were so many great reviews here so I came to try to food, but extremely disappointing and mediocre food. I ordered the chicken and three, which comes with two pieces of fried chicken and collard greens, waffles, and Mac n cheese. Firstly the fried chicken was flavorless and not crispy at all. The waffles did not stand out either. They tasted like those waffles you get at a continental breakfast buffet in a hotel. The collard greens were okay. It had very korean cuisine flavors to it which was unexpected. To be honest, the Mac and cheese was probably the best thing that I ordered. It was creamy, cheesy, and delicious, although a tad bit salty. The honey tobacco sauce and maple syrup were okay as well. The customer service is great and the interior is rustic and cozy, but the food was just ok. I will probably check out other restaurants if craving fried chicken. I was really impressed by the quality of benedicts they served. It was the best benedict I have ever had in the city. The bacon on the side was crispy and meaty at the same time. Also, with the eggs on top, the waffles tasted very soft and delicious. This is the must menu that everyone has to order!Because I knew this place was a pretty hot place, I picked such a random time to visit. (around 3pm) Thankfully, there was no line and so I did not have to wait at all. So... if you do not want to wait for a long time, I would recommend you to go to this place around<U+200B> 3pm or 4pm. It's everything as described and more. Cozy spot, outgoing and accommodating staff. Had supper with the Ladies, we feasted on the pre-fixed supper. Where do I start?Our Hostess,She greeted us with a warm engaging smile, and sat us at the most quaint delightful table. Our Waiter,A polite, friendly smile, which might I add fabulous eye candy! He did not rush us, explained the menu to us, and made sure our courses were paced, and we were happy campers. He also knew the menu intimately, which was a wonderful plus. The Food,Where could they go wrong, no where!  The biscuits - OMG, the Fried Chicken ("Smack Your Mama Good!") The desserts - I'm a fan of the chocolate pudding. The People,Engaged with some of the most friendliest people in NYC.  The first table next to us was a couple, who offered for us to try their dish when we inquired as it looked so delicious. Btw, it was a grilled salad. Second couple next to us were visiting from out of town, and she said she smelled fried chicken in the air, and her nose lead her to Root and Bone. We recommended the Supper to them. Ambience,Yes, it is everything - simply put #FablousChic Root & Bone is just wonderful for brunch. I was most shocked at the portion size for price point. I hope they change nothing about how they do business. Don't change the way your staff is approachable and full of patience, the tastiness of your food nor the price for which you offer it all for. I have nothing else to say. We came here at around 7.30 on a Saturday without a reservation. The wait to sit inside was about an hour so after some deliberation (it was a sub 60 evening) we agreed to sit outside rather than try to find somewhere else. In all honesty we probably didn't take full advantage of what was on offer (notably the chicken). But what we did have was really rather good and worth braving the mild outdoor temperatures. I opted for the shrimp and grits, which was really good but ultimately just shrimp and grits. My wife's pork dish was excellent, covered in some sort of green crumb and the meat fell apart easily. The outdoor seating is rather exposed but luckily it was a quiet side street. The seating in general is quite close together. I also found the service quite slow, which may or may not be to your liking. I would have preferred more options on the menu as well - due to allergies I only really had a choice between the shrimp and the chicken. I would probably go back if I could get a seat indoors - mainly to try the chicken but also some of the sides A cute and cozy spot for some delicious food! It's a very small and intimate restaurant so It seems like it can get crowded. I came at 2pm with a friend and luckily we didn't have to wait too long to be seated. You're basically sitting elbow to elbow with the tables next to you, so it's not really a great place for big parties and whatnot. We ordered the drunken deviled eggs, the half bird to share, buckwheat waffles and a side of Mac and cheese and collars greens. The drunken deviled eggs were pretty too look at and pretty good but I'm not really sure if it's worth it cause of its portion size. The eggs were a bit on the saltier side though. The buckwheat waffles were my favorite! I liked how fluffy and thick the waffles were! The Mac and cheese was delicious. It was crusted with biscuit and thyme on the top and complemented the Mac and cheese very well!  The chicken was moist and very flavorful. I loved how it was crunchy and crispy on the outside but still very juicy inside. Overall, would recommend this place but def would recommend making reservations or coming right before they close for dinner. I visited this restaurant during Restaurant Week with a few friends from work.Overall, the restaurant is pretty small but they make good use of the space that they have. The dcor was very homey and country kitchen styled. The mismatched dishes used also kept in line with the country homey feel. If you want to have dinner I definitely advise you to make reservations but they always seem to be crowded.To start for drinks we had the spiked peach ice tea which was very good but not apart of their usual menu from what I observed. Not too strong or weak. For appetizers we ordered the drunken deviled eggs which looked almost too pretty to eat and grandma daisy's angel biscuits. The eggs were pretty but we definitely eat every last one. The eggs were delicious but I definitely expected more of the biscuits. With a name like that I expected the biscuits to be the lightest and flakiest biscuits I had ever eaten but they weren't. The biscuits were good but I wouldn't order them again. My friends ordered the fried chicken while I had the meatloaf big mistake. In my opinion the meatloaf was a bit dry and I wouldn't order it again. Or maybe I felt that way because I did get to try the fried chicken. The fried chicken is definitely their specialty and a must try if you ever visit this restaurant. The chicken was very flavorful and fried to perfection. I loved the chicken so much that I neglected the food I ordered and placed an order for the fried chicken to go. It was even more flavorful the next day in my opinion. I would definitely return to this restaurant in the future but I will stick to their specialty dish next time. Probably one of my favorite restaurants in NYC. We ordered the the whole bird fried chicken, Mac n cheese, buckwheat cheddar waffles, succotash, and a whole lot of drinks.The fried chicken was cooked to perfection and I never would have thought I'd like buckwheat waffles but I loved them! Wonderful service and a really beautiful atmosphere in be restaurant. Came here, partly because really wanted chicken and waffles and partly due to all the good reviews.My review is based mainly on the food.  The place itself is cozy, not much else to really say.We ordered, the pickled deviled eggs...These were to die for.  Soooo very good.  Then of course we had to have the chicken and the waffles.We got the basket of the whole chicken.  Overall the chicken was very crisp and moist.  Perfectly seasoned.The waffles on the other hand, were not good at all.  I think they flash burned them.  When I took a bite into one of them, they completely crumbled.  For a chicken and waffle place this is what some would call an egg on the face.Now for the not so good part.  I might be picky but I like attention to detail.  In so many restaurants when they first open up, everything is looked over several times.  When they get popular, the little things start to go.Basically, when we got the chicken, the first thing I reached for, was a wing.  This particular wing was not quite fried and I ended up chewing on breaded skin.  The rest of the chicken was perfectly cooked.Another small thing to some, but I felt was lacking was the fact, that they didn't bring an empty bowl or something to put the bones in.  Imagine sitting a small table with a bucket of chicken and just one plate.  Not very fun.  This is what I call attention to detail.Overall, I would be back and the food was good.  I would however skip the waffles, and the drinks while good, a bit pricey. I really wanted to like this place, esp since my bf recommended Root & Bone for their fried chicken but it just didn't live up to its hype. When we checked in the hostess said the wait would take anywhere between 1-1.5 hrs but the place looked pretty empty to us. We also were called in about 20mins later.. and when we got in there were at least 4-5 empty tables around us. The service today was pretty bad all around. We had to wait a while for our waitress to come pick up our card and check and because she took so long my bf walked up to the counter. The lady there asked if he could wait for our waitress to come to our table but we had already been waiting for a while. The food was also a tad disappointing. I expected the chicken to be crispy but it clearly was not. The flavor was there if you squeezed some lemon juice and dipped it in their Tabasco/honey sauce. We also ordered their biscuits and shrimp and grits. The biscuits were my favorite today but I wish they came out with the chicken, which I'm sure we could've asked for. The shrimp and grits looked and tasted more like scrambled eggs than grits.

This place was very busy, plus it's very very tiny, but the outing is not hard to miss including the "Round K" flag it's cute. I'm not sure if he was the owner or not but the man making the drinks was very polite and very quick with making the orders. I ordered a matte black latte which includes: Coconut ash(why it's black), coffee, almond milk and the coconut ash whipped cream as well! It was delicious and very cool to look at. Small, Korean themed cafe!Really nice and cozy inside. They had many drinks (unique flavors) in their menu but we got americano and latte. You need to order up front, they bring it to you. Then you pat up front as you leave.Also the place wasnt noisy at all; very comfortable to sit and talk. They had outlets to plug in if you need to charge anything. There were Korean traditional decorations here and there, and it really added to the unique cute atmosphere.Coffee cups are very cute as you can see from the picture. Will come back! Egg yolk cappuccino!! One of the more interesting and delicious cappuccinos I've had.  This drink was creamy and delicious and I would come back for this again.  The two men sitting next to my friend and I saw our order as they were about to leave but decided to sit back down and order one to try.This shop has limited bar seating in the front but more table seating in the back.  It's a cozy place to relax, although I wish the area in the back was brighter.  They also offer astronaut brewed coffee, but for $50 I probably wouldn't try it unless I had disposable income to splurge. This place is sooo cute. It's such a shame it's only located in Chinatown. Overall rating: 5Coffee Presentation : 5/5Waitstaff: N/AAtmosphere: 5/5Bathroom: 5/5Food: N/ALoudness: quiet I came here on a Thursday night around 7pm. It started getting crowded around 7:30pm. When you walk in, there's a counter with the barista inside and 6 (?) stools on the outside. It seems cramped at first but behind the curtain, there's more seating! I think there were 7 tables. The little couch chairs can be moved around so you don't have to be all cramped and squished. We ordered the matte black latte which was such a delight to drink! You need to go up to the barista to place your order. The bathroom decor was so cute and the theme reminded me of the 1940s era. Best little hidden gem. I was actually walking down the street in search of something else for dessert, but I was immediately drawn into Round K by the strong coffee aroma (seriously, the coffee smell outside is intoxicating!!). Although the cafe looks tiny from the front, there are a few tables tucked away in the back where you'll find people working/studying or just chatting and chilling. The whole cafe gives off cool, hip vibes and has a sort of warm and cozy feel to it at the same time.Since they were all out of the black matte latte, I decided to order the mocha instead. It was rich, smooth and had just the perfect amount of sweetness, which is something I've found that a lot of other cafes struggle with. The drink also came out in a lovely drinking bowl and had the cutest bunny latte art on top! What a nice surprise. Love the ambiance and drinks here. Definitely will be back to try other drinks and food. Round K's entrance is so unassuming and average you'll walk past it a million times and not think twice or even inquire about it. Guilty. As. Charged.They have plugs and a cozy but very dim sitting area in the back - dim like Gryffindor's common room. It's perfect for work or for catching up with friends; I spent a solid 3 hours chatting away with a friend and it was perfect, though I wished the tables were bigger/taller because my 5'7" frame kept hitting the table corners and plates! Drinks/The barista makes kawaii latte art like bear and rabbit if you ask him to (and they're served in the cutest tea party-ish floral cups)! We wanted to try the wasabi latte but it wasn't available that day. Food/All their eggs are made using the espresso machine! We ordered Mrs. Lee and Michelle's breakfast sets, each of which included a latte for an additional .50. Michelle's was lightly fragranced with truffle oil and my favorite of the two. Think American breakfast, but lighter and healthier versions.I'll definitely be back to try the egg cappuccino and the matte black ash latte! What a cute little cafe!  The cafe doesn't look like much from the outside or from the bar you're ordering from, but when you go past the bar you'll find the most quaint dining area.  A perfect spot for a coffee date or to hang out with your best friends for an afternoon pick-me-up.I came here from watching a video of an egg cappuccino.  It was intriguing and I'm all up for something new.  Once I got to the cafe, I did just that.  I ordered the egg cappuccino and was told to take a seat in the back.  There's a back?  What!  So I walk past the bar, through a curtained area, and found a hidden gem.  While waiting, I went to the bathroom to wash off subway germs and found the bathroom to be decorated in a traditional Korean house.  Exposed wood, decor based around tea, and a cute desk area that's purely decorative.  Being Korean, this was highly amusing. Once I returned to my seat, they brought out my beautiful cappuccino in a vintage looking tea cup.  The egg cappuccino is divine!  Its a little denser than the traditional cappuccino, and the egg white that is frothed into the milk gives it a meringue like consistency.  Its dusted generously with dark cocoa.  Definitely a sipping beverage.The seating is quite small and cozy.  Try not to bring a lot of stuff with you. Got the Egg Cappuccino,  pretty good but not hot enough. Doesn't taste the egg Yolk but taste good. I will try the Matte Black Latte next time. Relaxing, cosy and amazing coffeeshop!Hall in the wall, japanese style with super awesome tea cups.Love this place and it's not touristy at all! Great coffee shop tucked away in the lower East side. Don't by deceived by the appearance when you first walk in. Behind the curtain is hip cozy seating. We got a house coffee and a cafe latte to start. The cafe latte came with very cute foam art. The house coffee was delicious and when I asked for cream he came back with freshly steamed cream. All the dishes and cutlery we're beautiful. The attention to detail here is amazing. We ate the carb-less creation with avacodo and salmon, and an almond croissant which had been heated up. The eggs were so good. Seriously the best scrambled eggs I've ever had. They're made using the steam wand of the espresso machine and we're flavored excellently. The salmon as well had such a wonderful flavor. Be prepared it's salmon lox style. Just a great place to spend a cold day hiding away from the world. I did NOT have the "egg cappuccino" here. Egg cappuccino is Round K's specialty item, hearkening back to '70s Korea when dropping a raw egg yolk into your morning coffee was a super trendy health concoction. Think "bulletproof coffee" - we're all bored enough for the next revival fad, right?When I asked the guy behind the counter what "egg cappuccino" on the menu was, he flatly said "just egg yolk mixed with the coffee" with no recommendation whatsoever. That lack of endorsement is deterrent enough for me! I might try it in a country where chickens are not subjected to all manner of weird diets and dangerous living conditions and bacterial vulnerabilities. Not the US. Hello, salmonella.I DID have a regular latte here, which was too bitter and gritty and generally not made very well.The decor made up for it. Drinks are served in mismatched vintagey teacups, with tiny, flowery spoons. There's a secret feel to the cafe, since the petite booths are in a narrow space separated from the front counter by a heavy curtain. When I came by on a weekday evening, it was empty - perfect for relaxing, getting some reading done. Warning: table heights are uncomfortably low, so you probably won't stay too long.Cash only (edit 12/24/2017: per Yelp user Brady D, they now take card). Coffee prices are high - you're definitely paying for the "hipster Korean" aesthetic. Round K is a pretty cool spot centered around a pretty diverse menu option for a coffee shop. They got a few different types of tea and even some light foods. I couldn't give this place a full 5/5 because of the price and the portion. I had an iced tea, which was nothing like I expected. It felt like drinking a light syrup but it wasn't sweet at all, more like a grapefruit flavor. It was delicious and I could've had another cup or two, but for 3.50, and the cup being all of 10oz I wasn't about to do that. Same with the yogurt. It was great with a similar marmalade type of thing on top. It tasted good, and for 4.50, almost reasonable/ worth it. The cafe it self is really nice with a fair amount of seating. Although small seats themselves I think it'll make a decent hangout spot for a group of four or less. The staff is really nice though it's more of a "I already know what I want" kind of place. Asking for suggestions didn't get me anywhere. As a weekly regular Round K always returns the best cofee again and again. Their coffee's are all Americano based, espresso mixed with hot water, which is really the real deal, it always taste better than drip. They have a great vibe with brick walls, cool decor, and a cozy seating in the back. You can even pull up a chair in the front by the barista bar and hang out, draw, chat and sip. They also have some really unique Coffee drinks on their menu that are awesome, check them out! Cute, hipster, and small cafe. After you pass through the bar area at the front, there is a small room with very small tables and chairs. Most of the seating areas have an outlet nearby, but since there are so little options, it's hard to get a table! The restroom is quite large, so that's a plus. The employees are friendly! I had two drinks while I stayed here working on some stuff:Matte black latte - pretty sweet, but I enjoyed this drink. Not a huge fan of the charcoal texture left on my tongue, but I do like that you can still taste some coffee.Cortado - quite strong! I definitely had to put a bit of sugar in this. Great coffee in this little hole in the wall spot in LES. They have Oatly oatmilk which already puts them above other coffee shops IMO! My oatmilk latte was creamy and delicious. It was ~$4. The shop is really really tiny and doesn't have much seating. It has a tiki bar kinda vibe. Really unique spot to grab a cuppa to go. My latte had some cute latte art on it ! Skip the wait at Russ & Daughters and walk into this sweet spot for personalized service, great coffee and espresso drinks and a creative Korean inspired breakfast.FYI: they roast their own coffee and it's pretty darn good. What a cute little cafe!  This cafe is off the beaten path, and I'm so glad it's still a hidden gem!  The cafe has a hipster vibe, and the workers are so friendly.  You order at the counter, and the workers will bring your drink over to your table.  The seating area is quiet, but not too much so that you can't have a conversation.  You'll see some customers chatting away while others are getting work done on their laptops.You must order their matte black latte ($6.50)!  It is made with charcoal, which is a good cleanser and has some ice cream in it which makes it a bit heavy.  But it is a good treat once in awhile!  I also heard good things about the egg cappuccino, which I must try next time! Delicious coffee, cool ambiance, unique selections and very friendly barista and staff. Came here after watching an insider video, was not expecting what we did. The aroma of the coffee was amazing once you step foot in the shop. It was a bit confusing when you first stepped in because it seemed like only bar seating but behind a small curtain to the back was small cozy seating. When I say small, I really mean small. The seats were tight. Their set up for 4 but honestly from standard American size it's a little more than a single seat. 4 would be tight unless you're super skinny. We order the egg cappuccino and the matte black latte. Expecting to see the egg yolk like in the video but I guess it was already blended in to the cappuccino itself unlike the video. The flavor was strong with a bit of smokines which I loved and you can really taste the creaminess of the egg.  The matte black latte was amazing. A little sweet with the rich bold flavors of coffee but what topped it over was the black cream that topped the latte. It tasted almost like ice cream! I highly recommend this place. Will be coming back to try the other selections and possibly brunch one day. A darling little coffee shop, hidden away in a non populated area of Chinatown.I walked in and felt like I was in the 1920's of Korea. Lots of Korean decor with swingers jazz playing. All cups they use are fun florals, non of which match. I felt like I was in an adult tea party!!Only negative thing is their seats are awfully small and uncomfortable for a coffee shop. My butt barely fit and I had to contort myself to get comfortable enough to read

OMG I can't believe i hadn't written a review for this place until now!!Ive been here like maybe 5 times...its in the list of italian restaurants in the city I love for their pizza and pasta!The tie die pizza is to die for!! Its got pesto, mozzarella , vodka sauce and its amazing!The pasta's are good too...The last time we had the ricotta Ravioli..was yummy..tons of other places in the city for good pasta...but you must have the pizza..Obviously going back!! The Tie-Dye pie was both simple and satisfying. With vodka sauce, tomato, pesto, and fresh mozzarella, you can't help but sink into the comfort of your own seat while taking in this delicious pie. The pesto gave the pie a very earthy and freshflavor. The mozzarella was layered on very thin, but the reason you are ordering this pie in the first place is because of that vodka sauce. It may be the best I've ever had. If I were to make a recommendationget the Tie-Dye - the combination of the vodka sauce and pesto is on point. I'd recommend getting some meat on it as wellTo continue reading review, go here:Check out my post!https://www.apizzanewyork.com/single-post/2018/01/25/Rubirosa-Ristorante-Nolita During my short stay in NY, I attempted to eat a slice of NY pizza every day. I ate Joe's twice and thought that was pretty good. On my last day before heading home, I had some time to kill and happened to be in Soho. I realized that Rubirosa was in Soho. Mikey Chen from Youtube's Strictly Dumpling said this was his #1 spot for NY pizza. I knew it was fate that I was near it on my last day.I got there a little before opening time, which was 11:30. My sis and I put in an order for two vodka slices to go. We had to wait about 20 minutes because they were just firing up the oven and hadn't started on the pizzas. No worries.Anyways, the two slices were $7-something together. It was scorching hot and my sister wanted to go to Doughnut Plant, so I held my precious baby protectively through the rain and dirty subway. While my sister was eating her donut, I took a bite into my slice. I was really, really, really happy because it did not disappoint. I declared it the best slice I've had in my life. The pizza itself it so thin and crisp. I love that it is so saucy. I mean, you can see the sauce throughout the whole slice. The chunks of melted cheese dispersed throughout the slice was perfect. Writing about my slice at work right now brings back fond memories... almost have tears in my eyes.The vodka sauce was out of this world. It was so flavorful and tomato-ey and a little sweet. Loved it!! When I go back to NY, I'm going to try to eat here every day.Give the vodka slice a try, everyone! Came here with a friend for a late lunch on a Saturday and was pleasantly surprised that we were seated right away, after hearing about the wait time. The restaurant crowd did die down by 2pm. We decided to get the smaller pizza (half Rubirosa Supreme and half Arugula) ~$21 and family size Tajarin alla Carbonara pasta $28. Their whole pizzas and pastas come in two sizes. Their pizzas are super thin and crispy- the way I like it. I liked the Rubirosa Supreme (meat) better than the Arugula, but both were good. The carbonara pasta came with egg yolk on top and had a good amount of richness and subtle flavor. My friend and I came in very hungry and out super full, so I would say one smaller size pizza and a family-size pasta could even feed some groups of 3. OMG the two R's - Roberta's and Rubirosa have my pizza heart.  We made reservations about a month in advance because, just a side note: if you walk in without a reservation and they tell you the wait is going to be 3 hours, then it truly is 3 hours.  We have tried this multiple times only to have been at home in bed already by the time we got the text that our table was ready. So anyways, on to the good stuff. WHAT WE ORDERED: - Half Tie-dye, half supreme - GET THIS! For 2 people, this and a pasta/appetizer is a good amount of food.  The vodka sauce is TDF. - carbonara pasta - GET THIS! all pastas are made in-house.  TRUST ME, there is a difference! - Rubirosa salad - perfect starter to the meal. Especially if you love arugula. We will be back! I had not tried Rubirosa since I moved to NYC 8 years ago and I am filled with regret, because the pizza here is MEMORABLY great. New York obviously has so many great pizzas, but Rubirosa's pizza was amazing, definitely worthy of the "best" pizza category. It is a thinner crust, super crisp, and stays crisp (I hate when the middle of the pizza gets soggy and drippy). I had the tie-dye which is a must. Topped with cheese and no extra toppings to get in the way, it highlights the amazing tomato sauce. I also had the Rubirosa supreme with perfect lil pepperonis. I would have a hard time choosing my favorite between the tie die and the supreme (get both). The third pie was a mushroom, good but didn't have that wow factor (I'm partial to red sauce). Start with mozzarella sticks - we all love them even if we're too embarrassed to order them because we are "adults now" but no one ever regrets ordering them. Rigatoni was a good mini break from the pizza, and we also ordered a pasta special with 4 kinds of meat (super meaty but delicious). The pastas alone might be worth going back for.Basically, if you haven't been to Rubirosa yet then do it ASAP. Reservations are near impossible to come by, but make them way in advance if you can. Tie-dye pizza and anything with red sauce is a must, but don't sleep on their pastas either. This is ultimate classic Italian spot for great food with great people. Love love love Rubirosa! Major tip: use the app RESY to make a reservation!! It is a major lifesaver. There are a couple times i came here without a reservation and the wait was 90 mins or more. Sure i can get a drink next door but when i want my Rubirosa, i want It when i walk in! Hehe :) Rubirosa is a cozy Italian spot in Nolita. It's dimly lit inside and has a full bar, which might be great for a little date night. We came late at night and it was still pretty crowded. The prices aren't that bad and the service was quick and friendly. If you're stuck deciding between 2 different pizzas, they can do split pizzas. We opted for half of the fresca and half of the Rubirosa supreme. The crust and pizza dough was as you would expect, thin but very crispy. I'm not a huge fan of the crispy crust and would prefer the crust be a little doughier. The toppings on the pizza were plentiful and I loved the fresh mozzarella. Rubirosa is a great spot for pizza, offering a nice ambiance and good pizza. When my friends ask me where they can find the best pizza in NYC, I say Rubirosa. After watching Strictly Dumpling's youtube video of his picks for best pizza spots in NYC, I knew I had to try this place.For $28 you can get a half and half large pizza. We got half Supreme (tomato, mozzarella, pepperoni, mini meatball, roasted garlic) and half Tie-Dye (vodka, tomato, pesto, fresh mozzarella). Tie-Dye was definitely the star here and is hands down the best thin-crust pizza ever. I never craved pizza before until I had this! It was love at first bite and I didn't want it to end...The wait can be pretty bad if you don't have reservations (1-2 hours). They also do to-go orders which I might do next time. However, there's just something special about eating pizza right out of the oven here. I'd recommend dining in if it's your first time. Was visiting the neighborhood and heard of their crispy pizza crust and wanting to go for the experience.  Walked into a dim and bar like atmosphere.   A bit of a surprised as I discovered it as a bar/restaurant servicing up more than just pizza fitting into many occasions from casual pizza lunch and brunch place to a fancy date or business ocassions. We were there for a casual lunch with our kids.  We ordered the half vodka and half original with pepperoni.  I left in love with their vodka pizza and their crispy and thin crust.  Its the crispiest and thinnest crust I have ever encountered as I am a big fan of. The half pepperoni pizza were least as crispy and was salty and greasy from the pepperoni.  Both kids approved both as each consumed both.Very nice staff as they persist in coming to us with assistance and attentive to our needs.  Almost given a 5 stars if i only their seatings were more comfortable and welcoming.  For a party of 4,  we find there being cramped in space as my hubby was constantly being bumped by the staffs having to move to and from the bar area.   I would definitely back to try their Italian entrees and different style pizzas as we left in love with their style pizza. Pizza in NYC, can it really ever be that bad? From the dollar slices to your gourmet establishments, NYC will hardly disappoint for a slice of heavenly carby goodness. I must admit, a bit skeptical on a place like this with wait times comparable to an amusement park ride, but Rubirosa did not disappoint, although unsure if I'd ever want to wait that long for pizza. I was fortunate enough to get a seating for 2 at the bar quickly and didn't have to suffer the agony that many others did, especially on a blistering cold night. The place is your typical Nolita trendy spot with the hip vibe, cute but close confined dining, and a sometimes pretentious atmosphere. Wait time not being an issue for my experience, so I'll get to it. The pizza is pretty special. The crust is extremely thin but crispy throughout yet really light. Think of a cracker or even motzah. The sauce...is crack infused bursting with flavored meth crystals. Put that sauce on a flip flop and you'll be convinced flip flops are delicious and should be the next novelty item at smorgasburg. Add some fresh ingredients and you got yourself an excellent disk of heaven. I love pizza so maybe I'm easy to please, but I do know good pizza and they just do the humble pie justice here. Lesbehonest, I will definitely not wait for hours for this, but that's just me, only because there are other phenomenal pizza spots without the wait. But if I had the opportunity to swoop in without too long of a wait again, I'd gladly come back and get lost in the flavors, flavors that make me want to do weird things to that pie that I can not speak of...Stay fat mother suckers BEST PIZZA IN THE WORLD HANDS DOWN.Came here on a recommendation from Strictly Dumpling and I'm SO glad we did. Writing this review as I'm in the restaurant because seriously I can't wait for everyone to try this place. MUST TRY: half tie dye, half supreme. The supreme was a little meat heavy for me but my male friends LOVED it. It truly is a meat lover's paradise. I personally really enjoyed the tie dye, the pesto is on point. The crust of these pizzas are so thin and unlike anything I've ever tried. I have nothing but good things to say about Rubirosa pizzas! A large pizza was perfect for 3 people, we were all full at the end but not over stuffed. The service here was good and the vibes are great here. This is definitely a gem in lower Manhattan and I can't wait to come back! Of all the food I ate in NY, this was probably my favourite spot. Oh and don't be afraid of the hour wait, it goes by quicker than you think. In my opinion, one of the most absolutely essential NYC restaurants. Some of the best pizza in the city, plus great pastas and other dishes. Last visit, we went with a group of four and got rice balls to start, followed by three small pastas (carbonara, cavatelli with broccoli rabe / sausage / garlic / oil, and a special tagliatelle with pork sugo) and two small pizzas (a vodka and a half Rubirosa Supreme / half Tie-Dye). Everything was excellent as always. The cavatelli was the group's favorite pasta, although I liked the sugo as much or more. (Don't think we'd get the carbonara again.) The pizzas are what I go for, though, and they didn't disappoint -- if there was anything I'd do differently, it might be to get a full tie-dye and skip the supreme, although the supreme is still great.Overall, just an incredibly good spot that is extremely hard to get into and so worth it when you do. Four stars only because the food took about an hour to come out. I tried the Brussels sprouts, they were a little charred but it was good. It probably would have been yummier if it didn't have burnt pieces but I was too hungry to send it back. I tried the vodka pizza & that was delicious. Thin crust. Service is also great. Staff is friendly. Definetly will eat here again when I'm in New York. OKAY FINE. Despite a particularly unpleasant experience with a wine bottle mixup at the bar, the food was just so phenomenal that I'm still rating it 4 stars. Like, let's put it this way - it was a miserably cold and rainy Sunday and my friend and I were in inexplicably atrocious moods and we left this place feeling like whole new humans thanks to how amazing the food was. I've been trying to come here for a while, but the wait's always somewhere in the ballpark of 2-3 hours and I've never been able to plan far enough ahead where I can kill that much time in the area waiting for a table. It was the Sunday after Halloween and the city was pretty dead on a Sunday night, so we decided we'd take a stab at it one more time. Sure enough, the wait was totally reasonable - maybe around 45 minutes or so, so we decided to stick it out.They asked us if we were willing to take bar seats and we didn't have a problem with that so we were able to be seated sooner. The bartender was friendly and helpful with recommendations - he suggested we split the calamari to start and we were SO glad we did - the portion size was huge and it was breaded/fried perfectly - crispy yet light, delicious with lemon, and served with an amazing marinara, of which we were given plenty yet still finished. We ordered a half and half large which was around $28 I believe. We got half of the Supreme (i believe thats what it was - basically a bunch of meats) and the tie-dye (pesto and vodka). The pizza was fairly thin but wasn't too crispy/burnt - both halves were delicious although I think I liked the tie-dye slightly more. It's also nice that you can opt to pick two different choices because everything on the menu sounded great so it would have been too tough to pick just one! We were stuffed when we finished eating although the pizza wasn't as filling as I was expecting - two girls split a large without bursting afterwards.Now on to the one negative: we ordered a different bottle of wine than the one we were given, which was at a higher price point. This has happened to me before and apparently is relatively common practice at restaurants, which bothers me because I feel like at least in some cases it's done intentionally. I guess I'll give Rubirosa the benefit of the doubt in this case, but I'll for sure be careful to check labels more intently when I return. TL;DR: phenomenal phenomenal food. Plan ahead with your wait or book a table because otherwise it's usually brutal, but worth it! I was in NYC for a couple of days and my friends took me to Rubirosa for lunch, and now it's a must visit every time I'm in the city...Service:  Excellent service from beginning to end. Our server was friendly and great with suggestions when we narrowed our picks down to two choices.  There was another server who kept our water carafe full and was also filling our glasses whenever he stopped by.  A manager checked up on as well at the end.  This made for a great lunch.Italian food: EVERYTHING we ate, was on point.  Here are my All Stars:  The mini-rice balls were very tasty, that Fontina cheese, so so good. I just wish there was more than 4 per order. hehe  The Calamari though, was not only was tasty but came out on a huge serving plate. We couldn't even finish it.  The Tajarin alla Carbonara was fantastic, the egg really brings it home.   The Tie-Dye pizza was amazing.  The mozzarella cheese, marinara, vodka and pesto sauces made for probably the best thin crust I've had this year.  Everything we tried was made with high quality ingredients and prepped extremely well.  Italian food game is on point here!Ambiance:  As soon as you walk in, you're greeted by a ull service bar to your right and the hostess stand to the left.  Wooden floors, tables and old school Italian decorations definitely gives that family run Italian-American run restaurant vibe.  Just like most Manhattan restaurants, there's not a lot of space so get ready for a very intimate dining experience but not a claustrophobic one.Pricing is your typical Manhattan restaurant for quality meals.  If you're hungry the bill can add up quickly, but this is a GREAT restaurant to be hungry af at.  I enjoyed everything we tried.  I guarantee this is not my last visit here.  Until next time Rubirosa! My friend and I came here after we wanted to replicate Mike Chen's pizza tour video and try out some of NY's best pizza places. We arrived at around 2 on a weekday afternoon and there really wasn't much of a wait. We were seated toward the back of the restaurant by the oven and it was pretty warm and toasty back there.Judging from the pictures and the tips from my fellow Yelpers, my friend and I decided to go with the large vodka pie to split amongst us two. The pie took a while to prepare, but we were both satisfied upon tasting it. The pie wasn't oily at all, being that it's a thin crusted pizza. The sauce was sweet and somewhat tangy and the mozzarella complemented everything else well. The crust was crunchy and had bit of char to add a little nice bitterness to the pizza itself. Overall, I agree with Mike Chen on Rubirosa being one of the better pizza places in NYC. The pricing for one large vodka pie was fair, they also offered other Italian dishes including pasta. The service was impeccable and the venue was clean. Will definitely be returning and will recommend this place to others! Pizza is tasty and I like their use of pesto - think this is an under-rated topping. Tie die and vodka are my favorites. Some pies are a tad too crispy and thin in the crust for me but delicious none the less. Overall quality pizza. There's a TON of artisanal pizza options in NYC, but this ranks right up there with the best of them. Definitely be prepared for a bit of a wait, but there's a good reason people are lined up on the block. As is the dilemma with most dining experiences, it's difficult to choose what to get, so if I had to recommend one thing, it would be the vodka and pesto pie - very unique and so delicious. Usually I'm a big topping person but the blend of sauces with the right amount of cheese and an ultra thin but crisp crust makes this just perfect as is. I came here last night with my parents who are visiting from out of town. Was super excited to take them to one of my favorite places for pizza. As expected the pizza was AMMAZING and pasta was too! Unfortunately, I felt the need to update my review and dock a star because the overall service was lacking and dampened the mood a little. First off, I made reservations more than a month in advance and when we arrived we got stuck in a dark corner table right by the bathroom. I can appreciate that the hostess only has so much control over table available so it didn't end up being a huge deal, but a little disappointing. Second, and most errking, were our waitresses (we had two because one was covering for the other during a break). One was very snooty and made me feel bad/awkward when I asked for a wine recommendation. I know ZERO about wine and was hoping to get some help. She stared at me and nearly rolled her eyes as if it was an inconvenience for her to just offer up a suggestion. I want to keep coming here but amazing food doesn't excuse poor service. Hoping it was a one off.

Ruby's Cafe has always been my go-to place to grab a bite. I never wrote a review for them in the past but I've been coming here since they first opened. Now, this place has been a popular restaurant. I loved the variety of food they serve from salads to pastas to burgers. The prices are also moderate, pretty inexpensive for NYC. Yes, it is a small sit down restaurant. I've always had to sit intimately with the table next to us whenever I dined with one person. I recently came here on a Tuesday night with a group of 7 people. They told us the wait was about 30 minutes, which wasn't bad for a group at a small restaurant. We received a text saying our table was ready after only a 10 minute wait. I JUST found out that they had expanded, so there's a part of the restaurant one store front down. I thought that was a little weird but hey, it's more seating and less waiting. The negative thing about the expansion was that there was no restroom on the new side of Ruby's. Our waitress was attentive and friendly while she was taking our orders. I had the Whaley's burger with fries (I typically order this when I'm here). The burger was cooked exactly the way I wanted it. I love how they use panini-like bread instead of hamburger buns. There's also a sweet taste (I think it's the pineapple) that balances out the beef. The fries with aioli sauce was so good, I couldn't stop eating them even though I was full. I haven't been here for awhile, they still have not failed at keeping me satisfied! Avoided the long wait during Sunday brunch! Lucky me because the Bronte burger was just what I needed after a month hiatus from Eggs Benedict, avocado toast, acai bowls...your typical brunch foods. But this burger is not so typical. I think what makes it so delicious is the sauce they add to it. Get this on a rainy day and you'll walk out happy. Get a side of seasoned fries with it and your palette is complete. Would definitely come back to try the rest of the menu. Or to simply enjoy the JT, Britney, and Jesse McCartney throwbacks (my review is more biased bc of the music)!! <U+200B>It's been a few years since I've been here and I remember it being really small--holding no more than ~20 people--it was cash only, no reservations and generally a wait. Oh, and the food was really good. I've had everything from burgers, to pasta to sides a few years ago.Fast forward to today.I was meeting a friend for lunch at 1pm and there were a ton of people already waiting outside. Fine. The guy inside said it would only be 15 minutes so we ended up waiting in her car right outside the restaurant. NBD.15 minutes later, I checked in w/ the host and we were seated immediately. So Ruby's has expanded and they also took over the place next door. CON: there is no bathroom there. You have to walk outside, next door to the original establishment to use the restroom. This alone was a MAJOR turn-off. It was a high of 23F today. My friend is also preggos so she had to walk next door a few times.On to the food. I got the Shrimp Avocado. In theory, it sounds delicious and I think it would've been good if the lettuce wasn't yellow, a bit bitter and old. There was also nothing spectacular about the shrimp. It was a little overcooked w/ no seasoning.We split the sweet potato fries which is topped with sour cream and sweet chili(?). This was good. I'd give it a 7/10.SUPER unimpressed by this place as it's gone way downhill.On a more positive note, if you do decide to go, they now take credit cards. But they still don't take reservations. Honestly quite not sure why this place is so popular especially among international tourist. My friend visited NYC from Korea wanted to check this place out. We stopped by the Ruby's Cafe at around 3 pm to avoid the crowds, but even at 3pm there was a long wait list. Because of my friend's ambition to try this place out, we decided to put our names and phone number at the waiting list. After a long wait, we finally got seated, but we didn't have the most pleasant experience as the lady who seated us rolled her eyes when my friend was tying his shoe lace, tossed the menu at a table and just walked away. Ruby's Cafe is a very small cafe where there aren't that many free spaces. Because everything is so narrow - including the hallway, the server will barely check up on you, and the servers make minimum interaction with the customers. I had to get an extra napkin because my hands were getting dirty from the burgers, and despite the numerous attempts to make an eye contact with the servers, I didn't get a chance to even ask for one. We ordered a  and ordered the Bronte Burger, and a Shrimp Pasta. The foods were good. But I'm not sure whether it's worth a +40 minutes wait considering the unpleasant experience due to a bad customer service. My friend and I went last night, it was pretty nice. There are apparently two places where you can eat. We went into the first section and thought it was pretty small. But the other section (which was two doors down) had about one group in it. So, if you feel like it looks to crowded ask if you can be seated next door. Food-Loved my meal- I got the crunchy grain bowl for 13 dollars! It was really good and fresh, I would recommend this healthy choice. Service- The workers were nice and attentive! Would go back again, especially for their brunch! Ruby's is a super cozy and trendy place that's perfect for bringing a hot date or a few close friends to. It is an Australian influenced cafe offering a variety of pastas, burgers, and salads. I thought it was fun how their burgers are named after beaches in Australia. Some burgers even include sweet chili, sliced beets, and/or pineapple which are all common staples in the country.On my visit, I ordered the pesto pasta. This dish consisted of spaghetti, pesto sauce, and chicken (or veggies if you're looking for a meatless alternative). It was the perfect amount of creaminess, full of flavor, and really delicious! I really enjoyed this dish and thought it was just the right portion size so I didn't pass out from carb overload. I tried a few bites of the Bronte burger and thought it was a solid choice as well.Definitely come here if you're in the area! They don't take reservations but it was only a 10-15 minute wait when I came on a weekday night. I already know I'll be coming back since there's so many other menu items I still want to try. Very cute small spot on Mulberry street in Manhattan. There's actually 2 rooms next to each other with 2 separate entrances. Open kitchen. They serve breakfast but ends early. Had lunch. I had lamb Ragu. Very delicious. A fettuccine type pasta with shredded lamb, very soft with tomato sauce. The other person had Rag Bol - spaghetti Bolognese with peppers and zucchini. The dishes came out very quickly. Excellent service. Demerit for no decaf coffee!!!!!!!' It was too late for me to drink caffeinated One of my favorite places in New York! The chicken pasta is amazing and never fails. The fries are an obsession. The burgers are great. My girl friend also really enjoys their pesto pasta. Also workers are super friendly and have a "cool" vibe. THE BRONTE BURGER::heart heart heart heart heart heart::yes, this counts as a reviewi am so depressed they don't have this in LAbut i'm on a mission to recreate itcurrently on batch #3 Casual brunch/lunch cafe with limited seating but lots of great offerings of pasta, burgers, salad. I've visited Ruby's twice and loved both visits. They expanded the store to additional seating next door, so make sure you ask about the wait! *Pumpkin Seed Pesto Chicken Pasta: DELICIOUS!! The pesto sauce was perfectly seasoned and you can taste hints of the pumpkin seed. The grilled chicken was very tender and was cooked well too. It is a creamier sauce but the nutty pesto flavor balances out the creaminess. Definitely recommend this one! *Spicy Rag Bol: Another success. Nice little kick of spice to the bolognese sauce. Sauce is quite hearty but can get heavy if you are just eating the pasta. We shared the pasta with the burger, so it was great. *Bronte Burger: I will clear things up and say this is not your typical burger. The bread is like a panini style and no typical lettuce, tomato on these. But instead, you get the spicy chili sauce that complements the patty so so well. The patty is very juicy and cooked well. -Whaley's Burger: meh on this one. I wasn't a big fan of the combo of sweetness from beet and pineapple with the savory flavor from the patty. The fried egg also doesnt really add too much flavor so was confused about the overall concept of this burger. Best for parties of 2-4 but could accommodate bigger parties if you come at off peak times. Come early on weekend brunches because Ruby's is a popular spot! Hands down, one of my go to restaurants in LES if I'm craving for pasta, burgers or fries.  Cute spot a little off Soho, but it is always packed so be prepared for a wait if you go for dinner or brunch.  I've been for both and I enjoy that they offer regular menu items during brunch time because the shrimp linguine pasta is just simply amazing.  It's super creamy without being overbearing and has just enough flavor.  Their famous Bronte burger is melt in your mouth good!! One of my favorite burgers in the city if I might say.And the fries with truffle aoli - must get, they've got these fries down to the T. Cute spot for date night or brunch if you don't mind the wait. Ruby's Cafe offers a wide variety of brunch items from your traditional breakfast food items, to delicious salads, to your standard burger and fries.  One thing that I appreciate about Ruby's is their variety of gluten free options.  While I did not try it, they offer gluten free buns for their burgers and sammies, and also gluten free pasta options. I will certainly have to come back and try it!As for what I did try...well it was delicious.  I ordered the crispy rice bowl filled with radish, scallions, cucumber, tomato, onion, cucumber, fried egg and haloumi cheese.  Because I was feeling bougie, I added avocado to my bowl. The rice was exactly what it is described as: crispy and delicious.  Think crunchy rice that almost tastes like it's been fried. To be honest, it could have been. And that would make sense given it's deliciousness.The ingredients were fresh and melted together nicely to create a celebration of flavors for my tastebuds.  As any other millennial would, I ordered the $7 fresh juice that came with freshly blended pineapple and mint for a refreshing and light drink that paired well with my bowl.The ambience is hip and trendy-with open walls that overlook the streets of Soho, allowing for the fresh, crisp, fall air to blow through your hair as you enjoy your meal.  Service was fast, friendly and the vibes were chill.  It was pretty busy and there was about a 25 minute wait for a table of two on a Sunday at 1pm.  Overall, if you're into the brunch scene, are gluten free (or not), you should definitely consider coming here! Ruby's Caf! Ahh what can I say. I'm speechless honestly. I love this place so much (seriously, I do--if you're ever reading this, like I am like most--H U G E FAN!).I love love love the creamy chicken pasta, it's soooo good. The last time I came here was probably a month ago--so sad. I would love to go every weekend if I can. But as usual--service is always on point here and so is the food. What I would recommend is definitely the creamy chicken pasta, the rag bol, and chicken burger. I really like the chicken burger since it's buttermilk marinated chicken mmm. The  Bronte is also very good so that's also something you may want to consider--there's sweet chilli in it by the way. Creamy polenta is also very good for breakfast if you're into that (cause I know I am).Honestly, everything is good so whatever. Go crazy, have fun. Eat. I'm just completely speechless because it's so great. Kay, bye. Forever Ruby's Caf lover. Besides the long wait this place is mad good!! Love love the truffle fries and the burgers is to die for ;D I believe the Kpop star snsd/girls generation also enjoyed this place as well. Honestly it's great for brunch, lunch, dinner or anytime. The service is great and the food is amazing. Even a simple salad is unique and delicious.One uncomfortable thing would be that it's a small, popular place. I was lucky enough to get a table right away but I would be cautious.Otherwise strongly suggested for everyone. Ruby's has been around for many many years now.  This is still my favourite place to get an Australian burger with the lot done right!  Definitely worth a visit if you feel like a casual bite to eat. Came back a second time to try their spicy seafood spaghetti and must I say, it was pretty darn good! One thing I would like to suggest is to add a little more to the portion of spaghetti. I thought the amount was too small for the amount I'm paying for.  I also thought it was quite inconvenient for me to sit on my jacket because all the hooks were taken. A suggestion I can give is I think it would be nice to have chairs with a removable lid so customers could place their jackets inside during the winter. Best pasta ever. Best sangria ever. The best food we had in NY while visiting. Fair prices also. Service 5 stars. My husband has some food allergies and we asked a thousand questions, they were very kind! Absolutely delicious! First of all, Ruby's Cafe offers gluten-free pasta and bread options. My husband, who has celiac sprue, ordered their gluten free cheeseburger. He applauds it as the best burger he has had in NY. I ordered the Whaley burger. Egg, beets, and pineapple do not sound like they go together well with a burger, but trust me, they actually do! I was pretty skeptical by the idea, but the Whaley was unexpectedly delicious. If you are feeling adventurous, I would recommend trying it out. Service was great. We went on a Saturday after 3 and had about a 15-20 minute wait, which wasn't too bad. 5/5 for the excellent burgers and gluten free friendly menu. Ruby's Cafe has two seating areas next to each other, separated by outside doors. The wait was estimated to be 40 minutes for 2 people on a Sunday, but ended up taking only 30 minutes. There was a long wait for the food after being seated. However, I did enjoy the throwback songs such as "I Want It That Way" and "Barbie Girl", which made the wait a lot more bearable. I ordered the Ricotta Hotcakes, which wasn't particularly impressive. My boyfriend on the other hand, kept raving about the fries that he ordered, but did not say much about his Whaleys.

Yummmm! This classic comfortable cafe is a great place for brunch. Greeted warmly by the hostess- thanks for charging my phone!Sat up at the counter/bar and shared a smoked salmon benny with kale a perfectly poached eggs on challah- sooooo good! Also had the blitzes with a blueberry compote and sour cream.I can see why this is a local regular spot- I'd be mine too if I lived here! The original NYC's Russ & Daughters Appetizing Store has been serving the best smoked fish in the US for more than 100 years.  It's a true must visit.  Located nearly next door to Katz's Deli creates the epicenter of New York's Jewish food culture and an unforgettable back to back noshing experience.  Russ & Daughters Cafe is what happens when the next generation takes over and merges the old with the new.  In this case it's the 4th generation of the Russ family finally giving their customers "a place to sit down".The Cafe keeps all the flavors, charm, and heritage from the original R&D and apply it to a new expanded menu.  The smoked fish remains the star but it is part of an inventive dishes like whitefish chowder or pastrami cured salmon.  For the classic experience you can order the smoked fish platters which come with a bread choice and all the expected accompaniments.  If you are local it's a perfect meal.  If you don't get to visit often and you want to try multiple dishes you can order the not on the menu fish only boards to get the same flavors at half the size and price.  Their menu even expands past fish to include perfect potato pancakes and amazing chocolate babka french toast.  Once you sit down this place lives up to the hype but unfortunately they don't take reservations.  Expect to wait even at odd times and like most places in NYC there is very little space to wait.   You are better off walking around this historic neighborhood while you wait which will make your eventual meal feel even more authentic. Stopped here over the Holidays on a frigid morning with a party of 6, and luckily didn't have a long wait. My wife insisted on wanting a lox bagel, and this place seemed to be the winner (and was).The food was delicious, and I'm not a huge cured fish kind of guy but thoroughly enjoyed my meal and the coffee. I wish I had a bigger appetite as everyone raved about their latkes and french toast. 3.5 starsThe wait is insane, we were quoted an hour and 45 minute wait, though to be fair it was prime brunch time on a Saturday. After we finally got in, we orders the hot smoke cold smoke appetizer, and I ordered the lower sunny side for my entree, which came with eggs sunny side up, latkes, and smoked salmon. The hot smoke cold smoke was good, and went especially well with  the bagel chips.The lower sunny side was solid comfort food, though the latkes were enormous and rather thick while the outside was a little bit too hard for my liking. Smoked salmon was good, but there were only a few slivers of it on my plate. I also tried some matzo ball soup (for the first time) which I was fan of for sure and tasted just like a warming bowl of chicken noodle soup. For dessert we were seduced by the honey cake, which in reality, was a glorified spiced muffin. Quite small as well for the price. All in all, not a bad experience, and would come back if the wait wasn't so ridiculously long. First stop of my long overdue visit to NYC. Was this worth it? I'd say sure, must try at least once. Good food, nice 1920s interior, interesting wall decor which is also found in the washrooms and NO insane wait as I have been told it gets crazy!My friends and I made a visit on a weekday afternoon just probably after the afternoon rush. We were seated approximately after a 5 minute wait and there were also empty booths that had just left. We were served water quickly, which was great and our server took our orders shortly after. We were hungry after a long flight delay and we were glad to be seated and served quickly. No complaints with the service!Our orders: 2 classic boards (Smoked salmon, Cream Cheese, Bagel/Bialy)Eggs Benny (Poached eggs, smoked salmon, spinach, hollandaise sauce)Lower sunny side (Smokes salmon, sunny side eggs, potato latkes)I have to say the presentation of all 3 dishes were nice and clean and picture worthy. The one dish which I thought was more of value and quality was the eggs benny...It just looked yummy and satisfying.The other dishes looked good but pretty much what you would expect on a wooden board or plate. Our meals generally tasted great, maybe also because we were deprived of food...Was the lox and bagel worth $17...Mmm not sure about that...I would definitely give it a try if you are in NYC (especially with all the hype) but for next time I will just get the lox bagel at the cafe as I am told it is more of a grab'n'go kind of thing.P.s I really like the "number ticket" wall paper in one of the washrooms...Unique idea! I was rather disappointed by Russ & Daughters Cafe. The name carries a mythical status in the region, and the food and service don't live up to it. I've had better smoked fish at a number of places, including the retail selection at Citeralla in the Hamptons. Although, Russ & Daughters does make one of the best latkes (potato pancakes) in America. After visiting the original location to take out some of the famous lox bagel, I felt obligated to try the dine-in location as well.This place has more of the real Jewish dishes that you heard about, but never dared to try.From Latke to Motze all the way up to caviar. All the goodness of smoked fish and heavy Jewish cuisine can be found here. A lot of the time you will not be lucky to get in as there's a wait, even for bar seating.I had the luck to get in rather quickly at 1 pm for a lunch but if you really commit to try, walk in between 4 and 6.The smoked fish is just as good as the original location. I have tried some of the other dishes but it just wasn't to my taste.I would prefer going to the original one if you are okay with eating outside or staying close by so you can enjoy this amazing culture well. This lox lover could not have been happier to dine at Russ & Daughters! Was my eggs and bacon fiancee just as happy? Maybe not, but he left satisfied in the end.It was a Friday morning and even at 11:00 am, the wait was almost an hour long. Thankfully, they take your phone number and text when your table is ready, so you're free to pop into a bar or coffeeshop nearby while you wait. We eventually landed a seat at the bar and were ravenous. We started with the latkes which were among the best I've had. They were thick and piping hot. Great when paired with the sour cream and apple sauce. From there, I got the classic board which came with lox, a bagel (everything, please!), tomato, onions, capers, and cream cheese. There's a reason why people call these the best lox they've had. They simply are! My fiancee got the cinnamon babka French toast which he devoured. The bartenders were our servers and they certainly had a lot on their plates so I didn't feel super taken care of, and our order got a little wrong but they were quick to correct. I'm happy I had the experience. I probably wouldn't rush back and opt for their grab-and-go spot instead; however, it was worth the wait this once for fish lovers like me! Spiritual. Fulfilling. Adventurous. Bold. Daring. I can use as many words as I need to in order to distract myself from analyzing the amount of food I eat at Russ and daughters. The wait is almost always an hour - today is was 90 min - but we have a good time walking around the neighborhood. It's the best meal in the world and the best place to have it which makes it arguably the best restaurant in the world. A bit pricey, but lovely.  An old-school diner feel, serving classic Lower East Side Jewish fare (which overlaps sizably with classic diner fare, and with classic brunch fare) plus some interesting standouts.The classics include smoked fish boards -- salmon or sturgeon or sable, tomatoes and onions and capers, cream cheese or butter, some sorta tasty bread.  If you like this sort of thing, you can't go wrong here.  They have individual boards (less than $20) or large platters meant for three to four people that go for $80-90 and come with an eye-catching assortment of all of the above, and then some.  (The platters are named after the eponymous Daughters--Hattie, Ida, and Anne--aka The Sturgeon Queens.)Some interesting standouts:* Halva ice cream.  If you like halva, this is a must-have.  If you don't know what halva is, this is as fine an introduction as any.  If you don't like halva... I don't know, man.* House-made sodas.  These are just syrup with seltzer, but each has a teeny twist of sophistication.  For example, the lemon-line soda layers in flavors of anise, dill, and cardamon. That seems like it should be off or too much, but was refreshing, and I don't even like anise.(One heart-crushing thing to be aware of: the famed babka ice cream sandwich is "a summer thing", according to our waitress.  I don't understand this menu madness, but it is what it is.)We came here after fasting for Yom Kippur.  The Cafe opened off-schedule for the holiday, at 5pm, and a small line had formed outside the door by 4:45pm.  Russ & Daughters brought out smoked salmon canaps for the folks in line--a lovely way to break a fast.  Service was solid to great throughout.  Thumbs up. 4 stars for the matzo ball soup. This is a very cute and photogenic place. Wait was a big long for New Year's Day. Didn't expect it to be packed but everything was fresh. I especially loved the matzo ball soup. I also got the classic platter (lox, cream cheese, onions, tomatoes, capers and choice of bread. I got the everything bagel). Nothing really blew my mind or stood out from the platter. I think next time I'll try a fish spread. But for sure coming back for the matzo ball soup. Highly recommend. Came by on a Wednesday at noon to no wait for counter seating. Here's the assessment. Is this spot a NYC staple? Yes. Is the food off the chain? Hell yes. Should that give them the right to charge 20 bucks (with tax and tips) for 3 pieces of lox, a bialy, cream cheese, and some vegs? Uhh questionable. I meannn, I get it. Your foods good. But $20 for a lox cream cheese bialy?! That's excessive. But let's talk about the restaurant itself. Super cute. Modern diner feel. Was planning to go to the deli, but good thing I didn't. It was nuts in there (up a few blocks frm the cafe). I had a much better lunch experience at the cafe. The deli is a grab and go. This is a sit down. I went to a few other bagel and bialy spots during my visit, and they're just as good IMO, and don't charge nearly as much as Russ and Daughters does. Sooo there's that. Am I glad I tried this spot though? Yes. Should you come by and try it as well? Yes. Will I come back again? Maybe to try something else. 4 stars. Every time I'm in NYC I make sure to grab breakfast at Russ & Daughters Cafe. I enjoy the service, the atmosphere, and I really love a delicious bagel with pastrami salmon.As others have mentioned there can be a wait, especially on the weekend. I typically go around 10am during the week and have never waited longer than 15 minutes. I always get the bagel board that comes with whipped goat cheese and swap in pastrami salmon, so yummy. My husband and I will usually also share an order or the latkes. The latkes are thicker than most people expect but they're seasoned well and cooked to perfection - I recommend the sour cream and apple sauce combo.I'm not a huge fan of their coffee, but their sodas are super delish.Is this place pricy, yes. Is the service great and the decor on point, yes. I love this place and don't mind dropping the extra cash for greatness. Food was great, but the wait was shocking. Granted, we did happen to go on a Saturday during the height of brunch time, but still, an hour and 45 minute wait is outrageous.We started off with the hot smoke and cold smoke dip, which was amazing. I could not get enough of it, and I thought the portion size was surprisingly good as well. I also ordered the eggs benny. Eggs Benedict is usually pretty indulgent, but the smoked salmon and challah on the Russ & Daughters eggs benny was even more indulgent than usual. At the end of our meal, we were also enticed by the honey cake, which was actually pretty disappointing because it was more of a muffin topped with ice cream.Ultimately, a great place and I would definitely return -- hopefully at a time when the wait isn't so insane. Personally the food, nor the service, were worth the 45-minute wait for ONE SEAT AT THE COUNTER. Having visited the LES many times, the constant lineup at both the Russ & Daughters cafe and the store piqued my curiosity. So, on a Tuesday, just before noon I figured I wouldn't have too long to wait - and boy was I wrong. I was honestly hoping for just a bagel and lox, though the cafe doesn't have that option. So instead, I got the dish with the latkes, the lox and 2 eggs. Admittedly, the latkes were AMAZING and the lox was pretty great, but worth the wait? Hardly. Worth a try if you don't have too long to wait. Otherwise, there are so many other amazing places in the LES, and NYC in general to waste time in line here. Fresh ingredients and good salmon. I sat at the bar and the service was very good. @manudominguezm A sit-down offering of the famed counter location serving Jewish cured fish specialties. Probably not the cheapest out there but the quality and reputation is partly what you're paying for. If you're ordering latkes, go for the salmon roe and creme fraiche. I came here with a party of 4 on a Saturday morning at 9:30am and the wait was 45min- 1 hour... I was actually surprised since 9:30am is considered early for a New Yorker. To pass the time, we waited at a coffee shop across the street. By the time we came back around 10:30, the wait for other parties was 1.5 hours.When we were finally seated, we ordered the Ida platter that serves 3-4 people. It had 4 different types of salmon for us to try alongside with toppings and bagels/bread. I would definitely recommend this option for those who want to try a bit of everything! The slices were extremely fresh and rich. I would recommend this place for sure, but I probably won't be back anytime soon as the wait for this place is so long and there are other delicious places around the area. We drove to New York for a "food trip" on a Saturday morning. I should have gotten us a reservation because the wait time was ridiculous. We had to wait an hour to get seated so call in advance and get reservations because this pace gets busy. My girlfriend and I shared the classic bagel which is basically smoked salmon and we picked scallion cream cheese and everything bagel. We shared a bagel because we were going to another place for lunch right after but if you are coming here for brunch then I say get one for yourself. I was first hesitant/shocked that a bagel would cost $17 but it was worth it. The bagel had the perfect texture and the salmon was so good. I loved the scallion cream cheese and it also came with onions, tomatoes and capers. They have a variety of cream cheese including plain, goat cheese, tofu cream cheese and few more that I can't remember. I enjoyed every bit of it.Th service was great. Everybody was super friendly and nice. They do not rush their guests which is a good thing but can become problematic when the line is so long  and the interior gets crowded. The place is also neat.Was it worth the hype? Yes but will I come back? Probably not because its expensive just for a bagel and the wait is way too long. However it's a one time must try place. Had to show my boo the food of my peoples so came here during our trip to NY. He loved it! The whitefish on a bagel with wasabi caviar and wasabi creme fraiche is legit! Got a shrub soda (can't remember which one) and enjoyed it thoroughly. Only thing we didn't rant and rave about, surprisingly, was the lox plate. It's beautiful for instagram but we both agreed the lox had very little flavor. Maybe we ordered the wrong kind, but the flavor was way too subtle for our liking. Would be willing to try again though since they had numerous varieties and I'm sure we'd find something we'd like better.

Still amazing after all these years!!! I very often to return to a restaurant after loving it so much to be disappointed in it the next time, but not here! They have the best Banh mi sandwiches I have ever had. The bread is fresh, toasted, and full of the perfect ratio of fresh and amazing fillings. My favorite is the number one combo and add $1 pate to it. Amazing!The man at the counter is as lovely and kind as ever too. I love this place. One of my top favorite meals in NYC! They stayed open toMake me a sandwich so I'm Indebted, thank you**also it was completely delicious and filling. Recommend traditional spicy The best banh mi in the area!I've came here several times for a quick takeout. The owner is friendly and efficient. Their sandwich buns have the right crispiness and weren't rock hard like its competitor next block. The ingredients are fresh and crunchy in generous amounts. Although their prices are a buck more than Bahn Mi Saigon, the sandwiches are heartier and worth the price and more. I found this gem, opened at 7am. I went and got #1 ($6.50). I also got a hot cup of Vietnamese Coffee ($1.50) This store is what makes this city so great. It gives me options: bahn mi for breakfast and why not? The definition of wholesome was probably inspired by this place. When you bite in, you feel your teeth cutting through plump pieces of ham and other meat and the sweet pickled veggies remind you that yes, you should definitely eat more vegetables. This is only the second time I've eaten their Bahn Mi's since Bahn Mi Saigon is only a block away and is one of the best Bahn Mi places around.  Saigon Bahn Mi's are pretty good. I got the #2 Chicken and the chicken was moist and flavorful, but the bread wasn't toasted much and their spicy option was pretty lame.  Any place that just throw in some generic hot sauce just doesn't hack it. This place is really a 3.5, but with Bahn Mi Saigon 3 minutes away, I rounded down. Solid bahn mi's. CASH ONLY. Very limited seating here. The pickled veggies were a bit too pungent, and everyone on the subway and at work could smell them from afar. Tasted amazing though. The #1 and #5 were pretty much the same thing, except #5 was longer... Came here during lunch from jury duty. Got the house special with hot sauce. Amazing! Was tempted to buy another sandwich to go but happy I didn't because 1 fills you up pretty good. The house special with hot sauce is excellent (order with  if you want an extra kick). They seem to bake the bread in-house a few times a day, and the ingredients are very fresh. The trade off is that they often run out of some ingredients around 4/4:30 and close early, so show up before then. I've been here twice and both times my bahn mi's were good. There's always a line and wait time possibly because the place is so small. There were two or three chairs to sit and eat at the tiny counter near the window. Both times I ordered the House special which is the spicy grilled pork. You have the option to not have it spicy.  I prefer my bread not toasted but it does come toasted. I love the tasty pork with all the flavors and right balance of spiciness. The sandwich is a decent size for a fair price in Manhattan. I could've used a little bit more meat because it was that good. The staff were friendly and the place is definitely more of a take out joint. I would keep this spot bookmarked to check out some other menu items. I can't believe that I never reviewed this place! I used to come here often when I worked in the area. The banh mi are delicious and a great deal. My favorite is the #5, the pate. Although it has pork liver in it, it doesn't have that liver taste.
