During lunch time it can get a little crowded since the space is so small. There are a few stools by the window but most people get it to go. It's cash only. This is by far our favorite Bnh m place. Small hole in the wall.  Absolutely no ambience.  Only four seats (sometimes 5).  Nice staff, great prices.  We ordered #1House Special and #8 curry chicken.  Ingredients are always fresh.  Flavors are wonderful.  The 2 Bnh Mia are fairly spicy.  Bread is toasted just right.  I haven't seen any curry chicken offered elsewhere.  This is cash only but this is a ATM machine inside if needed. Solid viet sandwich. My usual is the house special #1 bahn mi. A good amount of meat to vegetable ratio.They open early so I usually stop by on my way to work. They close shop once they run out of food so closing time varies day to day.Minus 1 star due to the fact that they increased prices twice in a short period of time. #1 used to be a great deal at only $5.50. Then they increased it to $6 and more recently $6.50. Hidden, off from the main streets of Chinatown, you would find this hidden gem spot.  Its small - from the looks of it outside, you will probably think its just another old chinese grocery store - but its actually the home of Manhattans best bahn mi sandwiches.The sandwiches will cost you around 6$ (CASH ONLY) - and although it is pricier than the ones in ct, these are worth the extra dollar.  Every single sandwich is packed with flavor.  My personal favorite is the #1 - combination.  Make it spicy (for no extra cost, peppers and hot sauce).  #3 is my second favorite, the minced pork.  I usually can only eat half a sandwich - and I bring home the other half, for dinner (so technically its 3$ meal for me) A little hole in the wall with great banh mi sandwiches. Minus one star because the bread was a little tougher than I would like. But flavorwise, everything is on point. Pickled veges are very well pickled...not too sweet/not too bland. We had the number one and number five. Number five was our favorite as the pate highlighted the flavors. Serving is huge. One sandwich is good for two people. Vietnamese sandwiches are in my top 5 favorite food.This place would be the place to go. I always get the house special with a Vietnamese ice coffee.The ice coffee is strong but sweet and the sandwich is on point. They have about 10 different types of sandwiches but the house special is the way to go. Hint of sweetness from the cucumbers, sour from the picked veggies and meaty with the deli meat and pork all in a 10inch-ish baguette.The problem with some places is that they toast the baguette to long where the bread would cut ur gums.They never toast it to long. It's always perfect.Sometimes I would bring it home and toss in a fried egg.... fireeeee One of the stop of the NY food tour. This place serve the best Vietnamese sandwich in the city. Get there before 4pm to guarantee they don't sell out of their sandwiches. No line but lots of patrons. The best bahn mi sandwich I've ever had! This place is a no-nonsense eatery that never fails. There is limited seating, only a couple of stools and small table space. Probably not the best location for a date or hours of juicy gossip to share, but you will have some tasty bites here. You will not regret this. Order #1, it's my jam. This place serves absolutely legit Bahn Mi.The bread had just the right texture and crunch on the outside, with all that tender soft breadiness inside.Just the right balance of everything.Chicken was cooked to perfection.I like that they give you a choice of spicy or not on any of the sandwiches. I love this place, try the chicken sandwich, it is very nice and juicy. The most important part of a sandwich is the bread and this store nails it. The bread is kinda like a real Vietnamese French baguette. Best banh mi's ever.My boyfriend and I always eat one there and bring home like 3 or 4. When you reheat them in the toaster oven, it's another level of magic.Speaking of, tomorrow, I plan on getting 4. hahahaha

We came here for Christmas Eve. The ambience is intimidate and quiet. It was a busy night so the servers tried their best to be attentive. They also helped me with charging my phone when the battery was almost dead. That's a plus!We booked Chef's Tasting Menu, and it was $120 per person for 6 courses. The portion was actually greater than what I expected. Egg on Egg on Egg is absolutely amazing, and it was served in a uni shell! Not to mention the freshness of the food, the combination of uni, sturgeon caviar and scrambled egg went very well. The scrambled egg was a little warm so when you eat it with the iced uni and caviar, the flavors with the freshness really came out and dissolve in the mouth. The price wasn't too expensive for the portion that we had. The lobster meat of the lobster ramen dish was actually big although the lobster meat was not fresh that day. The portion of the Wagyu Ribeye Steak was "too much" that we actually had it as to-go. I definitely miss their Egg on Egg on Egg! I was sick today, so I couldn't really taste much. But I like the octopus and shishito pepper. We also ordered the Wagyu steak, and it's a bit too fatty for me. The triple egg dish is ok, but I mean you gotta order it right?I just wish that they allow one person to order the chefs special, instead of a hard requirement for all or none.I might consider coming back if I'm ever around that neighborhood. This restaurant is incredible and one of my favorites in NYC.  If you like uni as much as I do, you will love the food here.  This restaurant is great for a dinner with friends, work meeting or I'm guessing date as well.  Special shout-out to Dolores, who is probably the kindest person I've spoken to about a restaurant reservation.  Can't wait to go back.Anybody giving this place less than four stars is completely wrong and should be given a puppy. Came here as a 2nd choice on a Sat night, but had a very enjoyable, nice time! Not busy at all, although we did make reservations just in case. So of course, I tried the famous egg on egg and egg. Yes, it's super tiny, but yes it's delicious! Super subtle, but very obviously uni tasting, the caviar and egg itself was superb! Could definitely eat like 20 of these. The bone marrow with the tartare was a really complimentary dish. Why is this pairing not as prevalent as it should be?! The fattiness of the bone marrow and the leanness of the meat work super well together.The kari kari crispy salad was super refreshing! And very plentiful.The grilled octopus was super interesting as it was quite meaty and not the typical octopus texture I was used to. Super tender and soft. Finally the waygu hamburger was probably the least exciting item I tried (it was also served last so I was a bit full). The meat itself taste good but it just got a bit mundane to eat after while, it's a huge patty! And out of the three sauces, I only enjoyed the sesame one.  Didn't have enough room for dessert, but had a very nice meal. Service was decent and ambiance is good for a date or group of friends. A bit pricey but worth it for a nice night out! Definitely recommend! A must try when you're here is the Egg on Egg on Egg. It is steamed egg, topped with uni and caviar. It is pretty small, so if you want to order one for just for yourself because you LOVE uni, no one will judge you!We also ordered the grilled octopus, which is served on spring mix and a few slices of red beets. Good, but nothing super ordinary. The sashimi for three was fresh and a solid choice. It came with fish roe, yellowtail, fluke, oysters, mackerel, salmon and one other fish, and of course, freshly grated wasabi. The duck was more on the sweeter side but still pretty good; it was served with collard greens. We ordered the uni pasta that comes with bone marrow and my favorite part of the meal was the truffle  uni rice pot. It is limited, so hope you are lucky that night to be able to order one.Overall, a delighted meal. I would recommended their Japanese whiskey cocktails when you are here. I just went to dinner here tonight for a work event and let me tell you it was amazing!!! The reviews for this place do not do it justice. If I could give more than 5 stars I would. I am a vegetarian so I couldn't try a lot of the dishes but what I had was cooked excellently, and flavors were mixed in a thoughtful and poetic way so much so that my meat eating friends loved the vegetarian dishes we tried as well. The dishes I tried were: charred broccolini, cha soba salad, little gem lettuce, and kari kari crispy salad. All were AMAZING and well worth it. To me what made this place the most excellent besides the amazing food was the service. Our wait staff was so attentive and knowledgeable and just made the whole experience one I'll never forget. Thank you, Sakamai, for a wonderful evening I'll cherish forever! A high quality Japanese restaurant with great service and unique entrees.Here's a more detailed breakdown of my order:1. EGG ON EGG ON EGG - This is the most famous dish at SakaMai, so of course I ordered it. My first impression was disappointment because it was a lot smaller than I had imagined, but then again, it is uni, so it couldn't be too big. This is such a unique combination and the small size of it made me savor each bite even more. It does feel like a one time thing, but because it is so unique, if I do return to SakaMai, I think I will find myself ordering it again.2. UNI MAZEMEN - My favorite thing I ordered. The ramen noodles were very well cooked and the texture of it mixed with the uni created a flavorful, creamy mix. Halfway through the dish, the waiter informed me that I was supposed to mix the bone marrow with the ramen, and the extra fat from the bone marrow transformed the dish into something completely else. Before and after adding the bone marrow had such different tastes that I would treat them as separate entrees, but both were amazing on their own (but I did prefer the before taste)3. GRILLED OCTOPUS - I was pleasantly surprised at how soft and perfectly charred this octopus was. I savored every bite of it and was incredibly disappointed when I finished it.4.WAGYU HAMBURGER STEAK - a bit of a disappointment. It was the heaviest thing I ordered, and it wasn't for me. Aa someone who prefers medium rare, the meat was very dry. The sauces were flavors I had never tasted before and were fun to experiment with.--Overall, I enjoyed my meal at SakaMai. It definitely is not an everyday restaurant due to its steep price, but I highly recommend it as a place to celebrate a special day.taste / 4aesthetics / 5vibe / 5service / 5price for quality / 4OVERALL / 5 This review is for sake only. We stopped by this sake lounge after being stuffed with ramen. One of my friends was looking for some hot sake which wasn't offered at Yokoya, so I looked up on yelp, and SakaMai popped up. Isn't it great to roam around in NYC? We got seated in the booth in front. Our lovely and knowledgeable waiter recommended a few great sake. We ordered a carafe of Nine-Headed Dragon and another carafe of some sake. Both of them were really good. I'd totally visit this place again. 3.5Everything looks super good but taste was a lil underwhelming as well as portion for the price point. I prob would have bumped it up to a 4 in terms of star if the price was a lil lower. The drinks were surprisingly really good though.Food-Egg on Egg ($19): Good but nothing earth shattering. Its like a japanese egg custard paired with uni and black caviar.Mazemen ($13): This was probably my favorite dish. Its a dry ramen dish with uni and bone marrow. The uni makes it a lil creamy, but not overdone that its a sauce. Taste was also really good.Truffle Uni Rice Pot ($75): This can feed a table of 5-6. Which explains why its 75 bux lol. The taste leaves a lil something to be desired. There were fresh truffles and uni and its cooked in a rice pot. The uni comes out cooked, which some of us didnt enjoy as much as it just being raw. And there just wasnt enough truffle flavor.Ikura Tofu ($12): This one was kinda like the egg custard again, but instead of egg, its tofu. I wouldnt say it tasted completely like tofu tho, it still has that custard texture. Its then topped with salmon eggs. Not bad but prob wouldnt get again. Overall, while I did enjoy the experience, I think at that price point, it isnt enough to make me come back. What an underrated find!! I loved this place! Let's start with the ambiance, the restaurant is beautiful with great decor and fine touches of sale barrels everywhere.Now the food...We started with the shisito peppers which were good but the cucumber dish is a must have. The spicy sauce on top really complemented the crispy raw cucumberThe egg on egg is no doubt amazing. Was really sad when that ended but happy to get the salad followed by the octopus. The octopus was so flavorful and tender it's a must have when you're there. The steak was good but nothing too special the potatoes that came with the steak and sauces were phenomenal! Get the pork belly sliders but you can skip the duck and the 75$ truffle pot might seems amazing but it was really just a lot of rice with a touch and truffle and uni.All in all great experience, great food will definitely come back THIS PLACE IS THE BEES KNEES. I went here for dinner and although the portions are small, the prices are decent for the quality and taste of the food. I stuffed my face with Lower East Side's finest Japanese restaurant. The music and atmosphere is also good here. It's a little dark but that's part of the hospitality experience. I tried the uni waygu rolls, pork sliders (the best i've ever had), sashimi, shashito peppers, duck proscuitto, and the deserts...unreal. You can't go wrong. I'll most definitely be coming back for the ramen, waygu, uni rolls (fantastic), sliders, and to try everything else on the menu. I thought I would like it more, cuz man I loooove my uni. But I can't help but feel a little disappointed because it is not as good as I thought. TLDR: It's a solid three star. There are good things and not so good things to say about this place.Let's go over the dishes we ordered:1.Egg on egg on egg. This is what drew me into the restaurant but it was unfortunately definitely not my favorite. Scrambled egg was too oily and the flavor was too overpowering. Being not the star of the dish, the egg was definitely trying too hard to be present...I imagine a softer steamed egg custard will compliment better for the star of the dish - uni and caviar. Of course I ate all of it cuz it's still delicious, but I wish it would be better. 2. Uni and Wagyu roll. I really didn't like it! For whatever reason, the Wagyu left a bad after taste. Maybe it was too fatty and they didn't do a good job to get rid of that beefy taste. The dish would be much better off without the Wagyu - it was just too much going on.3. Uni Mazemen. Of course we ordered all three of the uni dishes on the menu....This is probably my favorite out of the entire meal. Flavor and noodle's texture was superb. However, this is a very very heavy dish. Noodle was very creamy because of the uni and bottarga already, and they put bone marrow on top of it. My bowl was drenched with grease; but hey that's what makes it good.. 4. Ikura tofu. Not as memorable. I am not a fan of Ikura, but my friend enjoyed  it. 5. Sashimi Platter. Oyster was good, other cuts were not very memorable. Also they served us Ikura even though we already ordered Ikura tofu. Kind of not as considerate and redundant.6. Black sesame cream brulee and Mochi Parfait. Very delicious desert. My second favorite thing for the entire meal.  7. We also ordered Rihaku cloudy Sake. They do have a nice selection if you are into Sake.Other random things: 1. Ambiance is very good. Nice dating spot as they have some private booths in the back. 2. Service was excellent. We were able to get free Sake tasting. The server gave us a full glass for "test". 3. Halfway through the meal I noticed a small fly trying to get into my sake cup. There were also some small flies in bathroom. Kind of not expecting this in this upscale restaurant. I'm not a clean freak but it's kind of surprising to see...4. Price is definitely very high...food+drink+tip and tax come out to be $200+. Date spot alert! Tell that girl you like you'll take her to your fave Japanese restaurant. Come here and try the below, it'll (most likely) guarantee a second date. Maybe. Egg on Egg on Egg: I don't like uni. #sorrynotsorry But this soft scrambled egg dish topped with uni is savory, decadent and most importantly a #musttry. This seemingly odd dish melts in your mouth and is refreshingly different than most uni dishes I've tried.Uni Mazemen: Clearly, I didn't pick this. My date did because he wanted uni and I sat there like, "no dude, that's cool. I didn't just mention I don't like uni five times." Whatevs.  I'm glad we did because this creamy pasta dish topped with bone marrow is almost as good as the uni pasta from DomoDomo. The only note? Not a huge fan of the egg-y noodles. I wish they used some other type of noodles. Grilled Octopus: Literally, melts in your mouth. How? I don't know. This super tender octopus is delicious and seasoned well. Def have the octopus with some of the sauce that's on the plate, beneath the octopus. This place definitely exceeded my expectations!  I made a reservation for two for 6:00 PM on a Wednesday evening.  They open at 6 so a reservation is not really needed but it doesn't hurt right?!  We were seated promptly and ordered the following:Egg on Egg on Egg ($19.00): all I have to say is WOW.  This was one of the best uni dish I ever had and no wonder this is the most popular item on their menu!  The uni was SO fresh and it paired so well with the warm scrambled egg.  I highly recommend this!Uni Mazemen ($26.00): temomi ramen noodle topped with sea urchin with a bone marrow on the side.  The portion of this dish was small but the flavor was definitely there.  The ramen had a super rich flavor to it paired with the uni.Grilled Octopus ($18.00): I did NOT expect an octopus to be this SOFT.  The octopuses I usually eat are very chewy, gum-like texture but this one was soooooo good.  It takes no effort to bite into the octopus and it literally melts in your mouth once you bite into it.  SO GOOD!Beef Tartare ($19.00):  If you are a beef lover, you have to get this.  This dish consisted of a roasted bone marrow with bread and beef tartare.  Even though I did not try it myself, my friend who had it was blown away by this dish.  The portion is really good too!Spicy Cucumber ($9.00): I really wanted a veggie dish and decided to opt for this!  It was not spicy at all but definitely flavorful.Service - A1!!!  Everyone here is super polite and respectful.  The waiter who served us made sure our glasses were always filled with water.Price/Portion - the portion of this place is definitely more tapas style and the price is pretty high BUT I would definitely come again given the service and quality of their food! I've eaten here twice and both experiences were completely different. First time - overall great experience with delicious food and attentive service. Personally, I think the egg on egg on egg is not worth the price. Nice to try since it's a signature dish, but it's literally less than one full bite of food. The standouts for me are the green tea soba noodles, karage with dipping sauce, tartare, and sliders. If I were grading based on this experience alone, this place would have received more stars.Second time - safe to say that I will most likely not visit again after this experience. I made a reservation, but was told by the hostess that there was "no room" in the dining area of the restaurant even though I visibly saw open tables. Since it was winter, I was not pleased with the fact that I was seated across the bar right next to the door. This time, I went to the bathroom and realized not only was it tiny, the soap was SUPER watered down (one of my biggest pet peeves at restaurants). Honestly, if I am paying $$$ at a dining establishment, I expect there to be usable soap and to be seated in an area that doesn't require me to dine with my winter attire. Sometimes it feels like this city has a million "upscale but low-key izakaya-style Japanese-inspired small plates with sake and cocktails" places. And none of them deliver on their promise. Except for SakaMai.My friend just got into grad school and we were looking for a place to ball out last minute. I was able to book on OpenTable around 5 pm on a Saturday night for 8:30 that night. I had to call ahead to tell them that we were running 15 minutes late and they were super accommodating.The location is convenient to the F and J though unfortunately in the bustle of the LES bar scene. Inside is an oasis of dim lighting and brick walls. It was pretty full when we got there so they seated us in a back room that felt more Italian than Japanese, but it was nice for an intimate catch up dinner.The cocktail list is beyond tempting-- saw lots of tequila and sake-based drinks. The sake list is relatively curated but has a good mix. We went with a carafe of the Oze No Yukidoke junmai, which was dry and delicious. Service here is top notch; when he poured he let me taste and had some tasting notes on it which were spot on (full melon nose and a crisp clean finish! yum!). Markup is about double on the carafes but we did get reasonably soused for $32. Small beer and wine selection as well.There's a substantial specials list so don't plan your meal out too far ahead of time. This includes daily sashimi and some high-end meat options. The regular menu is divided into categories like meat and vegetables, with a section just for uni. We shared 8 plates among two people and were bursting; we could've gone one or two less. The rundown in order of dishes received:-  Shishito Peppers: Done well, but unless you're craving these and/or always get them, skip to save stomach space.- Egg on Egg on Egg: Wowowow. Everyone says to get this and they're right. I'm not even a big uni fan and thought this was amazing. The eggs are soft, the caviar is salty, the uni is rich. We devoured this. It's like a smoky and decadent upgrade on chawanmushi. Melt in your mouth.- Grilled Octopus: Yes! This was my friend's first time trying octopus (vegetarian until recently) and he said, "I didn't expect it to be so tender"... and the thing is, octopus can be chewy and rubbery but this was the perfect texture and had a charred and buttery flavor. Quite a dramatic dish too. The watermelon radish and gochujang sauce were nice counterpoints and not just plate decoration.- Amberjack Sashimi: Very good and fresh, served on a bed of ice with garnishes. Price is fair for quality and quantity. Their cooked dishes outperformed this, however.- Bone Marrow and Beef Tartare: More wowowow's from both of us. Another dramatic plate with the full bone. You spread the marrow on the bread and top with some of the raw beef. I could eat this bone marrow all day, it was so smoky and rich (a bit of a theme here). Fun to make little toast sandwiches and all the components are good but the marrow steals the show.- Duck Breast: Yum. Good ring of fat around it and cooked a perfect medium. Was fond of the greens too. Only get if you're craving duck though since it's pricy and the portion is small compared to other dishes.- Filet Mignon: Yes. Comes out on a sizzling plate so take it off quick since it's already cooked to a medium rare / medium. Definitely high quality beef. Comes with fingerling potato chunks and lovely fried garlic slices. The three sauces are fun to try out. I was enamored with the red sauce (Korean-inspired?) and my friend thought the creamy green chimichurri-style one was best.- Black Sesame Creme Brulee: The nutty flavor came through well, and the burnt sugar top was thin and fun to crack open. The almond biscuit didn't add much. Good stuff. Honorable mention for the hojicha tea, which gave us a soothing end to the meal.Overall, I would say the must get dishes were Egg on Egg on Egg, Octopus, Bone Marrow, and Filet Mignon. Everything else was still above average.Service mostly left us alone, though every interaction with them was positive, and it was a relaxed pace meal. It took us around 2 hours in and out. The bill was about $180 before tip, though you could definitely plan it smarter and get out of here cheaper. We were stuffed and went for some decadent dishes.Not an everyday place but worth it for a special occasion. If only you knew the kind of day I had... Possibly the fanciest business meeting at the fanciest building in the prettiest island in the world. That feeling that you had been on the top of the world, literately and figuratively speaking. You'd understand it if you followed me that day. It was that kind of day that led to my high expectations turned sour in Tribeca. Dinner reservation was made at 9:45. Went to the original restaurant three times and they were not ready for us, so I cancelled on my last try and headed to the lower east side. It was a brisk walk. My girlfriend and I were walking gingerly in a city filled with diners and soon to be nightclub goers at 10:30 pm. She had come from upper west side. I have become such a fan of the lower east side over the last three years that wheneverI'm in town I'm there. Passing the New Museum, passing more cool stores, passing slightly drunk Manhattanites, we looked for restaurants as I once again contemplated the real likelihood of living in New York. With a brand new office in Chelsea, and my new headcount and I could be based in New York, I feel a sense, or should I say, a "real" sense of possibility? That's when SakaMai came calling. We were hungry. We wanted a quiet place to catch up. This place is super chill. Mellow bartenders and excellent servers. Drink menu is all filled with chilled sake. They gave me an extended menu selection when the usual drink menu failed me. The sashimi for two are amazing and a super bargain at $39. Totally different fish and super fresh, the texture is almost not seen outside of Japan. Or maybe in San Francisco, people don't have such high standard on the freshness of the fish? At $16 for the pot of mussels, it's a steal. Excellent sake.Sashimi and Sake, what more do you really need? Sakes are all yummy. I ordered the cloudy one. We ordered sashimi for two - you get 14 pieces of excellent fish and oysters. Way better than you'd ever get in California and for 2/3 of the price too.The waitress poured more sake for us than we could drink.We catch up on lives - east coast and far east. West coast and its stress. Discuss possibilities. I pictured myself, properly middle aged, drinking sake, having some sashimi, day in and day out, working hard but also living happily for the remains of my day in New York. A life long dream, closer than ever. Property price is borderline a bargain bin basement price comparing to the San Francisco bay area. I will have Sakamai to thank for. Friday 11 pm. A perfect meal. A perfect evening. The night or perhaps a new life, is calling. First off: to the waiter that served us on Saturday June 10 7PM (sorry I forgot your name) YOU WERE AMAZING! Thank you so much for the amazing service and being so attentive and thoughtful. Our experience here was wonderful because of you!Surprisingly on a saturday at 7pm, the place was pretty empty. Onto what we ordered:Egg on Egg on Egg: So amazing, to die for. Every aspect of this dish was so amazing, and my boyfriend (who doesn't care for uni) said this was his favorite dish of the night!Beef Tartare: comes with bone marrow and sliced mini baguette. If you smear the bone marrow on the mini baguette and top it off with the tartare, it is phenomenal, but I do have to say that the beef tartare by itself is a little bland. The two combined together is a great flavor pairing though, so make sure you ration out everything evenly so you have enough bone marrow and baguette for the tartare!Bone-In Strip Loin Steak: flavors were all there, very tender and juicy. the fried garlic slices on top was the cherry on top. sooooooo delicious. the potatoes that comes with this is freaking amazing too.Sashimi Platter (for two): not much to say except very fresh and well sliced!Grilled Octopus: Probably the best grilled octopus I've very had. The dish was really cohesive in terms of flavor combination. Every component of the dish amazed us. 10/10 would recommend!Black Sesame Creme Brulee: yesssssssssss. so interesting, fragrant, and delicious. I would come back again and again just for this!!! This is my favorite spot when I crave some awesome uni. The Uni Mazemen is incredible. It is a mixture of temomi ramen , bottarga, bamboo shoots and YUMMY uni. It also come with bone marrow. This whole combo is really delicious and filling. I would share this bowl with someone or eat it last. It can make you full easily and you don't want to miss out on other things. I had their uni & wagyu roll and beef tartare recently. Both were great. The roll consisted of wagyu beef, uni, pickles and wasabi. Beef tartare was mixed with red miso paste, mushroom & horse radish paired with bone marrow and bread. I must say it can be pretty pricey to eat here. It is worth trying though =) We choose to have dinner here tonight merely based on the reviews. To our disappointment we all found that this Japanese fusion restaurant is overpriced, food was below expectations, bland sashimi that was probably comparable to buffet quality at best. Prior to entering the premises,  I noticed they had a letter B- grade posted at the door with the  last inspection being 12/30/16.  This was already a disappointment, since we know we will be wanting to have raw shellfish and or fish.  We arrived at 630pm, we found the place empty when other restaurants were crowded for dinner service on the same block.  We were seated in the very back of the restaurant on a table for 4.  We were given the pre fix $65 menu, ala carte menu and the menu which had the specials.  Right away I noticed colorful cloths which did not look like napkins but to my surprise these were the napkins we would be using for dinner service.  I swear, I thought it was a rag. I will show you a picture, threads were hanging at the end of the napkins and they do not clean your hands, on top of that we all had different color napkins for our table settings.  Egg on egg on egg ($19) is built inside the shell of a sea urchin. It has been hollowed and filled with a mixture of steam egg that is some what runny and soft. On top they add the uni which had hints of minerality and top with caviar. This all sounds awesome and it is truly beautiful to look at. However, I will start by telling you to not expect a mother of pearl spoon for the caviar. Instead you get a wood spoon, felt like a carpenter for a brief moment but I got over it in light of the beautiful presentation. The soft steam egg in combination with the uni and caviar failed to work harmoniously. The uni overpowered the egg and the caviar had no identity. Clearly I do not expect Beluga or Petrosian quality caviar but it lacked salt.  Beef tartare($19) was a lovely combination of the roasted bone marrow, red miss, crispy maitake mushroom and horseradish that worked harmoniously. We were instructed to make sure we mixed the red miss into the beef. The bone marrow should be used as butter and spread on to the French baguette and the beef is placed as a topping on the bread. I love it and so did the entire table.Wagu and uni roll ($18) 4 small rolls wrap in seaweed. Inside the taste of smoked takuan pickles was the most prominent ingredient, wasabi which I did not taste, wagu beef and top with sea urchin.  We all agreed that we could have done without it.Grilled octopus ($18)was very tender, had a nice char but oddly it lacked flavor. I asked the server where did they source the octopus from and she was frazzled, she simply excuse her self and she ran into the kitchen. She came out a few moments later to let me know it was from Spain. The octopus was resting on a slight amount of gochujang pepper sauce that was spread lightly on the plate, accompanied by a few pieces of frisee and watermelon radish.Chef special sashime plate for 2 ($39) a huge bowl filled with crushed ice and each order comes with 7 different pieces of sashimi.  Our order had an assortment of tuna, oysters, clam, salmon, fluke and amberjack. The tuna was a dull shade of red, seemed dry and it had no taste.  The amberjack was tough, did not care for it. The oysters were excellent, creamy and very meaty.  The salmon was just ok. Nothing stood out of the plate. My daughter even commented that if this was the chefs special platter, it really made you think what the regular sashimi order would be like. I know there is some sarcasm but if I go out for Japanese food. I expect great sashime. Instead today we relied heavy on cook food item menu, which is something we never do. Uni Mazemen ($26) is actually a bowl of them ramen noodle with sea urchin, bone marrow and bottarga ( cured fish roe) we were instructed to scoop the bone marrow out and mix it with the ramen.  The ramen itself was over cooked, the noodles had no bite but the did have a very good flavor. Once mixed with everything else in the bowl the combination of ingredients was very good.The ingredients form a creamy consistency and a silky feel to the palate.For dessert we had the black sesame creme brulee which everyone at the table raved about.Just in case you were wondering, we sort of made our own tasting menu and we shared the plates which was a fun way to try a few items without much commitment to anyone individual plate.  I don't think I would come back again. After reading the health inspection report, I give this place zero stars. However, there are some items that are good on the menu. To the management, your wait staff is very accommodating, polite and you restaurant has a nice ambiance. However, even with all that it is still not enough to create repeat customers. In case you were wondering dinner was about $225. No alcohol consumed on the table as we were there to have a pure experience based on food only.

My friend frequents Sel Rrose and highly recommended it. I made a reservation through OpenTable and was seated early on a Thursday evening. The service here is relaxed, but our server was too quick to leave the table and didn't check in on us. The servers float around a lot, checking to clear tables. I would give the service a 3, but honestly, I loved too much of the cocktails, food, and atmosphere that I am sticking with my 5 stars.We ordered a dozen oysters during Happy Hour. I enjoyed almost every oyster I tried. They were great! The Santa Rosa cocktail is incredible. I ordered 3 (no shame, it was my birthday!) It's a tequila cocktail with sparkling ros. We shared the Steak Tartare and Citrus Marinated Chiogga Beets. Both dishes were fantastic, and quite large portions for tapas (pic). We finished with the Chicken Liver Pat, which was very creamy and spreadable.I would love to come back to try more cocktails and different share plates. Highly recommend for date night or girls night. The ambience is dim, candlelit, and romantic. Highly recommend for after-work drinks. This place was suggested to me by my first Yelp (Elite!) friend ever, so I know she wouldn't suggest anything subpar (thanks, Mel!). The drinks here did not disappoint and neither did the decor. Very LES!I ordered the Santa Rosa - Sparkling Ros, tequila, orange bitters, lime, and rose syrup garnished with a rose bud because they're trendy like that. The drink was massive so I couldn't have more than one. I would say it was worth the price.I know this place has oysters but I didn't get a chance to try them or the other apps. I'd come back here for happy hour though. I believe it's until 7pm. I came here for happy hour at 4PM on a Friday and the place was empty. I was seated at a table immediately. There is only happy hour on oysters and not on drinks, which is from 4PM-7PM. If you want a drink with your oysters, then you need to pay full price ($14). I opted not to order one. There are six types of oysters on happy hour but please note that only ONE kind is $1 and the other five were $1.25 or $1.50. The six types available when I went were Big Rock, Wellfleet, Petite Crowe's Pasture, Capital, Fin De La Baie and St. Simon. I ordered a dozen, with two types each because I wanted to try all the different types and taste the different flavors. My favorite was Fin De La Baie because it was very smooth and not too briny. I did not enjoy the Petite Crowe's Pasture or Capital as much. St. Simon was worth it for a $1 - I could have ate another dozen of that. Solid place for oyster happy hour if you want to try different kinds for a good price. But I wish they had a happy hour for their cocktails. I found this place through yelp and have been wanting to try this place. When I was in NY, I came here with my friend for happy hour! I believe they don't take reservation if you want to do happy hour.The set up is kind of a weird juxtaposition. We sat outside and was facing the busy streets. It was a funny scene to pair with our meal. We ordered some truffle fries and oysters. The oysters were delicious! Also, you can't go wrong with truffle fries.  They also have a small selection of cocktails, wines, and beers to choose from. It's a cute date spot or to good spot to catch up with a friend! I definitely recommend trying this place if you are in the area! The restaurant is upscale, open and the perfect HH spot for good oysters and drinks. $1 oysters during happy hour, 4-7PM get you any oysters on their menu! I love this, because most happy hour oysters are limited to one selection. We got about two dozen oysters between the both of us, and tried most of the oysters on the menu. All were delicious and so fresh! We also got an order of truffle fries, which were seasoned and fried to perfection. I got the Spring and Delancey, which was on the sweeter side, but nonetheless tasted good. Cocktails all range from $12-$15, sadly there aren't any specials on the cocktails. There's a few tables outside as well, for a nice summer day. Definitely will be returning for some good oysters! Was craving some oysters so we went there for happy hour. There were , several kinds of oysters on the HH menu, were mostly $1.25 and $1.5.. I wasn't too happy with the oyster selections, most of them were like pink finger sized and not so briny. Also there was no drinks specials Service was not the best, not much attention from our waiter. And he also messed up our check with the regular oyster price instead. Cafe review;"It was great catching up with you. I have to catch my flight now"."I used to have my own office and was high up in cooperate but then I decided, screw that, and quit"."Can I get a double shot of espresso with that"."Excuse me, how do I get to Lafayette street, I'm trying to go to ______".I kid you not, it only takes sitting here a few hours to soak up all that quintessential NY-ness. It's buzzing outside on Delancey St but once you step inside, the playlist, calming feels, retro look with a dash of swanky French modernism all react to create the perfect buffer to noise cancel any concrete hustle decibel. I haven't tried their pastries but my latte was pretty solid. Prices are very reasonable considering the location. Come to read a novel. Come for your coffee break. Come to catch up with a friend. Other useful info:- WiFi is unlimited.- There are NO plugs/outlets. I repeat, no plugs or outlets!!-They've that ceiling paint chip look going on and I'm not sure if that's healthy/sanitary or just a design but they've an "A" so I guess NYC health approves. If you're sick and tired of Bluepoints oysters, Sel Rrose might've just become your next favorite oyster happy hour spot. Your search is probably over since this place has St. Simon oysters from New Brunswick for $1 apiece from 4-7. Please take note that happy hour only applies to oysters, not on any drinks. Draft beer selection is alright. You'd rather cross the street to One Mile House for a better selection there, plus cash back! I went crazy and ordered 3 dozens of oysters. I got 18 St. Simon, 6 Big Rock from MA, 6 Chelsea Gem from WA and 6 Aunt Dotty's from MA. I'd recommend the last two. Chelsea Gem are buttery and very briny. Aunt Dotty's are just perfectly briny. This place was decent. Your average cocktail bar slash gastropub.I got the le mount which is a nice whiskey based drink. The pink negroni was also nice. Cocktails are strong well made. Cocktails are all around $15In terms of food, I ordered the poached octopus which was really an octopus salad with celery and chickpeas. Not very impressive. It wasn't bad but not worth what they were charging. Dishes were around $15. I also tried their chickpea fries which were very good. Imagine vegan mozz sticks.Their truffle fries are incredibly addictive.My favorite dish of the night was probably the beef tartare. It was very well seasoned and the leeks went well with it.My friend found a fly in his drink, but they replaced it promptly.I don't think I'll be going out of my way to come to this place. It's hip and the drinks aren't bad but nothing about it really stands out to me. It's your typical pricey/sceney bar downtown. BF and I shared:+ truffled risotto croquettes+ watermelon & cucumber salad+ poached calamari+ truffled fries+ corn side dish (forget the exact name)Decent food. I'd say the standouts were the watermelon salad and truffle fries. Drinks were a little sweet for us. I had the poolside convo and was expecting a little more passionfruit flavor but couldn't really taste it. 3.5 stars. This place is great! We came with a group of friends Saturday night and the bar was pretty busy. By the time most of our group showed up, we were lucky to score some tables in the back. The bar was pretty much packed until we left. // DrinksThe drinks here are delicious! We didn't have a single one we didn't like. My bf and I started with some mezcal cocktails: Vida Verde and The Hunter. The Hunter was our favorite of the 2, so much that the bf ordered another. I also got the White Rose which is absolutely delicious and creamy because of the egg white. I highly recommend!// Service A waitress got us drinks from the bar and put them on our individual tabs that were already open behind the bar. Great service! Sel Rose makes an AWESOME cocktail.  In my mind I thought this was a wine bar, but cocktails are defined nicely their speciality.I got the White Rose, consisting of rye, honey, ginger syrup, lemon, egg white and pineapple. It was fantastic - smooth and balanced, not too sweet or liquor forward. Just wonderful.My friend and I split a bunch of small plates.  The Parmesan truffle fries were the clear winner - a must get! We also ordered the Tuscan kale salad and the bursts, both were excellent.  The plates were actually a pretty decent size, so we definitely didn't finish it all!The service was OK. The ambiance was great - dimly kit, rustic yet fashionable cocktail lounge decor. Good place to keep in mind when in the LES. Oysters, rose, and and good company? There's no better way to celebrate the end of the week. My girlfriend and I came to Sel Rrose with reservations Friday evening at 7 and the place was jammed packed. They offer a variety of seating options that include outside seating, bar seating, and regular table seating. The seating options are relatively small so this place is better for parties of 2-6. If you have a larger party I would definitely call in to see if they can accommodate. The decor of the place is very plain and simple, which I do not mind at all. The minimalisticness makes you focus more on the food and company. A-Okay in my book. For food my girlfriend and I got the Chef's Special Oyster platter and a few cups of rose. The oyster were all very fresh and super delicious. The vinegar is a perfect sauce to put on top.Overall, I am happy to find a place with great oysters. I am sad that I missed the $1 oyster happy hour but will definitely be back next time! Beautiful space, terrific cocktails, and oysters! What more can a girl want? Oh wait, they serve craft coffee too during the daytime? Now I'm really smitten! In all seriousness though, Sel Rrose's space is so gorgeous it should come at no surprise that plenty of IG pics get snapped and posted within their premises. I wish it was located along my daily route so I can frequent it more but for now I'll need to contend with planning oyster and cocktail hour dates or mid-day coffee stops at Sel Rrose. I first got to visit Sel Rrose on New Year's Eve. I was looking for a relatively low-key place to countdown the last of 2016 with my fiance and learned that they were offering reservations for NYE minus the usually overpriced prix fixe dinner menu. So I jumped on the chance, booked a table, and my fiance and I planned for a night out! And it was lovely! There were oysters and great wine and even a nice little burlesque show! We even danced as we waited for 2017. Thanks for the fabulous time Sel Rrose and see you soon! This review is for Sel Rrose cafe next to the restaurant. First impression of this hidden gem was how adorable the decor is! Baristas are always welcoming and the coffee is spectacular. I always get the iced latte here with a croissant, make sure to come in the morning when the croissants are fresh. It's flakey on the outside and soft on the inside, everything that makes up a great croissant. I was hesitant to write this review because I kind of wanted to keep this beautiful place hidden from the world but keeping this place from other coffee lovers such as myself, would be too selfish. I haven't dined in the restaurant but I am sure the restaurant is amazing as well. $1 and up oysters happy hour...I can't complain! Service was good..truffle fries are a must try! The oysters are pretty small though so don't expect big slimy oysters lol but you can't go wrong with two dozen oysters..they didn't offer any saltine crackers with the oysters..and I usually eat them with the crackers. Boo. But I'd still return :) I heard these guys do dollar oysters so I decided to check it out. It's true. I ordered a dozen and each was on the half-shell, already shucked for me. The bar serves a lot of cocktails. They also serve beer and wine. My early & casual happy hour easily became a great catch up session with a friend! Not so sure if it was their happy hour, but oysters were $1-$1.75 each. My friend and I got SO MANY. Maybe two dozen? I also got the Ros on tap, which was a great bubbly drink to have for a spring happy hour. We also ended up getting croquettes and the truffle fries, which we obviously devoured.  Our waitress was helpful--she seemed a little tired but I totally get it. (Who isn't on a Tuesday?!) Other servers were also helpful even though they were not in charge of our table!! When our server was not around, they checked in with us when we seemed like we were looking to order. I was there from 5-8pm on a weekday. At 5pm there were only a few people and by 7pm the music got louder with more people. I'll definitely be back! What a gem! A friend recommenced this place for drinks/oysters and it did not disappoint (I went back 2 out of the 3 days I was visiting)!  Their selection is great and if you have time/appetite, try one or two of each. I'm solely a sparkling wine drinker and don't like added flavors or "show". But I discovered their Lavender Piscine and it was amazing!  Not to mention, their truffle fries hit the spot and the service was great! This place was a pretty standard cocktail bar for the Bowery and Delancey area. The drinks were very good, and they have a lot of creative ones. I had the White Rose, a rye whiskey cocktail with a healthy dose of ginger syrup. It was right up against that line of too spicy on the backend. The drinks are priced accordingly and that's all I'll say on that. It was crowded and loud...cool if you're in that mood, just not my cup of tea.

Ok I loved this place. My bf and I didn't know reservations are preferred but a worker found a table to squeeze us in. From the second we walked in he was super accommodating and we were seated within a few minutes. We came on a Saturday night so I cant talk about the tacos (not available that night) but the sliders were amazing! Between the two of us we tried the dry aged burger, bulgogi cheesesteak, Bahn mi Vietnamese steak and fried chicken slider (can't remember the name). They were all great. Super flavorful and perfect sized.  The bun didn't get too soggy and fall apart and each bite was delicious! If I had to choose a favorite though, I'd go with the Vietnamese steak sliders. It comes with a slice of cucumber, carrots and sriracha mayo. The cucumber gives it a fresh light taste to counteract the spiciness of the mayo- just try it. You'll love it trust me. Another tip: try the tempura shrimp poppers to start. 10/10The loaded tots are great and come with a bunch of toppings. It's $13 and we could only eat half and had to bring the rest home with us lol. The service is great, food is great. I'll def be back. Set les was amazinggggggggg every food we tried hadFlavor, so so good I went with 5 other friends and we alllll loved it and can'tWaitTo go back Service: Our waiter was friendly and attentive. Food came out promptly. They even gave our birthday girl a champagne bottle with a sparkler! What I ordered: Set 3 - $13 (Vietnamese banh mi buttered steak slider, pork belly skewer and Cajun waffle fries). The slider was my favorite part, the steak was so tender and flavorful. The skewer was a little too fatty for me but it was pork belly though. Cajun waffle fries was your average waffle fries. Overall, it was a decent amount of food and tasted good. Price: Worth it. Overall thought: I would definitely come again, especially for a birthday dinner. I had bookmarked this spot after seeing pictures of amazing Asian fusion tacos on insta... unfortunately they only serve those M-F. I was still super impressed with the food and will definitely be back for tacos. I wasn't expecting a sports bar so I was especially impressed with the unique menu. My brother and I both ordered sliders, I love that they let you mix and match because a lot of places don't let you. I had the pork belly (a little too much fat but still tasty), bulgogi (*amazing*) and steak (slightly overdone but still delicious). My brother had the chicken instead of the bulgogi and we loved that one too. The sauces and spicing on each of the sliders was on point.We also split the loaded tots which were amazing (and hard to finish)... it was way too much food and nice to have leftovers! My friend was happy with his wings and beef skewer, I tried a bit of the skewer... it was perfectly tender! Our waiter was also super nice (and seemed to be running the place by himself!) can't wait to go back, highly recommend this place! My first time and overall a pretty good experience. We came just before the after work rush so we were seated immediately and ordered and received our food very quickly. Items we ordered included sliders, tater tots, and wings.3 sliders per order for $14 or you can mix and match sliders for $15 and option to add waffle fries for an additional $3***GRILLED SESAME CHICKEN SLIDERS  topped with their Slaw and a Tangy Spicy Sambal Sauce.BANH MI LEMONGRASS CHICKEN SLIDERS came with Slice of Cucumber, Pickled Carrots and Sriracha MayoSOY GLAZED PORK BELLY SLIDERS topped with Slices of Cucumber and Tangy Soy Garlic SauceSALT AND PEPPER FRIED CHICKEN SLIDERcame with Shredded Lettuce, Jalapeos,  Garlic, Sweet Chili Sauce.** sliders were pretty good. All were decent in size and shareable. Sesame Wings-$12 decent size wings that were crunchy tossed with a tangy sweet and spicy sauce. SET TATER TOTS  $13 Loaded Tots w SrirachaGarlic Cheese, Bulgogli Sliced Ribeye, Bacon Bits, Scallions, Fried Shallots, Slaw, Pickled Onions, Chipotle Mayo and Ketchupcrispy tater tots brought me back to grade school MmmMm. Definitely an artery clogger but worth it.CRISPY WAFFLE FRIES $6 crispy and perfectly friedPOPPER SHRIMP- crispy fried shrimp tossed in a yummy sauce. Service was average. Staff was there when needed and we had to ask for items we needed. Nothing too special or memorable I can recall. Good place to meet up with friends to grab a bite to eat, grab some drinks, or both. When I'm back in town visiting my sister I'll be stopping by since she often frequents this place. Not because I used to frequent this spot on a weekly basis for a year and on a first name basis with all the proprietors...Not because they serve banging... I mean Banging waffle fries Not because the calamari ranks pretty high with sweet tamarind-teriyaki sauce that you can dip those amazeball fries...Because of the Bulgogi Sliders. The perfect 3x3x5 full fist size slider I've ever had the pleasure to palm and ingest. Religious almost, the way the cheese melds into the shredded BBQ beef and clings on for dear life. Oh dear G*d. This single handedly beats out any burger joint, any slider, anyTHING sandwiched between 2 slices of carbohydrates I've had. So, come to set to have a fantastic time. But if you want to be mind-blown by unassuming corner bar turning out one of the best tiny burgers this little town has to offer- by all means, order the Bulgogi sliders. Great spot for getting some extremely tasty food and washing it down with drinks of your choice, or, ask the bartender to choose for you.All the sliders and tacos are super tasty. The pork belly skewer is really great (it's got a lot of fat in it. If you don't like fatty meat, skip this one).Charbroiled oysters reminded me of New Orleans. I left very satisfied. Of course will need to eat a salad  tomorrow. Amazing. This one word describes it all. The service, taste, quality, ambiance.. Its all just perfect. I contemplated on leaving this review cause I honestly don't want to share this place with everyone but they deserve it. Thumbs up. 5 stars. Just. freakin. beautiful.Steak and eggs - perfect. The picture says it all.Hangover tots - they were missing the spam but still delicious.& the sliders were absolutely mouth watering. The pork belly esp!!! I will start off by saying the food is delicious. I had the breakfast tacos and they were absolutely delicious. A friend of mine had three sliders, which he also said were very good. Unfortunately, the service was not as good. My friend and I placed our orders at the same time, except his food came out and mine did not. After waiting for at least 15 minutes and wondering what could take so long to make three breakfast tacos, I asked the waitress where my food was. She went to check and then came back stating that they forgot to make my food. Thus, I had to wait even longer for the food to be prepared. By the time my food arrives, my friend's was cold because he had been waiting for mine to come as well. It was redeeming that the food was really good and they took my meal off of the tab; however, the experience would have been at least a 4-Star had my food not have been somehow forgotten. I would definitely still go back to try for a better experience because of the great food. This is probably one of the place that I had a really bad experience with the waitresses. Like tbh service never bothered me in NYC because its fricken New York. I came to this place on a Saturday based on the reviews I had read from yelp and I liked what I read. The restaurant was decent size and there was like one or two other tables besides us. The other table was super loud and the music was on super loud too, could barely hear the person next to me talk. That was all fine. We ordered:Set 1 ($13): it had one chicken slider, one beef kebab and a lot of fries. First of all ask yourself if you would pay $13 for one small slider and one beef kebab with fries. Now the taste was very bland and no flavor whats so ever besides the kebab which was decent.Set 2 ($13): this had one pork belly slider, a chicken kebab and fries. This was worst than set 1 because the flavor was not good. To much combination of flavors that shouldn't go together.Sesame Chicken Wings ($10): this was my favorite actually. 6 wings to an order. The flavor was nice, sweet and spicy. Super crispy too. BUT BE AWARE... if you come on the weekends, they will try to charge a "mandatory gratuity" where they do not inform you about until you get your check. My waitress came over twice... to order and to give the check, there is one other time where she peep over from another table and was like everything ok, but before we answer she left already. When I got the bill, I realize it looks off... " mandatory gratuity" and then suggested more gratuity on the bottom... THE THING IS she had the audacity to charge an 18% gratuity... someone had to get her from the chair to bring me a check.. like you really think you deserve 18%? But after I confronted her about it, she was like "oh, so its fine if you don't want to tip me" and later took the "mandatory gratuity" off. Like honey please... Set had been on my list to check out for a while and I finally went for dinner this past Thursday night.  We walked in around 7:30pm and the place only had a few people.  It filled up by the time we left at 9pm though.  The atmosphere is sports bar chic, which I dug.  We made it in time for the happy hour and I got the $6 lycheetini, which I wasn't really a fan of.  There was something off.  I like latitude and verlaine's better.  Maybe a non-happy hour one tastes different? The service was really friendly but the server didn't come by again after we got our food so our water glasses were left empty for the rest of the meal.  Also, we were considering getting another drink but didn't get the chance.Alright, let's talk about the food. Some things I really liked and some things I really didn't.  Let me start by saying I'm not the biggest fan of mixing sweet and savory but I do make exceptions for korean food because some dishes are known to have a touch of sweetness.  However, the pork slider at Set was so sweet, I couldn't eat it.  The fried chicken slider was also a bit too sweet, but I could finish that at least.      We also got the loaded tots, which were pretty awesome I must say, but that too had a little more sweetness than I would like.  Hadn't had clams in a while so we threw clams casino into our order, which were just ok and probably wouldn't get again.  The aged beef slider was straight out amazing, could have had 5 of those. I'd say Set is a solid place to grab drinks and have a quick bite before a night out.  Also, although some food was too sweet, it was all still packed with flavor so I'd encourage you to still give it a try. Food is WAAAAAYYY too salty. Did not want to finish any of the food or even touch the pork belly skewer because of how salty it was. My friends and I ended up not finishing the food, what a waste. Prob won't be back for awhile. I ate at the bar with a friend on a Sunday night so it was pretty empty. I ordered the buttered cube steak skewers and the tangy garlic wings. Both were good but the wings were delicious. You get 6 with an order but they are meaty wings cooked with a texture that was crunchy enough for my liking. Friendly bartender! I could have got more stuff but I wanted to get home. Loved this place! I came here with a group of around 8 people on a Tuesday night for my roommate's birthday dinner. I ordered the 3 for $12 set taco special and it hit the spot. Bulgogi cheesesteak taco, tempura fish taco, and tempura shrimp taco were all excellent. The lychee martini was also super delicious!The staff was very attentive and even brought out a bottle of champagne with the sparkler on top for the birthday girl! It was a super sweet gesture. Definitely a great place to satisfy an asian-fusion craving :) I came here on a Saturday, pretty excited to try this place since it's been on my list a while. It was later in the afternoon so it wasn't crowded at all. I tried ordering the breakfast wontons but was later informed they were out. I instead got the breakfast tacos and had a Cape Code Lemonade. While I could taste the gin in the cocktail, I'm not sure if it's super strong since I had a pretty carby meal. So I think I'll have to come back to test that ;) The breakfast tacos were bomb and I got waffle fries with it which were very well-seasoned. This place is great for comfort food and you get a good amount of food for the price. I'd definitely come back again, maybe even for happy hour, or another brunch! I wish I could say that the food is good but unfortunately this is not the case. I came with high expectations from seeing the mouth watering pictures on social media but looks can be deceiving!I had ordered a sampler of tacos and sliders with waffle fries. Let's begin with the fries. Can someone tell me how you can mess up fries?! I absolutely LOVE anything potato and waffle fries especially but I just couldn't get myself to finish them or even enjoy them. There was something off about the sauce that came with the fries but that's okay, you should be able to have fries on their own right? Alright maybe it's not okay but I could live without some chipotle sauce. The fries were mostly stuck together and seemed to be over fried because it tasted like pure oil (where's the Cajun?). Then it was all downhill from there. The sliders came next and were nothing special except extremely salty. The tacos finally came and was probably the highlight of my meal even though it was mediocre at best. The only thing I really enjoyed was the fish taco. I didn't get to try the charbroiled oysters and cajun clams this time but after this visit, I don't know if I'd be back. So I've had Set L.E.S. bookmarked for a couple of months now, and I finally had a Thursday free to go try their tacos. Set opens at 5pm, and there's happy hour from 5-8. Me and my friend went right when it opened to take advantage of the happy hour specials, and to beat the inevitable crowd. It was actually very very empty even until 6, and it felt a bit weird being the only people at the restaurant so we waited a bit until it filled up some more. We chose the window seats right next to the street so there was a lot of natural lighting and a nice breeze. We got started with the loaded tots, the clams casino, a lychee martini for each of us, and we each got the 3 tacos for $12 (we both chose the chicken, shrimp, and fish tacos).The loaded tots are BOMB. There's everything you could possibly want on top of them- cheese, bulgogi, pickled cabbage, ketchup, scallions, and onions. There is more than enough toppings for all of the tater tots, and each bite is so amazing. I think this dish you can definitely share with 4 people. It's jam packed with tots and toppings.The clams casino were so good as well. The clams were pretty fat, and there's a nice herb breadcrumb crust, and most importantly, BACON BITS. It's 6 clams for $9 so not bad on the pricing either. The lychee martini was only $6 during happy hour, and they were surprisingly strong. I expected something cheap and weak, but I could definitely taste the alcohol.The tacos however were disappointing. The thing with the tacos is that they look absolutely amazing- popping with color, perfect tempura batter, the works really. The bahn mi chicken was probably the best out of the 3 I tried. The chicken was perfectly tender, and it went really well with the pickled carrots and radish. I think the "bahn mi" ended at that though- there wasn't anything else that was reminiscent of a bahn mi sandwich, but that's not necessarily a bad thing.The shrimp tempura was a bit of a letdown. What I noticed was that there was a lot of extra tempura batter only. The shrimp itself was nice and sweet, but there was so much unnecessary batter pieces. The overall taco was sweet due to the sauce as well.The fish taco could have been good, but i just found the whole thing to be too SOFT. The fish itself did not have the crispy tempura coating it desperately needed to give it a texture contrast. The fish was nicely cooked and soft, but the avocado just added to the softness, and the entire thing was just a bit too mushy for my liking. The pickled cabbage was a nice touch but I really wished it was more acidic and a bit crunchier. It wasn't bright enough to stand out from the fish or the avocado unfortunately. The biggest travesty of the tacos was the SHELL (or tortilla? I'm new to the taco game so I don't know my terminology yet). I really hope I'm wrong but they tasted store bought to me. The texture was just so off, and tasted NOTHING like the authentic tacos I've had before. Obviously this isn't legit Mexican tacos, but you would think the tortilla would be good at least. There was a really grainy and powdery taste to the tortillas, and it tasted EXACTLY like something you would find prepackaged at a supermarket. The tortilla just ruined all of the tacos for me, especially the bahn mi since that actually had the potential to be so good. Overall I think this is a pretty solid restaurant to drink and chill, but I would say avoid the tacos really. They look so good, but the taste just didn't match up. Came here for a birthday brunch -super chill place! I got the set#2 on the regular menu (pork belly slider and chicken skewer with waffles fries). The waffle fries are really good- the meal didn't look like that much but it was enough! Presentation is cute. Skewers were pretty good!!! Next time I'd try the smoked salmon slider. I really recommend the loaded tots to share for the table- so cheesy and yummy!!!I like the vibe of the place- will be back for tacos. Good comfort place food. I was attending an artist collective down the block two weekends ago and stumbled across this place with a few friends. The menu looked appealing enough and we were seated as soon as we walked through the door. Our waitress was very helpful and kind, allowing us ample time to look over the menu and bringing our drinks to us right away.For a table of three, we ordered the Banh Mi Buttered Steak Sliders, Waffle Fries, and the Set Loaded Tots. Everything came out quickly and tasted great. The tots were a bit spicy, to my liking but still very flavorful. My personal favorite was the sliders- the meat was like a flavor explosion in your mouth, and so very juicy. A bit on the tough side, but I didn't care as much about that.Overall, a great place to share some quick bites or small plates with friends! FRIES. TATER TOTS. Cute bar in the LES area - I've personally never had to wait too long for a table, and I usually come with a group of 6 or more.  Ive been here several times, and I always enjoy the food and atmosphere here.  Service here is always decent, waters get refilled, and they check up on your.  All tables share the servers - which can sometimes get a little messy i.e. they ask you twice if you've ordered already. Must get bar food: waffle fries, and tater tots.  MUST GET.  It is so crispy and done well.  I'm obsessed.  The kalbi slider is my favorite of the bunch - but get three different ones to try since its 3 for 12$.  Skip: Popcorn shrimp dish - not sure what the official name is on the menu, but it was soggy and did not have that wow factor.  The clams were also not memorable.Drinks are weak here - which is disappointing.  They range from about 10-12$ and I'd expect to taste some more alcohol.  If you're a girly drink type of person - this is the place for you.Most definitely will return, esp on a Tues or Thurs to try their taco HH - and when I'm in the mood for some classic bar food.  Also - if you come in a larger party, THEY ADD TIPS INTO YOUR CHECK - not a complaint on my part but something to note.

This is by far one of the best Shanghai soup dumplings places in Chinatown. Delicious fast, efficient & great service. Everything about this place gives me the good feels cause everything that I have ate here has made my soul feel even better. I'll let the pictures do justice. Truffle Soup dumplings ::drool::Make sure you order enough to at least get 2 for yourself!! I only had one, this was over a week ago now, and I'm still kicking myself for not ordering more! Found this place on Yelp. Thank you yelpers! Got there around 4pm on a Friday with my family of 8. After walking like 10 blocks from the subway, my family was all hitting their Hangry wall and probably would have killed me and ate me if we had to wait in a long line. (Yeah, they're savage like that.) But LUCK was on my side! The large group at the only large table was just leaving. So we were able to sit down in 5 minutes!! (I hear, it can be much longer) The staff was friendly and pretty on point. Except if you really want water. It seemed like the one thing that was a hassle to get. Ordered:#8 shrimp dumplingBlack truffle dumpling#11#38 Large egg drop#124 water cress w/ golden mushroom No frills, good food. My cousin was craving soup dumplings and Chinatown seemed to be the half way point between all of us. We showed up to Shanghai Asian Manor a little before 7PM, before a rush of people came in. We didn't have to wait but after we were seated, I noticed the crowd by the door slowly growing as our meal went on. Service at Shanghai Asian Manor is great, the servers are friendly and attentive. The food comes out quickly and is quite tasty.Between the three of us, we split (3) orders of pork soup dumplings, (1) order of the Szechuan-style wontons, (1) order of salt & pepper pork chops, (1) order of scallion pancakes and (1) large rice.  The soup dumplings were definitely tasty but my inner soup dumpling soul resides in Flushing. The wontons were SO good and very spicy. If my appetite allowed for it, I could've went for another order. The pork chops were filling, the portion was huge but was a little underwhelming without dowsing it in the dipping sauce. The scallion pancakes were OK. I highly regret not trying the truffle soup dumplings so I will definitely order that the next time around.In general, I thought our meal here was great. I definitely plan to return in the near future to try out other menu items! This place is more like 3.5, but I'll round up and give 4 stars. Delicious soup dumplings. Tried one of each. The pork, pork and crab, and pork and truffle. One thing I thought was lacking is that there wasn't that much soup inside the dumplings. But the pork and truffle one was so flavorful and delicious, I would highly recommend. Also tried some other things on their menu. The sesame chicken was ok, a little too sweet. The salt and pepper pork was also ok. The sauce it comes with didn't pair that great with the pork. The shrimp fried rice was standard and good. Can't go wrong there. And finally the Shanghai lo mein was the best fish besides the soup dumplings. They were chewy and so good but they give so little noodles. It was too little to share among 5 people. Anyway, relatively good service and good food. Definitely get the bang for your buck. Would recommend this place. On a mission to find soup dumplings and dim sum we decided to check out Shanghai. It was a small quaint restaurant and clean in the heart of Chinatown. Although you hear about poor and/or rude service in NYC, our server was quick and attentive. We started off with some hot and sour soup to warm up. The soup was delicious, it was thick and tart. It coated your mouth with flavour and had a nice black pepper kick going down. The Pork and Crab steamed soup dumplings were perfect. First, they came out with the soup still in them(big plus), as other places the skin is often punctured or ripped leaving the soup in the dish instead. The filling was savoury and wrapped inside a delicate dumpling skin. Next came the pan fried pork dumpling. We loved how the dumplings were soft and fluff on top with an excellent crunch on the bottom. Cantonese style is steamed all around, while Shanghainese style provides a diverse texture. The pork inside the bun was juicy and savoury. Dipped in the sauce they provided, it took them to a whole other level. The Szechuan Wonton weren't just regular wontons tossed in chili oil, the restaurant had their own unique savoury and spicy sauce. When you first bit into the wonton it had the savoury flavour, it wasn't until you swallowed that the heat kicked in. Lastly we got the shrimp dumplings, let me just say that they were hands down the best shrimp dumplings we have ever had. The skin was glossimer thin, yet durable. The filling was perfect, I could have eaten more but had to restrain myself. This restaurant set a high bar for the rest we of places tried. Din Tai Fung quality without the wait (no line for us, although others say differently), located in the heart of NY's Chinatown amongst numerous other excellent, delicious, and memorable choices. We were visiting from Minnesota so I can't say I have the breadth of experience in Chinatown cuisine as local would have - but it seems like Shanghai Asian Manor would be an exceptional restaurant anywhere but in NY it's just another really great restaurant in Chinatown. Our soup dumplings were done just about as good as you can expect - soft, juicy, and full of flavor. Our favorite of the bunch were the steamed pork dumplings, which we got three stacks. Another good choice was the boiled pork and leek dumplings. Overall, the soup dumplings were well made although lacked somewhat in presentation and size compared to other places I've been to (namely, in Hong Kong an Shanghai, as well as Din Tai Fung in Seattle). However, the prices here absolutely blow all those other places out of the water.Service was quick and efficient. We got our first batch of dumplings probably 5 minutes after our order. Restrooms are mega cramped and a little awkward since it is in the back where all the employees hang out (this place is TINY!). Cash or American Express only. Would definitely come back! Location: Located on Mott Street.Wait: I came here during lunch on a weekday. There was no wait. On the weekends and in the evenings, there is a wait.Seating: During the winter months, I would avoid sitting in the middle because you will feel the cool wind when someone enters.Food: I tried the following:Steamed Tiny Buns With Crab Meat And PorkSteamed Tiny Buns With Pork Fried Tiny Buns With Pork Steamed Pork DumplingsBeef With Rice CakesI recommend them all. The Steamed Tiny Buns With Pork was so good that the group I was with ordered 3 more orders.Overall, great Steam Tiny Buns (also known as xiao long bao). I highly recommend if you don't want to wait for Joe's Shanghai. Personally, maybe because of weather or because I was hungry, I thought the buns here were better. Came here on a Thursday at 4:45pm, after a friend recommended this place as having some of the best dumplings in NYC. 4:45pm is absurdly early by dinner standards anywhere in the world, so when we got here, we were shocked to see that there was already a line. Nevertheless, we put our names down. It was less than a 20 minute wait, and we were seated at a booth. After looking at the menu, we ordered a couple of items. For three people, we had 5-6 dishes, and couldn't finish everything. They had a special menu item, soup dumplings with black truffle, which were superb. Other standout dishes were the stewed beef with noodles in spicy soup, spicy wonton noodles, and pan fried dumplings. Everything was excellent. Service was fine. There was a funny moment when one of the waiters berated customers for keeping the entrance open (understandable though, as it's New York in winter). Will return. My friend and I were taking in the city sights and felt like Chinese food.  She had never eaten xiao long bao (soup dumplings) so off we went.  When yelp got us there, lots of people waiting (weekend tho..) so we knew it was going to be a little bit.  It was cold and rainy, but it was all good because we were so hungry....and sometimes a line means....you might be in the right place.  When we checked in, they said about 20 to 30 minutes for a table...but we got called in after 10 minutes...score!  It was probably because there was just two of us.What awaited inside was wall to wall people....only the clinking of chopsticks broke up the loud table chatter and kitchen orders....it was glorious...We were sat at a small table for two and quickly placed our order.  My friend ordered a beer, and I began the 'soup dumpling instructions' on how not to completely burn your mouth and throat...like I have done so many times...Our food quickly came...we ordered....Fried pork dumplings-these were nice and crispy...and very plump.  They were soft on the inside and had a nice crunch on the outside.  There was lots of filling but it needed a tad more seasoning.Shanghai style crispy noodle-this was really good.  It had a nice portion of 'crispy cake noodle' underneath and the sauce really soaked into it.  The veggies and meat tasted great...and this was the first plate that was cleaned.Xiao long bao-the dumplings were good, and the flavor was delightful.  They came out piping hot, and had to show my friend how to poke out and drink the juice before consuming the meat.  Although, she became impatient and started eating them whole and ended up squirting dumpling juice all over me!  I guess there could be worse things...I smelled delicious for the rest of the day!I will be back! Come here for soup dumplings! There's a few places that offer similar dishes but not like this one! We arrived on a Saturday for a late lunch. The place is packed and there's a bit of a wait but only 10 minutes. Our go-to: soup dumplings and pan fried noodles. Service is fast. Soup dumplings: The skin is on the thinner side but still holds the meat and soup well - none of them popped. There was a lot inside and the soup was delicious - flavorful and hot. The prices are also great and we end up spending less than what we would in Manhattan. Super easy and tempting to leave full and happy. PROTIP: CASH (or amex card) ONLY!!! PROTIP: no dim sum cartsbesides that, A MUST GO if you are a big xiao long bao (XLB, soup dumplings) fan! probably one of the better xlb places in the city. i will come back and update my review once i have tried every single place that offers xlb. but BONUS: they also make xue jiang bao! (pan fried bao) which wasn't bad.  we also ordered pan fried dumplings (guo tie) that were pretty good too! honestly nothing was real bad here. i had a great christmas eve brunch with my fam here! a must recommend if you're craving soup dumplings and or just looking for some good authentic asian food! Came here as a group of four at 8:30pm on Friday and waited about 10 mins compared to an hour wait at three other places in the area. Excellent crabmeat soup dumplings...so juicy and very thin skin. It has only 6 pieces in each serving (compared to 8 at Shanghai Cafe which is one of our other favorites). Wuxi spareribs were very flavorful although a bit on the sweet side. We weren't originally going to have rice but the sauce was so good that each of us finished a bowl. PS: No brown rice so only white rice available. Salt and pepper shrimp was great as well as the crispy duck. The tofu skin appetizer was great too. We left feeling full and happy. Sometimes finding somewhere to eat in china town can be very overwhelming due to all the choice! And let's be honest, not every where is going to be good. I done my research ahead of time and all yelp roads led me here!
