I actually tried to come here one Saturday but the wait was about 45 mins so I went elsewhere but today I was off of work and figured I'd have more luck getting a table which was true! I ordered the vegetable dumplings to start which were really good! It made me think that the other dumplings on the menu must also be good and will deffo be back to try. I also got the seafood noodle soup which was delicious! The seafood was all very fresh and it also came with baby corn, mange tour and carrots which is not something I have seen before. It's often just seafood or maybe some bak choi.Seeing some of the other 'family style' dishes coming out, this strikes me as a good place to come for a big Sunday lunch or something with a group of friends. The menu has a lot of options and for sure will be back again! The best dim sum I've had. And probably the best soup dumplings I've had. If you wanna eat here be prepared for a wait. But it's sooo worth it! We had array of things, but my favorites were the pork soup dumplings and the vegetables. Everything tasted fresh and were decent in portion size for the prices. Definitely can't wait to visit NYC again and eat here! Whenever I visit New York or California, I am always excited about two things : delicious, greasy Chinese food and being in dim sum heaven. Shanghai Asian manor is located within the heart of Chinatown, New York. I love their fast-pace service and it's understandable as to why their service is quick; they get extremely busy. The significant other and I avoided a long wait due to the restaurant having only two seats open upon us entering the establishment. We shared soup dumplings, scallion pancakes, and general tso's chicken. All were very good, but we were both very impressed by their soup dumplings!!Also, the business only accepts cash and American Express. I believe that they just started implementing this action, because they had signs posted all over the restaurant stating that they had change their form of payment on September 1. Don't worry, there's an ATM a block down from them. Delicious.Cheap.Friendly.Helpful.Accommodating.Semi clean.Great flavors.Many options.Authentic.Came back 2 days in a row cause my friends insisted on eating well and with a cheap bill. Typical authentic Asian place in Chinatown. Will be back again for sure!Happy eating. This isn't the most authentic of Shanghainese restaurants, especially in NYC Chinatwon, but the food is quite good! The staff was actually pleasant (surprise!), and we were seated quite quickly even though it was busy. One thing you MUST remember is that they only take CASH or AMERICAN EXPRESS. Make sure you have enough cash, or you'll probably have to make an embarrassing dash at the end of the meal.I decided not to order the xiao long bao because... I didn't see a middle-aged or older Asian person in a small corner making them. Sorry, but I like that fresh made xiao long bao! However, I did get the steamed watercress and shrimp dumplings that they're known for, and they were surprisingly good! The salt and pepper squid were perfectly fried: crunchy on the outside and just tender on the inside. Certainly not overcooked! Now for the actual Shanghainese dishes: the meatballs (lion's head) were well seasoned and cooked to perfection. I was so full, but I still managed to gulp downone more meatball. The watercress and golden mushrooms were also delicious, although perhaps a bit too oily. The best part is that the portions are generous! There was easily enough for 2 full meals, and I'm glad to report that the food reheated well the day afterwards. If you're looking for authentic Shanghainese food, there's better places. If you're just looking for good Chinese food, this place is a bargain! Cannot believe that I have never written a review for Shanghai Asian Manor. This place is my second favorite soup dumpling restaurant in New York City. My favorite in the city is still Shanghai Caf. The soup dumplings here contains less ginger taste. Of course also order the zha jiang mian. This place had a 5 star rating from me before I went back the second time.The first experience here was great. I went with a group of friends and enjoyed a fantastic meal at such an affordable price. The chili oil and wontons are so so good and almost everything I had that day I loved. The black truffle soup dumplings are so worth the extra bucks. If you haven't had them before, they are a treat, but you couldn't eat too many of them. It is great to try and experience.The soup dumplings in general are great and the skin around the dumpling is perfectly thin and delicious. The second time I came here I was so excited to have another great meal, but it was lackluster at best. I got the regular beef noddle soup thinking it would be similar to the first one I got, but I think the waitress messed order up. My friend got the beef and broccoli and there was just no flavor there. I am going to try this place again and hope they just had an off day. This is my favorite Shanghainese restaurant in NYC. I come here pretty often. It's one that I recommend to all my friends who visit because the food is delicious, the space is spacious (compared to Joe's Shanghai), and the price is affordable. You'll really get the bang for your buck here. Here are some dishes that I usually order that are musts:- Steamed tiny buns with pork (soup dumplings) - Pan-fried pork dumplings (I usually don't order pan-fried dumplings at restaurants but theirs are really good)- Shanghai style pan-fried noodles - Shanghai Lo Mien with mixed meat and shrimpSometimes, I'd also order their sesame chicken, fried rice, rice cakes, and Thai iced tea. I don't think you can really go wrong with anything on the menu. They also have photos of their dishes hanging on the walls - those are usually good!There's also usually a long wait here especially during lunch and dinner. So go early and tell them your name to reserve your seats. But if you don't want to wait, their sister restaurant (I believe) is a few blocks away and it's called Shanghai Asian Cuisine. Bring cash! They used to accept credit card but now they only accept American Express. Also, my photo does not do this place justice.

This place is Quality not Quantity ( you won't see all the dim sum as you would see at dim sum breakfast)steam pork bun: THE BEST , they were sesame seed covered, and soupy broth(nice surprise) with full portion of pork (unlike most places that place shavings/dried of pork inside), they browned on the bottom and the dough was not drysoup dumpling: great broth flavorable, good size was manageable to eat sits in spoon nicely so you can put some vinegar inside, and  good rice vinegar was not saltypeanut noodles: were good rice noodlescallion pancake: were crispy and not oilyBubble tea was ok ,  i expected to be ticker it was more like juice.They are very fast service , no wait for table. Thieves - they changed the bill by an additional $5, then when they overheard us questioning the difference a tiny boyish woman came over to harangue us about the tip and how tips work. Since it was our first day on earth it was helpful to find out that these thieves who gave us fast food customer service expected a 15% tip and that is what we should obviously give. She was told the tip is a recommendation and that because of their incredibly rude and poor service they would be getting NOTHING. Never go here. Value: 7/10Experience: 6/10Taste:: 7.10Known for their soup dumplings, but everything else seems just meh.Value: We got the pork soup dumplings, spicy wontons, and red bean buns for $15. As with most places in Chinatown, it's a good amount of food for a low price. Experience: The three of us shared a large round table with 2-3 other parties and seating was definitely a bit crowded. You have to be quick when ordering since the servers have so many other people to attend to. Taste: The soup dumplings were full of soup. It was flavored very well and I almost didn't even need the soy sauce. The wontons had the same filling I think and had a spicy peanut sauce on it. The red bean buns look store bought and had almost no filling, would not recommend Highly recommended by my Leo Sista Cynthia Z!After a long day me and Cynthia Z walking from Koreatown to Chinatown. We stopped by Shanghai Cafe for dinner. Holy moly this place was super duper packed! You must lined up to get a table...why not give customers a number like most restaurants. We decided to share table but I didn't know it was with six other people so crowded and not enough elbow space. Me and Cynthia Z shared a Pork + Crabmeat Xiao Long Bao and Pan Fried Noodles with Shrimp, Scallop, and Crabmeat (more like fake crab meat). Ooo the xiao long bao is tasty but I want more soup. There's nothing to pick up the bao besides your chopsticks which I ripped two...there goes my soup lol The two of us were definitely full and cheap prices! Busy...busy...super crowded but with good reason! The food is good, the service is fast and the price is low!!! Very casual, you will most likely be seated in extreme close proximity to strangers! Good selection of Dim Sum which is what we came in for! Will go back on future visits toChinatown! This is one of our favorite spots for juicy soup dumplings in Chinatown. Skin is thin and there are 8 pieces per order (compared to 6 at some other restaurants). Paired two orders with shredded pork noodle soup made it a perfect late lunch on a cold day. PS: two of us were seated right away at 2pm on a Sunday. I love this place!!! Every time I'm in New York I stop to eat here. It on the boarder of China Town and Little Italy. Think dumplings followed by Gelato...life can't get better. This is a cash only establishment, please keep that in mind. When you walk in it is always busy with waitstaff and customers everywhere. They offer community tables, so if you are in a hurry expect to sit with strangers, I personally like it and think it adds to the experience. Who knows maybe you'll make a new friend. If you want to sit with just your party it might be a bit but they will accommodate you. The decor is a mixture of bamboo plants, neon signs and that's about it. The lighting is perfect for eating and the noise of excited conversations adds to the atmosphere. Hands down get the soup dumpings. I'm a purist with my dumpings so I go with just pork. Don't plan to share, you will want your own. We traditionally also order crispy duck, scallion pancakes, broccoli with garlic sauce and warm milk tea. You can't go wrong with the food.The only thing about this place is that it is fast. You sit, order, eat and go. It's really not a place to hang out and socialize but it's so worth it for the heavenly pockets of handmade soup dumping joy. Go get some, you'll be hooked! This is my one of my go-to XLB places in Chinatown since it hasn't received the hype that Joe's Shanghai has while still serving better XLBs than they do. My go-to menu items to order when I come here are the crab meat and pork XLBs, pork and chicken pan fried noodles, pig ears and the scallion pancakes. The XLBs that they offer here are succulent sacks of dough filled with meat filling and hot soup on the inside, so definitely be careful when eating them so you don't burn your mouth! The demand for them is always high here so they come fresh out of the steamer every time. The pan fried noodles that they offer here are flavorful with the gravy and also crunchy. The service here is what you'd typically expect from a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. They only accept cash here, so make sure to go to the bank first for cash! I came here with a large group of people for dinner on a Friday night. Though the restaurant was packed with a line waiting, the turnover was quick and we were seated in less than 10 minutes. We ordered 3 crab and pork dumplings, 2 pork dumplings, a cha chang noodle (black bean noodle), lo mein with chicken, garlic eggplants, and Shanghai rice (pork, chicken, shrimp over rice). Highlights: black bean noodle - the flavor was rich and the black bean sauce was not skimpily given. Chinese eggplant in garlic isn't one to miss -- that is usually a star side dish for any Chinese restaurant. Let's talk soup dumplings -- they're delicious but they don't make the top few dumplings spots in New York. For one, most places in Flushing will most likely have better and cheaper soup dumplings (Nan Xiang is a winner). Compared to places in the city, I still prefer Shanghai Cafe Manor's dumplings slightly better. All in all, I'll definitely be back. Both small and large groups are easy to be seated. Service is quick, food is good, and it's cheap. **CASH ONLY** After a long day in New York City, what is better than a dinner over soup dumplings. This was my first time here, where I was brought here by my friends. They stated that this is one of the best and cheapest soup dumplings spots in Chinatown. The soup dumplings were amazing. The soup and the meat fuzed together really well. I also got the Shanghai style noodles which was also A+. If you are around Chinatown, I would definitely give this place a shot. This is my to go place for soup dumplings. I ordered the #2 soup dumplings, 8 pieces for $5. If you ever decide to stop here to eat, I recommend the soup dumplings, cold sesame noodles and the Shanghai pan fried noodles.The service is quick and the staffs are friendly when they aren't in a rush to get tables ready for the next customers. Cheap eats! Wait: 10 minute wait in a Weekday (Thursday) during lunch time (12:30 pm).Space: Place was packed with mainly tourist.Service: place was packed. As a result I felt rushed eating. Unlike the other shanghai dumpling places, they made eating there seem like a factory. I had to request multiple times from the server for sauce. There was no refill for water.Food: food was okay. I would on recommend soup dumplings. However, this is the first place I know of that don't have tongs for the soup dumplings. As a result, it was challenging picking up the dumplings without spilling the soup.Food was okay but service was horrible. There are other soup dumpling places in Chinatown to try to not feel rushed. The other dishes I tried were below average. Great spot to get XLBs! It's a small space, as is to be expected for Chinatown, so I don't recommend a huge group outing. Service isn't great either because they just want you in and out. So keep all that in mind when planning your trip.However, the soup dumplings are bomb. Get them and the pan-fried noodles to share. The portions are generous and you will never leave hungry. Totally enjoyed my meal! 8 dumplings for $6.50? Yes please!The soup dumplings here were amazing! A lot of places have thick-skinned dumplings, but theirs were pretty reasonably thin. Nothing like those at DTF but they were some of the thinnest I've had otherwise. The dumplings were served fresh, filled with piping hot soup on the inside. The soup was delicious, as was the pork filling.Cash only! After pressing @FoodBaby for the best soup dumpling place in Chinatown...he led me in the direction of soup dumpling heaven. Shanghai Cafe was everything I wanted in a soup dumpling joint, and dim [then] some! We knew the deal about cash only, quick service, and close seating arrangements. However, that didn't stop us. The 40 min subway ride was well worth the 30 minutes we spent in the restaurant. After we bobbed and weaved through Chinatown we eventually found the joint and were seated right away! Our table was full with people, which was odd at first, but we soon got over the feeling. What we got:-Pork Soup dumplings (the best I've had this side of the Mississippi) -Crunchy noodles w/ chicken and veggies (different texture, but DAMN good!) -Scallion pancake (succulent and fresh AF) We can't wait to head back for, dare I say, New YEARS! Thanks @Foodbaby for the recommendation. Love XLBs and scallion pancake so I had to head here after arriving to the City. I also ordered a crispy pan fried noodle dish too because the portions were kind of small. The XLBs were tasty and very juicy. The scallion pancakes were good but expensive ($5) for one pancake. The crispy pan fried noodle was good and well portioned. Service is lackluster and typical for any Chinese place. Probably will look elsewhere. We were in Chinatown and looked up the best place to eat, and of course, this place came up - unfortunately it did not live up to the hype. We ordered a handful of items of which not  all were good. My recommendations include the jelly fish appetizer (my husband tried it for the first time and loved it), and the seaweed egg drop soup. We ordered a "seafood fried rice" where there was practically no seafood in sight. The kung pao chicken was good and just like you could get at any Chinese restaurant. The crab noddle dish we got had almost no crab in it and was surprisingly bland. The most disappointing dish was the crispy duck (which is a chef's recommendation). It had an oily taste to begin with and they place it on a sauce that makes half the dish lose the crispyness (bottom side). Service was quick and over all friendly. We were seated right away and food came out shortly after we ordered it. I come here for the soup crab meat with pork dumplings and like a small white rice this comes up to around 10$ which is affordable for a meal. I love this as a quick meal but sometimes it can get too loud with drunk tourists which can get annoying. Sometimes it's too crowded and you'll have to wait a while to get served. Yo, there's always that triangle where you have to compromise on one thing, right? Good food, good price, good service.Okay, maybe you'll have to compromise on service *sometimes* but that's usually cause they're too busy! Now, this is my go-to for cheap sit down food in Chinatown, and if you got a better one... lemme know. Let's get into it:(!) THE SPREAD: Appetizers: Szechuan style wontons. // Main course: Crab and pork soup dumplings, pork soup dumplings, salt and pepper pork chop, Shanghai style pan fried noodle(!) HOW IT DID: The spread has been fine tuned over the course of many visits and will always leave me with leftovers. The dish to note, outside of what everyone's mentioned is the salt and pepper pork chop. The jalapeno gives it a nice kick akin to what I've loved since childhood--the salt and pepper squid entree at nearby Hop Kee. If you haven't yet ordered the pork here, please, please do. You won't regret it.(!) SEATING / AMBIENCE: It gets crowded and you might end up being seated at a communal table but you won't pay them any mind. You might even make a friend. It's got a nice hustle and bustle to it, and you'll always remember it in a neon pink vibe. Or is that just me? Hmmm....(!) TIDBITS: Cash only. Chase is across Canal. Citibank isn't too far from that. Credit union co-op folks, there's a McDonalds and a 7-11 near the NQRW/6 subway station on Canal. Let's caveat this review with the fact that it's not a XLB review bc I don't eat meat. Okay, moving on. Lezz be real. I've eaten at hundreds of Chinese restaurants of varying cuisines in my lifetime. People boast about Joe's and Shanghai Cafe bc they're supposed to be some kind of amazingly wonderful finds. Welp, sorry to burst your bubble...but they're not. The scallion pancake is some sort of deep fried concoction?! That was not okay. It should be pan fried, my friends. The steamed veggie dumplings had a pretty thick wrapper on them. So thick that I had to stop eating them at the folds. Ick. And then the lo mein. I mean, you can't really mess those up. And I guess they pre cut them for you...so are they hand pulled here or not?? Idk how I feel about that. Flavor-wise, not the worst. But definitely not the best. Tables are jam packed into this spot. And can we talk about the clubby light happenings?? Uh, it was 2pm on a Saturday and they had this dim pink and blue light situation happening inside. So strange. Not authentic. Catering to the wrong crowd. 2.5 stars rounded up to a 3 bc I'm feeling a little generous. Would I come back? Prob not.

Had a great chilaquiles here. I'm used to eggs over easy, but it was really tasty scrambled too. The eggs were done just right, and I loved the taste. The veggies were slightly on the salty side for my taste, but I sometime add no salt at all when I'm cooking, so this is something I run in to often. All the ingredients were cooked just right, and somehow stayed hot all the way through my meal.I really have to thank these guys! I got here a couple minutes before they were closing at 2pm, and they still let me order and eat at the bar. Seems like they enjoy what they're doing. They're certainly good at it!Definitely worth stopping by if you're in the area! This small resturant is located in the corner of the grocery store.Second the pricing here on the dishes are a bit much. Expect to spend 55 to 65 for breakfast for two with coffee.I had the fidel skillet under the blisters on my sister's area of the menu. This skillet was layered with yummy refried beans, cheese, egg  and other goodness. I absolutely loved all of the hot sauces they brought to the table. So good.My wife got the snitzel bowl which was pretty disappointing. Visually it was very off putting. It looked as if they scraped the scraps from the remaining plates into a bowl and lined the bowl with snitzel. Yeah kinda gross. The waiter did take half the cost off the bill though for the snitzel bowl when he saw my wife didn't really touch it. Now this is a diner experience!!!!Venue: (3/5) Hidden in the Essex St Market, it can be hard to find.  Minimal seating, but worth the experience.  Food (5/5) The breakfast is $$$ not $$.  However look at the menu with hundreds of choices and combinations.  I respect that and will come back to order other items.  (4/5) Macaroni pancake with egg and sausage - This was good the first few bites.  I think for my taste I prefer only sweet or only salty.  If you like both you should order this!  I just didn't like my choice for my self preference.Service - The service here is you order, you receive.... it is a diner. This place would get 5 stars from me, if it didn't make me sh*t my pants every time I go from fear I'll piss off the waiter and I won't get served. Fortunately the only thing that's ever happened to me was that they refused to make me a shake while I watched the people next to me get a shake. Also, save your money if you're a picky vegetarian and Vegans absolutely not welcome here. LOLOtherwise, my favorite brunch/breakfast place in NYC. The classic Mac&Cheese pancakes with hot sauce and syrup is truly a must every time. The sliders, the chili, the shakes (when I can get them Heheheh)... The list is as long as the menu coz I've never had anything I didn't like there. This place is amazing!! This is not a traditional, conceptual, high end or fusion restaurant. It's  a truly unique,  personal approach to many different types of cuisines around the world. Small place, efficient service and a ridiculously long menu!! But it's worth checking all the options. My friend has been coming to this place for years in their previous location and assures all the items he has tried are amazing. It was my first time there and I loved it! They don't accept parties bigger than 4, so I wouldn't recommend a bigger group to come. Look, Shopsin's is an experience as much as it is a restaurant. You have to know what you're walking into or else you will end up as part of the entertainment. Abide by the rules and you'll be fine. Those rules being no parties greater than four, each person orders a meal, no substitutions, and no talking on the cell phone. It also helps if you're not a vegan. With his long legacy of kicking people out, I was nervous sitting at the counter right in front of the legend himself, Kenny Shopsin, but I soon realized I had nothing to worry about. Kenny was deep in conversation with another patron, and I immediately felt at home in their quirky little space. I already pored over the menu before I came and wanted the sliders, which I had heard were the best in the city. I'm no slider expert but these were definitely tasty and very filling. I slathered them with hot sauce (there are six homemade choices in a little rack at each table), and they tasted particularly amazing with the smokey deep red one. Yum. They're also one of the more affordable things on the menu. The best part is the theatrics of eating there. Towards the end of my meal, Kenny's son, who mans the kitchen, came out and screamed expletives at his dad for misplacing something in the prep station. What followed is not family-friendly enough to write here but was super entertaining and totally playful on their part. Kenny made a wisecrack about his son's sex life and just like that, it was over. My only complaints are that the prices are pretty high, and the place is tiny. Expect to wait for a table unless you get there at 10am or earlier. The service can definitely be snarky but as long as you respect their rules, you'll be fine. I actually quite liked the waiter. The well-meaning Denver native next to me tried ordering off the menu (avocado toast) and got a rude reply, but she should have known better. This is not the place to order avocado toast. I'm definitely coming back to try something more creative next time! Greatest brunch I've ever had. The guys running it are awesome people - what might come across as rudeness is really just a singular vision of the place they've created and how you should enjoy their food. Don't ask for variations unless you're on first name terms. Order quickly and be respectful. The coffee is solid. This is where I'll have my last ever meal. If you had to only eat at one place for the rest of your life, where would it be?Here. It would be here. And you would still be the happiest person in the world. I mean, I love me my mom's cooking but omaigahtheselections!Yes. Normally I would look at a menu this extensive and correctly assume that the restaurant (normally a diner) can't do anything great. Shopsin's defies that. It is a small, magical, delicious unicorn. I can eat here. Always. Anytime (although only for breakfast and brunch according to their hours). Any Day (except the two days they are closed).This is THE definition of comfort food that crosses Southern, Jewish, Indian, TexMex, did I see some Chinese as well?I am in love with everything about the shop. The small size of it; the decorations; the seating; the exclusiveness; the eff you, we only open for 4 hours five days a week; the no parties greater than 4; the just nice enough to you to serve you, but who are we fooling, we're not bffs; the CHEF. YOU MAGICAL PERSON! HOW how do you make all this good food in your kitchen?I got mac n cheese pancakes because I have never heard of that. What? How does...ooooh that's how you make it. And it's awesome. And those scrambled eggs. I dream to be able to make scrambled eggs like that at home. But hands down, my friend got the best thing on the menu: Diego. I mean I've only been there the one time (today), but what more do you need in life than waffle fries, delicious gravy, melted cheese, and three pouched eggs on top? NOTHING. Vege what? Who needs greens when you have that deliciousness.Also, the hotsauce rack is awesome. If you can handle it, I would recommend #4 for everything. It adds spice without taking out or adding flavors to what you're eating.I want to come back. For the Diego. For the Indian. For the Hash. For the okra. For whatever that other guy is having. Just a sad experience. We didn't even get through our order before we lost our appetites and walked out. I don't want to have to over look the fact that the place and the people are filthy when trying to enjoy a Sunday brunch. The service is shit and as far as the menu, it's huge, and filled with items that are sure to leave you feeling like a pile of shit all day long. As many others have commented, the menu is bordering on comical.The good part about Shopsin's is that you can order anything possibly imaginable for breakfast: they have all kinds of typical diner food from eggs, pancakes, grits, processed meats, steaks, schnitzel, huevos ranchos, waffles, breakfast sandwiches... etc. The list goes on. They also have breakfast items from different cultures, so that means you can order Indian inspired curry like things here, but you can also get Chinese style jian bings- I didn't try any of them but I'm sure they're decent.I opted for the ABC (which is eggs, sausage, schnitzel and grits). It all came in this huge bowl and I was initially concerned that they had mixed it all together- it actually turned out to be just fine. The other cool thing is that they bring you this whole thing of seven different hot sauces that come with your food- many of them are great, and have tons of flavor packed in. There are even two ghost pepper options, so you can really knock yourself out.Having tried only one of like, three hundred items on this menu, this is by no means a comprehensive review. I will say that our food took nearly 30 minutes to arrive, and this wasn't even when the restaurant was full yet, so they ARE kind of slow here. However, I suppose this is the price to pay when you come to a restaurant that serves literally everything- they wind up getting spread a little thin.Will definitely be back. Huge difference between old-time NYC attitude take-it-or-leave-it/don't ask questions shtick and outright vitriol.  We have a sense if humor; we know your history and quirky rules.  We just wanted lunch, not your utter disdain.Can't write a review of food when you are asked to leave the premises. The unpardonable crime?  Four out of five in your party order full-on meals right off the menu no special requests, but one orders just a soda because she is feeling ill.  Maybe in the context of an assholes of NYC web reality series this would be viewed as a charming and an acceptable, inside baseball slice-of-life. Until then, just serve your friends and family. We were excited to try this place as we heard good things. I never actually ate here. I sat down to eat....My husband got his food. Nearly 25 minutes later mine still didn't come out and I was told it wasn't even started. So we cancelled it. Our waiter was very nice about the situation but what type of restaurant runs like this ? One of our worst dining experiences and I didn't even get to try the food.  Side bar, if you tell them a 3 or 4 out of 10 for spice level, that will actually mean really spicy. My husband's food was average, though overly spicy. Skip it. An awesome brunch/lunch place in the back of Essex Street Market. I've walked by it so many times but had to try it today. There menu is massive - they'll definitely have something for everyone. It is a little pricey though. I would say $$$ for a breakfast place. The quality was superb though! I got an egg special that came with scrambled eggs, bacon, two pancakes, and home fries ($15). Everything was so fresh and delicious. My boyfriend got eggs, biscuit, sausage gravy, and grits (~$23). He enjoyed it and enjoyed trying multiple hot sauces they bring to the table. Their hours are different - only open certain days and until 2pm. The server was nice and efficient. THE COLD BREW WAS AMAZING. It was choclately and full of flavor ($3.5). I'd come back just for that. If you're in the area of definitely recommend trying this hole in the wall. Listen carefully and be a easy to order. This eatery is straight out of a Seinfeld episode... Highly recommend the Rueben balls. For somewhere that presents itself as an interesting spot for food in a nice market it needs serious work. The tables and floor are filthy. The quirky enormous menu is a joke, or at least reads like one. Impossible to understand and appears to be very expensive for some options. We decided not to eat and quickly left our table in case anyone was waiting for seating. Told the server thanks but no thanks and he comes back with "knew that would happen, what was I not quick enough!?" Embarrassing himself and the business in front of a full house. We just left, I don't engage rude staff. Decipher the menu before you even attempt to sit down if you must visit this place. Oh and there's a hand sanitizer dispenser on the walls by the tables. Screams cleanliness. No thank you. This place is inside Essex St Market so don't miss it! It's very small with limited seating but it's worth it. They are also only open for a few hours in the day so get there early! Line does get longer during prime lunch time. They also have a very very very extensive menu so I'm sure you'll find something to eat. I got the Sneaky Pete (spicy garlic bread with bacon monterey jack and tomatoes and 3 poached eggs) it is so so so good and so filling. It doesn't look much but it'll fill you up. They also give you six different kinds of hot sauce, my favorite was the garlic one. My friend and I also shared the banana ebelskivers. Definitely get it. They're like mini pancake balls and the banana isn't overpowering. It's perfect. Great sweet dish to complement the savory Sneaky Pete. If you love food and haven't been here, what are you doing???Definitely a quirky place (Do your research before going, please) but absolutely worth every penny you pay.There are rules (don't take pictures aside from food pics, know what you want to eat beforehand, no substitutions, etc.) but again, so worth it.I came here for the first time last week. There was no wait at all (on a Friday around 12 pm) but from what I understand, this is quite unusual. There are only a few tables so try to go at an off-time if you can. Our waiter was friendly and attentive. And let's just talk about the food!I got the Bravacado. Maybe not your go-to for an epic food picture but definitely delicious. (If you like eggs and guacamole, I highly recommend it) My best friend got the Y3 and was also quite happy.Shopsin's has a cash-only policy so be sure to have enough on you. I will definitely be heading back soon. Hella bomb food! Got the Gumbo and grits so good. My friend got the Mo Betta and it's to die for! Limited seating makes this place a gem! Love it. You also earned a deservedly scathing review and earned and grand total of $2 for your crappy coffee. Been coming here for years and was recently turned away with my 4 and 5 year old.
